
                              1 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            January 17, 2017 Tuesday

Pennsylvania State Legislature Memoranda: Delinquent Debt Intercept Program

LENGTH: 521  words

DATELINE: New York



 Harrisburg: Pennsylvania State Legislature has issued the following Memoranda
updates:



 In the near future, I plan to introduce legislation to reduce the growing
strain on Pennsylvania taxpayers and local governments caused by outstanding and
delinquent taxes and debts, which leaves Pennsylvanians who have paid their
taxes paying an increasing bill for essential services through a growing tax
burden. My plan to address this growing burden is to create an independent
authority to offset government payments against outstanding taxes and debts owed
to the Commonwealth or local governments. This plan will be known as the
Delinquent Debt Intercept Program, and was introduced as Senate Bill 995 of the
2015-16 session.





 The Delinquent Debt Intercept Program will be structured similarly to the
United States Treasury's Offset Program (TOP), which is an agreement between the
states and the Federal government to collect outstanding money owed in
delinquent taxes and debt. The Delinquent Debt Intercept Program will provide
the Commonwealth, its agencies, political subdivisions and municipal authorities
with a clearinghouse for collecting all delinquent taxes and debts with no cost
to the governmental entity. This will lower the cost for the Commonwealth and
local governments in trying to acquire outstanding payments owed to them. The
authority, working in conjunction with the Governor's Office and the United
States Treasury Department, will collect outstanding payments from the Federal
tax returns and vendor payments as well as Commonwealth vendor payments and
income tax returns of those with delinquent and outstanding taxes and debts.



 Through this collection, the Delinquent Debt Intercept Program will restore
approximately $75 million to the General Fund. In addition, municipalities such
as Philadelphia can expect to see $125 million restored to their budget by the
authority collecting outstanding taxes and debts owed to the City. Consequently,
by collecting these delinquent taxes and debts, the authority assists local
governments as they see their revenue grow without placing an increased burden
on Pennsylvanians who followed the law and pay their taxes. Finally, the
authority, by levying a surcharge on those who have outstanding taxes and debts,
allows the Commonwealth and local governments to receive the full amount of the
delinquent revenues, without needing to finance the authority from our strained
budget.



 The impact of this self-funding authority is to restore funds to the
Commonwealth and local governments, to reduce costs on delinquent tax
collections for local governments and reducing the growing tax burden on law
abiding Pennsylvanians. The authority, acting as an efficient clearing house for
outstanding tax collections and debts, restores tax revenue to the General Fund
and the budgets of local governments.



 Cosponsors of Senate Bill 995 of the 2015-16 session included: Senators
RAFFERTY, VULAKOVICH, TEPLITZ, COSTA, BREWSTER, SABATINA, and DINNIMAN.



 In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: January 17, 2017

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


              Copyright 2017 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

                                US Official News

                            January 17, 2017 Tuesday

Pennsylvania State Legislature Memoranda: Delinquent Debt Intercept Program

LENGTH: 521  words

DATELINE: New York



 Harrisburg: Pennsylvania State Legislature has issued the following Memoranda
updates:



 In the near future, I plan to introduce legislation to reduce the growing

                     The Daily Item (Sunbury, Pennsylvania)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                          September 15, 2016 Thursday

Properties with delinquent taxes up for auction

BYLINE: Justin Strawser, The Daily Item, Sunbury, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 682 words


Sept. 15--SUNBURY -- Northumberland County has the potential to generate more
than $2.8 million in revenue if approximately 250 properties in delinquent taxes
are sold at today's annual upset sale.

As of Wednesday, approximately 31 percent of the properties are in the eastern
portion of Northumberland County. Shamokin has 85 properties. Mount Carmel
borough and township have 70 and Coal Township has 48, totaling $873,317.25 in
delinquent taxes.

While there is an opportunity for the county to generate $2,804,378, tax claims
Director Janel Barwick said an upset sale will rarely sell more than 30
properties.

"We will sell between 10 and 30 properties," she said. "This is because
mortgages and liens are attached to these."

The upset sale is the first step in delinquent taxes, but the properties are not
sold free and clear. Each property is subject to sale without owner's consent at
a public auction at 10 a.m. today in the public meeting room at the county
administration building at 399 Stadium Drive. The starting bid is the amount in
delinquent taxes plus costs to auction it off.

Sunbury has eight properties; Point Township has seven properties each; Kulpmont
and West Chillisquaque Township have six properties each; Delaware Township,
Marion Heights and Milton have four properties each; Zerbe Township has three
properties; East and West Cameron Townships, Turbot Township and Upper Augusta
Township have two properties each; and East Chilllisquaque Township, Lower
Township, Northumberland, Ralpho Township, Rush Township, Shamokin Township,
Snydertown, Turbotville and Upper Mahanoy Township have one property each.

Craig Hostrander has the highest and third highest delinquent property tax
bills. He owes $54,205 at 13 S. Front St. and $36,941 at 19 S. Front St., both
in Milton. Northeast Apartments LLC has 10 delinquent properties on the list in
Coal Township, Kulpmont, Mount Carmel and Shamokin totaling $183,459. Conduit
Estates LLC has 15 delinquent properties in Coal Township, Kulpmont. Mount
Carmel and Shamokin totaling $40,362.

Pat Grattan, a landlord from Sunbury, plans to attend the sale to scope out
potential purchases.

"I'm in real estate and I like a bargain," Grattan said. "Northumberland County
is the bargain basement of the East Coast for real estate."

Grattan said the county is well known in the real estate investment market for
having cheap properties within only hours of major metropolitan areas like
Philadelphia, New York City, Baltimore and Washington, D.C.

Story continues below video

"I'm not the only one who thinks this is a great place to invest," Grattan said.

Barwick said the advertisement of the Upset Sale brings in delinquent taxpayers
and helps to drastically drop the original list. This year, the Tax Claim Office
started with 1,600 properties, and will have 254 properties as of early
Wednesday afternoon. The number could decrease since property owners can settle
their debt up until the sale.

"This is what gets everyone to pay their taxes or get it back on the taxroll
when someone buys it who will pay the taxes," Barwick said.

If the properties are not sold today, they will be placed on the list for
judicial sale where each property will be free of liens. In the list, owners are
warned they must contact an attorney, the tax claim bureau or the county lawyer
referral system in order to determine what must be done to save their property
from the sale.

The owner or reputed owners of the properties sold are not permitted to redeem
the property after the sale.

The terms of the sale are cash or certified funds, and all sales are final. The
tax claim bureau warns that any mortgages, judgments or other liens of record
against the property purchased may not be divested by this sale.

Dave Hummel, the field assessor for the county assessor's office, will lead the
auction.

Barwick expects it to go smoothly.

Email Justin Strawser at jstrawser@dailyitem.com Follow him on Twitter
@JustinLStrawser.

___ (c)2016 The Daily Item (Sunbury, Pa.) Visit The Daily Item (Sunbury, Pa.) at
www.dailyitem.com Distributed by Tribune Content Agency, LLC.

-taxes-up-for-auction-0915-20160915

                          Mississippi Business Journal

                             March 16, 2010 Tuesday

Mortgage report finds Mississippi ranks high in bad loans

BYLINE: Wally Northway

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 370  words


The Feb. 2010 Mortgage Monitor report, released by Lender Processing Services
Inc., shows that while delinquency rates in the U.S. have risen to historic
highs, the pace of deterioration has slowed. However, the nation's housing
market remains far from a full recovery, and Mississippi has the third-highest
non-current loans in the nation.

Based on data extrapolated from the LPS servicing database, nearly 7.5 million
loans are in some stage of delinquency or foreclosure, with an additional one
million properties in REO or post-sale foreclosure. In addition, approximately
2.5 million loans that were current Jan. 1, 2009, were 60 or more days
delinquent (including foreclosures) as of Jan. 31, 2010. Despite extraordinary
loss mitigation efforts that have resulted in the execution of approximately two
million loan modifications, including the federal government's Home Affordable
Modification Program (HAMP) trial periods, the number of new delinquencies since
Jan. 1, 2009, still exceeds this number by 25 percent.

The nation's pool of problem loans continues to grow and stagnate. More than 31
percent of loans that have been delinquent for six months are not yet in
foreclosure, while 22.8 percent of loans delinquent for 12 months have not been
moved to foreclosure status (up from 9.0 percent in 2008).

Older loans now make up a higher proportion of new delinquencies, as more loans
experience repeat delinquencies. The average loan age of newly delinquent loans
is now 46 months, as compared to an average newly delinquent loan age of 27
months in Jan. 2007. During Jan. 2010, 346,000 borrowers became delinquent for
the first time, representing approximately 40 percent of all newly delinquent
loans for the month.

Other key results from LPS' Jan. 2010 Mortgage Monitor include:

* Total U.S. loan delinquency rate - 10.2 percent

* Total U.S. foreclosure inventory rate - 3.3 percent

* Total U.S. non-current loan rate - 13.5 percent

* States with most non-current loans - Florida, Nevada, Mississippi, Arizona,
Georgia, California, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan and Ohio

* States with fewest non-current* loans - North Dakota, South Dakota, Alaska,
Wyoming, Montana, Nebraska, Vermont, Colorado, Oregon and Washington

LOAD-DATE: March 30, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Financing

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              5 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                   Mississippi Business Journal (Jackson, MS)

                           February 9, 2011 Wednesday

Survey: Mississippi near top in U.S. in non-current loans

BYLINE: Wally Northway

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 375  words


The December Mortgage Monitor report released by Lender Processing Services Inc.
shows a continued increase in the inventory of foreclosed mortgages as more
loans advance through the default process. And Mississippi ranks near the top in
most non-current loans.

The number of newly delinquent loans declined during 2010, helping push overall
delinquent inventories down 18 percent for the year. The volume of loans moving
to REO remains extremely low as moratoria and process reviews continue, further
pressuring foreclosure inventories.

While the 90-days+ delinquency category has declined, the number of loans moving
to seriously delinquent status beyond 90 days still far outpaced the number of
foreclosure starts. Just over 2.1 million loans are 90 days or more delinquent
but not yet in foreclosure, with nearly 6.9 million loans in some stage of
delinquency or foreclosure. The total number of delinquent loans is nearly twice
as high as historical averages - and foreclosure inventory is currently 7.8
times higher than historical averages and is rising.

The report also shows that over one-third of borrowers with loans that are 90
days or more delinquent have not made a payment in over a year. Self-cures for
loans one-to-two months delinquent declined slightly in December, and late-stage
cures, usually related to modification activity, continue to decline. In
December, 259,518 loans were referred to foreclosure, which represents a 0.6
percent month-over-month decline.

Origination activity continues to increase with new production in November
reaching 2010 highs. While FHA originations have declined, the share of agency
loans increased, and 95 percent of all new issuance remains government
supported.

As reported in LPS' First Look release, other key results from LPS' latest
Mortgage Monitor report include:

* Total U.S. loan delinquency rate: 8.83 percent

* Total U.S. foreclosure inventory rate: 4.15 percent

* Total U.S. non-current loan rate: 12.98 percent

* States with most non-current loans: Florida, Nevada, Mississippi, Georgia, New
Jersey

* States with fewest non-current loans: North Dakota, South Dakota, Alaska,
Wyoming, Montana

Non-current totals combine foreclosures and delinquencies as a percent of active
loans in that state.

LOAD-DATE: February 16, 2011

                              6 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                              Daily the Pak Banker

                           February 10, 2011 Thursday

LPS' Mortgage Monitor Report: December Data Shows Foreclosure Inventory Rising
for Sixth Consecutive Month

LENGTH: 495  words

DATELINE: Karachi


Karachi, Feb. 10 -- The December Mortgage Monitor report released by Lender
Processing Services, Inc. (NYSE: LPS) shows a continued increase in the
inventory of foreclosed mortgages as more loans advance through the default
process. The number of newly delinquent loans declined during 2010, helping push
overall delinquent inventories down 18 percent for the year. The volume of loans
moving to REO remains extremely low as moratoria and process reviews continue,
further pressuring foreclosure inventories.

While the 90-days+ delinquency category has declined, the number of loans moving
to seriously delinquent status beyond 90 days still far outpaced the number of
foreclosure starts. Just over 2.1 million loans are 90 days or more delinquent
but not yet in foreclosure, with nearly 6.9 million loans in some stage of
delinquency or foreclosure. The total number of delinquent loans is nearly twice
as high as historical averages - and foreclosure inventory is currently 7.8
times higher than historical averages and is rising.

The report also shows that over one-third of borrowers with loans that are 90
days or more delinquent have not made a payment in over a year. Self-cures for
loans one-to-two months delinquent declined slightly in December, and late-stage
cures, usually related to modification activity, continue to decline. In
December, 259,518 loans were referred to foreclosure, which represents a 0.6
percent month-over-month decline.

Origination activity continues to increase with new production in November
reaching 2010 highs. While FHA originations have declined, the share of agency
loans increased, and 95 percent of all new issuance remains government
supported.

As reported in LPS' First Look release, other key results from LPS' latest
Mortgage Monitor report include:

Total U.S. loan delinquency rate: 8.83 percent

Total U.S. foreclosure inventory rate: 4.15 percent

Total U.S. non-current* loan rate: 12.98 percent'

States with most non-current* loans: Florida, Nevada, Mississippi, Georgia, New
Jersey

States with fewest non-current* loans: North Dakota, South Dakota, Alaska,
Wyoming, Montana

*Non-current totals combine foreclosures and delinquencies as a percent of
active loans in that state.

Note: Totals based on LPS Applied Analytics' loan-level database of mortgage
assets and are extrapolated to represent the industry.

About the Mortgage Monitor

LPS manages the nation's leading repository of loan-level residential mortgage
data and performance information on nearly 40 million loans across the spectrum
of credit products. The company's research experts carefully analyze this data
to produce a summary supplemented by dozens of charts and graphs that reflect
trend and point-in-time observations for LPS' monthly Mortgage Monitor Report.
Published by HT Syndication with permission from Daily Pak Banker. For any query
with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact
Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

LOAD-DATE: February 11, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              7 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                              Delaware State News

               Distributed by Knight/Ridder Tribune News Service

                            March 18, 2006 Saturday

Delaware lawmakers consider bill to publicly expose tax delinquents

BYLINE: Joe Rogalsky, Delaware State News, Dover

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 589 words


Mar. 18--DOVER -- The state's top tax scofflaws would find themselves publicly
exposed under legislation moving through the General Assembly.

House Bill 118, should it become law, authorizes the Department of Finance to
post a list of the top 100 delinquents for the state income tax and another top
100 list for business taxes on the state Web site.

The House of Representatives' Revenue and Finance Committee approved the measure
Wednesday and its sponsor hopes to have the full chamber consider the bill
before breaking April 14 for the legislature's Easter recess.

"I think this will be helpful," said Rep. Deborah D. Hudson, R-Wilmington, who
introduced HB 118.

"I think people who pay their taxes will be annoyed when they find out others
are not paying their fair share. I hope it will be successful."

To qualify for the list, a business or individual must owe at least $1,000 and
have a public judgment entered against them.

The bill exempts taxpayers who are receiving bankruptcy protection or have
entered into a payment plan with the state.

Taxpayers with "extraordinary circumstances" also are exempt.

According to the Department of Finance, the top 100 income tax delinquents owe
$18.3 million -- $4.6 million in back taxes and $13.7 million in penalties and
interest.

The top 100 business tax scofflaws, according to the department, owe $14.1
million -- $3.7 million in unpaid taxes and $11.4 million in penalties and
interest.

"The bill is designed to identify the people who are delinquent," said Deputy
Secretary of Finance Thomas Cook.

"It is not designed to identify the people who have a hardship case or are on a
payment plan.

"The hammer here is that people know they will be publicly listed and hopefully
that will lead them to make the right decision."

Rep. Hudson decided names of tax delinquents should be posted after attending a
national conference for legislators, where she learned at least a dozen states
publicly identify the scofflaws.

Those states take different approaches.

California limits its list to the top 12 delinquents for its sales-and-use tax,
with the minimum amount owed being $1 million.

Maryland lists 50 names, half are delinquent income tax payers and half are
business tax delinquents.

Minnesota delinquents must owe at least $5,000 and be six months behind before
their names are displayed.

"In every state that has this it has been effective," Rep. Hudson said.

"It's not really new because it has been around since Colonial times when they
would put people's names on the door of the town hall if they had not paid their
taxes.

"It's a method that has been around for years and is being brought into
cyberspace."

Before a person can be placed on Delaware's list, the state must send the
taxpayer notification by certified mail and give 60 days to make a payment.

Once an individual pays the amount they owe or enters into a payment plan, their
name will be removed within 30 days.

"We hold government officials accountable for what they do with our tax dollars
and we should hold citizens accountable who do not pay taxes," said John D.
Flaherty, a lobbyist for Common Cause Delaware.

"Accountability goes both ways. This is a good bill."

To see more of Delaware State News, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.newszap.com/dover Copyright (c) 2006, Delaware State News, Dover
Distributed by Knight Ridder/Tribune Business News. For information on
republishing this content, contact us at (800) 661-2511 (U.S.), (213) 237-4914
(worldwide), fax (213) 237-6515, or e-mail reprints@krtinfo.com.

LOAD-DATE: March 22, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ACC-NO: 20060318-DS-TAX-DELINQUENTS-20060318

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: DS

                                US Official News

                           January 18, 2017 Wednesday

Memorandum: Delinquent Debt Intercept Program

LENGTH: 515  words

DATELINE: New York



 Harrisburg: The Senate of Pennsylvania has issued the following Memorandum:



   From:     Senator Patrick M. Browne

 To:     All Senate members

 Subject:     Delinquent Debt Intercept Program



 In the near future, I plan to introduce legislation to reduce the growing
strain on Pennsylvania taxpayers and local governments caused by outstanding and
delinquent taxes and debts, which leaves Pennsylvanians who have paid their
taxes paying an increasing bill for essential services through a growing tax
burden. My plan to address this growing burden is to create an independent
authority to offset government payments against outstanding taxes and debts owed
to the Commonwealth or local governments. This plan will be known as the
Delinquent Debt Intercept Program, and was introduced as Senate Bill 995 of the
2015-16 session.





 The Delinquent Debt Intercept Program will be structured similarly to the
United States Treasury's Offset Program (TOP), which is an agreement between the
states and the Federal government to collect outstanding money owed in
delinquent taxes and debt. The Delinquent Debt Intercept Program will provide
the Commonwealth, its agencies, political subdivisions and municipal authorities
with a clearinghouse for collecting all delinquent taxes and debts with no cost
to the governmental entity. This will lower the cost for the Commonwealth and
local governments in trying to acquire outstanding payments owed to them. The
authority, working in conjunction with the Governor's Office and the United
States Treasury Department, will collect outstanding payments from the Federal
tax returns and vendor payments as well as Commonwealth vendor payments and
income tax returns of those with delinquent and outstanding taxes and debts.



 Through this collection, the Delinquent Debt Intercept Program will restore
approximately $75 million to the General Fund. In addition, municipalities such
as Philadelphia can expect to see $125 million restored to their budget by the
authority collecting outstanding taxes and debts owed to the City. Consequently,
by collecting these delinquent taxes and debts, the authority assists local
governments as they see their revenue grow without placing an increased burden
on Pennsylvanians who followed the law and pay their taxes. Finally, the
authority, by levying a surcharge on those who have outstanding taxes and debts,
allows the Commonwealth and local governments to receive the full amount of the
delinquent revenues, without needing to finance the authority from our strained
budget.



 The impact of this self-funding authority is to restore funds to the
Commonwealth and local governments, to reduce costs on delinquent tax
collections for local governments and reducing the growing tax burden on law
abiding Pennsylvanians. The authority, acting as an efficient clearing house for
outstanding tax collections and debts, restores tax revenue to the General Fund
and the budgets of local governments.

Memorandum: Delinquent Debt Intercept Program

LENGTH: 515  words

DATELINE: New York



 Harrisburg: The Senate of Pennsylvania has issued the following Memorandum:



   From:     Senator Patrick M. Browne

 To:     All Senate members

 Subject:     Delinquent Debt Intercept Program



 In the near future, I plan to introduce legislation to reduce the growing
strain on Pennsylvania taxpayers and local governments caused by outstanding and

                              10 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                   The Daily Independent (Ashland, Kentucky)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             July 1, 2009 Wednesday

Deadline is approaching for delinquent taxes

BYLINE: Carrie Stambaugh, The Daily Independent, Ashland, Ky.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 505 words


Jul. 1--CATLETTSBURG -- Delinquent county property taxpayers have a little more
than a month to pay their bills before they can be sold to a third party.

Boyd County Clerk Debbie Jones said although more than 900 delinquent tax bills
have been paid since they were turned over to the clerk's office in April, more
than 1,400 delinquent tax bills remain in Boyd County.

Jones said residents have until Aug. 10 to pay their bills in full or make a
partial payment to prevent them from being sold to a third party. Taxpayers can
check to see if their bill is delinquent online at www.bcdelinquenttaxes.com.

All delinquent bills will also be advertised in the local newspaper 30 days
prior to their sale to alert the public of their pending sale, Jones said.

"Everyone who has a delinquent tax bill will be printed in the paper," she said,
adding the half page ad will run in The Independent on July 11.

All bills that remain delinquent after that date will be eligible to be sold to
third parties on Aug. 11. Jones said some third party purchasers have already
sent her a list of bills they want to purchase along with a check to purchase
them.

The largest purchaser of delinquent bills in Boyd County is Texas-based Tax Ease
Lien Investments LLC. The company purchased more than $1 million in delinquent
Boyd County bills last year, Jones said.

Third parties often attach large fees and interest rates to the bills but new
state legislation now in effect limits those fees and sets interest rates. The
legislation also requires extensive notification to property owners by third
parties and requires them to register with the state Department of Revenue and
be in good standing with the Attorney General's Office of Consumer Protection.

Delinquent taxpayers, however, can still lose their property to third parties.
Last year, Tax Ease and others began foreclosing on a large number of Boyd
properties whose delinquent tax bills had been purchased by the company in
previous years.

According to the new legislation, if a third party has purchased previous
delinquent bills they have first rights to purchase subsequent unpaid bills,
Jones said.

Despite the seemingly large number of delinquent bills that remain, Jones said
she has been impressed by the number of individuals who have come in to pay
compared to last year.

"I wanted to compliment the Boyd County residents for being so vigilant with the
delinquent tax process this year," she said, adding the 931 bills paid so far
added up to a total of $575,000 in revenue.

                              11 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                   The Daily Independent (Ashland, Kentucky)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             July 1, 2009 Wednesday

Deadline is approaching for delinquent taxes

BYLINE: Carrie Stambaugh, The Daily Independent, Ashland, Ky.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 505 words


Jul. 1--CATLETTSBURG -- Delinquent county property taxpayers have a little more
than a month to pay their bills before they can be sold to a third party.

Boyd County Clerk Debbie Jones said although more than 900 delinquent tax bills
have been paid since they were turned over to the clerk's office in April, more
than 1,400 delinquent tax bills remain in Boyd County.

Jones said residents have until Aug. 10 to pay their bills in full or make a
partial payment to prevent them from being sold to a third party. Taxpayers can
check to see if their bill is delinquent online at www.bcdelinquenttaxes.com.

All delinquent bills will also be advertised in the local newspaper 30 days
prior to their sale to alert the public of their pending sale, Jones said.

"Everyone who has a delinquent tax bill will be printed in the paper," she said,
adding the half page ad will run in The Independent on July 11.

All bills that remain delinquent after that date will be eligible to be sold to
third parties on Aug. 11. Jones said some third party purchasers have already
sent her a list of bills they want to purchase along with a check to purchase
them.

The largest purchaser of delinquent bills in Boyd County is Texas-based Tax Ease
Lien Investments LLC. The company purchased more than $1 million in delinquent
Boyd County bills last year, Jones said.

Third parties often attach large fees and interest rates to the bills but new
state legislation now in effect limits those fees and sets interest rates. The
legislation also requires extensive notification to property owners by third
parties and requires them to register with the state Department of Revenue and
be in good standing with the Attorney General's Office of Consumer Protection.

Delinquent taxpayers, however, can still lose their property to third parties.
Last year, Tax Ease and others began foreclosing on a large number of Boyd
properties whose delinquent tax bills had been purchased by the company in
previous years.

According to the new legislation, if a third party has purchased previous
delinquent bills they have first rights to purchase subsequent unpaid bills,
Jones said.

Despite the seemingly large number of delinquent bills that remain, Jones said
she has been impressed by the number of individuals who have come in to pay
compared to last year.

"I wanted to compliment the Boyd County residents for being so vigilant with the
delinquent tax process this year," she said, adding the 931 bills paid so far
added up to a total of $575,000 in revenue.

CARRIE STAMBAUGH can be reached at cstambaugh@dailyindependent.com or (606)
326-2653.

http://www.dailyindependent.com. Copyright (c) 2009, The Daily Independent,

                              13 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                            Collection & Credit Risk

                                 September 2010

Experian's Business Benchmark Report Shows Positive Signs

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2 Vol. 15 No. 8

LENGTH: 475  words


Experian's latest monthly Business Benchmark Report shows that businesses of all
sizes were relatively stable in the first half of 2010, with only slight
variations in the average percentage of dollars delinquent and percentage of
dollars severely delinquent.

Exceptions were seen only among very large businesses (with more than 1,000
employees) and mid-size businesses (with 100 to 249 employees), both of which
saw significant improvements in percentage of dollars delinquent.

- Nearly all industry groups remained stable in the percentage of dollars
delinquent and severely delinquent since the start of the year. Exceptions
include the Utilities and Retail Trade sectors, which showed significant
improvements in the percentage of dollars delinquent. The Utilities sector also
saw a large improvement in the percentage of severely delinquent dollars.

- California, Massachusetts, New York and Pennsylvania were the only states with
the largest metropolitan areas that showed improvement in the average percentage
of dollars delinquent. In terms of percentage of dollars severely delinquent,
Texas, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and California were the only ones that
consistently fell below the national average since the beginning of the year.

Experian's reports also shows that since the start of the year, businesses with
more than 1,000 employees have experienced a 25.9% improvement in the average
commercial risk score category - jumping from 33.0 in January to 41.5 in June.

By contrast, non-employer firms - meaning those that have no paid employees -
showed a 3.3% improvement for the half overall, including a dramatic drop in Q2,
falling from 61.2 in March to 59.9 in June.

When looking at average days beyond terms (DBT), however, the latest (June)
report showed that very large businesses paid their bills 24.2% slower than they
did at the beginning of the year, going from 6.6 DBT in January to 8.3 DBT in
June. Non-employer firms saw an increase of 12% in DBT, going from 5.0 DBT in
January to 5.6 DBT in June.

While the increase in DBT indicates slowness in average payment behavior, the
likelihood of these segments becoming severely delinquent over the next 12
months (as evidenced by the improvement in risk scores) is apparently lessening.

Other key findings from this month's Business Benchmark Report include the
following:

Risk score:

- The average commercial risk score for June was 58.2. When compared with the
beginning of the year, this score has improved by 1.6%. However, Q2 showed some
decline, as the national average score has actually fallen by 1% since March
when it peaked at 58.6.

- Almost all industry sectors have improved in the risk score category since the
end of Q1. The greatest improvements were found in Public Administration (from
60.4 to 61.4 - 1.7%), followed closely by Transportation (from 52.1 to 52.9 -
1.6%).

URL: http://www.creditcollectionsworld.com/

LOAD-DATE: September 2, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Magazine

                              14 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         The Brownsville Herald (Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           February 16, 2012 Thursday

BISD raises delinquent tax penalty

BYLINE: Gary Long, The Brownsville Herald, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 706 words


Feb. 16--The Brownsville Independent School District Board of Trustees approved
a resolution Wednesday night raising the penalty charged on delinquent taxes
from 12½ percent to 15 percent.

The resolution had been requested by Cameron County Tax Assessor-Collector Tony
Yzaguirre after trustees on Jan. 17 hired the delinquent-tax collection law firm
of Linebarger Goggan Blair & Sampson, LLP to collect BISD's delinquent taxes.

Explaining the action, Chief Financial Officer Ismael Garcia said Yzaguirre
asked for the resolution so that notices that go out to taxpayers could be
changed to reflect the higher fee.

The vote was 4-3, with board President Enrique Escobedo and trustees Catalina
Presas-Garcia, Luci Longoria and Christina Saavedra voting in favor and Rolando
Aguilar, Joe Colunga and Minerva Pena voting against.

Explaining the delinquent-tax collection process to the board, Garcia said that
ad valorem property taxes become due on Jan. 31 and that taxes not paid by June
30 are referred for collection on July 1. Notices that accompany tax bills note
that taxes delinquent as of June 30 are subject to collection including a
delinquent-tax collection fee.

Previous fee

BISD's previous delinquent-tax collection firm, Enrique Pena and Associates, had
charged a fee of 12½ percent. Pena's contract was not renewed after the firm
failed to meet expectations. Also, it was revealed that property Pena has owned
in Brownsville since 2004 had been omitted from the tax rolls and he had never
paid taxes on the property. Tax officials said the omission was due to an
oversight and the matter would be corrected.

Garcia said Linebarger was one of three firms that submitted qualifications to
collect BISD's delinquent taxes. He said that 92 percent of taxpayers pay their
taxes on time and that it is the other 8 percent who become delinquent and are
subject to the collection fee.

Firms ranked

Garcia said the three firms were ranked according how they met the criteria in
bid specifications and that the Linebarger firm came out on top. Predue,
Brandon, Fielder, Collins & Mott, L.L.P. of McAllen also submitted a proposal.

In analyzing data submitted by the firms, Garcia said it became evident that
Pena's numbers "were not what they needed to be," with Pena showing an average
collection rate of 35.57 percent compared to Linebarger's 39.54 percent during
the time it had BISD's delinquent tax account prior to Pena.

Linebarger's trend line was constant with a slight increase from year to year,
while Pena's trend line was going down, he said.

Linebarger

John D. Guevara, a Linebarger partner and its Brownsville representative, said
the firm offers better service to taxpayers. The firm also collects delinquent
taxes for Cameron County and the city of Brownsville.

"We have excellent rapport with taxpayers. We work with them. They can come in
and get a payment agreement done for all three entities in one place," Guevara
said, noting that Linebarger is a national firm headquartered in Austin with
superior human and technological resources.

"I know of no one else doing collections for 12½ percent," Guevara said. "Our
collection rate was 39 percent when we had the account for 26 years prior to
Pena and we met our goals every year."

Garcia said he checked with other school districts. None of their delinquent tax
firms are charging 12½ percent, with most charging 15 percent and some charging
20 percent, the maximum allowed under state law.

Penalty

He pointed out that the 15 percent fee is a penalty paid by delinquent
taxpayers, not BISD, and because Linebarger has a higher collection rate the
district comes out ahead.

"Every dollar that we don't collect, we have to find it somewhere else," he
said.

In other matters at Wednesday's BISD board meeting, the Dallas firm of
Deffenbaugh and Associates presented the forensic audit of district operations
that it has been conducting since September. The firm made the presentation
during a closed, executive session in consultation with BISD attorneys.

The Herald has made a public information request for the audit.

                             National Mortgage News

                                  June 7, 2010

Delinquency Stabilization, Taken with a Grain of Salt

BYLINE: Amilda Dymi

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1 Vol. 34 No. 36

LENGTH: 602  words


Signs of stabilization in the delinquent and foreclosed markets must not be
taken at face value since improvements "remain largely neutralized" by the more
than 7 million loans in distress.

Deterioration vs. improvement ratios remain high with two loans rolling to a
"worse" status for every one loan that fares "better," according to a report by
Lender Processing Services Inc., Jacksonville, Fla.

These improvements, deemed "artificial" because they resulted from government
intervention efforts like the Home Affordable Modification Program, are more an
indicator of political success rather than economic.

Between March and April, the number of loans 90 or more days delinquent
-including presale foreclosure-declined by 112,184 to 4,074,443.

The total number of noncurrent U.S. loans, which combines foreclosures and
delinquencies as a percent of active loans in that state, plus REO, reached just
over 7.3 million when extrapolated to represent total mortgage market.

The overall volume of loans moving from delinquent to current status declined to
a three-month low supported primarily due to HAMP modifications.

A much more revealing sign of market stabilization, however, may be the fact
that newly delinquent loans that were current at yearend and 60 or more days
delinquent as of April declined from the 2009 levels "but still remain extremely
high from a historical perspective, particularly within prime product."

These findings are in line with MBA first-quarter data showing unprecedented
defaults in prime loans.

The LPS Mortgage Monitor Report shows another positive development as only eight
states still exceed the foreclosure inventory national average.

If one were to equate the positive and the negative findings mathematically the
scale would stay put at zero gains.

The report shows the total U.S. loan delinquency rate is at 8.99%, the
foreclosure inventory rate at 3.18% and the total U.S. noncurrent loan rate at
12.17%.

States with the most noncurrent loans were Florida, Nevada, Mississippi,
Arizona, Georgia, California, Illinois, New Jersey, Michigan and Rhode Island.
States with the fewest noncurrent were North Dakota, South Dakota, Wyoming,
Alaska, Montana, Nebraska, Vermont, Colorado, Iowa and Minnesota.

The tsunami of default risk is still receding based on data for in the spring of
2010, according to the latest UFA Mortgage Report by University Financial
Associates of Ann Arbor, Mich.

The UFA Default Risk Index for the second quarter of 2010 has dropped to 182,
half the peak level of 362 set in 2007. Under current economic conditions,
investors and lenders should expect defaults on loans currently being originated
to be 82% higher than the average of loans originated in the 1990s, but much
less than the worst vintages of this cycle (2006-2008).

If, as some observers expect, inflation spikes due to excessive monetary ease,
nominal house prices will be higher and defaults will be lower, said Dennis
Capozza, a founding principal of UFA.

"Although default risks remain elevated, the index is steadily returning to
prebubble levels," said Capozza.

"The worst vintages of this mortgage cycle are behind us. However, a return of
the default risk index to prebubble levels is still several years away."

The UFA Default Risk Index measures the risk of default on newly originated
prime and nonprime mortgages. UFA's analysis is based on a "constant-quality"
loan, that is, a loan with the same borrower, loan and collateral
characteristics.

The index reflects only the changes in current and expected future economic
conditions, which are much less favorable currently than in prior years.

URL: http://www.nationalmortgagenews.com//

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              16 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Monitor (McAllen, Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           February 18, 2014 Tuesday

Delinquent tax attorney jumps ship, plans to work with rival firm

BYLINE: Dave Hendricks, The Monitor, McAllen, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 642 words


Feb. 18--MCALLEN -- Attorney John David Franz -- a high-profile player in
Hidalgo County's delinquent property tax collection arena, where rival firms
play hardball for lucrative contracts -- switched sides Monday.

Franz severed the joint venture agreement between the Law Office of John David
Franz and Houston-based delinquent tax collection agency Perdue Brandon Fielder
Collins and Mott on Monday morning. Several people familiar with the situation
said Franz plans to start working with Austin-based rival Linebarger Goggan
Blair and Sampson instead.

"It is with a heavy heart that Annette and I inform you that the association
between Perdue Brandon and our law office will be ending," Franz wrote to
co-workers at 10:09 a.m. Monday, according to an email obtained by The Monitor.
"We have just informed Perdue's management of our decision. We intend to work
alongside you until the dissolution process is completed."

Neither Franz nor attorney Hiram Gutierrez, the McAllen-based partner for Perdue
Brandon, responded to email and voicemail messages Monday.

Property tax largely fuels local government spending in Texas. When property
owners don't pay, local governments send a delinquent tax firm to collect the
money, along with penalty and interest. Attorneys typically attempt to negotiate
payment agreements with property owners. People who can't or won't pay their
delinquent taxes face lawsuits and, eventually, property auctions at the Hidalgo
County Courthouse.

Both Linebarger and Perdue Brandon collect delinquent taxes in Hidalgo County,
and play hardball for lucrative contracts.

With the joint venture agreement nixed, Franz apparently plans to join
Linebarger, according to several people familiar with the situation. Details
about the pending arrangement with Linebarger weren't immediately available.

Working together, Franz and Perdue Brandon locked down the Hidalgo County
delinquent tax collection contract -- by definition the county's largest --
along with major contracts with the McAllen school district and the La Joya
school district.

Both Linebarger and Perdue Brandon regularly make top-dollar donations to
Hidalgo County political candidates. Attorneys also donate time and money to
charitable causes, seeking to curry favor with elected leaders.

"They're both equally capable of doing the taxes for large entities like cities,
the county and the school districts," said attorney Marcus Barrera, who served
on the McAllen City Commission for 12 years. "So when you have people that are
pretty much equal, it gets down to elected officials looking at subtle
differences."

When vying for delinquent property tax collection contracts, Linebarger and
Perdue Brandon occasionally submit identical offers, elevating the importance of
personal connections and campaign contributions.

"And it's so much more money than people realize," said Virginia Townsend, a
good-government activist who helped establish the Objective Watchers of the
Legal System and regularly attends county meetings. "It's not in the thousands
anymore. It's a lot more than that."

In January 2012, Linebarger and Perdue Brandon both offered to collect Hidalgo's
delinquent city property taxes in exchange for 15 percent of tax, penalties and
interest actually collected. Politics cemented the deal.

The City Council unanimously picked Linebarger, following a spat between Franz
-- then Hidalgo's mayor -- and the majority voting bloc. Franz's influential
uncle, Rudy, brokered the deal with Linebarger.

"Some people take 360-degree turns," Rudy Franz said, amused by his nephew's
planned switch from Perdue Brandon to Linebarger. "Some land on their feet and
some don't. And that's the rest of the story."

dhendricks@themonitor.com

___ (c)2014 The Monitor (McAllen, Texas) Visit The Monitor (McAllen, Texas) at
www.themonitor.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

                              17 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                          September 15, 2016 Thursday

Revenue Publishes List of Top Delinquent Taxpayers

LENGTH: 355  words

DATELINE: New York



 Dover: Delaware Gov   has issued the following news release



 Today, Division of Revenue Director Patrick Carter has announced the next
posting of Delaware's top 100 delinquent individual and business taxpayers on
the state's Delinquent Taxpayers website. The website posts the names of people
and businesses who owe unpaid taxes to the state for public view.





 "Posting these lists puts pressure on those in violation," said Carter, "Anyone
with access to the Internet can view the name, address, and amount of tax owed
by some of our most chronic delinquent taxpayers, helping Delaware recoup
outstanding balances with minimal expense." Larger balances are targeted first
for publication, and each quarter the next 100 consecutive business tax and 100
consecutive personal unresolved tax balances over $1,000 are posted to the site.
Delinquent taxpayers can avoid appearing on the list by paying their balance in
full or making payment arrangements.



 In order to meet the criteria for having your name posted to the Delaware
Delinquent Taxpayers site, individuals and businesses must have already received
a judgment for unpaid taxes. They are then notified by mail that their names may
be posted online, and given 60 days to respond. Delaware is one of over 20
states and the District of Columbia to publish delinquent taxpayers' names
online.



 The names of those who enter into a payment agreement with the Division of
Revenue or pay their balance in full are either not published or will be removed
from the Delinquent Taxpayers list, depending on when the agreement takes place.
Taxpayers who have filed for bankruptcy protection or who have incurred a
liability that is being appealed are excluded from the published list until
their case has been resolved.



 Since its inception in February 2007, the Delinquent Taxpayers webpage has
collected in excess of $12.5 million in back taxes from those whose names were
published, or who were advised that they qualified to have their names published
online.

                              18 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                   December 10, 1998, Thursday, Final Edition
                              Correction Appended

THE DISTRICT IN BRIEF

SECTION: WEEKLY - DC; Pg. J02; THE DISTRICT IN BRIEF

LENGTH: 765 words


Census Bureau Seeks Local Workers

The Census Bureau wants to hire several thousand temporary workers in the
Washington area to verify and update street address lists in their own
communities for the 2000 Census.

The jobs begin in January, last up to eight weeks, can be part time and pay from
$ 8.50 to $ 14.50 an hour. Job applicants must take a written test, must have a
valid driver's license and must have access to a vehicle.

"We are recruiting people to work within their neighborhoods because they are
most familiar with the residents in their community," said Fernando E.
Armstrong, regional director for the Census Bureau in Philadelphia, whose area
includes the District and the Maryland suburbs.

Information about becoming a census worker is available at a toll-free number:
1-888-325-7733.

Water Authority Moves to Collect Debt

The D.C. Water and Sewer Authority has approved the sale of $ 17 million in
delinquent water and sewer accounts to Breen Capital Group. In return, the
authority will receive $ 5 million, as well as 50 percent of all collections
over $ 8 million.

Customers whose accounts have been sold to Breen will be notified beginning
later this month, authority officials said.

The sale of delinquent debt is part of an intensive collection campaign by the
authority, which has been criticized for not trying harder to collect delinquent
bills even as it imposed a 42 percent rate increase last year.

Over the past year, the authority has added a service charge to late fees,
placed liens on properties with delinquent bills and published the names of
delinquent customers. That has resulted in collection of more than $ 6 million,
officials said.

After the sale, the authority is left with $ 12 million in delinquent debt. Most
of it is owed by apartment building owners, some of whom are bankrupt.

Authority officials have announced that they will terminate water and sewer
service to apartment buildings with delinquent accounts, a new policy for the
city. Authority officials said they are developing a plan to notify tenants
before service is cut off.

Santafest Planned for Next Week

The D.C. Department of Recreation and Parks will hold its annual Santafest from
11 a.m. to 7 p.m. on Dec. 17 and 18, at the Wheatley Recreation Center, 1200
Morse St. NE.

The event for youths ages 2 to 19 includes hands-on workshops to create
Christmas cards, wreaths, ornaments and centerpieces, live entertainment,
refreshments, face painting and games. Santa Claus will also make a guest
appearance, and gifts will be on sale.

For more information on Santafest or to donate materials or gifts, call the
Special Events Office at the Department of Recreation and Parks, 202-673-7660.

Public's Input Sought on School Budget

The D.C. Emergency Transitional Education Board of Trustees will hold a public
hearing Tuesday at 7 p.m. in the fifth-floor board room, 825 North Capitol St.
NE. The meeting will discuss the fiscal year 2000 budget and solicit public
views on programs and levels of funding to be sought for D.C. public schools.
Those interested in speaking at the meeting should call Jacqueline Brocks,
administrative officer in the trustees office, at 202-442-5454.

Center for Blind Moves, Adds Programs

The Center for the Blind Elderly, previously at the Logan School, has relocated
to 2900 Newton St. NE, where it will offer upgraded services to blind and
visually impaired senior citizens.

The Center for the Blind, under the administration of the Greater Urban League
Division of Aging Services, is open to District seniors. It aids with mobility
training, Braille instruction, peer counseling, life skills management, health
promotion, recreation and case management. The center also offers traditional
senior center activities such as arts and crafts and music appreciation.

For more information, call the league's aging services division at 202-529-8701.

Howard Univ. Radio Station Manager

Wins Award Millard J. Watkins III, general manager of WHUR radio, Howard
University's radio station, received the Master Communicator award presented by
the National Black Media Coalition earlier this month.

Watkins was employed by the station as chief engineer when it went on the air 27
years ago and has worked his way up to his current position.

Last year, he chaired the AIR awards, a radio competition that raised $ 52,000
for the March of Dimes. He founded Project Harvest and sits on the boards of the
Capitol Hill Day School and Woodley House, a shelter for the mentally ill and
homeless.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CORRECTION-DATE: December 17, 1998

CORRECTION: An item in last week's The District in Brief column misidentified
Millard J. Watkins as a founder of Project Harvest. Watkins is a board member of
the organization.

                   The Times-Tribune (Scranton, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            February 25, 2011 Friday

Scranton treasurer's office, Single Tax Office collect delinquent taxes

BYLINE: Josh Mrozinski, The Times-Tribune, Scranton, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 360 words


Feb. 25--Collection of Scranton's delinquent property taxes this year is split
between the treasurer's office and Single Tax Office, with the tax office
collecting only for 2010.

The remaining years -- from 2009 and before, as well as all delinquent refuse
accounts -- are being collected by the city's treasurer's office, resulting in
confusion for some taxpayers, officials say.

"They (Single Tax Office) are collecting 2010 and 2010 only," said Ryan McGowan,
Scranton's business administrator. "Anything previous to that, people should
contact the city treasurer's office."

The practice marks a departure from previous years, when only the treasurer's
office handled delinquent property tax accounts up to April 1.

Municipal Revenue Service, a company that collects delinquent taxes for
municipalities and school districts, had collected Scranton's delinquent real
estate tax, but the city's contract with that firm ended last year. City council
last year authorized the Single Tax Office to collect delinquent property taxes
for 2010.

The treasurer's office won't be able to hold a sale this year because the budget
does not contain any funding for it, Mr. McGowan added. Council voted down
legislation to let the city collect fees that would have gone toward the cost of
suing delinquent taxpayers, he noted.

The city has about $11 million in uncollected back taxes stretching back to 1946
and accrues between $2 million and $3 million in new back taxes each year, Mr.
McGowan said.

The city has $2,019,903 in delinquent property taxes for 2010, according to the
treasurer's office. The delinquent property tax list contains about 4,000
entries.

At the Single Tax Office, workers have sent out more than 3,000 delinquent
notices, Tax Collector Bill Courtright said.

Contact the writer: jmrozinski@timesshamrock.com

                               Right Vision News

                            November 26, 2010 Friday

USA: LPS' Mortgage Monitor Report: October Data Shows Foreclosure Inventories at
All-Time High Rates

LENGTH: 520  words

DATELINE: Karachi


Karachi, Nov. 26 -- The October Mortgage Monitor report released by Lender
Processing Services, Inc. (NYSE: LPS) shows that accelerated foreclosure
referral activity over the last several months has pushed the foreclosure
inventory rate to all-time highs. As of the end of October 2010, foreclosure
inventories are 7.4 times historical averages and rising.

The report also shows that foreclosure sales decreased dramatically over the
last month as a result of the widespread moratoria. Overall, the percentage of
loans moving from the foreclosure process to bank-owned status (or other
involuntary liquidation) dropped by 35% in October. The moratoria contributed to
further timeline extensions, as the average number of days past delinquent for
loans in the foreclosure process approaches 500.

As foreclosure activity increases, more 6- and 12-month delinquent loans are
moving to foreclosure, but the extremely delinquent category (more than 12
months) continues to grow and age. A payment has not been made in more than year
on almost one-third of all loans that are 90 or more days delinquent. And, of
loans that have not made a payment in two years, more than 18% are still not in
foreclosure.

In the month of October, 263,000 loans entered the foreclosure process, which
represents a 4.4% month-over-month decline. Total inventory of foreclosures is
nearly 2.1 million loans with another 2.2 million loans in the "greater than
90-days delinquent, but not yet in foreclosure" status. While delinquencies
remain elevated - currently registering at 2.7 times historical averages - an
ever-growing number of new 60-day delinquencies are re-defaults of loans that
had previously been 60-days or more delinquent, and had become current. The
number of "first-time" troubled loans, however, remained relatively stable
during the last several months.

As reported in LPS' First Look release, other key results from LPS' latest
Mortgage Monitor report include:

Total U.S. loan delinquency rate:

9.29 percent

Total U.S. foreclosure inventory rate:

3.92 percent

Total U.S. non-current* loan rate:

13.20 percent

States with most non-current* loans:

Florida, Nevada, Mississippi,

Georgia, Louisiana

States with the fewest non-current* loans:

North Dakota, South Dakota,

Alaska, Wyoming, Montana

*Non-current totals combine foreclosures and delinquencies as a percent of
active loans in that state.

Note: Totals based on LPS Applied Analytics' loan-level database of mortgage
assets and are extrapolated to represent the industry.

About the Mortgage Monitor

LPS manages the nation's leading repository of loan-level residential mortgage
data and performance information on nearly 40 million loans across the spectrum
of credit products. The company's research experts carefully analyze this data
to produce a summary supplemented by dozens of charts and graphs that reflect
trend and point-in-time observations for LPS' monthly Mortgage Monitor Report
Published by HT Syndication with permission from Right Vision News. For any
query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please
contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                              21 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                The Morning Call

                           February 11, 2005, Friday

Allentown considers selling its delinquent tax liens

BYLINE: By Scott Kraus

LENGTH: 716 words



Allentown has found a Morristown, N.J., company that is willing to pay the
cash-strapped city as much as $ 1.5 million up front for the right to collect
its delinquent 2003 and 2004 property tax.

City officials are talking with Xspand Inc., a company headed by former
Democratic New Jersey Gov. James Florio, that would buy the city's delinquent
tax liens.

The price is subject to negotiation.

Finance Director Barbara Bigelow said the firm has done similar work for Camden,
N.J., New York City and Erie County, N.Y., and is hoping to move into
Pennsylvania.

If hired, Bigelow said, Xspand would send estimators into neighborhoods to
evaluate the properties on which delinquent tax is owed.

"They provide the city with an estimate of what they think will be collectible
and pay for what they think they can collect up front," Bigelow said. "At this
point, we are just looking on a year-to-year basis."

Bigelow said the contract would not need to be competitively bid or subject to a
request for proposals process because the city would not be paying Xspand, which
she said was selected by Mayor Roy C. Afflerbach.

"They are paying us, we're not paying them," Bigelow said.

Assistant solicitor Martin Danks said City Council will have to approve the
deal, and council President David M. Howells Sr. said company officials have
been trying to set up briefing meetings with council members.

Under former Mayor William L. Heydt, Allentown contracted with Portnoff Law
Associates of Montgomery County to collect delinquent tax, but Afflerbach did
not renew the contract at the end of 2002 over complaints that Portnoff was
charging taxpayers exorbitant legal fees. Portnoff collected the tax and
remitted it to the city, and collected legal fees from the tax delinquents.

Alan Portnoff, one of the principals of the company, said Thursday that his
company's legal fees are charged only to tax delinquents who repeatedly ignore
collection notices from the company, and that the fees have been upheld by
judges.

Portnoff said the city could be making a mistake by selling its tax liens
because it will lose out on interest income.

The city relied on sending letters to collect delinquent 2003 and 2004 tax,
Bigelow said, while it looked for a company to substitute for Portnoff.

It could have certified delinquent property tax to Lehigh County's Tax Claim
Bureau for collection, Bigelow said, but that process can take 18 months before
revenue starts coming in.

The city's 2005 budget projects the collection of $ 1 million in delinquent tax,
so the net gain in revenue could be about $ 500,000. Bigelow said it could be
more because the city will receive some revenue from collections of tax owed
before 2003 from the county tax claim bureau and Portnoff.

Legislation signed into law by Gov. Ed Rendell in November allows the city to
explore contracting with Xspand or a similar company to "monetize" delinquent
tax liens.

Xspand Vice President Charlie Smith said the company would rely on the county
Tax Claim Bureau to collect the city's tax delinquencies. The delinquencies
would have to be "certified" to the county by April 30.

All the payments and interest would go to Xspand instead of the city.

Delinquent tax liens accrue interest at a rate of 9 percent a year.

"Companies such as ours make their money on the interest that accumulates on the
assets," Smith said. "We assume the risk of nonpayment. It allows
[municipalities] to receive that value which is locked up in those tax claims as
an immediate source of revenue."

Smith said the company is working with several municipalities in Pennsylvania
including Chester, Delaware County, in the hopes of securing tax collection
contracts.

Several council members said they had not seen details of the Xspand proposal
and couldn't say whether they would agree with it.

Councilman Louis Hershman said he'll consider the Xspand program but would still
like the city to figure out a way to grant tax delinquents some form of amnesty
that would allow them to escape penalties or interest in exchange for becoming
current.

"I think I have a better deal," Hershman said.

http://www.mcall.com.

                        The Augusta Chronicle (Georgia)

                           December 2, 2010 Thursday
                                  ALL EDITION

Three overdue tax bills get paid;
Other accounts say check is in the mail

BYLINE: By Sylvia Cooper< Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A01

LENGTH: 871 words


Three of the 15 biggest delinquent Richmond County property tax bills listed in
an Augusta Chronicle article Sunday have been paid, and a check is supposed to
be in the mail for three other overdue accounts.

The top delinquent account of $143,716.96 on National Hills shopping center at
2701 Washington Road remains unpaid, however. The property is owned by Abernathy
Timberlake Investment Group of Duluth, Ga., but Richard Swope, a partner in that
company, refused to discuss the matter Tuesday.

The next-highest delinquent account was paid seven days after Nov. 15, the
deadline for paying without a 1 percent interest charge. USPG Portfolio One LLC
paid $108,876.64 in overdue real estate taxes on the Sam's building at 596 Bobby
Jones Expressway on Nov. 22, leaving interest of $1,007.99 due.

On the same date, Portfolio One paid $82,895.62 in late real estate taxes on the
Walmart building at 594 Bobby Jones Expressway, leaving $820.75 in interest
still due.

A check for the third-highest delinquent account and two other large overdue
accounts is in the mail, according to the owner of the properties.

Although a $92,525.62 delinquent bill for Iron Horse Apartments on Stevens Creek
Road lists ATC Development as the owner, the partnership has been split, and
those apartments and two other complexes are now owned by PMG of Greensboro,
N.C.

Wade Doggett, the CEO of PMG, said ATC had managed the properties until April,
when his company took over. In North Carolina, property taxes are due Jan. 5.

"In taking over the Augusta properties, we assumed they were due in December,"
he said. "There is no problem with paying.

"The check is actually going to go out today."

In addition to Iron Horse Apartments, PMG owes $63,761.28 in delinquent taxes on
Spicewood Apartments at 3721 Wheeler Road and $35,867.01 on Thornberry
Apartments at 3204 Skinner Mill Road.

Doggett said he was glad to learn the accounts' status before the Dec. 20
deadline, after which a 10 percent penalty is added to each bill.

Next on the list of top delinquent tax accounts is RDC Properties LLC, which
owes $92,048.65 for the SunTrust Building at 801 Broad St. and $69,983.91 for
the Lamar Building at 753 Broad St. RDC Properties is owned by Bettis Rainsford,
who did not respond to phonemessages left with an assistant in his office.

FPL Food LLC, which owns Shapiro Meat Packing, has two delinquent tax bills,
including a $64,936.36 real estate bill for the plant at 1301 North Savannah
Road and a $55,336.16 personal property tax bill for equipment and inventory at
a warehouse at 1150 Fifth St.

Phone messages left for Scott Anderson, the financial officer for FPL Foods,
were not returned.

USPG Portfolio One LLC still owes $61,179.69 in delinquent taxes on a portion of
Walmart in Richmond County at 590 Bobby Jones Expressway. Cindy Hicks, a
spokeswoman for that property said she would provide information concerning the
delinquency Tuesday, but did not.

Purohit & Associates LLC owes $59,033.10 in delinquent taxes for the Staybridge
Hotel and Suites. That hotel is one of five raided and padlocked by the Georgia
Department of Revenue on July 26 for failure to pay sales taxes and withholding
from their employees' income taxes. Owner Jugal Purohit paid those taxes that
same day.

Richmond County taxes are delinquent on those same five properties. In addition
to Staybridge Hotel, $19,721.29 in real estate taxes and $3,817.48 in
business/personal property taxes are overdue from Washington Hospitality LLC DBA
Ramada Inn, 2564 Center West Parkway.

Others are:

l $18,640.89 in real estate taxes and $4,430.16 in business/personal property
taxes are overdue from Belair Hospitality DBA Best Western, 2562 Center West
Parkway.

l $16,154.02 in real estate taxes and $3,816.42 in business/personal property
taxes are overdue from Shri-om Enterprises LLC DBA Days Inn, 3037 Washing-ton
Road.

l $32,833.30 in real estate taxes and $3,110.85 in business/personal property
taxes are overdue from Augusta Center LLC, DBA Country Inn & Suites, 103
Sherwood Drive.

Purohit did not return phone messages left Tuesday and Wednesday with an
assistant at Staybridge Hotel.

A $58,348.12 delinquent business/personal property tax bill is owed by Finnchem
USA, DBA Huron Tech Chemical, 2360 Doug Barnard Parkway. Belinda Rosario, at the
corporate office of that company, did not return phone messages Tuesday and
Wednesday.

Jerath Hospitality LLC, DBA Comfort Inn, 1455 Walton Way owes $48,475.37 in
delinquent real estate taxes. David Beerman, controller for Augusta Management
Co., said the taxes will be paid before the Dec. 20 deadline. He said they have
not already been paid because revenues have been down.

"Personally, I think it's (the property) over-assessed," he said.

A $44,312.40 delinquent real estate tax bill to AOA Investment Co. LLC for
Augusta Oncology, 3606 Wheeler Road was paid Monday.

No. 15 on the list of delinquent taxes is $39,466.84 billed to Cascades Pointe
at Augusta LLC for College Station Apartments, 3105 Wrightsboro Road. The
property is now controlled by Hediger Enterprises, whose main office is in
Greenville, S.C. A phone message left with Gary Hediger was not returned.

Reach Sylvia Cooper at (706) 823-3228or sylvia.cooper@augustachronicle.com

                              23 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                               The New York Times

                            April 15, 2015 Wednesday
                              Late Edition - Final

Shaming Those Who Skip Out on Taxes

BYLINE: By RICARDO PEREZ-TRUGLIA and UGO TROIANO.

Ricardo Perez-Truglia is a researcher at Microsoft Research in New England. Ugo
Troiano is an assistant professor of economics at the University of Michigan.

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Editorial Desk; OP-ED CONTRIBUTORS; Pg. 25

LENGTH: 878 words


IN 2006, according to an estimate by the United States Treasury Department,
Americans underpaid their taxes by about $450 billion. For that year, that's
roughly equal to Pentagon spending, and more than the gross domestic products of
Sweden and Switzerland.

A good chunk of the missing tax revenues comes from underreporting income, or
tax evasion. The rest, roughly 25 percent -- about $110 billion -- comes from
failure to pay taxes, or tax delinquency.

Some people are hard up and can't afford to pay their taxes. But others simply
choose not to pay. When traditional enforcement strategies, like charging
above-market interest rates on the debt, don't work, the government uses a
number of tools to collect these taxes. For instance, some states, like
Kentucky, can order employers to take a bigger tax bite from the wages of tax
delinquents, as allowed by federal and state law.

But traditional collection methods don't always work. In a recent study, we used
another strategy that got results: publicly shaming tax delinquents. It should
be a key part of government efforts to increase the collection of tax debts, and
thanks to the Internet and social media, the government has the means to make it
even more effective.

Public shaming is already used throughout the world to collect taxes. The city
of Bangalore, India, hires drummers as tax collectors to visit the homes of tax
evaders and to literally bang the drum if they don't pay. In England, Her
Majesty's Revenue and Customs publishes details of deliberate tax defaulters.
Argentine local governments are also adopting shaming lists.

They are also used to a limited extent in the United States. Nearly two dozen
states -- among them California, Massachusetts and New York -- publish online
lists on state websites revealing the identities of tax delinquents.

But many people worry that the publication of the lists could backfire by
insulting individuals who are in temporary financial hardship, making them less
likely to pay once they are back on their feet. Or the shaming could alienate
delinquents from future sources of income that could have been used to pay up.

In our study, though, we found a specific shaming policy that worked. We sent
letters to 34,344 individuals who were publicly listed as tax delinquents in
Kansas, Kentucky and Wisconsin. The lists included detailed information about
these individuals, including their full names and addresses. They owed from $250
to $150,000 per person, and altogether nearly half a billion dollars in taxes.

We divided recipients into two groups. In the first, only the recipient was
chosen to get information about an online list of tax delinquents. In the
second, the recipient and other people from the same community were given that
information. Those in the second group should have felt that their delinquent
status could be monitored by neighbors.

In the following months, people in the second group -- the ''shamed''
delinquents -- were more likely to pay off their debts than those who did not
feel monitored. This intervention was effective mostly for people who owed tax
amounts up to $2,500. For this group, the shaming treatment increased the
probability of leaving the list by 20 percent.

Since tax agencies already send several letters to delinquents, our results
suggest that including a shaming list of delinquent neighbors can result in a
highly cost-effective way to raise revenues. In addition, although we shared the
shaming information only with neighbors, exposing the delinquency status to
friends, relatives, co-workers, clients and bosses as well could make the policy
effective even for higher debt amounts.

If shaming works, other states may start publishing online lists of delinquents,
while states that have already adopted the policy may increase its scope. For
instance, in California, only the top 500 delinquents are listed.

Tax agencies could also make the delinquency records more conspicuous by
advertising the existence of the lists on the Internet and television and even
in tax forms.

Social media offers an even greater opportunity for shaming. Tax agencies could
use targeted online advertisements on social networks to raise awareness among
the social contacts of delinquents.

That said, shaming penalties come at a cost: the violation of privacy.
Governments face a trade-off between privacy and increasing the effectiveness of
tax collection. This preference for privacy may help explain why most agencies
have not taken advantage of the full potential of shaming penalties. In his new
book ''So You've Been Publicly Shamed,'' Jon Ronson looks at a real risk: In
some cases, social media may amplify shaming penalties to the point of greatly
outweighing the crime.

This could change as open disclosure becomes more common. Indeed, government
agencies are increasingly filling the Internet with detailed lists of Americans'
activities, from their political campaign contributions to their criminal
records.

We believe that shaming policies are an effective tool and should be part of the
effort to make citizens pay their fair share. More effective and fair tax
collection will fund the infrastructure, research and education that pave the
way for economic growth and opportunity.




URL:

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              Daily the Pak Banker

                           November 25, 2010 Thursday

LPS' Mortgage Monitor Report: October Data Shows Foreclosure Inventories at
All-Time High Rates

LENGTH: 520  words

DATELINE: Karachi


Karachi, Nov. 25 -- The October Mortgage Monitor report released by Lender
Processing Services, Inc. (NYSE: LPS) shows that accelerated foreclosure
referral activity over the last several months has pushed the foreclosure
inventory rate to all-time highs. As of the end of October 2010, foreclosure
inventories are 7.4 times historical averages and rising.

The report also shows that foreclosure sales decreased dramatically over the
last month as a result of the widespread moratoria. Overall, the percentage of
loans moving from the foreclosure process to bank-owned status (or other
involuntary liquidation) dropped by 35% in October. The moratoria contributed to
further timeline extensions, as the average number of days past delinquent for
loans in the foreclosure process approaches 500.

As foreclosure activity increases, more 6- and 12-month delinquent loans are
moving to foreclosure, but the extremely delinquent category (more than 12
months) continues to grow and age. A payment has not been made in more than year
on almost one-third of all loans that are 90 or more days delinquent. And, of
loans that have not made a payment in two years, more than 18% are still not in
foreclosure.

In the month of October, 263,000 loans entered the foreclosure process, which
represents a 4.4% month-over-month decline. Total inventory of foreclosures is
nearly 2.1 million loans with another 2.2 million loans in the "greater than
90-days delinquent, but not yet in foreclosure" status. While delinquencies
remain elevated - currently registering at 2.7 times historical averages - an
ever-growing number of new 60-day delinquencies are re-defaults of loans that
had previously been 60-days or more delinquent, and had become current. The
number of "first-time" troubled loans, however, remained relatively stable
during the last several months.

As reported in LPS' First Look release, other key results from LPS' latest
Mortgage Monitor report include:

Total U.S. loan delinquency rate:

9.29 percent

Total U.S. foreclosure inventory rate:

3.92 percent

Total U.S. non-current* loan rate:

13.20 percent

States with most non-current* loans:

Florida, Nevada, Mississippi,

Georgia, Louisiana

States with the fewest non-current* loans:

North Dakota, South Dakota,

Alaska, Wyoming, Montana

*Non-current totals combine foreclosures and delinquencies as a percent of
active loans in that state.

Note: Totals based on LPS Applied Analytics' loan-level database of mortgage
assets and are extrapolated to represent the industry.

About the Mortgage Monitor

LPS manages the nation's leading repository of loan-level residential mortgage
data and performance information on nearly 40 million loans across the spectrum
of credit products. The company's research experts carefully analyze this data
to produce a summary supplemented by dozens of charts and graphs that reflect
trend and point-in-time observations for LPS' monthly Mortgage Monitor Report.

with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact
