                              25 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                  The Register-Herald (Beckley, West Virginia)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            June 18, 2014 Wednesday

Audit shows $300 million in delinquent taxes

BYLINE: Pamela Pritt, The Register-Herald, Beckley, W.Va.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 474 words


June 18--CHARLESTON -- With nearly $300 million in delinquent taxes, the State
Tax Department should enforce payment plans and levy joint debtors for tax debt,
according to the State Auditor's Office.

The audit was released Tuesday during the Legislative interim session.

About a third of delinquent taxes are personal income taxes at more than $104
million in 50,189 accounts. Delinquent sales tax follows at $83,929,903 in
41,112 accounts and more than 20,000 state employer accounts are delinquent on
withholding tax with $40,166,958 not paid to the state.

The audit found that the department has lack of management oversight in
administering payment plans of more than 12 months.

Also the department does not have adequate documentation supporting those
payment plans, the audit said.

Levies for delinquent accounts are not initiated in a reasonable time frame,
some of them for as many as 553 days, according to the audit. The audit said not
initiating those levies in a reasonable time frame "reduces the effectiveness of
the Tax Department in the collection of taxes due the state," and increases the
likelihood the debt will not be satisfied.

The State Tax Department also does not initiate liens in a timely manner, and
does not have internal control over write-offs and waivers.

Corporate Income Tax transactions were granted "erroneous extensions (to
corporations that did not meet the requirements) and were not assessed interest
and penalties," according to the audit.

Rounding out the 10 findings  by the State Auditor, the department's satellite
offices in Huntington and Beckley did not deposit revenues collected within 24
hours, and instead, mailed checks to the Charleston office three days a week.

The audit spanned fiscal year 2011-2012.

State Tax Department Commissioner Mark Matkovich told the committee he was
"disappointed" with the way the audit portrayed his agency.

Matkovich said a better term for the outstanding debt is "accounts receivable."

He said that the number of accounts do not necessarily equate to the number of
taxpayers, either businesses or individuals.

Matkovich said receivables as a percentage of collections over the last 10 years
-- $298,283,873 -- is less than 1 percent. The commissioner said the report
reaches back to 1994 and encompasses accounts pending before the courts and
those that have declared bankruptcy, as well as some that are currently being
processed.

Matkovich said his department showed some leniency in collections because of the
overall economic climate.

"We are interested in collecting taxes, (but also) in maintaining goodwill," he
said. "(We) try to keep businesses open and preserve jobs."

-- E-mail: ppritt@register-herald.com

(Beckley, W.Va.) at www.register-herald.com Distributed by MCT Information

                     The News-Item (Shamokin, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            October 8, 2011 Saturday

Church was never delinquent

BYLINE: Rob Wheary, The News-Item, Shamokin, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 456 words


Oct. 08--TREVORTON -- The pastor of a church here says her congregation was
embarrassed to see their church identified as a state tax delinquent.

Especially when they knew it wasn't true.

In January, the Pennsylvania Department of Revenue website included Trevorton
United Methodist Church on its list of delinquents, saying it owed $2,213.83 in
employment taxes. Adding salt to the wound was a resulting story in The
News-Item that highlighted the church and 163 other local delinquents that had
been "outed."

"I was appalled," said the Rev. Kay Painter. "This little church has always paid
everything that is due, so our church board and I got right to work to
straighten out this problem."

It wasn't easy, but they got to the bottom of it. Turns out, not only was the
delinquency incorrect, Trevorton UM had actually overpaid in taxes. And now,
ironically, it is the church that is waiting on its refund -- from the state.

What happened?

With the help of the church's Philadelphia Area Episcopal Office, and several
months of sifting through information, the problem was identified.

"The Department of Revenue had the money, but it was not being put in the right
place," Painter said. "It was paid to Harrisburg, but not being credited to us."

The church was making monthly payments instead of quarterly payments, which
apparently caused the money to be incorrectly credited.

A spokesperson for the Department of Revenue could not comment on the specifics
of the case, citing taxpayer confidentiality, but confirmed the church made all
necessary payments to satisfy the lien, first filed in October 2009.

The church is expecting a refund of between $500 and $600.

"In this economy, that's going to help," Painter said. "That's a lot of money to
be getting back."

Reputation damaged

Still, the church says the biggest problem was the damage to its reputation.

"Trevorton United Methodist Church was founded in 1853, and there's never been a
problem until now," Painter said. "It was upsetting to see."

Bishop Peggy A. Johnson, of the Eastern Pennsylvania Conference, agreed.

"The pastor, members and friends of the church work hard to maintain and grow
their witness in their community and surrounding area," Johnson said. "The
January 2011 article deeply hurt a congregation which loves its church and
community."

Despite the negativity, Painter knew her parishioners never lost faith.

"Everyone knew what was going on through our board meetings, and knew that there
had to be some sort of explanation for it all," Painter said. "It's just sad
that it came out the way it did, but we showed that we were in the right."

___ (c)2011 The News-Item (Shamokin, Pa.) Visit The News-Item (Shamokin, Pa.) at
www.newsitem.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

                              27 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        San Bernardino Sun (California)

                             April 13, 2009 Monday

San Manuel members among delinquent taxpayers

BYLINE: Joe Nelson, Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 367 words


Four San Manuel tribal members, including one who sits on the tribe's business
committee, have made the Franchise Tax Board's list of the top 250 delinquent
taxpayers in the state.

The board started publishing the list annually in 2007, which lists the top 250
taxpayers with liened state income tax delinquencies greater than $100,000.

Each delinquent taxpayer is notified in advance via certified mail that their
names will be published on the list if they do not take action to settle their
tax debt.

"It is mandated by law for us to issue it (the list), and it is to help close
the $6.5 billion tax gap we have," said board spokeswoman Brenda Voet.

Byron Marquez, a former minor league baseball player and brother of former
tribal chairman Deron Marquez, is delinquent $439,024.47 as of April 2, 2008.

Marquez is director of business relations for the San Bernardino Inland Empire
66ers. He is also the president of the team's family outreach program and is
director of the 66ers' dance team.

Stephanie Bustamante, the secretary of San Manuel's business committee, is
delinquent $481,453 as of December.

Tribal member Kenneth Ramirez was delinquent $470,255.95 as of Nov. 4.

Tribal member Martin Hernandez Jr. was delinquent $700,092.87 as of Oct. 14.

Other noteworthy people from the Inland Empire who made the list include San
Bernardino attorney Byron E. Congdon, who is delinquent $1.1 million.

Their names dot an 11-page list of names released on April 9 that include such
celebrities as the comedian Sinbad Adkins, who is delinquent $2.5 million, and
Dionne Warwick, who is delinquent about $2.2 million.

None of the tribal members could be reached for comment on Monday.

The board sent out two certified letters, one in October and another in
February, warning the delinquent taxpayers their names would appear on the list
unless they took immediate steps to pay their debt, Voet said.

California taxpayers are paying about 20 percent more in taxes as a result of
the $6.5 billion gap created by the delinquent taxpayers, Voet said.

The notifications sent in October and February spurred some delinquent taxpayers
to action, resulting in the board's collection of $14 million in delinquent
taxes, Voet said.

                              28 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                            Dayton Daily News (Ohio)

                           November 19, 2005 Saturday

Companies to buy local liens;
Auction will offer 2,950 delinquent tax bills

BYLINE: By John Nolan jnolan@DaytonDailyNews.com

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 684 words


DAYTON - Two Floridabased companies qualified Friday for today's first auction
to buy liens from Montgomery County on 2,950 tax-delinquent properties.

Montgomery County is following the lead of other Ohio metropolitan counties that
have pressured property owners to pay overdue tax bills.

Two other bidders dropped out of the scheduled auction. They did not wire a $1.5
million deposit - 10 percent of the projected purchase price of the liens - to
the county by noon Friday, the office of county Treasurer Hugh Quill announced.

The downtown Dayton Arcade was to have been among delinquent properties whose
liens were to be sold, but its owner made a last-minute down payment and got off
the list.

Brownfield Charities Inc. submitted a certified check for $7,910 to the county
treasurer and committed to pay that amount for 20 months to retire the $158,000
debt, said Nicolette Jaworski, a spokeswoman for the treasurer.

The $158,000 debt was the highest owed for any single property in the county,
she said.

If the Arcade's owner misses any future payments, it will be added to the
properties whose liens will be sold at future annual auctions, Jaworski said.

Centerville businessman Tony Staub, founder of Brownfield Charities, is trying
to sell the 1902-vintage Arcade and is seeking plans to redevelop it.

Aware that the Arcade's tax bill would be going up, Brownfield sold another
property to raise money for the Arcade's initial payment Friday, Staub said.

"This will give us a little breathing room," Staub said . "Hopefully, we can
come up with the rest of the money."

Quill is to choose either American Tax Funding Services of Jupiter, Fla., or
BankAtlantic of Fort Lauderdale at the auction this morning to determine which
bidder will accept the lowest interest rate for repayment of the taxes owed on
the various properties.

The bidding is to start at an 18 percent interest rate and be bid down to the
lowest level accepted by one of the two parties.

The winning bidder will give the county $10.5 million to pay the delinquent
taxes and a $180 administrative fee on each of the delinquent properties,
providing revenue to school districts and local governments, Jaworski said.

In exchange, the winner gets either a guaranteed rate of return on repayment
from the delinquent property owner or the right to foreclose on the property at
sheriff's auction after a year, if repayment hasn't been arranged by then.

The lien holder also could choose to use the liens as writeoffs against taxes.

Until now, the delinquent property owner could release the lien by paying taxes
owed. Now, the owner also must pay interest on the lien plus a $180
administrative fee, which the county will collect and pay to the lien holder.

Montgomery County has been telling delinquent taxpayers for months of the
planned auction.

In response, the delinquent property owners have fully paid about 8,000 overdue
bills since August and made down payments on at least 4,000 others, an
unprecedented rate in that time period, Jaworski said.

The tax lien auctions have become popular around the country, as government
revenues have shrunk.

They generate upfront cash for governments and increase the likelihood that
properties can be made productive again, advocates say.

"With the values of property going up, the values of liens on those properties
goes up also," said Scott Carr, founder and chief executive officer of Save
Wealth Financial, a financial planning firm in San Diego. "As long as government
is holding the liens, there isn't much that can be done with them. They'd prefer
to have the cash in hand."

Other Ohio counties - including Summit, Franklin, Cuyahoga, Stark and Mahoning -
also have sold liens since a 1998 law allowed the state's 12 largest counties to
do so.

Summit County went first, has done it since 1999 and has sold more than $50
million in liens to date, said Shelley Davis, chief of staff for the Summit
County treasurer in Akron.

After observing the other counties, Montgomery County decided to proceed this
year in light of shrinking state financial support to counties, Jaworski said.

Contact John Nolan at 225-2242.

LOAD-DATE: November 22, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                     Copyright 2005 Dayton Newspapers, Inc.


                              29 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Tampa Tribune (Florida)

                             April 9, 2005 Saturday
                                 FINAL EDITION

COMMUNITY LIVING

BYLINE: RICHARD WHITE, Tribune correspondent

SECTION: BAYLIFE AT HOME; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 474 words


By RICHARD WHITE

Tribune correspondent

Force Payments With Liens, Not By Publishing List Of Delinquent Owners

Q. Is it permissible to publish the names of property owners who have not paid
their assessments in the association reports? Is it advisable? My thought is
that maybe peer pressure is preferable to legal action.

R.C.

Jensen Beach

A. I have been advised there is no violation of law to publish a delinquent
owner's name. However, it could alleged that it violated their right to privacy
regarding credit information. I never recommend that you display print the names
of delinquent owners because of the repercussions from the owner and the
neighbors. You have the strongest legal powers through the lien and foreclosure
rocedures. Why not force collections via this method? Once you force payment
through liens, the word will get out and you will see that others will pay on
time. A very large community of more 3,000 homes recently printed the names of
all owners who were delinquent. There were so

many delinquent owners that it took several pages to print their names. Other
owners who were paying said they were not going to pay next year. Why should
they, when there was no action taken by the board to force payments? I think it
is poor management by the board if they do not have a strong collections policy
and immediately file liens and start foreclosure. Any account that is more than
90 days delinquent should have legal action started. You need an attorney to
advise you and take the necessary legal action. Usually any legal costs will be
paid by the delinquent owner. It should not cost the association any funds to
take the legal action to collect the delinquent

accounts.

Q. I live in a 300-unit condominium. Must we have an outside audit by a CPA
every year? We have one person that enters everything into our records.

R.M.

Fort Lauderdale

A. Short answer is no. Correct answer is that you should have a third
independent person review your records each year. People make mistakes. It could
be an honest mistake or a dishonest mistake. The members need to have confidence
that their funds are being protected and properly preserved. They need to know
that operations and management are accurately handling the financial functions
for the members. Florida statute 718.111 (13) establishes the three types of
reports: compiled, reviewed and audit. The members can vote to reduce the
statute requirements or your document requirements.

Richard White is a licensed community association manager. He does not offer
legal opinions; any other questions and comments concerning association
operations can be sent to Richard White, 6039 Cypress Gardens Blvd., No. 201,
Winter Haven FL 33884-4115; or e-mail

camquestion@cfl.rr.com.

Copyright © 2005, The Tampa Tribune and may not be republished without
permission. E-mail library@tampatrib.com

LOAD-DATE: April 23, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


           Copyright 2005 The Tribune Co. Publishes The Tampa Tribune

BRIEF: Chester delinquent on Augusta taxes

BYLINE: Bob Stuart, The News Virginian, Waynesboro, Va.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 163 words


Feb. 26--VERONA -- Churchville attorney Francis Chester, the leader of a
petition drive against the Augusta County reassessment, owes more than $2,800 in
2008 real estate and personal property taxes.

Chester is delinquent on $2,562 in real estate taxes on parcels in Churchville
and West Augusta, and owes $328 in delinquent personal property taxes, according
to records in the Augusta County Treasurer's office.

Augusta County Treasurer Richard Homes said there is an "issue with anyone being
delinquent,'' whether it is a county employee or other person.

                            The Blade (Toledo, Ohio)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             April 30, 2010 Friday

Bell promises new policy on overdue bills: City will continue liens, but become
'more user-friendly'

BYLINE: Ignazio Messina, The Blade, Toledo, Ohio

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 528 words


Apr. 30--Toledo Mayor Mike Bell said his administration has for weeks been
working on changing a policy that one of his top administrators called "patently
ridiculous" in which a property owner gets a lien because of delinquent utility
bills from a previous homeowner.

"This process has been going on since 1986," Mr. Bell said a day after Lucas
County Auditor Anita Lopez told The Blade that she had has stopped processing
property water liens from the city because of complaints over the practice.

"Within two weeks, we will have a new policy of debt owed to the city," the
mayor said during a news conference he called to address the issue.

Tom Crothers, director of the Department of Public Utilities for the city, said
the city would not completely stop the process of placing liens on properties
for delinquent bills from previous owners.

"We recognize, as the mayor indicated, we have to be more user-friendly," Mr.
Crothers said.

Although he said it is "patently ridiculous" for someone to get a lien for a
bill they did not create, Mr. Crothers said it is absolutely legal.

However, Ms. Lopez said her office's attorneys have interpreted the city's law
to say the administration cannot place a lien on a property if the delinquent
bills are from a previous owner.

Ms. Lopez on Wednesday said her office is investigating the validity of 2,000
liens from the city filed in 2009 under Mayor Carty Finkbeiner.

But yesterday, Mr. Crothers said the city had filed 1,495 liens last year.

Ms. Lopez also highlighted one extreme case of an individual, who does not wish
to be identified, who purchased a home and later learned of a lien on the
prop-erty for a delinquent water bill of $7,149.

Mr. Bell said that bill was "taken care of" last week, that the man was no
longer responsible for the bill, and the lien would be lifted.

The city has been behind in collections in the water department.

City Council voted April 13 to put more collection firms to work to bring in
$18.7 million in water and sewer bills. The ordinance allows the city to
contract with three agencies.

Of that money, $5.4 million represents current invoices that have been sent out
less than 30 days ago; $1.1 million is less than 60 days delinquent, but more
than 30 days delinquent; $632,000 is less than 90 days delinquent, but more than
60 days delinquent; $1.4 million is less than 180 days delinquent, but more than
90 days delinquent; $1.7 million is less than 365 days delinquent, but more than
180 days delinquent; and $8.4 million is greater than 365 days delinquent.

The city considers $13.3 million delinquent from water, sewer, storm water, and
garbage services, said Jeff Pax, manager of utilities administration for the
city.

imessina@theblade.com

or 419-724-6171.

                   The Times-Tribune (Scranton, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           October 6, 2010 Wednesday

Carbondale authority seeks tax abatement

BYLINE: Caitlin Heaney, The Times-Tribune, Scranton, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 394 words


Oct. 06--Carbondale agency seeks tax relief on 8 properties

Carbondale Redevelopment Authority filed eight petitions Tuesday in Lackawanna
County court seeking relief of more than $189,000 in delinquent taxes and
related fees on several of its properties.

The authority wants all taxing authorities and the Lackawanna River Basin Sewer
Authority to "abate, forgive and/or mark satisfied" delinquent taxes, penalties,
interest and sewer charges attached to eight authority properties in Carbondale.

"We can't rehabilitate them or resell them to a private developer if there are
substantial taxes that are owed against them," authority Solicitor David J.
Tomaine said.

The authority acquired the properties between December 2004 and July 2010. They
include:

n 8 Belmont St.; delinquent 2002 to 2010; $24,903 owed.

n 82-84 Belmont St.; delinquent 2007 to 2010; $11,227 owed.

n 2 Cemetery St.; delinquent 1998 to 2010; $22,063 owed.

n 4 Cemetery St.; delinquent 2001 to 2010; $18,586 owed.

n 16 Reynolds Ave.; delinquent 2007 to 2010; $11,150 owed.

n 18 River St.; delinquent 2003 to 2007; $47,071 owed.

n 22 River St.; delinquent 2003 to 2007; $47,071 owed.

n 6 Rock St.; delinquent 2007 to 2010; $7,325 owed.

The amounts owed exceed what could be realized not only through selling each
property but also by "enforced collection" of the money from the property
owners, according to the petitions.

Although Carbondale would lose money owed to it, Mayor Justin Taylor said the
city would not oppose the tax abatements. Some of the property owners have died
or simply walked away, he said, and the city recognizes that it likely would
never receive that money anyway.

The city's portion of the delinquent taxes is about 15 percent, or approximately
$29,500. But with the authority redeveloping the properties in question, Mr.
Taylor said, they eventually will return to the tax rolls.

Contact the writer: cheaney@timesshamrock.com

                        San Bernardino Sun (California)

                             April 14, 2009 Tuesday

San Manuel members among delinquent taxpayers

BYLINE: Joe Nelson, Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 383 words


Four San Manuel tribal members, including one who sits on the tribe's business
committee, have made the Franchise Tax Board's list of the top 250 delinquent
taxpayers in the state.

The board started publishing the list annually in 2007, which lists the top 250
taxpayers with liened state income tax delinquencies greater than $100,000.

Each delinquent taxpayer is notified in advance via certified mail that their
names will be published on the list if they do not take action to settle their
tax debt.

"It is mandated by law for us to issue it (the list), and it is to help close
the $6.5 billion tax gap we have," said board spokeswoman Brenda Voet.

Byron Marquez, a former minor league baseball player and brother of former
tribal chairman Deron Marquez, is delinquent $439,024.47 as of April 2, 2008.

Marquez is director of business relations for the San Bernardino Inland Empire
66ers. He is also the president of the team's family outreach program and is
director of the 66ers' dance team.

Stephanie Bustamante, the secretary of San Manuel's business committee, is
delinquent $481,453 as of December.

Tribal member Kenneth Ramirez, who is the tribe's former vice chairman, was
delinquent $470,255.95 as of Nov. 4.

Tribal member Martin Hernandez Jr. was delinquent $700,092.87 as of Oct. 14.

None of the tribal members could be reached for comment. Jake Coin, spokesman
for the tribe, declined to comment.

Other noteworthy people from the Inland Empire who made the list include San
Bernardino attorney Byron E. Congdon, who is delinquent $1.1 million.

Their names dot an 11-page list of names released on April 9 that include such
celebrities as the comedian Sinbad Adkins, who is delinquent $2.5 million, and
singer Dionne Warwick, who is delinquent about $2.2 million.

The board sent out two certified letters, one in October and another in
February, warning the delinquent taxpayers their names would appear on the list
unless they took immediate steps to pay their debt, Voet said.

California taxpayers are paying about 20 percent more in taxes as a result of
the $6.5 billion gap created by the delinquent taxpayers, Voet said.

The notifications sent in October and February spurred some delinquent taxpayers
to action, resulting in the board's collection of $14 million in delinquent
taxes, Voet said.

                              34 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                The New York Post

                              March 6, 2009 Friday

NY WORST IN HOME $ICKNESS - MORTGAGE DELINQUENCY SURGES 35%

BYLINE: CARL CAMPANILE

SECTION: All Editions; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 487 words


The number of New York homeowners more than 90 days late in paying their
mortgages skyrocketed 35 percent in the final quarter last year - the biggest
jump in delinquencies in the country, a new survey has found.

The Mortgage Bankers Association attributed the increase to the financial
tsunami engulfing the Northeast, along with the rest of the nation.

"While California, Florida, Nevada, Arizona and Michigan continue to dominate
the delinquency numbers, some of the sharpest increases we saw last quarter in
loans 90 days or more delinquent were in Louisiana, New York, Georgia, Texas and
Mississippi," Jay Brinkmann, the MBA's chief economist, said in releasing the
report.

All home loans past due in New York surged to 7.58 percent in the fourth quarter
- up from 6.14 percent in the third quarter of 2008. That's a 19 percent
increase.

The number of mortgages in New York that were at least 90 days delinquent soared
to 2.49 percent from 1.61 percent - a 35 percent increase.

And the number of mortgages deemed "seriously delinquent" - a category that
includes foreclosures - is up 18 percent, to 5.10 percent from 4.18 percent.

The increase in New York's 90-day delinquency rate exceeded that of Arizona (34
percent), California (31 percent), Florida (29 percent) and Michigan (22
percent) - although the delinquency problem overall is still more severe in
these states than in the Northeast.

New York's neighbors are also reeling.

The number of New Jersey homeowners more than 90 days delinquent shot up 28
percent, to 2.38 percent from 1.71 percent. As in New York, nearly one in 12
residents is at least 30 days behind in payments.

In Connecticut, the number of residents more than 90 days delinquent in payments
jumped 29 percent. More than 7 percent of homeowners there are now at least 30
days delinquent - a 19 percent hike.

The worsening delinquency rate in New York clashes with a study released
Wednesday that showed the Empire State with the lowest percentage of mortgage
holders "underwater" - owing more than their homes are worth.

That's because New Yorkers have more equity in their homes, and property values
have not plummeted as markedly here as in Sunbelt states and the heartland.

But that could change as the economy worsens, researchers warned.

The mortgage-delinquency rate nationally shattered the record set in the third
quarter, and is the highest since the MBA began tracking housing data in 1972.

In total, 11 percent of the nation's homeowners are delinquent on their
mortgages - or one out of every nine.

But the number of foreclosure sales was flat, as federal and state governments
put a moratorium on such actions last fall.

---

Late and lamented

The states with the biggest increase in homeowners 90 days late in paying
mortgages (fourth quarter 2008):

1. NY UP 35%

2. AZ UP 34%

3. CA UP 31%

4. CT UP 29%

5. NJ UP 28%

Source: Mortgage Bankers Association

LOAD-DATE: March 6, 2009

                              35 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                     The Santa Fe New Mexican (New Mexico)

                             July 1, 2004 Thursday

'MOST WANTED' PARENTS EXPOSED

BYLINE: YASMIN KHAN

SECTION: SANTA FE/EL NORTE; Pg. B-4

LENGTH: 762 words


Human Services Department seeks public's help in finding parents who don't pay
child support

The delinquent parents on Northern New Mexico's newest 25 Most Wanted list owe
their children a total of $1.4 million, according to the New Mexico Human
Services Department.

"The point and goal of the 25 most wanted is to bring attention to the fact that
there's noncustodial parents who are not taking responsibility for their child's
life," said Betina Gonzales McCracken, the department's communications director.

State law requires human services to release in a quarterly report the names of
the noncustodial parents who owe back child support. The department hopes the
public will help find the parents if their names and most recent addresses are
given.

The state reports cover the top 25 delinquent parents in specific regions of the
state, which allows more names to be included on the list. The list also
includes the top female delinquent in each region.

"In past years, we would just publish the top 25 heavy hitters in the state. At
(that) point, they would all be people who owed six figures," McCracken said.
"We needed to get more names out. It's not just a financial matter."

More than 63,000 custodial parents, with up to five children each, depend on
child support in New Mexico. According to McCracken, from May 2002 to May 2003,
61 percent of those families were not receiving childsupport payments. During
that time, she said, 35,364 noncustodial parents were delinquent.

After the last report, which came out in March, the department received tips for
finding several of the noncustodial parents, McCracken said. One delinquent
parent was located working in Arizona, she said, and he is now paying his child
support through his employer. One father was located through the food-stamp
system, and one father had died.

At the top of the latest list is Cedric A. Graves, who owes his family $142,898.
His last known address is in Amarillo, Texas. Robert L Martinez, who is second,
owes $108,790. His last known address is in Pueblo, Colo. The lone female on the
list is Alicia Subia, who owes $9,898 - less than many men but more than any
other woman in the region. Her last known address is in Las Vegas, N.M. Three
and a half percent of all delinquent parents in New Mexico are women, which
prompted the department to begin including a woman on each list.

This quarter's list covers dependent families who live in Colfax, Taos, San
Miguel, Harding and Union counties in northeastern New Mexico. Eighteen of the
25 delinquent parents' last known residences are in New Mexico.

Recent child-supportenforcement legislation includes negotiating options and
low-interest rates for noncustodial parents who owe back child support,
according to a recent press release.

The department's goal is to encourage both parents to assume responsibility for
improving the economic and social well-being of their children, Stephanie
Gonzales, the Human Services Department's child-enforcement division director,
said in the press release.

"This could be the first step for them to get on a payment plan that will
benefit their child or children," she said.

                 The Daily Courier (Connelsville, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           February 16, 2012 Thursday

Delinquent per capita taxes go to collection in Connellsville

BYLINE: Judy Kroeger, The Daily Courier, Connellsville, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 524 words


Feb. 16--Connellsville City Council announced Wednesday night that treasurer
Judy Keller will turn over all delinquent 2010 city per capita taxes to Central
Tax Bureau immediately. Fines and penalties will be added.

Residents have until June 1 to pay their 2011 city per capita taxes before those
also are turned over to Central Tax Bureau for delinquent collection.

The Private Industry Council of Westmoreland-Fayette offers free GED instruction
at Connellsville's Carnegie Free Library for adult Pennsylvania residents
interested in making the transition to new or updated employment or
post-secondary classes that yield college credit.

Tami Ozegovich, of PIC, said the council has a well-equipped classroom in the
basement and offers classes that directly relate to career and higher education
exploration four days a week. The library also functions as an official GED test
center. The $60 test is offered two days each month.

Registration takes place at the library. Call PIC Uniontown at 724-437-2590 and
ask for Roxanne for more information on class times and offerings.

The Second Annual World Championship of the World Cornhole Tournament will take
place at 1 p.m. March 4 at New Haven Hose Company social hall. Doors open at
11:30 a.m.

Two-person teams cost $30. Team registrations and sponsorships benefit the
city's parks and recreation department. New Haven will sell food and drink to
benefit its operation. Armstrong Cable will tape the competition.

Councilman Tom Karpiak said registrations will be taken at the door, with a
limit of 80 teams. Registration forms are also at City Hall.

The Annual Geranium Festival will take place from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. May 26 on
West Crawford Avenue, between Pittsburgh and Arch streets.

In other business:

-- Council made several appointments. Geno Gallo resigned from the Zoning
Hearing Board. Jamie Cross will take his seat. His term expires in January 2014.
Council also appointed Mike Napolillo to the ZHB. His term expires in January
2017. Council reappointed Patty Handford to the Connellsville Housing Authority.
Her term expires in January 2017. Council reappointed Johanna Harden to the
Connellsville Board of Health. Her term expires in January 2017.

-- Health, code and zoning officer Tom Currey reported that the planning
commission approved 59 building permits in 2011, yielding $1,500 in fees and
$800,000 in increased property value in the city. Permits included 4 house
additions, 14 sheds or garages, 14 commercial expansions and two new houses.

-- Council changed its employee insurance broker to Paychex Insurance Agency,
Rochester, N.Y., at a savings of $120 per month. Mayor Charles Matthews said
employee dental vision, short-term disability, life and health coverage will not
change, just the broker that provides the coverage.

-- Councilman Brad Geyer congratulated the street department for fixing their
own equipment and vehicles rather than sending them out. "It saves a lot of
money in the end," he said.

Information Services

                              Daily the Pak Banker

                           December 28, 2010 Tuesday

LPS' Mortgage Monitor Report: November Data Shows Foreclosure Inventory Rising
for 5th Straight Month

LENGTH: 485  words

DATELINE: Karachi


Karachi, Dec. 28 -- The November Mortgage Monitor report released by Lender
Processing Services, Inc. (NYSE: LPS) shows that the volume of loans moving to
REO continued to drop as moratoria further delayed foreclosure sales. While the
90+ delinquency category has steadily declined, the number of loans moving to
seriously delinquent status beyond 90 days far outpaced the number of
foreclosure starts. Nearly 2.2 million loans are 90 days or more delinquent but
not yet in foreclosure.

Foreclosure inventories also continued to rise for the fifth straight month as
delinquent accounts are referred for foreclosure, but the sale of foreclosure
properties continued to decline. When compared to January 2008 levels, the
foreclosure inventory of Jumbo Prime loans is nearly seven times higher; the
inventory of Agency Prime loans is nearly six times higher; and the foreclosure
inventory of Option ARM loans is approaching five times the inventory in January
2008.

The report also shows that one-third of loans that are 90 days or more
delinquent have not made a payment in a year; however, the number of new problem
loans declined nearly 5.4 percent from October, which is opposite of the
seasonality trend that typically impacts new delinquencies this time of year.
Self-cures for loans one to two months delinquent increased in November to a
six-month high.

In the month of November, 261,153 loans were referred to foreclosure, which
represents a 0.7% month-over-month decline. The total number of delinquent loans
is nearly 2.1 times historical averages - and foreclosure inventory is currently
at 7.7 times historical averages.

As reported in LPS' First Look release, other key results from LPS' latest
Mortgage Monitor report include:

Total U.S. loan delinquency rate: 9.02 percent

Total U.S. foreclosure inventory rate: 4.08 percent

Total U.S. non-current* loan rate: 13.10 percent

States with most non-current* loans: Florida, Nevada, Mississippi, Georgia, New
Jersey

States with fewest non-current* loans: North Dakota, South Dakota, Alaska,
Wyoming, Montana

*Non-current totals combine foreclosures and delinquencies as a percent of
active loans in that state.

Note: Totals based on LPS Applied Analytics' loan-level database of mortgage
assets and are extrapolated to represent the industry.

About the Mortgage Monitor

LPS manages the nation's leading repository of loan-level residential mortgage
data and performance information on nearly 40 million loans across the spectrum
of credit products. The company's research experts carefully analyze this data
to produce a summary supplemented by dozens of charts and graphs that reflect
trend and point-in-time observations for LPS' monthly Mortgage Monitor Report.
Published by HT Syndication with permission from Daily Pak Banker. For any query
with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact
Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                         Palestine Herald-Press (Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              May 14, 2013 Tuesday

County OKs increase in delinquent tax fees

BYLINE: Mary Rainwater, Palestine Herald-Press, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 525 words


May 14--PALESTINE -- Anderson County commissioners heard a presentation on
delinquent property tax collections, approved an increase in collection
penalties and agreed to a contract with the collection firm during their regular
meeting Monday.

Tax attorney Robert Meyers of McCreary, Veselka, Bragg & Allen, PC presented the
report to the court, telling commissioners that the county collects more taxes
than are levied each year.

"That includes the delinquent taxes and fees that are collected each year,"
Meyers said. "At the end of 2011, the county collected about 97 percent of the
tax levy and in 2010, 98 percent of the levy was collected."

Meyers requested an increase in penalty costs, from 15 to 20 percent, to
delinquent tax payers beginning with 2012 tax collections.

"The state now allows up to a 20 percent penalty," he said. "With the money
generated from those additional penalties, we want to add a third employee to
the tax office to increase those collection efforts even more."

Taxing entities do not pay any money to the collection firm, but the firm
receives payment directly from the tax payer through their fees.

Commissioners approved the penalty increase and, in a separate, related action,
OK'd a three-year contract between the county and McCreary, Veselka, Bragg &
Allen, PC for the collection of delinquent property taxes.

Also on Monday, the court:

--APPROVED budget amendments, bills and utility crossing county roads.

--APPROVED a resolution from the District Attorney's Office regarding the Crime
Victim Coordinator and Liaison Grant (VCLG).

--APPROVED a tax abatement contract between Anderson County and Sanderson Farms
Inc. for the value of improvements to be placed on property in the established
reinvestment zone for the purpose of operating a Sanderson Farms Inc. hatchery.

--APPROVED a 5-year maintenance contract renewal with Otis Elevator Company for
a cost of $6,830 per year.

--AWARDED Requests for Qualifications (RFQs) to Burns Roofing and Remodeling
(Plano); Wiginton, Hooker Jeffry Architects (Plano); and RoofTech (Fort Worth)
for the Anderson County Jail roof.

--HEARD the reading of a proclamation by a representative of Adult Protective
Services declaring May as Elder Abuse Prevention Awareness Month.

--APPROVED transferring an equipment attachment from Precinct 1 Road and Bridge
Department inventory to Precinct 2 Road and Bridge Department inventory.

--APPROVED taking different pieces of equipment for viewing to Washington Early
Childhood Development for Pre-K and Kindergarten students.

--APPROVED the removal of cattle guards on Anderson County Road 4651. A petition
of area residents calling for the action (or for proper installation of the
cattle guards) was submitted to commissioners.

--APPROVED a resolution to participate with Texas Department of Transportation
in the Off-System Bridge Program for a bridge on Anderson County Road 2418 (in
Precinct 4).

Mary Rainwater may be reached via e-mail at mrainwater@palestineherald.com

                   Standard-Speaker (Hazleton, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           October 14, 2009 Wednesday

Many pay garbage bills before list's release

BYLINE: Mia Light, Standard-Speaker, Hazleton, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 646 words


Oct. 14--More than 200 people with overdue garbage accounts have visited
Hazleton City Hall with payments since city officials threatened last week to go
public with the delinquency list.

With more than 2,000 names on the delinquency list, payments received since the
announcement equal just 10 percent of the people with past-due accounts. Acting
City Administrator Mary Ellen Lieb said the city is "pleased" with the number of
people who have made payments, "but we have a long way to go."

Unpaid residential garbage bills in the city this year total about $500,000. The
city does not have the money to pay the trash hauler without payment from the
delinquent property owners.

The original 2009 delinquency list included the owners' names of 2,034
properties.

As of Tuesday afternoon, 207 people came forward with payment, leaving 1,827
unpaid garbage bills on the list.

There are 116 delinquent property owners who have home addresses in New York.

Among the New York addresses is a corporation called Hazleton Homes Inc., which
owns 11 properties in Hazleton, each with an unpaid garbage bill in the amount
of $229.32 for a total delinquency of $2,522.52.

Additionally, there are 54 delinquent properties owned by New Jersey residents.

A Clifton, N.J., resident on the list owns four Hazleton properties, each one in
arrears $229.32 for a total delinquency of $917.28.

While a majority of the delinquent accounts are held by local residents, other
properties in delinquency have owners listed in Texas, Florida, Connecticut,
Mississippi, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Massachusetts, Illinois, Georgia,
Maryland, California, Virginia, Tennessee and Puerto Rico.

The annual price for residential garbage disposal in the city is $208.

The city bills property owners on behalf of the trash hauler in two annual
installments of $104.

In a press conference at City Hall last week, Lieb said the list of delinquent
account holders would be made available for public inspection Tuesday. The
announcement was made in effort to give people with unpaid garbage bills
opportunity tomake payment arrangements before the accounts are turned over to
the local district court for prosecution.

A representative of the district court office of Magisterial District Judge
Joseph Zola, Hazleton, said the delinquent accounts are filed as private
criminal complaints on behalf of the City of Hazleton. The court schedules a
hearing date and sends written notice of the hearing to the account holder.

"They can come to court before the hearing date, plead guilty, and we will set
up a payment plan. Or, they can wait for the hearing date, come to court and
have a hearing before the judge," the spokesperson for Zola's court said.

Lieb said the city will hold the delinquent list until the end of October. Then
the list goes to court.

Lieb urged citizens with delinquent bills to contact city hall.

"Don't just ignore the bill. Contact us. We are not cruel. We will find a way to
work with you," she said.

Lieb said monthly billing for all garbage customers is not a cost-effective
option for the city, but special arrangements can be extended in certain
situations.

"If you are one person out there on Social Security and you really cannot pay
$104 in one lump sum, call right away. We can work something out where you might
pay $15 a month instead of one lump sum," Lieb said.

Divided into 12 monthly installments, the $208 annual garbage fee is $17.33 per
month.

mlight@standardspeaker.com

                            The Blade (Toledo, Ohio)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             June 10, 2010 Thursday

Toledo plans fewer water liens: Users who don't pay bills face shutoff, mayor
says

BYLINE: Ignazio Messina, The Blade, Toledo, Ohio

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 573 words


Jun. 10--Toledo Mayor Mike Bell yesterday said his administration would cut back
on the practice of placing liens on properties because of delinquent utility
bills from a previous homeowner.

The mayor also said people who don't pay their water bills, and who don't
attempt to get on a payment plan for an unpaid bill, will have the service shut
off after seven weeks.

Mr. Bell said there was concern that the city was not fairly placing liens on
properties where unpaid water bills had accrued.

"We sat down with the auditor's office to see if there was a way we could work
together to be able to pursue collections in a more fair way," Mr. Bell said.
"When we got together, we realized there were a couple little glitches in the
system. A lot of it was just being able to talk to each other."

Mr. Bell said the city and the Lucas County auditor's office will make available
on their Web sites information about properties and whether a lien exists. But
that still would not eliminate the problem of a lien being filed on a home for
water usage by a previous owner after the house is purchased by someone else.

"It is important for us to collect on fees that are not being paid," Mr. Bell
said. "When we do that, we are able to keep our rates down for our customers who
are paying."

In April, Mr. Bell said the process had been going on since 1986. He made the
statement a day after Lucas County Auditor Anita Lopez told The Blade that she
had stopped processing property water liens from the city because of complaints
over the practice.

Tom Crothers, the city's director of the Department of Public Utilities, said
the city would not completely stop the process of placing liens on properties
for delinquent bills from previous owners, which he maintains is legal.

"We are not doing away with liens because that is a bona fide way and an
effective way of getting our money," Mr. Crothers said yesterday.

Ms. Lopez previously has said her office's attorneys have interpreted the city's
law to say the administration cannot place a lien on a property if the
delinquent bills are from a previous owner.

The city filed 1,495 liens last year, before Mr. Bell was mayor.

City Council voted April 13 to put more collection firms to work to bring in
$18.7 million in water and sewer bills. The ordinance allows the city to
contract with three agencies.

Of that money, $5.4 million represents current invoices that have been sent out
less than 30 days ago; $1.1 million is less than 60 days delinquent, but more
than 30 days delinquent; $632,000 is less than 90 days delinquent, but more than
60 days delinquent; $1.4 million is less than 180 days delinquent, but more than
90 days delinquent; $1.7 million is less than 365 days delinquent, but more than
180 days delinquent; and $8.4 million is greater than 365 days delinquent.

The city considers $13.3 million delinquent from water, sewer, storm water, and
garbage services, said Jeff Pax, manager of utilities administration for the
city.

Contact Ignazio Messina at:

imessina@theblade.com

or 419-724-6171.

To see more of The Blade, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.toledoblade.com. Copyright (c) 2010, The Blade, Toledo, Ohio

                     The Mecklenburg Times (Charlotte, NC)

                            August 11, 2015 Tuesday

CoreLogic: 0.8% of Charlotte-area homes in foreclosure

BYLINE: Roberta Fuchs

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 501  words


The share of Charlotte-area homes with a mortgage that were facing foreclosure
in June remained at 0.8 percent, the same as in April and May but down 0.3
percentage points from July 2014. According to real estate data firm CoreLogic,
statewide levels also did not move. In North Carolina, 0.7 percent of homes with
a mortgage were in the foreclosure process in June, the same as in April and
May, but 0.2 percentage points lower than a year ago.

North Carolina's foreclosure rate was lower than the nation's 1.2 percent rate
in June. According to CoreLogic, the nation hasn't seen a rate this low since
December 2007. Across the United States, only Massachusetts saw a rise in its
foreclosure inventory last month.

CoreLogic considers only mortgaged homes with first liens in determining its
foreclosure inventory data, which covers the number of homes placed in the
foreclosure process by the mortgage servicer.

Locally, the rate of Charlotte-Concord-Gastonia area mortgages that were 90 days
or more past due, or seriously delinquent, in June was 2.9 percent, the same as
in May. The region had a 3.8 percent seriously delinquent rate in June 2014.

Nationally, 3.5 percent of homes were seriously delinquent in June, down from
4.4 percent a year ago. States with the highest seriously delinquent rates are
Florida, New York, New Jersey, Maine and Maryland.  In North Carolina, the
seriously delinquent rate dropped to 2.9 percent in June from 3.6 percent a year
ago.

"Serious delinquency is at the lowest level in seven and a half years,
reflecting the benefits of slow but steady improvements in the economy and
rising home prices," said CoreLogic Chief Executive Anand Nallathambi, in a
written statement. "We are also seeing the positive impact of more stringent
underwriting criteria for loans originated since 2009, which has helped to lower
the national serious delinquency rate. "

There were 4,476 completed foreclosures in the Charlotte metro area for the year
ending in June, down 37 percent from 7,125 during the previous 12 months.

Nationally, completed foreclosures for the year ending in June fell to 526,189
from 641,154 the previous year. In North Carolina, that figure fell 28 percent
to 18,258 from 25,220.

Since the financial crisis began in September 2008, according to CoreLogic,
about 5.8 million homes nationwide have been lost to foreclosure.

The five states with the highest number of completed foreclosures for the 12
months ending in June were Florida with 102,000, Michigan with 46,000, Texas
with 33,000, California with 29,000, and Ohio with 27,000. These states
accounted for nearly half of all completed foreclosures nationally.

Washington, D.C., and four states had the lowest number of completed
foreclosures in the same period. They were South Dakota at 32; Washington, D.C.,
at 107; North Dakota at 313; Wyoming at 499; and West Virginia at 566.

http://www.mecktimes.com/be-the-first-to-know/ Click here for more from this
resource.

                              42 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                  Herald-Journal (Spartanburg, South Carolina)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              May 10, 2009 Sunday

Delinquent tax notices flat, so far: Authorities expect collection rate to
decline in recession

BYLINE: Lynne P. Shackleford, Spartanburg Herald-Journal, S.C.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 690 words


May 10--The number of notices sent to the Spartanburg County delinquent tax
collector remained relatively flat, compared with last year's figures, but
collection rates could decline over the next two years.

Scott Slatton, an S.C. Municipal Association field services manager, works with
115 cities and towns from Columbia to the Upstate, and he isn't surprised that
counties aren't seeing more delinquent taxpayers this year.

"From my perspective, the economic downturn didn't set in until the third
quarter of last year, which might be the reason why government entities aren't
seeing the full effects of high unemployment and the housing slump," Slatton
said. "We're in the full throes of the housing downturn now, so next year's
budget and even planning for 2010-2011 will be more challenging."

In 2008, 25,206 Spartanburg County property and real (boats, airplanes) bills
remained unpaid after March 16, the date the county treasurer must turn over
unpaid bills to the delinquent tax collector.

The previous year, 22,886 bills were turned over to the delinquent tax office, a
difference of about 2,320. Last year was a reappraisal year, and County Auditor
Sharon West said her office received 2,606 reappraisal appeals, which could
account for the increase in the number of late payments in 2008.

In Cherokee County, the county treasurer sent 655 more late notices this year to
the delinquent tax office for collection. In 2007, 3,587 notices were "rolled
over," and 4,242 have been sent this year. The county sent out 34,679 tax
notices in 2007 and 35,064 this year.

Union County Treasurer Diane Wilkins said officials expected an increase in the
number of delinquent tax notices, but only 64 more notices were sent to the
delinquent tax office over 2007.

The Spartanburg County treasurer's office collects taxes for the county, 13
municipalities, seven school districts and 40 fire districts. County Treasurer
Oren Brady said it's difficult to determine how many individuals pay their taxes
after the March 16 deadline -- because one person could own multiple properties
and other taxable assets -- so the office calculates the number of tax notices
that haven't been paid.

Tax notices were issued from mid-October to mid-November, and South Carolina
taxpayers have until Jan. 15 to pay without penalty.

Local property taxes are the largest revenue stream for the county and
municipalities, so several entities scrutinized budgets when the economy started
to decline.

The city of Spartanburg slashed $750,000 from its budget in October when county
projections showed that a slowed economy and high unemployment rate could
trigger a lower percentage of property tax collections than the historic average
of 92 to 93 percent. This year's budget is based on a 92 percent collection
rate, and officials predicted that number could drop by as much as 3 percent,
causing a $275,000 budget shortfall. City officials adjusted their budgets to
make up for the expected collection decline, although they anticipated some
revenue could be recovered in delinquent tax collections.

City Manager Mark Scott said the city is using the same tax collection
projections as the county and anticipates a modest 1.5 percent growth in the tax
base next year.

This year, it looks as though Spartanburg governments might have dodged a
bullet, with tax collections that are in line with previous years.

Spartanburg County Administrator Glenn Breed said the staff is using a
conservative collection percentage of 91.48 percent while crafting next year's
budget.

"We track collection rates and use an average based on the last five years,"
Breed said. "There are a couple of variables to account for, but in the past
we've been pretty consistent."

To see more of The Spartanburg Herald-Journal or to subscribe to the newspaper,
go to http://www.goupstate.com. Copyright (c) 2009, Spartanburg Herald-Journal,
S.C. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                              43 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                Payments Source

                           January 22, 2015 Thursday

Private Firm Will Collect on Purchased Ohio Tax Liens

BYLINE: Darren Waggoner

SECTION: CCR - DEALS & PRICING Vol. 1 No. 1

LENGTH: 233  words


An Ohio County's tax lien sale of unpaid penalties and taxes on more than 1,000
properties resulted in more than $1.1 million.Private Cincinnati company Tax
Ease Ohio paid Columbiana County $560,000 for the bundle and the county's
certified letter campaign warning delinquent taxpayers resulted in another
$584,000 in payments.Tax Ease Ohio will now collect on the debt in purchases
from the county. The company will charge delinquent taxpayers 18% interest.The
sale was Columbiana County's' first tax lien sale. County Treasurer Linda Bolon
said selling tax liens helps revenue, motivates delinquent taxpayers to make
good, returns delinquent property to active tax rolls and helps avoid drawn-out,
costly foreclosure actions. Â Nearly half of the people receiving letters
notifying them of the planned sale either paid their entire delinquent bill or
entered into a payment contract, according to county officials.Ohio law allows
counties to turn over unpaid taxes to collection agencies. Â Bolon said Tax Ease
Ohio rejected some of the county's delinquent properties. The county will review
starting foreclosure procedures on those properties.Bolon told local media that
delinquent taxes have been reduced from $11 million to $8.5 million since she
took office, according to WFMJ, an NBC television affiliate. The county plans to
conduct tax lien sales each year with the next one set for September.

URL: http://www.paymentssource.com

LOAD-DATE: January 22, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Magazine

JOURNAL-CODE: PAYMENTSSOURCE_NEWS


                        Copyright 2015 SourceMedia, Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                              44 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            October 17, 2014 Friday

Zombie Foreclosures Result in Millions of Delinquent Tax Revenue Dollars

LENGTH: 359  words


Washington, D.C.: American Land Title Association has issued the following news
release:

So-called "zombie" foreclosures have been known to lower property values of
surrounding homes. But they also present another problem: property tax revenue
lost, RealtyTrac recently reported.

According to RealtyTrac's most recent data on zombie foreclosures, about 21
percent of the 141,406 total foreclosures reported in Q2 were of the zombie
variety. With the owner having deserted the distressed property, not only is
there no one to maintain the property's outward appearance, but there is no one
paying taxes on the property.

RealtyTrac estimates near $400 million in delinquent property tax revenue as a
result of zombie foreclosures in Q2. The top metropolitan statistical area (MSA)
as far as delinquent property tax revenue in Q2, according to RealtyTrac, was
New York-Northern New Jersey-Long Island, with $208.5 million. This MSA also
reported the highest total number of zombie foreclosures of any MSA in the
nation in Q2 with 13,574, according to RealtyTrac.

The MSA with the second highest delinquent tax revenue total was
Chicago-Naperville-Joliet with $45.1 million. This area placed third in total
zombie foreclosures with 9,975 behind New York and Miami-Fort Lauderdale-Pompano
Beach (12,958). Miami placed third in delinquent property tax revenue due to
zombie foreclosures, with $36.3 million.

Much has been made in the last few months about the problems caused by zombie
foreclosures, which are properties that have been deserted by their owners but
the title is still in the owner's name because the foreclosure process has not
been completed. The fact that these homes fall into disrepair with no one to
maintain them, as well as the fact that they attract vandals and other crime,
has been well documented. Zombie foreclosures declined in 38 states according to
RealtyTrac's Q2 report, but they were still up in several states. With more than
48,000 zombie foreclosures in Q2, Florida accounted for nearly a third of the
nation's total.

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: October 18, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


              Copyright 2014 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited
                              All Rights Reserved


                              45 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                  Herald-Journal (Spartanburg, South Carolina)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           February 7, 2007 Wednesday

Most eateries on delinquent list have paid up

BYLINE: Lynne P. Shackleford, Herald-Journal, Spartanburg, S.C.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 410 words


Feb. 7--One local restaurant and two others that have closed are five months
delinquent paying their hospitality taxes to the city.

Spartanburg City Attorney Cathy Hoefer McCabe released the names of those
restaurants that were delinquent as of Jan. 24, the date the Herald-Journal
requested the names of delinquent restaurants under the S.C. Freedom of
Information Act.

On Jan. 24, the date the newspaper's request was filed, 14 restaurants were
delinquent. All but three have since paid in full.

DQ Grill & Chill, located in Dorman Centre, is the lone restaurant remaining
open that hasn't paid the two percent tax levied on all prepared foods sold
inside the city.

Bryan Henson, who owns the local franchise, admitted he was late paying the tax,
but said he didn't realize he was five months behind.

McCabe said the city has tried to contact DQ Grill & Chill by phone and has sent
notices by mail, but hasn't been able to make contact with anyone.

Henson said he did plan to pay the taxes, but said he got behind because "it's
been a bad winter (for sales)."

"It's not their money," McCabe said. "It's the city's money and they're the
keepers of it."

According to the ordinance, the city may prosecute restaurant owners in
municipal court for failing to pay hospitality taxes and they could be ordered
to pay fines with each delinquent day being a separate offense.

The city might also suspend a restaurant's business license for failing to pay.

Hub City Grille and Pranza, both of which have closed, are also five months
delinquent.

The hospitality tax was enacted four years ago and generated about $3 million
for the city in 2006. There are approximately 238 restaurants, grocery store
delis and caterers required to pay the tax.

Spartanburg City Council is considering increasing the penalties for delinquent
restaurants. Currently, a restaurant that is late in paying the tax is subjected
to a one-time 10 percent levy. Under the new ordinance, a restaurant would be
required to pay a 10 percent penalty for each month they are late paying the
fee.

To see more of the Herald-Journal, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.GoUpstate.com. Copyright (c) 2007, Herald-Journal, Spartanburg, S.C.
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

LOAD-DATE: February 10, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ACC-NO: 20070207-SG-DELINQUENT-EATERIES-20070207

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: SG


                         Copyright 2007 Herald-Journal


                              46 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           October 23, 2014 Thursday

Hawaii: DELINQUENT TAX COLLECTION ASSISTANT II (SR-17) - OAHU

LENGTH: 385  words

DATELINE: Honolulu


Department of Human Resources, The State of Hawaii has issued the following job
opportunities:

Recruitment Number 214308 - Downtown, Oahu Employment Only.

A continuous recruitment may be closed at any time. The notice of the last day
to file applications will be posted on the Civil Service Hawaii State Government
Jobs page of our website.
 Duties Summary:
Performs delinquent tax collection assignments which regularly encompass complex
problems and which require immediate action to prevent loss of revenue to the
State; may supervise lower level delinquent tax collection assistants and
performs other related duties as assigned.
 Minimum Qualification Requirements:
To qualify, you must meet all of the following requirements:

Specialized Experience:
A. One year of experience in the tax field which required the application of tax
laws and related regulations and procedures in collecting current or delinquent
taxes, in preparing tax returns, or in determining tax liability AND one year of
tax collection experience performing a variety of delinquent tax collection
assignments involving moderately difficult cases comparable to the Delinquent
Tax Collection Assistant I * level in the State service.

*The Delinquent Tax collection Assistant I performs a variety of delinquent tax
collection assignments ranging from the simple to moderately difficult which
require field contacts and which include individuals with medium to large
income, and businesses of a small to moderately large nature.

OR

B. Two years of collection experience.*

*Collection Experience: Experience performing a variety of collection activities
such as contacting debtors and negotiating payment plans; evaluating financial
records and other documents and identifying assets that may be used to satisfy
debts; evaluating the debtors' ability to pay; determining the most productive
collection method to pursue; and/or using legal proceedings (e.g., levy, lien)
and/or court actions (e.g., seizure and foreclosure) to satisfy the debt.

Substitutions Allowed: Relevant substitutions as described in the Minimum
Qualification Requirements, will apply.

License: You must possess a valid drivers license at the time of appointment.

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: October 24, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


              Copyright 2014 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

tax collection experience performing a variety of delinquent tax collection
assignments involving moderately difficult cases comparable to the Delinquent
Tax Collection Assistant I * level in the State service.

*The Delinquent Tax collection Assistant I performs a variety of delinquent tax
collection assignments ranging from the simple to moderately difficult which
require field contacts and which include individuals with medium to large
income, and businesses of a small to moderately large nature.

OR

B. Two years of collection experience.*

*Collection Experience: Experience performing a variety of collection activities
such as contacting debtors and negotiating payment plans; evaluating financial
records and other documents and identifying assets that may be used to satisfy
debts; evaluating the debtors' ability to pay; determining the most productive
collection method to pursue; and/or using legal proceedings (e.g., levy, lien)
and/or court actions (e.g., seizure and foreclosure) to satisfy the debt.

Substitutions Allowed: Relevant substitutions as described in the Minimum
Qualification Requirements, will apply.

License: You must possess a valid drivers license at the time of appointment.

contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

Hawaii: DELINQUENT TAX COLLECTION ASSISTANT II (SR-17) - OAHU

LENGTH: 398  words

Department of Human Resources, The State of Hawaii has issued the following job
opportunities:

Recruitment Number 214308 - Downtown, Oahu Employment Only.

Note: The starting monthly salary is at the minimum rate of pay advertised
above.

A continuous recruitment may be closed at any time. The notice of the last day
to file applications will be posted on the Civil Service Hawaii State Government
Jobs page of our website.
 Duties Summary:
Performs delinquent tax collection assignments which regularly encompass complex
problems and which require immediate action to prevent loss of revenue to the
State; may supervise lower level delinquent tax collection assistants and
performs other related duties as assigned.
 Minimum Qualification Requirements:
To qualify, you must meet all of the following requirements:

Specialized Experience:
A. One year of experience in the tax field which required the application of tax
laws and related regulations and procedures in collecting current or delinquent
taxes, in preparing tax returns, or in determining tax liability AND one year of
tax collection experience performing a variety of delinquent tax collection
assignments involving moderately difficult cases comparable to the Delinquent
Tax Collection Assistant I * level in the State service.

*The Delinquent Tax collection Assistant I performs a variety of delinquent tax
collection assignments ranging from the simple to moderately difficult which
require field contacts and which include individuals with medium to large
income, and businesses of a small to moderately large nature.

OR

records and other documents and identifying assets that may be used to satisfy
debts; evaluating the debtors' ability to pay; determining the most productive
collection method to pursue; and/or using legal proceedings (e.g., levy, lien)

                      Pharos-Tribune (Logansport, Indiana)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                           December 29, 2015 Tuesday

Delinquent properties available in tax sale

BYLINE: Pharos-Tribune, Logansport, Ind.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 269 words


Dec. 29--The Cass County Board of Commissioners will conduct a live tax
certificate sale of delinquent properties that did not sell at the prior Cass
County Tax Sale at 10 a.m. (EST) Thursday, Jan. 7, in the Commissioners' Hearing
Room on the second floor of the Cass County Government Building, 200 Court Park.

Commissioners' certificate sale is to offer delinquent properties at a
discounted price. About 71 previously unsold certificates will be offered for
opening bids that equal less than the total amount due in taxes, costs and
penalties.

Subsequently, an internet sale of leftover properties will begin at 9 a.m. (EST)
Saturday, Jan. 16, and will close at 2 p.m. (EST) Friday, Jan. 22. Auction
participation and registration is located at www.zeusacution.com. The parcels
that will be available at that sale will be those that do not sell during the
Jan. 7 live auction.

The Cass County Commissioners have contracted with SRI Inc., an
Indianapolis-based company founded in 1989 that conducts county tax sales and
commissioners' certificate sales for 84 counties in Indiana plus additional
counties in Colorado, Iowa, Florida, Louisiana and Michigan.

Persons interested in the sale should visit SRI Inc.'s corporate site at
www.sriservices.com.

IF YOU GO

WHAT: Cass County Commissioners' tax sale

WHEN: 10 a.m. Jan. 7

WHERE: Commissioners' Hearing Room on the second floor of the Cass County
Government Building, 200 Court Park

INFO: www.sriservices.com

                              60 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                  August 8, 1989, TUESDAY, ST. CHARLES Edition

AMNESTY FOR CHILD-SUPPORT PAYMENTS THIS WEEK

BYLINE: Marianna Riley Of the St. Charles Post

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1014 words


Ruby McDonald says her ex-husband is willing to sit in jail rather than pay
about $10,000 in child support he owes her daughter. Pam Jungwirth says her
husband is hiding in the jungles of Belize rather than cough up the $40,000 she
says her children are owed.  But neither is giving up. And they hope their
openness will help other women.  ''I've struggled for 10 years,'' Jungwirth
said. ''He owes it to the kids to get them through their teen-age years and
college.'' Jungwirth, now remarried to a man with no children, considers herself
luckier than most.  She says her ex-husband went from South Carolina to North
Carolina to Alabama to Texas to Mississippi before taking off for Central
America to avoid his increasingly delinquent child-support payments.  On Monday,
McDonald and Jungwirth participated in a news conference by the prosecuting
attorney's office in St. Charles County to tell parents who are delinquent in
their child-support payments that Monday through Friday is an amnesty period in
St. Charles County. During that time, they can make arrangements for payment
without fear of prosecution.  It is ''one last chance,'' said St. Charles County
Prosecutor William J.  Hannah, in announcing that his office, along with the
cooperation of the Missouri Department of Social Services' Division of Child
Support Enforcement, would conduct the project.  For those who do not come
forward, arrests will begin Monday.  In the meantime, parents who make sincere
efforts to make arrangements for child-support payments will have nothing to
fear, said Bill Rapps, director of the Division of Child Support. Leah B. Haub,
assistant prosecuting attorney in charge of child support, said she encouraged
delinquent parents to ''make deals in order to avoid criminal prosecution. We're
trying to get people out of the woodwork.'' She said she would like to collect
at least $1,000 from each delinquent parent in this week's amnesty program.
Haub said she had files on about 1,200 parents delinquent in their payments.
Some files are dormant, and others are on file simply so the office can monitor
payments, she said.  In addition, 7,000 cases in St. Charles County do not
involve criminal prosecution and will be handled administratively, she said. But
at any time, some of that number could be sent to her office for legal action,
she said.  She estimated that delinquent child-support payments in Missouri
could add up to as much as $1 billion.  Rapps estimated that Missouri had
300,000 delinquent child support cases, representing 375,000 children.  ''But in
reality, the cases we're working on number about 260,000, which represents about
300,000 children,'' he said. Last year, this translated into $106 million in
delinquent child support payments.  He insisted that the parents subject to
arrest would be those who had been offered every opportunity to make
arrangements to catch up on their payments.  ''We know they can and they
didn't,'' he said.  The amnesty program was preceded by an inquiry by state
investigators, who came to St. Charles County last month to locate parents
behind in their payments.  Haub says she will work out the deals depending on
the reasonableness of the offers. ''If they say they don't have any money, we
will explore why.  If it's because they have a job that pays $3.50 an hour and
are disabled, that's reasonable. But if they are living extravagantly, with good
jobs and are buying luxury items, these are the people we'll start arresting.
''You'd be surprised how much they can cough up once they've been put in jail.
And even if they're in jail, mom and the kids aren't any worse off.  They
weren't paying before anyway.'' Said Rapps, ''It's a lot like being in jail if
you're a kid and living in poverty and you don't do well in school because your
eyes are bad or you don't want to open your mouth because your teeth are
crooked.  ''As it is, a lot of these kids are being taken care of at the
taxpayers' expense.''

LOAD-DATE: October 25, 1993

LANGUAGE: English

GRAPHIC: Photo; Photo by L.T. Spence/St. Charles Post ... Pam Jungwirth (left)
and Ruby McDonald, both of St. Charles, talking at a news conference about an
amnesty program. Both women say their ex-husbands owe large amounts of child
support. Photo by L.T. Spence/St. Charles Post ... Bill Rapps, director of the
Division of Child Support enforcement, Missouri Department of Social Services,
and Leah B. Haub, assistant prosecuting attorney of St. Charles County, at the
St. Charles County courthouse to announce an amnesty program for those
delinquent in child-support payments.

                              61 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          Reading Eagle (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            October 19, 2010 Tuesday

City seeks repayment of delinquent loans

BYLINE: Darrin Youker, Reading Eagle, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 350 words


Oct. 19--Reading is trying to recoup delinquent loans dating back more than 20
years given to businesses for projects and then never repaid.

The city has more than 30 delinquent loans, totaling $15 million, that were
given as part of community development projects but never repaid by businesses,
offi cials said.

The city administration is now in talks with legal authorities and collection
agencies about going after those outstanding loans.

After reviewing the list of delinquent loans, Dan Robbins, the city's director
of community development, told City Council on Monday that he believes about 18
of those loans-- totaling $1 million--could be collected.

The rest were given to businesses that have either folded or the person who
received the loan can't be found, he said.

Money collected from the delinquent loans cannot be used to balance the city
budget, but instead would be returned to a community development fund for future
loans, Robbins said.

"Some of this is found money for the city," he said.

Most of the outstanding loans date back to before 1994, with a handful given out
more recently, Robbins said.

Councilman Francis Acosta said he was angered that the loans have not been
repaid.

"I want people to know that we are taking care of this issue," he said.

Robbins said he would like to work out an agreement with a collection agency
where the city receives a portion of the funds collected but pays no upfront
costs for services.

Council also learned that the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation will
repave North Sixth Street from Amity Street to Hiester's Lane next spring at a
cost of $500,000.
