                              62 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                  The Leader-Telegram (Eau Claire, Wisconsin)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           January 28, 2012 Saturday

Area counties see drop in delinquent property taxes

BYLINE: Jon Swedien, The Leader-Telegram, Eau Claire, Wis.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 290 words


Jan. 28--Delinquent property taxes owed by Eau Claire County residents are
hovering around $3 million, about the same as last year.

And while the amount of delinquent taxes plateaued this year, outstanding taxes
have fallen since the height of the recent economic recession, county Treasurer
Larry Lokken said. In 2008, delinquent property taxes in the county had reached
$4.5 million.

"It's getting better" compared to then, Lokken said, adding the treasurer's
office has been especially busy in recent days.

Tuesday is the deadline to pay first-half property taxes for 2011.

The outstanding property taxes pales in comparison with the total amount taken
in by the county, Lokken said. In 2011, more than $100 million was collected in
2010 taxes, Lokken said.

Chippewa County

In Chippewa County, delinquent tax dollars fell steadily in recent years,
dropping from $2.15 million on Dec. 31, 2009, to $1.93 million on Dec. 31, 2011.

"It went down a little bit," said county Treasurer Patricia Schimmel.

While there is some good news in the decrease in delinquent taxes, Schimmel
said, the decrease is caused in part by the processing of home foreclosures.
Outstanding property taxes are paid as the foreclosure process concludes.

Dunn County

In Dunn County, there were $1.65 million in delinquent taxes as of Dec. 31,
2011, down from $1.99 million on Dec. 31 2010.

"It's up and down," in recent years, said county Treasurer Mary Erpenbach,
noting outstanding taxes in the county stood at $1.09 million on Dec. 31 2009.

Swedien can be reached at 715-833-9214, 800-236-7077 or jon.swedien@ecpc.com

                         The Brownsville Herald (Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           February 2, 2012 Thursday

Rezoning, delinquent taxes on BISD agenda

BYLINE: Gary Long, The Brownsville Herald, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 349 words


Feb. 02--Brownsville Independent School District trustees will meet in special
session today to discuss redistricting for the 2012-2013 school year and fees
that BISD's new delinquent tax-collection firm will be allowed to charge.

Two weeks ago, trustees hired the Edinburg firm of Linebarger, Heard, Goggan,
Blair, Graham & Sampson L.L.P. to collect the district's delinquent ad valorem
taxes and directed the administration to negotiate a contract.

Trustees will be asked to approve a resolution raising the delinquent ad valorem
tax collection penalty to 15 percent from 12½ percent. If approved, the
resolution would allow Linebarger to collect a 15 percent fee, or $15 per $100
of delinquent taxes actually collected and deposited into BISD accounts.

Board President Enrique Escobedo said the higher rate is what the Linebarger
firm charges and that the resolution is needed to comply with the contract.

Several factors are at work in BISD's rezoning considerations for the coming
school year as the district looks to maximize use of its facilities, improve
feeder school patterns and equalize school enrollments.

-- Daniel Breeden Elementary, 3955 Dana Ave., will open for the first time in
2012-2013. The school has been finished for more than a year but didn't open
because of budget considerations.

Having Breeden open is expected to relieve overcrowding at Burns, Gallegos,
Hudson and Paredes elementary schools.

--Veterans Memorial High School will add another class.

VMHS opened in August 2010 with freshman and sophomore students. It added a new
freshman class this year and will do so again in 2012-2013, giving the school
freshmen, sophomores, juniors and seniors next year.

BISD also will open the Science, Technology, Architecture and Medical
Professions College Preparatory Program at VMHS in 2012-2013.

Today's meeting starts at 5:30 p.m. in the boardroom of the BISD Administration
Building at 1900 Price Road.

                              64 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         The Brownsville Herald (Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           January 19, 2012 Thursday

Linebarger to collect BISD back taxes

BYLINE: Gary Long, The Brownsville Herald, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 418 words


Jan. 19--By a 4-3 vote Tuesday night, the Brownsville Independent School
District Board of Trustees chose the Edinburg firm of Linebarger, Heard, Goggan,
Blair, Graham & Sampson L.L.P. to collect the district's delinquent ad valorem
taxes.

The Linebarger firm specializes in delinquent tax collections. It was one of
three firms to submit qualifications for BISD's consideration, including the
current tax-collection firm of Enrique Pena and Associates.

Terms of the contract are being negotiated, BISD legal counsel Arturo Michel
said. The contract is to be negotiated for a one-year term with an option to
renew, according to information provided for Tuesday's meeting.

Pena and Associates, which has been BISD's delinquent collection firm for the
past five years, receives a fee of 12½ percent of all delinquent taxes,
penalties and interest actually collected and deposited into BISD accounts. For
example, if a taxpayer owes $100, Pena is allowed to collect $112.50.

Board President Enrique Escobedo the decision to award delinquent tax
collections to Linebarger boiled down to a calculation of which firm was most
likely to collect the highest amount of back taxes. The third firm to submit
qualifications was Perdue, Brandon, Fielder, Collins & Mott, L.L.P. of McAllen.

"Delinquent tax collection doesn't cost the district anything," Escobedo said.
"The difference is the revenue generated. ... All three firms are very well
qualified, but the question is who can collect more for us. We looked closely at
the numbers and determined who could get us more revenue. ... For us, (the
difference in favor of Linebarger) was significant enough to merit a change."

During a presentation earlier in the meeting about his firm's activities, Pena
said that as of July 1 BISD was owed $12.32 million in delinquent taxes.

Trustees Catalina Presas-Garcia, Luci Longoria and Christina Saavedra voted with
Escobedo in favor of Linebarger, while Joe Colunga, Rolando Aguilar and Minerva
Pena opposed the move.

In other business, trustees voted unanimously to accept the Hanna High School
Performing Arts Instructional Facility at 2617 Price Road as substantially
complete. Hanna had been the only BISD high school without an auditorium. The
$6.46 million project was paid for with federal stimulus funds utilizing
Qualified School Construction Bonds.

___ (c)2012 The Brownsville Herald (Brownsville, Texas) Visit The Brownsville
Herald (Brownsville, Texas) at www.brownsvilleherald.com Distributed by MCT
Information Services

                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           February 5, 2014 Wednesday

City Council discusses options to curb delinquent garbage bills

BYLINE: Kevin Flowers, Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 285 words


Feb. 05--The city of Erie and Erie Water Works could explore combining
customers' water, sewer and garbage bills, lawsuits and rescinding or denying
landlords' eligibility for city-required rental licenses as a way to better
collect more than $1.6 million in delinquent refuse fees.

City Council and other city officials discussed the issue with Paul Vojtek, the
Erie Water Works' chief executive, at council's Finance Committee meeting this
morning at Erie City Hall.

Vojtek told City Council that the city's total delinquencies, including accounts
that have municipal liens filed against them, is $2.3 million.

Some customers, Vojtek said, have not paid their bills in a decade, likely
because they know there is little penalty for nonpayment and the city continues
to collect garbage at properties with delinquent accounts.

City officials have been criticized by some citizens for not being aggressive
enough on the issue, especially since residents' garbage fees were increased in
the city's 2014 budget.

Councilman Cas Kwitowski said the city needs to get tough regarding the
delinquent accounts. Kwitowski suggested filing lawsuits to get the largest
delinquent customers to pay up.

"We've got to start having some guts around here," Kwitowski said. "People are
mocking us over this."

Vojtek said that Erie Water Works received $55,500 in payments from delinquent
customers in the wake of a Jan. 19 Erie Times-News story on the city's problems
with delinquent garbage accounts.

A list of accounts that were delinquent at that time was posted at
www.goerie.com/garbagebills.

Pa.) at www.GoErie.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

                              66 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                March 15, 1982, Monday, Late City Final Edition

THE DEFECTS IN A COURT SYSTEM FOR YOUTH CRIME

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 706 words


To the Editor:

The Times's dramatic six-part series on the subject of juvenile crime directed
much attention to the shortcomings of the Family Court system of New York State,
and especially New York City. It isn't that the criticism isn't valid; rather,
it is misdirected -it might be compared to denouncing a duck because it is not a
swan.v.hen the people of our state determined in 1962 that a separate court
should deal with children who engage in criminal acts, the Family Court was
created. The people, through their legislators, made the rules under which this
new court would function.

It was to be a civil court, not criminal. It was to guarantee all who appeared
before it due process, the assistance of counsel and the right to a trial,
albeit without a jury.

In adjudicating issues involving alleged delinquents, the Legislature provided
that there be two trials. The first, known as a fact-finding hearing, would be
conducted essentially under the dueprocess rules of a criminal proceeding. If
the facts were proven beyond a reasonable doubt, the court was obliged to
conduct a second trial to determine whether the delinquent was in need of
treatment and, further, whether treatment was available.

It is the requirement regarding the availability of treatment that exposes the
court to its greatest public criticism. The Legislature did not permit the judge
to punish the delinquent. Neither is the judge allowed to compel any institution
to accept the delinquent for treatment: the treatment facility determines
whether help is available.

This mandate led to the most glaring dissatisfaction with the court, since it is
the delinquent most in need of help - the sickest, if you will - who is the
least likely to be found eligible for treatment by any existing facility. The
situation thus created resembles the case of a terminally ill patient who is not
accepted into a hospital, not because he doesn't need treatment but because no
treatment is available.

Virtually every other state in the union provides for the transfer of a
delinquent from its family court to the jurisdiction of the criminal court
system, where punishment is an option, when it is found that he is untreatable.
Despite the recent amendments with regard to juvenile offenders, the Albany
Legislature still has not made such provision.

The Legislature imposed other peculiarities on the Family Court, particularly in
the area of pretrial detention. Bail is not an option because provisions were
made for speedy fact-finding. The court must release the accused back into the
community unless it can be established that he is not likely to return to court
voluntarily or that he likely will commit another criminal act. Even in
instances where the delinquent is placed in a treatment institution, the
Legislature provided for his discharge upon determination that the treatment
program is complete, either by ''cure'' or because no ''cure'' is possible.

These procedures have exposed the court to criticism most often involving such
words as ''wrist-slapping,'' ''revolving door'' and ''indecisive.'' These
observations are no doubt valid, but correction must come from the Legislature;
it cannot come from the courts.

As an independent third branch of government, the courts are in a peculiar
position of dependency. They must apply the laws written by the Legislature and
function with the resources provided by the executive. New York State's Family
Court, unlike those in some other states, has no control over placement and
treatment facilities; that is an executive function.

It is indeed ironic that a newspaper as sophisticated as The Times should not
recognize this basic fact and point its expositive skills in the proper
direction.  (Judge) EDWARD J. MCLAUGHLIN Syracuse, March 5, 1982

The writer heads the Association of New York State Family Court Judges.

*

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Illustrations: drawing

TYPE: Letter

                   Copyright 1982 The New York Times Company


                              67 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            October 14, 2014 Tuesday

Washington: Zombie Foreclosures Result in Millions of Delinquent Tax Revenue
Dollars

LENGTH: 361  words

DATELINE: Washington


American Land Title Association has issued the following news release:

zombie foreclosuresSo-called "zombie" foreclosures have been known to lower
property values of surrounding homes. But they also present another problem:
property tax revenue lost, RealtyTrac recently reported.

According to RealtyTrac's most recent data on zombie foreclosures, about 21
percent of the 141,406 total foreclosures reported in Q2 were of the zombie
variety. With the owner having deserted the distressed property, not only is
there no one to maintain the property's outward appearance, but there is no one
paying taxes on the property.

RealtyTrac estimates near $400 million in delinquent property tax revenue as a
result of zombie foreclosures in Q2. The top metropolitan statistical area (MSA)
as far as delinquent property tax revenue in Q2, according to RealtyTrac, was
New York-Northern New Jersey-Long Island, with $208.5 million. This MSA also
reported the highest total number of zombie foreclosures of any MSA in the
nation in Q2 with 13,574, according to RealtyTrac.

The MSA with the second highest delinquent tax revenue total was
Chicago-Naperville-Joliet with $45.1 million. This area placed third in total
zombie foreclosures with 9,975 behind New York and Miami-Fort Lauderdale-Pompano
Beach (12,958). Miami placed third in delinquent property tax revenue due to
zombie foreclosures, with $36.3 million.

Much has been made in the last few months about the problems caused by zombie
foreclosures, which are properties that have been deserted by their owners but
the title is still in the owner's name because the foreclosure process has not
been completed. The fact that these homes fall into disrepair with no one to
maintain them, as well as the fact that they attract vandals and other crime,
has been well documented. Zombie foreclosures declined in 38 states according to
RealtyTrac's Q2 report, but they were still up in several states. With more than
48,000 zombie foreclosures in Q2, Florida accounted for nearly a third of the
nation's total.

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact:    editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                              68 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                          South Bend Tribune (Indiana)

                     June 4, 2002 Tuesday Marshall Edition

Building to get new roof;
Commissioners also hear request from county treasurer for measure to improve
collection of tardy personal property taxes.

BYLINE: By JENNIFER MACK; Tribune Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. D1

LENGTH: 500 words


PLYMOUTH -- The Marshall County Building will get a new $60,216 roof later this
month.

The Marshall County Board of Commissioners approved a bid from Slatile Roofing
in South Bend to put the new roof on the building the week of June 17.

The building was constructed more than 20 years ago, and according to county
Maintenance Superintendent Mike Rooney, the roof has never been replaced.

The commissioners also hired Mike Strang, of the Plymouth engineering firm
Strang and Associates, to oversee the project when Rooney is unavailable to
inspect the work. He told the commissioners Slatile Roofing will work out of the
parking lot north of the county building. The parking lot, he said, likely will
be roped off.

Strang also said Slatile's bid was lowest in a range from about $60,000 to
$80,000 to replace the roof.

In other business, the commissioners said they would consider a request by
Treasurer Penny Lukenbill to pass a personal property demand ordinance.
Lukenbill said she does not have an effective mechanism to collect delinquent
personal property tax.

Personal property, she said, includes items such as snowmobiles.

She said she can notify the owner after one year that delinquent taxes are owed.
Then she could certify a judgment against the taxpayer in the clerk's office,
she explained.

"Most (cases) just quietly die," she said, noting that many delinquent taxpayers
have since moved away without a forwarding address, leaving her no way to track
them down.

In 2001, she said, her office showed that $76,800 in personal property taxes
were delinquent. As of Monday, she said, $60,750 of that is still uncollected.

According to Lukenbill, if the commissioners pass her proposed ordinance, she
would be able to publish the delinquent taxpayer's name in the newspaper. She
said this would help notify the taxpayers they are delinquent if she has been
unable to find them.

Also, Lukenbill explained, she believes printing the names of delinquent
taxpayers in the paper could also act as a deterrent. She said printing the
names of those who are delinquent paying their real estate taxes has been
effective.

"People will do anything to keep their names out of the paper. Plus it will
increase our chances of notification," Lukenbill said.

She said Rush County, Ind., has instituted the personal property tax demand
ordinance and has increased collections.

Also Monday, Marshall County Sheriff Bob Ruff indicated he would work with an
Argos man, Tom Smith, and not require that he remove several abandoned vehicles
on his property at the request of a neighbor.

Smith runs a car restoration business and has several cars on the property in
open view.

Ruff said since Smith is trying to rectify the situation, he will allow Smith
time to get the necessary variance to run a business on his property, as well as
put up a fence so that the cars are not visible to the public.

Staff writer Jennifer Mack:

jmack@sbtinfo.com

(574) 936-2921

LOAD-DATE: June 10, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                 Copyright 2002 South Bend Tribune Corporation


                              69 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          December 25, 2013 Wednesday

BRIEF: Sinnott: Garbage-bill delinquents could see their names posted on city
website

BYLINE: Kevin Flowers, Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 213 words


Dec. 25--The city of Erie might take a different approach to try to collect more
than $2 million in delinquent garbage fees -- listing the names of those who
haven't paid on the Internet.

Mayor Joe Sinnott said adding a database to the city's website, www.erie.pa.us
-- which would include the names of people delinquent on their garbage bills and
the amounts they owe -- "is one thing we have talked about doing" in 2014.

City Council President Jim Winarski said he supports the move.

The approach is similar to one the city of Scranton took earlier this year, when
it created a searchable, online database of past-due garbage bill accounts.

That city is trying to collect nearly $8 million in overdue garbage bills.

"My thought is that it would include those who get behind by a year or more,"
Sinnott said. "Those are the most seriously delinquent people. It's not the
people who miss a payment and quickly catch up."

Sinnott's proposed $69.7 million city budget for 2014, approved by Erie City
Council on Dec. 18, included increases in city residents' garbage and sewer
fees. The fee hikes meant $3.1 million in new money for the spending plan.

                          Reading Eagle (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             October 5, 2012 Friday

5 teens found delinquent in melee at alternative education school

BYLINE: Holly Herman, Reading Eagle, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 355 words


Oct. 05--Five Reading juveniles were found delinquent Thursday in Berks County
Juvenile Court on riot charges for participating in a Sept. 21 melee in an
alternative education school in the city.

Two others were found delinquent of disorderly conduct for their roles in the
melee at Delaware Valley High School, 905 Margaret St.

Judge Scott E. Lash ordered five of the teens to remain in the Abraxas juvenile
detention center in New Morgan. The others were released to relatives pending
disposition of their cases.

Juvenile law allows authorities to provide supervision until the offender turns
21. Lash ordered all seven not to return to school.

Investigators said they were called to the school to break up a melee at 8:45
a.m. that broke out because 10 boys had been suspended the day before for
vandalism and refused to leave the school cafeteria.

They said the seven students were interfering with the school authorities'
attempts to remove the students and became unruly.

Those found delinquent on riot charges are Natasha M. Kuilan, 17; Madyson A.
Thomas, 17; Omari Carrion, 16; Jose Medina, 16; and Christian Perez, 14.

Kuilan was allowed to remain free to take care of her 11/2-year-old daughter,
pending disposition of her case.

The others will stay in Abraxas.

Rhepeeq Bland, 14, pleaded guilty to disorderly conduct and was placed on
probation and ordered to attend an evening treatment program. He was also
ordered to perform 40 hours of community service.

Jesse Fleming, 14, also pleaded guilty to disorderly conduct and was ordered to
remain in detention.

Assistant District Attorney Catherine Nadirov said the 14-year-olds were
disrespectful to police, and officers needed 11/2 hours to get the students off
the property.

Delaware Valley High School is operated by a Philadelphia-based organization
that the city district contracts with for alternative education.

The school opened Aug. 27 in the former Gateway magnet school.

Contact Holly Herman: 610-478-6291 or hherman@readingeagle.com

Pa.) at readingeagle.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

-in-melee-at-alternative-education-school-1005-20121005

                          Copyright 2012 Reading Eagle


                              71 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                March 20, 1984, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

TAX AMNESTY, TAX HONESTY

SECTION: Section A; Page 22, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 362 words


Honesty may be the best policy, but amnesty is giving it a good run among state
tax collectors. Impressed by Massachusetts' recent revenue windfall, Governor
Cuomo wants to try it in New York. It's a gimmick.

Tax amnesties, as recently practiced by a half- dozen states, don't excuse all
unpaid taxes, but they do forgive penalties, interest and possible prosecution.
There are several arguments in favor of doing so. Some are practical. For
instance, amnesties boost revenues and also flush some delinquents. Other
arguments are philosophical. Amnesties provide a humane way for delinquents to
wipe their slates clean. Amnesties are politically appealing. Every dollar they
smoke out is a dollar less needed in taxes.

But amnesties are bad tax policy. They penalize the great majority of honest
taxpayers who've had to pay more taxes all along because delinquents weren't
paying their share. They're a confession of weakness, acknowledging that the
system can't collect what it should, thus further eroding confidence in its
fairness. They invite noncompliance. If the revenuers grant forgiveness once,
people will be encouraged to expect further amnesties in the future - which is
just what has happened in Italy.  The revenue results are mixed, and there's a
carrot-and-stick lesson in the difference. Massachusetts attracted attention by
permitting delinquents to come in for three months, after enacting rigorous new
penalties, beefing up enforcement and warning delinquents that if they didn't
take advantage of the amnesty, they'd really get it in the neck. It collected
$54 million - far more than expected. But Missouri engaged in no such
preliminaries. Few delinquents bothered to declare, and the state collected less
than $1 million.  In New York, Governor Cuomo wants to copy Massachusetts,
putting together a package of stiff penalties and audits that he'll propose to
the Legislature. Only after that becomes law would amnesty be tried.  Even so,
the idea rankles. If there has to be an amnesty, at least don't let it become a
free ride. Forgive the penalties, but make the delinquents pay interest on the
money they've been delinquent with.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: EDITORIAL

                   Copyright 1984 The New York Times Company


                              72 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                            The Blade (Toledo, Ohio)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            December 21, 2012 Friday

BRIEF: Delinquent mortgages fall below 6% in area

BYLINE: The Blade, Toledo, Ohio

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 97 words


Dec. 21--The percentage of Toledo-area mortgage loans that were 90 or more days
delinquent has fallen below 6 percent for the first time since April, 2009,
according to CoreLogic, a California real estate data firm.

CoreLogic said that in October, 5.95 percent of mortgage loans were 90 days or
more delinquent. That compares to 6.07 percent in September and 6.51 percent in
October of 2011. The rate was above 7 percent for the first six months of 2010.

                              74 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        Contra Costa Times (California)

                             January 2, 2011 Sunday

Foreclosure process moves at snail's pace

BYLINE: By Marcie Geffner bankrate.com

SECTION: REAL ESTATE; Business

LENGTH: 704 words


Six hundred days. That's how long, on average, mortgage loans in the foreclosure
process in New York have been delinquent.

That's the longest average in the nation, but not by much, according to LPS
Applied Analytics, in Jacksonville, Fla. Loans in foreclosure in Florida, New
Jersey, Hawaii and Maine have been delinquent more than 500 days, on average,
while home loans in California and Nevada have been delinquent 461 and 427 days,
respectively. In the two speediest states, Nebraska and Wyoming, loans in the
foreclosure process are delinquent by an average of 358 days.

Those statistics raise a question: Why do foreclosures take so long?

Some states use a judicial process. The causes of delays in judicial foreclosure
states include backlogged courts, antiquated systems and judges' schedules, says
Shari Olefson, an attorney with Fowler White Boggs in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and
author of "Foreclosure Nation," a book about the subprime mortgage crisis.

In one case, Olefson says, "We went down for the hearing and the judge said,
that morning, you are moved to (another) judge, and we went to that judge, and
the earliest hearing date he has is April."

The problem may be most severe in Florida, which has the highest number of
foreclosures in the country, according to Rick Sharga, senior vice president at
RealtyTrac, a foreclosure information service in Irvine. The backlog in Florida
has been so severe that the state has set up separate courts and brought in
retired judges to handle foreclosure cases.

Government officials and agencies cause delays through temporary moratoriums,
mandatory mediation sessions and loan modification or assistance programs such
as the federal Home Affordable Modification Program, or HAMP.

Mortgage servicers -- the companies that process monthly payments -- have been
equally ill-equipped to handle the large volume of foreclosures. While it may
seem counterintuitive, they have reasons to drag their feet:

Servicers' philosophies and directives are "constantly in flux," Olefson says.
One may need to raise cash to meet regulatory guidelines, while another may have
too much inventory of unsold real estate on its books. Staid corporate cultures
and high staff turnover contribute to slow decision-making.

Servicers don't want to take on the legal and financial responsibilities of
owning more homes. As soon as the foreclosure is completed, the lender
"immediately assumes liability and carrying costs," Sharga says. Examples of
such costs include property taxes, casualty insurance, repairs and maintenance,
and homeowner association dues.

Lenders are loath to write off losses on unpaid loans.

"Foreclosure typically isn't making a profit, it's minimizing a loss. It's hard
to get the (investors) who own the notes excited about spending more money to
execute a foreclosure," Sharga says. "Ironically, the longer these things take,
the more it costs."

Lenders securitized and sold many of their loans to investors, whose objectives
may conflict. One investor may want to foreclose quickly and take the cash,
Sharga says, while another might want to keep the loan and pressure the borrower
to resume the payments. Disagreements lead to process paralysis.

Lenders may be especially unwilling to negotiate settlements with borrowers who
own expensive homes and are believed to have fraudulently hidden other assets in
offshore bank accounts, Olefson says.

"The banks are a lot less likely to settle because their feeling is that (the
borrower) has assets somewhere or will have assets," she says.

A rumor, whether true or not, that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. may take
over a lender can cause disruptions and delays, Olefson says. Lenders, investors
and borrowers alike tend to think they'll get a better loan workout deal if the
government agency steps in, but that's a "complete misconception," she says.

Years ago, foreclosures usually were uncontested, but today, homeowners are more
likely to hire a foreclosure attorney to stall the outcome, Olefson says.

Bankruptcy and other court filings can delay a foreclosure, but such actions may
be costly for the borrower. Default interest, force-placed insurance, property
taxes and legal fees can all end up on the borrower's account.

LOAD-DATE: January 2, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC:

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                     Copyright 2011 Contra Costa Newspapers
                              All Rights Reserved


                              75 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                       San Jose Mercury News (California)

                             January 2, 2011 Sunday

Foreclosure process moves at snail's pace

BYLINE: By Marcie Geffner bankrate.com

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 704 words


Six hundred days. That's how long, on average, mortgage loans in the foreclosure

over a lender can cause disruptions and delays, Olefson says. Lenders, investors
and borrowers alike tend to think they'll get a better loan workout deal if the
government agency steps in, but that's a "complete misconception," she says.

Years ago, foreclosures usually were uncontested, but today, homeowners are more
likely to hire a foreclosure attorney to stall the outcome, Olefson says.

Bankruptcy and other court filings can delay a foreclosure, but such actions may
be costly for the borrower. Default interest, force-placed insurance, property
taxes and legal fees can all end up on the borrower's account.

                         Hays Free Press (Buda, Texas)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any

                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                October 6, 2010

Montgomery judge owes big Hays bill;
DELINQUENT

BYLINE: BY JENNIFER BIUND0

LENGTH: 240  words


Montgomery County Judge Alan Sadler is attempting to pay off more than $50,000
in delinquent tax debt to Hays County, part of $300,000 in unpaid taxes that
Sadler and his business partner have amassed over the last two years throughout
the state.

Under the name of Development II Partners Inc., Sadler and his business partner
Aslam Kapadia own On the Run convenience store at IH-35 and Wonder World Drive.
The business owes $41,253 in delinquent taxes on the real property account and
$9,549 on personal property, said Hays County Tax Assessor-Collector Luanne
Caraway. The taxes are owed to Hays County, San Marcos ISD, the city of San
Marcos and a road district.

Taxes for the previous year come due on Jan. 31, and the county initiates legal
action against delinquent properly owners after July 1, Caraway said. Typically,
about two percent of property tax owed to the county is delinquent or unpaid.

The McCreary law firm filed a lawsuit seeking back taxes for the real property,
or land and buildings on behalf of Starting balance: $29,617

Total contributions: $40,085

Total expenditures: $22,683

In the bank as of Oct. 4: $46,319

Cobb Fendly PAC, Austin, $300

Lloyd Doggett, Austin, $1,000

Mitch and Betsy Taylor, Houston,

$1,000

Scott Polikov, Fort Worth, $1,000

Joe Phillips, McAllen, $5,000

James Farr, Dripping Springs, $500

Bob Gregory, Austin, $500

Nancy Ledbetter, Pflugerville, $200

John and Hope Sanford, Buda,

$250

                              77 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                      Pharos-Tribune (Logansport, Indiana)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                           September 3, 2015 Thursday

County tax sale coming Sept. 9

BYLINE: Pharos-Tribune, Logansport, Ind.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 238 words


Sept. 03--Cass County will conduct a tax sale on Wednesday, Sept. 9, for
delinquent properties that have delinquent taxes and special assessments due
from the prior year's spring installment.

In Indiana, the county treasurer and auditor are required to sell tax liens on
delinquent properties that remain unpaid from the prior year's spring
installment. Cass County will offer the tax sale certificates at a public sale
that is not less than the total amount due in delinquent taxes, costs and
penalties.

In addition to serving as a source for local governments to collect unpaid
property taxes, tax sales also serve as an opportunity for real estate investors
to earn interest income upon redemption of the property within one year from the
sale, or to take title to the property though a post-tax sale process that
involves petitioning the local court for a tax deed.

Cass County has contracted with SRI Inc., an Indianapolis-based company founded
in 1989 that conducts tax sales, commissioners' certificate sales and
commissioners' deed sales over 80 counties in Indiana, Michigan and Colorodo.

Persons interested in registering and bidding at the Cass County Tax Sale should
visit the SRI Inc. website at www.sri-taxsale.com and read the information
regarding tax sales.

___ (c)2015 the Pharos-Tribune (Logansport, Ind.) Visit the Pharos-Tribune
(Logansport, Ind.) at www.pharostribune.com Distributed by Tribune Content
Agency, LLC.

                              78 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                    November 3, 1987, Tuesday, Final Edition

Md. Collects $ 25 Million In Amnesty;
10,000 People, Firms Pay Delinquent Taxes

BYLINE: Eugene L. Meyer, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: METRO; PAGE B1

LENGTH: 739 words


Maryland's carrot-and-stick tax amnesty ended last night after paying handsome
dividends to the state. Delinquent people and corporations came forward and paid
more than $ 25 million, easily exceeding the goal for the two-month program.

The 10,000 delinquent taxpayers ranged from a multinational corporation that
wrote a check for $ 2.7 million, to a 21-year-old custom cabinet maker from
Temple Hills, who paid $ 700 he said he owed for 1985. The smallest payment was
20 cents for unpaid sales tax.

People accounted for 80 percent to 85 percent of the checks and returns
submitted, but corporations provided 70 percent of the funds received, according
to Assistant State Comptroller Marvin Bond.

Maryland was the latest of several states and the District of Columbia --
starting with Massachusetts in 1982 -- to go after back taxes with the promise
that civil and criminal penalties would be waived, and the threat that they
would be stiffened after the deadline.

Starting today, delinquent Maryland taxpayers will be subject to stiffer
criminal penalties, up to five years in prison and a $ 5,000 fine for each
count, compared with the one year and $ 1,000 previously in effect. Furthermore,
civil penalties will increase from 10 percent to 25 percent of taxes owed.

Comptroller Louis L. Goldstein said his office would begin withholding checks
from firms doing business with the state, if they are delinquent in their taxes.
A sophisticated new computer and 36 more auditors will also be employed to beef
up the state's enforcement.

To encourage corporate compliance, the state in recent years has used retired
Internal Revenue Service auditors based in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles to
review company returns and to develop and follow up investigative leads. State
officials would not identify delinquent taxpayers.

Amnesty payments were no windfall of surplus funds for the state. The governor
had already committed the $ 20 million in his 1987 budget. By last night, the
Maryland program had brought in $ 25.1 million. Of the total, $ 9 million came
from out-of-state taxpayers, including $ 1 million from the District.

Within the state, Montgomery County was producing the largest amount of revenue,
more than $ 2 million. A Montgomery County taxpayer's check for $ 10,000,
representing five years of delinquent income taxes, pushed the state total over
$ 20 million, according to Bond.

"We're very well satisfied," said Bond, who, with Goldstein, toured the state to
promote the program. "The end of September, we hadn't heard from Garrett
County," the westernmost in the state. "Three days after we got back from there,
checks started coming in."

The state spent $ 375,000 to advertise the program. But at least one
advertisement, noting that 1920s mobster Al Capone had gone to jail for tax
evasion, was canceled after some Italian Americans in Baltimore criticized it as
an ethnic slur.

Another widely circulated advertisement showed a picture of cocky but ill-fated
Indian fighter Gen. George Custer with the legend: "Custer was sure to beat the
Indians. Are you sure you can beat Maryland out of back taxes?"

According to Bond, the state sought to learn from the failures and successes of
amnesty programs elsewhere. The most successful -- among them Illinois,
Massachusetts, California -- advertised and stiffened penalties. But some
states, such as New York, allowed for installment payments, slowing the incoming
cash flow.

Massachusetts brought in more than $ 40 million in its pioneering effort. New
York and New York City combined brought in 10 times as much. The District's
three-month amnesty program, which ended Sept. 30, was said by city officials to
have brought in around $ 10 million.

At the New Carrollton state tax office yesterday, six persons were sitting in
the hallway when office manager Virginia Shaw opened for business at 8:30 a.m.
By 1:30 p.m., 99 persons had visited the office and 15 of them were waiting in
the small reception room to meet with state auditors.

Almost all of them declined to give their names, but several offered anonymous
explanations. One man, 39, said he owed $ 3,000 in taxes for the years he lived
in Maryland and worked in Virginia.

"It's always been in the back on my mind," he said. "I've never done a dishonest
thing in my life. I have a 22-month-old I have to tell to do the right thing all
his life, so it was a matter of conscience."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: MARYLAND NEWS

                       Copyright 1987 The Washington Post


                              79 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                              Daily The Pak Banker

                            October 8, 2013 Tuesday

Average debt rose 17 percent between 2007 and 2012

LENGTH: 278  words

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif


The average debt held by consumers who are behind in their debt repayments rose
17 percent between 2007 and 2012, as per data released by FICO.

FICO is a leading predictive analytics and decision management software company.
The mean total debt for consumers who were 60+ days delinquent on at least one
account grew from $53,706 (adjusted for  inflation) in October 2007 to $62,642
in October 2012, fuelled largely by student loan debt and mortgage debt.

Andrew Jennings, chief analytics officer at FICO and head of FICO Labs, said,
"This is a tale of two Americas. Most Americans have deleveraged, bringing their
total debt down, but debt loads have risen for the one in five Americans who
have problems making payments. Ultimately it is up to the lenders and debt
collectors to tailor their approaches to different consumers in order to
increase their yield, and help customers get back on track."

The biggest rise occurred in student loan debt, which jumped 89 percent over the
five-year period for delinquent consumers. By contrast, the mean student loan
debt rose 58 percent for consumers who were not 60+ days delinquent on any
accounts. For delinquent consumers, the amount owed on student loans in October
2012 was also 66 percent higher than for non-delinquent consumers.

The mean mortgage loan debt was 14 percent higher in 2012 for delinquent
consumers, whereas it fell by 22 percent for non-delinquent consumers. An even
greater discrepancy occurs for all other credit (not including student loans,
credit cards, mortgages or auto loans): the average debt rose 61 percent among
delinquent consumers, whereas it fell by 28 percent among non-delinquent
consumers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              80 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            August 17, 2013 Saturday

Missouri: SB 248

LENGTH: 730  words

DATELINE: Jefferson City


Office of the Missouri House of Representatives has issued the following bill:

This act modifies provisions relating to property taxes.

NOTICE OF NEIGHBORHOOD IMPROVEMENT DISTRICTS

Section 67.457

This act requires the county or city clerk of the governing body creating a
neighborhood improvement district (NID) to file a notice with the recorder of
deeds in the county where the land is located. Such notice shall contain the
following information: each owner of property in the NID listed as a grantor,
the governing body establishing the NID listed as a grantee, a legal description
of the NID, and the identifying number or a copy of the ordinance creating the
NID.

This provision is similar to HB 980 (2013). This provision is similar to a
provision contained in SCS/HCS/HB 161 (2013), HCS/HB 175 (2013), SCS/HB 568
(2013), CCS#2/SCS/HCS/HB 1035 (2013), and SCS/SB 83 (2013).

NEIGHBORHOOD IMPROVEMENT DISTRICTS SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS

Currently, the Boone County collector is authorized to collect a fee when
collecting special assessments for NIDs. This act allows the Jackson County
collector to also collect this fee. (Section 67.463)

This act also expands the existing law that allows liens against property to be
foreclosed for failure to pay NID special assessments, so that certain first
class counties, charter counties, and the city of St. Louis may also foreclose
on these liens by a land tax sale under the provisions of law that govern land
tax sales in those counties. (Section 67.469)

These provisions are similar to SB 138 (2013), HB 104 (2013), and HB 568 (2013).
These provisions are similar to provisions contained in HCS/HB 74 (2013), HCS/HB
161 (2013), HCS/HB 175 (2013), HB 197 (2013), SCS/HCS/HB 1035 (2013), SCS/SB 83
(2013), SS/SCS/HB 1170 (2012) and SS/SCS/HCS/HB 1865 (2012).

DELINQUENT PROPERTY TAXES

Despite contrary provisions of law, currently the county collector in Boone
County is authorized to add special assessments levied for community improvement
districts to the annual real estate tax bills for the properties being
benefitted by the district. Unpaid special assessments on the first day of
January are considered delinquent and enforcement of the delinquent bills is
governed by the laws concerning delinquent and back taxes. A lien may be
foreclosed in the same manner as a tax upon real property by land tax sales.
This act allows these provisions to apply to any county. (Section 67.1521)

This act allows county collectors to deliver an electronic copy of the back tax
book. (Section 140.050)

This act specifies that when property taxes are delinquent, if a person other
than the owner or a lienholder pays the original property taxes plus interest
without the knowledge and consent of the owner, that payment will not invoke a
lien on the property or person. (Section 140.115)

Currently, county collectors are authorized to use procedures for selling
property when the property taxes are delinquent and when special assessments for
Neighborhood Improvement Districts are delinquent. This act gives collectors the
option to use these procedures when other types of special assessments are
delinquent. (Section 140.150 & 140.160)

When real estate is sold for delinquent taxes or other debt, if the property
sells for a greater amount than the debt, the additional money is placed in a
trust fund for the owners of the property for three years. This act specifies
that if the funds are not called for as part of a redemption or collector's deed
issuance, then they become part of the permanent school fund of the county.
(Section 140.230)

The act eliminates specific language authorizing fees of twenty-five and fifty
cents that the county collector is authorized to collect when recording a
certificate of purchase of land sold at a tax sale. The collector will continue
to be authorized to receive the fee necessary to record the certificate of
purchase. The act also eliminates language authorizing a one dollar and fifty
cent fee for certain tax deeds. (Sections 140.290 & 140.470)

The act also removes a requirement that the county clerk witness the county
collector sign the deed given to someone who purchases property at a tax sale.
(Section 140.460)

These provisions are similar to HB 175 (2013) and SB 83 (2013). These provisions
are similar to provisions contained in HCS/HB 74 (2013).

For further information please visit: http://house.mo.gov/

                      The Times-Tribune (Corbin, Kentucky)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           August 26, 2009 Wednesday

Knox County adds nearly $1 million to budget

BYLINE: Carl Keith Greene, The Times-Tribune, Corbin, Ky.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 295 words


Aug. 26--Knox County's fiscal court added $935,000 of unexpected funds to next
year's budget at its meeting Tuesday.

It also acknowledged the collection of about $267,000 in tax collections,
delinquent and otherwise.

The report from County Attorney Charley Greene Dixon showed collections of
$11,636 in 2007 delinquent taxes.

$62,000 was collected from the sheriff's sale of delinquent taxes and $194,000
collected by selling delinquent taxes to a company called Tax Ease, of Houston,
Texas.

Delinquent taxes that have been sold can be redeemed by the property owner by
paying 12 percent in interest and processing fees.

If the taxes aren't redeemed in a stated time frame, the owner of the delinquent
taxes may foreclose on the property and sell it.

In other business, the court allowed Laurel County Water District No. 2 to lay
water lines along the roadsides where Laurel and Knox counties meet.

The lines will bring water to residents of Knox County near the county line.

The court also approved cost of living raises at the Knox Detention Center by
five percent and adding $1 per hour to the pay of new employees who were hired
more than a year ago and were promised that they would get the raise after they
had worked at the jail for a year.

And the court accepted a petition to revert the name of Gray Cox Cemetery Road
to simply Gray Cemetery Road.

To see more of The Times-Tribune or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.thetimestribune.com/. Copyright (c) 2009, The Times-Tribune, Corbin,
Ky. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                           October 14, 2015 Wednesday

NY Fed Examines Regional Debt in Collections, Delinquency Rates

BYLINE: Darren Waggoner

SECTION: CCR - CREDIT CARD Vol. 1 No. 1

LENGTH: 367  words


The Federal Reserve Bank of New York's latest regional look at debt in
third-party collections, consumers' delinquency rates and credit card and
student loan debt focused on three Eastern states.

The report revealed that the rate of overall consumer distress - meaning loan
payments 90 or more days late or debt in third-party collections in the last 12
months - is lower in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut compared to overall
U.S. figures.

Connecticut has the highest average balances on mortgages and student loans and
the lowest levels of delinquency, according to the Fed.

The average student loan balances for the three states range from $31,000 to
more than $32,000, compared to $29,000 nationwide. The average credit card
balances range from $5,800 to $6,200, compared to $6,200 nationwide.

An estimated 16% of consumers in New Jersey have some debt listed as seriously
delinquent or in third-party collections compared to 20% in the U.S. New York
and Connecticut (both at 14.8%) have even lower consumer distress rates.

The Fed's Regional Household Debt and Credit Snapshot, released Wednesday, is
the second in a series ofÂ regional reports on debt and credit. The report is
designed to include data about mortgages, student loans, credit cards, auto
loans and delinquencies for New York City and its boroughs, as well as various
metro areas in New York State, northern New Jersey and western Connecticut.Â

The April snapshot was comprised of 27 reports, and the reports in the most
recent snapshot are current as of June.

A breakdown of delinquency rates for the three states includes:

New Jersey

     ·    13.6% of borrowers are seriously delinquent on their student loans,
          compared to 16.3% nationwide.
     ·    8.3% of borrowers are seriously delinquent on their credit cards,
          compared to 8.5% nationwide.


Connecticut

     ·    13.1%Â of borrowers are seriously delinquent on their student loans,
          compared to 16.3%Â nationwide.
     ·    7.7%Â of borrowers are seriously delinquent on their credit cards,
          compared to 8.5%Â nationwide.


New York

     ·    12.6%Â of borrowers are seriously delinquent on their student loans,
          compared to 16.3%Â nationwide.
     ·    8.2%Â of borrowers are seriously delinquent on their credit cards,
          compared to 8.5%Â nationwide.

                              83 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                            Mortgage Servicing News

                                  January 2011

Servicers to Watch for More Seriously Delinquent Borrowers

BYLINE: Amilda Dymi

SECTION: MANAGING REO; Pg. 11 Vol. 15 No. 1

LENGTH: 642  words


Research throughout the recession shows the financial vulnerability of
delinquent consumers has worsened and is bound to push these borrowers into even
more severe stages of delinquency.

The trend is shaped by economic and behavioral factors fueled by still-dropping
house prices and high unemployment.

According to TransUnion, the number of consumers "rolling" their delinquency
status on mortgage payments from 30 to 60 and 60 to 90 days past due peaked in
July 2009.

A recent TransUnion study found that 24.4% of consumers who were 30 days past
due on their mortgage payments in June 2009 became 60 days past due in July
2009. At the same time 37.6% of consumers 60 days delinquent on their mortgage
payments became 90 days late.

It specifically examined roll rates for nondelinquent accounts that went 30 days
past due, accounts moving from 30 to 60 days past due and those accounts going
from 60 to 90 days past due. After analyzing information from a pool of data
between March 2006 and December 2009, which is the period that encompassed the
entire recession that began in December 2007 and ended in June 2009, TransUnion
reaffirmed industry findings that the all-time high overall foreclosure
inventory will go further up, not down.

Lender Processing Services Inc., Jacksonville, Fla., reports that by the end of
October 2010 the total U.S. foreclosure inventory rate reached 3.92%, which
equals 7.4 times the historical averages and continues to rise despite an
improvement in the monthly rate.

Even though in October only 263,000 loans entered the foreclosure process,
declining 4.4% month-over-month, the total inventory of foreclosures is nearly
2.1 million loans, while another 2.2 million loans are seriously delinquent or
over 90 days past due, but not yet in foreclosure status.

When including a loan delinquency rate of 9.29% the total U.S. noncurrent loan
rate that combines foreclosures and delinquencies as a percent of active loans
increases to 13.2%.

More than anything "the widespread moratoria" further extended the average
number of days past delinquent for loans in foreclosure to a number approaching
500 days.

Foreclosure activity changes include increases in the number of loans six to 12
months delinquent. However, as more of these loans are moving to foreclosure the
number of loans that are extremely delinquent or over 12 months past due
"continues to grow and age" but still are not in foreclosure.

LPS reports that currently a payment has not been made in more than one year on
almost one-third of all loans that are 90 or more days delinquent. Another 18%
are seriously delinquent loans also still not in foreclosure on which payments
have not been made in two years.

TransUnion found an "interesting dynamic" in the early-stage roll rates in
California.

Current 30-day roll rates in that state remained well below the national average
in delinquency levels except from the roll rates from 30 days past due and
onward which "were significantly worse in California than for the nation."

For example, in December 2007, only 0.58% of current accounts rolled to 30 days
past due in California while for the nation at large it was 0.79%; yet the
state's 30- to 60-day roll rate that same month was 27.15%, compared to the
national average of 17.12%.

Serious mortgage delinquency in California is one of the highest in the nation
and at nearly twice the national average and in line with analysts'
expectations.

So while Californians appear to be less likely to enter delinquency with their
mortgages, "once they do they are more likely to fall into severe delinquency"
due to disproportionately higher monthly mortgage payments relative to incomes
given the fact that the recession has made it "far more difficult" for
California consumers to recover from delinquency, says FJ Guarrera, vice
president of TransUnion's financial services.

URL: http://www.mortgageservicingnews.com/

                          South Bend Tribune (Indiana)

                             October 6, 2006 Friday
                                Marshall Edition

Properties auctioned;
Delinquent taxpayers have a year to redeem properties.

BYLINE: By NANCY J. SULOK, Tribune Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 491 words


SOUTH BEND -- St. Joseph County Treasurer Sean Coleman was both relieved and
satisfied Thursday night as the auction of tax-delinquent properties drew to an
end.

More than 1,800 properties were on the sales list, and some of them sold for
substantially more than the amount of taxes due.

Coleman said he likely would have a final tally of income some time today.

Although successful bidders were required to pay the money by later today, the
county cannot really spend it right away.

Delinquent taxpayers have a full year to recover the property. Bidders Thursday
actually were purchasing liens on the properties.

In order to redeem a property, the delinquent payer has to pay the amount of
taxes due, plus a 10 percent penalty. The penalty jumps to 15 percent after six
months.

On top of that, he has to pay interest to the purchaser calculated at 10 percent
per annum on the difference between the taxes and the successful bid.

For example, one property had taxes due of $3,147, and it sold for $14,000. If
the owner tried to redeem it today, he would have to pay a penalty of $314.

Then he would have to pay the purchaser a prorated interest of 10 percent on
$10,853, the difference between $14,000 and $3,147.

That makes the sale attractive for investors, since a 10 percent return is
better than most other investments in today's market.

Several out-of-town investment groups each bought dozens of properties at
Thursday's sale.

One was Roger Becks of Birmingham, Ala., who declined to identify the client he
was bidding for.

He said his employer, "an institutional investor,'' was interested in 150
properties, all of which had houses or commercial structures on them. He was the
successful bidder on about half of them, he said.

If the original owners do not redeem them after a year, the bidder becomes the
new owner. He then can sell it, often at a nice profit.

The sale attracted a large crowd Thursday morning.

Just as it was getting under way, Assistant Fire Chief Howard Buchanon paid a
visit in response to a complaint that too many people were packed into the
council chambers and spilling into the lobby on the fourth floor of the
County-City Building.

The room has a capacity of 155, but at least twice that number attended the
start of the sale.

Buchanon informed the organizers that too many people were on hand.

"We got busted,'' said auctioneer James Hughes, of Synergistic Resource
Integration, the company hired to run the tax sale.

A rearrangement of the crowd then took place. People interested in properties
far down the list were asked to step outside the chambers until the auctioneer
got close to their intended purchase. Those in the lobby were admonished to keep
the doorways clear.

"I appreciate you folks cooperating with this,'' Hughes said.

The auctioneers worked their way through the list, wrapping up at 6:45 p.m.
After a short break, they reopened the bidding for some of the properties that
had not sold on the first go-around.

LOAD-DATE: October 6, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Brian Gathen, of South Bend, scans a list of properties being offered
for sale Thursday at St. Joseph County's property tax sale, conducted in the
County-City Building. Successful bidders received a lien on the property, and
the delinquent taxpayer has a year to redeem it by paying the sale price plus
penalties. Tribune Photo/SHAYNA BRESLIN

                            The Blade (Toledo, Ohio)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             March 26, 2013 Tuesday

BRIEF: Delinquent mortgages in area drop slightly

BYLINE: The Blade, Toledo, Ohio

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 111 words


March 26--The percentage of mortgage loans in the Toledo area that were at least
90 days delinquent dropped slightly in January, according to California-based
CoreLogic.

The percentage dropped from 5.96 percent in December to 5.9 percent in January.
A year earlier, the rate was 6.69 percent.

January was the fourth consecutive month the rate was below 6 percent. Before
October, it hadn't been below 6 percent since April, 2009.

Statewide, almost 6.5 percent of mortgage loans were 90 days delinquent;
nationally, the rate was 6.34 percent.

                              86 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                    September 2, 1997, Tuesday, ALL EDITIONS

Private firm may buy Fulton tax liens;
'60-day letters' have been mailed to delinquent taxpayers warning them they have
until Oct. 19 to pay property taxes or their debt will be purchased.

BYLINE: Carlos Campos; STAFF WRITER

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. 01D

LENGTH: 562 words


In late October, Fulton County, the city of Atlanta and their school boards
could be as much as $ 50 million richer, and they will barely have to lift a
finger for the money.

Capital Asset Research Corp., a West Palm Beach, Fla.-based company with a
Buckhead office, has sent thousands of letters warning delinquent taxpayers in
Fulton County to pay their property taxes within 60 days.

If they don't, the company intends to buy their debt from the county, with the
prospect of eventually foreclosing.

Citing competitive reasons, John "Buddy" Ramsey, Capital Asset's vice president
in Atlanta, declined to say how many letters his company sent out, or what the
value to Fulton County will be. The company is not required to divulge that
information to the county, either.

Ramsey would only offer this: "Hopefully, we can purchase up to $ 50 million
worth of delinquent taxes by the end of the year."

The so-called "60-day letters" are the first step in a complicated process
required under Georgia law to purchase someone else's delinquent property tax
lien. In this case, the clock for the delinquent taxpayers runs out Oct. 19,
according to officials in the Fulton County tax commissioner's office.

If a delinquent property tax owner does not pay county taxes owed within that
60-day period, Capital Asset can buy the debt. At that point, the company pays
Fulton County the amount owed. Proceeds are split among Fulton County, the city
of Atlanta, and their school boards. The city of East Point and the state of
Georgia will also get a small share

The collection of the taxes then becomes the responsibility of Capital Asset
---which then adds a slew of administrative fees and interest costs to the debt.
If the taxes still are not paid after 365 days, Capital Asset can then move to
foreclose on the property and have it auctioned on the courthouse steps.

Fulton County is owed $ 130.9 million in delinquent real and personal property
taxes. The debt had reached $ 208 million when Fulton County Tax Commissioner
Arthur Ferdinand took office in January, but he has used aggressive measures
since then to collect more than $ 77 million.

Tom Biggers, Ferdinand's chief of delinquent tax collections, said the pursuit
of taxes by a third party has the effect of increasing collections for his
office during the 60-day period from taxpayers hoping to avoid having to deal
with a private company less sympathetic to delinquents.

"Historically, it generates payments in the neighborhood of 25 percent to 30
percent of the total amount mailed through 60-day letters," Biggers said. "It
does generate payments."

That means of the estimated $ 50 million, Fulton County could collect as much as
$ 15 million before Oct. 19.

Capital Asset's latest move follows a failed attempt in June to purchase more
than $ 82 million in delinquent tax liens.

The company had wanted to purchase the county's delinquent liens in bulk through
a contract, but the sale failed to clear the County Commission.

The bulk sale allows companies to receive up to a 10 percent discount on the tax
lien's costs.

Capital Asset officials later vowed to simply "cherry pick" the delinquent
parcels they wanted through the 60-day letter method, picking the best
properties. That does not require a vote of the Fulton County Commission, but
does not allow for a discount.

LOAD-DATE: September 3, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                    Copyright 1997 The Atlanta Constitution


                              87 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                   The Times-Tribune (Scranton, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             July 24, 2010 Saturday

Dunmore Council pursuing delinquent trash fees

BYLINE: Megan Reiter, The Times-Tribune, Scranton, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 370 words


July 24--Dunmore will be cracking down on delinquent trash bills, while
hopefully streamlining the process for the borough and for residents.

Borough council recently voted to end collection of delinquent refuse fee bills
by Northeast Credit and Collection and will pursue back payments in-house. The
borough was not under contract with Northeast Credit, borough solicitor Thomas
Cummings said.

As of June 30, delinquent refuse fees from 2009 were nearly $87,500. That amount
will surely be welcome in Dunmore's coffers, considering the borough has ongoing
financial problems and officials are constantly looking for ways to cut
expenses.

Council Vice President Paul Nardozzi said Northeast would deduct between 20 and
25 percent of each bill as a fee before forwarding the payment to the borough.

"It was actually a lose-lose situation," Mr. Nardozzi said. "The resident would
have to pay more, and we would get less."

The borough's refuse ordinance was amended in 2002 to require a $150 annual
trash collection fee per residential unit. The fee can be made in two payments,
and the borough is allowed to assess $10 penalties for late payments.

However, the council could send the delinquent bills to the magistrate, which
will then tack at least an additional $200 onto a delinquent bill, Mr. Cummings
said.

Before any bills are submitted to the magistrate, however, residents should
check their mailboxes. Mr. Cummings said the borough plans on sending letters
out to residents with late refuse bills to remind them to remit payment.

"We're going to make every attempt to collect it ourselves before it goes to the
magistrate," Mr. Nardozzi said, adding council will work with residents who are
feeling the financial strain.

Contact the writer: mreiter@timesshamrock.com

http://www.thetimes-tribune.com/. Copyright (c) 2010, The Times-Tribune,
Scranton, Pa. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For more

services@mctinfoservices.com, or call 866-280-5210 (outside the United States,
call +1 312-222-4544).

                              88 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                            Kokomo Tribune (Indiana)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            September 8, 2006 Friday

Delinquent taxpayers miss opportunity

BYLINE: Ken De La Bastide, Kokomo Tribune, Ind.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 445 words


Sep. 8--Only one person that owed delinquent personal property taxes took
advantage of the notice to avoid paying an additional 30 percent penalty.

Back in July the Howard County commissioners approved a request from Treasurer
Martha Lake to hire the local law firm of McCann & Peelle to begin collection
procedures.

Lake said at the time that residents had until Sept. 1 to make the payments.
After that date, an additional 30 percent would be tacked onto the delinquent
bill to cover the attorney costs.

Delinquent taxes for 2003, 2004 and 2005, amounting to $539,461, have gone
unpaid. The total amount now due is $701,299.

As of Friday the 30 percent penalty was added to the delinquent personal
property taxes, Lake said.

"The end result is we will take those people to court," Lake said. "We have
gotten only one payment on the delinquent personal property taxes.

"I wish we would have gotten a better response," she said.

People normally fall into one of four categories when it comes to paying taxes,
Lake said.

"There are those who pay early, those paying on time, a group that pays up to a
week late and those who avoid paying as long as possible," she said.

In addition to the 30 percent penalty, delinquent taxpayers also must pay a 10
percent late penalty and interest on the amount owed.

The law firm sent out the first delinquent letters last Friday.

Attorney Jeremy Peelle said in July that after the letter is sent the next step
is going to court. He said at the time that people who ignore the first letter,
will probably ignore further letters.

Once the case is taken to court, there is an additional attorney fee added to
the bill.

The county is collecting on delinquent property taxes and there is a tax sale
scheduled for Oct. 24.

The number of delinquent property taxes is on the increase, according to Lake.
The number was 521 in 2004, dropped to 486 in 2005 and is currently 578.

"There has been an increase in the number of people unable to pay," Lake said.
"They have to be 1.5 years behind in their property taxes before the property
can be sold through tax sale."

At the tax sale, people can bid on the property, the minimum bid has to be the
amount owed.

Lake said a property can be reclaimed, but the owner has to pay a percentage of
the tax sale price to the prospective buyer. It is 10 percent for the first six
months and then increases to 15 percent.

Copyright (c) 2006, Kokomo Tribune, Ind. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune
Business News. For reprints, email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call
800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The
Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                     Charleston Daily Mail (West Virginia)

                            July 31, 2014, Thursday

W.Va. ranks high for delinquent debts

BYLINE: JARED HUNT, DAILY MAIL BUSINESS EDITOR

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. P1C

LENGTH: 597 words


West Virginia has some of the most delinquent borrowers in the nation, according
to a new national survey about consumers' past-due debt.

The Urban Institute released a study Tuesday that found more than one in three
Americans - 35.1 percent - have a delinquent debt that's been turned over to a
credit agency. Among those with collections, the average amount is $5,178,
roughly 7 percent of the nation's average household income of $72,254.

The numbers are worse in West Virginia. The state ranks ninth among states with
the most delinquent borrowers.

The Urban Institute study found that 41.5 percent of West Virginia consumers had
a debt in collection, with an average amount in collection of $4,697. While that
amount is less than the national average, because the state's average household
income ($54,676) is less than the national average, the percentage of debt
compared to annual income is greater, at 8.6 percent.

Alabama, Kentucky, Georgia, Louisiana, Texas, Mississippi, South Carolina and
Washington, D.C., were among the places with higher rates of debt in collection.
Nevada topped the list among states, with 46.9 percent of consumers having a
debt in collection.

Meanwhile, a separate Urban Institute report released Tuesday found West
Virginians on average had the second lowest amount of total household debt,
including mortgage and non-mortgage debt, at $33,970. That was well below the
national average of $53,850.

The delinquent debt report, which was based on 2013 data from credit bureau
TransUnion, found most of the West Virginia debt in collections was concentrated
in the southern end of the state.

Jill Epstein, the president of the Associated Collection Agencies of West
Virginia industry group, said that was driven in part by lackluster performance
of the state's coal economy.

"Obviously in southern part of state, where the coal mines are closing and
laying off lots of people, that has an impact, Epstein said. "In the northern
part of state, where you have the Marcellus shale boom and money is flowing, and
economy's a little better.

Poor health and hospital stays are also a factor.

"As people get hit with high out-of-pocket deductibles and co-pays, that's an
issue, Epstein said.

According to data from Associated Collection Agencies International, health care
debt made up about 38 percent of collections in 2013. Student loan debt followed
at 25 percent, financial services debt (which includes credit card debt) made up
about 13 percent, while debt owed to government agencies accounted for 10
percent.

Mark Schiffman, spokesman for ACA International, said more than 1 billion new
accounts totaling $756.5 billion were placed into collections during 2013. Of
those, agencies only recovered about 7 percent, or $55.2 billion.

Schiffman and Epstein said most debts go uncollected because people usually
don't respond to debt collection letters or don't pick up the phone when the
caller ID indicates a collector is calling.

"People just think if they ignore it they don't have to pay, Epstein said.

Schiffman said, despite perceptions, the vast majority of debt collection firms
are willing to work with consumers to being a payment plan or negotiate the debt
down to a more affordable level.

The organization has set up a website, www.askdoctordebt.org, to help consumers
facing a collection. But Schiffman said the first thing to do is pick up the
phone and talk to the collection agency.

"We're keenly aware nobody wants to talk to a debt collector about owing money,
but by picking up the phone, opening a letter, it's the best thing you can do,
he said.

LOAD-DATE: July 31, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
