                              90 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                   August 23, 1989, Wednesday, Final Edition

Virginia List Aims to Shame Fathers Into Paying Child Support

BYLINE: Sandra Evans, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: METRO; PAGE D1

LENGTH: 964 words


After chasing, threatening and suing to no avail, Virginia child support
enforcement officials are trying a new weapon to collect payments from what they
say are 10 particularly recalcitrant fathers: public exposure and humiliation.

In announcing the state's first 10 Most Wanted list of delinquents, officials
released the names of a chemical analyst with his own business in Chantilly, a
pediatrician who practices in Louisiana, a silver-haired Maryland man who
transports boats, and an unemployed construction worker who apparently lives
with his father in Danville.

They each owe, according to state records, $ 11,000 to $ 107,000 in unpaid child
support to their former wives. The men who were chosen for the list were not
necessarily the top delinquents in terms of dollars unpaid, but had been
"particularly elusive over the years," said Harry W. Wiggins, director of
Virginia's division of child support enforcement.

"We think this is an effective way to get their friends and relatives to turn
them in," Wiggins said after the list was released in Richmond.

The agency, which is responsible for collecting delinquent child support
payments, said outstanding deliquencies total more than $ 250 million.

Virginia was among the worst states in the country only a few years ago in its
record of collecting child support payments from delinquent parents, and remains
hampered in its efforts by a flawed computer system. But new enforcement
authorities and resources have helped the state increase its child support
collections from $ 20 million in fiscal 1986 to $ 103 million in fiscal 1989,
according to Wiggins.

Robert K. Simon, No. 2 on the most wanted list and the only one from the
Northern Virginia district office's files, operates his own chemical laboratory
in Chantilly, Washington Analytical Laboratories, according to child support
officials.

Officials, who said Simon owes $ 39,250 in payments for his three children in
North Carolina, said that they have been unable to make him pay up or even to
serve necessary court documents on him. "You can't enforce if you can't serve
the person" with legal papers, said Susan Hayes, district manager for the
Northern Virginia office.

The idea of putting Simon, 50, on the 10 Most Wanted list is to "put some
pressure on him" to pay up on his own, Wiggins said.

Simon did not return calls to his Chantilly office.

Delinquent parents can use a variety of evasion tactics that can be successful
even when child support authorities know where the person is and where the
parent's assets are, officials said. These may be as simple as going out the
back door when a sheriff comes to the front to serve court papers, or they may
be as elaborate as shifting assets from company to company or moving across
state lines.

One of the main legal tools child support officials have is withholding payments
from the delinquent parent's paycheck. But people who are self-employed can
ignore orders to withhold money from paychecks or can get paid in cash to keep
the state from claiming a slice, officials said.

The idea behind putting this type of person on the most wanted list is to appeal
to pride and to enlist the help of others in pinpointing when and how delinquent
parents can be caught rather than helping them hide.

Ruth E. "Betty" Murphy, executive director of the National Child Support
Advocacy Coalition, supported the use of the most wanted list as a way of
alerting the public that it should not shield delinquent parents out of
misguided loyalty. Three other states -- Texas, Illinois and Missouri -- have
used similar devices with some success, she said.

"Some of these men lead charmed lives," Murphy said. Embarrassing delinquent
parents and those covering for them "may be the only effective way" of dealing
with some cases, she said.

Murphy noted that parents can be put in jail for failure to pay child support
and can be extradited from other states, but said this is viewed as a tactic of
last resort, and prosecutors and judges often are reluctant to use it.

Virginia lists its No. 1 delinquent parent as Vern Meyer, 42, who has his own
pediatrics practice in Destrehan, La., and is said to owe $ 107,105 in back
payments. Meyer said in a telephone interview yesterday that the child support
payments were initially set much higher than he could afford to pay for his
three children: $ 21,000 a year when his then-new practice was netting $ 23,000
a year. While not disputing the state's figures, he called the amount the court
ordered him to pay "unrealistic."

Meyer said Virginia officials know exactly where he is. "I'm not hiding from
anybody," he said. "I feel like I'm being put on trial through the newspapers."

A man identifying himself as the father of one of the others on the most wanted
list, 33-year-old Frankie L. Adams, said Adams is living with him in Danville.

"He paid while he could," but then got laid off his job, the man said.

The others on the state's list could not be reached for comment. They are:

Michael Andrew Charles Auth, also known as Michael Abel, 50, last known to live
in Worton, Md., and believed to transport boats for a living, is said to owe $
36,498.

Carl Columbus Pearson, 51, a painter from Portsmouth, is said to owe $ 23,578.

Wesley Oliver Griffin, 52, previously of Hampton, Norfolk and possibly Emporia,
listed as owing $ 15,116.

William Randolph Johnson, 33, a laborer from Culpeper, listed as owing $ 13,302.

William Moore Harris III, 35, a consultant, pilot and flight instructor last
known to live in Christiansburg, is said to owe $ 13,240.

Eugene T. James, 50, thought to be a truck driver in Melbourne, Fla., listed as
owing $ 12,289.

Eddie Chastine Smith, 38, a laborer from Woodford, Va., is said to owe $ 11,966.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: VIRGINIA NEWS

                       Copyright 1989 The Washington Post

                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           February 20, 2014 Thursday

City of Erie website includes list of delinquent garbage accounts

BYLINE: Kevin Flowers, Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 319 words


Feb. 20--The city of Erie is now using the Internet as part of its plan to
better collect more than $1.6 million in delinquent refuse fees.

An 88-page list of all delinquent garbage accounts greater than $100, as of
Wednesday, is now posted on the city's website, www.erie.pa.us.

The list includes names of people delinquent on their garbage bills, the billing
address, and the amounts owed. Mayor Joe Sinnott said this morning that the list
will be updated every three months.

Sinnott said in December that the city was considering adding the information to
its website, so that the public could view it. He believes posting the
information might prompt some people to pay their bills quickly so that their
names either do not appear on the city's website, or can be removed.

Delinquent garbage bills -- in the wake of a recent garbage fee increase -- have
become a huge political issue at City Hall. Many city residents have expressed
outrage that their garbage fees were increased at a time when hundreds of
customers refuse to pay their bills.

Sinnott and City Council members have said they will work together to find
solutions.

Paul Vojtek, chief executive of Erie Water Works, has told Erie City Council
that the city's total delinquencies, including accounts that have municipal
liens filed against them, is $2.3 million, and that some customers have not paid
their bills in more than a decade.

Erie Water Works handles billing and collection for garbage customers on the
city's behalf.

Vojtek said that the Erie Water Works received $55,500 in payments from
delinquent customers in the wake of a Jan. 19 Erie Times-News story on the
city's problems with delinquent garbage accounts. A list of accounts that were
delinquent at that time was posted at GoErie.com/garbagebills.

                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                            February 21, 2014 Friday

City of Erie website includes list of delinquent garbage accounts

BYLINE: Kevin Flowers, Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 365 words


Feb. 21--The city of Erie is now using the Internet as part of its plan to
better collect more than $1.6 million in delinquent refuse fees.

An 88-page list of all delinquent garbage accounts greater than $100, as of
Wednesday, is now posted on the city's website, www.erie.pa.us.

The list includes names of people delinquent on their garbage bills, the billing
address, and the amounts owed.

Mayor Joe Sinnott said Thursday that the list will be updated every three
months.

Sinnott said in December that the city was considering adding the information to
its website, so that the public could view it. He believes posting the
information might prompt some people to pay their bills quickly so that their
names either do not appear on the city's website, or can be removed.

Delinquent garbage bills -- in the wake of a recent garbage fee increase -- have
become a huge political issue at City Hall.

Many city residents have expressed outrage that their garbage fees were
increased at a time when hundreds of customers refuse to pay their bills.

Sinnott and City Council members have said they will work together to find
solutions.

Paul Vojtek, chief executive of Erie Water Works, has told Erie City Council
that the city's total delinquencies, including accounts that have municipal
liens filed against them, is $2.3 million, and that some customers have not paid
their bills in more than a decade.

Erie Water Works handles billing and collection for garbage customers on the
city's behalf.

Vojtek said that Erie Water Works received $55,500 in payments from delinquent
customers in the wake of a Jan. 19 Erie Times-News story on the city's problems
with delinquent garbage accounts.

A list of accounts that were delinquent at that time was posted at
GoErie.com/garbagebills.

City Council approved the city's 2014 budget in December that increased garbage
fees from an average of $48 every three months, or $192 per year, to $55 every
quarter, or $220 per year.

                            The Blade (Toledo, Ohio)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                            August 25, 2016 Thursday

Delinquent mortgages up for first time in 2016

BYLINE: Jon Chavez, The Blade, Toledo, Ohio

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 427 words


Aug. 25--The delinquency rate on mortgage payments in metro Toledo jumped in
June from the previous month, the first time this year the rate increased, a new
report shows.

After four months of steady decreases, the percentage of mortgages in the Toledo
area that were delinquent by 90 days or more reached 3.23 percent, according to
CoreLogic Inc., a California data firm that tracks home loans.

In May, the 90-day delinquency rate had dropped to 3.04 percent. The change in
June from May was unusually large for the monthly figures reported by CoreLogic.

Shane Marzullo, a mortgage lender with Greentree Mortgage Services Inc. in
Holland, said no specific event could have triggered the sharp rise in
delinquencies.

"The only reason I could think of that could make it go up that way is there was
a big giant backlog of delinquencies in the courts, and finally we were able to
get through them all and release them," he said. "Maybe the banks were holding
off on stuff and decided to move on them."

But Nita Haas, senior sales consultant for CU Member Mortgage and past president
of the Mortgage Bankers Association of Northwest Ohio, said the seller's market
may be the event triggering the rise in delinquencies. "I haven't heard of any
large employer layoffs or something that would have triggered that. But at the
same time, something to take into consideration is ... the overall sales
activity," she said.

The Toledo real estate market is becoming heated, and banks recognize now is a
good time to sell distressed properties that have either been foreclosed upon or
in the foreclosure process. Mortgages that may have been modified and allowed to
be delinquent without consequences because the real estate market was slow now
could be declared delinquent as the area turns into a seller's market, Ms. Haas
said.

"If I had some delinquent accounts and I've modified them as much as I could, I
might take advantage of the current market conditions when it is the best time
to do that," she said.

Historically, Ms. Haas noted, the summer brings an uptick in payment
delinquencies.

In 2015, the 90-day delinquency rate began rising in July, and continued to rise
in August and September, Core-Logic figures show.

"I have had lenders tell me that some people take their mortgage money and go on
vacation in the summer. They swap out household money for other needs," Ms. Haas
said.

Contact Jon Chavez at: jchavez@theblade.com or 419-724-6128.

www.toledoblade.com Distributed by Tribune Content Agency, LLC.

                              94 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                             National Mortgage News

                                 March 20, 2015

Freddie Mac Selling $1 Billion of Soured Debt in Largest Deal

SECTION: DISTRESSED Vol. 1 No. 1

LENGTH: 457  words


Freddie Mac is selling more than $1 billion of soured U.S. home loans in its
largest sale of the debt.

Potential buyers are bidding on three pools of nonperforming loans, with unpaid
principal balances of about $660 million, $249 million and $125 million,
according to debt broker Mission Capital Advisors. Homes tied to loans in the
smallest group are all located in New York, while properties linked to the other
two pools are geographically dispersed. Offers are due March 24.

"All the traditional NPL players will certainly be interested in bidding on
these pools," said Gary McCarthy, a partner in HMC Assets LLC, a Redondo Beach,
California-based firm that invests in delinquent loans. "This is something that
we're going to see on an ongoing basis for a period of time."

The offering is the government-backed mortgage company's third large sale of
delinquent home loans. Freddie Mac has been accelerating auctions of soured
mortgages, bought from bonds guaranteed by the McLean, Virginia-based company
that went bad after the housing crash. Demand has been increasing as Wall Street
firms compete to buy the loans at a discount after a real estate market rebound.

Rising home values have prompted bidders for the loans to raise their offers,
pushing up the prices of the debt and driving lenders such as Bank of America
Corp., JPMorgan Chase & Co. and Citigroup Inc. to accelerate their sales of
delinquent loans this year.

"The loans involved in this transaction are deeply delinquent, including a large
share that are more than two years delinquent," Thomas Fitzgerald, a Freddie Mac
spokesman, said in an e-mail. He wouldn't comment on the size of the pools being
sold.

Banks and the Department of Housing and Urban Development have been the biggest
sellers of the debt. Freddie Mac held its first loan sale in July of last year,
for $659 million of nonperforming loans.

The Federal Housing Finance Agency, which regulates Freddie Mac and
Washington-based Fannie Mae, is requiring the companies to reduce the number of
severely delinquent loans on their books this year. This month, the agency
released a set of new rules for the sale of troubled mortgages.

FHFA will require prospective investors to prove they've retained a loan
servicer with a track record of handling delinquent debt, the agency said in a
March 2 statement. Servicers also will have to offer aid to avoid foreclosures
as a condition of sale.

Investment firms including Lone Star Funds, Bayview Asset Management LLC and
Selene Finance LP have been some of the biggest buyers of delinquent home loans.

The New York pool may attract different buyers than the others, McCarthy said.

"To buy the New York pool, you better have boots on the ground to properly
manage it," he said.

                               The New York Times

                             March 27, 2005 Sunday
                              Late Edition - Final

Bridgeport Taking Aim At Tax Delinquents

BYLINE: By JEFF HOLTZ

SECTION: Section 14CN; Column 4; Connecticut Weekly Desk; WORTH NOTING; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 297 words


Impressed with the success New Haven has had with the BootFinder, a device
similar to a radar gun that identifies motor vehicles with delinquent taxes on
them by scanning license plates, Bridgeport has decided to become the second
municipality in the state to use it.

Caryn S. Kaufman, a spokeswoman for Mayor John M. Fabrizi of Bridgeport, said
the common council voted 15 to 3 with 1 abstention Monday night to authorize the
use of the BootFinder.

Ms. Kaufman said letters notifying scofflaws that they had 10 days to pay their
motor vehicle taxes had been sent Tuesday. She said warrants would be issued at
the end of the month for accounts that had still not been paid.

Robert G. Tetreault, Bridgeport's tax collector, said that the city purchased
three BootFinders and that state marshals would begin using them and the city
would begin towing vehicles that have delinquent taxes on them by late April.

Mr. Tetreault said Bridgeport had $20 million in delinquent motor vehicle taxes,
but expected that the most the city could realistically collect would be
slightly more than half of that.

''Our collection rate has traditionally been under 70 percent,'' Mr. Tetreault
said. ''Historically, people have not paid their motor vehicle taxes here until
they have to get a vehicle registered and they have to pay them.''

In the three weeks since the city announced it was considering the BootFinder,
Mr. Tetreault said his office took in about $638,000 in delinquent motor vehicle
taxes, much more than it usually does over that length of time. He said there
have been long lines every day.

Ms. Kaufman said that the city was considering using the BootFinder to identify
other types of offenders through license plates, such as those with outstanding
parking tickets.   JEFF HOLTZ


URL: http://www.nytimes.com

LOAD-DATE: March 27, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                   The News Virginian (Waynesboro, Virginia)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            February 27, 2009 Friday

Francis Chester delinquent on Augusta taxes

BYLINE: Bob Stuart, The News Virginian, Waynesboro, Va.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 350 words


Feb. 27--VERONA -- The Churchville lawyer leading the petition drive against
Augusta County's reassessessment owes more than $2,800 in real estate and
personal property taxes.

Francis Chester is delinquent on $2,562 in real estate taxes on parcels in
Churchville and West Augusta, and owes $328 in delinquent personal property
taxes, according to records in the Augusta County Treasurer's office.

"I'm not a hypocrite,'' Chester declared Thursday. He said he can account for
why taxes were not paid in December.

An employee, he said, told him that "we don't have enough to pay payroll and
real estates taxes. And if it's taxes or employees, I will pay the employees."

Chester employs 10 people in three separate businesses he owns. These business
include a sheep operation, wool mill and his law firm.

Augusta County Treasurer Richard Homes said there is an "issue with anyone being
delinquent."

All county supervisors, assessors board members and department heads are current
in the property tax payments, according to county records.

Augusta County Administrator Patrick Coffield said he is notified if any of the
county's employees are delinquent on taxes.

"This is why I'm fighting taxes for the people,'' Chester said. "It's about time
we do something about it. We're being taxed to death."

Chester said he is paid when he finishes work or ships a product. "My money does
not come in steady,'' he said.

The attorney has mounted a petition drive to roll back the county's
reassessment, and will present the petitions when Augusta County supervisors
meet March 11. Chester has said he will sue the county on behalf of taxpayers if
supervisors do not act on the petitions.

                              97 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                 NEW YORK TIMES

                             March 31, 1974, Sunday

BYLINE: BY RONALD SULLIVAN

SECTION: Page 65, Column 6

LENGTH: 185 words

NJ Public Interest Research Group is pressing for change in state law that
allows banks and corps to reap financial windfalls by investing money that they
owe in delinquent property taxes.  At issue is fact that tax delinquents find
they can make profit by investing elsewhere money they owe communities.  Under
NJ law, maximum penalty on delinquent taxes is 12% while current interest rates
on loans earns better than this.  State Sen Joseph A Maressa recently introduced
bill that will raise to 18% interest rate on delinquent munic property taxes
exceeding $1,000.  Earlier, Assemblymen James J Florio, Ernest F Shuck and James
W Bornheimer sponsored legis that will increase interest rate on delinquent
levies exceeding $1,000.  Public Interest tax-reform dir Jim Hely says he
supports both bills but declares that 12% rate should apply to delinquent taxes
totaling $2,000 so that small property owners could have greater leeway.  Says
interest rate on taxes in excess of $2,000 should be raised to as much as
20%.Public Interest orgn notes Natl State Bank in Trenton owes city $44,223.50
in taxes (M).

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

JOURNAL-CODE:  NYT

TYPE: 90-74

                 The Tribune-Democrat (Johnstown, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             March 31, 2009 Tuesday

Roustan United facing claims, delinquent taxes

BYLINE: Sandra K. Reabuck, Tribune-Democrat, Johnstown, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 529 words


Mar. 31--EBENSBURG -- Roustan United, the Richland Township-based company that
hoped to be part of a deal to manage the Cambria County War Memorial Arena, is
facing financial woes, with civil financial claims totaling more than $120,000
in Cambria County Court and an even higher amount due in delinquent property
taxes.

The company is in arrears on payments it's making on 2006 real estate taxes.

In addition, more than $140,000 is owed on delinquent property taxes for 2007
and 2008, the county tax claim office said.

And, Roustan settled another lawsuit last June for $12,612 by agreeing to make
staggered payments to Lakeland Plastics Inc., of Pittsburgh, for plastic spacer
strips and other products, according to records in the county prothonotary's
office.

Roustan has been managing the arena's primary tenant, the Johnstown Chiefs
hockey team.

Last year, it partnered with Global Spectrum of Philadelphia, one of the
nation's leading managers of public assembly venues, in submitting a proposal to
the county commissioners for the management of the War Memorial Arena.

On Monday, the county commissioners said that any deal with Roustan and Global
was dead.

The commissioners did not discuss Roustan's financial problems, but said there
were several confidential business considerations they considered.

Likewise, Roustan President Scott Branovan would not discuss the lawsuits and
delinquent taxes.

On March 26, Advantage Staffing Inc. of Altoona obtained a $49,944 default
judgment against Roustan United and Burley's Rink Supply of Salix for temporary
staffing services.

Maintenance services and a laborer were supplied, according to the civil lawsuit
filed by Advantage in April.

A lien for $3,734 was filed by the state's Unemployment Compensation Fund
against Roustan United on Sept. 19. That amount remained outstanding from
$10,218 owed, the state said.

This month, two new lawsuits were filed against Roustan.

Adex Sales of Westbank, B.C., Canada, is suing for $45,580 for glass panels to
Roustan at facilities in Meadville, and Northbrook, Ill. EDC Industries of Elk
Grove, Ill., is suing for $21,010 for merchandise allegedly supplied to Roustan.

The tax claim bureau said that the delinquent taxes are due on Roustan's Planet
Ice property at 195 Jari Drive.

The company went on a payment plan last summer, agreeing to pay $6,399 a month.
Six payments were made, with six remaining.

No payments were made in January, February or March, Joanne Ranck, assistant
director, said.

The original amount delinquent for 2006, with interest and penalties, was
$76,792 in property taxes owed to the county, Richland School District and
Richland Township, she said.

Ranck said that Roustan also owes $71,518 in delinquent tax for 2007 and $69,261
for 2008.

To see more of The Tribune-Democrat or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.tribune-democrat.com. Copyright (c) 2009, Tribune-Democrat,
Johnstown, Pa. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For
reprints, email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or
847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group
Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                                Payments Source

                            October 15, 2012 Monday

Class-Action Certified Against Texas Collection Agency

SECTION: CCR - REGULATION Vol. 1 No. 1

LENGTH: 263  words


Thousands of residents of Memphis, Tenn., who paid 20 percent fees to collection
agency Linebarger Goggan Blair & Sampson, could be affected by a federal judge's
ruling last week to certify a class-action suit against the firm.The case
surrounds the interpretation of two Tennessee statutes that provide for
additional charges against delinquent taxpayers when they have to be sued for
collection. At issue is whether Linebarger can charge a 10 percent or 20 percent
fee for collecting delinquent property taxes on homes and businesses.A Tennessee
law says attorneys pursuing back taxes cannot receive compensation greater than
10 percent of all delinquent fees collected.

Another statute says a 10 percent penalty can be imposed on those whose taxes
are delinquent, and that the penalty will go to the attorney suing to collect
the back taxes. Linebarger has interpreted that wording to allow for a total fee
of 20 percent; the plaintiffs argue the two statutes limit the total fees to 10
percent. In a 2010 opinion, the Shelby County (Tenn.) Attorney's office said the
fee is limited to a 10 percent penalty, including the delinquent tax attorney
fee.Linebarger won a contract from the city in 2004 to collect delinquent city
taxes. As part of the deal, the city does not pay any direct fees to Linebarger,
which instead charges delinquent taxpayers fees along with the taxes owed. The
debts must be 17 months past due before the city turns them over to the firm.
Linebarger's contract with the city expires in December. A decision on whether
to retain the firm has not been made.

URL: http://www.paymentssource.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Magazine

                             100 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                              May 11, 2010 Tuesday
                                2 Tampa Edition

DELINQUENT PROPERTY TAX BILLS DECLINE

BYLINE: BILL VARIAN, TIMES STAFF WRITER

SECTION: TAMPA BAY; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 629 words



HIGHLIGHT: Tax collectors in Hillsborough and Pinellas are surprised by the
drop.


For the first time in several years, the number of property tax scofflaws has
dropped - dramatically in Hillsborough and Pinellas counties.

Both counties report sharp declines in the number of properties whose owners
failed to pay their 2009 property tax bills by April 1, the point at which
government considers an owner delinquent.

Tax collectors aren't sure why.

The amount owed on those delinquent bills is down by an even greater margin.
That is at least partly a reflection of tax bills plummeting with property
values.

"It came as a total surprise," said Sam McClelland, deputy tax collector for
Pinellas County. "Because we have had no indicators in the economy that things
are better. We do know that we've lost a lot of value."

Consider:

- In Hillsborough, 39,579 parcels are listed as delinquent on their taxes, 6,492
fewer than April 1 of last year. The amount owed in taxes is $115.6 million,
down from $159.6 million last year.

- In Pinellas, the number of delinquent property tax payers is down 17 percent,
from 40,134 last year. The amount they owe is down 26 percent, from $139.2
million last year.

Both numbers began spiking in 2005 as nonhomesteaded property owners saw their
tax bills skyrocket with rising property values before the bubble burst. The
rising number of delinquencies foretold the housing market meltdown that would
start to unfold two years later.

The reversal is not evident in all bay area counties. Pasco saw delinquencies
and the amount owed on back taxes stay almost flat during the past year, said
Tax Collector Mike Olson.

Delinquencies are actually up slightly in Hernando County, although the amount
owed is down "due to the decrease in property values," said Tax Collector
Juanita Sikes.

Officials in Hillsborough offered a few theories for what is happening there and
in Pinellas.

One is that because tax bills are lower mainly due to declining values, property
owners are having an easier time paying.

"That's likely to be in some instances a factor," said Hillsborough County
Property Appraiser Rob Turner.

That may be getting offset in Hernando County, which has experienced
comparatively greater job losses.

On the downside, it also is likely a reflection on the high number of home
foreclosures in the Tampa Bay region, which may be the more plausible
explanation. With banks taking over record numbers of homes, it puts them on the
hook for the tax bill.

They've got to pay the tax bill before they can unload a house, said Turner and
Hillsborough County Tax Collector Doug Belden. If they don't pay by the end of
this month, the tax collector can sell the debt off to private collectors who
will seek to recoup the money, with interest.

A list of delinquent Hillsborough properties published Monday appears to bear
that out, as few are listed as owned by banks.

"I believe there's a correlation between (the banks) owning the title and paying
off the taxes," Belden said. "If you're in the foreclosure process, the taxes
need to be paid before you can have a sale, in order to get clear of the title."

Bill Varian can be reached at (813) 226-3387 or varian@sptimes.com

* * *

                                US Official News

                            August 25, 2016 Thursday

Virginia: Bland County Delinquent Real Estate & Personal Property Tax List

LENGTH: 166  words

DATELINE: New York



 Richmond: County of Bland, The state of Virginia has issued the following news
release:



 The publication of the lists of delinquent real estate and personal property
taxes have been released and can be viewed on the county website at
www.blandcountyva.gov and will be submitted for publication in the Bland County
Messenger.





 The Bland County ordinance adopted in 2014 in accordance with § 46.2-752 of the
Code of Virginia, authorizes the Treasurer of Bland County to place a stop on
delinquent personal property tax payers with the Department of Motor Vehicles
(DMV). This prevents the issuance of any vehicle registration or renewal of such
license or registration until all delinquent taxes and fees are paid in full to
the County of Bland.



 Delinquent tax payers are asked to contact the Treasurer of Bland County, John
Goins, (276-688-3741) to settle any delinquent accounts.

                             102 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                          February 10, 2016 Wednesday

New York: Moody's Servicer Dashboard: Florida servicers' payments on delinquent
loans may benefit RMBS

LENGTH: 404  words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Albany: Moody's Investors Service has issued the following news release:



  Florida servicers' payments on delinquent loans are credit positive for the
residential mortgage-backed securities (RMBS) backed by the loans, Moody's
Investors Service says in the lead article of its latest Servicer Dashboard. The
practice may protect servicers' right to restart the foreclosure process on
properties underlying long-delinquent loans, and so gain recoveries on them.





 Some servicers have been crediting payments on borrowers' delinquent loans in
an effort to position foreclosures to comply with Florida's statute of
limitations. This practice may protect their right to restart foreclosures on
loans delinquent for more than five years that the Florida courts previously
dismissed, and keeps foreclosures moving. The courts are divided on various
issues related to applying the statute of limitations, and the Florida Supreme
Court is currently reviewing a case servicers hope will clarify many of these
issues. "Even if the court rules unfavorably for lenders and servicers, the
impact on private-label RMBS would be limited, because it wouldn't affect more
than 3% of Florida loans," says Moody's analyst, Frank Wissman.



 Elsewhere in the latest dashboard, which presents a month-to-month comparison
of servicers' performance, collections metrics continued to improve slightly or
remained flat in 2015's third quarter. Though Ocwen's performance improved, the
company remained the worst performer in the prime and Alt-A categories. Wells
was the best in subprime, and Citi the best in Alt-A. Continued improvement in
the economy contributed to declines in new delinquencies and in roll rates for
all product types, notably subprime loans.



 Similarly, total cure and cash-flowing metrics were slightly better or flat for
all product types in the third quarter of 2015, with the exception of Citi in
Alt-A. Ocwen's level of modifications increased, and the servicer continues to
have the highest level of loss-mitigation activity among peers across all
products.



 Modification re-default rates also improved slightly or were flat, with Ocwen's
re-default performance worse for all product types due to the company's high
re-modification count. Meanwhile, foreclosure timelines were flat for all
product types.





 In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: February 10, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


              Copyright 2016 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited

                                US Official News

                             August 1, 2014 Friday

Jared Hunt: WV ranks high for delinquent debts

LENGTH: 618  words

DATELINE: Minneapolis


ACA International has issued the following news release:

West Virginia has some of the most delinquent borrowers in the nation, according
to a new national survey about consumers' past-due debt.

The Urban Institute released a study Tuesday that found more than one in three
Americans -- 35.1 percent -- have a delinquent debt that's been turned over to a
credit agency. Among those with collections, the average amount is $5,178,
roughly 7 percent of the nation's average household income of $72,254.

The numbers are worse in West Virginia. The state ranks ninth among states with
the most delinquent borrowers.

The Urban Institute study found that 41.5 percent of West Virginia consumers had
a debt in collection, with an average amount in collection of $4,697. While that
amount is less than the national average, because the state's average household
income ($54,676) is less than the national average, the percentage of debt
compared to annual income is greater, at 8.6 percent.

Alabama, Kentucky, Georgia, Louisiana, Texas, Mississippi, South Carolina and
Washington, D.C., were among the places with higher rates of debt in collection.
Nevada topped the list among states, with 46.9 percent of consumers having a
debt in collection.

Meanwhile, a separate Urban Institute report released Tuesday found West
Virginians on average had the second lowest amount of total household debt,
including mortgage and non-mortgage debt, at $33,970. That was well below the
national average was $53,850.

The delinquent debt report, which was based on 2013 data from credit bureau
TransUnion, found most of the West Virginia debt in collections was concentrated
in the southern end of the state.

Jill Epstein, the president of the Associated Collection Agencies of West
Virginia industry group, said that was driven in part by lackluster performance
of the state's coal economy.

"Obviously in southern part of state, where the coal mines are closing and
laying off lots of people, that has an impact," Epstein said. "In the northern
part of state, where you have the Marcellus shale boom and money is flowing, and
economy's a little better."

Poor health and hospital stays are also a factor.

"As people get hit with high out-of-pocket deductibles and co-pays, that's an
issue," Epstein said.

According to data from Associated Collection Agencies International, health care
debt made up about 38 percent of collections in 2013. Student loan debt followed
at 25 percent, financial services debt (which includes credit card debt) made up
about 13 percent, while debt owed to government agencies accounted for 10
percent.

Mark Schiffman, spokesman for ACA International, said more than 1 billion new
accounts totaling $756.5 billion were placed into collections during 2013. Of
those, agencies only recovered about 7 percent, or $55.2 billion.

Schiffman and Epstein said most debts go uncollected because people usually
don't respond to debt collection letters or don't pick up the phone when the
caller ID indicates a collector is calling.

"People just think if they ignore it they don't have to pay," Epstein said.

Schiffman said, despite perceptions, the vast majority of debt collection firms
are willing to work with consumers to being a payment plan or negotiate the debt
down to a more affordable level.

The organization has set up a website, www.askdoctordebt.org, to help consumers
facing a collection. But Schiffman said the first thing to do is pick up the
phone and talk to the collection agency.

"We're keenly aware nobody wants to talk to a debt collector about owing money,
but by picking up the phone, opening a letter, it's the best thing you can do,"
he said.

For more information please visit: http://www.acainternational.org

LOAD-DATE: August 1, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

* * * * * * * * * * COMPANY INFORMATION * * * * * * * * * *
INCORPORATION DATE: November 3, 1986
PLACE OF INCORPORATION: Nevada
LEGAL STATUS: Equity Issue
OPERATING STATUS: Inactive
EMPLOYEES: 306

* * * * * * * * * * DESCRIPTION * * * * * * * * * *

   TaxMasters, Inc., (TaxMasters) is a tax resolution company, engaged in the
business of assisting taxpayers with matters at the United States Internal
Revenue Service (IRS), especially the resolution of disputes and assessments and
the settlement of tax liabilities. The Company' s tax professionals help its
clients solve their Federal tax problems, ranging from filing delinquent tax
returns to settling tax debts. Its tax professionals include tax attorneys,
Certified Public Accountants, Former IRS agents, Licensed Tax Preparers and
other tax professionals who are authorized to practice before the IRS. The tax
professionals also help its clients reduce taxes, eliminate penalties, and get
representation before the IRS. The Company helps its clients understand how they
wound up with the tax problems they have and help them fix the entire problem
that caused their tax debt. The Company' s services include: Get its clients
into compliance with their obligation to file income tax returns and pay back
taxes due; Reduce taxes by reducing penalties and interest on tax debts; Settle
the Company' s client' s tax debt for the lowest amount possible under the law;
Stop IRS wage garnishments; Stop IRS property seizure; Defend its client in an
IRS audit or IRS criminal investigation; Recover seized funds, and Remove an IRS
levy or lien.

   Delinquent Tax Returns and Back Taxes

   The Company' s tax professionals help the individuals and businesses with
delinquent returns, back taxes or delinquent taxes minimize the penalties and
interest they would otherwise have to pay to the IRS by assisting them file all
past-due returns before the IRS notifies them of delinquent returns or back
taxes. The Company also assists its clients who have delinquent tax returns in
overcoming a substitute return filed by the IRS. The professionals assist
clients in overcoming the substitute returns by filing the delinquent tax
returns with deductions to which its clients are entitled and obtaining any
refunds that may be due to them.

   Settle Taxes and Offer in Compromise

   The Company helps its clients settle their tax debt for the lowest amount
possible. The professionals look at their client' s options that may be
available to him or her to reduce the tax liability at issue. These options
include submitting or resubmitting corrected tax returns, such as filing
delinquent returns or filing amended returns to claim overlooked deductions and
establishing favorable monthly installment agreements. Once the professionals
have determined that a client' s specific tax problems have been addressed and
tax penalties minimized, and all other settlement offers have been exhausted,
they submit an offer in compromise.

   Cease IRS wage garnishments and other IRS Levies

   One of the method, the IRS uses to collect back taxes is to levy wages, which
is referred to as wage garnishment. The IRS can notify a person' s employer that
such person has a back tax debt. The employer is then required by law to send a
portion of each of that person' s paychecks directly to the IRS to offset the
debt. The IRS do not stop salary garnishment unless a client takes action to
settle what he or she owes, because the IRS usually levies wages to force a
person to take action or after all other attempts by the IRS to collect the
delinquent tax have failed. The Company assists its clients in stopping wage
garnishment by getting its clients back in compliance with the requirement to
file their tax returns and negotiate a release of their wages from levy.

   Recover Property Seized by the IRS

   The IRS seizes assets and places liens on property to satisfy unpaid and
delinquent taxes. The IRS can take and sell any property, such as a boat, car of
even a house. The Company addresses liens and property seizures by different
approaches. Depending on the client' s situation, it requests a Stay of
Collections with the IRS for up to a 90-day period. If the Stay of Collections
is granted, the IRS do not contact its client about his or her back taxes.
During the Stay of Collection, the tax professionals use that period to resolve
the tax debt with the IRS, whether by an installment plan or an Offer in
Compromise or some alternative settlement.

   IRS audit

   The Company represents clients in normal audits, audit letters, and even
fraud audits and criminal investigations. The Company' s tax representative
services in audits and audit appeals include: Acting as an intermediary between
the IRS and the client, Rescheduling the audit if necessary, Requesting specific
information from the IRS related to the matter under investigation; Defending
the client' s tax return at the audit (to the extent of any legal position taken
by the client), and Receiving any findings from the IRS and negotiating to
reduce any proposed settlement.

   The Company competes with JK Harris & Company, Roni Lynn Deutch, Effecteur,
Inc., Allied Tax Solutions, Inc., American Tax Relief, Freedom Tax Relief, 411
Tax Relief and eTaxes.com.

                             106 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           February 6, 2014 Thursday

City Council discusses options to curb delinquent garbage bills

BYLINE: Kevin Flowers, Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 431 words


Feb. 06--Combining water, sewer and garbage bills for city of Erie residents.

Lawsuits.

Rescinding or denying landlords' eligibility for city-required rental licenses.

Erie City Council talked about all of these options -- and examined what other
cities do -- on Wednesday as the panel discussed ways to better collect more
than $1.6 million in delinquent refuse fees.

Council members, other city officials and Paul Vojtek, the Erie Water Works
chief executive, met for nearly 90 minutes during council's Finance Committee
meeting Wednesday.

City officials have been criticized by some citizens for not being aggressive
enough on the delinquency issue, especially since residents' garbage fees were
increased in the city's 2014 budget.

Councilman Cas Kwitowski said the city needs to get tough regarding the
delinquent accounts. Kwitowski suggested filing lawsuits to get the largest
delinquent customers to pay up.

"We've got to start having some guts around here," Kwitowski said. "Let them sue
us. ... People are mocking us over this."

Vojtek on Wednesday told City Council that the city's total delinquencies,
including accounts that have municipal liens filed against them, is $2.3
million. Some customers have not paid their bills in a decade, Vojtek said.

He added that Erie Water Works received $55,500 in payments from delinquent
customers in the wake of a Jan. 19 Erie Times-News story on the city's problems
with delinquent garbage accounts.

A list of accounts that were delinquent at that time was posted at
GoErie.com/garbagebills.

Vojtek said Erie Water Works is committed to working with city officials.

"Our staff ... we hate to see people become scofflaws or thumb their noses at
our collection practices," Vojtek said.

He said the Water Works solicitor, Tim Sennett, will look into the legality of
shutting off customers' water service because of delinquent garbage bills, if
water/sewer/refuse is combined into one bill.

City Council, at its regular meeting Wednesday, also passed a resolution asking
City Solicitor Greg Karle to look into whether the city can legally require all
landlords seeking a rental unit license with the city to be current on all taxes
and fees, including garbage. That includes those who currently hold rental
licenses.

Council will continue the discussion at its next Finance Committee meeting,
scheduled for March 5.

KEVIN FLOWERS can be reached at 870-1693 or by e-mail. Follow him on Twitter at
twitter.com/ETNflowers.

___ (c)2014 the Erie Times-News (Erie, Pa.) Visit the Erie Times-News (Erie,
Pa.) at www.GoErie.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

                             107 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         The Daily News of Los Angeles

                           February 3, 2011 Thursday
                                 VALLEY EDITION

Late taxpayers pay up $5.3M;
WEBSITE: City controller posted names of delinquent residents.

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A4

LENGTH: 199 words


City Controller Wendy Greuel announced Wednesday that her office had collected
more than $5.3 million in delinquent taxes over the past year.

A total of 38 taxpayers agreed to pay the taxes after the city posted a list of
overdue taxes at finance.lacity.org/delinquent.htm. Greuel said she hoped that
publicizing the names of those who are delinquent on their taxes will prompt
them to pay what is owed.

"I'm pleased that we were able to collect more than $5.33 million since the
inception of the program," Greuel said. "With over $200 million in delinquent
taxes still to be collected, we will remain vigilant in cracking down on tax
cheats.

"Cheating on your taxes may seem appealing in the short term, but costing the
city puts an unfair burden on millions of law-abiding Angelenos."

In addition to the collections, Greuel said her office has filed cases against
57 others, seeking back taxes of more than $40 million.

VICA President Stuart Waldman, who has called for the creation of a city office
that would deal solely with collections, praised Greuel's efforts.

"VICA is impressed with the progress that has been made," said Waldman, whose
group represents businesses in the San Fernando Valley.

                             108 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                  April 16, 1993, Friday, Late Edition - Final

Topics of The Times;
Zapping Delinquents on TV

SECTION: Section A; Page 30; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 183 words


Tax collectors for Fairfax County, Va., across the Potomac River from
Washington, D.C., don't have computer resources to match the mighty Internal
Revenue Service in the pursuit of delinquents. But they have television -- and a
clever producer.

This week the county launched a 10-minute cable TV show called "Tax Evaders!"
with the names and addresses of more than 100 county tax delinquents writ large
on the screen. Just to be sure no one missed the point, the names were paired
with pictures of county deputies seizing automobiles and auctioning off houses.
And there was a "delinquent taxpayer" with a big black dot obscuring her face.

It is not unusual for newspapers to publish lists of delinquents, but
embarrassment by video adds a whole new dimension. Fairfax County claims 72,000
individuals and businesses are overdue in their payments on real estate taxes,
personal property taxes or business licenses. But to qualify for "Tax Evaders!"
you have to be at least two years behind. Even citizens who yearn for a moment
in TV's spotlight may want to avoid this form of celebrity.

LOAD-DATE: April 16, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

                   Copyright 1993 The New York Times Company


                             109 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           Pittsburgh Tribune Review

                             June 1, 2013 Saturday

Monessen loses on housing

BYLINE: by KATE WILCOX

LENGTH: 435 words


Monessen officials say a perfect storm of lost industry and a plummeting
population has saddled the city with an unwelcome distinction - more than half
of the 539 properties in Westmoreland County's repository of tax-delinquent
parcels are in the struggling river town.

Although other communities with comparable or larger populations, such as
Jeannette and New Kensington, have weathered crippling economic blows, Monessen,
with 7,700 residents, has nearly 12 times the number of parcels - 273 - in the
list of delinquent properties.

Real estate that is at least two years delinquent on local and county taxes and
has been put up for sheriff's sale, but not sold, is listed.

Although Monessen has attempted to demolish its blocks of ramshackle, sometimes
collapsing residential and commercial buildings, city officials say there is not
enough money to raze every blighted structure.

Westmoreland County Commissioner Charles Anderson said the success of one town
over another comes down to a community's mindset and the ability of a mayor and
council to make difficult decisions.

For Monessen to pull out of its spiral, two things must happen, according to Liz
Hersh, executive director of the Pennsylvania Housing Alliance.

Strict code enforcement is crucial, along with careful crafting of a process to
obtain delinquent properties then demolish or rehabilitate them, Hersh said.

"The biggest failure (comes with) not trying," she said.

Monessen's attempt to deal with its blighted properties has divided the
community and sparked bitter political skirmishes that many believe resulted in
Mayor Mary Jo Smith's defeat in last month's primary election.

Smith was the leading proponent of a controversial plan called "Monessen
Rising," which called for buying the delinquent parcels from the county then
reselling them to artists looking for low-cost properties where they can live,
work and sell their wares.

Smith and other officials enlisted the aid of two Staten Island, N.Y.,
developers, who met stiff opposition along with jeers and shouts at public
meetings where they discussed the plan.

Brian Jensen, executive director of the Pennsylvania Economy League of  Greater
Pittsburgh, agreed that "once a particular house gets blighted, there's a
tendency for that rot to spread."

Monessen's aging population has played a role, according to city administrator
John Harhai, who on a recent tour of the city pointed to a house that belonged
to an elderly woman who moved out of the state.

"They can't sell it, can't afford to keep it up," Harhai said.

Kate Wilcox is a staff writer for Trib Total Media.

                             110 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             March 21, 2010 Sunday

Delinquent refuse customers cost Erie: City looks at how to collect unpaid trash
bills

BYLINE: Mike Maciag, Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 756 words


Mar. 21--For many people and businesses in Erie, unpaid garbage bills haven't
stopped piling up for years.

Five hundred property owners with the highest delinquencies have racked up more
than $555,000 in overdue refuse and penalties, an Erie Times-News analysis of
collection data has found.

Their bills account for just under half of the more than $1.2 million owed to
the city in delinquent refuse payments.

Some city officials began proposing ideas to recoup money from these and other
delinquent refuse customers after the newspaper published an initial report in
January.

"These are people who intentionally did not pay for several years," Council
President Jim Thompson said. "They are costing the rest of the good people in
the city money."

The review of refuse data -- obtained in mid-February from Erie Water Works,
which collects the fees -- showed the top 100 refuse customers owed from $1,288
to $13,341 at a time when city budgets have tightened.

In all, the city was owed $1,213,749 in overdue refuse payments and penalties at
the end of February. Up to 5,000 accounts were considered delinquent, according
to Water Works, which is paid to manage billing for the city.

Erie landlord Louis Vomero is the property owner with the highest delinquency
total, according to billing records.

Eleven accounts in his name owed a total of $13,342 as of Friday.

When reached by phone, Vomero said several of his tenants were behind in paying
their refuse bills. With liens already filed against many of his properties,
Vomero said, he plans to take delinquent tenants to court.

"I'm doing the best I can to get them paid," he said.

Still, Vomero and other landlords in his situation, not their tenants, are on
the hook for the bills.

Records show that seven of Vomero's 11 delinquent properties owe an average of
$1,464, which reflects more than seven years of unpaid bills. One property
account is currently billed $48 per quarter.

Nearly all of the outstanding refuse bills are from residents or landlords who
live in Erie. Of the total owed for accounts at least two payments behind, only
about 3 percent of customers list billing addresses outside Erie County.

It's the property owners with the highest tabs who Thompson thinks the city
should target.

"People don't care because they don't think anything will happen," he said.

Others might have been misled. Thompson said some people were given the
impression many years ago that they didn't have to pay garbage bills.

Garbage collection is not stopped for delinquencies, so bills can continue to
pile up. Water and sewer services, though, are often terminated for delinquent
customers.

"It's very difficult to maintain any level of delinquency when you really have
no teeth in the collection policy," said Paul Vojtek, Erie Water Works' chief
executive.

Customers are charged a 1.5 percent penalty per month on delinquent accounts.
Once warning notices have been sent and a property is at least $250 delinquent,
Water Works typically places a lien on a property, Vojtek said.

Thompson said the city should first look to make sure liens are placed on
delinquent properties and set a limit for when they're used.

"It's something that has to be more aggressively looked at," he said.

Erie Water Works had filed about $561,000 in unpaid liens against delinquent
properties as of the end of February.

Some of the highest tabs belong to area landlords.

To entice them to pay up, the city had considered imposing penalties, including
nonrenewal of rental licenses.

But the city's finance director, Paul Lichtenwalter, said it is not legally
possible to rescind a rental licensee because of a refuse delinquency.

Councilwoman Jessica Horan-Kunco asked the City Solicitor's Office to explore
hiring a collection agency to force delinquent property owners to pay up.

"A collection agency would be aggressive about getting these collected," she
said.

If nothing is done, Horan-Kunco fears overdue refuse payments will only continue
to climb.

"It's important to try to figure out a strategy to combat these delinquencies,"
she said. "We can't just accept it."

MIKE MACIAG can be reached at 870-1776 or by e-mail.

                             111 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                             El Paso Times (Texas)

                           February 12, 2008 Tuesday

Caples building again on delinquent-tax list

BYLINE: By David Crowder / El Paso Times

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 345 words


El Paso City Council members went on a collective rant about some of the
community's major delinquent taxpayers during a briefing on the subject Tuesday.

Topping the list of the city's least-favorite property owners is William "Billy"
Abraham, whom the city, acting on behalf of other taxing entities, has sued
repeatedly.

"There's a pattern," tax lawyer Carmen Perez said of Abraham and other owners.
"The taxes were delinquent, we sued, they paid and then they went delinquent
again."

For the second time in the past five years, Abraham is the owner of a property,
the Caples Building, that has made the list of the state's most-endangered
historic properties compiled by Preservation Texas Inc., a nonprofit based in
Austin.

The nonprofit's Web site describes the Caples Building at 300 E. San Antonio --
designed by Henry C. Trost and built to five stories in 1909 -- as the 1910 home
of Francisco Madero's provisional Mexican government and now in serious
disrepair.

The city has sued Abraham twice over that property and collected $43,947. The
city has a new suit pending over $109,408 in back taxes, penalties and interest.

"The Caples Building is the most egregious example of abuse," said West-Central
city Rep. Susie Byrd. "I think we need to do something different than what we
have done because what we have done hasn't worked."

Perez said that under Texas law there is little to do except to make not paying
taxes on time so expensive that owners pay up.

Abraham later said he pays the city more than $350,000 a year on the Caples
Building and other properties while contesting the valuations and the tax bills
he regards as unfair.

"These people are trying to portray me as some jerk who doesn't pay his property
taxes, and that is not accurate," he said. "I love this city and I am very proud
to be a descendant of the Caples family. Of the dozen or so Trost buildings my
company owns É none is more important to me than the Caples Building."

He said those buildings "are all earmarked for renovation."

David Crowder may be reached at dcrowder@elpasotimes.com; 546-6194

                         Portland Press Herald (Maine)

                            August 5, 1996, Monday,

SEVERAL PROPERTIES DELINQUENT FOR 20 YEARS

BYLINE: From staff reports

SECTION: FRONT, Pg. 10A

LENGTH: 383 words


Taxes on some Portland properties have been in arrears as long as 20 years.

Linda McLeod of the city's Treasury Department said long-delinquent properties
often are wetlands or vacant property that cannot be built on. Because they have
little market value, such properties have been hard for the city to sell.

Here, according to the city, are the 10 property owners with the oldest unpaid
property taxes:

Jordan & Hammond Inc. Delinquent since 1976. Owes $ 3,589 on lots at 9-13 and
10-12 Aspen Drive. No known address; could not be reached for comment.

Elmer F. Holding. Delinquent since 1976. Owes $ 1,460 on a lot at 2-14 Berry St.
No known address; could not be reached for comment.

Merrill Y. Stephens, 164 Coyle St., Portland. Delinquent since 1976. Owes $ 722
on 9,325 square feet on Greenville Avenue.

''I haven't even thought about it for 20 years, so I can't even tell you about
it,'' Stephens said when asked about the land. Stephens said he did not know why
he hadn't paid the property taxes. ''I'd just as soon get rid of it; I thought
they'd already taken it,'' he said, referring to the city.

Mark & Mary E. Gollance. Delinquent since 1976. Owe $ 609 on two Villa Avenue
lots. No known address; could not be reached for comment.

George L. Curtis. Delinquent since 1976. Owes $ 313 on 2,262 square feet of land
at 1780 Washington Ave.No known address; could not be reached for comment.

Leo Warner. Delinquent since 1976. Owes $ 118 on 200 square feet at 110 Congress
St. No known address; could not be reached for comment.

Philip E. Hamlin Devel. Delinquent since 1976. Owes $ 46 on a small piece of
property at 92 Caron St. with an assessed value of $ 90. No known address; could
not be reached for comment.

Philip E. Hamlin Devel. Delinquent since 1977. Owes $ 132 on two bits of land at
79 and 80 Caron St. with a total assessed value of $ 270. No known address;
could not be reached for comment.

John D. O'Rourke heirs. Delinquent since 1979. Owe $ 968 on 17,533 square feet
of land on Luther Avenue on Peaks Island. No known address; could not be reached
for comment.

Sadie Messer Fisher heirs. Delinquent since 1979. Owe $ 927 on 4,000 square feet
of land at 87-89 Riggs St. No known address; could not be reached for comment.

                             113 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Monitor (McAllen, Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            October 27, 2009 Tuesday

McAllen school board switches firms to collect delinquent taxes

BYLINE: Jennifer L. Berghom, The Monitor, McAllen, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 499 words


Oct. 27--MCALLEN -- The school district will have a new firm collecting its
delinquent taxes Nov. 1.

Members of the McAllen school board voted via closed ballot Monday to select
Perdue, Brandon, Fielder Collins and Mott, which is in a partnership with
attorney John David Franz, to collect levies that were not paid on time. The
decision ends a decade-long contract with Linebarger, Goggan, Blair & Sampson, a
national firm with a local office in Edinburg.

McAllen attorney and Hidalgo Mayor John David Franz has a partnership with
Perdue Brandon, which has offices throughout the state of Texas.

"We're excited at the prospect for working with the MISD," Franz said after the
meeting.

Franz said he plans to start the transition process with the school district
Tuesday and hopes to be fully ready to take over delinquent tax collections by
Nov. 1, when the contract is expected to begin. Franz said his firm's
compensation rate would be 15 percent.

"I'm very proud. I'm a McAllen High School graduate, I have ties to the area, my
law office in McAllen. I'm very happy the school district though enough of us
and our firm (to select them)," Franz said.

Representatives from Linebarger referred comments to their spokesman in the
Washington, D.C., area.

"We are disappointed but we certainly respect the decision of (the board)," said
Joe Householder, a spokesman of the firm.

He also said the firm views that the work it has done for the McAllen school
district and all of its clients in the Rio Grande Valley have been a service to
them and the firm looks forward to continuing that work.

The school board originally voted at its Oct. 13 meeting to renew its contract
with Linebarger after representatives from Perdue Brandon revealed that some
delinquent taxpayers were overcharged legal fees related to the collections.
School district and Linebarger representatives said the overcharge was the
result of a miscommunication as to who was supposed to contact the county's tax
assessor-collector, with whom the district contracts to calculate how much money
is due.

But at a special called meeting the following week, the board decided to rescind
that vote and find out how the miscommunication happened and interview the firms
again.

In total, about 1,200 delinquent account holders overpaid more than $78,000.
Linebarger gave the district a check at its Oct. 20 special meeting a check for
the overpayment plus interest. The school district will be reimbursing those
taxpayers.

Jennifer L. Berghom covers education and general assignments for The Monitor.
She can be reached at (956) 683-4462.

To see more of The Monitor, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.themonitor.com. Copyright (c) 2009, The Monitor, McAllen, Texas

to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

LOAD-DATE: October 27, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ACC-NO: 20091027-MC-McAllen-school-board-switches-firms-to-collect-delinquent

                     Valley Morning Star (Harlingen, Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          December 15, 2010 Wednesday

Law firm: $2M owed in delinquent city property taxes

BYLINE: Jacqueline Armendariz, Valley Morning Star, Harlingen, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 686 words


Dec. 15--HARLINGEN -- The law firm contracted to collect delinquent city
property taxes reported $2 million owed to the city this past fiscal year.

The firm, Linebarger Goggan, Blair & Sampson, is set to make a presentation on
the subject at the 5:30 p.m. City Commission meeting today, while other
financial matters are discussed.

The firm collected 31.4 percent of the city's $2 million in delinquent taxes, or
$645,284, for the past fiscal year, exclusive of penalties and interest on the
taxes owed, according to the company's report.

John Guevara, a lawyer based at the law firm's Brownsville office, said
delinquent tax collections are consistent each year.

He explained further that at the end of each fiscal year, any outstanding taxes
are tacked onto the delinquent tax roll, which explains why it seems the amount
doesn't decrease year after year.

The law firm's collection of delinquent taxes has hovered around 30 percent
since at least 2006, as has the amount of delinquent taxes at around $2 million
with slight increases and decreases through the years, city documents show.

For example, in fiscal year 2006 the city was owed $1.9 million with about
$610,410, excluding penalties and interest, collected on the city's behalf.

But, in fiscal year 2007, the amount owed was $2 million and the amount
collected was $599,899. The next fiscal year, the amount owed was $1.9 million
and the amount collected was $626,770.

"One important thing here is that when you see revenue either decrease or
increase it's because of the economy," Guevara said of the unpaid city property
taxes. "This particular revenue stream has been increasing over the years. Every
year there's more collections."

Guevara acknowledged that his law firm sometimes sells homes that are delinquent
, but said that the number of homes sold is minimal compared to the number of
taxpayers who are helped by setting up payment plans to satisfy tax obligations.

"Times are tough," Guevara said. "We try to work with people, put them on
payment plans. The important thing to note is that people should not ignore
their taxes. Contact our office. That's critical."

Guevara said most of the properties sold are vacant lots or abandoned
properties, while most property owners in debt choose to accept a payment plan.

The legal process for bringing a property to sale for delinquent taxes is
complicated and "a whole other story," Guevara said.

As for the other financial matters to be discussed at the City Commission
meeting today, the Economic Development Corporation will increase its 2010-2011
fiscal year budgeted revenues and expenditures from about $5.3 million to about
$7.5 million.

Roel Gutierrez, finance director for the city, said the EDC had $2 million in
unused budgeted expenditures from last fiscal year.

Meanwhile, the city will amend its 2010-2011 fiscal year budget to include
funding for a new part-time municipal court clerk.

The city will also amend its budget to include services or items that were
outstanding as of Sept. 30, 2010, and grants that were not yet accounted for
when the budget was finalized.

The city general fund's budgeted revenues will increase by $658,587 and
expenditures will increase by $1.1 million from September 2010 projected
revenues of $36.9 million and $36.9 million in expenses.

Gutierrez said revenues will increase to $37.5 million and expenses will
increase to $38 million, with the small difference made up by a portion of the
general fund's fund balance of an estimated $11 million.

The Downtown District will also increase its budgeted expenditures for the
2010-2011 fiscal year by $26,520, to make a total of $289,587.

The increase is a result of carryover from grant expenditures given to local
businesses in the district from the previous fiscal year.

To see more of the Valley Morning Star, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.valleystar.com. Copyright (c) 2010, Valley Morning Star, Harlingen,
Texas Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For more
information about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information
Services (MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com.

                                US Official News

                           September 8, 2016 Thursday

Relating to quarterly payment of real and personal property taxes

LENGTH: 701  words

DATELINE: New York



 Charleston: The State of West Virginia has issued the following bill status:
 LAST ACTION:     H To House Finance 01/13/16

 SUMMARY:     Relating to quarterly payment of real and personal property taxes

 LEAD SPONSOR:     Rodighiero

 SPONSORS:     Marcum
 West Virginia Legislature



 2016 Regular Session



 Introduced



 House Bill 2400



 2015 Carryover



 (By Delegates Rodighiero and Marcum)





 [Introduced January 13, 2016; referred to the



 Committee on Finance.]



















 A BILL to amend and reenact §11Aâ[#x20ac]'1â[#x20ac]'3 of the Code of West
Virginia, 1931, as amended, relating to quarterly payment of real and personal
property taxes; and requiring new tax tickets to be mailed after property is
transferred.



 Be it enacted by the Legislature of West Virginia:



 That §11Aâ[#x20ac]'1â[#x20ac]'3 of the Code of West Virginia, 1931, as amended,
be amended and reenacted to read as follows:



 ARTICLE 1.  ACCRUAL AND COLLECTION OF TAXES.



 §11Aâ[#x20ac]'1â[#x20ac]'3.  Accrual; time for payment; interest on delinquent
taxes.



 (a) (1) All current taxes assessed on real and personal property may be paid in
two installments.  The first installment shall be is payable on September 1 of
the year for which the assessment is made, and shall become becomes delinquent
on October 1; the second installment shall be is payable on the first day of
following March 1 and shall become becomes delinquent on April 1.  Taxes paid on
or before the date when they are payable, including both first and second
installments, shall be are subject to a discount of two and oneâ[#x20ac]'half
percent.  If taxes are not paid on or before the date on which they become
delinquent, including both first and second installments, interest at the rate
of nine percent per annum shall be added from the date they become delinquent
until paid.



 (2) Beginning July 1, 2015, current taxes assessed on real and personal
property may be paid in quarterly installments.  The first quarterly installment
is payable on September 1 of the year for which the assessment is made, and
becomes delinquent on October 1; the second quarterly installment is payable on
the following January 1 and becomes delinquent on February 1; the third
installment is payable on the following March 1 and becomes delinquent on April
1; the fourth installment is payable on the following August 1 and becomes
delinquent on September 1. Taxes paid on or before the date when they are
payable, including both first and second installments, are subject to a discount
of two and oneâ[#x20ac]'half percent.  If taxes are not paid on or before the
date on which they become delinquent, including both first and second
installments, interest at the rate of nine percent per annum shall be added from
the date they become delinquent until paid.



 (b) With regard to real and personal property taxes, when any return, claim,
statement or other document is required to be filed, or any payment is required
to be made within a prescribed period or before a prescribed date, and the
applicable law requires delivery to the office of the sheriff of a county of
this state, the methods prescribed in section fiveâ[#x20ac]'f, article ten,
chapter eleven of this code for timely filing and payment to the Tax
Commissioner or Department of Tax and Revenue shall be the same methods utilized
used for timely filing and payment with such the sheriff.  Nothing contained in
this subsection (b) shall prohibit prohibits the sheriff from establishing
additional methods of payment in accordance with the provisions of section
eightâ[#x20ac]'a of this article.



 (c) For property which is transferred from grantor to grantee, the assessor
shall, within three months of the filing of the deed in the county clerk's
office, notify the sheriff who shall prepare a new tax ticket and mail it to the
new property owner.











 NOTE:  The purpose of this bill is to allow quarterly payment of real and
personal property taxes and to require new tax tickets to be mailed after
property is transferred.







 Strikeâ[#x20ac]'throughs indicate language that would be stricken from the
present law, and underscoring indicates new language that would be added.

contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                                Payments Source

                              June 12, 2015 Friday

Agency Hired to Collect Town's Delinquent Vehicle Taxes

BYLINE: Darren Waggoner

SECTION: CCR - DEALS & PRICING Vol. 1 No. 1

LENGTH: 358  words


Town officials in Manchester, Conn. have hired a collection agency to pursue
people who are delinquent on their motor vehicle taxes.

TaxServ will collect taxes that are more than four years overdue. Town officials
say that while Manchester has a strong tax collection rate, delinquent motor
vehicle bills often have proven much more difficult to collect, especially if
the vehicles are taken out of the state, said John Rainaldi, Manchester's
director of assessment and collection.Â

TaxServ is based in McLean, Va. and has offices in Florida and Hartford, Conn.

Unpaid vehicle taxes that were due in 2011 total roughly $6 million, including
interest. Hiring the collection agency should not cost taxpayers money because
the fees the company expects to earn will be added to the bills they collect.
Rainaldi added that almost all of the delinquent taxes are owed by people who
have moved and left the state.

TaxServ does collection work for several other Connecticut municipalities -
including Hartford, Waterbury, Danbury, Canton and Durham. According to the 2010
Census, Manchester has approximately 58,000 residents.

Â

Manchester had used a different collection agency in the past but that contract
ended several years ago. Town leaders at that time chose not to pursue a new
agreement because of the struggling economy.

Â

Municipalities throughout the U.S. increasingly are turning to third-party
agencies to collect outstanding fees, fines and accounts.

Â

In April, Sean Sander, director of Revenue and Recovery, County of San Diego,
Calif., was the featured speaker for abest practices in government collections
Web seminarhosted by Collections & Credit Risk and sponsored by FICO. The event
focused on the unique challenges faced by state, county and municipal
governments when working to resolve constituents' delinquencies. Sander
discussed how governments can navigate limited resources and shifting mandates
and still improve efficiencies.Â

Â

The County of San Diego is considered one of the most award-winning and
innovative government agencies in the U.S. and is the nation's fifth-most
populous county, with more than three million residents.

Â
