                     Valley Morning Star (Harlingen, Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          February 14, 2007 Wednesday

County may seek new tax law firm: Cascos, commissioners favor proposals from law
firms charging cheaper attorneys' fees

BYLINE: Allen Essex, Valley Morning Star, Harlingen, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 646 words


Feb. 14--BROWNSVILLE -- A statewide tax collection law firm that has collected
delinquent taxes for Cameron County and other governmental bodies since 1986 may
soon have competition.

Representatives of Linebarger Goggan Blair & Sampson learned that county
officials plan to seek proposals from other law firms later this year.

The Linebarger firm merged in 1998 with its main competitor, Heard Goggan Blair
& Williams, which had had Cameron County contracts since 1986.

The Heard and Linebarger law firms also have collected current property taxes
for Harlingen and the Harlingen school district for many years, Cameron County
Tax Assessor-Collector Tony Yzaguirre said.

County Judge Carlos Cascos and commissioners agreed to favor proposals from law
firms willing to charge 10 percent attorneys' fees on tax cases, rather than the
20 percent now being charged by the Linebarger firm.

State law was amended two years ago by the Legislature, changing the maximum
attorney fees to be charged on each delinquent tax lawsuit filed from 15 percent
to 20 percent, Yzaguirre said. "But they can charge less, if they want to," he
said.

Commissioners also agreed to choose a law firm to collect delinquent taxes that
does not also collect current taxes.

Cameron County now collects current property taxes for 28 taxing entities,
including itself, Yzaguirre said.

The Linebarger firm's contract to collect delinquent taxes for 28 out of 38
taxing districts in the county is a lucrative business, Yzaguirre said.

"Last year, they made a little over $1 million," Yzaguirre said. "The year
before it was $980,000 and the year before, it was $950,000."

But the law firm actually loses money collecting current taxes for the city of
Harlingen and Harlingen school district, he said.

Yzaguirre said Wednesday the State Comptroller's Office considers it a conflict
of interest for a company to collect both delinquent and current taxes.

"If they don't do a good job collecting current taxes, they can make more filing
delinquent tax lawsuits," he said. "We can't compete (on current tax
collections) because they are a huge firm."

Joe Householder, spokesman for the Linebarger firm, claims the firm's efficiency
saves money for the counties, cities and school districts it serves.

The firm does an excellent job of collecting both current and delinquent taxes,
he said.

"When Linebarger Goggan Blair & Sampson contract to do a job, they strive 100
percent to do the best possible job that can be done," he said.

He declined to comment on the county's plans to advertise for competitors.

"We haven't seen the (request for proposals) yet because I understand it's still
being developed," he said. "It's a legal and very public process. We respect the
county's right to go through the process."

"Over the last three fiscal years, our firm has collected over $10 million in
delinquent base tax, penalty and interest and current delinquent taxes," states
the law firm's report, presented by attorneys Lucy G. Canales and John D.
Guevara.

"Base tax collections rose 10 percent from tax year 2003 to 2004 and 16 percent
from tax year 2004 to 2005," the report states.

Their firm has collected about $1 million in "current-delinquent taxes" in each
of the last three years, the report states.

"The county has raised the goal considerably in the last four years," Guevara
said.

There are presently 30,864 delinquent tax accounts in Cameron County, the law
firm's report states.

"A lot of those accounts, we may have already filed lawsuits on, or they may now
be in bankruptcy," Canales said to commissioners.

                       The Day (New London, Connecticut)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            October 9, 2010 Saturday

State offering delinquent lottery agents a break

BYLINE: Brian Hallenbeck, The Day, New London, Conn.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 389 words


Oct. 09--Delinquent lottery agents owe the state around $1 million in ticket
sales -- more, apparently, than the cash-strapped state can afford to ignore.

The state Division of Special Revenue launched an amnesty program Friday in an
effort to collect the debt. Under the program, spelled out in legislation
enacted this spring by the General Assembly, delinquent lottery agents who
receive notification letters will have 60 days to pay any outstanding principal
and penalties they owe as well as 50 percent of the interest on their debt. The
state will forgive the remaining 50 percent of the interest.

Paul Young, the division's executive director, puts the amount of the delinquent
sales "in the neighborhood" of $1 million, some of which could date back to the
1990s. He estimated that about 400 agents -- or former agents -- are currently
delinquent, a number, he said, that does not suggest a chronic problem.

"We've never done this before, so I have no feel for how much we might recover,"
Young said. "We're in uncharted waters."

When an agent fails to forward to the Connecticut Lottery Corp. money he
collects in ticket sales, the division summons the agent to a hearing at which
it establishes a settlement plan, Young said. The agent either pays up, agrees
to pay according to the plan or faces collection efforts.

"We put liens on property and attempt to attach wages, if necessary," Young
said.

The first notification letters went out Friday and more will follow next week.
According to the legislation, all former and current delinquent agents must be
notified by Nov. 1. Those who agree to participate in the program must pay up by
Dec. 31. All debts collected by the division are to be deposited in the state's
General Fund.

Those who believe they may be eligible for the program may contact the division
by e-mail at dosr@po.state.ct.us or by phone at (860) 594-0650.

b.hallenbeck@theday.com

                       Florida Times-Union (Jacksonville)

                             June 30, 2011 Thursday

A.M. BRIEFING

SECTION: Pg. D-1

LENGTH: 533 words


SERIOUSLY DELINQUENT MORTGAGE LOANS DROP

News on the nation's foreclosure front appears to be improving, as the number of
seriously delinquent mortgage loans continued to drop in May and foreclosure
starts dropped by nearly 17 percent compared with May 2010.

Year to year, mortgage delinquencies fell by more than 18.3 percent and
seriously delinquent mortgages - behind by three months or more - fell by
slightly more than 10 percent, LPS Applied Analytics, a subsidiary of Lender
Processing Services Inc., reported. The number of mortgage holders who are
delinquent on their loans by two years or more is climbing as financial
institutions take longer to process foreclosures, but those behind by 23 months
or less continue to drop.

Overall, 4.1 percent of all homes nationwide were in some stage of foreclosure,
a 0.7 percent drop from April but a 12.3 percent increase from May 2010.

Kevin Turner

CLINTON ANNOUNCES 1,000 JOBS FOR JOPLIN

CHICAGO - Former President Bill Clinton has some good jobs news for Joplin, Mo.,
as it works to recover from a devastating tornado.

Clinton is in Chicago for the Clinton Global Initiative conference. On
Wednesday, the Democrat announced that a technology company has promised to
create 1,000 jobs in rural Missouri over the next five years with a focus on
Joplin.

The company is Onshore Technology Services.

Clinton says the company eventually plans to create 12,000 new jobs in the
coming decade in other parts of rural America.

Associated Press

GOLDMAN SACHS PLANS TO LAY OFF 230 WORKERS

NEW YORK - Goldman Sachs Group Inc. said Wednesday that it could lay off as many
as 230 workers in New York by next spring.

The investment firm notified the New York State Department of Labor of the
possible layoffs in a notice filed on Wednesday. In the filing, Goldman said the
layoffs would happen between now and March 31. The company simply cited economic
reasons for the layoffs.

Goldman Sachs has about 35,000 employees worldwide. David Wells, a spokesman for
Goldman, declined to provide further details on the layoffs.

The layoffs would be in addition to the company's annual firing of workers who
perform in the bottom 5 percent.

Goldman Sachs in April reported that its first-quarter income fell 72 percent to
$908 million.

Associated Press

PILOT APOLOGIZES FOR GAY, FAT, OLD REMARKS

DALLAS - The Southwest Airlines Co. pilot who insulted gays and older workers in
an open-mike rant has apologized.

The 12-year veteran of the Dallas-based airline, James Taylor of Argyle, Texas,
was caught on an open cockpit mike using slurs and profanity to complain that
attendants were mostly gay or too old or too heavy for him to date. The comments
went out over an air-traffic control frequency.

Taylor said in an email that Southwest distributed this week to employees that
the comments were "truly insensitive of me and I would like all of you to know
that from now on, I will show nothing but the utmost respect during my
interactions with all employees."

Taylor said the incident had "forever changed me and I hope that others can
learn from my mistake."

The flight attendants' union dropped plans to file a complaint with the U.S.
Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

                            nationalmortgagenews.com

                                February 2, 2016

CMBS Delinquency Rate Improves on Stuy Town Resolution

BYLINE: Andy Peters

SECTION: SERVICING Vol. 1 No. 1

LENGTH: 242  words


The delinquency rate on commercial mortgage-backed securities dropped sharply in
January, thanks to the resolution of New York's Stuyvesant Town loan, according
to Trepp.

The rate of U.S. commercial real estate loans embedded in CMBS that were
delinquent fell 82 basis points in January to 4.35%, compared to December, Trepp
said. The delinquency rate is 131 basis points lower than the rate of 5.66% a
year earlier.

The improvement was primarily attributable to the resolution of the $3 billion
loan on the Stuyvesant Town/Peter Cooper housing development in Manhattan. An
additional $300 million of loans were also cured in January.

About $1.7 billion of CMBS loans became newly delinquent in January. The largest
newly delinquent loan in the quarter was a $126 million loan attached to the Two
Gateway office complex in Newark, N.J. Also going delinquent in the quarter was
a $62 million loan for the Stamford Marriott hotel in Stamford, Conn., and a $62
million loan on the Chesapeake Square retail complex in Chesapeake, Va.

Total delinquencies stood at $23.5 billion.

The industrial CMBS delinquency rate rose 23 basis points to 5.96%, while the
lodging delinquency rate was unchanged at 2.82%.

The multifamily delinquency rate plunged 597 basis points to 2.31%. Apartment
loans are now the best performing major property type.

The office property delinquency rate fell 55 basis points to 5.24% and the
retail delinquency rate fell 14 basis points to 5.62%.

                             121 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                              Credit Union Journal

                                August 23, 2010

Solution Helps Attack Delinquencies Before They Become Write-Offs

BYLINE: Kevin Jepson, Technology Correspondent

SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Pg. 12 Vol. 14 No. 34

LENGTH: 659  words


ST. LOUIS, Mo.-Anheuser-Busch Employees' CU (ABECU) is making more than 45
collections calls per hour to members with early-delinquent auto loans, lines of
credit and credit cards, helping to nip late delinquencies in the bud.

Better yet, the calls are triggered by targeted collections software that links
members with multiple delinquent loans so that collectors can address total debt
in one call, according to Virgil Mueller, VP-credit and collections at the
$1.3-billion CU here.

The software is part of TotalCollections, a new solution from St. Petersburg,
Fla.-based PSCU Financial Services. The solution combines automated, interactive
calls with manned campaigns to help collect on any delinquent loan.

"TotalCollections is making many more phone calls and contacts than we could
possibly make with the 10 people in our internal collections staff, and they can
make the calls cheaper," said Mueller. Mueller said he could not quantify the
difference in volume of calls or the difference for cost per call.

In June, TotalCollections made more than 7,000 early-delinquent collections
attempts for ABECU, with nearly 370 successful contacts representing more than
1,200 accounts, Mueller said.

ABECU looks to TotalCollections to help reduce its growing number of
early-delinquency loans, he continued. "No matter how we do the accounting,
delinquencies go against our bottom line. We expect TotalCollections will stem
the increase in early delinquencies so that our internal staff will be able to
handle late delinquencies."

Early-delinquency collection calls weren't practical for ABECU before
TotalCollections. "There are too many 10-day delinquencies for us to call,"
Mueller explained. About 400 to 700 loans are early-delinquent at any time,
depending on the time of month, he said.

"We used to send them an automated letter," he said. "But calls act as the
squeaky wheel to get the member's attention. The sooner you can get to the
member, the sooner you can set up a repayment schedule."

ABECU sets the criteria for delinquent loans addressed by TotalCollections, with
calls scheduled for auto and signature loans and lines of credit that are about
16 to 35 days delinquent, said Mueller. Calls scheduled for credit card loans
are 10 days up to 55 days delinquent. All loans targeted have a balance of at
least $700.

The CU uploads flagged accounts from its Akcelerant collections solution, where
members are linked to multiple delinquent loans, into the TotalCollections
solution for collections calls. "We can accommodate any credit union's
collections system, however," according to Bryan Scalise, collections analyst at
PSCU.

Automated calls with an ABECU-branded digital message are placed to members'
home phones. In cases where no contact is made, live collectors determine
whether to follow-up with calls to work or home numbers.

Whether contacted via digital call or a collections agent, members can choose to
make a payment on the spot. "Our Smart Collection strategy allows members to
make an urgency payment and give payment information over the phone," according
to Donna Floyd, PSCU collection relationship manager. Alternatively, members can
indicate they've already paid or promise to pay, and TotalCollections will
automatically stop all calls to those members.

Automated calls eliminate busy signals and "dead air" for collections agents,
said Scalise. "There's no unproductive time for the collector."

"In collections, you go through 10 to 15 dials before you even speak to
someone," Mueller said. "That ties up my collections staff. Auto-dialed calls
save the collector all that dialing time." If TotalCollections fails to reach
the debtor, the solution tries again, about three to four times per day.

Although ABECU is seeing fewer early-delinquent accounts and a lower delinquency
cycle in the two months it has used TotalCollections, Mueller said he's not sure
whether to attribute the results to TotalCollections or economic factors.

URL: http://www.cujournal.com/

LOAD-DATE: August 20, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newsletter

JOURNAL-CODE: CUJ

                             National Mortgage News

                                 June 10, 1991

Calif. CRE Delinquency Low

BYLINE: By STEPHEN P. PIZZO

SECTION: Pg. 1

LENGTH: 237 words

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif.


Only 77 or less than 1% of 8,741 commercial loans serviced by California
mortgage banking firms were delinquent by two months or more, according to the
California Mortgage Bankers Association.

By amount, the newest survey shows $ 577 million, or 2.3% of the $ 23.1 billion
in loans being serviced by the state's mortgage bankers, were two months or more
behind in payments.

Excluding the $ 184 million in loans in foreclosure, $ 393 million were
delinquent.

By comparison, the latest survey by the American Council of Life Insurance
Companies showed that as of December 31, 1990, 3.69% of loans in insurance
company portfolios were delinquent.  And Moody's reported that 3% of loans used
to back mortgage-backed securities were delinquent.

Specifically, $ 7.8 billion of the $ 211.4 billion of commercial property loans
in the portfolios of insurance companies nationwide were delinquent.

According to CMBA president Peter Ulrich, office buildings, hotel and motel
loans accounted for 51% of the total delinquent commercial property loans.

By type of property, he said, the lowest delinquencies were among apartment and
mobile home property loans.

The 77 delinquent loans surveyed were broken down into property type by the
CMBA; 27% were loans on office buildings; 23% hotels/motels; 18% R&D buildings;
12% retail properties; 8% warehouse/industrial; 6% apartments; and 6% loans on
mobile home parks.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1991 National Thrift News, Inc.

                     Deseret Morning News (Salt Lake City)

                            June 22, 2005 Wednesday

Foreclosure rates finally dip in Utah

BYLINE: Dave Anderton Deseret Morning News

LENGTH: 376 words


Fewer Utah homeowners found themselves facing foreclosure in first quarter,
mirroring a national trend of falling foreclosure rates.

Of the nearly 360,000 mortgage loans serviced in Utah for the three months ended
March 31, just 1.33 percent were in foreclosure, the lowest rate since the
fourth quarter of 2000 and down from 1.80 percent in the 2004 first quarter,
according to a quarterly national delinquency survey released Tuesday by the
Mortgage Bankers Association of America.

Utah's foreclosure rate in first quarter ranked 13th-highest in the nation, an
improvement from previous quarters when the state rated among the highest rates
in the country. Yet the state's average still is higher than the national rate
of 1.08 percent.

Ohio had the highest percent of loans in foreclosure at 3.37 percent. California
showed the lowest at 0.2 percent.

The five-state Pacific region -- including Alaska, California, Hawaii, Oregon
and Washington -- showed the lowest overall regional foreclosure rate at 0.31
percent.

The five-state East North Central region -- comprising Illinois, Indiana,
Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin -- had the highest rate at 2.08 percent.

Utah's delinquency rate -- mortgage loans 30 days or more past due -- declined
to 4 percent in first quarter, down from 4.62 percent in the fourth quarter and
also a decline from 4.4 percent during the first quarter of 2004.

For the first time, the MBA survey in the first quarter measured serious
delinquent loans -- defined as the percentage of loans that are 90 days or more
delinquent or in the process of foreclosure.

In Utah, serious delinquent loans were at 2.31 percent. Across the nation, 15
other states ranked higher in the percentage of serious delinquent loans.

Utah economists have attributed the state's falling foreclosure rate to strong
economic performance and rising real estate values.

Yet Utahns holding subprime mortgages were more likely to enter foreclosure. Of
nearly 40,000 subprime loans serviced in Utah in the first quarter, the
foreclosure rate reached 4.11 percent, nearly three times higher than the
overall state average of all loans serviced.

Nationally, the foreclosure rate of 1.08 percent in the first quarter was down
from 1.27 percent. E-mail: danderton@desnews.com

LOAD-DATE: June 22, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                 Copyright 2005 The Deseret News Publishing Co.


                             124 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                       Florida Times-Union (Jacksonville)

                           September 16, 2005 Friday

Commissioners warn of possible mail, real estate scam;
Some residents received letters from California investors warning of delinquent
taxes.

BYLINE: christina abel

SECTION: Pg. SU-37

LENGTH: 360 words


A possible real estate and mail fraud scam from California has targeted at least
two St. Johns County residents, including County Commission Chairman Bruce
Maguire.

At a Sept. 6 commissioner's meeting, Maguire warned the public about the
potential scam after he said he received about 15 letters postmarked from the
Property Tax Department in Irvine, Ca. The letters, signed by Scott Santos,
refer to Maguire's property identification numbers and imply that there are
delinquent taxes and liens on the properties.

Maguire said the county Tax Collectors Office assured him that he had no
delinquent taxes. He said he turned the letters over to the U.S. Postal Service
because of potential mail fraud. Maguire said he also thinks the letters could
be part of a real estate scam.

A St. Augustine couple received an identical letter about their property and
told the police and County Commissioner Ben Rich.

Rich said he knew what "the deal was" as soon as he heard about the letter.

The letters said, "If the Tax Collector sells your property at public auction or
if the lien holder chooses to foreclose when your parcel becomes too delinquent,
you could no longer own the property. However, I may be willing to pay you cash
for your property and pay all your delinquent taxes, interest, penalties and
fees before your property is lost."

The only business referred to in the letters is the Property Tax Department, but
the phone number is for a company called National Land Liquidations.

A woman who answered the phone at the company last week and would identify
herself only as Katie K., said the letters were sent out by mistake and that the
company was sorry for the mix-up.

Maguire was skeptical of this being a simple mistake.

He compared it to other situations in which developers purchase 60 to 70 houses,
then go out to investors in California and sell them 10 houses at a time, with
the investors never having seen the property.

"It's a big marketing scheme out in California and something like this may be
tied in. So if you get anything from California about buying your property, be
very careful," Maguire said.

christina.abel@jacksonville.com,

(904) 249-4947 ext. 19

                      Post-Bulletin (Rochester, Minnesota)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             March 20, 2009 Friday

Property owners delinquent on $1.4 million to Olmsted County

BYLINE: Laura Gossman, Post-Bulletin, Rochester, Minn.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 464 words


Mar. 20--Since the start of the housing crisis, developers have had a harder
time selling lots for new homes. And some homes currently for sale have been on
the market for months.

Compared to the 2007 listing, nearly twice as many Olmsted County property
owners have failed to pay their 2008 property taxes on time, but the total
amount the taxes due increased only 30 percent.

In 2007, there were 837 delinquent parcels published in Olmsted County, totaling
$1,069,368 in tax dollars. In 2008, the number jumped to 1,620 parcels totaling
$1,446,399 in tax dollars.

Olmsted County director of property records and revenue Mark Krupski said many
of the delinquent properties are vacant lots, so they don't accumulate a lot of
tax dollars.

"Developers are paying only the things they absolutely have to pay now, so they
choose to put property taxes aside," Krupski said. "I doubt they'll walk away
from their taxes and start tax forfeiture, however, by not paying right away
there's going to be fees and interest tacked on. It's going to cost them more."

Krupski doubted that many of the residential homes listed are foreclosed homes.

"When a home is foreclosed, the bank typically pays any property taxes on the
home," Krupski said.

Olmsted County property records and revenue supervisor Tom Olney said most taxes
are eventually collected.

"There's a three- to five-year time frame before it goes to tax forfeiture,"
Olney said.

He said the delinquent taxes make up only 1 percent of the Olmsted County's 2008
levy.

Dodge County finance director Lisa Kramer said that county also has a list of
tax delinquencies that is longer than past years'.

"There's been an increase in residential property delinquencies," Kramer said.
"Eleven more residential parcels are delinquent compared to last year."

While the list might be long, Kramer said land developers owe less money in
taxes because most of the lots are without houses.

Wabasha County treasurer Jerry Leisen was surprised to learn that the tax
delinquencies in Wabasha County had decreased.

He said 200 parcels were delinquent in 2007 and only 167 parcels were delinquent
in 2008.

He couldn't pinpoint what had caused the number to decrease for 2008, but said
back taxes may have been paid after mortgages were foreclosed.

In print

Look for Olmsted County tax delinquencies in a 12-page section in today's
Post-Bulletin newspaper.

To see more of the Post-Bulletin, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.postbulletin.com. Copyright (c) 2009, Post-Bulletin, Rochester, Minn.

to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                 The Tribune-Democrat (Johnstown, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             April 2, 2009 Thursday

Roustan United facing claims, delinquent taxes

BYLINE: Sandra K. Reabuck, Tribune-Democrat, Johnstown, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 605 words


Apr. 2--EBENSBURG -- Roustan United, the Richland Township-based company that
hoped to be part of a deal to manage the Cambria County War Memorial Arena, is
facing financial woes, with civil financial claims totaling more than $120,000
in Cambria County Court and an even higher amount due in delinquent property
taxes.

The company is in arrears on payments it's making on 2006 real estate taxes.

In addition, more than $140,000 is owed on delinquent property taxes for 2007
and 2008, the county tax claim office said.

And, Roustan settled another lawsuit last June for $12,612 by agreeing to make
staggered payments to Lakeland Plastics Inc., of Pittsburgh, for plastic spacer
strips and other products, according to records in the county prothonotary's
office.

Roustan has been managing the arena's primary tenant, the Johnstown Chiefs
hockey team.

Last year, it partnered with Global Spectrum of Philadelphia, one of the
nation's leading managers of public assembly venues, in submitting a proposal to
the county commissioners for the management of the War Memorial Arena.

On Monday, the county commissioners said that any deal with Roustan and Global
was dead.

The commissioners did not discuss Roustan's financial problems, but said there
were several confidential business considerations they considered.

Likewise, Roustan President Scott Branovan would not discuss the lawsuits and
delinquent taxes.

On March 26, Advantage Staffing Inc. of Altoona obtained a $49,944 default
judgment against Roustan United and Burley's Rink Supply of Salix for temporary
staffing services.

Maintenance services and a laborer were supplied, according to the civil lawsuit
filed by Advantage in April.

A lien for $3,734 was filed by the state's Unemployment Compensation Fund
against Roustan United on Sept. 19. That amount remained outstanding from
$10,218 owed, the state said.

This month, two new lawsuits were filed against Roustan.

Adex Sales of Westbank, B.C., Canada, is suing for $45,580 for glass panels to
Roustan at facilities in Meadville, and Northbrook, Ill. EDC Industries of Elk
Grove, Ill., is suing for $21,010 for merchandise allegedly supplied to Roustan.

The tax claim bureau said that the delinquent taxes are due on Roustan's Planet
Ice property at 195 Jari Drive.

The company went on a payment plan last summer, agreeing to pay $6,399 a month.
Six payments were made, with six remaining.

No payments were made in January, February or March, Joanne Ranck, assistant
director, said.

The original amount delinquent for 2006, with interest and penalties, was
$76,792 in property taxes owed to the county, Richland School District and
Richland Township, she said.

Ranck said that Roustan also owes $71,518 in delinquent tax for 2007 and $69,261
for 2008.

A story in Tuesday's editions incorrectly identified the owner of Planet Ice
property as Roustan United, when records at the courthouse identify the owner as
Roustan Johnstown, a limited liability corporation. Information filed with the
Pennsylvania Department of State lists Walter G. Roustan as president of Roustan
Johnstown. Roustan United leases space in the buidling, along with Roustan
Planet Ice Inc. Roustan United's chairman is W. Graeme Roustan.

To see more of The Tribune-Democrat or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.tribune-democrat.com. Copyright (c) 2009, Tribune-Democrat,
Johnstown, Pa. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For
reprints, email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or
847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group
Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                 The Tribune-Democrat (Johnstown, Pennsylvania)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                             May 23, 2015 Saturday

City trash hauler to crack down on delinquent accounts

BYLINE: Dave Sutor, The Tribune-Democrat, Johnstown, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 306 words


May 23--It is time for Johnstown residents to either pay their garbage bills or
possibly pay a fine.

Beginning June 1, the city's trash hauler, Advanced Disposal, will start issuing
notices to the 1,200 delinquent accounts on file for the first quarter of 2015.

"First will be the suspension of the service," City Manager Carlos Gunby said.

"But, if it continues, we are in the process of finalizing -- and will be
implementing at the same time -- a ticketing process that residences without
paid garbage will receive a ($25) ticket on their door."

Customers who still do not settle their bills could be taken to a magistrate,
which costs the city money and time.

Overall, the expense of dealing with the delinquent accounts is a burden paid
for by customers in good standing.

"It is quite disheartening and disturbing that we have 1,200 delinquent garbage
accounts," Gunby said. "At the end of the day, if that service is suspended,
someone is going to have to pay for that garbage to be picked up, and,
unfortunately that will be the 6,000 to 7,000 folks who have already paid their
garbage bills."

Garbage left out by delinquent customers will still be picked up, though.

"We met with Advanced Disposal (on Thursday) to discuss that situation," said
David Andrews, the city's solicitor.

"Because of the safety and health and welfare issues, we're still going to have
to go pick up that garbage. It's still the city's responsibility to make sure
it's being taken care of."

Anybody with a delinquent account is asked to contact Advanced Disposal or City
Hall.

Dave Sutor is a reporter for The Tribune-Democrat. He can be reached at (814)
532-5056. Follow him on Twitter @Dave_Sutor.

(Johnstown, Pa.) at www.tribune-democrat.com Distributed by Tribune Content
Agency, LLC.

                                US Official News

                            December 9, 2014 Tuesday

West Virginia: Map: Where West Virginia Mine Operators Owe Millions in
Delinquent Fines

LENGTH: 274  words

DATELINE: Charleston


West Virginia Public Broadcasting has issued the following news release:

A recent investigation by NPR and Mine Safety and Health News revealed thousands
of delinquent fines by mine operators across the county. Those fines, which are
handed down by the U.S. Department of Labor's Mine Safety and Health
Administration, range in their delinquency from months to decades--sometimes
adding up to millions of dollars worth of fines. West Virginia mine operators
had nearly $10.8 million in delinquent mine safety penalties at 312 mines (as of
March 31, 2014).

Three West Virginia-based mine controllers are among the mine owners with the
ten highest delinquent penalty amounts, according to the investigation by NPR
and Mine Safety and Health News:

James C. Justice II, Southern Coal Corp.: $1,995,327  (Justice's delinquencies
are in multiple states. He began paying delinquent penalties at the rate of
$100,000 a month after being contacted by NPR.)
    Brandy M. Horvath, New West Virginia Mining Company: $1,369,224 (Horvath was
involved in a federal criminal case for tax charges that resulted in a 2013 plea
agreement and prison sentence.  The court ultimately ruled that Horvath was not
the actual controller.)
    Richard H. Abraham, Rio Group: $ 982,252 (After NPR series aired, MSHA
revealed that Abraham is engaged in negotiations.)

The map below represents a summary of delinquent fines by county in West
Virginia. Click on a county to view the number of delinquent fines and the sum
of delinquent fines as of March 31, 2014:

contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                     News-Journal (Daytona Beach, Florida)

                              May 11, 2009 Monday
                             Volusia Review Edition

Delinquent tax certificates up 19 percent Online bidding begins today

BYLINE: AUDREY PARENTE, AUDREY PARENTE - STAFF WRITER

SECTION: SECTION A; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 362  words


Delinquent Volusia County real estate property tax certificates totaling nearly
$61 million, nearly 19 percent higher than last year, will be listed at
bidvolusia.com beginning today for a sale to take place on May 30.

The tax certificate sale is not a sale of land, but a sale of liens against
27,348 properties for the amount of delinquent real estate taxes.

Information on the delinquent properties is available at the Property
Appraiser's Web site, volusia.org/property where interested buyers can look up a
parcel to find its exact location, Revenue Director Peggy Flomerfelt said.

Certificate buyers bid the lowest interest rate charged against the total
delinquency, including interest and fees, a $3 parcel advertisement fee for the
property owners. The successful bidder pays for the certificate by electronic
funds transfer.

To avoid the auction, delinquent payments plus the interest and fees, must be
made to one of four county locations not later than 5 p.m. May 29. The locations
are: 123 W. Indiana Ave., Room 103, DeLand; 250 N. Beach St., Daytona Beach; 111
Canal St., New Smyrna Beach; and 2744 Enterprise Road, Orange City.

The tax collector's office also publishes a list of delinquent tangible property
taxes, including such items as business assets, mobile home attachments, rental
condo fixtures and other items. This year, 699 delinquent tangibles total nearly
$2 million. If payments of tangible property taxes are not made by May 31,
warrants are issued and later ratified.

Once warrants are ratified, the tax collector has the right to levy fines and
seize tangible property to sell for taxes.

Published lists are included with The Volusia/Flagler Review at the following
locations:*Daytona Beach: 901 Sixth St.; Publix, 1500 Beville Road.*Ormond
Beach: Post Office, 145 W. Granada Blvd.*DeLand: Corner of North Woodland
Boulevard and West Rich Avenue; Potato Patch Restaurant, 635 S. Woodland
Blvd.*Orange City: Post Office, 260 Industrial Drive.*Deltona: Post Office, 944
Deltona Blvd.*New Smyrna Beach: Courthouse, 124 Riverside Drive; corner of Rush
and Canal streets, Manny's Pizza, 3318 S. Atlantic Ave.*Edgewater: Post Office,
400 S. Ridgewood Ave.

                             131 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                     Charleston Daily Mail (West Virginia)

                            March 17, 2009, Tuesday

Taxpayers may face lawsuits;
Carper releases list of largest delinquent accounts; $2.2 million owed by
companies

BYLINE: GEORGE HOHMANN, DAILY MAIL BUSINESS EDITOR

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. P1A

LENGTH: 701 words


Kanawha Commission President Kent Carper released a list of the 20 largest
delinquent tax accounts in the county and said lawsuits will be filed against as
many as possible.

"We're going to sue," Carper said Monday. "For every dime that someone - a
company or a private individual - owes and doesn't pay in taxes, you pay more."

The 20 owe a total of $2.2 million. Some owe for tax years as far back as 2003.

Topping the list is Union Stamping & Assembly Inc., which owes $893,055 in
personal property tax, according to Allen Bleigh, the county's chief tax deputy.

The South Charleston company went bankrupt in 2006.

"They're deadbeats - I can't sue them," Carper said. "What I can do is work with
the new management and hope we can eventually bring back some of those jobs."

Cleveland financier Ray Park bought Union Stamping's assets in bankruptcy and
established Charleston Stamping, which now occupies the South Charleston
factory.

Caterpillar Financial Services owes $245,059, the second largest amount on the
list. The Nashville, Tenn.-based company is the financial arm of Caterpillar
Inc., the world's largest manufacturer of construction and mining equipment,
natural gas and diesel engines, and industrial gas turbines. Caterpillar
Financial Services has been at or near the top of the deadbeat account list for
several years.

Point Mining Inc. owes $226,759, the third largest amount. According to
Secretary of State Natalie Tennant's online business database, the Belle
company's state registration was terminated last June.

Bleigh prepared the list of delinquent accounts. He said in a March 11 memo to
Carper that the county has about 44,783 delinquent tax tickets that date from
the 2003 to 2007 tax year.

"The reason I say approximately is my information is about 30 days old, and I am
sure some of these tickets have been paid," he wrote.

Bleigh said that 42,709 or 95 percent of the delinquent accounts are for amounts
ranging from one cent to $250. He said 1,345 or 3 percent of the accounts are
for amounts ranging from $250.01 to $500. Bleigh said 375 or 1 percent of the
accounts are for amounts ranging from $500.01 to $1,000 and 354 or 1 percent of
the accounts are for more than $1,000.

"My policy has been not to pursue accounts with a balance of less than $250
because it will actually cost more to pursue the matter than we would ultimately
receive," Bleigh wrote.

"As of the end of February the total dollar value of these outstanding taxes is
$1,127,225. I have looked at sending these smaller accounts to a collection
agency like General Recovery Services, but it is still a loss to the county. I
can try mass mailings in the hope someone will be honest and pay, but that is
more wishful thinking than practical logic.

"My efforts with the prosecuting attorney's office is centered on the accounts
that are in the upper 2 percent, with emphasis on taxpayers who owe multiple
year taxes," Bleigh wrote.

Demand letters have been sent to all of the top 20 accounts, and "I am currently
working to define another 20 accounts," he wrote.

Carper said, "I credit the sheriff. He's taking this serious and doing
everything he can. The new prosecutor is doing an excellent job in taking this
serious."

                             132 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          South Bend Tribune (Indiana)

                           January 10, 2008 Thursday
                                  Mars Edition

For some, tax rebate already spent

BYLINE: ED RONCO, Tribune Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. B3

LENGTH: 238 words


SOUTH BEND - A tax credit passed last year by the General Assembly promised
rebate checks to homestead property owners across the state.

But those with delinquent taxes in St. Joseph County will be waiting by the
mailbox for a long time under a new ordinance.

The measure, approved Tuesday night by the St. Joseph County Council, says that
for property owners delinquent in paying taxes on homestead property, rebate
checks will go to pay down the back taxes rather than to the property owner
directly.

The remainder of the rebate, if any, will then be sent to the property owner.

Many counties in Indiana are using similar methods to obtain delinquent tax
revenue, said St. Joseph County Treasurer Sean Coleman.

The number of delinquent taxpayers - and how much they owe - will likely be
calculated by the end of the week, he said.

Putting the money toward delinquent tax balances helps not only the county but
also the property owner to pay down his or her debt, Coleman said.

The council approved the measure by a vote of 8 to 1.

Dissenting was council member Dennis Schafer, R-District F, who said the move
punished residents who received late tax bills because of problems in
calculating reassessments.

Tax bills went out to property owners back in October, months later than usual,
Coleman said.

They also were due in a single installment. Usually, bills are sent out early in
the year and are payable in two installments.

LOAD-DATE: January 26, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                 Copyright 2008 South Bend Tribune Corporation
                              All Rights Reserved


                             133 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                       The Daily Reporter (Milwaukee, WI)

                            January 25, 2008 Friday

Mortgage crisis threatens Milwaukee County budget

BYLINE: Sean Ryan

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 545  words


If the mortgage crisis keeps driving up delinquent taxes in Milwaukee County, it
could force the county to either increase taxes or cut program spending.

So Daniel Diliberti, the county's treasurer, has found himself in the unusual
position of helping Milwaukee County residents pay their mortgages. Although the
county treasurer is in charge of collecting delinquent taxes, Diliberti doesn't
want to use foreclosure to do his job.

"We're not interested in taking people's property away, but we need to collect
these taxes," he said. "Every delinquent property has a story, and,
unfortunately, more and more are problems on the mortgage itself that never
should've been taken out. "

There were 3,575 Milwaukee County properties with delinquent payments in 2006,
but the treasurer's office foreclosed on only 12, Diliberti said. The County
Board this month will consider a plan to put those 12 houses up for sale.

Many residents try to get a loan from a bank or negotiate a payback plan when
they hear the county collects 18 percent in interest on unpaid taxes, Diliberti
said. In other situations, banks that foreclose on houses will take a chunk of
the home sale and pay for the taxes.

But to help ensure late mortgage payments don't create more delinquent taxes,
Diliberti is partnering with the University of Wisconsin-Extension to organize a
workshop on Feb. 16 where residents can get advice on how to handle their
mortgage payments or avoid taking out a sub-prime loan.

"Don't wait, don't ignore the problem," said Suzanne Dennik, consumer and
housing education coordinator for the UW-Extension in Racine and Milwaukee
counties. "People are embarrassed. They're afraid. They're in fear of losing
their home, and they follow this natural human instinct to shut down, which is
the worst thing you can do. "

Diliberti's motives go beyond simply not wanting to take residents' homes away.
He doesn't want delinquent payments to affect the county's operating budget.

Every year, the county pays municipalities, except the city of Milwaukee, for
delinquent taxes and shoulders the responsibility of collecting the unpaid
money, with interest. For the past two years, the delinquent taxes the county
owes municipalities increased about $2 million, Diliberti said, or 43 percent.

The situation isn't hurting the county budget yet, but if spiking foreclosures
keep driving up delinquent taxes - and Diliberti expects them to - it could
become a problem.

"You are seeing major impacts on the budgets of local and state agencies," he
said. "It hasn't happened in Milwaukee because the change is more gradual. "

The county budget considers delinquent taxes as receivables that will be
collected, but the more unpaid taxes there are, the more money the county needs
to dump into a contingency fund and the longer it takes to collect the money.

The contingency fund grew by about $100,000 this year, which isn't a big issue
in a $1 billion operation like the county's, said Scott Manske, county
controller. The unpaid taxes aren't a budgetary problem now because the county
is collecting them fast enough, and the interest it collects helps balance the
books, he said.

"I think the tipping point would be a real slowdown in collections," Manske
said. "Right now, they're offsetting each other. "

LOAD-DATE: January 26, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Government activity

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                         The Brownsville Herald (Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             August 3, 2010 Tuesday

Tax auction set for today

BYLINE: Laura B. Martinez, The Brownsville Herald, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 516 words


Aug. 03--Taxpayers on Monday were scrambling to pay delinquent taxes or face
seeing their property being sold to the highest bidder today.

Delinquent taxpayers headed to the Cameron County Tax-Assessor Collector's
Office and to the law firm that collects delinquent taxes for several entities
to pay back taxes owed.

The Linebarger, Goggan, Blair & Sampson LLP law firm will hold an auction from
10:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. on the steps of the Cameron County Courthouse on East
Harrison Street to sell some 60 properties that are delinquent on their taxes.

One of the most delinquent on the list is the old Dolly Vinsant Memorial
Hospital in San Benito, which according to the tax office owes $630,275 in back
taxes to Cameron County, the city of San Benito and the San Benito Consolidated
Independent School District.

The property has an appraised value of more than $2.7 million and as of Monday,
the hospital still remained on the property tax sale list, said John Guevara, a
partner with the law firm.

"Something could happen tomorrow (Tuesday)...like with any taxpayer if they came
in the morning and paid. We could still put it from the sale, but as far as I
know they have not paid," Guevara said on Monday afternoon.

The hospital has been closed since October 2007 because of financial problems.

Also on the list is property where two Taiwan Shrimp Farms are housed. Listed as
Lot No. 13 and Lot No. 14, a combined $57,874 in back taxes is owed.

Guevara said property owners have been stopping by the law firm to either pay
the taxes owed or make payment arrangements to prevent their property from being
sold. As each arrangement or payment is made, the sale of the property becomes
cancelled.

"The numbers are changing by the minute," Guevara said.

On Friday, 64 properties throughout the county were originally scheduled to be
sold, which combined owe more than $1 million in delinquent taxes, officials
reported.

"It's not fair to those citizens who pay their taxes to not go after those who
refuse to pay," said County Tax Assessor-Collector Tony Yzaguirre Jr.

According to Yzaguirre's office, the 2009 taxes became delinquent in February
and the accounts were turned over in July to Linebarger, Goggan, Blair & Sampson
LLP for collection.

Guevara said 36,361 delinquent notices have been mailed out to the property
owners. The amount of money owed on these delinquent taxes is more than $26.9
million.

In addition, 533 lawsuits have been filed to collect an additional $1.5 million
on back taxes, Guevara said. The law firm expects to file more lawsuits in
August and September against those delinquent taxpayers.

lmartinez@brownsvilleherald.com

http://www.brownsvilleherald.com. Copyright (c) 2010, The Brownsville Herald,

                             135 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Tampa Tribune (Florida)

                            October 31, 2010 Sunday
                                 FINAL EDITION

In foreclosure, board protects itself with fast action

BYLINE: RICHARD WHITE, Special correspondent

SECTION: BAYLIFE & TRAVEL; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 581 words


BY RICHARD WHITE

Special correspondent

Q. I read in your column that you recommend the board foreclose on any
delinquent account. Many of the delinquent accounts are upside down and to
foreclose would be wasted money. Why should the board take legal action when
such action is very expensive and will not result in eliminating the mortgage
obligation?

BC, Miami

Answer: I recommend that the board, working with an attorney, develop a
collections and delinquent policy. That policy would include fast action to
eliminate large delinquent amounts. The objective is to get the delinquent
account paying faster. Thus, an owner in bank foreclosure would know that the
association will act faster to obtain title to the property than the bank will.

Once the association has title, it has several options. It can notify the bank
that the title can be passed back to the bank as a deed to stop foreclosure.
Once the title is passed to the bank, it must start paying the fees.

The association can rent the property to generate income. Or, it can sell the
property with the approval of the bank.

Keep in mind, fast action is key. If there's a delay, the legal and delinquent
fees can quickly mount. A recent news story proves the point: A major lender
that has a huge number of delinquent mortgages has resulted in a middle manager
signing more than 10,000 foreclosures a month and then notarizing his own
signature, which is illegal here in Florida.

Several state attorney generals, including Florida's, have filed legal action to
stop foreclosures because of this practice. In the Florida case, the employee
testified that he signed the affidavits without reviewing the paperwork and thus
had no way of knowing whether the information was actually true. The mortgage
company has suspended foreclosures in 23 states. A class-action lawsuit could
result in the cancellation of foreclosures filed nationwide through the Mortgage
Electronic Registration System. What we now have is a situation where delinquent
owners can live in the home without fear of bank foreclosure for months and
maybe years.

Establishing a fast action policy may result in preventing an owner from sitting
in a home without paying his mortgage or association fees.


Q. My condominium unit was placed in foreclosure and I am not living in the
apartment. The furnished unit was unoccupied and payments to the association
were not made, so the association decided to remove the furniture and allowed
someone to move in. Can an association evacuate a foreclosed unit and allow
someone else to move in?

JV, Miami

Answer: Who is foreclosing, and has the final foreclosure taken place? If it is
a bank foreclosure, then the association does not have title and cannot use the
unit or remove the personal property. If the association has foreclosed, then it
has title to the unit and can rent it out.

As for personal property, whoever is foreclosing can remove what the former
owner has not taken and can do with it anything they want. If an eviction notice
was served, then the items would be placed on the street. The key is, who has
title to the unit?

Richard White is a licensed community association manager. He does not offer
legal opinions; any other questions and comments concerning association
operations can be sent to Richard White, 6039 Cypress Gardens Blvd., No. 201,
Winter Haven FL 33884-4115; or e-mail

camquestion@cfl.rr.com

Copyright © 2010, The Tampa Tribune and may not be republished without
permission. E-mail library@tampatrib.com

LOAD-DATE: December 3, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

NOTES: RULES OF THE ROOST

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


           Copyright 2010 The Tribune Co. Publishes The Tampa Tribune


                             136 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                              The Washington Post

                           September 2, 2003 Tuesday
                                 Final Edition

Va. Offers A Deal To Tax Evaders;
Partial Interest Waived for Most

BYLINE: R.H. Melton, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: METRO; Pg. B01

LENGTH: 743 words

DATELINE: RICHMOND


Virginia launches a 63-day tax amnesty program today aimed at coaxing a
projected $ 48 million from the 400,000 delinquents who owe nearly four times
that amount to a state government in fiscal distress.

With a television ad campaign featuring a hapless tax delinquent being chased by
a giant, two-legged envelope, the state is notifying delinquents that it will
waive all penalties and half of the accrued interest on most back taxes if paid
by Nov. 3.

"The message is: Pay now, or pay more later," Tax Commissioner Kenneth W.
Thorson said.

This year's nine-week program is similar to the tax amnesty of 1990, when the
state government, enduring a recession, welcomed the $ 32 million that was
recovered during the grace period. Maryland and the District have also offered
delinquent taxpayers some short-term amnesty periods in recent years, with mixed
results.

Gov. Mark R. Warner (D) and the Republican-led General Assembly approved the
2003 amnesty as part of a bipartisan package of budget repairs, closing a $ 6
billion shortfall that could still widen in the months ahead. Warner told the
legislature's money committees last week that further spending cuts may be
required to offset escalating costs in health care and other services. Leading
lawmakers estimate the looming shortfall to be at least $ 1 billion.

"It's fair to say that when states are in hard economic times, amnesty always
pops up as a partial solution," Thorson said. "It's not a windfall -- it's
accelerating revenues that we would eventually collect."

Officials said that more than 209,000 regular filers who failed to file in
recent years owe the state a combined $ 180 million, while a slightly smaller
number of businesses and individuals who never file owe an undetermined amount.
A tax department spokesman said that one delinquency notice is being mailed to a
Virginia Beach resident who originally owed $ 8,000 in 1965 and 1966 but now,
because of penalties and interest, has a tax bill of $ 129,000.

"The department has a long memory," Thorson said. "We don't forget."

For instance, of the 27,000 individuals and companies participating in the 1990
amnesty, only four were previously unknown to the state as being delinquent,
Thorson said. This year, about one-third of the tax delinquents reside in
Northern Virginia, accounting for 41 percent of back taxes, officials said.

About 2.5 million Virginians pay their taxes on time every year.

Thorson and other officials said this year's amnesty has added urgency, in part,
because of a new law making it a felony to defraud the tax department.
Delinquents who are eligible for amnesty but do not participate will be assessed
an additional 20 percent penalty and may have their federal refunds reduced to
pay their Virginia bills.

"Amnesty gives delinquent taxpayers opportunities to get a fresh start," Warner
said in a statement.

In Maryland, a spokesman for Comptroller William Donald Schaefer (D) said that
the state's most recent amnesty, in September and October 2001, yielded $ 39.4
million, up from $ 34.6 million in 1987, in the only other grace period for tax
delinquents.

Schaefer spokesman Michael D. Golden said that Maryland legislators had hoped
the 2001 amnesty would generate as much as $ 70 million, but the goal was not
met as the national economy turned sour. About 14,000 individuals paid $ 21.4
million in back taxes and interest during the 2001 amnesty.

In the District, Eric Balliet, a spokesman for the tax and revenue office, said
that a two-month business and excise tax amnesty in 1995 and a subsequent
property tax amnesty later that year generated $ 11.2 million; a three-month
amnesty in mid-1987 yielded just over $ 10 million.

The District has a year-round voluntary tax settlement program allowing
residents and companies to avoid civil penalties by paying back taxes, with
interest, Balliet said.

Virginia's tax amnesty will cost $ 7 million to administer, including $ 2
million for a statewide publicity campaign that features wry TV ads depicting
the pursuit of a chubby, panting taxpayer by a delinquency notice from the tax
department.

In one TV spot, the envelope on two legs calls after the fleeing scofflaw: "But
I know where you live!"

Thorson said the ad campaign was designed to "convey a message that this is
serious business -- but we don't want to come across as being brutal."

Details on Virginia tax amnesty eligibility are available at the Web site
www.VaTaxAmnesty.com.

LOAD-DATE: September 2, 2003

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              The Washington Post

                    August 9, 1984, Thursday, Final Edition

Arlington Cracks Down on Delinquent Taxpayers;
County Nets $2.7 Million, 1 Congressman

BYLINE: By Anndee Hochman, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: Metro; C3

LENGTH: 532 words


A crackdown on delinquent taxpayers in Arlington County has netted the county
more than $2.7 million but has swamped court dockets and forced sheriff's
deputies to work weekends.

County Treasurer Frank O'Leary, a Democrat, said the crackdown shows that he is
fulfilling a campaign promise he made last fall. He then charged his Republican
predecessor with having allowed millions of dollars in county taxes to go
uncollected.

Arlington County has the highest combined rate of delinquent real estate and
personal property taxes in Northern Virginia, according to a county report
released last fall. Earlier this year O'Leary put the total amount overdue at $5
million.

O'Leary announced the crackdown this spring, focusing it on delinquent personal
property taxes, which are assessed largely on boats and automobiles.

Since then the Arlington General District Court docket has swelled to include
about 400 tax cases a week, according to court clerk Mary E. Lamanna.

Sheriff's deputies have served 6,500 warrants since April, according to Chief
Deputy Treasurer Kevin R. Appel. "They're working nights, they're working
weekends, they're working a lot," he said.

O'Leary said the effort has already decreased the delinquent tax rate and halved
the amount of delinquent personal property taxes owed the county since 1979. In
June of 1983, Arlington's delinquent tax rate was 8.3 percent, O'Leary said. By
June of this year, that rate had dropped to 6.5 percent.

So far, the crackdown has cost the county $15,000 in printing bills for court
warrants and rental fees for computer terminals, which are being used to cross
check the names of delinquent taxpayers with credit bureaus and the Virginia
Division of Motor Vehicles.

"Within the office, it hasn't cost anything except in blood, sweat and tears,"
O'Leary said. "It's been a relatively inexpensive program."

The largest owed were "in the $2,000 range," said deputy treasurer Appel. Most
were between $100 and $150. He said the treasurer's office went after the older
and larger cases first.

Among those caught in the crackdown was a member of Congress who, according to
O'Leary, "had been advised by his peers that he didn't have to pay personal
property taxes." The congressman, whom O'Leary would not identify, paid up after
the treasurer's office notified him. O'Leary said many members of Congress
living in Arlington do not realize they must obtain county decals for their cars
and pay county taxes on them.

Few of the citizens named on the court warrants ever appear in court, O'Leary
said. Many people pay after receiving initial notices from the treasurer's
office, and others default on their court appearances.

Others cannot be found at all. "Arlington does have a transient population. I
think what we're going to find in a lot of these cases is that the people aren't
there," Appel said.

State law allows five years for the collection of personal property taxes, so
those who owed taxes in 1979 will soon be on the safe side of the statute of
limitations.

"At some point, we're going to have to write them off," Appel said. "We'll never
retrieve all of it, but we're going to retrieve the bulk of it."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Picture, Frank O'Leary . . . "blood, sweat, and tears"

                       Copyright 1984 The Washington Post


                             138 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                             National Mortgage News

                               September 12, 1994

Life Insurance Delinquencies Drop Again

SECTION: Pg. 3

LENGTH: 426 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


At the end of the second quarter, the number of delinquent mortgages owned by
life insurance companies fell to its second lowest point since March 1991,
according to data from the American Council of Life Insurance.

As of June 30, life company deliquencies represented 4.95% of the industry's
mortgage portfolio, down from 5.08% as of March 31, and 6.14% as of June 30,
1993.

Delinquencies peaked in the third quarter of 1992 at 7.12% before falling to
4.38% at the end of last year.

Mortgage account for 13% of life insurer's total assets, according to ACLI.

At the end of 1992 mortgages were 16% of total assets; by Dec. 31, 1993, they
slipped to 14% of total assets.

Nearly 93% of the mortgage portfolio consists of commercial mortgages; the
delinquency rate for these loans fell from 5.24% in the first quarter to 5.07%.

ACLI said that life company mortgage professionals are currently expressing
cautious optimism, as the economy grew by 3.8% in the second quarter while
inflation was stable.

"Property values have bottomed out or are rising slightly in many areas of the
country, as liquidity continues to improve.

"More borrowers are reaching into their pockets to bring delinquent loans
current or are obtaining financing to pay off their loans.

"With the outlook improving, more companies are actively seeking new commercial
mortgage business," ACLI said.

By region, only the Pacific states (5.57%) and the Mid-Atlantic states (6.68%)
showed an increase in delinquencies, of 34 basis points and 30 basis points
respectively.

The Pacific region, once among the lowest in delinquencies, now is the third
highest behind New England and the Mid-Atlantic states.

ACLI said that "while delinquencies continue to trend higher in the Pacific
region, the California economy is showing signs of climbing out of its
recession."

Residential mortgages, which make up just 3% of industry holdings, fell from
3.34% in the first quarter (which was their all-time high), to 2.75%.

On the other hand agricultural mortgages (4% of the total) increased from 2.78%
in the first quarter to 3.77%.

However, ACLI said this increase can be attributed to one large agribusiness
loan that went delinquent during the quarter.

The life insurance industry has $ 190.2 billion in loans outstanding, of which $
9.4 billion are delinquent.

By type; commercial, $ 176.5 billion outstanding, $ 8.9 billion delinquent;
agricultural, $ 8.7 billion outstanding, $ 327.6 million delinquent; residential
$ 5.0 billion outstanding, $ 137.5 million delinquent.

LOAD-DATE: September 27, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Graph, Life Co. Delinquencies Improve in 2Q, The percentage of
delinquent mortgages owned by life insurers decreased 13 bp during the second
quarter to 4.95%, from 5.08% as of March 31.  This improvement was driven by a
17 bp drop in commercial delinquencies.  Commercial mortgages account for 93% of
life co. holdings, Source: ACLI

                          The Tampa Tribune (Florida)

                             August 17, 2009 Monday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Investors grab tax bills

BYLINE: KRISTA KLAUS, kklaus@wfla.com

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 326 words


Hillsborough to recover $115 million in "lost" funds.

By KRISTA KLAUS

kklaus@wfla.com

TAMPA - Hillsborough County expects to recover $115 million in potential lost
revenue through investors' purchases of delinquent property tax certificates.

That means Hillsborough recouped about 85 percent of its delinquent tax bill,
one of the highest rates of recovery in the state.

That's important this year. With home foreclosures in free fall, the number of
properties where owners failed to pay their taxes is high.

More than 46,000 properties appeared on the delinquent tax list issued by the
county April 1.

The certificates were purchased online through a bidding process. The lowest bid
is awarded the certificate.

In return, investors hold a lien on the property that must be paid off with
interest.

For the first time in several years, institutional investors hard hit by the
banking crisis didn't snap up the majority of the certificates. Rather,
mom-and-pop investors did, the tax collector's office said.

And in some cases, they made out like bandits.

They will average 9.2 percent interest on their purchase of certificates from
the county. Investors are guaranteed a return of 5 percent and can receive up to
18 percent.

If no one pays the tax on a property by 22 months after the sale, the
certificate holder can foreclose on the property. But eventually, most property
owners pay.

Here's how other Bay area counties fared in selling this year's delinquent tax
certificates: Pinellas, 94 percent; Sarasota, 75 percent; Pasco, 74 percent;
Manatee, 64 percent; Polk, 53 percent; and Hernando, 52 percent.

The highest rates in the state were Broward County, 99 percent, and Miami-Dade
County, 97 percent. The lowest rates were in Highlands County, 16 percent, and
Hendry County, 19 percent.

News Channel 8 reporter Krista Klaus can be reached at (813) 225-3736.

permission. E-mail library@tampatrib.com

                                Payments Source

                            October 29, 2012 Monday

Memphis May Not Renew Contract With Embattled Collection Agency

BYLINE: Darren Waggoner

SECTION: CCR - DEALS & PRICING Vol. 1 No. 1

LENGTH: 295  words


The city of Memphis, Tenn. likely will end its relationship with Texas-based
Linebarger Goggan Blair & Sampson as the collection agency deals with a
class-action lawsuit in the city that could cost it millions of dollars.

Linebarger has collected an estimated $190 million for the city since 2004. The
agency's contract expires Dec. 31.City officials would not elaborate on how many
proposals for delinquent tax collection the city is reviewing, and would not
explain specifically why the city did not want to renew Linebarger's contract.
Linebarger officials were unavailable for comment.Sources said the city's Legal
Division received multiple proposals for the tax-collecting contract, including
one from Linebarger, and that city officials interviewed some vendors that
submitted proposals last week. Â Linebarger's primary target in Memphis has been
delinquent property taxes on homes and businesses. The debts must be 17 months
past due before the city turns them over to the firm. Under the contract, the
city does not pay Linebarger any direct fees and the firm makes its money by
charging debtors fees in addition to the taxes owed.The fees charged by
Linebarger have drawn multiple lawsuits, including the ongoing class-action suit
that could impact as many as 60,000 people. That case surrounds the
interpretation of two Tennessee statutes that provide for additional charges
against delinquent taxpayers when they have to be sued. At issue is whether
Linebarger can charge a 10 percent or 20 percent fee for collecting delinquent
property taxes on homes and businesses.Linebarger won a professional services
contract, which did not require a bid process or council approval, from former
Memphis mayor Willie Herenton in 2004 to collect delinquent city taxes.

                                US Official News

                            September 5, 2016 Monday

Allowing quarterly payment of real and personal property taxes

LENGTH: 588  words

DATELINE: New York



 Charleston: The State of West Virginia has issued the following bill status:
 LAST ACTION:     H To House Judiciary 01/13/16

 SUMMARY:     Allowing quarterly payment of real and personal property taxes

 LEAD SPONSOR:     Caputo

 SPONSORS:     Manchin, Longstreth
 West Virginia Legislature



 2016 Regular Session



 Introduced



 House Bill 2076



 2015 Carryover



 (By Delegates Caputo, Manchin and Longstreth)





 [Introduced January 13, 2016; referred to the



 Committee on the Judiciary then Finance.]



















 A BILL to amend and reenact §11Aâ[#x20ac]'1â[#x20ac]'3 of the Code of West
Virginia, 1931, as amended, relating to allowing quarterly payment of real and
personal property taxes.



 Be it enacted by the Legislature of West Virginia:



 That §11Aâ[#x20ac]'1â[#x20ac]'3 of the Code of West Virginia, 1931, as amended,
be amended and reenacted to read as follows:



 ARTICLE 1.  ACCRUAL AND COLLECTION OF TAXES.



 §11Aâ[#x20ac]'1â[#x20ac]'3.  Accrual; time for payment; interest on delinquent
taxes.



 (a) All current taxes assessed on real and personal property may be paid in two
installments.  The first installment shall be is payable on September 1 of the
year for which the assessment is made and shall become becomes delinquent on
October 1; the second installment shall be is payable on the first day of the
following March 1 and shall become becomes delinquent on April 1.  Taxes paid on
or before the date when they are payable, including both first and second
installments or quarterly installments, shall be are subject to a discount of
two and oneâ[#x20ac]'half percent.  If taxes are not paid on or before the date
on which they become delinquent, including both first and second installments or
quarterly installments, interest at the rate of nine percent per annum shall be
added from the date they become delinquent until paid.  Beginning July 1, 2015,
current taxes assessed on real and personal property may be paid in quarterly
installments: (1) The first quarterly installment is payable on September 1 of
the year for which the assessment is made and becomes delinquent on October 1;
(2) the second quarterly installment is payable on the following January 1 and
becomes delinquent on February 1; (3) the third installment is payable on the
following March 1 and becomes delinquent on April 1; and (4) the fourth
installment is payable on the following August 1 and becomes delinquent on
September 1.



 (b) With regard to real and personal property taxes, when any return, claim,
statement or other document is required to be filed or any payment is required
to be made within a prescribed period or before a prescribed date and the
applicable law requires delivery to the office of the sheriff of a county of
this state, the methods prescribed in §11â[#x20ac]'10â[#x20ac]'5f section
fiveâ[#x20ac]'f, article ten, chapter eleven of this code for timely filing and
payment to the Tax Commissioner or Department of tax and Revenue shall be the
same methods utilized used for timely filing and payment with such the sheriff.
Nothing contained in this subsection (b) shall prohibit prohibits the sheriff
from establishing additional methods of payment in accordance with the
provisions of section eightâ[#x20ac]'a of this article.











 NOTE: The purpose of this bill is to allow quarterly payment of real and
personal property taxes.







 Strikeâ[#x20ac]'throughs indicate language that would be stricken from the
present law and underscoring indicates new language that would be added.

contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                     The Pantagraph (Bloomington, Illinois)

                            November 11, 2005 Friday

Interstate cooperation should aid children in support cases

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. A6

LENGTH: 289 words


A new pact between Illinois and Iowa to go after parents delinquent in child
support might have little direct impact in McLean County.

But society will benefit by the increased collection rates likely to result from
such cooperation.

Delinquent child support payments can result in families going on welfare --
which costs all of us.

Most important, children will benefit if their parents receive the money needed
for their care.

Todd Miller, an assistant McLean County state's attorney in the child support
division, said very few cases in McLean County involve delinquent parents who
have moved to Iowa.

However, statewide, about 12.3 percent of child-support cases involved
out-of-state parents and they account for about 22 percent of the money owed.

Federal law provides tools for going after delinquent parents who leave a state
in an attempt to avoid their financial obligations to their children. But
Illinois officials say the interstate pact will provide a closer working
relationship.

That seems to be the case with a similar agreement between Iowa and Nebraska.
Since opening an office in Omaha, Neb., Iowa has seen its on-time collections
and total child support payments increase by several percentage points. We hope
the Iowa-Illinois initiative results in similar success. An office was opened
last month in the Quad Cities staffed jointly by Illinois and Iowa.

Illinois is pursuing a similar agreement with Wisconsin. Eventually, Illinois
officials would like to collaborate with all our neighbors in pursuing parents.
That's a good idea.

But state officials also should keep records of whether the increased child
support collections merit having special offices and whether an initial boost in
collections is sustained.

LOAD-DATE: November 17, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                         Copyright 2005 The Pantagraph


                             143 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Monitor (McAllen, Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           September 25, 2012 Tuesday

McAllen ISD keeps Perdue for delinquent tax collection

BYLINE: Andrew Kreighbaum, The Monitor, McAllen, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 540 words


Sept. 25--McAllen school board trustees opted Monday to retain the firm of
Perdue Brandon Fielder Collins and Mott LLP as the district's delinquent tax
collection firm, accepting a staff recommendation.

Only one other firm out of 40 approached by the district, Linebarger Goggan
Blair and Sampson LLP, had responded to a request for proposals.

Linebarger, a national firm that handles delinquent tax collection contract for
public entities across the state, had held the contract from 1992 until 2009
when the contract was awarded to Perdue in association with the law office of
former Hidalgo Mayor John David Franz.

A five-member staff committee recommended going with Perdue again after a Sept.
12 evaluation meeting.

But Monday, after the item was brought up, board Vice President Erica De La
Garza moved to award the contract to Linebarger.

Both De la Garza and trustee Sam Salvidar Jr. questioned whether the incumbent
firm was meeting collection goals included in its contract with the district.

Perdue's contract included collection goals of 48 percent for the 2010-11 budget
year and 45 percent for the 2011-12.

Connie Lopez, assistant superintendent for business operations, told trustees
the firm had not met those goals, which are not contractually binding.

Perdue collected about $4 million in delinquent taxes in 2010-11 and $3.4
million in 2011-12.

Staff considered the delinquent tax collection performance compared to other
districts as well as documents submitted by the firm and overall presentations
during the interview process.

"It was close," Lopez told The Monitor.

The board voted 5-2 to keep Perdue, with De La Garza and Saldivar the only
dissenting votes.

Lucy Canales, managing partner at Linebarger, said she was disappointed in the
board's decision considering significant declines in delinquent taxes collected
for the district during the last two years.

"I, of course, believe that our law firm was the better qualified firm but
respect the decision of the board," she said.

Perdue partner Hiram Gutierrez said those declines were a result of shrinking
delinquent tax rolls.

"We're very grateful for the opportunity to continue serving the McAllen school
district," he said. "We believe we've been working very hard and doing well for
the school district. I think the majority of the board has shown today
confidence in us."

The firm receives 15 percent of all delinquent taxes, including interest and
penalties, collected for the school district.

The two firms had also competed earlier this year for the City of Hidalgo
delinquent tax contract, which was awarded to Linebarger in January.

Those discussions were marked by questions raised by political rivals of Franz,
who stepped down as mayor the following month, over his relationship with
Perdue. While the firm has a joint venture agreement with Franz for other taxing
entities, representatives said it did not include the City of Hidalgo.

Andrew Kreighbaum covers education and general assignments for The Monitor. He
may be reached at andrew@themonitor.com or (956) 683-4472.
