                                Tampa Bay Times

                            July 30, 2014 Wednesday
                           4 State / Suncoast Edition

41% OF FLORIDIANS HAVE DELINQUENT DEBT

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. 4B

LENGTH: 385 words



HIGHLIGHT: That tops the national figure of 35 percent who have accounts in
collections.


More than 35 percent of Americans have debts and unpaid bills that have been
reported to collection agencies, and that number is even higher across much of
the South, in Florida and in the Tampa Bay metro area, according to a study
released Tuesday by the Urban Institute.

Eleven Southern states plus Nevada and the District of Columbia top the list of
past-due-debt states, all reporting more than 40 percent of their populations
with a credit file reporting debt in collections. Statewide, Florida had 41
percent with delinquent debt, with some of the highest delinquencies appearing
in metropolitan Lakeland (47.3 percent), Jacksonville (45 percent), Orlando
(44.8 percent) and Tampa Bay (41.6 percent).

These consumers fall behind on credit cards or hospital bills. Their mortgages,
auto loans or student debt pile up. Even past-due gym membership fees or
cellphone contracts can end up with a collection agency, potentially hurting
credit scores and job prospects, said Caroline Ratcliffe, a senior fellow at the
Urban Institute, a Washington public policy think tank.

"Roughly, every third person you pass on the street is going to have debt in
collections," Ratcliffe said. "It can tip employers' hiring decisions, or
whether or not you get that apartment."

The "Delinquent Debt in America" study indicates that the share of Americans in
collections has remained relatively constant, even as the country as a whole has
whittled down the size of its credit card debt since the official end of the
Great Recession in the middle of 2009. The study found that 35.1 percent of
people nationwide with credit records had been reported to collections for debt
that averaged $5,178, based on September 2013 records.

The average debt in collections in the Tampa Bay area was higher at $6,287.

Ratcliffe said that stagnant incomes are key to why some parts of the country
are struggling to repay their debt.

Information from the Associated Press was used in this report.

* * *

Most, least delinquent debt in U.S., by metropolitan area

Most

Metro area................Percentage

1. McAllen, Texas..........51.7

2. Las Vegas.................49.2

3. Lakeland...................47.3

Least

1. Minneapolis-St. Paul...20.1

2. Honolulu...................21.0

3. Boston......................22.4

Source: Urban Institute "Delinquent Debt in America"

                               The New York Times

                   July 8, 1994, Friday, Late Edition - Final

COMPANY NEWS;
CALIFORNIA FEDERAL REDUCES LEVEL OF DELINQUENT ASSETS

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News

SECTION: Section D;  Page 3;  Column 1;  Financial Desk

LENGTH: 107 words


California Federal Bank said yesterday that it had sold $439 million in
performing and delinquent property loans and properties, the third selloff by
the institution since April. California Federal did not disclose the price. The
sale is part of a plan to reduce the Los Angeles savings bank's delinquent
loans. In May, California Federal agreed to sell $350 million worth of
performing and delinquent income-producing properties to Argo Partnership L.P.,
after selling $231 million in assets in April. With the three sales, California
Federal has cut its delinquent assets to 2 percent of total assets, which is in
line with the industry.

                          The Monitor (McAllen, Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           January 25, 2012 Wednesday

Hidalgo hires Linebarger for delinquent taxes

BYLINE: Dave Hendricks, The Monitor, McAllen, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 457 words


Jan. 25--HIDALGO -- The City Council hired law firm Linebarger Goggan Blair and
Sampson on Tuesday night to collect Hidalgo's delinquent property taxes.

The unanimous decision to hire Linebarger -- a major player in the lucrative and
highly political delinquent tax collection business -- came after controversy
over Mayor John David Franz's connection to rival firm Perdue Brandon Fielder
Collins and Mott, which collected the city's delinquent taxes last year.

Mayor Franz did not attend the meeting.

While the mayor's eponymous law firm has a joint venture agreement with Perdue
Brandon, that agreement doesn't cover the city contract. Nevertheless, the
mayor's uncle, longtime Hidalgo power broker Rudy Franz, had raised questions
about whether Mayor Franz would use his allies on the City Council -- including
his mother, Siglinde Franz -- to ensure Perdue Brandon kept the contract.

The furor reached a fever pitch on Jan. 10, when Linebarger attorneys arrived at
City Hall for the regularly scheduled meeting, only to find out elected
officials had canceled it for lack of quorum. Attorneys from Perdue Brandon,
apparently aware the meeting had been called off, didn't show up.

Asked for an interview, Perdue Brandon released a statement.

"While Perdue Brandon has a joint venture agreement with the Law Office of John
David Franz in the delinquent tax area, it is for the representation of other
taxing entities, not the City of Hidalgo. That has always been the case and will
remain that way," reads the statement. "Therefore, Perdue Brandon does not have
a conflict of interest representing the City of Hidalgo."

Both Linebarger and Perdue Brandon offered to collect Hidalgo's delinquent taxes
in exchange for a 15 percent cut of tax, penalties and interest actually
collected.

Perdue Brandon touted its nearly 44 percent collection rate during the past
year, and told Hidalgo Finance Director Xavier Moron in a letter that the firm
"knows the City of Hidalgo and your taxpayers." Perdue Brandon warned that the
Hidalgo Independent School District had experienced a lower year-to-date
collection rate for delinquent taxes after picking another firm.

The Hidalgo school district is controlled by Mayor Franz's rivals, and the
decision to switch delinquent tax collection firms was widely seen as a
political move.

Linebarger also submitted a letter detailing its experience and work with local
taxing entities, including McAllen and the Pharr-San Juan-Alamo school district.

Dave Hendricks covers McAllen and general assignments for The Monitor. He can be
reached at dhendricks@themonitor.com and (956) 683-4452.

BRIEF: Delinquent trash accounts on Monday's council agenda

BYLINE: Carly Gelsinger, The Gilroy Dispatch, Calif.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 214 words


June 15--During City Council's regular June 18 meeting, Recology South Valley,
Gilroy's exclusive trash-collecting company, will ask permission to send 168
delinquent Gilroy homeowner accounts to the County Auditor to place liens on
their properties.

The total amount in delinquent funds from Gilroy homeowners is $47,000. A
warning letter was sent out to homeowners who have outstanding Recology bills on
May 2, with a final payment deadline of June 15.

Also on Monday's agenda:

Council plans to vote on passing a $5,000 budget amendment to perform a
structural analysis at the interim Center for the Arts at 7341 Monterey St. and
provide an estimate on how much upgrades such as fire safety and structural
retrofitting would cost.

Council will also vote to appoint one member to an unexpired seat on the library
commission. Two applications were received for the seat.

The five-member library commission serves as an advisory and liaison body to the
Gilroy City Council, the City staff and Community Librarian on matters
concerning the Gilroy Library.

Monday's council meeting starts at 6 p.m. in Council Chambers, 7351 Rosanna St.

                         The Brownsville Herald (Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            June 13, 2012 Wednesday

County sells 20 tax-delinquent properties

BYLINE: The Brownsville Herald, The Brownsville Herald, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 237 words


June 13--Twenty properties were sold recently for a total of $302,922 to recover
back taxes, Cameron County Tax Assessor-Collector Tony Yzaguirre said.

The 20 properties were in a group of 68 recently offered for sale to recover
$750,000 in delinquent property taxes, he said.

Another 17 properties were struck from the list because no bids were received,
he said.

The remaining 31 properties were pulled from the tax sale when payment
arrangements were made with the county or the Linebarger law firm before the
sale, Yzaguirre said.

The next property tax sale is scheduled for September.

"To date, we have approximately 74 properties that will be posted for that
sale," he said. "I cannot stress how important it is to contact our office or
the law firm office to make payment arrangements before a delinquent tax lawsuit
is filed or before getting to the tax sale stage."

By making these arrangements, Yzaguirre said, property owners who are delinquent
on their taxes can preclude additional costs of penalties, interest and legal
fees.

He said his office is willing to work with property owners.

"But to be fair to the citizens of our county that pay their fair share, we
can't ignore those taxpayers who simply refuse to pay their taxes," Yzaguirre
added.

                   The Times-Tribune (Scranton, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            February 14, 2011 Monday

Valley View looks into financial option on tax delinquents

BYLINE: Caitlin Heaney, The Times-Tribune, Scranton, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 381 words


Feb. 14--The Valley View School District might not need the financial help right
now, but it nevertheless is looking into a program that could provide it with
money in the future.

At the school board's work session last week, district officials heard from a
representative of Municipal Revenue Service about buying the delinquent taxes
owed to the district.

"We're just in the initial stages of it," district business manager Corey
Castellani said. "We have to look into it, and we have some questions about it
and everything."

Superintendent Joseph Daley pointed out that the company neither collects taxes
nor is "tacking dollars on top of the existing cost." Rather, it buys delinquent
taxes owed to municipalities and school districts, providing those groups with
the money owed to them.

When the county collects those taxes, Mr. Castellani said, the money is paid to
the company.

Valley View is owed about $2.6 million in delinquent taxes, some of which go
back as far as 1993, Mr. Daley said.

"After a while, we have to at least start looking into what are our options," he
said.

Mr. Castellani said the district did not seek out the company, and it does not
necessarily need the service right now since it has a healthy fund balance. But
it is looking into it nevertheless.

There is "no better time to explore it than when you don't need it," Mr. Daley
said.

"It's just a matter of making sure everything is lined up and available should
we need it," he said.

And the district probably will not make a decision before Gov. Tom Corbett
addresses questions about education funding next month, Mr. Daley noted.

In the meantime, Mr. Castellani is speaking with other schools with which the
company has worked so it can "make the proper decision for Valley View."

"We have to sit down and talk about it," he said. "As of right now, we're in
pretty good shape. That will probably factor into our decision."

Contact the writer: cheaney@timesshamrock.com

                          The Monitor (McAllen, Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           October 21, 2009 Wednesday

Refunds pending to account holders overcharged for delinquent property taxes

BYLINE: Jennifer L. Berghom, The Monitor, McAllen, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 639 words


Oct. 21--Some McAllen school district taxpayers paid a little more than they had
to this year. But the district and the law firm it contracted to collect
delinquent taxes said they are working on giving out refunds.

In total, about 1,200 delinquent account holders overpaid to the tune of more
than $78,000, according to the school system and representatives of Linebarger,
Goggan, Blair & Sampson, the firm hired to collect from the late payers. The
national law firm has an office in Edinburg.

Both the district and the law firm said the overcharge resulted from
miscommunication among the school system, Linebarger and the Hidalgo County Tax
Assessor/Collector's Office.

The school district contracts with the county's tax assessor/collector to
calculate how much money needs to be recouped. The district also contracts with
the law firm, which then does the legwork to collect those delinquent taxes.

The law firm is paid though the legal fees that are included in the collection
of delinquent taxes. Since 2004, the firm had received a 20 percent fee, but in
October last year the school board voted to reduce it to 15 percent.

District residents who were delinquent on their 2008 taxes, therefore, should
have been charged a 15 percent legal fee. Instead, those who made late payments
between July 1 and Oct. 13 were charged a 20 percent fee because the county was
not made aware of the change.

The overpayment came to light at the school board's meeting on Oct. 13 when
board members were deciding whether to renew the district's contract with
Linebarger or sign on with a new firm, Perdue, Brandon, Fielder, Collins and
Mott, which is in a partnership with attorney John David Franz, the mayor of
Hidalgo.

Franz said his partners discovered the other firm's overcharge when it was
preparing to bid for the contract and that it disclosed that information at the
school board meeting.

The board originally voted at the Oct. 13 meeting to renew its contract with
Linebarger, but at a special called meeting Monday, the panel decided to rescind
that vote, determine how the miscommunication occurred and interview the firms
again.

Linebarger representatives said at the meeting Monday that they did not realize
the county had assessed the delinquent tax charges using the 20 percent fee and
gave the district a check for the overcharge plus interest so that it could
reimburse its taxpayers.

"The goal is to get the money back (to taxpayers) as quickly as possible," Joe
Householder, a spokesman for the Linebarger firm, said in a telephone interview
Tuesday.

But the school system remains in limbo as to who will collect its delinquent
taxes come Nov. 1. Its contract with Linebarger expires Oct. 31 and the board
members remain in a 3-3 deadlock. Board Trustee Danny Vela abstained from voting
at both meetings and from related discussions.

The board plans to revisit the issue on Oct. 26. McAllen School Board President
Richard Moore said Tuesday he has asked the board's attorney to see if any other
avenues can be taken to resolve the issue should the panel fail to reach a
majority vote.

"This is the first time the board is locked and I'm struggling with it," Moore
said. "We can't sit on the fence forever."

Next week's meeting will be at 1 p.m. at the Staff Development Center at Lamar
Academy, 1009 N. 10th St.

Jennifer L. Berghom covers education and general assignments for The Monitor.
She can be reached at (956) 683-4462.

                   The Times-Tribune (Scranton, Pennsylvania)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                           December 5, 2015 Saturday

Local tax collection firm in midst of Allentown scandal

BYLINE: Borys Krawczeniuk, The Times-Tribune, Scranton, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 753 words


Dec. 05--An official for the firm that collects delinquent real estate taxes for
Scranton and Luzerne County denied the company did anything wrong to gain a
contract that is a focus of an FBI investigation of Allentown city government.

Company officials were unaware of Allentown's process in awarding a delinquent
real estate tax collection contract, said Sean Shamany, treasurer and half-owner
of Wilkes-Barre-based Northeast Revenue.

"We always operate with the highest ethical standards," Mr. Shamany said.

He said Northeast Revenue is not a target of the investigation and local
officials don't have to worry about whether the firm can continue to collect
delinquent taxes. Neither Northeast Revenue nor any of its officials have been
charged.

A call to Mayor Bill Courtright was returned by city solicitor Jason Shrive, who
said the city would have no comment on the matter because of the criminal
investigation.

"As you know, Northeast Revenue ... has been a vendor of the City of Scranton
for some time, starting years before Mayor Courtright's administration," Mr.
Shrive wrote in an email. "During Mayor Courtright's tenure, (Northeast) has
always done the city's collections in a professional manner."

Efforts to reach Luzerne County manager Robert Lawton were unsuccessful.

On Monday, federal prosecutors in Philadelphia filed a criminal information
against Dale Wiles, Allentown's former assistant city solicitor, charging him
with conspiracy to commit mail and wire fraud. Mr. Wiles pleaded guilty to the
charges.

The information says Mr. Wiles was one of several officials who manipulated
Allentown's contract-awarding process in 2013 and 2014 to ensure the contract
for collecting delinquent Allentown real estate taxes went to donors to the
campaigns of someone named in the information only as Public Official No. 3.

The information says Public Official No. 3 had the power to decide Allentown's
contracts and "aspired to win election to a statewide elective office."

The only person who matches that description is Allentown Mayor Ed Pawlowski,
who ran briefly for governor in 2013 and 2014, and the U.S. Senate for three
months earlier this year. Efforts to reach Mr. Pawlowski were unsuccessful.

Public Official No. 3 fixed the process to ensure the contract to collect
delinquent property taxes went to Northeast Revenue and Friedman Schuman, a
Montgomery County law firm, which teamed up on their proposal, according to the
information.

In the information, Northeast and Friedman are known only as "the Partnership,"
but are identifiable because they received the contract.

Public Official No. 3 did that because he was unhappy with campaign
contributions from the city's existing delinquent tax collector and said he
would measure future contract awards by contributions, according to the
information.

The mayor got campaign contributions from the Pennsylvania Liberty Fund, a
political action committee organized and heavily funded by Friedman Schuman
officials. The fund gave $5,000 as the contract was being decided in late 2013
and $10,000 more in 2014 afterward.

Though no one at Northeast gave directly to the mayor's committees, three of its
officials -- Mr. Shamany, company president John P. Rodgers, and company
official Daryl Boich -- gave $20,000 total to the liberty fund as Allentown was
deciding on the contract. Mr. Rodgers, Northeast's other half-owner, gave
$14,000 with $10,000 as the contract was being awarded, and Mr. Boich and Mr.
Shamany gave $3,000 each.

In an interview, Mr. Rodgers denied contributing as part of a pay-to-play
scheme. He referred further questions to Mr. Shamany, who, he said, runs
Northeast Revenue's day-to-day operations. Mr. Shamany denied company officials
contributed to get the contract and denied anyone asked them to contribute in
exchange for it.

"There was no quid pro quo," Mr. Shamany said.

So far, federal prosecutors have not charged anyone with contributing to get the
contract or anyone with asking for contributions in its award, though the
information mentions the Partnership's contributions to Public Official No. 3's
campaigns.

Mr. Shamany said the fund gave to many officials, Republican and Democratic,
across the state.

"We felt we could take the politics out of our hands and allow the PAC to handle
donations to different politicians," he said.

Contact the writer:

bkrawczeniuk@timesshamrock.com

                          The Decatur Daily (Alabama)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           September 21, 2010 Tuesday

Decatur seeking delinquent taxpayers

BYLINE: Evan Belanger, The Decatur Daily, Ala.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 310 words


Sept. 21--Delinquent taxpayers beware, the city of Decatur is looking for you.

The City Council voted Monday to hire Revenue Discovery Systems of Birmingham to
assist the city in identifying and collecting delinquent taxes from companies
and individuals that have done business in Decatur without purchasing a business
license.

Revenue Administrator Tina Boyles said the company will compare a database of
business records to the city tax records to detect those who have operated in
the city without a business within the past three years.

The first letters seeking payment of back taxes will be mailed within three to
four weeks, she said.

The contract comes as part of Mayor Don Stanford's proposed budget for fiscal
2011, which predicts an additional $250,000 in revenue next year from the
back-tax payments. Boyles predicted most of the culprits would be companies that
deliver their own products in Decatur without purchasing a required business
license.

Only Councilman Billy Jackson voted against the measure.

During discussion, he said the Revenue Department should be doing the work on
its own.

Boyles said the Revenue Department does not have access to the same database
information that RDS does.

Under the three-year agreement, RDS will keep 50 percent of the revenue it
collects for the city. Boyles said the city will take 100 percent of the revenue
once those businesses begin renewing their licenses next year.

To see more of The Decatur Daily, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.decaturdaily.com Copyright (c) 2010, The Decatur Daily, Ala.

                             153 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         The Brownsville Herald (Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           January 25, 2007 Thursday

One last chance: County to sue more than 100 tax delinquents Friday

BYLINE: Laura B. Martinez, The Brownsville Herald, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 355 words


Jan. 25--January 25, 22007 --

Cameron County taxpayers delinquent on their county, school and city taxes will
soon be the defendants in lawsuits the county plans to file against them on
Friday.

The county will sue 105 individuals and businesses that have failed to pay an
estimated $868,884.92 in delinquent taxes from 2005 and earlier, officials said.

The taxing jurisdictions seeking unpaid taxes are in Brownsville, Harlingen, La
Feria, Los Fresnos, Port Isabel, Rio Hondo, San Benito, Santa Rosa and Santa
Maria.

Approximately $140,879.29 of the amount is owned to Cameron County alone.

County Tax Assessor-Collector Tony Yzaguirre Jr. said 61 of the defendants are
personal property owners, while the remaining 44 deal with real or business
property taxes.

"The vast majority of Cameron County taxpayers pay what they owe on time and in
full," Yzaguirre said in a press release. "It is unfair to them when others who
know their taxes are due refuse to do anything about it.

Joe Householder, with Linebarger Goggan Blair & Sampson, which has a contract
with the county to collect unpaid taxes, said the delinquent taxpayers have
received at least four notices or more regarding their status.

The law firm sends delinquent notices and conducts research before it files the
lawsuits, he said.

The names of individuals and businesses that are delinquent and are being sued
will be made public at 11 a.m., after the lawsuits become public record.

"If they want to avoid litigation they need to take care of it before 11 a.m.
Friday,'" Householder said.

Yzaguirre said if any individuals wish to pay or settle their debts, they should
contact either him or the law firm of Linebarger Googan Blair & Sampson.

Ad valorem taxes for 2006 are due by Jan. 31. After this date, they are
considered delinquent.

lmartinez@brownsvilleherald.com

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                   August 20, 1993, FRIDAY, FIVE STAR Edition

CROWD OF DELINQUENT TAXPAYERS EXPECTED

BYLINE: Ralph Dummit Of the St. Charles Post

SECTION: ST. CHARLES; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 432 words


Delinquent taxpayers are expected to crowd the windows at the St. Charles County
collector's office today to avoid having their property auctioned off at an
annual tax sale on Monday.  Friday will be the last full day taxpayers have to
square away their real estate tax accounts before the properties go on the
block.  "We expect a lot of action," said Barbara J. Walker, the county
collector.  The owners of more than 800 properties were identified late last
month as being delinquent for two years or more in the payment of their real
estate taxes. After the publication of that list, the property owners started
paying, and the list shrank by Thursday afternoon to 647.  The original list of
delinquent accounts totaled $3.41 million. So far, delinquent payments have
amounted to $2.35 million. That leaves a little over $1 million unpaid. "We're
coming along," Walker said.  Much of the uncollected balance consists of
interest and penalties on the late taxes, Walker said.  One of the largest
outstanding accounts is for delinquent taxes on 343 condo units owned by Cedar
Ridge Associates at Lake Saint Louis. The taxes owed on each unit range from
$797 to $986. The owners of Cedar Ridge owe about $330,000, Walker said.  Walker
said that collecting delinquent taxes and making arrangements to auction off the
properties for which taxes have not been paid is one of the more troublesome
tasks of her job as collector.  "It seems like every year it gets a little more
complicated," she said. For example, Walker said late Thursday that a delinquent
taxpayer had called to say that he lived in the flood plain and had received an
insurance check for flood damage. The man asked Walker if he could sign the
insurance check over to her as payment of his taxes. "I had to tell him that we
just can't do that," she said.  Taxes on property scheduled for the auction must
be paid by certified check, money order or cash.  The collector expects many of
the delinquent tax bills to be paid today and right up to the 11 a.m. deadline
on Monday. The collector's office will be open from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. today on
the lower level of the county Administration Building, 118 North Second Street,
St. Charles.  "We expect to have people coming right at 5 p.m. Friday," Walker
said. And Monday morning will be busy, too." Before starting the auction at 11
a.m. Monday on the west steps of the courthouse, Walker said, "I'll make a phone
call down the hill," to see if any last-minute taxpayers have met the deadline.
"We don't want to sell something that's already been paid," she said.

LOAD-DATE: October 11, 1993

LANGUAGE: English

                  Copyright 1993 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.

                   The Times-Tribune (Scranton, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            February 14, 2011 Monday

Fell lowers delinquent sewer bills

BYLINE: Caitlin Heaney, The Times-Tribune, Scranton, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 420 words


Feb. 14--Fell Twp. has started a forgiveness program for residents on its sewer
system who owe delinquent payments.

"We're going to give the people 50 percent off as long as they pay the other 50
percent," Supervisor Ron Cosklo said. "There's too many people that are really
hurting."

Of the approximately 650 people billed, about 90 are delinquent, Mr. Cosklo
said. He attributed some of the delinquencies to the fact that there are older
residents in the area living on Social Security who "don't have this kind of
money."

The forgiveness program only applies to people hooked up to the Simpson Sewer
System. Residents who choose to participate will be required to start making
their quarterly payments or else forfeit the 50 percent reduction, Mr. Cosklo
said.

The 50 percent residents can pay will go into the Simpson Sewer Fund, the $2.6
million low-interest, state loan the township took out from the Pennsylvania
Infrastructure Investment Authority, or Pennvest, to install sewers in Simpson
in 1992-93. That project cost $2.8 million.

The township still owes about $750,000 toward the loan and must pay
approximately $8,600 at minimum per quarter toward that amount. Usually enough
residents pay their sewer bills to cover that amount, Mr. Cosklo said, but the
township would have to pay any remaining amount owed if it were short.

Sewer bills for residents hooked up to the Simpson system cover not only their
service but also help pay back the state loan, the "Simpson Sewer Fund." Per
quarter, residents there pay $38 to the fund and $60 to the Lackawanna River
Basin Sewer Authority.

Mr. Cosklo expects the new program might encourage people to start paying again
and also increase the rate at which the township pays off the state loan. The
forgiveness program also will benefit people who diligently paid their sewer
bills each quarter because more payments coming in will reduce the amount of
time it takes for the township to pay off the loan.

The long-term loan is a "major expense," township solicitor Joseph O'Brien said.

"If the loan were all paid off, the sewer rates would certainly go down
substantially," he said.

Contact the writer: cheaney@timesshamrock.com

To see more of The Times-Tribune or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.thetimes-tribune.com/. Copyright (c) 2011, The Times-Tribune,
Scranton, Pa. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For more
information about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information
Services (MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com.

                        The Augusta Chronicle (Georgia)

                          December 29, 2010 Wednesday
                                  ALL EDITION

Office plans to send out new warning;
Nonpayment would result in lien on property

BYLINE: By Sylvia Cooper < Staff Writer

SECTION: METRO; Pg. B01

LENGTH: 375 words


If your 2010 property taxes still haven't been paid, expect to hear from the
Richmond County Tax Office next week.

Tax Commissioner Steven Kendrick's office will mail 12,000 letters Friday,
giving taxpayers 30 days to pay, or the tax office will place liens on their
properties.

A 10 percent penalty was placed on delinquent property taxes after the Dec. 20
deadline.

Meanwhile, 12 of the 15 biggest delinquent property tax bills listed in recent
Augusta Chronicle articles have been paid.

The largest delinquent account and three others were paid this month before
penalties went into effect.

National Hills Exchange paid $143,716.95 in taxes for National Hills shopping
center at 2701 Washington Road on Dec. 7, settling the top delinquent account.
Others that paid before the penalty deadline:

USPG Portfolio One LLC paid $61,179.69 for a portion of Walmart, 590 Bobby Jones
Expressway, on Dec. 8.

Purohit & Associates LLC paid $59,617.59 for Staybridge Hotel, Center West
Parkway, on Dec. 20.

Finnchem USA Inc., Huron Tech paid $58,348.12 for Huron Tech chemical, 2360 Doug
Barnard Parkway, on Dec. 10.

Those on the original list of top tax bills that still haven't been paid are:

RDC Properties LLC, $102,073.75 in taxes, penalty and interest for the Sun Trust
Building at 801 Broad St.

RDC Properties LLC, $77,605.92 in taxes, penalty and interest for the Lamar
Building, 753 Broad St.

Cascades Pointe at Augusta, $43,765.21 in taxes, penalty and interest for
College Station Apartments, 3105 Wrightsboro Road.

Since the first article listing the 15 biggest delinquent property tax bills was
published Nov. 27, the following accounts have been paid:

$108,876.64 on the Sam's building at 596 Bobby Jones Expressway

$92,525.62 for Iron Horse Apartments on Stevens Creek Road

$82,895.62 on the Walmart building at 594 Bobby Jones Expressway

$63,761.28 for Spicewood Apartments on Wheeler Road

$35,867.01 on Thornberry Apartments at 3204 Skinner Mill Road

$48,475.37 for Comfort Inn, 1455 Walton Way

$64,293.43 for Shapiro Meat Packing at 1301 N. Savannah Road

$54,788.28 for Shapiro Meat Packing personal property and inventory at 1150
Fifth St.

$44,312.40 for Augusta Oncology, 3606 Wheeler Road.

                             157 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                  July 9, 1999, Friday, Sunday, Final Edition

Back Taxes Put Property On the D.C. Auction Block

Eric Lipton, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: METRO; Pg. B01

LENGTH: 986 words



Republican presidential candidate Patrick J. Buchanan, Democratic Rep. Thomas
Lantos, the Embassy of Botswana, an association of wheat growers and the
Archdiocese of Washington. What could possibly tie these parties together?

They're all on a list of 7,730 D.C. property owners that the city government
claims as so delinquent on their taxes that their homes, land or buildings could
be sold off later this month. Although several of those on the list--including
Buchanan and Lantos--say they've paid their taxes, their properties remain on
the city's auction list.

At the D.C. Office of Tax and Revenue auction July 20 to 23, bidders will be
able to buy thousands of homes and buildings on the delinquent tax rolls for as
little as $ 100.08, the amount of delinquent taxes owed on one of the
properties.

The District hopes to collect $ 19.8 million in back taxes. Ultimately, the
auction is more of a debt collection effort than a land sale, given that all but
a couple hundred of the land owners likely will pay their bills before losing
their property. But in the last two years, the city has earned $ 20.7 million
through the process and cleared up debts on 9,025 accounts, said Stan Jackson,
the city's chief of assessment services.

Property owners can end up on the auction list even if they are only six months
late in paying their taxes, but some bills have been accumulating for years.
Only about 220 of the thousands of property owners owe more than $ 10,000, and
in some cases they are delinquent only on late-payment interest.

The single largest delinquent property owner is listed as the San
Francisco-based Trust for Public Land, a nonprofit land conservation group that
14 years ago embarked on a much-delayed project to build affordable housing in
the Mayfair-Parkside area.

The trust, which did succeed in building some housing in the area, still owns
about 50 parcels on Kenilworth Terrace, Foote Street and Anacostia Avenue that
are slated to be auctioned, based on delinquent tax bills totaling about $ 1.2
million. Phyllis Nudelman, regional counsel for the group, said yesterday that
she was unaware the property is on the auction block.

"I am a bit surprised," she said, blaming one of the trust's partners for the
delinquency. "Our hope and goal is the land will still be developed for
affordable housing."

Several of the other large delinquent bills are the subject of disputes.

The District-based National Association for Home Care, for example, owes $
215,523 in taxes for six properties on A Street NE, where it operates the
Frederick Douglass Museum and Hall of Fame for Caring Americans. Val J.
Halamandaris, president of the group, said the properties should be tax-exempt
because they serve as a museum. But so far, the museum is still on the auction
list, Jackson said.

The eight-page, fine-print listing of properties on the auction block, published
recently in The Washington Post, also included the Embassy of Botswana on New
Hampshire Avenue NW, suggesting that the nation was $ 83,553 in debt to the
District. But Jackson said this week that after consultations with the State
Department, the embassy won't be offered at auction because the city intends to
give Botswana a tax exemption.

The Shakespeare Theatre and the Bureau of National Affairs both had properties
on the auction list, but they too have since been removed after the city
realized it had made an error.

Buchanan and Lantos each say they have paid their past-due bills, listed as $
215 for a Connecticut Avenue NW home owned by Buchanan and $ 109 for the
California congressman's home on Maryland Avenue NE. Buchanan's property manager
even provided The Post with a copy of a check he said he had sent in.

That check shows that the payment was made late, and it is the past-due interest
that appears to have landed Buchanan's property on the auction block.

Lantos aide Bob King said the tax bill on the Maryland Avenue property "did not
reach the congressman because of some misaddressing. It has been taken care of."

But the District's Jackson said that as of yesterday, his records showed that
the Buchanan and Lantos debts are still pending.

Among the other notables on the city's list of delinquents are the Archdiocese
of Washington, which owes a total of about $ 7,300 on several pieces of land in
Southeast that city records indicate are not tax-exempt, and eight pieces of
Chinatown land controlled by prominent real-estate developer Douglas Jemal, for
which a total of $ 31,843 is owed. The National Association of Wheat Growers was
listed as owing $ 65,219 on its Second Street NE headquarters.

The bidding, which will start at 9:15 a.m., July 20 at 941 North Capitol St. NE,
is open to the general public. But buying a delinquent property can be
complicated.

Bidders need put up only as much money as is owed on the past-due tax bills,
such as the $ 170.73 owed on a single-family home on Q Street SE that has an
assessed value of $ 86,734. But the delinquent owners may reclaim their property
within six months after the auction by paying the bidder back the investment,
plus 1.5 percent per month interest.

Before the deed is transferred to the new owner, all outstanding debts to the
city must be cleared, including any water and sewer bills, housing code fines or
other pending tax bills, which sometimes can cost more than $ 20,000.

Some bidders in such auctions have learned about these other debts after
purchasing the tax lien, and have lost their investment after realizing they
could not afford the additional costs.

"You have to make sure you do your homework before you bid on a property,"
Jackson said.

(This graphic was not available) Delinquent Property Owners Republican
presidential candidate Patrick J. Buchanan is one of 7,730 D.C. property owners
whose homes, land or buildings could be sold because of delinquent taxes.

                          Harlan Daily Enterprise, Ky.

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            August 29, 2013 Thursday

Delinquent county tax bills due

BYLINE: Nola Sizemore, Harlan Daily Enterprise, Ky.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 474 words


Aug. 29--With 1,700 delinquent tax bills remaining unpaid in the county, Harlan
County Clerk Donna Hoskins said the deadline to pay and avoid the sale of tax
bills is Sept. 5.

"This amounts to several hundreds of thousands of dollars," said Hoskins. "The
deadline for property owners to pay their current 2012 tax bills is no later
than 4:30 p.m. on Sept. 5. On the very next day at 9 a.m., no payments can be
accepted because the bills will be presented to companies wishing to purchase
the tax bills and place liens against your property."

Hoskins said the companies purchasing delinquent tax bills are registered with
the state and receive a certificate saying they may participate in the sale.

She said there are companies from as far away as Nebraska, Texas and Ohio, along
with companies from Pikeville, Bowling Green and Olive Hill with certificates
ready to participate in this year's sale.

"These companies purchase the delinquent tax bill and they become the first lien
holder on your property even if you have a mortgage with the bank," said
Hoskins. "They hold these bills for a year, some two years, and then they
foreclose on the property. This process goes through circuit court, where they
force the sale of the property and they can do this because they are the first
lien holder."

Hoskins said, "These delinquent tax bill purchasing companies make their money
through a 12 percent penalty and interest rate at 1 percent per month allowed
through the state, plus other legal and administrative fees they are also
allowed to charge. We've had people tell us these companies have purchased their
tax bill for $300 and it may be $1,500 to $2,000 before they pay it off. We have
no control over that. It stops with us when the tax bill is sold on Sept. 6."

Hoskins said property owners will save a "tremendous amount of money" if they
will try to pay their delinquent tax bill in full by Sept. 5.

She said if that is not possible, property owners may set up a payment plan
through the county attorney's office.

"They can call or visit the county attorney's office and sign a contract for a
payment plan, but this must be done by Sept. 3 or 4," said Hoskins. "The payment
plan will keep their tax bills from being sold. When they sign the contract they
are agreeing to make a payment every month and, if they don't, the tax bill will
be turned back over to the clerk's office to be in the next tax sale.

"I know it's a bad time and money is tight, but tax bills are there if you own
property -- they have to be taken care of," said Hoskins.

For more information, call the clerk's office at 606-573-3636.

Reach Nola Sizemore at 606-573-4510, ext. 115, nsizemore@civitasmedia.com

                                Payments Source

                             March 12, 2012 Monday

City To Hire Agency To Collect $1.5M In Delinquent Business, Utility Loans

SECTION: CCR - DEALS & PRICING Vol. 1 No. 1

LENGTH: 214  words


Pennsylvania's capital city of Harrisburg, reporting that two-thirds of 44 loans
made under the city's small business loan program are delinquent, expects to
soon announce the name of a collection agency that will chase the outstanding
loans "at no charge".

Mayor Linda Thompson says that more than $800,000 is delinquent. The same
collection agency also will be in charge of pursuing delinquent utility bills
totaling an estimated $674,000

The city has a hit list of the 31 delinquent small-business lendees. Thompson
said she is willing to work with business owners who still owe but that
collection efforts put a burden on an already depleted city staff. "We are
always trying to work with people to restructure loans, but they have made no
effort to negotiate with us," she said.Of the outside collection agency: "They
are not expecting any percentage of the collections," she said. "What they
collect will go 100% back to the city. Nothing will come off the top to them."

In related news, Harrisburg will skip $5.3 million of debt payments due next
week, the first time the city has defaulted on its general obligation bonds, to
ensure there is enough cash to fund vital services.

The city is mired in $326 million of debt due to retrofits and repairs of its
troubled trash incinerator.

                             160 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             August 4, 2014 Monday

Section 8 change brings $22K in delinquent garbage fees

BYLINE: Kevin Flowers, Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 516 words


Aug. 04--Landlords with delinquent city of Erie garbage accounts who want to be
part of the federal Section 8 housing assistance program are paying up.

John Horan, the Erie Housing Authority's executive director, said a new
authority policy requiring all landlords who participate in the Section 8
program to be current on all local taxes and fees, including refuse bills, has
prompted Section 8 landlords to pay more than $22,000 in delinquent bills to
Erie Water Works since January.

Erie Water Works collects water, sewer and refuse bills on the city's behalf.

The policy took effect in April and was explained to Erie City Council at the
panel's June 4 Finance Committee meeting. The Housing Authority's move came as
city government continues to look for ways to collect $2.15 million in
delinquent garbage fees owed to the city.

Many of the largest delinquent accounts belong to landlords, and several of them
own multiple properties. City officials have been criticized by many residents
for not being aggressive enough over the years in collecting overdue garbage
bills, especially since residents' garbage fees were increased in the city's
2014 budget.

"Our policy has definitely had an impact," Horan said. "I think that is a real
good result, and I expect that by next spring, we will have these things down to
zero, or close to it."

Section 8 is a federal program that provides rent subsidies to eligible
low-income people and families and is funded by the U.S. Department of Housing
and Urban Development. People who qualify pay a set portion of their rent, and
the federal government covers the rest.

The Housing Authority administers the program within the city limits, and there
are about 900 Section 8 housing units citywide owned by roughly 400 landlords
who participate in the program, according to Horan.

Erie Water Works in January provided information to the Housing Authority that
indicated the owners of 122 Section 8 properties owed a collective $55,752 in
delinquent refuse bills, Horan said.

After the Housing Authority changed its Section 8 policy and notified landlords,
many of them started paying their delinquent bills, Horan said.

Currently, the owners of 41 Section 8 properties owe a collective $33,577, which
means the Section 8 garbage delinquencies have been reduced by $22,175 since
January.

Horan added that more than $11,000 in delinquent refuse bills have been paid
since June 6, when the Erie Times-News first reported on the policy change. At
that time, there were 54 delinquent Section 8 accounts totaling $44,871, which
means the Section 8 delinquencies have dropped by $11,294 since early June.

Paul Vojtek, chief executive of Erie Water Works, applauded the Housing
Authority's policy change.

"That is good news," Vojtek said. "I think these are the kinds of things that
are going to make a big difference down the road."

KEVIN FLOWERS can be reached at 870-1693 or by e-mail. Follow him on Twitter at
twitter.com/ETNflowers.

                        Topeka Capital-Journal (Kansas)

                           December 30, 2014 Tuesday

Kansas consumers took on more debt this year

BYLINE: Megan Hart.

megan.hart@cjonline.com

LENGTH: 499 words


Kansas consumers increased their debt in the third quarter to an average
$16,127, according to data from the U.S. Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City.

That means Kansans have an average of $110 more in consumer debt than they did
in the second quarter. Consumer debt has increased 10 percent since the second
quarter of 2011, rising in most quarters.

Consumer debt, as defined by the Federal Reserve, includes credit cards, home
equity lines of credit, auto loans, student loans and mortgages on properties,
such as vacation homes that weren't purchased for business reasons. The mortgage
on a family's primary home isn't included.

The Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City covers seven states. Colorado and
Wyoming had higher average debts than Kansas, while Missouri, Nebraska, New
Mexico and Oklahoma had lower averages.

The Federal Reserve information doesn't attempt to quantify whether the debt
burden will be higher than the average consumer can bear, so it isn't clear if
the trend is a good or bad sign for the future economy. Heavy debts were a major
drag on the economy during the recession, but rising debts also can be a sign
that consumers feel confident enough about the economy to make purchases they
might have been putting off, such as replacing an old car.

Most of the increase in debt in Kansas was driven by student and auto loans,
while credit card and home equity debt remained largely flat. A similar trend
happened nationwide, though the average American has more total and credit card
debt than the average Kansan.

About 4.2 percent of all consumer debt accounts in Kansas were delinquent, down
0.1 percent from the previous quarter. Delinquent accounts are at least 30 days
behind on payments, and while it isn't impossible consumers will eventually pay
up, they are an indication that they could default. Nationwide, 5.8 percent of
all consumer debt accounts were delinquent, down 0.2 percent from the second
quarter.

Those averages conceal broad differences among debt types, though. Student loan
debt showed the most trouble, with 15 percent of student loans nationwide and
13.7 percent in Kansas behind at least 30 days. Auto loans had the second
highest rate, with 8.5 percent delinquent nationwide and 6.5 percent delinquent
in Kansas.

About 7 percent of mortgages were 30 days behind in Kansas and 3.1 percent were
90 or more days behind, making it likely they will enter foreclosure. The rates
were higher in Topeka, where 9.2 percent of mortgages were 30 days behind and
4.4 percent were 90 days behind.

Morris and Jewell counties had the highest rates of mortgages that were behind
by 90 days or more. The rates were lowest in Cheyenne, Smith, Sheridan, Graham,
Gove and Lane counties, where less than 1 percent of mortgages were that far
behind. In some cases, however, that may not reflect actual conditions. If a
county has a low number of outstanding mortgages, a small number of
delinquencies will skew its rate and make it appear the county has a serious
problem.

LOAD-DATE: December 30, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                   Copyright 2014 The Topeka Capital-Journal
                              All Rights Reserved


                             162 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                               India Retail News

                      November 8, 2013 Friday 6:30 AM EST

South Dakota Retailers Association: Business Tax Delinquency Report Expanded

LENGTH: 279  words


New Delhi, Nov. 8 -- A report that allows the South Dakota Department of Revenue
to list businesses with business tax delinquencies on its website has been
expanded to include a greater number of delinquent businesses.



The report, authorized by SDCL 10-59-46, serves as an additional resource for
the Department to use in its efforts to collect delinquent taxes according to
Business Tax Director Doug Schinkel.

"The Revenue Department makes every effort to collect past-due taxes," said
Schinkel. "This report is one of the tools we use in our collection process.
Expanding the report to include more delinquencies will help support our
collection efforts."

The Department can publicly list delinquent people who owe sales tax, use tax,
tourism tax, municipal tax, municipal gross receipts tax, contractors' excise
tax, motor vehicle leasing tax or telecommunications gross receipts tax to the
state of South Dakota if a lien has been filed against those people.

The list displays the top delinquent taxpayers owing the largest amount of tax,
and includes the person's name; the business name, if any; and the amount of
total tax, penalties and interest outstanding for each delinquent business.

A business will be removed from the report within 10 days after the full
delinquent debt payment has been processed by the Department of Revenue.

People on the list, or any taxpayer with a delinquent amount owed to the state,
can pay the amount due by mailing a check payable to the S.D. State Treasurer.
Payments should be sent to Department of Revenue Remittance Center, P.O. Box
5055, Sioux Falls, SD 57117-5055. A business license number should be included
on the check, if possible.

                             163 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                     The News Herald (Panama City, Florida)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              May 12, 2009 Tuesday

Delinquent tax rolls jump 23.6 percent

BYLINE: Pat Kelly, The News Herald, Panama City, Fla.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 498 words


May 12--PANAMA CITY, Fla. -- PANAMA CITY -- Whether caused by the state of the
economy or a state of mind, Bay County's delinquent tax rolls jumped nearly 25
percent this year over last.

County Tax Collector Peggy Brannon said more than 9 percent of property owners
who pay real estate taxes in Bay County are delinquent on their 2008 taxes,
representing almost $21.5 million after penalties and fees are added.

Brannon said 10,366 names appear on the delinquent rolls this year, compared to
8,389 names last year, an increase of about 23.6 percent. She called it "a sign
of the times that is magnified throughout the state."

The delinquent property taxes embody money owed to Bay County, the various
municipalities within the county and the Bay District Schools, Brannon said.

Brannon said interested individuals and institutional investors can begin
bidding today on the sale of tax certificates for each delinquent parcel.
Citizens can bid on and purchase the tax certificate by paying the owed tax plus
a 3-percent penalty, she said.

The sale is conducted in reverse-auction style with participants bidding
downward on interest rates starting at 18 percent. The certificate, which
represents a lien on the unpaid property, is awarded to the lowest bidder.

When the taxes are paid and the certificate is redeemed, an investor can earn up
to 18 percent on his or her money, Brannon said. Very few certificates are
bought by individuals actually interested in purchasing the piece of property,
she said.

"In fact, we tell people who are interesting in buying a certain piece of
property that they should contact the individual property owner," she said.

Bay County Clerk of Court Bill Kinsaul said if the property taxes remain
delinquent for two years, the holder of the tax certificate can force a sale of
the property. The property then would be sold to the highest bidder and the tax
certificate would be redeemed.

In a random sample of 130 delinquent parcels listed consecutively on the rolls
this year, individual tax certificates could be purchased by paying anywhere
from $73.01 to $24,987.01.

According to the Bay County Tax Collector Web site, all unpaid real estate taxes
become delinquent April 1 each year. The Web site also is used to bid on the tax
certificates.

Beginning today, the delinquent taxes are advertised in The News Herald once a
week for three consecutive weeks before a tax certificate sale is held following
the payment deadline. The advertising cost is added to the amount of the tax
bill. Brannon said the tax certificate sale will be held by June 1.

To see more of The News Herald or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.newsherald.com. Copyright (c) 2009, The News Herald, Panama City,
Fla. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                             May 31, 2014 Saturday

Montana: Collector 10054177

LENGTH: 414  words

DATELINE: Helena


Department of Labor & Industry, The State of Montana has issued the following
job announcement:

10054177
Job Title:  Collector
Employer:  EXPRESS PROFESSIONALS
Location:  KALISPELL MT, 59901
Description:  Collect all assigned later-stage delinquent accounts, to reduce
the risk of loss to the organization.

Pursue, develop and maintain positive relationships with all customers who are
delinquent in their loan payments. Contact all customers who are behind on their
loan payments on a daily basis, as directed by Collections Supervisor and Senior
Management. Complete each customer contact with definite understanding by each
party as to the current payment commitment. Document all customer contact
attempts and their specific outcomes. Maintain updated contact information on
all delinquent customers. Process and document all extensions, modifications and
refinancing arrangements. Monitor, identify, process and document all
repossessions, bankruptcies and NSF checks. Effectively strategize a variety of
approaches to the handling and resolution of delinquent accounts. Work to
resolve situations in which delinquent customers are defensive, hostile,
evasive, or unresponsive to suggested resolution methods. Exercise reasoned
judgment with regard to unusual collection circumstances and challenges.
Effectively review and explain all aspects of a delinquent customers account(s)
to them, including loan documents, loan terms, payment due dates, interest
rates, loan modifications, forced placed insurance, and other related account
questions and/or issues. Generate collection reports as needed and required.
Recommend and implement Collections procedures as they relate to delinquent
accounts, internal procedures and policies, and new regulatory compliance when
applicable. Maintain ongoing communication with Collections Supervisor,
informing them of all pertinent problems, irregularities, new developments,
changes and other important information within area of Collections. Work
proactively and positively with other Collections department personnel to ensure
a team effort and prompt service. Assist other Collections department personnel
by answering questions, solving problems and helping with complex work-related
matters. Forward written correspondence to appropriate departments for filing.
Associates or Bachelors degree in accounting, finance or banking preferred but
not required. At least 2 years professional experience with collection
procedures required.
Open

Treasurerâ[#x20ac][TM]s Office Announces Online Option for Setoff Debt Protests

LENGTH: 198  words

DATELINE: New York



 Columbia: Beaufort county, The state of South Carolina has issued the following
news release:


 The Beaufort County Treasurer's Office will offer an online form for taxpayers
wishing to protest a delinquent

 tax debt submitted to the Department of Revenue for collection pursuant to the
Setoff Debt Collection Act.



 On August 12, 2016, Collection of Debt letters were sent to delinquent
taxpayers with delinquent real and/or

 personal property taxes in an attempt to collect tax debts. Previously, the
only method to protest a debt was

 by submitting a written protest via mail."In the last year, the Treasurer's
Office collected over $540,000 in delinquent taxes through the Setoff Debt

 Collection program. By offering an online protest option, a taxpayer may
conveniently dispute and hopefully

 resolve the debt owed prior to having their state refund garnished for the
debt," said Maria Walls, Beaufort

 County Treasurer.

 Taxpayers will be able to protest delinquent debts in writing, by mail or using
the new online option within

 30 days of the date listed on their letter.

                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           January 18, 2014 Saturday

Total delinquent Erie garbage bills: nearly $2.5 million -- and counting

BYLINE: Kevin Flowers, Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 305 words


Jan. 18--Every three months, Erie's Joe Koehle pays his garbage bill.

Koehle, co-coordinator of the East Bayfront Neighborhood Watch, said he expects
others to do the same, on time, even after the city increased garbage fees by
nearly 15 percent to help balance its 2014 budget.

When people don't pay, Koehle believes the city of Erie should aggressively go
after that delinquent revenue -- especially when those overdue bills represent
millions of dollars.

"I just don't understand why in this day and age it's so hard to collect this
money," said Koehle, 55, who lives in the 200 block of East Second Street.

The Erie Times-News examined the issue of delinquent garbage fees in 2010. At
that time, overdue garbage payments and penalties totaled $1.16 million,
according to Erie Water Works, which took over billing for the city in 2006.

As of Dec. 31, that total was nearly $1.6 million, according to the Water Works,
which means overdue payments/penalties have increased 38 percent since 2010.

Further, when you include municipal liens totaling more than $930,000 filed
against scores of other delinquent customers/accounts, the total delinquency
amount swells to about $2.5 million, said Paul Vojtek, the Erie Water Works'
chief executive.

Many of the overdue accounts go back more than a decade, with many individual
customers owing thousands of dollars each. In one case, Water Works records
show, a customer owes more than $26,000 on multiple rental properties.

Erie City Councilwoman Jessica Horan-Kunco said city officials, including
council and Mayor Joe Sinnott's administration, have not done enough in recent
years to tackle the delinquencies.

That needs to change in 2014, Horan-Kunco said.

                          The Monitor (McAllen, Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           January 12, 2013 Saturday

La Joya ISD switches up its delinquent tax collector

BYLINE: Andrew Kreighbaum, The Monitor, McAllen, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 395 words


Jan. 12--La Joya school board trustees voted this week to terminate Linebarger,
Goggan, Blair & Sampson as the district's delinquent tax collection firm,
awarding the deal to its chief local competitor.

Perdue Brandon Fielder Collins and Mott LLP, which collects delinquent taxes on
behalf of McAllen Independent School District among other local entities, will
take over the service for La Joya.

Board president Juan Jose Pena Jr. declined to comment on the board's Thursday
decision, instead referring questions to school district attorney Jaime Munoz.

The contract with Linebarger had not yet expired but Munoz said board members
undertook a study of their current deal after taking office in November.

"It didn't have anything to do with the terms," of the contract, Munoz said.
"The board of trustees basically analyzed the district's current relationship
with the tax attorney and felt it was in the interest of both parties to go in a
different direction."

Pena and trustee Espie Ochoa were the only board members to vote against the
deal with Perdue.

Trustee Juan Jose Garza, who voted for the contract, referred questions to
Munoz. Other board members did not respond to requests for comment on the vote.

The board also voted to terminate the district's contract with Ruth Villarreal
as insurance agent for its self-insured Health Insurance Program. Pharr-based
insurance agent Bob Trevino will take over those services for the district.

Ochoa was the only incumbent candidate to join Team Liberty, the five-person
slate that swept the school board elections last year. Pena and trustee Johnn V.
Alaniz, who did not face reelection in November, also endorsed the slate.

The two tax collection firms are known for being generous to political
candidates' campaign accounts. Team Liberty members each reported receiving $800
from Linebarger from August through October.

The slate's candidates reported campaign contributions totaling $1,270 from
Perdue over that period and an additional $1,190 in donations from John David
Franz, the former Hidalgo mayor whose law office is affiliated with the firm.

__

Andrew Kreighbaum covers education and general assignments for The Monitor. He
can be reached at andrew@themonitor.com and (956) 683-4472.

                      Orange County Register (California)

                            December 5, 2011 Monday

Two O.C. firms on state's tax delinquent list

BYLINE: JAN NORMAN Register writer, The Orange County Register

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A

LENGTH: 242 words



HIGHLIGHT: Companies in Irvine, Garden Grove added to list, which is updated
quarterly.


Two Orange County firms are among 16 taxpayers added to the state's list of
largest sales and use tax delinquents, which was updated Nov. 30.

Dragon Auto Inc., a used-car dealer in Garden Grove, owes the state $960,564.

Event Masters International Inc. in Irvine owes $878,829. Its website lists it
as an event production company whose clients include the Anaheim Ducks hockey
team, John Laing Homes, Google and several Orange County cities.

Dragon's phone number has been disconnected. Event Masters has not yet responded
to an Orange County Register email for comment.

The 16 new entries on the list owe a total of $21.1 million in delinquent sales
and use taxes.

A 2007 state law requires the California State Board of Equalization to post
online the 250 largest tax delinquencies of more than $100,000. The list is
updated quarterly.

The biggest delinquent added this quarter is 21st Century Oil Corp. in Solana
Beach, which owes $2.83 million in unpaid sales and use taxes.

The biggest debtors on the complete list of 250 are:

California Target Enterprises Inc., Downey, $18.4 million, first lien was 2002

C & JD USA Inc., Oakland, $16.5 million, first lien in 2010

Gary Lazar, doing business as P&M Service Stations, Garden Grove, $11 million,
first lien in 2002.

Since the delinquent list went online, the Board of Equalization and Franchise
Tax Board have collected $87 million in delinquent state and local taxes.

                           Pittsburgh Tribune Review

                           February 21, 2008 Thursday

Change in city tax collection reviewed

BYLINE: Jeremy Boren

LENGTH: 352 words


Pittsburgh might be able to scoop an extra $10 million from a sea of delinquent
taxes under a plan that city Controller Michael Lamb offered Wednesday to Mayor
Luke Ravenstahl.

An immediate boost could come from eliminating the 15- to 21-percent fee the
city's tax collection agency -- Penn Credit Corp. -- charges the city for each
deadbeat taxpayer it gets to pay real estate, earned income or other taxes, Lamb
said.

"That way, the city could get 100 percent of the tax and interest owed, and the
collection agency could get its fee from the taxpayer," Lamb said.

The change would take advantage of a 2003 amendment to Pennsylvania's Municipal
Claims and Tax Lien Law, which allows collection agencies to charge delinquent
taxpayers a fee of up to 10 percent of what they owe a municipality.

Lamb said Allegheny County officials have collected delinquent taxes this way
through Jordan Tax Service Inc. since May 2004 and have netted more than $50
million.

Pittsburgh collected roughly $2 million in delinquent taxes in 2007, but the
city still is owed about $30 million in unpaid taxes, said Finance Director
Scott Kunka.

Kunka said the city performs well collecting taxes, but he's open to exploring
Lamb's recommendations.

County Treasurer John K. Weinstein lauded Lamb's initiative, and said the city
and county could one day combine delinquent tax collection contracts to save
even more.

"I'm a firm believer that the delinquent taxpayer should pay the cost of the
delinquency," he said. "I have a 97 percent collection rate. That 97 percent
should not pay for the 3 percent that doesn't pay."

Payment plans are available to those who can't pay all at once to prevent them
from losing their homes through tax liens, Weinstein said.

Weinstein said the county has found that delinquent taxpayers are motivated to
pay when they're told they must cover an additional 10 percent fee.

For example, someone who owes $1,000 to the county would be charged $1,100, with
$100 going to the tax collection agency.

"They have an incentive to collect," Weinstein said. "The more they collect the
more money they make."

                             170 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                   USA TODAY

                              May 23, 2014 Friday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Fed workers owe $3.3B taxes;
Congress' delinquents worse than Treasury

BYLINE: Gregory Korte, USA TODAY

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 311 words


Federal employees owe a total of $3.3 billion in back taxes to the federal
government, according to Internal Revenue Service data released Thursday.

In all, 318,462 federal employees owed back taxes as of last Sept. 30 -- an
increase of 2.6% from the previous year. That puts the average tax bill at
$10,391, according to IRS data obtained by USA TODAY under the Freedom of
Information Act.

But federal workers are better at paying than the average taxpayer. Their
delinquency rate of 3.19% is far lower than the 8.7% for the population at
large.

Some federal workers are worse than others. The non-payment rate for employees
of the House of Representatives is 4.87%. In the Senate, it's 3.24%. That's 714
tax delinquents on Capitol Hill owing $8.6 million -- more than one for each
representative or senator. Thirty-six employees in the Executive Office of the
President are delinquent on taxes, a rate of 2.06%.

Tax delinquencies on Capitol Hill are four times more common than at the
Treasury Department, which has come under scrutiny over bonuses paid to tax-
delinquent IRS employees.

A report by the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration last month
found that the IRS paid more than $1 million to employees who didn't pay their
federal taxes. But at 1.2% delinquent, the Treasury Department has the best rate
of tax compliance in the federal government, according to reports.

The statistical reports tally tax delinquencies at the agency level, so it's
unclear who's not paying taxes and whether any members of Congress are
delinquent. The reports are part of a 20-year-old IRS effort, called the Federal
Employee/Retiree Delinquency Initiative, to raise tax compliance by federal
workers. The report doesn't break out the IRS, which is part of the Treasury,
but IRS Commissioner John Koskinen said more than 99% of IRS workers are current
on their taxes.

                            Dayton Daily News (Ohio)

                            November 20, 2005 Sunday

Auction helps county clear debt;
Delinquent taxpayers now have to pay more to lienholder

BYLINE: By John Nolan jnolan@DaytonDailyNews.com

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 597 words


DAYTON - A company that buys delinquent real-estate tax liens from local
governments agreed Saturday to pay Montgomery County $9.1 million for tax debts
owed on 1,986 properties countywide.

American Tax Funding LLC's winning bid at auction not only took those debts off
the county's hands, but had spurred a repayment since August of $17 million in
delinquent taxes, officials said.

That is an unprecedented collection rate over that period, said county Treasurer
Hugh Quill, who has been in office since 1993 and conducted the auction Saturday
that involved two bidders who posted $1.5 million deposits to qualify.

Two other potential bidders dropped out prior to the auction - Montgomery
County's first - after they inspected the available properties.

Days ago, Quill had projected the winning bidder might pay the county as much as
$18 million for the liens, but that amount decreased as more delinquent
taxpayers paid up and properties were deleted from the offering. The county
plans to do the lien auctions annually to spur timely tax payments, Quill said.

The property-tax revenues benefit school districts, libraries, Dayton and the
county's other municipalities, and Montgomery County itself.

American Tax Funding, of Jupiter, Fla., accepted the county's opening offer
Saturday to buy the entire liens portfolio at an 18 percent interest rate.

When the county treasurer offered the only other bidder, BankAtlantic of Fort
Lauderdale, Fla., the opportunity to bid on an interest rate a quarter
percentage point lower at 17.75 percent, bank representative Gary Branse shook
his head no. Quill banged down his gavel to end the 2-minute auction.

Matthew A. Marini, who represented American Tax Funding, said county officials
seemed to have prepared well by mixing financially distressed, undesirable
properties in with marketable properties to compile the portfolio.

"We are not going to make a lot of money on this. In fact, it's really close,"
Marini said after the auction. "It's clear to me that these guys did their
homework on how this should be done."

His company's check to the county covers the unpaid taxes and a $180
administrative fee on all 1,986 properties. Prior to the auction, a delinquent
taxpayer would have had to pay only the overdue taxes to be free of the lien.
Now, the debtor will have to pay American Tax Funding the equivalent of the
unpaid taxes and administrative fee, plus the 18 percent interest.

That interest rate is higher than would generally be available on the market
without paying a premium, Marini said. In addition, his company has the right to
foreclose on a property through a sheriff's auction if the delinquent taxpayer
hasn't paid up in a year. The liens are good for three years.

American Tax Funding has bought more than 300,000 tax liens from government
entities around the country since its 1997 founding.

The county treasurer's office had adjusted the mix of properties as the result
of discussions with bidders in recent weeks to arrive at a portfolio that would
attract bidders and relieve the county of hard-tocollect debts, said Nicolette
Jaworski, a spokeswoman for Quill. The varied portfolio includes vacant lots,
residential properties and larger tracts that could be developed for office
parks, officials said.

Summit, Franklin, Mahoning and Stark counties have done similar auctions of
unpaid property tax debts. Ohio has allowed its most populous counties to sell
the liens since 1998, following the lead of other states. The auctions have
become more popular as government revenues have shrunk.

Contact John Nolan at (937) 225-2242.

LOAD-DATE: November 21, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                   October 22, 1997, Wednesday, ALL EDITIONS

Fulton gets first payment in taxes collected by private Florida firm

BYLINE: Carlos Campos; STAFF WRITER

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. 04B

LENGTH: 337 words


Fulton County received an $ 8.7 million payment on Tuesday from a private
company that is purchasing its delinquent tax liens, the first in a series of
installments that could reach $ 50 million.

The $ 50 million will be shared with several other governmental entities, since
Fulton County also collects taxes for the city of Atlanta, the Atlanta school
board and the Fulton County school board. The city of East Point and Georgia
also will get small shares.

Capital Asset Research Corp., a West Palm Beach, Fla., company with a local
office in Buckhead, wired the bank transfer payment late Tuesday afternoon. The
payments will continue through mid-November. Capital Asset sent out so-called
"60-day letters" in August to delinquent taxpayers, giving notice that the
company was about to purchase the delinquent tax liens from the county if the
debts weren't paid.

Now that the letters have matured, the company has begun to purchase the
delinquent tax liens. Under Georgia law, Capital Asset now can charge interest
to the delinquent taxpayers and eventually foreclose on the properties if owners
don't pay up.

Fulton County Tax Commissioner Arthur Ferdinand, who has reduced the county's $
208 million delinquent tax debt by $ 97 million since taking office in January,
said Tuesday he was pleased to get the money.

"It's a great start to reducing the current delinquency to a manageable level,"
Ferdinand said.

Under the Capital Asset purchase, Fulton County stands to gain about $ 16
million and its board of education about $ 11 million, while the city of Atlanta
could get about $ 11 million, and its board of education almost $ 12 million.
East Point will get about $ 267,000, and Georgia about $ 318,000.

Ferdinand cautioned, however, that those amounts likely will decrease in the
coming weeks as taxpayers pay up in order to avoid having their debt transferred
to a private collector like Capital Asset.

Ferdinand noted the county collects about $ 285,000 per day in delinquent taxes.

LOAD-DATE: October 23, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                           The Jena Times (Louisiana)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                               September 25, 2013

LPSO contracts agency to collect delinquent parish property taxes

BYLINE: The Jena Times staff

LENGTH: 283  words


Because of new state legislation, LA R.S. 47:2062, the LaSalle Parish Sheriffs
Office has contracted with the company, ARCHON, to secure payment of delinquent
property taxes, according to an announcement by Sheriff Scott Franklin.

The company is authorized to locate delinquent taxpayers, generate and mail
notices of all tax sale related events, process payments, and provide taxpayer
customer service through its Louisiana based call center.

To date, the use of this new technology and service has been beneficial in
recovering delinquent property taxes in over 25 other Louisiana parishes and
cities.

These new services cost neither the Sheriffs Office nor timely taxpayers
anything; however, delinquent LaSalle Parish taxpayers will be assessed a
10-percent tax sale cost. The additional cost will take effect on February 1st,
pursuant to state statute.

By utilizing this approach for delinquent collections and tax sales, the Sheriff
will no longer have to expend timely paid tax revenue to collect delinquent
taxes. Instead, delinquent taxpayers are essentially paying for delinquent tax
collections.

In Louisiana, interest accrues on delinquent property taxes at a rate of
1-percent per month until paid, beginning January 31st of each year.

"As stated before, this action will not cost our faithful timely taxpayers
anything," Sheriff Franklin said. "It does keep us from spending some of that
revenue to collect delinquent taxes."

Parish property tax notices for year 2013 should be in the mail in early
November. The notices will be printed and ready for mail as soon as final
approval of the tax rolls are received from the Louisiana Tax Commission. Taxes
for 2013 are due by December 31, 2013.
