                          The Tampa Tribune (Florida)

                             May 26, 2011 Thursday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Tax delinquencies still on decline

BYLINE: CHRISTIAN M. WADE, The Tampa Tribune

SECTION: METRO; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 400 words


Fees on foreclosed properties are being paid off by lenders

BY CHRISTIAN M. WADE

The Tampa Tribune

TAMPA -- The economy is still struggling to rebound and unemployment remains in
the double digits, but more Hillsborough County property owners are paying their
taxes.

For the second year in a row, the number of delinquent properties on the
county's tax rolls has declined, according to figures from Tax Collector Doug
Belden's office.

As of April 1, 36,349 delinquent property owners owed the county more than $85
million, according to 2010 tax roll figures. That's compared with 2009, when
about $116 million was owed on 39,734 properties. In 2008, 46,071 property
owners owed about $160 million.

County tax officials attribute the decline to lower property values, but moreso
to the fact that banks and lenders are paying off delinquent taxes on hundreds
of foreclosed properties.

"We don't have any hard evidence to suggest so, but we suspect that has been a
major factor in the decline," said Brenden Chiaramonte, Belden's administrative
assistant.

On May 9, the tax collector's office opened bidding on tax certificates for
delinquent properties, giving investors a chance to bid on interest earned on
outstanding debt. The auction ends Saturday. Winning bids will be announced
Wednesday.

The amounts owed by property tax scofflaws range from a few bucks for vacant
lots to hundreds of thousands of dollars owed by developers of subdivisions and
apartment complexes.

Property taxes are due Nov. 1 and become delinquent if not paid by April 1.

Most of the delinquent property taxes will be paid by homeowners, mortgage
holders such as banks and lenders or through the sale of the certificates. Bids
typically range from zero to 18 percent. Although the lowest interest rate bid
on properties get the certificates, state law ensures the winning bidders a
minimum return of 5 percent.

If no one pays the taxes on a property by 22 months after the sale, the
certificate holder can foreclose. Unsold certificates will be issued to the
county at 18 percent interest. If no one purchases the county certificates, the
county will foreclose on the property as long as the value is more than $5,000.
The county would then issue a lien.

For information, visit www.hillstax.org.

cwade@tampatrib.com

(813) 259-7679

Copyright © 2011, The Tampa Tribune and may not be republished without
permission. E-mail library@tampatrib.com

LOAD-DATE: May 27, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


           Copyright 2011 The Tribune Co. Publishes The Tampa Tribune


                             175 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        Tribune-Review (Greensburg, PA)

                              March 7, 2005 Monday

District may hand firm its tax liens

BYLINE: Paul Paterra

LENGTH: 582 words


Penn-Trafford School District has received a proposal from a company looking to
collect its delinquent taxes.

Under the proposal, XSPAND Inc., headquartered in Morristown, N.J., would
purchase the district's tax liens and then would set about the task of
collecting those taxes.

"We get the money up front," said Brett Lago, Penn-Trafford's business manager.
"We don't have to wait however long it would take the county to collect taxes.
It's a way to speed up the cash flow on those properties. Anything we can do to
improve our cash flow, we're going to take a look at."

XSPAND, which has a branch office in Cranberry Township, Butler County, is one
of the largest purchasers of tax liens in the country. The company works with
local governments to convert the purchased liens to revenue and to find
permanent solutions that place these properties back on the active tax rolls.

The firm is offering Penn-Trafford 91 cents on the dollar for the delinquent
properties. The district has $661,180 in delinquent taxes eligible for purchase.

Only recently has such a step been permitted. Act 70 of 2004 allows Pennsylvania
school districts to assign some or all of their claims for delinquent school
taxes.

"We're looking at a direct purchase of the tax liens," explained Larry Marsh,
vice president of sales and marketing for XSPAND. "We replace the district as
the owner of the lien. We augment the collection process through our efforts."

Those efforts involve collectors, who are trained credit advisers, attempting to
assist the delinquent taxpayer.

"We try to generate a conversation with the property owner," Marsh said. "We may
try to put them together with someone who gets them on a payment plan.
Oftentimes, it's a case of they didn't know or they're frozen and they don't
know where to go.

"The tax collector is the one who takes the first shot at it. Normally, they
only send the tax notice. Usually there's not a lot of follow-up. Other than the
initial effort, there's not a lot done."

The school district would have final approval of any correspondence sent out by
XSPAND. Marsh stressed that a "heavy-handed" approach is not used.

"We have never had a complaint filed against us by a property owner in any of
the areas we've done," Marsh said. "You're going to know what we're doing. We
have had good relationships with every taxing authority we've done business with
in the past, and we do not expect that to change."

Because the legislation is relatively new, only a few districts in the state
have taken this step.

In June, the Harrisburg School District employed Municipal Revenue Services, of
Erie, to go after four years of delinquent liens.

William R. Gretton III, assistant superintendent for business affairs, said the
district realized more than $5 million.

"I recommend this to any school district that's looking to advance funds to them
in the future," he said. "The bank is forwarding us money, rather than us
getting it over the next few years. Ultimately, districts will receive 100
percent of what they would receive over a period of time. They're receiving it
up front."

XSPAND's proposal is being reviewed by Ken Murray, Penn-Trafford's solicitor. It
may be discussed when the board meets tonight.

"I think it's beneficial to us," school Board President Sallie Bradley said.
"Obviously, we get money up front, and we get interest on it. I think we're all
thinking it's favorable. It would be a financial shot to the district, and we're
out looking for money."

LOAD-DATE: March 7, 2005

                            July 13, 2016 Wednesday

Bill summary and status of SB 542 Delinquent sewer charges; lien on property,
delinquent charges.

LENGTH: 398  words

DATELINE: New York



  Richmond: Virginia Lagislative Information System has issued the following
bill summary and status:



 SUMMARY AS PASSED SENATE:

 Delinquent sewer charges; lien; unlimited time. Allows a locality that provides
water or sewer service to a property owner, rather than to a tenant, to place a
lien on the property receiving the service in the amount of the number of months
of delinquent charges. Current law allows the placement of liens in the amount
of up to three months of delinquent water and sewer charges.

                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                           October 7, 2015 Wednesday

BRIEF: Erie City Council forgives delinquent taxes on 16 properties

BYLINE: John Guerriero, Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 179 words


Oct. 07--ERIE, Pa. -- Erie City Council took a step today to get 16 properties
back on the tax rolls when it unanimously approved forgiveness of the face value
of delinquent city taxes totaling $6,159.

The properties -- 15 vacant lots and one structure -- have been acquired at
various times by the Erie Redevelopment Authority from delinquent property
owners, Erie City Councilwoman Jessica Horan-Kunco said.

The delinquencies go back as far as 2000.

For all property taxes to be forgiven, the other two taxing bodies, Erie County
government and the Erie School District, must follow council's lead. Horan-Kunco
said that is likely, now that City Council has given its approval.

The school district taxes on the properties are about $9,157 and the county
taxes are about $2,875, said Scott Henry, the authority's executive director.

City Council took the action, Horan-Kunco said, because "we wanted to move these
into taxable value again."

___ (c)2015 the Erie Times-News (Erie, Pa.) Visit the Erie Times-News (Erie,
Pa.) at www.GoErie.com Distributed by Tribune Content Agency, LLC.

                             178 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                 December 23, 1998, Wednesday, JOURNAL EDITION

Bad rap for juvenile justice system

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. 16A

LENGTH: 470 words


LOCKING UP young delinquents in Georgia is a difficult, thankless job. The state
Department of Juvenile Justice has been sued, threatened, slammed and sued some
more, in large part because the system and its funding have not kept pace with
the increasing number of delinquents sentenced to detention. As a result, it
often appears Georgians are doing a half-hearted job of ensuring that
delinquents are getting the support they need.

This year, the state agreed to settle a suit by the U.S. Department of Justice
that highlighted a series of problems in the juvenile system. This week, a
separate suit was settled.

The more recent action was launched in March 1996 by the Dalton-based Voice of
the Children. The group charged that the Dalton facility was dilapidated,
overcrowded, understaffed and failed to provide adequate medical care, mental
health treatment and educational opportunities. The federal suit highlighted
similar problems systemwide.

Under the settlement reached Monday, the state agreed to house only two
juveniles in a cell, to classify delinquents appropriately, to hire more guards
and to provide juveniles with more psychiatric and medical care.

On its face, it sounds as if the system warehouses delinquents with little
regard for their health, education or welfare. Indeed, U.S. Judge Harold Murphy
insisted the state find grounds for a settlement, lest he issue an order with
disclosures that would "embarrass" the state agency.

We don't dispute that detention is less than ideal for delinquents. Faced with
explosive growth in the number of delinquents, there's little doubt that there's
overcrowding, that too few guards oversee too many delinquents, that medical
care and educational opportunities go wanting.

We just don't buy the characterization by children's advocates and others that
the system is unresponsive, uncaring and insensitive to the needs of detainees.
Rather, the department has lacked adequate funding to keep up with the increase
in the number of juveniles and the support systems --- education, health care
--- they need and deserve.

By all means, fix this system. It should meet every medical and educational
need, protect detainees from abuse and provide effective programs aimed at
rehabilitating young criminals --- while keeping in mind that detention is not a
picnic, but punishment. The system must also be adequately funded, and the
settlement with the Justice Department earlier this year committed millions more
to upgrading the system and a timetable for making improvements.

But at bottom, despite real problems that must be addressed, we don't believe
Georgia runs an uncaring juvenile justice system. It's fair to demand that the
state do better. It's unfair to indict a system overwhelmed by an ever-rising
tide of juvenile crime.

LOAD-DATE: December 24, 1998

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SERIES: Final

                    Copyright 1998 The Atlanta Constitution

                           The Philadelphia Inquirer

                            February 5, 2013 Tuesday
                                JERSEY-D Edition

New Phila. effort to locate tax delinquents announced;
Nutter: Plan was not timed to coincide with release of reassessment data.

BYLINE: By Troy Graham; Inquirer Staff Writer

SECTION: SOUTH JERSEY; P-com News Local; Pg. B06

LENGTH: 633 words


Just two weeks before property owners learn the results of a reassessment that
will alter tax bills across Philadelphia, Mayor Nutter on Monday announced a new
effort to find tax deadbeats and "encourage" them to pay up.

Nutter said the city would spend $40 million over the next five years to
overhaul the Department of Revenue's software - which dates to 1993 - hire 55
new employees, and start a call center to chase down tax delinquents.

The city also will employ outside collection agencies and get cases to them
quicker than in the past.

"We will do whatever is necessary to provide further inspiration for those who
think they can get away with not paying their taxes," Nutter said. "Those days
are clearly coming to an end."

Tax delinquents - and the perception that the city has not done enough to chase
them - have been cited frequently in the discussions surrounding Nutter's
property tax reform, the Actual Value Initiative (AVI).

The argument has been that the city should collect from delinquents before
implementing a system that is going to cause some homeowners' bills to
skyrocket.

But Nutter said unveiling his get-tough effort was not timed to coincide with
the releasing of the reassessment data, which could be mailed to property owners
by the end of next week.

"This message is timed to say, 'Pay your taxes, whenever they are due,' " Nutter
said. "It's also putting people on notice that we'll be much more aggressive in
coming after you."

Nutter said the city was owed $518 million in back taxes, interest, and
penalties at the end of the last fiscal year - $248 million from property taxes
over the last decade.

The city has been collecting about 91 percent of the taxes owed in recent years,
said Revenue Commissioner Keith Richardson.

But the city has had a spotty history of collecting taxes, even from its own
employees. Nutter has launched a number of efforts since 2008, including one
that forced tax-delinquent city workers into payment plans.

An Inquirer/PlanPhilly series of articles since 2011 has documented how
Philadelphia has the least-effective delinquent-property-tax collection system
of the nation's biggest cities, and the pile of delinquent property taxes has
continued to grow on Nutter's watch.

Nutter, who said the goal was to collect "everything," said the new strategy
could bring in about $260 million over the next five years.

With AVI looming, both City Council and the Philadelphia delegation in
Harrisburg have introduced legislation to give the city more tools to pursue
delinquent property owners, especially speculators who own multiple properties.

The delegation's bill, for example, would give the city permission to place
liens on any property in the state owned by someone not paying their property
taxes in Philadelphia.

Using city data, staff for Council President Darrell L. Clarke concluded that
100,000 parcels are tax-delinquent and 35,000 of them have owners with multiple
delinquent properties.

Going after back taxes is one way politicians hope to soften AVI's impact on
homeowners, clustered in fast-growing areas of the city, who are facing enormous
increases.

Politicians fear taxes under AVI could force out some older residents and stunt
the real estate market in neighborhoods such as Northern Liberties.

In about two weeks, most owners should get a letter informing them what the city
thinks their properties are worth.

The tax rate would be set during the budget process this spring. The
administration maintains that the rate would have to be between 1.3 and 1.4
percent to collect the same amount of revenue as last year, meaning $1,300 to
$1,400 per $100,000 of a home's value.

The resulting bills would be due in 2014.

Contact Troy Graham at 215-854-2730 or tgraham@phillynews.com, or follow on
Twitter @troyjgraham.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              The Washington Post

                             April 5, 2014 Saturday
                                 Every Edition

Montgomery condos must disclose names of delinquent owners

BYLINE: Benny L. Kass

SECTION: REAL ESTATE; Pg. T43

LENGTH: 855 words


If you live in a Montgomery County condominium and are delinquent on your
periodic assessment, your name must be disclosed if a request is made by another
unit owner.

That's the decision of the Montgomery Commission on Common Ownership Communities
(CCOC), which was affirmed in February by the 6th Judicial Circuit Court of
Maryland.

Carl Brown is an owner at Americana Finnmark Condominium Association in Silver
Spring. A couple of years ago, he raised several concerns with the association's
management company, including a request for a list of the names and unit numbers
of all owners who were delinquent. Brown's legal argument in support of his
request was based on the bylaws of his association, which specifically state
that the board of directors may post a list of members who are delinquent.

When the association refused to honor any of Brown's requests, he filed a
complaint with the CCOC. This is a governmental agency with authority to
adjudicate disputes between homeowners and their associations.

The CCOC referred the matter to a Montgomery County hearing examiner, who
concluded that Brown could obtain a report with the names of delinquent owners
redacted. Moreover, the examiner denied Brown's request that the association
publicly post a list of delinquent owners. Her reasoning was based on the
language of the bylaws, namely that the board "may" post. This, according to the
examiner, "left the matter to the discretion of the Board . . . and thus comes
within the scope of the business judgment rule."

That rule - which applies in Maryland and Virginia - essentially means that
"courts will not second-guess the actions of directors unless it appears that
they are the result of fraud, dishonesty or incompetence," according to a 1992
Maryland court case. While the District previously rejected that rule,
legislation awaiting the mayor's approval would follow the law in neighboring
jurisdictions.

The CCOC rejected the examiner's recommendation regarding the disclosure of the
names of delinquent owners. However, it agreed with the examiner that the
association is under no duty to publicly post the names of its delinquent
members.

On Feb. 28, this ruling was affirmed by the Maryland court.

Publication of delinquent homeowners' names is a hot topic in community
associations. Proponents of disclosure argue that unit owners who are delinquent
will be shamed into bringing themselves current. Opponents say that disclosure
is an intrusive invasion of privacy and that the board has other remedies - such
as filing liens, lawsuits and foreclosures - to address the issue.

What should a condo board do when faced with a request for the names of
delinquent owners? In Maryland - especially in Montgomery - the law is clear.
The board must release those names.

However, there are some conditions that a board should impose on itself as well
as on the owner receiving the list. First, make absolutely sure that the list is
accurate. If, for example, the list says that Mark is delinquent as of the date
the owner received the list but Mark paid up before the list was printed, it is
an error and Mark could sue the association for libel. Accordingly, the list
that the board submits should be dated at least one month before it is provided
to anyone. That way, one can correctly state that "as of Feb. 1, Mark was
delinquent" in a certain dollar amount.

Next, the owner requesting the list should be asked to sign a confidentiality
agreement, consenting not to circulate the names outside the condominium
association. This is consistent with the law of this case, namely that the
delinquency list does not have to be posted for all to see.

Finally, the board should advise all owners who are delinquent that it is about
to provide a list to a requesting owner and then give them a few days to bring
themselves current so they can be removed from the list.

The Virginia condo act has language similar to Maryland's. Maryland law allows
the withholding, among other things, of "an individual's personal financial
reports." Virginia law allows associations to withhold "personnel matters
relating to specific, identified persons." The District's law is less clear: It
merely says that books and records must be made available for examination by
owners, and has no language that authorizes any withholding. And the courts in
the District, when confronted with an issue that has never been decided before
in the city, will often rely on Maryland law.

Delinquent owners clearly will object to any disclosure.

If a unit owner has a legitimate reason for the delinquency, he or she can meet
in private with the board (called executive session) and explain the problem.
The board can work out a reasonable payment plan, but any such agreement must be
reduced to writing and signed by the owner and a board member.

Benny L. Kass  is a Washington lawyer. This column is not legal advice and
should not be acted upon without obtaining legal counsel. For a free copy of the
booklet "A Guide to Settlement on Your New Home," send a self-addressed stamped
envelope to Benny L. Kass, 1050 17th St. NW, Suite 1100, Washington, D.C. 20036.

LOAD-DATE: April 5, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DISTRIBUTION: Every Zone

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


     Copyright 2014 Washingtonpost.Newsweek Interactive Company, LLC d/b/a
                            Washington Post Digital
                              All Rights Reserved


                             181 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                 The Bond Buyer

IRS Mulling Proposal Allowing Michigan Counties to Continue Crucial Note Program

                              May 29, 1987, Friday

By Lynn Stevens

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 28


The Internal Revenue Service is considering a proposal to allow Michigan
counties to continue issuing tax-exempt, tax delinquent notes in return for an
agreement by the counties to phase out the notes by 1991.

The compromise proposal, which calls for the counties to take interim steps to
avoid earning arbitrage from the notes, was made on May 21 by the National Bank
of Detroit, a purchaser of the notes, on behalf of Wayne and other Michigan
counties.

The counties, supported by Rep. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., had hoped that the IRS
would accept their proposal quickly so they could resume the delinquent tax note
program and avoid a financial crisis. Michigan counties, localities, and school
districts depend on proceeds from the notes to carry them through the fiscal
year, which ends June 30. At stake are hundreds of millions of dollars of notes.

In a May 12 letter, Rep. Wolpe urged J. Roger Mentz, the Treasury Department's
assistant secretary for tax policy, to make a decision on the proposal soon,
because of the "critical cash flow crisis (that) currently exists in Michigan."

But in another letter the Treasury received today, Michigan treasurer Robert A.
Bowman asked Mr. Mentz also to apply whatever decision the IRS makes on
delinquent tax notes to consolidated tax anticipation notes. Mr. Bowman's
request may slow the IRS' deliberations and is certain to cause concern among
some county officials who have been urging the IRS to consider delinquent tax
notes and consolidated anticipation notes separately.

Both the delinquent tax note and consolidated anticipation note programs are
unique to Michigan. The delinquent tax note program was started in the early
1970s to handle cash-flow shortages that occur at the end of the fiscal year,
before delinquent property taxes can be collected.

The program, which the counties run, operates on a revolving fund basis.
Essentially, county treasurers are empowered to borrow on the amount of
outstanding delinquent taxes. They compute the amount of delinquent taxes -
those that have not been collected as of March 1 - and then issue tax-exempt,
three-year notes to cover that amount. The proceeds of the notes are put into
the fund and then distributed to localities and school districts. The fund is
replenished from the delinquent taxes collected and the fees and interest
generated from the sale of the notes are pledged for repayment of the notes. Any
additional interest income from the notes is reinvested.

The consolidated anticipation note program was established in the early 1980s.
The program is run by cities and townships that borrow on the amount of total
taxes they expect to collect for the fiscal year. They issue notes that mature
within a year.

The IRS first raised questions about whether consolidated anticipation notes
should be considered tax-exempt under the Tax Reform Act of 1986 when the city
of Lansing announced an offering last summer. In November, an anonymous letter
focused the IRS' scrutiny on delinquent tax notes as well. These concerns
brought both programs to a standstill, which created serious problems for at
least one county - Kent - which had already sold, but had not delivered, $15.5
million of delinquent tax notes. That sale has since been canceled.

Meanwhile, counties and localities, which cannot get opinions from bond counsel
verifying that the delinquent tax notes and consolidated anticipation notes they
plan to issue will be tax-exempt, are sweating out the last few months of the
fiscal year, waiting for clarification from the IRS.

"It's creating a real fiscal hardship," one county official said.

The issue is whether or not delinquent tax notes and consolidated anticipation
notes are acquired obligations or cash-flow borrowings. Either of these
categories would be considered tax-exempt under the new tax reform law. The IRS,
sources said, has suggested that the notes would not qualify as either -
particularly not as cash flow borrowings - because neither the counties nor the
localities can show deficits for the months in which they issue the notes.

The counties, sources said, are taking the position that delinquent tax notes
are acquired obligations.

"We're acquiring a delinquent tax obligation from townships and school
districts," said one county official, "With (consolidated anticipation notes)
there is no acquired obligation and no cash flow problem. We feel that these are
two separate issues, and we don't want them considered together."

But Michigan state officials see things differently. They contend that the two
types of notes are very similar and have even coined the acronymn D-Tans - which
county officials refuse to recognize - to suggest a relationship to consolidated
anticipation notes, which are often referred to as C-Tans.

"The only difference between C-Tans and D-Tans is that C-Tans are for current
taxes and D-Tans are for delinquent taxes," said one state official, adding
that, "We want the IRS to consider the notes together. We don't want the IRS to
treat one governmental entity differently from another." The state, the official
stressed, is not taking a position on whether the notes should be tax-exempt,
just that they should be treated comparably.

SECTION: Pg. 1

LENGTH: 879 words

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 1987 The Bond Buyer, Inc.


                             182 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                   The Daily Independent (Ashland, Kentucky)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             March 22, 2009 Sunday

New bill to protect Ky. delinquent taxpayers

BYLINE: Carrie Stambaugh, The Daily Independent, Ashland, Ky.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 1043 words


Mar. 22--CATLETTSBURG -- Gov. Steve Beshear signed into law last week a bill
that restricts the fees and penalties placed on delinquent property tax bills
purchased by third parties, local officials say.

The new law also transfers responsibility of selling the bills from the
sheriff's office to the county clerk's office. Boyd County officials say they
will put new software in place in time for the sale of 2008 property tax bills.

Boyd County Clerk Debbie Jones said she and Boyd County Sheriff Terry Keelin are
already working with their software providers to update and allow for smooth
transition this year. On April 15, the sheriff's tax office will close for 2008
bills and they will go to the clerk's office.

The tax bills will eventually go up for sale and third parties will still be
allowed to buy up to 10 percent of the total amount delinquent or $200,000,
which ever is less. But Jones said she expects to be able to delay their sale
longer to give residents more opportunities to pay them before they fall into
the hands of third parties.

Under the new law, after the bills are transferred to the clerk's office the
public has until July 16 to pay the bill before they can be purchased by third
parties.

Boyd County Attorney Philip Hedrick said the new law also requires additional
notification to property owners that their tax bills are delinquent. Letters
must be sent to property owners after 30 days and then again after 60 days that
tax bills are delinquent.

The new law also requires individuals and entities who purchase three bills in
one county, five statewide or more than $10,000 worth to register with the State
Department of Revenue and be in good standing with the Attorney General's Office
of Consumer Protection.

In addition, the new law severely limits the amount of fees third parties can
place on the tax bills and prohibits tax liens to be sold to any third party if
the county has set up a payment plan in which payments are current or when the
property is involved in litigation. (See box for a schedule of fees third
parties can charge).

The bill also requires additional correspondence from the third parties to the
property owner. A copy of the notices must be retained by the third party as
well.

Jones said she thinks the new regulations will help to eliminate residents
having to pay exorbitant fees or having their property foreclosed on by third
parties. "We want people to have every opportunity to pay those bills before
third parties come in and buy them," she said.

A Dallas-based company, Tax Ease Lien Investments 1, LLC, is the No. 1 purchaser
of delinquent tax bills in Boyd County, Jones said. Wachovia and Kentucky Tax
Service are also frequent purchasers.

Jones said the companies began buying more than $1 million in property tax bills
delinquent in 2005, but despite their ability to foreclose on homes a year and a
day after purchasing the bills many including Tax Ease waited until this year to
begin collection procedures on most of them, she said.

According to records collected from the Boyd County Circuit Clerk's office,
there are at least five properties in the process of being foreclosed on by Tax
Ease. Records show the company, in addition to collecting the original amount of
delinquent taxes, are charging residents the same 12 percent annual interest
rate counties would charge in addition to attorneys', late and interest fees.

She said the trend of purchasing, tacking on large fees and the foreclosing on
properties seems to be accelerating. "We always have (third party) attorneys in
the vault researching these properties they have liens on for foreclosures," she
said.

If a third party doesn't buy a delinquent bill, the county attorney has the
obligation to collect that property bill for two years, Jones said. If that
doesn't happen, the county clerk can try to collect. Most counties are vigilant
about doing that, she said, because they need the revenues.

Being able to collect revenue is the reason the bills are up for sale in the
first place, Jones said. The companies provide revenue by paying the delinquent
bills.

"The county does get some reward from the third party purchases, but I just
think it's terrible that the Boyd County taxpayers and property owners are
caught in the middle of this," Jones said.

The Kentucky County Clerks Association supported the legislation, which was
introduced by state Rep. Arnold Simpson D-Covington.

Phone calls to both Tax Ease and Wachovia seeking comment about the practices
went unanswered during the course of two weeks.

On its Web site, Tax Ease describes itself as "an investment company focused on
community opportunities. TELI works with state and local taxing authorities to
provide millions of dollars in revenue by paying the tax obligations of
delinquent debtor."

Jones said her office is also trying to educate financial institutions and
taxpayers to be vigilant in knowing when a tax bill is due on a property.

"I also want to encourage the financial institutions to make sure that when
property mortgages and loans are finalized, that person realizes there is a tax
bill due in October that year regardless of when they buy that property and to
be vigilant of owing that bill. That will eliminate a lot of delinquencies
also," she said.

To further improve services to taxpayers, Jones and Keelin are also planning
eventually to combine their tax offices when the new Boyd County Justice Center
is completed. Currently the two offices are in the old courthouse but are not
accessible to each other except through an outside door. When the new justice
center opens, the sheriff plans to relocate most of his staff to the annex, but
the tax staff will stay behind. Renovations will connect the clerk's and
sheriff's offices.

CARRIE STAMBAUGH can be reached at cstambaugh@dailyindependent.com or (606)
326-2653.

To see more of The Daily Independent or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.dailyindependent.com. Copyright (c) 2009, The Daily Independent,
Ashland, Ky. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For
reprints, email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or
847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group
Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                            nationalmortgagenews.com

                                January 4, 2016

CMBS Delinquency Rate Worsened in December: Trepp

BYLINE: Andy Peters

SECTION: SERVICING Vol. 1 No. 1

LENGTH: 172  words


The delinquency rate on commercial mortgage-backed securities rose slightly in
December, according to Trepp.

The rate of U.S. commercial real estate loans embedded in CMBS that were
delinquent rose 4 basis points in December to 5.17%, compared to November, Trepp
said. Even with the worsening, the delinquency rate is still 58 basis points
lower than the end of 2014.

About $1.6 billion of CMBS loans became newly delinquent in December. The
largest newly delinquent loan in the quarter was a $190 million office property
loan in Bridgewater, N.J. Also going delinquent in the quarter was a $133
million loan for the Triangle Town Center retail development in Raleigh, N.C.

Total delinquencies stood at $26.4 billion.

The industrial CMBS delinquency rate fell 26 basis points to 5.73%. The lodging
delinquency rate rose 7 basis points to 2.82%. The multifamily delinquency rate
rose 13 basis points to 8.28%.

The office property delinquency rate rose 6 basis points to 5.79% and the retail
delinquency rate rose 12 basis points to 5.76%.

                    Messenger-Inquirer (Owensboro, Kentucky)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            October 27, 2013 Sunday

City taxes due Friday

BYLINE: Steve Vied, Messenger-Inquirer, Owensboro, Ky.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 296 words


Oct. 27--City of Owensboro property taxes are due on Friday, Nov. 1, and will
become delinquent if not paid by the last day of November, Angela Hamric, the
city's director of finance, announced.

But taxpayers who wait until the final few days of the month to pay in person or
by telephone could run into difficulty. Because of the Thanksgiving holiday,
City Hall will be closed on Thanksgiving Day, Nov. 28, as well as Nov. 29. The
last day of the month, Nov. 30, is a Saturday, and City Hall is closed on that
day as well.

To avoid penalty and interest, payments made in person or called in must be made
no later than 5 p.m., Nov. 27. Mailed payments must be postmarked no later than
Nov. 30.

Last year, more than 1,900 city property tax bills were delinquent, resulting in
penalties assessed and interest charged, Hamric said.

"In 2012 we had 24,852 tax bills," Hamric said. "Of that, we had 1,905 bills
delinquent. We collected $41,669 in penalty/interest on the delinquent bills
that have been paid."

Penalty and interest will be applied to all delinquent accounts starting on Dec.
1. The penalty for delinquent property taxes is 10 percent. Interest is applied
monthly at a rate of 0.5 percent, or 6 percent on an annual basis.

Hamric said payments may be made in person at City Hall, phoned in or mailed.
The city accepts checks, cash and Visa, MasterCard and Discover. Cash should not
be mailed, however.

City Hall is located at 101 E. Fourth St. Business hours -- Monday through
Friday -- are 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. The phone number for tax payments is
270-687-8537.

Steve Vied, 691-7297, svied@messenger-inquirer.com

                        Coal Valley News, Madison, W.Va

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                              May 23, 2016 Monday

Bill gives cities new options in B&O tax collection

BYLINE: Coal Valley News, Madison, W.Va.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 487 words


May 23--CHARLESTON, W.Va. -- The WV Municipal League has announced that bill HB
4163 passed during the 2016 Legislative Session will assist municipalities in
the collection of delinquent Business and Occupation taxes.

HB 4163 provides municipalities plenary power and authority to adopt an
ordinance providing for the publication of delinquent business and occupation
taxes; provides notice requirements; requires policies and procedures regarding
the preparation, publication and posting of a delinquent business and occupation
list; and allows for a reasonable charge to be added to the amount owed by a
delinquent taxpayer to cover the costs of preparing, publishing and posting a
delinquent list. The bill was passed on March 2nd and goes into effect ninety
days from passage.

"Like the State, municipalities are seeing a significant downturn in tax
collections with the energy market weighing in on their general revenues", Lisa
Dooley Executive Director of the WV Municipal League said. "In order to continue
to provide services to our constituents it is imperative that we be given the
tools to collect what is due to the city."

Dooley also said the work of the Logan City Clerk paid off during the session.
Amber Miller-Viars assisted the League in its lobbying effort and from her hard
work the bill has been named by the League as "Amber's Bill".

The WV Municipal League represents all 234 municipalities in the State of West
Virginia and has more than 2,500 elected and appointed members. City of Logan
Mayor Serafino J. Nolletti has served as a board member for the Municipal League
for five years and both Nolletti and Viars have been active in the League
activities. The City of Logan hosted the first Municipal League board meeting in
October of 2015 which showcased the Hatfield McCoy Trails, Logan County Airport,
Chief Logan Convention Center and downtown businesses.

"I am very proud of our City Clerk for assisting the League in getting this very
critical bill passed that will assist all cities in the State of West Virginia
in collecting revenue to support their vital services," said Mayor Nolletti.
"She went above and beyond out of her scope of work to ensure this bill saw
passage and she did it to help all cities."

Viars was quick to give credit to the League and leaders on the State level when
asked about the bill.

"It was an honor to have this opportunity to do this on behalf of the League.
They are a true friend of all cities and give us tools to be more successful,"
Viars said. "I have to credit Senator (Craig) Blair -- as well as Senator Mark
Maynard -- who are members of the Government Organization Committee. I
appreciate all of their leadership and look forward to working with them on more
Municipal issues in the future."

___ (c)2016 the Coal Valley News (Madison, W.Va.) Visit the Coal Valley News
(Madison, W.Va.) at www.coalvalleynews.com Distributed by Tribune Content
Agency, LLC.

                       Charleston Gazette (West Virginia)

                            March 11, 2010, Thursday

Kanawha going after 14 delinquent taxpayers owing $525,000

BYLINE: Rusty Marks, Staff writer

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. P1C

LENGTH: 302 words


Kanawha County tax officials are getting ready to go to court to try to collect
more than $500,000 in delinquent property taxes.

Last year, officials for the sheriff's tax department and prosecutor's office
joined forces against companies and individuals who are perpetually delinquent.
They went after 20 of the worst offenders last year.

Allen Bleigh, chief tax deputy for Sheriff Mike Rutherford, said county
officials are about to go after 14 more delinquent taxpayers who owe the county
about $525,000. Bleigh said letters are being drawn up now telling them they
need to pay up.

"We're going to give them 20 days to respond," Bleigh said Wednesday. After
that, county prosecutors will take the deadbeat taxpayers to court.

The largest overdue tax bills - which total just under $174,810 - come from
three defunct synthetic fuel companies that trace back to the same address in
Massachusetts. New River Synfuel LLC, Imperial Synfuel LLC and Calla Synfuel LLC
all have links to the same address in Cohasset, Mass., according to records on
file with the Secretary of State's Office.

The last of the companies apparently went out of business in 2008.

Several of the companies that still owe property taxes have gone out of
business. Steve & Barry's, a discount clothing store at the Charleston Town
Center Mall that went out of business in November 2008, still owes the county
close to $96,000. Value City Department Store, which shut down its store in St.
Albans after the parent company went bankrupt in 2008, left town owing more than
$25,000 in property taxes.

Bleigh said that if county officials can't find local company officials who are
still in business, they'll try to go after parent companies.

"You just have to take it one step at a time," he said.

Reach Rusty Marks at rustymarks@wvgazette.com or 304-348-1215.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             187 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                 FEBRUARY 7, 1996 Wednesday CNEW JERSEY EDITION

WHITMAN PROPOSES GENEROUS TAX AMNESTY< SCOFFLAWS WOULD HAVE 90 DAYS TO PAY UP
WITHOUT LATE< FEES AND INTEREST. THAT'S A BIGGER BREAK THAN IN PA.

BYLINE: James M. O'Neill, INQUIRER TRENTON BUREAU

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. A01

LENGTH: 779 words

DATELINE: TRENTON


Pennsylvania's tax cheats would be envious.

First Gov. Whitman cut the state income tax 30 percent. Now she wants to give
New Jersey's tax delinquents a reprieve. And the deal she proposes is far more
lenient than the one Pennsylvania recently offered.

The Whitman administration has unveiled a plan to give anyone who is delinquent
on state income, sales and corporate business-tax payments a 90-day amnesty
period. If the scofflaws made their full tax payment, they would avoid late fees
and interest penalties.

Those who ignore the amnesty would be subject to an extra non-negotiable 5
percent fine. Treasurer Brian Clymer predicted the amnesty program would bring
in an extra $70 million in revenue.

The Pennsylvania amnesty plan enacted under Gov. Ridge took a more aggressive
stance. It waived the normal late fee charged to any tax delinquent, but not
interest penalties. While that may not sound as enticing as New Jersey's plan,
consider that Pennsylvania's plan also slapped a 15 percent charge on those who
ignored the amnesty, far more severe than Whitman's 5 percent fine.

So while Pennsylvania, with a more powerful compliance tool at its disposal,
sought to collect accrued interest from delinquents, the Whitman plan would
write off the chance to collect interest.

Under New Jersey tax law, delinquents are subject to a 5 percent late fee and an
additional 5 percent interest penalty for each month that taxes are not paid, up
to a ceiling of 25 percent.

At any given time, New Jersey's 4.5 million taxpayers owe the state about $1
billion in delinquent taxes, according to Matt McDonald, a spokesman with the
treasurer's office. He said the state's normal enforcement manages to bring in
$550 million of that, and the rest slips through the cracks.

McDonald said the $70 million generated by the amnesty plan would be above the
$550 million normally collected through enforcement. The state had no figures on
delinquency, but the federal government estimates that 13 percent of taxpayers
underpay or fail to pay.

In Pennsylvania, which estimates that delinquent taxes amount to $900 million at
any given time, the recent amnesty generated 56,000 filings and pulled in $90
million.

That's slightly less than the $117 million that had been predicted, according to
Deb Snyder, a spokeswoman with the Pennsylvania Department of Revenue. Because
it was Pennsylvania's first amnesty ever, it was open to anyone with delinquent
taxes up to Dec. 31, 1993. Snyder said the oldest filing generated by the
amnesty processed so far involves a sale-and-use tax bill from 1963.

New Jersey's amnesty would be limited to those with delinquent bills from Jan.
1, 1987 to Jan. 1, 1996. Those who were eligible to file under the state's
previous amnesty in 1987 and did not participate would be ineligible this time.
Neither would businesses or individuals under criminal investigation for failure
to pay taxes or those who had already negotiated a settlement with the state.

The 1987 amnesty, like Pennsylvania's, required delinquents who settled to pay
interest as well as the principal.

Assemblyman Walter J. Kavanaugh (R., Somerset), who sponsored the amnesty bill
before the legislature, said an amnesty would not only bring in money from
delinquents the state knows about, but generate new revenue from businesses the
state does not have on file and should be paying taxes.

The 1987 amnesty brought in $183 million, of which $67 million was from
businesses not previously on the state rolls, according to Kavanaugh.

Some might argue that an amnesty would be unfair to those who pay on time. But
Kavanaugh and others said amnesties bring in money that might otherwise not have
been collected, easing the tax burden on the righteous and broadening the base
of who pays.

The $70 million that Clymer says he expects to raise through the amnesty has
already been included in a projected $890 million surplus to be carried over in
Whitman's proposed budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1.

But Verenda Smith of the Washington-based Federation of Tax Administrators said
much revenue generated by amnesties often amounts to accelerated collections
that would have occurred through a state's enforcement anyway. That means
collection of delinquent taxes falls off sharply in the months or years after
the amnesty expires, she said.

The administration needs approval from the full Senate and Assembly for the
amnesty to take effect. But an Assembly committee approved the amnesty proposal
earlier this week, and lawmakers in both parties have expressed support for the
measure.

LOAD-DATE: October 28, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1996 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC
                              All Rights Reserved

                   The Daily Independent (Ashland, Kentucky)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            April 23, 2009 Thursday

Gate City to collect late taxes

BYLINE: Carrie Stambaugh, The Daily Independent, Ashland, Ky.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 596 words


Apr. 23--CATLETTSBURG -- While some local governments are taking steps to shield
delinquent taxpayers from third party purchasers of late bills, the city of
Catlettsburg is encouraging it.

Gate City officials hope to collect thousands of dollars in unpaid property
taxes and boost city coffers through the practice. After a brief discussion
Tuesday night the council voted 6-0 in favor of contacting Dallas-based Tax Ease
Lien Investments 1 LLC, to ask it to purchase all the city's delinquent bills.

Mayor Pauline Hunt said the city has "thousands" in unpaid property tax bills
dating back as much as seven years. She said the city sends notices to those
taxpayers about their overdue bills but few ever pay them.

Councilman Donald Wellman raised the issue at Tuesday's meeting. He said other
local governments, including Boyd County, benefit from having tax bills paid by
third parties, who then place liens against the property to collect, and
Catlettsburg should, too.

Wellman said he doesn't feel sorry for delinquent taxpayers whose late bills
will increase when sold and could be at risk for having their property
foreclosed on if they don't pay up.

"We send them tax bills. If they had any intention to pay the taxes why wouldn't
they pay them? They owe us. We ought to sell these taxes. We need the money," he
said.

Councilman David Marushi also spoke in favor of the move. "I think we should
move forward," he said.

Marushi also said he thought it was unnecessary to inform delinquent taxpayers
that their unpaid bills were at risk of being sold to a third party. They have
already received ample delinquent notices, he said.

Several meeting attendees spoke out against the practice, pointing out that
companies such as Tax Ease have been criticized for tacking other large fees on
delinquent bills in addition to 12 percent late penalties allowed under state
laws.

They also argued substantial liens could sour investments in town by turning off
buyers of vacant property. Several potential buyers of one such building at the
corner of 23rd Street and Broadway, which has substantial liens by third
parties, have opted not to buy the property because of the situation, they said.

Other council members were skeptical at first, including Jimmie Epling.

Epling said he wanted to know if the city could see the fees and penalties Tax
Ease would charge residents before deciding.

Councilman Randall Peterman asked if other third parties would be allowed to
purchase bills if they wanted. Wellman responded they always could.

New legislation passed by the Kentucky General Assembly in the last session and
now in effect does set forth some new restrictions on the sale of delinquent tax
bills.

Third parties who purchase $10,000 worth, or more than five bills statewide, or
three in one county, to register with the state Department of Revenue and be in
good standing with the Attorney General's Office of Consumer Protection.

The new law also severely limits the amount of fees third parties can place on
bills. It also has notification and record retention provisions.

CARRIE STAMBAUGH can be reached at cstambaugh@dailyindependent.com or (606)
326-2653.

To see more of The Daily Independent or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.dailyindependent.com. Copyright (c) 2009, The Daily Independent,
Ashland, Ky. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For

847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group
Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                          The Tampa Tribune (Florida)

                              May 8, 2008 Thursday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Bylaws May Deny Delinquent Owners Positions On Board

BYLINE: RICHARD WHITE, Tribune correspondent

SECTION: BAYLIFE AT HOME; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 592 words


By RICHARD WHITE

Tribune correspondent

Q. What ethics are involved if a unit owner has decided to run for the board and
has not paid maintenance on his condominium unit? Suppose he wins the election
with maintenance in arrears and the voters do not know this information. Do the
owners have a right to know this information?

Can a unit owner ask and be given this information? Do unit owners have the
right to know who has not paid maintenance on a unit?

B.I.

Hollywood

A. Normally, I do not recommend that names of delinquent owners be made public.
I recommend that unit numbers or addresses be published.

But in this case, I would have the candidates put the information in their
candidate information sheet. I would put the pressure on the delinquent owner by
making sure that a lien is placed on the unit and have an attorney to start
foreclosure action.

Some documents say a delinquent owner cannot hold a director's position, so
check your bylaws.


Q. Where can I find (via a Web site or handbook) a copy of laws that govern
property owners associations?

F.P.

Inverness

A. For condominiums, use FS 718; for cooperatives, use FS 719. For homeowners
associations, use FS 720. For time shares use FS 721, and mobile home rental
associations use FS 723. They can be located at www.leg.state.fl.us.

There are other statutes that an association can become involved with. The
statute for not-for-profit corporations is FS 617. Associations also maybe
involved with the Florida Administrative Codes and other state documents.

Do not forget that associations fall under certain federal codes such as IRS tax
requirements. If you cannot find the statutes you need, call the state at (850)
488-1122 or write DBPR, 1940 N. Monroe St., Tallahassee FL 32399-1030.


Q. Our association is starting the process of updating our official documents.
The documents that were inherited from the builder were very generic and are in
need of updating. Can you please provide any guidance on this process; i.e., any
steps that we need to consider or pitfalls to avoid?

Are there sample documents that you can point us to that would be a good
starting point? Do you have a check list of items that need to be considered to
write good documents?

J.K.

Miami

A. The primary reason for me not addressing modification of documents is that I
am against most changes to the documents.

You do not change just because you want to add or remove restrictions. Owners
purchased with a set of rules and regulations regardless of how good or bad they
are. If you have read your documents, you should understand what you purchased.
You do not go in with the attitude of trying to modify your lifestyle.

There is no such thing as a guide or standard set of documents. Although many
developers ask an attorney to draft the first set of rules and regulations, many
call them boiler-plate documents.

If you feel the documents need to be changed, you need to talk with the members
and get their input and suggestions. Once you have members' approval, contact an
attorney to draft the new documents.

Caution: Do not attempt to make the changes without legal guidance. Some changes
could result in documents that make home transfers impossible.

Richard White is a licensed community association manager. He does not offer
legal opinions; any questions concerning association operations can be sent to
Richard White, 6039 Cypress Gardens Blvd., No. 201, Winter Haven FL 33884-4115;
or e-mail camquestion@cfl.rr.com

Copyright © 2008, The Tampa Tribune and may not be republished without
permission. E-mail library@tampatrib.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                        San Bernardino Sun (California)

                               May 6, 2011 Friday

San Bernardino going after tardy landlords

BYLINE: Josh Dulaney, Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 245 words


SAN BERNARDINO - The city is setting liens on properties to collect rising
delinquent business registration fees from landlords.

A preliminary list showing 224 delinquent landlords was presented to the City
Council, which took action Monday.

City Clerk Rachel Clark later said more than $89,000 in delinquent fees were
owed to the city.

Twenty-one people paid their overdue fees Monday, she said.

When someone rents out a property, they must pay a $60 annual fee to the city.

The city typically conducts about four sets of liens a year on delinquent fees.
The city code requires that landlords be given proper notice of delinquent
registration fees.

Three notices were mailed to each property owner on the preliminary list
provided to the council, the last notice being sent by certified mail, according
to a staff report.

A notice also was sent out about Monday's hearing on the liens.

"We give them several opportunities to come forward," Clark said.

She said the liens initially go through the San Bernardino County Recorder's
Office, and then to the county Assessor's Office.

"They go on the tax rolls in August and (the money) ultimately comes back to the
city," Clark said.

Penalties also are tacked onto the fees.

Staff removed 20 names from the preliminary list because those people no longer
were renting their properties out, having moved back onto the sites.

Clark said the number of such delinquencies has gone up and that staff has been
shuffled around to handle the load.

                             191 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        Whittier Daily News (California)

                           November 30, 2010 Tuesday

Foreclosure rate slows: Metro Los Angeles area sees decrease in delinquent loans

BYLINE: By Gregory J. Wilcox Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 448 words


Foreclosure activity in metropolitan Los Angeles slowed in the second quarter,
with the region ranking well below the nation's 25 most-distressed communities,
according to a study released Tuesday.

Los Angeles fell from 98th place in the first quarter to 124th in the second
quarter in terms of foreclosure activity, said foreclosure-response.org , which
based its report on loan performance data provided by LPS Applied Analytics.

The region ranked 68th in loans that are considered seriously delinquent,
compared with 64th the previous quarter.

"Relative to other places, things have gotten better in Los Angeles," said
Jeffrey Lubell, executive director of the Center for Housing Policy, a partner
in the website.

The group tracks the foreclosure landscape in 366 of the nation's metro areas.

In Los Angeles, the report said, 4.6 percent of loans were in foreclosure from
April through June, and 6.4 percent were at least 90 days past due.

The number of loans considered seriously delinquent is the total of those two
numbers, or 11 percent for the metro area. That's down slightly from 11.7 in the
first quarter.

A year earlier, the rate of loans in Los Angeles considered seriously delinquent
was 9.9 percent.

While the foreclosure inventory may continue to climb as past-due loans move
into foreclosure, there is reason to think the problem may be stabilizing,
Lubell said.

"There may still be more foreclosures to come, but the rate of foreclosures is
declining," Lubell said. "There is a quarter-to-quarter improvement. If that
trend were to continue, it would be quite encouraging."

If anything, activity here seems to have flattened out, he said.

In contrast, the Miami-Fort Lauderdale-Pompano Beach area ranks first in
foreclosures and serious mortgage delinquencies with rates of 17.8 and 25.6
percent, respectively.

And Florida could be in for some more housing pain and foreclosures, the report
noted. That state dominated the top 25 list and placed nine cities in the top
10.

By comparison, California had seven of the 25 metro areas with the highest
serious delinquency rates. Among those were the Riverside-San Bernardino-Ontario
areas, where 17 percent of mortgages are in foreclosure or three months past
due.

Andrew LePage, an analyst at MDA DataQuick, said that it appears Los Angeles,
and some parts of California, are recovering from the flood of foreclosures on
subprime loans that were rapidly flushed through the system and drove down
housing prices.

"Does it appear we'll see that again? No, there hasn't been any evidence of
that, but that's not to say we won't be at a relatively high level of
foreclosures for the next two years or so."

greg.wilcox@dailynews.com

818-713-3743

LOAD-DATE: December 1, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC:

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


   Copyright 2010 MediaNews Group, Inc. and Los Angeles Newspaper Group, Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                             192 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           Pittsburgh Tribune Review

                            February 2, 2009 Monday

Unified system might collect delinquent Allegheny-area tax

BYLINE: Tim Puko

LENGTH: 401 words


Delinquent taxes and fees soon could be collected by one program shared by
Allegheny County, Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh Public Schools and the Pittsburgh Water
and Sewer Authority.

Tax collection would be outsourced to Jordan Tax Service, which brings $1
million per month into county coffers, according to county Treasurer John
Weinstein. The other agencies have up to $100 million combined in outstanding
taxes and fees, and government officials said the program could double their
annual collections.

The authority and city schools have approved cooperation agreements. County
Council has a bill in committee, and Mayor Luke Ravenstahl could propose
legislation within weeks, city finance director Scott Kunka said.

Weinstein said the move is a big step for local consolidation efforts and could
lead eventually to total tax consolidation.

"I think it's pretty historic because it's a large service to start
integrating," said Christopher M. Berdnik, chief financial officer for
Pittsburgh Public Schools. "It's a pretty big deal."

The county first contracted with Jordan about five years ago, Weinstein said.
The company has collected $60 million for the county by setting up payment plans
with delinquent taxpayers. It uses a state law allowing Jordan to charge people
a 10 percent fee on top of the back taxes.

The Water and Sewer Authority, which is moving to Jordan in anticipation of
combined collection, had outsourced before, but had to pay its contractor from
the collected money. Government officials think they can save money by charging
that fee to the delinquent payers and by having one unified bill to simplify the
payment process and cut down on administrative costs.

"Government is not very good at delinquent tax collection, especially on real
estate," Weinstein said. "People get notice from the government and they don't
pay a lot of attention to it."

Dan Holland of the Young Preservationists Association of Pittsburgh said
delinquent taxes and vacant properties have been a barrier to development in the
city for years.

"It sounds like a good idea," he said. "(But) there's an assumption that they
can collect. ... You can send them a bill, but that assumes they're responsible
and will pay."

The agreement could be implemented by March 1, Pittsburgh Water and Sewer
Authority Executive Director Michael Kenney said. Berdnik said it likely will
take longer, maybe three to six months.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             193 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                             El Paso Times (Texas)

                            August 4, 2007 Saturday

Bankruptcies, lawsuits slow payments

BYLINE: El Paso Times Staff

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 1318 words


By David Crowder

El Paso Times

Asarco, El Paso's newest hospital, the Tiguas and the man who owns more historic
buildings than anyone else in town are among the city's top 20 delinquent
taxpayers.

The city's tax office, which collects property taxes for all 29 taxing entities
in El Paso County, sent out tax notices last year for $718 million in all, of
which about $22 million -- or 3 percent -- has gone delinquent.

In all, according to the city's consolidated tax records, more than $63 million
in delinquent taxes is owed to those jurisdictions.

"We've already collected $719 million in current and delinquent taxes this
fiscal year, and of the $63 million that is delinquent, we'll probably collect
$20 million to $21 million in the next 12 months," City Tax Assessor-Collector
Juan Sandoval said.

The top 20 delinquent accounts total $4.7 million, of which $719,198 is owed to
the city.

"I would say most are in bankruptcy, in lawsuits for nonpayment, or they just
became delinquent and have been turned over to our attorneys," Sandoval said.

At the top of this list is Albuquerque-based Roadrunner Trucking Inc., which was
among the biggest trucking companies in the nation before it went out of
business in 2005.

"They're not in bankruptcy, but we have a court judgment on that account, which
became delinquent in 2004," Sandoval said.

Today, Mesilla Valley Trucking is operating on Roadrunner's former site at 7440
Doniphan.

Physician's Hospital East, which filed for bankruptcy this year, is second on
the list at $579,525 when its delinquent personal property taxes for 2006 are
combined with the unpaid taxes on real estate listed under Physicians Specialty
Hospital's account at the same address, 1416 George Dieter.

"There's a bankruptcy pending," said Dr. O.R. Brooker, who is among the
hospital's owners. "There are bidders that are going to be bidding on the
hospital. There will be an auction ... that I suspect will be in October."

Brooker said the high-tech, 40-bed hospital had a great location in an area of
the city that is medically underserved, but it could not attract enough doctors.

"There's a shortage of physicians in El Paso, and it's hard to get people to
move their business somewhere else," Brooker said. "Recently, the hospital has
been doing well, breaking even and close to a profit."

Fourth on the list at $375,815 is Asarco, which filed for bankruptcy in 2004 and
has not paid that year's taxes on 22 accounts for equipment and properties
contiguous to the plant.

"They have paid for '05 and '06, but their bankruptcy plan has not been
approved, so that's why they're not making any payments," Sandoval said. "They
are current except for that one year."

Heritage Automotive, fifth on the list with $211,550 delinquent on 22 accounts
for 2003 and 2004, filed for bankruptcy in 2004.

Also in bankruptcy is Delphi Automotive Systems, the General Motors supplier,
which owes $204,075 in taxes for 2005, the year it filed for bankruptcy
protection.

The corporation that owns El Paso's premier Downtown hotel, the Camino Real, is
ninth on the list at $165,064 -- one year's delinquency.

The hotel's taxable valuation dropped from $11.7 million last year to $9.2
million this year, indicating a valuation challenge.

South-West city Rep. Beto O'Rourke said he was disturbed to hear that the
biggest and oldest Downtown hotel is behind in its taxes at a time when the city
is trying to revitalize the area.

He said that the city has been concerned about the hotel for some time and that
last year, he met with the Camino Real's general manager, Michelle Kaip, to
voice his concerns about the hotel's condition.

"She assured me they are committed to bringing that hotel back up to the
community's expectations," he said.

Kaip said she could not discuss the delinquent taxes because a lawsuit is
pending that involves taxes.

"I will tell you we have completed a multimillion renovation earlier this year,
so the hotel is in great shape now," she said. "As far as our financial
viability, we are doing very well."

On the tax rolls, the Camino Real is owned by Hotel Paso del Norte Inc. Kaip
said it is owned by Camino Real Hotels and Resorts, a Mexico City corporation
that owns more than 20 hotels in Mexico and one in the United States, El Paso's
Camino Real.

The Tigua Indian reservation, Ysleta del Sur Pueblo, is No. 17 on the list and
owes $113,611 in back taxes on 45 property accounts, Sandoval said.

The tribe has payment agreements on every account that Sandoval checked.

And 18th on the delinquency list is William D. "Billy" Abraham, who owes
$112,411 in back taxes on two properties, the Newberry Building at 201 Stanton
and the historic but vacant 1880s railroad depot at Campbell Street and
Interstate 10.

Abraham said he is protesting the valuation on both buildings and has paid the
taxes on the uncontested value.

He owns nearly 20 historic buildings in the Downtown area, and is being
prosecuted by the city over code violations at a number of them. The city has
initiated eminent domain proceedings against him to take possession of the
Albert Fall Mansion, alleging Abraham has allowed it to fall into serious
disrepair.

Central Appraisal District records show a protest is active on the Newberry
Building, the valuation of which was raised to $800,525 this year from last
year's $685,865.

The protest over the former depot's value appears to be concluded, and it is
listed on the appraisal roll at $809,048, about $10,000 higher than last year's
value.

Sandoval said the city aggressively pursues delinquent taxes, through the law
firm hired to handle collections and tax lawsuits: Delgado, Acosta, Spencer,
Linebarger and Perez.

After July 1, a 20 percent surcharge is applied to tax accounts that go
delinquent each year and, when the taxes, penalty and interest are paid --
whether legal action has been taken or not -- that surcharge goes to the law
firm.

Last year, the firm received $3.5 million in collection fees, and the firm has
been paid that much through July for the first 11 months of this fiscal year,
Sandoval said.

"There are accounts that are easy to collect," Sandoval said. "But, there are
other accounts that are not resolved for years that take a considerable amount
of effort to collect."

David Crowder may be reached at dcrowder@elpasotimes.com; 546-6194

Ruben R. Ramirez / El Paso Times

                             194 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           The Philadelphia Inquirer

                             May 29, 2013 Wednesday
                                 CITY-D Edition

New Pa. bills for city school shortfall

BYLINE: By Martha Woodall; Inquirer Staff Writer

SECTION: NATIONAL; P-com News for PC Home Page; Pg. A01

LENGTH: 1150 words


As the Philadelphia School Reform Commission prepares to vote on a doomsday
budget with massive cuts, a state senator Tuesday announced legislation that
would funnel more funds to the schools by giving the city new powers to crack
down on delinquent taxpayers.

State Sen. Mike Stack (D., Phila.) said the legislative package he will
introduce this week in Harrisburg - with support from Mayor Nutter - would
require the city to garnish up to 10 percent of the wages of delinquent
taxpayers, give local governments authority to attach bank accounts to collect
unpaid taxes without going to court, and allow municipalities to put liens on
property anywhere in the state that is owned by delinquent taxpayers.

Stack's proposals are the latest ideas for helping the district plug a $304
million shortfall it will face July 1. His bills join others in the legislative
hopper, including one that would tax cigarettes in Philadelphia by $2 a pack and
raise the city's liquor-by-the-drink tax from 10 percent to 15 percent.

In an interview, Stack pointed out that the city was owed $249 million in
delinquent property taxes alone.

"Let's first collect the taxes that are already owed," said Stack, who
represents Northeast Philadelphia, Bridesburg, Kensington, and Port Richmond,
and has been mentioned as a possible gubernatorial candidate.

In addition to unpaid property taxes, Stack's five-bill package would give the
city power to go after $91.5 million in delinquent business income and receipts
taxes, and $47 million in late city-wage taxes.

"It is wrong that delinquent property and business owners are playing a big part
in the starvation of Philadelphia school students and teachers," Stack said. "It
is equally wrong that the city lacks the legal muscle to take action against the
negligent people who are robbing our students of a quality education."

Nutter spokesman Mark McDonald said the measures "were referenced in an early
February announcement by the Revenue Department as part of a new Delinquent Tax
Collection Strategy. It calls for a city investment of roughly $25 million in
capital funds and an additional $15 million in new operating funds to create a
range of enforcement tools to help Revenue do its work."

He said the strategy also called for legislative changes at both the city and
state levels and that Stack "had introduced this package on our behalf."

If approved by the legislature, the measures could produce an additional $20
million the first year, Stack estimated.

"I think we will collect even more revenue based on the fact we are sounding the
horn, and people will know it's time to pay the piper," he said.

If approved, Stack's proposals would allow all Pennsylvania municipalities to
place a lien on properties for unpaid taxes and add the cost of collection to
any lien attached to a delinquent property or business.

The wage-garnishment provision would give Philadelphia the power other
municipalities already have under state law to go after delinquent property and
business owners.

His plan to allow Philadelphia to put liens for delinquent taxes on properties
outside the city limits is similar to a bill State Rep. Cherelle Parker (D.,
Phila.) introducted in the House that targets deadbeats' suburban properties.

Stack said his bills would help the city address longstanding problems with
collecting taxes and "send a powerful message that Philadelphia is getting its
house in order."

Senate Republican spokesman Erik Arneson said he had not had an opportunity to
review Stack's proposals in detail, but added: "Clearly, those who owe back
taxes should pay those taxes. To the extent that existing tools may be
insufficient to accomplish that goal, that's an issue the General Assembly
should dive into."

Stack unveiled his proposals outside Lincoln High School in Mayfair with Jerry
Jordan, president of the Philadelphia Federation of Teachers.

"We're glad to see Sen. Stack and other elected officials proposing sustainable
education funding that will end the current practice of taking programs away
from our children," Jordan said.

To plug the massive shortfall projected to hit the district, Superintendent
William R. Hite Jr. has asked for $60 million in extra funding from the city and
$120 million from the state. The district also is seeking more than $100 million
in givebacks from the PFT.

Hite welcomed Stack's support and said he was grateful elected officials were
taking the district's plight seriously.

"Just like in all the other cases, I'm especially appreciative that Sen. Stark
is also trying to find ways to generate more revenue for the school district,"
Hite said in an interview.

Nutter has announced plans to raise $95 million for the schools in 2013-14
through a package that included imposing a new cigarette tax, raising the city's
drink tax, and a strategy to crack down on delinquent tax collections.

The mayor estimated his total package could generate $135 million in the second
year.

Both the cigarette and drink taxes require approval from Harrisburg and City
Council.

Council last week introduced two bills from Nutter to raise the liquor tax and
create the cigarette tax, although Council President Darrell L. Clarke said the
bills would be meaningless unless the state approves enabling legislation, which
has not been introduced.

Despite the flurry of proposals, the district has no guarantee it will receive
more money from the city or the state.

And facing a May 31 legal deadline for acting on a new budget, the School Reform
Commission is scheduled to vote Thursday on a $2.7 billion spending plan that
Hite has said would be catastrophic for city schools.

"We have proposed a budget that is based on what we know we will have," Hite
said.

He said the SRC can amend the budget if the revenue picture changes. Both
Council and the state legislature have June 30 budget deadlines.

Hite and the district have laid out a scenario in which there could be 3,000
layoffs, including some teachers. Schools could open in the fall without new
books, paper, clubs, counselors, librarians, music teachers or secretaries.

Class sizes would be larger, but schools would have no aides to help manage them
or support staff to monitor lunchrooms and playgrounds.

A rally protesting the cutbacks is scheduled outside the district's headquarters
at 440 N. Broad St. an hour before the SRC's 5:30 p.m. meeting.

Students are taking action, too. A letter-writing campaign led by students from
Central High School delivered more than 2,000 missives to City Hall for Council
last week and sent more than 500 to Gov. Corbett.

"I think Harrisburg often forgets about the students," said Jacquelyn
Mancinelli, an English teacher who has worked with the teens.

"The students are just so invested in this," she said. "They know this could
really be devastating for them."

Contact Martha Woodall

at 215-854-2789 or martha.woodall@phillynews.com.

LOAD-DATE: May 29, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
