                              LNP (Lancaster, PA)

                            March 1, 2017 Wednesday

School Brief;
Columbia

BYLINE: Correspondent

SECTION: A; Pg. 18

LENGTH: 355  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


n What happened: A delinquent 2016 per capita tax list was approved for agency
collection by the board Feb. 16. A motion to publicize the names of delinquent
taxpayers was tabled until March.

n Why it's important: Out of the 6,247 Columbia residents who received $15 per
capita tax bills in 2016, only 4,078 residents paid their bills on time. The
remainder of residents (2,169) who did not pay their bills translates into a
revenue loss to the district of $35,789, according to Tom Strickler, director of
operations.

n Quotable: "Do we publish these names (delinquent taxpayers) anywhere?" - Barry
Ford, school board director.

n Discussion: With board approval, the 2016 delinquent per capita list was
turned over to Powell, Rogers & Speaks for collection. Ford wanted to know if
the list can be publicized. Keith Ramsey, interim business manager, responded
that the names are not published to his knowledge. Superintendent Bob Hollister
interjected that the school solicitor would be consulted for an answer to Ford's
question. Following motion protocol to add an agenda item, there was a motion to
publicize the delinquent tax list. After discussion, there was a motion to table
that motion until the Committee of the Whole meeting on March 2.

n Software update: Under its shared leadership agreement with Eastern Lancaster
County School District, Columbia was able to update its financial software.
Ramsey, who is Elanco's chief of finance and operations, saved the district
$6,746 by converting to CSIU. The changeover in software makes it easier for
Columbia to submit state reports and includes tax collection and census software
as well. For the first time in February, financial reports were embedded in the
online meeting agenda for public perusal.

n What's next: Keith Combs, Columbia school board president, is in the process
of contacting Glenn Yoder, Elanco school board president. Under the shared
leadership agreement, it is time for the two school boards to meet and discuss
how the arrangement is working and if there is an interest to discuss continuing
the agreement beyond the 2016-17 school year.

-Ann Marie Steele,

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                    Messenger-Inquirer (Owensboro, Kentucky)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           November 26, 2013 Tuesday

City tax deadline looms

BYLINE: Steve Vied, Messenger-Inquirer, Owensboro, Ky.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 302 words


Nov. 26--City of Owensboro property taxes will become delinquent if not paid by
the last day of November, but taxpayers who wait beyond Wednesday to pay in
person or by telephone will run into difficulty.

Because of the Thanksgiving holiday, City Hall will be closed on Thursday,
Thanksgiving Day, as well as Friday.

On the last day of the month, Saturday, City Hall is closed as well.

To avoid penalty and interest, payments made in person or called in must be made
no later than 5 p.m. Wednesday.

Mailed payments must be postmarked no later than Saturday.

Payments may also be placed in an outside drop box at City Hall.

Any payments placed in the drop box prior to City Hall opening Monday morning
will be counted as being on time.

Last year, more than 1,900 city property tax bills were delinquent, resulting in
penalties assessed and interest charged, Angela Hamric, city finance director,
said earlier this month.

According to Hamric, the city had 24,852 tax bills last year, with 1,905 bills
delinquent.

The city collected $41,669 in penalties and interest on the delinquent bills
that were paid.

Penalty and interest will be applied to all delinquent accounts starting on Dec.
1.

The penalty for delinquent property taxes is 10 percent.

Interest is applied monthly at a rate of 0.5 percent, or 6 percent on an annual
basis.

The city accepts checks, cash and Visa, MasterCard and Discover credit cards.

Cash should not be mailed, however.

City Hall is at 101 E. Fourth St. Business hours -- Monday through Friday for
regular weeks -- are 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. The phone number for tax payments is
270-687-8537.

Steve Vied, 691-7297, svied@messenger-inquirer.com

                          The Tampa Tribune (Florida)

                              May 11, 2010 Tuesday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Unpaid property taxes fall

BYLINE: RAY REYES and JOSH THOMAS, The News Center

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 463 words


Numbers for 2009 are lower than 2008.

By RAY REYES

rreyes@tampatrib.com

and JOSH THOMAS

jthomas@wfla.com

TAMPA - Despite a foundering economy and a record number of foreclosures, fewer
Hillsborough County properties owed unpaid taxes in 2009 than in 2008.

As of April 1, 39,734 delinquent properties owed more than $116 million to the
county, according to 2009 tax roll figures. The year before, 46,701 properties
owed more than $159 million.

Officials at the Hillsborough County Tax Collector's Office hadn't predicted the
number of delinquent properties would decrease.

"It was a big surprise to everybody," said Dana Dove, general manager of the
processing operations center for county Tax Collector Doug Belden. "Maybe it is
a trend that we're improving. I don't know. You would expect with the economy
the way it is, things would be reversed."

One possible reason there were fewer delinquent homeowners in 2009 could be that
banks paid the taxes on foreclosed homes to avoid more penalties and protect
their interest in the property, Dove said.

The tax collector's office released the 288-page delinquent tax list today. A
quick scan of the listings shows that individuals owed from as little as pocket
change to tens of thousands of dollars.

Alexander and Melinda Veloz for example, owed $13.93 in taxes on a vacant lot at
16315 Lonely Lane in Odessa; Albert and Christine Slattman owed $36,662 on a
4-bedroom, 2-bath home at 6621 Appaloosa Drive in Tampa.

Property taxes are due Nov. 1 and become delinquent if not paid by April 1.

To encourage payment, the tax collector's office opened bidding today on tax
certificates for delinquent properties. Investors have a chance to bid on
interest earned on the outstanding debt.

Most of the taxes will be paid by homeowners, mortgage holders or through the
sale of the certificates, Dove said.

Bids range from zero to 18 percent. Although the lowest interest rate bid on a
property gets the certificates, state law guarantees the winning bidders a
minimum return of 5 percent. The auction ends May 29.

If no one pays the tax on the property by 22 months after the sale, the
certificate holder can foreclose on the property. Unsold certificates will be
issued to the county at 18 percent interest. If no one purchases the county
certificates, the county will foreclose on the property as long as the value is
over $5,000.

For information on the sale, visit the Hillsborough County Tax Collector's
Office website at www.hillstax.org.

Information from Tribune archives was used in this report. Tribune reporter Ray
Reyes can be reached at (813) 259-7920. News Channel 8 reporter Josh Thomas can
be reached at (813) 221-5737.

Photo: Dana Dove

Copyright © 2010, The Tampa Tribune and may not be republished without
permission. E-mail library@tampatrib.com

LOAD-DATE: June 2, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             198 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                     The Santa Fe New Mexican (New Mexico)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           December 4, 2013 Wednesday

Delinquent tax bills linked to Richard Cook project

BYLINE: Tom Sharpe, The Santa Fe New Mexican

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 687 words


Dec. 04--Two of Santa Fe County's biggest delinquent property-tax bills appear
to be connected to Española businessman Richard Cook's plan to build a new
interchange on N.M. 599 to reach his proposed office park near the Santa Fe
Municipal Airport.

In both cases, the overdue taxes are accruing in the names of other entities
because the sales to Cook's companies apparently were never properly recorded.

In the first case, Albuquerque lawyer Hans William Voss has Santa Fe County's
fifth-largest delinquent bill, at $68,832, according to a list of tax-delinquent
properties from the Santa Fe County Assessor and Treasurer's offices.

Voss, the immediate past president of the state bar association, said the bill
resulted from him accepting 4.23 acres at 43 Aviation Drive in payment for a
legal fee, then discovering later that his client already had conveyed her
interest in the property to Santa Fe Transit Mix.

"We made those folks aware of the fact that ... they weren't paying their bill,"
he said. "I guess they're just going to let it go. It's disappointing to me that
it continues to rack up in my name."

State corporation records don't list Santa Fe Transit Mix, but they do list
Española Transit Mix, Los Alamos Transit Mix and Associated Asphalt & Materials
in Santa Fe, and the company that seems to be working in the area, EMCO of Santa
Fe. Cook's daughter, Katharine Cook Fishman, is listed as the organizer of all
four companies. Messages left for Cook, Fishman and Phillip Sena, a development
consultant for the Cook family, were not returned.

Voss said the property near the airport is vacant except for a small shed, but
Santa Fe Transit Mix has been using it as a waste dump.

"I don't think they ever intend to pay the taxes on it," he said. "They're
dumping old concrete there and soil and things that are byproducts of their
business. ... Someday the county will repossess it, and it'll be full of stuff."

Work began this summer extending Jaguar Drive west over N.M. 599, also known as
the Santa Fe Relief Route, to reach 371 acres where Cook plans to build an
office park called The Pavilion. Cook also has plans for commercial developments
along the extended Jaguar Drive. The overpass, expected to cost $6 million to
$10 million, would be the first highway interchange ever built by a private
developer in Northern New Mexico.

The Tierra Contenta Corp. has the county's sixth largest delinquent tax bill,
$62,588, according to the list from the county.

But James Hicks, executive director of the nonprofit formed to distribute some
1,000 acres of city-owned land for housing, said the bill is for a tract of land
that Tierra Contenta sold a Cook family company called Commercial Center at 599
Inc. at the end of 2009. Fishman is listed as the firm's president and director
in state corporation records.

Like in Voss' case, Hicks said he has tried several times to get the Santa Fe
County Assessor to send the tax bill to Cook's corporation without success.

"Normally, I don't like to blow the whistle on somebody else other than to say,
'It's not ours,' " he said. "But we have taken the deeds over to the county
several times to show them what the transactions were, and every time we take
them over there, they have this big question mark on their face like, 'We don't
remember.' "

Chief Deputy Assessor Gary Perez said the problem appears to be that the Santa
Fe County Clerk's Office has never forwarded a deed proving that the two tracts
have been transferred to Cook's corporations. He said Tuesday that his
researcher has yet to find another deed for the Voss property and is still
looking for one on the Tierra Contenta transfer.

"We usually get these on a daily basis, so for whatever reason maybe this is one
that didn't get found and didn't get changed to the correct name," he said. "I
ran into a couple of these with some condos in Edgewood, and we're fixing that
right now."

Contact Tom Sharpe at 986-3080 or tsharpe@sfnewmexican.com

Mexican (Santa Fe, N.M.) at www.santafenewmexican.com Distributed by MCT
Information Services

                             199 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                          The York Dispatch (York, PA)

                            February 18, 2005 Friday

City school district may sell delinquent tax caseload

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS

LENGTH: 251 words


The York City School District may take advantage of two new state laws that
allow school districts to sell their caseload of delinquent taxes to a private
debt collector.

Board member Tom Foust said the district is in discussions with XSPAND, a
company that promised it could pay the district up to 90 cents on the dollar it
is owed in back taxes.

For example, if a taxpayer owes $10,000 in delinquent taxes, XSPAND could pay
the district up to $9,000 to take the debt. The company will then try to collect
the entire amount of debt from the taxpayer, making $1,000 for the company.

Currently, the York County Tax Claim Bureau collects the district's delinquent
taxes, but it doesn't buy the district's debts.

According to the company's Web site, XSPAND is operated by James Florio, former
governor of New Jersey, and Paul V. Scura, former vice-chairman of Prudential
Securities.

"Since 1997, we have helped local governments in over 21 states to realize over
$700 million in revenue from the conversion of delinquent property tax
receivables into cash," the Web site says.

It also claims that the company serves some very large government entities, such
as the city of New York and the county of Los Angeles.

Foust said Florio has visited the district to talk about the company's services,
and may visit again.

The school district is owed more than $3 million in delinquent taxes, Foust
said.

Acts 70 and 168 of 2004 would make the change possible.

Chris Kauffman

LOAD-DATE: March 26, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                 Copyright 2005


                             200 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                       The Daily Record (Baltimore, MD.)

                             June 27, 2000, Tuesday

BYLINE: By Todd Karpovich; Daily Record Business Writer

SECTION: Pg.  3A

LENGTH: 452 words


Maryland Comptroller William Donald Schaefer is going after people who owe taxes
by "naming names."    As of yesterday, 50 of the biggest tax delinquents in 1999
have been listed on the comptroller's Web site (www.marylandtaxes.com) as an
incentive to get them to pony up. The 50 names are a matter of public record
because tax liens have been filed in circuit court for each of the cases.     "I
do not think it is an invasion of privacy," Schaefer said. "They owe a lot of
money. We have given these people notice. It is just not fair to the people who
pay their taxes."    So far this year, the comptroller's office says it has
collected more than $ 153,000 from seven delinquents and received commitments
from about 12 others after issuing notices to them. The 50 delinquents listed on
the Web site yesterday failed to respond to the agency's request for payment,
according to Schaefer's office, and owe more than $ 9.7 million in past taxes,
penalties and interest.  Schaefer said that posting the delinquent taxpayers
names on a Web site has worked in such states as Connecticut and Illinois. Other
states that publicly list names of delinquent taxpayers include California,
Montana and New Jersey, along with cities such as Washington, D.C., and New
York.     "Nothing else has worked so we are going to publicize the people who
owe taxes," Schaefer said.     Francis X. and Patricia Gaegler, of Hyattsville,
topped the list with $ 626,152.77 due in taxes, penalties and interest,
according to the Web site. None of the taxpayers listed on the site is in
bankruptcy and none is on an active payment plan with the state.     Linda
Tanton, director of the comptroller's compliance division, said that a citizen
or business is mailed a letter by the comptroller's office specifying the
overdue taxes, plus any interest and penalties.     A late withholding return or
underpayment on state sales or use taxes is subject to an initial 5 percent
penalty, followed by an additional 10 percent after 30 days, plus interest
calculated at 1.08 percent monthly, according to the comptroller's office. An
underpayment for personal income tax is subject to a 25 percent penalty plus
interest. .  Tanton said that if people do not pay their taxes, the money can be
taken out of their salary. Businesses that do not pay taxes can be penalized by
losing their licenses to practice in the state. Penalties also can be assessed
on the firms' officers, and payments can be held up if the company does work for
the state, "We gave them warnings and told them they would show up on our Web
site if they did not pay," Tanton said. "Everyone was notified personally, and
they made no effort to pay us."

LOAD-DATE: June 28, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 2000 The Daily Record Co.


                             201 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                            March 27, 2002 Wednesday

Camden council to hire Florio's firm;
The company will work to collect delinquent taxes in the city. There is nearly
$40 million at stake.

BYLINE: Dwight Ott Inquirer Staff Writer

SECTION: REGION

LENGTH: 337 words


CAMDEN - City Council is expected to approve tomorrow a contingency contract
with a revenue collection firm headed by former Gov. Jim Florio to help the city
redeem close to $40 million in delinquent tax liens.

Camden would become the first city in New Jersey to use Florio's firm since a
bill was passed recently allowing the company to operate in the state.

Florio said the contract had already been approved through the state Department
of Community Affairs, which oversees Camden's spending practices.

The former Democratic governor told a Council caucus yesterday that his firm
would provide software to the city at no cost during the term of the three-year
contract to help analyze and prioritize delinquent properties. He said his
company's profits would be a percentage of what was collected.

"These are delinquent taxes that are so delinquent that when the city tries to
sell the liens no one will buy them," Florio told Council.

In New York state, Florio said, his firm's fees were about 20 percent of what
was collected.

The proposed contract with Camden calls for a 9 percent fee the first year, 12
percent the second year, and 14 percent in the third year.

Council President Angel Fuentes welcomed Florio's new company. "For us, it's a
blessing to have you with us."

Florio found no irony in the fact that he was helping collect taxes that some
claim he helped to raise.

"I never raised property taxes," Florio said before last night's meeting. "I
raised income taxes."

In other business, Council members were informed that Police Chief Robert E.
Allenbach was still meeting with state officials on the deployment of state
troopers in Camden. Gov. McGreevey promised the troopers to the city earlier
this month.

Allenbach said after the caucus meeting that although a few troopers had already
begun working in Camden, the full complement would arrive over the next 45 days.
He said he expected more than 80 troopers.

Contact Dwight Ott at 856-779-3844 or dott@phillynews.com.

                             202 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                            Mortgage Servicing News

                                 November 2008

AGs Say Too Few Get Forbearance

BYLINE: Jennifer Harmon

SECTION: Pg. 1 Vol. 12 No. 10

LENGTH: 610  words


Washington-A new report says too many homeowners face foreclosure without
receiving meaningful assistance from their mortgage servicer.

In its third "Analysis of Subprime Mortgage Servicing Performance," the State
Foreclosure Prevention Working Group concluded things are getting worse as the
number of delinquent loans, prime and subprime, increases. Industry measures to
keep homeowners out of foreclosure have slipped, according to the group, which
is made up of state attorneys general and state banking regulators.

Based on data collected from February through May, the report said eight out of
10 seriously delinquent homeowners are not on track for any loan workout or
loss-mitigation assistance to enable them to avoid foreclosure, a higher
percentage than the group found in its April report. Previously, seven out of 10
are not on track for any loss-mit outcome.

"Servicers appear to have reached the 'low-hanging fruit' of subprime loans
facing interest rate resets, while not developing effective approaches to
address the bulk of subprime loans which are in default before interest rate
resets," the report said. "Based on the rising number of delinquent prime loans
and project numbers of payment-option ARM loans facing reset over the next two
years, we fear that continued reactive approaches will lead to another wave of
unnecessary and preventable foreclosures."

While banks and Wall Street firms continue to report record writedowns of
mortgage loan portfolios and securities, the losses do not appear to be flowing
down to homeowners in the form of sustainable loan modifications, said Iowa
attorney general Tim Miller, a founder and leader of the group. Since October
2007, the group has been collecting data from the largest subprime mortgage
servicers. The group is led by representatives of the AGs of 11 states,
including Arizona, California, Colorado, Iowa, Illinois, Massachusetts,
Michigan, New York, North Carolina, Ohio and Texas; two state banking
departments (New York and North Carolina); and the Conference of State Bank
Supervisors.

New efforts to prevent foreclosures are on the decline, despite a temporary
increase in loan modifications through the second quarter of 2008. The number of
homeowners working toward a loan mod has fallen to a level not seen since late
2007.

One out of five loan modifications made in the past year is currently delinquent
, the report said. "We are concerned that unrealistic or 'Band-Aid'
modifications have only exacerbated and prolonged the current foreclosure
crisis," the report said.

Three hundred thousand subprime loans are in the process of foreclosure as of
the end of May. Thirty-eight percent of seriously delinquent subprime loans are
in the process of foreclosure with over 131,000 foreclosures completed on
subprime loans in May alone.

"The financial turmoil we see today is in part a result of a 'pennywise,
pound-foolish' approach of the mortgage industry to prevent foreclosures," added
Mark Pearce, North Carolina deputy commissioner of banks. "Instead of developing
efficient approaches to reduce the payment burdens of large numbers of
unaffordable loans, mortgage servicers have relied on the same approach used
before the foreclosure crisis. The result has been record levels of unnecessary
foreclosures that have accelerated declines in property values that have
affected all of us."

The Working Group said it hopes that recently enacted federal legislation to
provide a new federally guaranteed refinance program, Hope For Homeowners, will
increase the level of refinancing for poorly performing subprime loans. However,
the ultimate impact of the program has not yet been seen.

URL: http://www.mortgageservicingnews.com/

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newsletter

                             El Paso Times (Texas)

                              May 27, 2012 Sunday

El Paso County tax assessor-collector Victor Flores denies conflict of interest

BYLINE: By Aileen B. Flores \ El Paso Times

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 972 words


A candidate for the El Paso County tax assessor-collector's office has raised
questions about a possible conflict of interest involving incumbent Victor
Flores and the law firm hired to collect delinquent taxes.

Flores denied the allegations and said his opponent is trying to connect him
with corruption in an effort to get elected.

Tax assessor-collector candidate Armando Rodriguez, a member of Canutillo
Independent School District Board of Trustees, said the agreement to have
delinquent taxes of public entities collected by the city's tax office has not
been re-examined in more than 20 years and needs to be investigated to determine
its effectiveness.

Rodriguez is challenging Flores in the Democratic primary.

Rodriguez said a brother of Flores' works for the law firm hired by the city to
collect delinquent taxes. The firm also contributes to Flores' campaign, he
said.

The Austin-based law firm of Linebarger Heard Goggan Blair & Sampson has worked
for the city of El Paso collecting delinquent taxes for almost 30 years.

In 1999, the law firm responded to the complaint that most of the fees earned by
the firm were sent out of town and partnered with local lawyers Hector Delgado,
Alejandro Acosta, Joe Spencer and Carmen Perez, according to El Paso Times
archives.

Since then, Delgado, Acosta, Spencer, Linebarger & Perez have enforced the
collection of delinquent property taxes for 26 taxing entities throughout the
county, including school districts, the county, the hospital district and El
Paso Community College.

"The Austin firm is the one doing the work, but partnered with a group of local
attorneys to lend their names to secure the contract," Rodriguez said.
"Everybody has their hands in there to get the money."

He said there are no records that explain the relationship between the lawyers
involved in the contract, their duties and how much each of them gets paid.

According to the city contract for the collection of delinquent property taxes
with Delgado, Acosta, Spencer, Linebarger, & Perez, the law firm earns 20
percent on the delinquent tax money it collects. The firm collects more than $20
million a year.

Nobody questions a contract that pays more than $4 million to the law firm every
year, Rodriguez said.

"As tax assessor-collector, you have the authority to question the delinquent
tax contract," he said.

Rodriguez said his opponent has not questioned the contract because his brother,
David Flores, is the manager of Delgado, Acosta, Spencer, Linebarger & Perez.

"There is a direct conflict of interest under Flores' direct duties as county
tax assessor-collector to question the delinquent tax firm to make sure the work
has been done efficiently," he said.

According to Victor Flores' campaign reports, Perez has contributed $400,
Delgado and Acosta $500, Spencer $200 and Linebarger Heard Goggan Blair &
Sampson $500 to his campaign.

"The city has had that contract for more than 10 years. We are not able to see
if there is somebody else that can do that job better because the way this
system is set up," Rodriguez said.

Victor Flores said there is no conflict of interest because the county does not
contract with the law firm to collect delinquent taxes. He said the city
contracts with that firm.

Under the agreement, school districts, county, University Medical Center and El
Paso Community College give the city the authority to choose the law firm that
collects those taxes, Victor Flores said.

The contract for the collection of delinquent property taxes states that under
the tax agreement, an advisory committee monitors the performance of the tax
collection procedures.

The committee has unanimously recommended to the city that it keep the Delgado,
Acosta, Spencer, Linebarger & Perez firm as delinquent tax collector, said the
city document.

In 2009, the City Council extended the agreement with Delgado, Acosta, Spencer,
Linebarger & Perez until 2015.

The law firms reports to the city and does monthly reports on the work it has
done, said City Tax Assessor-Collector Juan Sandoval.

Copies of those reports are sent to the city attorney's office, he said.

Sandoval said the firm does "a great job" in collecting delinquent taxes.

Rodriguez tried to find out through an open-records request how much each one of
the attorneys in the law firm gets paid, but the city does not have that
information, Sandoval said. "We are not involved in that. We don't know how they
divide up their money," Sandoval said.

Victor Flores said his brother was working for the law firm long before he was
first elected in 1996.

"My opponent is sitting there trying to make an issue out of something," Victor
Flores said. "I am the last person to have any say-so in the matter."

The County Tax Assessor-Collector's Office abides by the contracts that the
County Commissioners Court decides, he said.

Victor Flores said he does not have any influence on decisions made by the
county commissioners or the City Council.

Victor Flores said Rodriguez should understand the agreement because he is the
vice president of the Canutillo Independent School District Board of Trustees,
which is bound by the same contract the city uses.

"He works under the same contract that the county works under. And if he does
not know it, I feel really bad for Canutillo because he is the vice president,"
Victor Flores said.

Too many governmental bodies are involved in the agreement to allow a conflict
of interest, Victor Flores said. Lawyers for the Canutillo school district
should know exactly how the contract works, he added.

Victor Flores said Rodriguez has launched a negative campaign against him trying
to connect him with corruption to get into office.

Rodriguez has yet to say what he brings to the table if he gets elected, Flores
said.

Aileen B. Flores may be reached at aflores@elpasotimes.com; 546-6362. Follow her
@AileenBFlores.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Armando Rodriguez

                     The Santa Fe New Mexican (New Mexico)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           December 4, 2013 Wednesday

Some blame economic downturn for hefty delinquent tax bill

BYLINE: Tom Sharpe, The Santa Fe New Mexican

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 604 words


Dec. 04--Financial straits, erroneous land records and unresolved legal disputes
are among the reasons given for Santa Fe County's largest delinquent property
tax bills.

"Believe me, I'm no deadbeat," said Robert Frost, whose Two Spirits Inc., with
his partner Ralph Bolton, has the third largest delinquent tax bill in Santa Fe
County, according to a list of delinquent taxpayers provided to The New Mexican.

"It's a simple matter of economics," Frost said last week. "We've already agreed
and set things up [so that] we'll have it paid off one way or another by the end
of January. We'll either bring it from our own funds or the property will have
sold."

Since 1996, Frost and Bolton have run the Inn of the Turquoise Bear at 342 E.
Buena Vista St. in the 8,600-square-foot compound built in the early 20th
century for Witter Bynner, a poet, interpreter of Chinese poetry and Santa Fe
arts maven.

Beginning in 2003, Frost said, the bed and breakfast has suffered from a
downturn in the tourist industry, complicated by his recent bout with cancer. In
2006, they stopped paying the property taxes on the property valued at $1.05
million and put the property on the market in 2006 for $3.3 million. Last year,
they dropped the price to $2.45 million.

Santa Fe County's single largest delinquent property-tax bill belongs to
Northern Rio Grande Sportsman's Club, a nonprofit that has run a shooting range
in La Puebla since the 1960s.

Many of the delinquent taxpayers on the county list could not be tracked down or
did not respond to messages.

For example, Morrow Investments was second on the list for six years of
delinquent taxes at 333 E. Palace Ave., a house just across from La Posada,
valued at $1.69 million. J.D. Morrow, an architect and artist who lives and
works there, did not respond to a message.

Kaye E. Sandford, who is fourth on the list, also was unavailable for comment.
She has had a number of addresses in Santa Fe, Lamy and Galisteo over the past
decade, and it's not clear where the property is located on which she owes
taxes, but in 2004 she owned the Vista Clara Ranch Resort and Spa in Galisteo.
Online court records indicate she was sued for foreclosure by Los Alamos
National Bank in 2010 before the cases were suspended due to a filing for
bankruptcy.

Aspen Blue Sky Holdings, which has the seventh largest bill, is not listed in
corporation records. However, they list both Aspen Holdings (Dirk and Liz
Stronck of Santa Fe are the organizers) and Blue Sky Holdings (Justin Tallman of
Española is the organizer). But it is not clear from public records where its
property is.

JDM LLC, a company connected to developer Steve Duran, holds the eighth largest
bill for a tract of land once slated for development near the corner of Rufina
Street and South Meadows Road. Duran did not return a message seeking comment.

Tesuque Partners, which has the ninth largest bill, owns the Tesuque Village
Market. But state corporation records do not list any officers of the firm,
which has an address on Gonzales Road in Santa Fe.

RainbowVision LLC has the 10th largest delinquent bill. The retirement complex
marketed to same-sex couples, with 121 independent-living units and 25
assisted-living units on 13 acres of land at 500 Rodeo Road, filed for Chapter
11 bankruptcy in June 2011.

This article has been amended to reflect the follow correction:

Correction: Dec. 4, 2013

The first name of Ralph Bolton was incorrect in earlier versions of this story.

                             205 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           December 26, 2013 Thursday

Sinnott: Garbage-bill delinquents could see their names posted on city website

BYLINE: Kevin Flowers, Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 660 words


Dec. 26--The city of Erie is considering a different approach toward trying to
collect more than $2 million in delinquent garbage fees -- listing the names of
those who haven't paid on the Internet.

Mayor Joe Sinnott said that adding a database to the city's website,
www.erie.pa.us -- which would include the names of people delinquent on their
garbage bills and the amounts they owe -- "is one thing we have talked about
doing" in 2014.

City Council President Jim Winarski said he supports the move.

The approach is similar to one the city of Scranton took earlier this year, when
it created a searchable online database of past-due garbage bill accounts.

That city is trying to collect nearly $8 million in overdue garbage bills.

"My thought is that it would include those who get behind by a year or more,"
Sinnott said. "Those are the most seriously delinquent people. It's not the
people who miss a payment and quickly catch up."

Sinnott's proposed $69.7 million city budget for 2014, approved by Erie City
Council on Dec. 18, included increases in city residents' garbage and sewer
fees. The fee hikes meant $3.1 million in new money for the spending plan.

The garbage fee increase means that the average city resident will see garbage
fees rise from an average of $48 every three months, or $192 per year, to $55
every quarter, or $220 per year, said Paul Lichtenwalter, the city's finance
director.

Many city residents, though, have expressed outrage that the garbage fees were
increased at a time when hundreds of customers refuse to pay their bills. In
some cases, the delinquent bills exceed $10,000, city officials have said.

"I think it would have some value," Sinnott said of the database. "It's hard to
determine the magnitude of that value until we do it."

Scranton officials could not be reached for comment about the online database,
launched in August. But within a week of that database being launched, Scranton
officials received roughly $40,000 in overdue garbage payments, the Scranton
Times-Tribune reported.

Sinnott said he will discuss the issue with officials from the city's finance
and information technology departments in the new year. The city will also talk
with Erie Water Works officials about the situation, since the utility collects
garbage fees from residents on the city's behalf.

Sinnott said the situation, which the city has wrestled with for years, does not
come with easy solutions.

Placing a municipal lien on the property of someone who hasn't paid their
garbage bill -- which the city does in many cases -- is "one of our only
collection options." And the city cannot refuse to collect a delinquent
customer's trash if the refuse is placed outside because it's a public health
issue, he said.

The online database, Sinnott said, might prompt some people to pay their bills
quickly so that their names either do not appear on the city's website, or can
be removed.

Winarski said he likes the idea. "I'm thinking anything would help," Winarski
said. "Do I think it would solve the problem completely? Probably not. But it's
another option. People don't like their names brought out when they're
delinquent like that."

City Council included what's known as sunset provisions on the garbage fee
increase, meaning it is in place for 2014 only, unless council agrees to an
extension.

The provision was intended to push Sinnott's administration, council and other
city officials to work together to find a solution to the delinquency problem.

"It just isn't fair that you pay, but your neighbor doesn't," Winarski said.
"Some people are just working the system. ... They can get away with it and they
know it. That's the only reason they're doing it. But eventually it's going to
catch up with them."

KEVIN FLOWERS can be reached at 870-1693 or by e-mail. Follow him on Twitter at
twitter.com/ETNflowers.

Pa.) at www.GoErie.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                            June 17, 1993, Thursday

County searches for ways to pursue delinquent taxes

BYLINE: By Actor Cordell STAFF WRITER

SECTION: EXTRA; Section K; Page 5

LENGTH: 430 words


Look for more tax sales on the Fulton County Courthouse steps.

It's one of the steps county tax officials are considering to pursue delinquent
property taxes more aggressively.

Tax Commissioner Sondra R. Burnett said she has even considered buying newspaper
space to list names, addresses and amounts owed, but that idea has been put on
hold.

The county started the year with unpaid property ad valorem taxes totaling $ 7
2.9 million. By May, the figure had been whittled to nearly $ 53 million, with
about $ 20 million in collections and nearly $ 208,000 in adjustments - not bad,
but not good enough, officials say.

Delinquent tax totals have been increasing over the past two years, and laggards
"do need to understand that we are going to collect these taxes," said tax
administrator Thomas G. Biggers.

Sales at the courthouse - the last resort - take place 10 times a year, usually
on the first Tuesday of the month at 10 a.m.

"We would like to have more bidders show up," said Mr. Biggers, who sees greater
public awareness and an increase in the frequency of sales as potential
solutions for the county.

A Fulton program called TACT - Targeted Ad Valorem Collection Technique - now
starts with a phone call to a delinquent taxpayer, followed by four letters,
with urgency increasing each time. The last letter says the tax commissioner's
office is getting ready to put the property up for sale.

There's no such thing as a delinquent taxpayer profile, said Ms. Burnett. They
run the socio-economic gamut.

"The most interesting thing is that when they come in, they want to negotiate on
paying interest or penalty," said Ms. Burnett. "No matter how unique their
individual story may be, taxes are not negotiable," she said. "Interest is 1
percent a month. If we don't collect the year the tax becomes delinquent, the
likelihood becomes slimmer and slimmer."

Cecilia Williams, delinquent tax administrator, said she has "four people out in
county cars who are collecting all day long," but she has had no reports of
miscreants running out the back door.

In delinquent tax cases in her south Fulton neighborhood, she personally
delivers bills. Payments sometimes are left in her mailbox or handed to her at
church.

"You have to have some humor somewhere along the line because there's so much
tragedy involved with people losing their business and going bankrupt," said
Mrs. Williams.

Fulton is unique in that no effort can be made to collect a property tax that is
under appeal, and there are many unsettled cases from 1991 and 1992, Mr. Biggers
said.

LOAD-DATE: June 24, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH931750448

administrator, sells property on which taxes have not been paid. Assisting her
are William Durham and Judy Dunn. / ACTOR CORDELL / Staff

                             207 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                    October 1, 1991, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

CHILD SUPPORT CRISIS // RUNAWAY PARENTS // Panel seeks cooperation among states

BYLINE: Mimi Hall

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 1042 words


Ten minutes after Linda Patrick got home from the hospital with her newborn son,
her husband walked out.

What has happened in the 10 years since is a story of desperation being played
out in at least 3 million homes across the nation.

Within four months, Patrick, left alone to care for the baby and her two young
daughters, had to trade in her suburban, middle-class lifestyle for welfare
checks.

And her ex-husband, Lyle Patrick, became one of a growing number of parents who
simply disappear. These parents, 95% of them men, owe $ 5 billion in unpaid
child support each year - leaving a legacy of poverty and pain for 11 million
children and a national crisis that's forcing thousands of families on welfare.

Now the problem, quietly simmering for decades, is getting some attention, from
TV movies to hearings before Congress.

''It's reached a point ... where we can't ignore it any more,'' says Margaret
Haynes, head of the U.S. Interstate Commission on Child Support. The commission
met Monday in Washington to push for national laws to cut through the red tape
that inadvertently protects delinquent parents.

Authorities say 40% of child-support evaders are on the run. Many move from
state to state; some change their names and Social Security numbers. Other
delinquent parents escape paying because of an underfunded, overloaded court
system incapable of processing thousands of new cases every year.

The consequences for the families left behind can be devastating. But the impact
doesn't stop there: ''If you're a taxpayer, you should be concerned because
people who don't receive support ... end up on public assistance,'' says Haynes.

That's what happened to Lyle Patrick's family in Gilbert, Ariz. Ordered in 1982
to pay $ 1,500 a month in child support, the agriculture and forest service
pilot helped initially with the $ 600-a-month rent. The child support never was
paid.

Linda Patrick, who couldn't go back to work because her infant son Travis was
born with medical complications, was forced to do something she never dreamed
of: go on welfare.

''I can't express in words the trauma,'' she says. As for plans for the future:
''You wake up and it's over. It's real scary.''

Since he left in 1982, Lyle Patrick has stayed a step ahead of authorities -
despite a warrant for his arrest and efforts by his ex-wife to make him pay in
court. But Lyle Patrick has ignored the court orders and, most of the time,
stays in hiding. The last time he was heard from was two years ago, when one of
the children got a birthday card postmarked Puerto Rico.

Now, nearly $ 120,000 in arrears, he tops Arizona's list of delinquent parents.
This month, his face will appear on posters across the state as part of a new
''most wanted'' campaign to track down missing parents and make them pay.

If he's not in Arizona, the process gets more complicated - and that's where the
commission hopes to make a difference.

States have differing laws and tactics - ''most wanted'' posters, wage
withholding, publishing names in newspapers, withholding professional licenses -
to find delinquent parents.

''There's no uniformity,'' says Haynes. Once a delinquent has crossed state
lines, ''lawyers and parents are confronted with a nightmare maze of different
laws and procedures.''

And each state is so overwhelmed with its own cases, authorities have little
time to look for parents from other states.

''They flat tell you, 'Don't keep your hopes up. There are so many ... that your
chances are nil,' '' says Linda Patrick.

The commission, appointed by Congress in 1988 to recommend new ways to handle
interstate cases, likely will propose:

- Establishing a national computer network to help states find delinquent
parents and determine their assets.

- Revising federal W-4 tax forms so employers can automatically withhold wages,
starting with the first paycheck, rather than waiting until the parent already
is in arrears.

- Speeding up the system so children with delinquent, out-of-state parents won't
wait years because of paperwork.

Patty Lesefske says it's about time.

For seven years, she's been supporting her two sons without any help from her
ex-husband, who abandoned the Germantown, Md., family in 1984 and moved to
upstate New York.

Lesefske spent two years on welfare before job training to become a data entry
clerk at the National 4-H Council.

But on less than $ 15,000 a year, she can barely support her sons - growing boys
who ''always have their heads in the refrigerator.'' David Lesefske is $ 70,000
in arrears, despite court orders and years of investigative work by Lesefske to
track him down. Lesefske says nothing has been done because Maryland and New
York won't cooperate.

''I'm angry,'' says Lesefske, who testified Monday. ''He left me totally
destitute and he's paid absolutely not one red cent. Women really get the shaft
when they get divorced.''

But it may be the children who lose the most.

Tom Mihalic's father, who disappeared in 1982 and is $ 66,000 behind in his
payments, also will appear on the ''wanted'' posters in Arizona, where
authorities believe he's hiding.

Mihalic, 18, a college freshman who lives at home in West Terre Haute, Ind.,
says he's angry that after a decade, authorities still haven't been able to
track down John Mihalic.

''I have no respect for him,'' Tom Mihalic says.

Since he was 15, Tom has been bagging groceries, mowing lawns and busing tables
- not for ''stereo equipment or a car,'' but for ''school clothes, tires for
mom's car, dog food and clothes for my sister.''

Linda Patrick's daughter, Nichole, also has had to help support her family, and
uses the money she earns babysitting to buy clothes and school supplies.

''It's pretty bad when your 15-year-old has to work to help support the
family,'' Patrick says.

The Patricks' long-term dreams have been put away.

Nichole has always wanted to go to college, but ''she's stopped talking about it
because she knows that it's a dream we may never be able to fulfill.''

But with Congress considering new laws to help find men like her ex- husband,
Linda Patrick says there's hope.

''I will never give up. I feel he has jeopardized my children (and) I just think
my kids deserve a fair share.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CUTLINE: STRUGGLING: Linda Patrick of Gilbert, Ariz., and her children, Nichole,
15; Stacey, 11; and Travis, 9, were forced on public assistance after her
ex-husband disappeared without paying support. CUTLINE: OTHER SIDE: Eric
Anderson of Austin, Texas, has custody of his son Brandon, 7. His ex-wife owes
almost $ 4,000 in child support. CUTLINE: LYLE PATRICK: Arizona's 'most wanted'
owes family almost $ 120,000

                             208 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           February 8, 2017 Wednesday

Bill summary and status of HB 1909 Real property tax; nonjudicial sale of tax
delinquent property.

LENGTH: 398  words

DATELINE: New York



  Richmond: Virginia Lagislative Information System has issued the following
bill summary and status:



 SUMMARY AS PASSED HOUSE: (all summaries)



 Real property tax; nonjudicial sale of tax delinquent property. Permits the
nonjudicial sale of unimproved real property valued at less than $5,000 if taxes
are delinquent for at least three years. The bill also permits the nonjudicial
sale of real property valued at no less than $5,000 but no greater than $20,000
if taxes are delinquent for at least three years, the property is not subject to
a recorded mortgage or deed of trust lien, and the property (i) is unimproved
and measures less than 4,000 square feet; (ii) is unimproved and has been
determined to be unsuitable for building (the bill expands the bases on which
unsuitability may rest); (iii) has a structure on it that has been condemned by
the local building official; (iv) has been declared a nuisance by the locality;
(v) contains a derelict building; or (vi) has been declared to be blighted by
the locality. The bill also modifies current law regarding notice of the sale,
redemption of the property, and application of surplus proceeds.





 Current law permits the nonjudicial sale of unimproved real property valued at
less than $10,000 if taxes are delinquent for at least three years and the
property (a) measures less than 4,000 square feet or (b) has been determined to
be unsuitable for building.







 AMENDMENTS



     House amendments



 HISTORY



     01/10/17  House: Prefiled and ordered printed; offered 01/11/17 17101474D

     01/10/17  House: Referred to Committee on Finance

     01/20/17  House: Assigned Finance sub: Subcommittee #1

     02/01/17  House: Subcommittee recommends reporting with amendments (8-Y
1-N)

     02/01/17  House: Reported from Finance with amendments (19-Y 3-N)

     02/03/17  House: Read first time

     02/06/17  House: Read second time

     02/06/17  House: Committee amendments agreed to

     02/06/17  House: Engrossed by House as amended HB1909E

     02/06/17  House: Printed as engrossed 17101474D-E

     02/07/17  House: Read third time and passed House (82-Y 15-N)

     02/07/17  House: VOTE: PASSAGE (82-Y 15-N)

     02/08/17  Senate: Constitutional reading dispensed

     02/08/17  Senate: Referred to Committee on Finance

                             209 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         Star Beacon (Ashtabula, Ohio)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            September 7, 2007 Friday

County DES cracks down on delinquent utility customers

BYLINE: Doris Cook, Star Beacon, Ashtabula, Ohio

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 368 words


Sep. 7--JEFFERSON -- Ashtabula County commissioners and the county's Department
of Environmental Services are going after 240 delinquent water and sewer system
customers owing nearly $120,000 in past due bills.

Commissioners certified a list of delinquent users Thursday to be sent on to
County Auditor Roger Corlett's office for collection on the 2007 real property
tax list.

DES utilities administrator Vicky Ledford said the total of unpaid water bills
is $35,759.21 including penalties applied. Another $80,264.81 is due the county
from delinquent sewer system customers.

On top of those figures, Ledford said another $979 is due from several
customers, who buy bulk water from the DES. When the county commissioners
purchased the Aqua Ohio water system in 2003, two years of delinquent billings
were certified for collection in 2005, Ledford said.

"We've been taking payments from customers right up to Aug. 31, plus making
telephone calls to get people to pay. Many delinquent customers are tenants, who
leave behind unpaid utility bills. The property owners are liable for paying
these bills," Ledford said.

The certified delinquent water/sewer services bills are due for payment in 2008
along with property taxes on the parcels listed to Corlett's office.

"If we don't go after the delinquencies by certifying the amounts to go on the
tax bills, we would be forced to raise rates. Unlike a private water company,
the county can't just write off the losses," Ledford said.

At the same time, commissioners approved the tap-in fee assessments for four
property owners tying into the Route 45 waterline extension project. These
assessments will be certified to the county auditor to be placed on their real
estate property taxes. A total of $20,700 will be paid by all four owners over
five years.

To see more of the Star Beacon or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.starbeacon.com/. Copyright (c) 2007, Star Beacon, Ashtabula, Ohio
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                             210 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                             El Paso Times (Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              May 27, 2012 Sunday

El Paso County tax assessor-collector Victor Flores denies conflict of interest

BYLINE: Aileen B. Flores, El Paso Times, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 998 words


May 27--A candidate for the El Paso County tax assessor-collector's office has
raised questions about a possible conflict of interest involving incumbent
Victor Flores and the law firm hired to collect delinquent taxes.

Flores denied the allegations and said his opponent is trying to connect him
with corruption in an effort to get elected.

Tax assessor-collector candidate Armando Rodriguez, a member of Canutillo
Independent School District Board of Trustees, said the agreement to have
delinquent taxes of public entities collected by the city's tax office has not
been re-examined in more than 20 years and needs to be investigated to determine
its effectiveness.

Rodriguez is challenging Flores in the Democratic primary.

Rodriguez said a brother of Flores' works for the law firm hired by the city to
collect delinquent taxes. The firm also contributes to Flores' campaign, he
said.

The Austin-based law firm of Linebarger Heard Goggan Blair & Sampson has worked
for the city of El Paso collecting delinquent taxes for almost 30 years.

In 1999, the law firm responded to the complaint that most of the fees earned by
the firm were sent out of town and partnered with local lawyers Hector Delgado,
Alejandro Acosta, Joe Spencer and Carmen Perez, according to El Paso Times
archives.

Since then, Delgado, Acosta, Spencer, Linebarger & Perez have enforced the
collection of delinquent property taxes for 26 taxing entities throughout the
county, including school districts, the county,

the hospital district and El Paso Community College.

"The Austin firm is the one doing the work, but partnered with a group of local
attorneys to lend their names to secure the contract," Rodriguez said.
"Everybody has their hands in there to get the money."

He said there are no records that explain the relationship between the lawyers
involved in the contract, their duties and how much each of them gets paid.

According to the city contract for the collection of delinquent property taxes
with Delgado, Acosta, Spencer, Linebarger, & Perez, the law firm earns 20
percent on the delinquent tax money it collects. The firm collects more than $20
million a year.

Nobody questions a contract that pays more than $4 million to the law firm every
year, Rodriguez said.

"As tax assessor-collector, you have the authority to question the delinquent
tax contract," he said.

Rodriguez said his opponent has not questioned the contract because his brother,
David Flores, is the manager of Delgado, Acosta, Spencer, Linebarger & Perez.

"There is a direct conflict of interest under Flores' direct duties as county
tax assessor-collector to question the delinquent tax firm to make sure the work
has been done efficiently," he said.

According to Victor Flores' campaign reports, Perez has contributed $400,
Delgado and Acosta $500, Spencer $200 and Linebarger Heard Goggan Blair &
Sampson $500 to his campaign.

"The city has had that contract for more than 10 years. We are not able to see
if there is somebody else that can do that job better because the way this
system is set up," Rodriguez said.

Victor Flores said there is no conflict of interest because the county does not
contract with the law firm to collect delinquent taxes. He said the city
contracts with that firm.

Under the agreement, school districts, county, University Medical Center and El
Paso Community College give the city the authority to choose the law firm that
collects those taxes, Victor Flores said.

The contract for the collection of delinquent property taxes states that under
the tax agreement, an advisory committee monitors the performance of the tax
collection procedures.

The committee has unanimously recommended to the city that it keep the Delgado,
Acosta, Spencer, Linebarger & Perez firm as delinquent tax collector, said the
city document.

In 2009, the City Council extended the agreement with Delgado, Acosta, Spencer,
Linebarger & Perez until 2015.

The law firms reports to the city and does monthly reports on the work it has
done, said City Tax Assessor-Collector Juan Sandoval.

Copies of those reports are sent to the city attorney's office, he said.

Sandoval said the firm does "a great job" in collecting delinquent taxes.

Rodriguez tried to find out through an open-records request how much each one of
the attorneys in the law firm gets paid, but the city does not have that
information, Sandoval said. "We are not involved in that. We don't know how they
divide up their money," Sandoval said.

Victor Flores said his brother was working for the law firm long before he was
first elected in 1996.

"My opponent is sitting there trying to make an issue out of something," Victor
Flores said. "I am the last person to have any say-so in the matter."

The County Tax Assessor-Collector's Office abides by the contracts that the
County Commissioners Court decides, he said.

Victor Flores said he does not have any influence on decisions made by the
county commissioners or the City Council.

Victor Flores said Rodriguez should understand the agreement because he is the
vice president of the Canutillo Independent School District Board of Trustees,
which is bound by the same contract the city uses.

"He works under the same contract that the county works under. And if he does
not know it, I feel really bad for Canutillo because he is the vice president,"
Victor Flores said.

Too many governmental bodies are involved in the agreement to allow a conflict
of interest, Victor Flores said. Lawyers for the Canutillo school district
should know exactly how the contract works, he added.

Victor Flores said Rodriguez has launched a negative campaign against him trying
to connect him with corruption to get into office.

Rodriguez has yet to say what he brings to the table if he gets elected, Flores
said.

Aileen B. Flores may be reached at aflores@elpasotimes.com; 546-6362. Follow her
@AileenBFlores.

___ (c)2012 the El Paso Times (El Paso, Texas) Visit the El Paso Times (El Paso,
Texas) at www.elpasotimes.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

of-interest-0527-20120527

JOURNAL-CODE: EY

                             211 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                             National Mortgage News

                                August 22, 1994

Calif. Delinquencies Showing Slight Drop

SECTION: Pg. 21

LENGTH: 439 words

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif.


According to the June 30th quarterly delinquency survey conducted by the
California Mortgage Bankers Association, 93.4% of the commercial real estate
loans serviced by 30 California mortgage banking firms either were current or
only one payment delinquent.

Three months earlier the figure was 93.2%.  It should be noted, however, that
10.8% of the delinquencies, all loans on properties in the Los Angeles area, are
the direct result of the Northridge earthquake.  Were it not for
earthquake-damaged properties, 94.1% of the loans would have been current.

In terms of dollars, $ 1.54 billion of the $ 23.4 billion of loans being
serviced by the California mortgage bankers were two or more payments past due.
Excluding $ 526.3 million of loans in foreclosure, a fraction over $ 1 billion
of the loans were delinquent.  This compares with $ 1.14 billion as of March 31.
Loans delinquent due to the Jan. 17th earthquake totaled $ 166.7 million.

By number, 267 (or 3.2%) of the 8,211 loans included in the survey were two or
more payments past due.  Three months earlier, 3.6% were delinquent.

By type of property, office buildings continue to show the highest delinquency
rate, accounting for 37.5% of the delinquencies.  Apartments are a distant
second place, representing 17.8% of total delinquencies; next are retail
properties, representing 17.3%; followed by warehouse/industrial building loans,
accounting for 17% of the total delinquencies.

R&D buildings account for 2.8%, and hotels/motels and "other" types of buildings
each represent 3.8% of the percentage distribution of delinquencies by property
type.  Again, there were no delinquent mobile home park loans reported.

A year-to-year comparison of the delinquencies by property type shows some
fairly significant changes.

A year ago, office buildings accounted for 52.3% of the delinquencies, this year
they account for the aforementioned 37.5% of total delinquencies.  On the other
hand, industrial/warehouse properties increased from 11.1% to 17% of the
delinquent loan total.  Apartments, likewise, now represent a greater percentage
(17.8%) of the total delinquencies than a year ago (13.1%).

For survey purposes, a loan is considered delinquent if it is two or more
payments past due.  Loans in the process of foreclosure are included, regardless
of the number of payments past due.

Thirty income property mortgage bankers participated in the CMBA survey.  These
companies originate and service loans on apartments, retail, industrial and
other commercial properties for institutional investors such as life insurance
companies and pension funds.

LOAD-DATE: September 01, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1994 National Thrift News, Inc.


                             212 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        Crossville Chronicle (Tennessee)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                              June 22, 2015 Monday

County OKs delinquent tax property sale

BYLINE: Gary Nelson, Crossville Chronicle, Tenn.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 325 words


June 22--The Cumberland County Commission approved the sale of one delinquent
tax property in Fairfield Glade during Monday night's monthly meeting.

Resolution 06-2015-2 accepts the offer of $500 for a parcel of property at 126
Norcross Rd. from Valerie Scrivener.

Last month an offer of $100 for the parcel was presented to the county through
the delinquent tax committee from Scrivener.

The committee turned down the offer last month.

John Kinnunen, 9th District commissioner, had said the property is worth
considerably more and was appraised for $7,500.

The lot is in the St. George area and has water and sewer improvements.

This month Scrivener increased her offer to $500 and the delinquent tax
committee approved the offer.

At the delinquent tax committee meeting earlier in the day, Cumberland County
Mayor Kenneth Carey Jr. said the bidder would not offer more than $500. Bids are
submitted through the mayor's office.

When delinquent tax properties are sold by the county they are advertised in the
newspaper and bids are accepted for the parcel.

The county attempts to get 10 percent of the properties value, or the amount of
delinquent tax and fees owed against the property.

As of last month, $638.20 was owed against the property.

The county currently has several properties in delinquent tax status and
additional sales are forthcoming.

The delinquent tax committee and county commission must approve the sale of the
property.

The resolution was unanimously approved after a motion was made by Dave Hassler,
3rd District commissioner.

Hassler's motion was supported by Tom Isham, 2nd District commissioner.

Commissioners Terry Carter, 6th District; and John Kinnunen, 9th District, did
not attend the meeting.

Gary Nelson may be reached at gnelson@crossville-chronicle.com

Chronicle (Crossville, Tenn.) at crossville-chronicle.com/ Distributed by
Tribune Content Agency, LLC.

                               MortgageDaily.com

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                            February 9, 2015 Monday

BRIEF: MGIC Delinquent Inventory Up 1st Time Since 2011

BYLINE: Mortgage Daily

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 178 words


Feb. 09--For the first time in more than three years, delinquency at MGIC
Guaranty Insurance Corp. has worsened. New business was off too.

The Milwaukee-based company reported in its monthly operational summary that it
wrote $2.9 billion in new insurance during January.

Activity slowed from the previous month, when business volume was $3.3 billion.

But the mortgage insurer managed to improve on January 2014, when it wrote just
$1.7 billion in new policies.

MGIC said its delinquent inventory ended last month at 80,144 months, increasing
from 79,901 in December.

It was the first increase since July 2011, when the distressed inventory was
185,093.

As of Jan. 1, 2014, there were 102,351 loans in the delinquent inventory.

Using an estimated 971,381 policies in force as of Jan. 31, the estimated
delinquency rate was a hair over 8.25 percent, up from a hair under 8.25 percent
in December.

The estimated delinquency rate was 10.70 percent as of Jan. 31, 2014.

                             214 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           September 4, 2014 Thursday

Pennylvania: Commonwealth Saves More Than $1 Million through Payment Offset
Program

LENGTH: 296  words

DATELINE: Harrisburg


The Keystone State, The State of Pennsylvania issue the following news release:

Budget Secretary Charles B. Zogby today announced that the commonwealth has
saved more than $1 million by offsetting payments to vendors and business
partners with debts more than 90 days delinquent to the commonwealth.

The Commonwealth Offset Program (COP) began in July 2013 to offset any payment
to delinquent business partners by the amount they may owe the commonwealth for
license fees, assessments or delinquent loans last year.

"As budgets continue to get tighter, it is important for the commonwealth to be
good stewards of public funds," Zogby said. "Each year, the commonwealth used to
pay millions of dollars to vendors that were delinquent on debts owed back to
it.  With the offset program, we keep valuable funds available for commonwealth
programs and services."

The COP uses the current Contractor Responsibility Program to identify vendors
who are set to receive commonwealth payment, yet are 90 days or more delinquent
on non-tax debts.  Under the COP, the debt owed to the commonwealth is deducted
from the vendor payment.  If the debt exceeds the payment, future payments would
be offset by the corresponding amount.

The commonwealth urges its business partners to pay any delinquent debts to
avoid having any future payments delayed or offset.

The COP was developed as part of the Governor's Innovation Initiative.  Since
its inception the Governor's Innovation Office has worked with state agencies on
efforts to reduce costs, increase efficiency and improve services.  These
initiatives have resulted in more than $690 million in savings and productivity
gains.

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: September 5, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                                US Official News

                           September 2, 2014 Tuesday

Pennsylvania: Commonwealth Saves More Than $1 Million through Payment Offset
Program

LENGTH: 296  words

DATELINE: Harrisburg


The Keystone State, The State of Pennsylvania issue the following news release:

Budget Secretary Charles B. Zogby today announced that the commonwealth has
saved more than $1 million by offsetting payments to vendors and business
partners with debts more than 90 days delinquent to the commonwealth.

The Commonwealth Offset Program (COP) began in July 2013 to offset any payment
to delinquent business partners by the amount they may owe the commonwealth for
license fees, assessments or delinquent loans last year.

"As budgets continue to get tighter, it is important for the commonwealth to be
good stewards of public funds," Zogby said. "Each year, the commonwealth used to
pay millions of dollars to vendors that were delinquent on debts owed back to
it.  With the offset program, we keep valuable funds available for commonwealth
programs and services."

The COP uses the current Contractor Responsibility Program to identify vendors
who are set to receive commonwealth payment, yet are 90 days or more delinquent
on non-tax debts.  Under the COP, the debt owed to the commonwealth is deducted
