                             216 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                             August 5, 2016 Friday

Texas: Pennsylvania Tax Changes and Tax Amnesty Program

LENGTH: 2361  words

DATELINE: New York



 Austin: JD Supra Business Advisor, The State of Texas has issued the following
news release:



   As part of the budget package, the Pennsylvania General Assembly made many
significant changes to various Pennsylvania tax laws and the unclaimed property
law (including a tax amnesty program) that are estimated to generate $752
million of additional revenue for the Commonwealth.





 Tax Amnesty Program



 The new law requires the Department of Revenue to administer a 60-day tax
amnesty program ending no later than June 30, 2017. Amnesty will be available
only to taxpayers who did not participate in the Commonwealth's 2010 tax amnesty
program and will not be available to taxpayers who are on notice that they are
the subject of a criminal investigation or have been named a defendant in a
criminal complaint alleging a violation of tax laws. The program will apply to
all taxes administered by the Department--including sales tax collection and
employment tax withholding obligations--for which a taxpayer was delinquent as
of December 31, 2015.



 Eligible taxpayers may participate in the program by filing a tax amnesty
return, paying the tax and 50 percent of the interest, and filing completed new
and/or amended returns for each year of delinquency. In exchange, the Department
will waive 50 percent of the interest and all of the penalties that otherwise
would be imposed on the delinquent taxes. Additionally, eligible taxpayers with
"unknown" tax liabilities--i.e., liabilities for which the taxpayer has not been
contacted by the Department regarding unfiled returns and which are not
currently under audit--will not be liable for any delinquent taxes of the same
type that were due before January 1, 2011. If a taxpayer seeks to participate in
the program for a liability that is subject to a deferred payment plan, as a
condition for amnesty, the taxpayer must agree to pay the full tax amount by the
end of the amnesty period.



 Participation in the amnesty program is contingent on continued compliance with
Pennsylvania tax obligations. Specifically, if, within two years from the end
date of the program, unless a valid appeal is pending, a taxpayer becomes
delinquent for three consecutive periods for semi-monthly, monthly, quarterly,
or other periodic tax liabilities, or becomes eight months or more delinquent
for filing or paying any annual tax liabilities, the Department can collect all
penalties and interest waived pursuant to the amnesty program. Following an
unsuccessful appeal, a taxpayer must pay the liabilities within applicable time
limits to avoid becoming delinquent and liable for the waived penalties and
interest. As was true of the 2010 amnesty program, participation in the program
will waive any right to participate in any future amnesty program.



 The Department is tasked with promulgating guidelines detailing the program and
procedures by September 11, 2016.



 Sales and Use Tax Changes



 The new law subjects digital delivery (including streaming) of games, music,
movies, and apps, among other digital products, to sales and use tax effective
August 1, 2016, giving vendors very little time to prepare. Specially, the new
law provides that "tangible personal property" subject to tax includes "video;
photographs; books; any otherwise taxable printed matter; applications, commonly
known as apps; games; music; any other audio, including satellite radio service;
canned software, notwithstanding the function performed; or any other tangible
personal property electronically delivered, streamed, or accessed."



 Notably, in addition to subjecting digital products to tax and expressly adding
canned software to the list of taxable products (which software was subject to
tax by virtue of a 2010 Pennsylvania Supreme Court decision, Dechert LLP v.
Commonwealth), the new law provides that updates, maintenance and support of
these digital products are subject to tax. Although it was not expressly part of
the Dechert holding, the Court indicated that maintenance and support for canned
software likely were exempt from tax.



 Other sales and use tax changes include:



     A reduction in the vendor discount for vendors who timely report and pay
tax. Prior to the new law, all vendors who reported and paid timely were
entitled to a 1 percent discount. Effective for sales tax returns due after
August 1, 2016, the new law caps the discount at the lesser of 1 percent or $25
per return for monthly filers, $75 per return for quarterly filers, and $150 per
return for semi-annual filers, all capped at $300 annually. It is possible that
some vendors may argue that this severely reduced cap violates the Uniformity
Clause of the Pennsylvania Constitution;

     The addition of criminal penalties for vendors who use "zappers" or
devices/software programs that suppress sales and use tax with the intent to
evade tax; and

     The addition of exclusions from sales and use tax for returnable corrugated
boxes used to deliver snack foods, services related to the setup, teardown, or
maintenance of certain tangible personal property at the Pennsylvania Convention
Center in Philadelphia or at a convention center or public auditorium
established under the Second Class County Code (i.e., the David L. Lawrence
Convention Center in Pittsburgh), or the County Code (e.g., the Lancaster County
Convention Center and the Bayfront Convention Center in Erie), and property and
services used directly in timbering operations.



 Corporate Net Income Tax Changes



 Before the new law, Pennsylvania corporate net income tax (CNIT) law did not
provide for amended returns. By regulation, taxpayers could file amended returns
but there was no requirement that the Department process such returns.
Additionally, confusion and missed deadlines arose when taxpayers filed amended
returns claiming refunds rather than filing formal refund claims with the Board
of Appeals. The new law attempts to address these issues by requiring the
Department to act on amended returns; providing that if there is no action by
the Department within one year from filing (a period that can be extended to two
years with mutual consent), the return is deemed accepted; and allowing a
taxpayer to appeal to the Board of Appeals if it disagrees with the Department's
action on an amended return. However, it is important to note when considering
whether to file an amended return that, when a taxpayer files an amended return,
the statute of limitations for the Department to assess tax with respect to the
entire return (not just the item or items causing the taxpayer to file an
amended return) is extended to the later of one year from the date of the filing
of the amended report, or three years from the filing of the original return.
Thus, if an amended return is filed near the end of the limitations period for
the Department to assess CNIT, an amended return could give the Department a
substantial amount of additional time to review the entire tax year and assess
additional CNIT. As under prior law, the taxpayer may consent to an additional
extension of the statute.



 Importantly, an amended return may not be filed:



     in lieu of a timely appeal of an assessment "except if a taxpayer would be
entitled to an adjustment of the taxpayer's tax liability as defined by the
regulations of the department;"

     if the issue giving rise to the amendment has been addressed on its merits
by an administrative tribunal or court;

     or if the amended return "takes a position that is contrary to law or
published department policy."



 The last exception is particularly troubling because it leaves open the
possibility that the Department could argue that an amended return is contrary
to its policy and therefore not subject to the requirement that the Department
act within one year. Therefore, taxpayers still should consider filing refund
petitions with the Board of Appeals rather than amended returns.



 The new law also clarifies CNIT return filing dates by providing that all CNIT
returns are due 30 days after the federal return is due (or would be due if the
corporation is not required to file a federal return). Prior to this change, the
statute provided that all returns were due on April 15 unless there was a valid
federal extension. This change addresses a federal change effective for the 2016
tax year establishing April 15 (instead of March 15) as the due date for federal
income tax returns filed by calendar year corporate taxpayers, and ensures
consistent treatment for non-calendar year taxpayers that do not file a federal
extension.



 Changes to Unclaimed Property Law



 Under the new law, subject to certain conditions, the Treasurer can require
unredeemed and unclaimed U.S. Savings Bonds issued to Pennsylvania residents to
be escheated to the Commonwealth if the bonds are more than three years beyond
the date of final maturity and the owner has not indicated an interest in such
bond.



 Additionally, the new law provides new details regarding escheatment of
property held by a fiduciary or agent-in-fact, including 401(k) accounts and
individual retirement accounts (IRAs). Such property now is presumed abandoned
and unclaimed three years after the holder has lost contact with the owner (as
now defined in great detail in the unclaimed property law) unless the owner has,
within that period increased or decreased the principal amount in the account,
accepted a distribution or other payment of principal or income; or otherwise
indicated an interest in the property or in other property of the owner in the
custody of the holder.



 Finally, the new law provides detailed instructions to holders for determining
the specific date on which a holder has "lost contact" with a property owner for
purposes of the unclaimed property law and establishes new, very detailed,
notification requirements for the holder of the property to send to the owner
prior to reporting the property to the Commonwealth as unclaimed.



 Bank Shares Tax



     The new law raises the bank shares tax rate to 0.95 percent from 0.89
percent effective January 1, 2017;

     Effective for years beginning after December 31, 2016, the new law
eliminates the $100,000 gross receipts threshold in the statutory definition of
"doing business in this Commonwealth;"

     The new law allows a phased-in exemption from the tax base for subsidiaries
formed under the federal Edge Act to conduct international business;

     The bank shares tax apportionment rules allow banks to apportion receipts
from investments and trading using either Method 1 (the fraction of other
receipts that are sourced to Pennsylvania) or Method 2 (the fraction of
investment and trading assets that are in Pennsylvania). The new law reverses a
published position of the Department and makes clear that all banks--even those
with receipts from both investment and trading assets--may elect to use Method
1; and

     The new law also changes the bank shares tax base by clarifying that the
goodwill deduction applies to both the bank shares tax base and the deduction
for U.S. obligations, and changing the definition of "total receipts" used in an
institutions apportionment denominator to include all receipts reported on the
bank's call sheet; previously, the factor was calculated on a separate company
basis.



 New Credit/Incentive Programs and Changes to Existing Programs



 The new law creates several new tax credit programs (to be administered by the
Department of Community and Economic Development) beginning July 1, 2017:
Manufacturing Tax Credit; Computer Data Center Equipment Incentive Program,
Rural Jobs and Investment Tax Credit; Concert and Rehearsal Tour Tax Credit;
Video Game Production Tax Credit; Coal Refuse Energy and Reclamation Tax Credit;
Waterfront Development Tax Credit; and Mixed Use Tax Credit.



 In addition to the new credits, the new law:



     retroactively extends the Research and Development Tax Credit, which had
expired on December 31, 2015;

     re-establishes the Brewer's Tax Credit effective June 30, 2017;

     expands the Tax Credit for New Jobs to provide enhanced benefits when a
taxpayer hires a veteran; and

     increases the Film Tax Credit cap and provides that post-production
expenses can qualify as qualifying expenditures for purposes of determining the
credit amount.



 The new law also makes changes to several of the special economic development
zone programs. Of note, the new law authorizes the creation of 12 additional
Keystone Opportunity Expansion Zones. It provides that tax benefits to parcels
within certain existing Keystone Opportunity Zones, Keystone Opportunity
Expansion Zones, or Keystone Opportunity Innovation Zones can be extended for an
additional 10 years if (among other requirements) the extension application
reflects a commitment to create at least 350 new jobs in Pennsylvania and to
make a capital investment in Pennsylvania of at least $35 million within three
years of receiving the extension.



 Other Notable Changes



     Effective 60 days after the Department issues notices clarifying the
procedures for collection, the new law expands the tax on tobacco products by
increasing the tax on cigarettes to $2.60 per pack (an increase of $1), imposing
a 40 percent tax on the wholesale price of electronic cigarettes, and imposing a
55-cent tax on several other types of tobacco products.

     Retroactive to January 1, 2016, the new law provides that Pennsylvania
Lottery winnings are subject to personal income tax and personal income tax
withholding at the time of payment.

     Effective September 11, 2016, the new law creates new exclusions from
realty transfer tax for:

         Transfers of certain agricultural conservation easements;

         Transfers under the "Conservation and Preservation Easements Act;"

         Transfers of certain perpetual easements to federal, state, or local
governments or to conservancies;

         Transfers to veterans' organizations; and

         Transfers to land banks.

     Effective August 1, 2016, the Table Games Tax rate is increased from 12
percent to 14 percent.



 In case of any query regarding this article or other content please contact:
editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                     News-Journal (Daytona Beach, Florida)

                              May 8, 2010 Saturday
                                 Final Edition

Property-tax certificates listing available Monday

BYLINE: AUDREY PARENTE, AUDREY PARENTE - STAFF WRITER

SECTION: SECTION A; Pg. 11A

LENGTH: 389  words


Delinquent Volusia County real-estate property- tax certificates totaling nearly
$52 million, about 15 percent lower than last year, will be listed at
bidvolusia.com beginning Monday for a sale to take place May 29.

The tax certificate sale is not a sale of land, but a sale of liens against
25,985 properties for the amount of delinquent real- estate taxes.

Information on the delinquent properties is available at the property
appraiser's website, volusia.org/property where interested buyers can look up a
parcel to find its exact location, Revenue Director Peggy Flomerfelt said.

Certificate buyers bid the lowest interest rate charged against the total
delinquency, including interest and fees, a $3 parcel advertisement fee for the
property owners. The successful bidder pays for the certificate by electronic
funds transfer.

To avoid the auction, delinquent payments plus the interest and fees, must be
made to one of four county locations not later than 5 p.m. May 28. The locations
are: 123 W. Indiana Ave., Room 103, DeLand; 250 N. Beach St., Daytona Beach; 111
Canal St., New Smyrna Beach; and 2744 Enterprise Road, Orange City.

The tax collector's office also publishes a list of delinquent tangible-property
taxes, including such items as business assets, mobile-home attachments, rental
condo fixtures and other items. This year, 665 delinquent tangibles total nearly
$1.7 million. If payments of tangible-property taxes are not made by May 31,
warrants are issued and later ratified.

Once warrants are ratified, the tax collector has the right to levy fines and
seize tangible property to sell for taxes.

Published lists are included with The Volusia/Flagler Review at the following
locations:

Daytona Beach: 901 Sixth St.; Publix, 1500 Beville Rd.

Ormond Beach: Post Office, 210 Williamson Blvd.

DeLand: Corner of N. Woodland and W. Rich Ave.; Potato Patch Restaurant, 635 S.
Woodland Blvd.

Orange City: Post Office, 260 Industrial Dr.

Deltona: Post Office, 944 Deltona Blvd.

New Smyrna Beach: Courthouse, 124 Riverside Dr.; Corner of Rush St. and Canal
St.; Manny's Pizza, 3318 S. Atlantic Ave.

Edgewater: Post Office, 400 S. Ridgewood Ave.

Flagler: Palm Coast Library, West Palm Coast Parkway; Radio Shack, West Palm
Coast Parkway; Winn-Dixie, S.R. 100; Food Lion, S.R. 100; Publix, S.R. 100;
Flagler Pier North/South, A1A Flagler Beach

                             218 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           Pittsburgh Tribune Review

                           November 17, 2007 Saturday

23 area businesses ID'd as delinquent on taxes

BYLINE: Tony LaRussa

LENGTH: 257 words


Nearly two dozen local companies are among the 213 Pennsylvania businesses
identified as being delinquent in paying state taxes.

The 23 Western Pennsylvania companies that made the delinquency list owe about
$476,260 to the Department of Revenue. Statewide, companies owe $6.4 million in
back taxes.

"These businesses collected millions of dollars in taxes from their customers
and employees and failed to send the money to the state," said Tom Wolf, state
revenue secretary. The businesses publicly identified by the state owe sales
tax, employer withholding taxes or both.

Since the list was initiated in April 2006, 286 of the 465 businesses, or 60
percent, that have appeared on the tax delinquent list have been removed from
the Web site because they either paid their taxes in full, committed to a
deferred payment plan or went out of business, revenue department officials
said.

Before being placed on the list, businesses are contacted by the state and given
a final chance to make payment arrangements.

The prospect of appearing on the list has helped convince delinquent taxpayers
to pay $37 million and enter into deferred payment plans for an additional $18.8
million in unpaid taxes, officials said.

Other states have found that the threat of public exposure can be a successful
tax collection tool. At least 21 other states, including Maryland, New Jersey
and Virginia, use Internet lists to help collect unpaid taxes.

Delinquent taxpayers who appear on the list can contact the revenue department
to make payment arrangements.

                        Journal-World (Lawrence, Kansas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune News Service

                           August 16, 2006 Wednesday

Tax delinquency down from one year ago

BYLINE: Mike Belt, Journal-World, Lawrence, Kan.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 415 words


Aug. 16--Douglas Countians seem to be doing a better job of paying their
property taxes this year.

While the number of land parcels that were taxed increased in 2005, the number
currently showing delinquent taxes has dropped, according to the Douglas County
Treasurer's Office.

"We have more parcels, fewer delinquencies," Treasurer Paula Gilchrist said.

A list of delinquent properties and their owners published by the county in
Tuesday's Journal-World showed that as of Aug. 1, there were 969 parcels
delinquent. That was down from 1,316 delinquent parcels on July 27 when an early
list was prepared, Gilchrist said.

A year ago at this time, there initially were 1,370 delinquent parcels based on
2004 property tax notices. Total properties taxed were 37,193.

Taxes still owed this year on 2005 property delinquencies amount to almost $2
million. There were a total of 38,383 parcels taxed in 2005, Gilchrist said.

If taxes plus interest and fees are not paid by Sept. 5, the county will put a
tax lien on the property. That prevents the owner from selling it without paying
the taxes first.

The wording of the state statute that appears with the published tax list causes
confusion among some land owners, said Stacy Kurtz, director of taxation and
accounting in the treasurer's office.

"We have a lot of people who call in and think we are selling these
(properties), and that is not what is happening," she said.

Delinquent properties can't be auctioned by the county until they have been
delinquent for at least two years and 10 months, Kurtz said. A tax sale will be
scheduled sometime this year for nine properties that are delinquent from 2000
and 2001, Gilchrist said.

Property tax notices are mailed to owners in November. No second notice is
mailed. If at least the first half of the taxes are not paid by Dec. 20,
interest will start accruing. By May 10, the entire tax should be paid.

Owners who are delinquent should get a notice before the tax list is published,
as long as the treasurer's office has the correct address.

Owners sometimes miss the notices as well as previous tax notices if they have
moved or switched mortgage companies because of refinancing, Gilchrist said.

to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                          The Tampa Tribune (Florida)

                            March 17, 2011 Thursday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Belden, Crist face off over delinquent tax collections

BYLINE: MIKE SALINERO, The Tampa Tribune

SECTION: METRO; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 294 words


BY MIKE SALINERO

The Tampa Tribune

TAMPA Hillsborough County Tax Collector Doug Belden on Wednesday angrily
disputed comments by County Commissioner Victor Crist that suggested Belden
might need help from a private firm to collect delinquent tangible taxes, such
as on farm equipment and mobile home registrations.

Belden, taking the podium at Wednesday morning's commission meeting, told Crist
the commissioner should have exercised "professional courtesy" by discussing his
concerns about delinquent taxes with the tax collector privately. Belden said
his office writes off 2 percent to 3 percent of delinquent intangible taxes a
year.

"I will take that write-off and compare it to any collection statewide,
nationwide or whatever," Belden said.

He said law firms out of Texas have been lobbying legislatures in multiple
states to allow them to offer their services to county governments that need
help collecting taxes. He said they charge the delinquent taxpayers fees up to
40 percent over the amount of tax due.

Crist ended up apologizing to Belden, but did not say he would withdraw his
proposal. At one point, Crist held up his hand, spreading his thumb and a finger
about 2 inches apart, to illustrate a stack of delinquent intangible tax
collections he had seen.

"Again, as a county commissioner, I am free to discuss at the dais what I
believe we need to discuss at any time," said Crist, a former state legislator
who was elected to the commission in November. "I don't need to clear it with
anybody."

Belden said the commission has always had the power to hire outside collection
firms, but that he doesn't need one.

                            Dayton Daily News (Ohio)

                              May 25, 2009 Monday

Tug-of-war over funds divides commissioners, elected officials

BYLINE: By Lynn Hulsey Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. A8

LENGTH: 1078 words


DAYTON - When Montgomery County Administrator Deborah Feldman surveys the
county's dismal financial picture, she can't help but notice the $9.4 million
sitting in county treasurer and prosecutor coffers.

That money, accumulated from delinquent property tax payments, can only be used
to collect additional late taxes. But neither office can get it all spent. So it
just sits there collecting interest, even as county commissioners dip into
reserves and require a second round of across-the-board budget cuts to offset
this year's projected $7.6 million General Fund shortfall.

The county's approximately $7.4 million in across-theboard-cuts - first in
December and now in progress for mid-year - have led to layoffs in the sheriff's
office and clerk of courts, the planned closure of Memorial Hall and elimination
of parks and recreation programs. More layoffs are likely.

State law keeps Feldman from tapping the $9.4 million held by the treasurer and
prosecutor. The law allows those offices to keep and divide evenly 5 percent of
delinquent tax collections. Had the taxes been paid on time the money would have
gone to schools, the human services levy, Sinclair Community College, the Dayton
Metro Library and other property tax recipients.

33 special funds

The delinquent tax funds are just two of 33 special purpose funds totaling $19.4
million controlled by elected officials other than Montgomery County
Commissioners.

County Prosecutor Mathias H. Heck Jr. has the largest pot of special fund money,
with nearly $5.8 million accumulated in his delinquent tax fund. County
Treasurer Carolyn Rice has the second largest: $3.6 million in her delinquent
tax fund. Money coming into those funds - about $935,000 for each office last
year - far exceeds the amount that each office spends collecting delinquent
taxes.

"It appears that we are consistently collecting more than has been needed to
perform the function," Feldman said. "(That) fund has had me concerned for a
very long time."

Rice and Heck defend the funds, saying they are using the money to aggressively
seek past due taxes. This year Rice plans to spend $783,440 of the money and
Heck will spend about $500,000. Both say they may need the balances in the
future, particularly if the state loosens the rules to allow them to spend the
money more broadly.

Rice would like to use the money to help with the home foreclosure crisis, or as
seed money for a landbanking program to redevelop foreclosed property. She
supports changing state law to permit that.

Other area counties also have millions accumulating in dozens of special purpose
funds. Warren County has about $2.7 million. Greene has approximately $1.8
million and Miami has about $2 million.

Many of the funds are controlled by the courts and supported through fees
charged to users, typically to pay for computers and equipment or legal
research. The sheriff's office has funds from seized assets in drug cases, and
also uses license fees to administer concealed carry laws. Several elected
officials have special project funds, such as the nearly $500,000 Montgomery
County Court Administrative Judge James Manning said he's saving in case the
Ohio Legislature allows the court to convert to full-time operations.

"I have plans for it," Manning said. "It would be frustrating if the county came
around and grabbed money we've been saving."

Legislation sought

The County Commissioners' Association of Ohio wants the Legislature to give
commissioners access to elected officials' special funds during times of fiscal
stress. The proposal would require public hearings and prohibit commissioners
from draining the funds.

"We are trying to be introspective at the county level as to how we can become
more efficient and maximize taxpayer dollars and resources," said Cheryl Subler,
managing director of policy for the CCAO.

Area elected officials and statewide associations representing elected officials
are lining up in opposition to the proposal, although many want additional
flexibility for the officials who now control the funds.

"I think its completely wrong," said Montgomery County Recorder Willis
Blackshear. "It limits our ability to do our job."

Plans for funds

Greene County Sheriff Eugene Fischer said he's building up his $485,000
seized-asset fund for computer systems in deputies' cars. He said he understands
times are tight, and he's lost sleep over having to lay off 10 corrections
employees. But he said commissioners should leave his special funds alone.

"It's just like getting kicked when you're down," Fischer said. "And you're
getting kicked by fellow elected officials that are supposed to be doing what's
best for the entire county."

But Warren County Commissioner Pat South said counties need flexibility during
times of fiscal crisis.

"I think that what the CCAO is proposing is good, but it certainly does need to
have a definition as to what constitutes a financial emergency due to an
economic condition, as opposed to a self-imposed financial emergency because of
poor management," South said.

Montgomery County Commission President Dan Foley and Feldman also support the
idea, which has yet to gain traction in the Legislature.

Feldman normally opposes using one-time money to pay for operations, but she
said having access to the special funds could help the county weather the
current crisis until the economy recovers.

"Why not use that money right now to help us maintain basic services," Feldman
said.

Greene County Administrator Howard Poston said any change in the law would be
contentious, and Miami County Commission President John O'Brien is concerned
about the impact on relations between commissioners and elected officials.

Several area state legislators say they see some merit in at least studying the
idea of loosening restrictions on the funds. But the legislators, who include
Sen. Jon Husted, R-Kettering; Sen. Fred Strahorn, D-Dayton; Rep. Peggy Lehner,
R-Kettering; and Rep. Clayton Luckie, D-Dayton, all expressed reluctance to give
commissioners free hand with the money.

Montgomery County Probate Judge Alice McCollum said she can see why
budget-conscious county commissioners may look hungrily at the $449,000 she is
saving up for computer equipment and software.

"I understand their concern because they think you are sitting on a pile of
money that we're not using," McCollum said. "(But) it is something that I use
and something that I need."

Contact this reporter at (937) 225-7455 or lhulsey @DaytonDailyNews.com.

LOAD-DATE: May 27, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                     Copyright 2009 Dayton Newspapers, Inc.

                       The Day (New London, Connecticut)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                             March 10, 2015 Tuesday

Stonington residents warned of mortgage-tax scam

BYLINE: Joe Wojtas, The Day, New London, Conn.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 402 words


March 10--STONINGTON -- Tax Collector Linda Camelio warned residents Tuesday of
an apparent scam in which those who have mortgages are told to forward a copy of
their canceled check to the company to prove they have paid their taxes.

The instructions have come on the letterhead of banks such as Chase, Bank of
America and the Home Equity Service Center.

Camelio said over the past two days she has received several phone calls from
taxpayers who said they've received a letter from their mortgage company stating
that they have delinquent taxes and in order to prove they have paid, the
taxpayer must send them a copy of the front and back of their canceled checks.

Camelio said she believes the letters are a scam, since in each case the
homeowner has not owed any taxes.

Camelio said that if residents receive one of the letters, they should not
forward a copy of a canceled check because that gives the scammer their bank
account numbers and check routing numbers in addition to their names and
addresses.

If anyone has questions about whether their taxes are paid, Camelio said they
should call her office at (860) 535-5080.

Camelio provided The Day with a copy of one of the letters brought to her by a
taxpayer.

The official-looking letter states that "A recent review of tax records has
revealed delinquent taxes on the property securing the above referenced loan,"
and it goes on to list the parcel number, delinquent tax year and alleged unpaid
amount.

"Based on the terms outlined in your Home Equity Credit Line Agreement and Deed
of Trust, you are required to pay all tax assessments prior to their becoming
delinquent. If payment has been made, please forward a copy of the front and
back of your cancelled check(s) or a copy of your paid receipt(s), along with
the tear-off below within thirty (30) days. PLEASE DO NOT SEND FUNDS FOR YOUR
DELINQUENT TAXES TO OUR OFFICE. Your prompt attention to this matter is
appreciated."

A P.O. Box in Fort Worth, Texas, is provided as a mailing address.

Police Capt. Todd Olson said Tuesday that Camelio has contacted him about the
scam and he is preparing to send out an email to residents warning them about
it.

"It's fortunate that the people who received the letters called her first," he
said.

                             223 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           Palm Beach Post (Florida)

                           September 6, 2008 Saturday
                                 FINAL EDITION

FLORIDA TOPS IN LAPSED MORTGAGES

BYLINE: By JEFF OSTROWSKI Palm Beach Post Staff Writer

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 6C

LENGTH: 340 words


One in 12 mortgage borrowers in Florida are critically behind on their loan
payments, the Mortgage Bankers Association said Friday.

Some 8.43 percent of borrowers were either in foreclosure or 90 days late in the
second quarter of 2008, the group said. That's up from 6.71 percent in the first
quarter, and it's by far the highest level of "seriously delinquent" loans in
Florida in the organization's 29 years of records.

"It used to be 1 percent was a red flag," said Miami bank analyst and economist
Ken Thomas. "When you get over 5 percent, that's a Category 5 type of number."

Florida leads the nation in seriously delinquent loans, ranking ahead of
boom-and-bust states Nevada, Arizona and California, the association said.

The spike in delinquent borrowers didn't surprise real estate experts.

"How can we be surprised?" said mortgage lender Bill Davis, president of Private
Funding Specialists in Palm Beach Gardens. "In fact, the numbers are going to
get worse."

As home prices spiked and lenders demanded only tiny down payments, many buyers
used adjustable-rate mortgages and other types of exotic loans to buy homes.

"Runaway home prices coupled with extremely easy credit meant a lot of home
buyers were resorting to risky mortgage products as an affordability crutch,"
said Greg McBride, senior financial analyst at Bankrate in North Palm Beach.

McBride called the flood of loan defaults "unprecedented." Until late 2007, the
rate of seriously delinquent loans in Florida had never topped 3 percent.

Plummeting home prices are fueling the number of foreclosures.

"People chose the lowest payment option to get into some of the very expensive
housing markets, and now that prices are coming way down, they can't sell and
they can't afford the higher payments,'' Jay Brinkmann, chief economist of the
Mortgage Bankers Association, told Bloomberg News.

In Palm Beach County, the median home price has fallen from a peak of $421,500
in November 2005 to $291,300 in July 2008, the Florida Association of Realtors
said.

~ jeff_ostrowski@pbpost.com

                             224 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           February 25, 2014 Tuesday

Washington: Pennsylvania's new lien law could monkeywrench REO sales in 6 ways

LENGTH: 914  words

DATELINE: Washington


American Land Title Association has issued the following news release:

A new law in Pennsylvania requires that delinquent taxes on one property will
create liens on all of owners' other properties in that county, and real estate
agents and lenders are worried it will put a kibbosh on business.

"I admit to being blindsided by this new law. I can't comprehend how it was
passed without being blocked by Realtors, mortgage lenders and title insurers,"
said one HousingWire tipster, located in Pennsylvania. "I can only imagine that
they didn't see it coming or couldn't conceive that the legislators would give
it credence or didn't understand the full complexity of unintended
consequences."

In November 2013, Act 93 of 2013 was signed into law by the Pennsylvania
Legislature. The act amends the Municipal Claim and Tax Lien Law to provide for
the collection of delinquent property tax claims through judgment liens as
opposed to a municipal lien.

When a title is searched, real estate professionals are now required to discover
all real estate owned by the vested owner in the county. Then they must check to
see if there are any liened delinquent property taxes owed and all of the liened
delinquent property taxes owed for any properties owned by this entity will be
considered a lien against all property they own in that county.

Municipal liens stay with the property, while judgments stay with the person. If
an owner does not pay the real estate taxes on his Pennsylvania property, that
judgment will now attach to any and all other property he may own in the same
Pennsylvania county.

"The system already in place for collection of delinquent property taxes in PA
works just fine. I hear that the impetus behind this law was Philadelphia. I
fail to see why the entire state must suffer for the failure of Philadelphia to
manage its business," said the source.

Our source outlined for HousingWire their thoughts on the potential impact of
this new Pennsylvania law:

1) It can jam up a sale needed to raise capital to remove a lien

A seller in a purchase transaction who is in financial distress having
delinquent taxes on more than one piece of real estate in a county will have
difficulty liquidating individual properties as there may not be sufficient
equity in one transaction to cover all outstanding delinquent tax obligations.
In these cases, buyers of the property would not be able to complete their
transaction and by the time this information has been discovered are likely to
have spent significant time and money on the potential purchase.

2) It can jam up other sales

A borrower in a refinance transaction who is in financial distress having
delinquent taxes on more than one piece of real estate in a county will have
difficulty liquidating individual properties as there may not be sufficient
equity in one transaction to cover all outstanding delinquent tax obligations.

3) Institutional investors, REO are looking at major headaches

Large entities who take title to real estate following foreclosure such as
Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac, HUD, VA and lots of mortgage lenders are likely to have
delinquent property taxes outstanding on multiple properties. I can only imagine
the complexity of the search process, competing transactions taking place at the
same time and deciding who has paid what at what time. I just can't conceive of
how these entities will cover shortages to pay all taxes as these REO properties
close. Perhaps they will simply advance funds to clear delinquent taxes on all
properties as they acquire them, however, even in this case, we will have to
live through a period of transition that might be crazy.

Click below for four through six.

page 2
A lien on one becomes a lien on all
taxlien

A new law in Pennsylvania requires that delinquent taxes on one property will
create liens on all of owners' other properties in that county, and real estate
agents and lenders are up in arms. Here are ways four-six on how it could impact
real estate business in Pennsylvania, according to one HousingWire tipster:

4) Compliance costs roll downhill

Increased search time and costs which will be passed onto consumers in some
fashion yet to be determined.

5) It will slow real estate productivity

Pennsylvania businesses including real estate offices, mortgage lenders, and
title insurance agents such as myself will suffer loss of productivity and more
importantly, loss of out of pocket funds expended for transactions which might
have otherwise closed if not for this new law.

6) It may result in less delinquent collections, not more

We had a good system in place for collection of delinquent property taxes.
Allowing transaction to close, always results in the delinquencies for each
property to be resolved individually. Now, with this new law, you are likely to
see less collection of delinquencies as people are unable to move properties due
to lack of equity sufficient to cover delinquencies on multiple properties.
Trey Garrison is the Senior Financial Reporter for HousingWire magazine and
HW.com. Trey has served as real estate editor for the Dallas Business Journal,
and was one of the founding editors of D CEO Magazine. He has been an editor for
D Magazine -- considered among the best city magazines in the United States --
and a contributor for Reason magazine, the national magazine that promotes free
minds and free markets. Follow him on Twitter @TreyGarrisonHW and reach him at
469-893-1502.

                             225 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                       Florida Times-Union (Jacksonville)

                          September 14, 2005 Wednesday

Maguire warns of possible real estate scam

BYLINE: Christina Abel

SECTION: Pg. V-1

LENGTH: 372 words


A possible real estate and mail fraud scam from California has targeted at least
two St. Johns County residents, including County Commission Chairman Bruce
Maguire.

At a Sept. 6 commissioner's meeting, Maguire warned the public about the
potential scam after he said he received about 15 letters postmarked from the
Property Tax Department in Irvine, Ca. The letters, signed by Scott Santos,
refer to Maguire's property identification numbers and imply that there are
delinquent taxes and liens on the properties.

Maguire said the county Tax Collectors Office assured him that he had no
delinquent taxes. He said he turned the letters over to the U.S. Postal Service
because of potential mail fraud. Maguire said he also thinks the letters could
be part of a real estate scam.

A St. Augustine couple received an identical letter about their property and
told the police and County Commissioner Ben Rich.

Rich said he knew what "the deal was" as soon as he heard about the letter.

The letters said, "If the Tax Collector sells your property at public auction or
if the lien holder chooses to foreclose when your parcel becomes too delinquent,
you could no longer own the property. However, I may be willing to pay you cash
for your property and pay all your delinquent taxes, interest, penalties and
fees before your property is lost."

The only business referred to in the letters is the Property Tax Department, but
the phone number is for a company called National Land Liquidations.

A woman who answered the phone at the company last week and would identify
herself only as Katie K., said the letters were sent out by mistake and that the
company was sorry for the mix-up.

Maguire was skeptical of this being a simple mistake.

He compared it to other situations in which developers purchase 60 to 70 houses,
then go out to investors in California and sell them 10 houses at a time, with
the investors never having seen the property.

"It's a big marketing scheme out in California and something like this may be
tied in. So if you get anything from California about buying your property, be
very careful," Maguire said.

Staff writer Christina Abel can be reached at (904) 249-4947, extension 19, or
via e-mail at christina.abel@jacksonville.com.

LOAD-DATE: September 24, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             226 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                December 11, 1999, Saturday, THREE STAR EDITION

NATION & WORLD BRIEFS

BYLINE: From News Services

SECTION: NEWS, Pg. 22

LENGTH: 1451 words



NATION

MARYLAND

Juvenile delinquents allege abuse at camps

A Maryland judge pulled 26 juvenile delinquents from state-run boot camps Friday
after the boys testified that camp guards had thrown them through windows, stuck
thumbs in their eyes and routinely beat them.

Judge Martin P. Welch ordered the boys placed immediately into other secure
juvenile facilities.

The teens, all of whom are from Baltimore, were summoned from the three
state-run camps 150 miles away in western Maryland.

The judge wanted to determine whether the teen-agers were appropriately housed
after reading reports this week in The (Baltimore) Sun that guards in at least
one camp routinely attacked delinquents.

Gov. Parris Glendening has ordered an investigation into abuse alle gations at
the camps.

WASHINGTON

Government seeks to halt sale of cancer products

The government asked a federal judge Friday to stop the sale of a popular brand
of shark cartilage and two other alternative remedies, saying the manufacturers
illegally claim the products can be used to treat cancer.

BeneFin, the shark cartilage, has not been proved to treat cancer, the Food and
Drug Administration said in seeking a permanent injunction against the product.
Lane Labs-USA packages the product in Allendale, N.J.

The FDA complaint also names a Lane skin cream called SkinAnswer, purported to
be a treatment for skin cancer, and a rice-bran extract called MGN-3, with is
purported to be a treatment for both cancer and AIDS.

Joyce Steel, a spokeswoman for Lane, said, "We have no comment at this time
except to say we believe we've done nothing wrong."

IDAHO

Government pays to stop proposed subdivision

The federal government is paying $ 2.3 million to stop a proposed subdivision in
central Idaho that would threaten a spectacular view of the Sawtooth Mountains.

"We are preserving a precious piece of Idaho not only for American taxpayers
today but for generations to follow," Sawtooth National Forest Supervisor Bill
LeVere said Friday.

The deal with the WOMAC Land and Cattle Co., owned by Joe, Julian and Bob Piva,
ended three years of negotiations over the future of the meadow about 80 miles
northeast of Boise. The Pivas acquired the land long before the Sawtooth
National Recreation Area was created in 1972.

Under the agreement, the Pivas retain ownership of the 160-acre tract, but they
and subsequent owners will be restricted to building only one home on any of the
three parcels. The proposed subdivision had 20 lots.

The Piva easement brings all but 2,500 acres of the privately owned land in the
756,000-acre recreation area under development restrictions.

CALIFORNIA

Rescuers search for 7 Marines lost in crash

Rescuers searched the Pacific Ocean on Friday but held out little hope for seven
Marines who were lost when their helicopter crashed.

The CH-46 Sea Knight helicopter went down Thursday afternoon about 15 miles off
San Diego during a training exercise, while flying from one ship to another.
Eleven of the 18 Marines aboard were quickly rescued.

The wreckage was submerged in 3,600 feet of water. Only a few pieces of the
helicopter were recovered by Friday afternoon, said Lt. Scott Bowman, a Marine
spokesman.

==============

WORLD

BRITAIN

Investigate Seattle police, Amnesty International says

Amnesty International on Friday called for an inquiry into police action taken
during demonstrations in Seattle against the World Trade Organization.

The international human rights group, based in London, said in a statement that
it was concerned about allegations of indiscriminate use of tear gas, pepper
spray, rubber bullets and noisemakers.

The group also called for an investigation into allegations of cruel treatment
of the hundreds of arrested protesters at Seattle's King County Jail. It said
some of the alleged incidents, such as the use of restraint chairs and beatings,
appeared to have violated international human rights standards.

SWITZERLAND

Experts call for delay in destroying smallpox

Experts have recommended further research on the smallpox virus before the
world's only known remaining stocks in the United States and Russia are
destroyed, the World Health Organization said Friday.

The recommendation was made by the group's advisory committee on variola virus
research, composed of 16 experts from all regions, who ended a four-day meeting
at the group's headquarters in Geneva Thursday.

Last May, the WHO's 191 member nations voted to delay destruction of the
smallpox virus stocks until 2002 at the latest.

The deadly stocks are kept in high-security laboratories at the Centers for
Disease Control in Atlanta and at the Russian State Center for Research on
Virology and Biotechnology in Novosibirsk.

INDONESIA

New government releases political prisoners

Indonesia's new reformist government freed almost all the country's remaining
political prisoners today, reversing a path followed by a prior regime that had
jailed thousands of opponents.

About 90 dissidents - including 18 East Timorese independence activists - were
released from prison, said director-general of correctional affairs, Hasanuddin.
Like many Indonesians, he uses only one name.

The prisoners include six men who were jailed for being members of an illegal
communist group. Thousands of suspected communist sympathizers were jailed
following an aborted coup in 1965.

Following the election of the new President Abdurrahman Wahid in October, the
government promised it would release all remaining political prisoners.

MEXICO

Human rights group cites Mexico for torture

Serious and widespread human rights violations continued in Mexico this year,
including torture and arbitrary arrests, Human Rights Watch said in its annual
report.

In the report received Friday in Mexico, the U.S.-based human rights group said
"the gap between rhetorical support for human rights and their effective
protection ... remained great."

Despite a new federal effort to promote and strengthen respect for human rights,
"another year passed in which Mexico's deeply rooted human rights problems
received inadequate attention from authorities," it said.

"Rather than confront these problems head-on, politicians either ignored human
rights topics altogether or chose to blame human rights groups for exacerbating
public security problems."

There was no immediate response from the government, and the Foreign Ministry
said it had not issued a statement.

FRANCE

Unmanned rocket launches 3.7-ton satellite

The Ariane 5 rocket accomplished a smooth first mission Friday.

The unmanned rocket rose into a cloudless sky from Europe's space base in
Kourou, French Guiana, on the northern shoulder of South America.

The 746-ton launcher lobbed the European Space Agency's X-Ray Multi-Mirror
scientific satellite, weighing 3.7 tons, into orbit 29 minutes after the launch.

The satellite is equipped with three powerful telescopes, each holding 58
mirrors.

Ariane 5 is the most powerful in the European series of unmanned rockets. The
control center for the missions is outside Paris.

ARGENTINA

New president promises more austere times

Fernando de la Rua was sworn in Friday as Argentina's 47th president. He
promised to create an austere government in contrast to the flamboyant decade of
Carlos Menem.

"One era is over, and a new century is beginning," said De la Rua, 62, a former
mayor of Buenos Aires.

Menem's two terms and 10 years in power were the longest uninterrupted stay in
the presidency.

De la Rua, leader of the centrist Radical party, teamed up with the leftist
Frepaso party to defeat the Peronists in the Oct. 24 election. De la Rua easily
won election over his Peronist challenger, saying Menem's record left high
unemployment and other social costs unattended.

"All Argentines across length and breadth of this country are seeking better
times. We are going to work to that end!" he said.

CANADA

Law aims to hinder Quebec's plan to secede

The Canadian government unveiled legislation Friday that seeks to make it more
difficult for the French-speaking province of Quebec to secede from Canada.

"This is the time to act, to make sure things are clear," Prime Minister Jean
Chretien told reporters after his government submitted the draft legislation to
the House of Commons.

The bill seeks to make law a 1998 judgment of the Supreme Court of Canada which
said that any referendum about whether Quebec should secede from Canada would
have to be won by a clear majority on a clear question.

demonstration Friday against a proposed constitution by university students in
Caracas. The nation will vote Wednesday on a constitution drafted by an assembly

                             227 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           The Philadelphia Inquirer

                           January 12, 2008 Saturday
                                 CITY-D Edition

Phila. groups helping late borrowers;
Unemployment Project, ACORN work with lender Countrywide to negotiate affordable
mortgages.

BYLINE: By Harold Brubaker; Inquirer Staff Writer

SECTION: NATIONAL; Inq Front Page; Pg. A01

LENGTH: 716 words


Regina Taylor was in a heap of financial trouble last month.

The payment on the $78,000 adjustable-rate mortgage for her house in Mount Airy
climbed from $515 to a scheduled $1,010 this month.

Taylor, 53, a grandmother of eight, had fallen behind the year before after a
job loss and couldn't catch up, barely escaping a sheriff's sale last summer.

Then last month, Countrywide Financial Corp. agreed to modify her loan, giving
her a fixed payment of $535 a month, including taxes and insurance.

"Everything worked out really well," said Taylor, who went to Cleveland last
month to meet with Countrywide officials as part of the Philadelphia
Unemployment Project's campaign to switch delinquent borrowers to affordable
fixed-rate mortgages.

A menacing increase in delinquent subprime loans like Taylor's drove
Countrywide, the nation's largest mortgage lender, to be rescued from possible
bankruptcy by Bank of America Corp., which said yesterday that it would pay $4.1
billion in stock for Countrywide, of Calabasas, Calif.

Bank of America plans to dump Countrywide's huge subprime business, Ken Lewis,
the Charlotte, N.C., bank's chief executive officer, said yesterday during a
conference call.

But until then, Countrywide's mortgage-servicing arm is dealing with a surge in
delinquent loans - many of them subprime - from 411,583 in December 2006 to
628,820 last month.

Next week, Countrywide plans to announce an agreement with the Association of
Community Organizations for Reform Now, or ACORN, to contain an anticipated
flood of foreclosures by streamlining procedures for moving delinquent subprime
borrowers into affordable loans.

Marcia Morgan-Coleman is among the Philadelphia borrowers seeking help from
ACORN in negotiating with Countrywide over better loan terms.

Morgan-Coleman was anything but a subprime borrower when she bought a house for
$82,000 in 2003. Her 30-year mortgage for $72,000 had a fixed interest rate of
5.375 percent, she said yesterday.

But coming off a divorce and starting over as a single mother with a
middle-class lifestyle, she ran up a chunk of credit-card debt.

Meanwhile, Countrywide sent her a stream of offers for a home equity loan to
consolidate her credit-card debt. She said that every time she got on the phone
to confirm a payment, Countrywide customer-service representatives badgered her
about getting a second loan. In 2005, she relented, taking out a $15,000
home-equity loan. "I thought it was going to save me money in the long run," she
said.

But she did not know that she was only paying interest on the home-equity loan
and that the interest rate was climbing, until it reached the 15 percent to 16
percent range, about the same as the credit-card rate.

A Countrywide spokesman could not be reached for comment on the terms of
Morgan-Coleman's loan.

The monthly interest payment has gone from $80 to $150, and she can't keep up,
especially after losing her job in retail a year ago and going to school to
become a medical technician.

Morgan-Coleman said she was current on her first mortgage, which costs $550 a
month, including taxes and insurance. But the lender is threatening to foreclose
because she's been months behind on the second mortgage.

"Right now, I don't even consider myself middle class," said Morgan-Coleman, who
has also fallen behind on other bills.

"It's horrible when you get bamboozled by these big companies who just want to
make money," she said. "It's just not right. It really, really angers me."

Taylor, the Mount Airy woman whose loan was modified by Countrywide, is happy
now. "I'm settled," said Taylor, who had refinanced in 2005 to pay her
grandmother's nursing-home expenses and to finance home repairs.

But John Dodds, director the group that took Taylor to Cleveland, pointed out
that Taylor would pay only interest for four years.

"Basically, she has no equity in her property," Dodds said. That's after 30
years in the house and a succession of four mortgages, including the
modification.

Dodds was pleased that Countrywide allowed Taylor to stay in her house, he said,
but "they could have been a little nicer about it."

Inside


Countrywide sold to Bank of America. Stocks plunge on woes in financial sector.
C1.

hbrubaker@phillynews.com.

                             228 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Philadelphia Daily News

                             May 28, 2009 Thursday
                                 FINAL Edition

Letters: What Revenue Dept. is doing on unpaid taxes

SECTION: EDITORIAL OPINION; P-com Opinion; Pg. 18

LENGTH: 487 words


RE YOUR MAY 15 editorial, "New BRT-Related Tax Outrage: Unpaid Biz Taxes the
Latest Black Mark":

In it, you ask, "Is it too much to ask that city, state and quasi-governmental
agencies require from their contractors proof that

they've paid their business taxes?"

The simple answer to that question is "obviously not." Contractors should be
required to pay all of their taxes before they do business with the city and
other agencies, and we are taking steps to make sure that happens.

As a result of the economic decline, delinquent taxes are on a rise both
nationally and regionally. The city of Philadelphia is no different and has seen
recent slowing in overall tax collections. We have begun to implement aggressive
delinquent collection strategies to enhance revenue collections.

Many collection strategies are underway, including a vendor-compliance
initiative that addresses the question raised in the editorial.

We are aggressively discovering businesses that are active in Philadelphia but
not filing and paying taxes.

This year, we have added a new mechanism, a review of vendors for the
Philadelphia Parking Authority. We will work with the authority to require such
compliance by contract in the future so that tax-delinquent vendors will have
their payments interrupted similarly to delinquent city vendors.

We will also expand our compliance review to vendors of quasi-municipal
organizations and other government entities. Soon, all contractors will be
required to complete a tax status application and obtain clearance prior to
doing business with the city.

In addition to the vendor compliance initiative, I would like to highlight some
of the other enforcement tools we've put in place to expand our delinquent
collections.

On May 11, we launched the Tax Fraud Hotline, which gives law-abiding taxpayers
a tool to report suspected tax fraud. Tax fraud can be reported by calling the
hotline at 215-686-3852 or sending an e-mail to taxfraud@phila.gov.

We also continue to publicize the names of delinquent taxpayers and enhance our
audit and discovery functions.

As noted in your editorial, we have increased the number of sheriff's sales, an
effort that received considerable attention when the mayor became personally
involved with by getting into a discussion with a lawyer who owed the city over
$100,000 in taxes.

You also proposed that we require delinquent businesses to display a decal
indicating they owe taxes.

ILIKE YOUR idea - but there have been many recent initiatives that shine a
spotlight on delinquent individuals and businesses.

Perhaps we can modify your recommendation and issue decals to those who actually
pay their taxes. The decals would show that they are paying what they owe and
supporting their city government.

The city of Philadelphia continues to use and expand every tool legally
available to go after those who withhold tax revenue.

Keith J. Richardson, Commissioner

Department of Revenue

                              The Washington Post

                            March 26, 2005 Saturday
                                 Final Edition

Borrowers On Time in Pricey Markets

BYLINE: Kenneth R. Harney

SECTION: Real Estate; F01 , THE NATION'S HOUSING Kenneth R. Harney

LENGTH: 749 words


Although some economists are concerned about homeowners' rising debt burden
especially in high-cost, high-inflation markets, a new study suggests that those
worries may be misplaced. Homeowners in  "bubble markets" such as metropolitan
Washington, California, Nevada, New England and the mid-Atlantic region are more
likely to pay their mortgages on time than homeowners in parts of the country
with lower housing inflation rates.

In California, for example, where house prices have risen  at double-digit rates
each year for five years, just 2.04 percent of  borrowers were behind on their
payments in the final quarter of 2004, according to the latest loan delinquency
data compiled by the Mortgage Bankers Association. The national average during
the same period was 4.6 percent.

In Texas, by contrast, where prices and inflation rates have been much lower,
6.8 percent of homeowners were behind on their  payments. In Mississippi, 8.8
percent  were delinquent. In Louisiana, 7.2 percent.

In high-priced Massachusetts, where aggregate housing price inflation has led
the nation over a 20-year period, 3.2 percent of homeowners were delinquent. In
the District, where prices have been high for years and keep rising, 3.7 percent
of borrowers paid their mortgages late. Delinquency rates in high-cost New York,
New Jersey and Florida were below the national average, while rates in Georgia
(6.3 percent), Tennessee (6.4 percent) and West Virginia (6.6 percent) were
considerably higher.

The new national delinquency and foreclosure figures, which cover payment
performances on nearly 39 million outstanding mortgages, also documented wide
variances among credit categories of homeowners and the types of loans they
obtain. For example, if you are what the mortgage industry classifies as a
"prime" borrower  --  you have a solid credit history and you qualify for the
best rates available  --  you are far more likely to pay your loan on time than
borrowers ranked "sub-prime," or riskier, no matter where you live.

Nationwide at the end of last year, according to the mortgage bankers'
delinquency study, just 2.4 percent of all prime mortgage borrowers were behind
on their payments, compared with nearly 11 percent of sub-prime borrowers with
less favorable credit histories and scores. Sub-prime borrowers were 7.5 times
more likely to be 90 days delinquent than prime borrowers, and eight  times more
likely to be in foreclosure proceedings.

Homebuyers who take out loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration  are
the most likely to let their payments slip. Nearly 13.2 percent of all FHA
borrowers were delinquent at the end of 2004, according to the study, and 3.1
percent were three months or more behind. That's not surprising, however,
because the FHA program specifically seeks to assist first-time buyers with
moderate incomes. The FHA program is also lenient on credit history problems,
offers minimal down payments and relaxed standards on household debt-to-income
ratios.

Borrowers with adjustable-rate mortgages,  including interest-only and "option"
payment loans, were only slightly less likely to pay on time than borrowers with
fixed-rate mortgages. In California, where interest-only mortgages have been a
key factor in lowering monthly payments on high-cost houses, just 1.4 percent of
prime credit-quality borrowers were behind on their loans in the last quarter of
the year. Contrast that with low-cost, low-inflation Iowa, where more than 3
percent of prime ARM borrowers were delinquent, and Nebraska, where the
late-payment rate was 3.9 percent.

Worst in the country on prime adjustable-rate on-time payments was Mississippi,
where more than 8.5 percent of all homeowners with adjustables were delinquent.
Worst for sub-prime ARMs: West Virginia, where more than 21 percent of
homeowners with such loans were behind.

Apart from the regional and loan credit category results, the latest homeowner
delinquency study contains an important national finding: Despite rising home
mortgage debt levels around the country, on-time payment performance overall in
2004 was better than in the three preceding years. Households may be saddled
with big mortgages in some of the biggest-ticket markets, but  they seem to be
handling that  burden.

As long as interest rates remain low and employment growth continues, that could
be an indicator that bursting bubbles are nowhere in sight.

Kenneth R. Harney's e-mail address is KenHarney@earthlink.net.

LOAD-DATE: March 26, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                       Copyright 2005 The Washington Post


                             230 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        The Pueblo Chieftain (Colorado)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           September 6, 2012 Thursday

Garcia aghast by delinquent bills

BYLINE: Gayle Perez, The Pueblo Chieftain, Colo.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 439 words


Sept. 06--Former Colorado State University-Pueblo President Joe Garcia said he's
dumbfounded as to why the university under his tenure failed to detect the
problem with such a large number of students being delinquent on their bills.

"We had audited financial statements every year and that never came up," Garcia
said Wednesday. "I don't have an explanation about how something like that went
on undetected."

Now Colorado's lieutenant governor, Garcia was president at CSU-Pueblo from June
2006 through September 2010.

A May 2011 audit of the university's accounts receivables determined the
university had, for several years, failed to withdraw students who did not pay
their bills nor had it tried to collect on delinquent payments.

The issue recently came to light after it was announced that CSUPueblo's fall
enrollment had taken a significant dip.

One of the factors contributing to the decrease was the large number of students
who were dropped from classes, per university policy, for not making the first
installment of their tuition payment due Aug.

20.

University records dating back to 2000 showed there had been a significant
number of students who were delinquent on their payments but were not withdrawn.

Garcia said he has not seen the audit report but was unaware of any significant
problems with student bills.

"I was not aware that we had any problems that were different than any other
school with similar populations," he said. "It's not in the best interest for
any business to give services to anybody without them paying for services."

Julio Leon, who served as interim president from November 2010 to November 2011,
said he was aware of problems and had started to fix them while the audit was in
progress.

A few students were dropped last fall for nonpayment and a process for
reregistering dropped students was being implemented, Leon said.

"It's something that needed to be done," Leon said of dropping students.

"Sometimes you want to give students an opportunity. You hate to withdraw them
for financial difficulties but you can only go so far."

Garcia and Leon praised Di Mare for her work in remedying the situation.

"I'm sure Lesley is doing everything she can do to make sure the university is
financially sound. I have a lot of confidence in her abilities," Garcia said.

Leon said Di Mare is "doing the right thing."

"I think the school is on the right path. It's going to hurt a little bit but
when the new culture takes over it will get better."

gperez@chieftain.com

                           Palm Beach Post (Florida)

                              May 22, 2011 Sunday
                              Correction Appended
                                 FINAL EDITION

In your community

BYLINE:

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. 3B

LENGTH: 601 words


palm beach county

Last day to pay property taxes nears

May 31 is the last day to pay delinquent property taxes. After that, a first
lien is placed on a delinquent property and auctioned by the Palm Beach County
Tax Collector. By law, a property owner has two years to pay delinquent taxes,
but once the tax certificate is sold, interest and advertising fees are applied
to the amount owed so that amount increases by a minimum of 10 percent. Payments
must be made at a service center or by mail, postmarked no later than 5 p.m. May
31. No delinquent taxes can be paid online or with a credit card. The tax
collector will accept cash, money order, certified check, bank draft, U.S.
postal order, cashier's check or wire transfer.

--Bonnie Chynoweth

lake park

Three vie to replace deceased mayor

Three candidates filed to replace Mayor Desca DuBois, who died April 30 in her
hometown of Barnwell, S.C., where she was visiting family. The candidates are
James DuBois, her husband; Brenden Beard; and James Lloyd. The three-year
position pays $10,000 annually. The election is June 28 in the town of about
9,000 residents.

-- Bill DiPaolo

lake worth

City pool won't open this summer

The city pool will not open this summer as expected. The city originally had
planned to open the pool on Memorial Day and keep it open until construction
began on the casino and common areas at Lake Worth Beach. Public Services
Director Joseph Kroll said Friday that opening the pool for a week or two does
not make sense. The pool is part of the historic casino building that is
scheduled to undergo a $6 million renovation starting in June. The pool will be
closed until construction is completed next summer, Kroll said. Lake Worth
Beach, the William O. Lockhart Municipal Pier and Benny's on the Beach
restaurant, on the pier, will stay open during construction, as well as at least
40 percent of the beach parking spaces.

-- Willie Howard

martin county

Peck recommended as health boss

STUART -- The Martin County Health Department will have a new permanent director
Tuesday pending final approval from county commissioners. Karlette Peck, who
currently serves as deputy health officer for the St. Lucie County Health
Department, was recommended for the position by Florida's Department of Health.
Peck has had a 30-year career in public health in Florida. Peck would replace
Interim Director Robin Wright, who took over after the former director, Mark
Chittum, retired last year.

-- TCPalm.com

tequesta

Memorial Day service at Riverside Park

Riverside Memorial Park will hold its 63rd annual Memorial Day service at 11
a.m. May 30 at 19351 S.E. County Line Road, Tequesta, in partnership with The
Rood Williams American Legion Post 271. The event, which is open to the public,
also will serve as a fund-raiser to benefit Wounded Warriors Second Chance,
providing time away from the hospital to wounded soldiers and their families.
Call (561) 747-1100 for more information.

-- TCPalm.com

crime stoppers

Zakia Gammage, 20, is wanted for violating probation for robbery. She was born
June 8, 1990, and has black hair and brown eyes. She is 5 feet and 162 pounds.
Her last known address was on North Seacrest Boulevard in Boynton Beach.

Rose Collins, 29, is wanted for violating probation for possession of cocaine
and a controlled substance. She was born July 8, 1981, and has black hair and
brown eyes. She is 5 feet 1 inch and 125 pounds. Her last known address was on
Sleepy Willow Way in Delray Beach.

These suspects were wanted as of Thursday. Anyone with information on their
whereabouts is asked to call Crime Stoppers at (800) 458-TIPS (8477).

                             232 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                            Crain's Detroit Business

                           September 9, 2002, Monday

Week in Review

SECTION: Pg. 30

LENGTH: 942 words


Water department owed $59M in past-due bills

The Detroit Water and Sewerage Department has failed to collect $59.3 million in
delinquent water bills from Detroit homes and business, The Detroit News
reported. Thirty-seven percent of all water customers in Detroit, or about
110,000, have delinquent bills. Department officials say they plan to ask the
Detroit City Council to approve a contract with an undisclosed law firm to help
collect past-due water bills, the Detroit Free Press reported.

Detroit ordered to pay tribe's lawyer fees, costs

U.S. District Judge Robert Holmes Bell ruled that the city of Detroit must
reimburse the Lac Vieux Desert Band of Lake Superior Chippewa Indians $545,000
in attorney fees and costs in the tribe's 5-year-old lawsuit against the city's
casino ordinance. The case is still on appeal.

Local Jacobson stores may have private sale

At least two of Jacobson's local department stores are likely to be sold through
private sales prior to a public auction on Sept. 18. Josh Joseph, vice president
of Hilco Real Estate Inc., said last week that preliminary agreements have been
reached to sell Jacobson's stores in Grosse Pointe and Rochester Hills through
private sales.

Joseph declined to identify the buyers, but said one is an investor and the
other is a retailer. A third store, in Naples, Fla., is also being purchased
through a private sale, Joseph said. The landlord is buying that property.

Even though the Grosse Pointe and Rochester Hills stores won't be part of a
public auction set for Sept. 18, other bidders could submit higher bids at a
hearing later this month.

MGM picks Perini, Brinker to build permanent casino

MGM Grand Detroit Casino L.L.C. selected Perini Building Co. and L.S. Brinker
Co. as 60-40 joint-venture general contractors to build MGM's permanent $500
million hotel-casino complex in Detroit. Perini is a wholly owned subsidiary of
Framingham, Mass.-based Perini Corp. Brinker is a minority-owned company based
in Detroit. Perini and Brinker were involved in the construction of the
temporary, $220 million MGM Grand Detroit Casino.

CMS credit rating falls

The credit-rating agency Fitch Ratings downgraded the debt of Dearborn-based CMS
Energy Corp. (NYSE: CMS) and utility subsidiary Consumers Energy Co., citing
concerns over cash constraints at each company. New York City-based Fitch
lowered CMS' senior unsecured debt to B+ from BB-. The senior secured debt of
Jackson-based Consumers dropped to BB+ from BBB, and its senior unsecured debt
fell to BB from BB+.

Also, CMS Generation Co. sold its 66 percent ownership in a power plant in
Thailand for $47 million. The stake was sold to Thailand's Advanced Power Supply
Public Co. Ltd.

Museum promenade named for Heinz Prechter

Henry Ford Museum & Greenfield Village dedicated its restored front promenade to
the late automotive entrepreneur Heinz Prechter. Prechter was a member of the
Dearborn museum's board and chairman of Southgate-based ASC Inc. He died July 6,
2001.

Tobacco initiative heads to Supreme Court

Opponents to a tobacco-spending ballot initiative today planned to head to the
Michigan Supreme Court, in the wake of a Michigan Court of Appeals ruling Friday
that gave the tobacco measure new life.

The appeals court ordered a state elections board to meet and certify the
November ballot measure by the end of the day Tuesday, reversing the Board of
State Canvassers' action. The proposed constitutional amendment, would require
the state to spend most of its tobacco-settlement dollars on health care and
smoking-prevention.

Briefly

* Childtime Learning Centers Inc. in Farmington Hills appointed Frank Jerneycic
as vice president and CFO.

* Oakland County Circuit Judge Gene Schnelz upheld the city of Clawson's
billboard ban, The Daily Tribune of Royal Oak reported. Billboard company Viacom
Outdoor Inc. had sought to overturn the ban.

* Lufthansa German Airlines moved from the Berry International Terminal to the
new McNamara terminal at Detroit Metropolitan Airport.

* The Fifth Estate, a Detroit-based anarchist newspaper, is moving its
operations to Pumpkin Hollow, Tenn., the Detroit Free Press reported.

* Detroit Mayor Kwame Kilpatrick created the East Riverfront Study Group to
develop a plan to revitalize the city's riverfront from Joe Louis Arena downtown
east to the Belle Isle bridge. The committee has 90 days to come up with the
plan.

* Comerica Bank's Business Activity Index gained 6 points in July to close at
118. A year earlier the index was 106.

* Clayton Johnson, the Detroit attorney who is leading a drive to recall Detroit
City Clerk Jackie Currie, filed a new recall petition with the Wayne County
clerk's office, The Detroit News reported. The Wayne County Election Commission
rejected an earlier recall petition, citing unclear language.

* The Wayne County Commission approved a restructured deal for the repayment of
$114 million in bonds for Detroit Metropolitan Airport, the Detroit Free Press
reported. Two German banks, Bayerische Landesbank and Landesbank
Hessen-Thuringen, will back the bonds.

Obituaries

* Detroit City Councilwoman Brenda Scott died Sept. 2 as a result of
complications from stomach-reduction surgery. Scott was 47. She had served on
the council since 1994. She was noted for her responses to neighborhood concerns
and for opposing the Dennis Archer administration on locating casinos to the
riverfront and on proposals to charge a fee for using Belle Isle Park.

* James Foley, president and chairman of Michigan Foundation Co. in Trenton,
died Sept. 3. The Grosse Ile resident was 86.
