                             233 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                            The New York Times Blogs
                                   (DealBook)

                           September 2, 2014 Tuesday

Federal Program Helps Keep Some Delinquent Borrowers in Their Homes

BYLINE: MATTHEW GOLDSTEIN

SECTION: BUSINESS

LENGTH: 535 words



HIGHLIGHT: A HUD program to sell its most delinquent mortgages to private
investors has resulted in about 2,000 borrowers being able to stay in their
homes, though an overwhelming majority have been foreclosed upon or have
forfeited any rights to the properties.


A four-year program by a federal housing agency to sell its most delinquent
mortgages to private investors is producing modest returns when it comes to
keeping those struggling borrowers in their homes.

To date, 2,049 mortgage sold to investors under the program have been reworked
to allow the borrowers -many of whom had not made a mortgage payment in three
years-to remain in their homes and start making payments again, according to a
report released Friday by the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

But the overwhelming majority of the 73,000 troubled mortgages sold to
investment firms, private equity shops and hedge funds have been either
foreclosed upon or the borrower was permitted to walk away from a home in
exchange of forfeiting any rights to the property. Roughly half of the loans
sold to investors remain delinquent and have yet to be reworked, sold or
foreclosed.

The report from HUD offers the first comprehensive look at the sale of
non-performing loans guaranteed by the Federal Housing Administration. HUD began
the selling seriously delinquent mortgage to private investors at a discount in
an attempt to reduce the federal government's potential exposure. The
government's obligation to pay out on any claims arising from the loans ends
once they are sold to private buyers.

The report said that without the mortgage sales, almost all of the loans would
end up in foreclosure given how delinquent the borrowers were on making
payments. Federal officials have said private buyers have a better chance of
reworking the mortgages given the loans are bought at a significant discount.

"For the purchasers, the program is an opportunity to acquire assets at
competitive prices with the flexibility to service the assets while providing
borrowers an opportunity to avoid costly foreclosures," the report said.

From 2010 through 2013, private investors acquired loans with unpaid balances of
$12.6 billion. HUD has sold another 23,000 delinquent loans worth about $4
billion that were not included in the report because the sales took place in the
just the past few months.

Private investors have been buying these delinquent loans from HUD and packaging
the ones that can't be worked into unrated bondsthat are then sold to mutual
funds, insurance firms. The bonds typically are short-duration securities that
payout based on the value of the mortgages being liquidated in a foreclosure
proceedings.

The investors buying the non-performing loans are generally prohibited from
foreclosing on the mortgages until at least six months after purchasing them.

Some private buyers also are starting to pool reworked loans into securities,
while other buyers are more interested in foreclosing on the mortgages to
acquire the homes in order to operate them as rental properties.

The HUD report said the biggest buyers of the delinquent loans, many of which
were issued to borrowers in Florida, New Jersey and Illinois, are Lone Star
Funds, Bayview Asset Management, a firm backed by the Blackstone Group and
Oaktree Capital Management.

A significant number of delinquent loans purchased by the private buyers at the
HUD auctions were later resold to other firm, the report found.

LOAD-DATE: September 3, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: News

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Blog

                           The Philadelphia Inquirer

                            February 4, 2013 Monday
                                  WEB Edition

Nutter says Philly's getting tough on tax deadbeats

BYLINE: By Troy Graham; INQUIRER STAFF WRITER

SECTION: WEB; P-com News City; Pg. WEB

LENGTH: 683 words


Just two weeks before property owners learn the results of a reassessment that
will alter tax bills across Philadelphia, Mayor Nutter on Monday announced a new
effort to find tax deadbeats and "encourage" them to pay up.

Nutter said the city would spend $40 million over the next five years to
overhaul the Department of Revenue's software - which dates to 1993 - hire 55
new employees, and start a call center to chase down tax delinquents.

The city also will employ outside collection agencies and get cases to them
quicker than in the past.

"We will do whatever is necessary to provide further inspiration for those who
think they can get away with not paying their taxes," Nutter said. "Those days
are clearly coming to an end."

Tax delinquents - and the perception that the city has not done enough to chase
them - have been cited frequently in the discussions surrounding Nutter's
property tax reform, the Actual Value Initiative (AVI).

The argument has been that the city should collect from delinquents before
implementing a system that is going to cause some homeowners' bills to
skyrocket.

But Nutter said unveiling his get-tough effort was not timed to coincide with
the releasing of the reassessment data, which could be mailed to property owners
by the end of next week.

"This message is timed to say, 'Pay your taxes, whenever they are due,' " Nutter
said. "It's also putting people on notice that we'll be much more aggressive in
coming after you."

Nutter said the city was owed $518 million in back taxes, interest, and
penalties at the end of the last fiscal year - $248 million from property taxes
over the last decade.

The city has been collecting about 91 percent of the taxes owed in recent years,
said Revenue Commissioner Keith Richardson.

But the city has had a spotty history of collecting taxes, even from its own
employees. Nutter has launched a number of efforts since 2008, including one
that forced tax-delinquent city workers into payment plans.

An Inquirer/PlanPhilly series of articles since 2011 has documented how
Philadelphia has the least-effective delinquent-property-tax collection system
of the nation's biggest cities, and the pile of delinquent property taxes has
continued to grow on Nutter's watch.

Nutter, who said the goal was to collect "everything," said the new strategy
could bring in about $260 million over the next five years.

With AVI looming, both City Council and the Philadelphia delegation in
Harrisburg have introduced legislation to give the city more tools to pursue
delinquent property owners, especially speculators who own multiple properties.

The delegation's bill, for example, would give the city permission to place
liens on any property in the state owned by someone not paying their property
taxes in Philadelphia.

Using city data, staff for Council President Darrell L. Clarke concluded that
100,000 parcels are tax-delinquent and 35,000 of them have owners with multiple
delinquent properties.

Going after back taxes is one way politicians hope to soften AVI's impact on
homeowners, clustered in fast-growing areas of the city, who are facing enormous
increases.

Politicians fear taxes under AVI could force out some older residents and stunt
the real estate market in neighborhoods such as Northern Liberties.

In about two weeks, most owners should get a letter informing them what the city
thinks their properties are worth.

The tax rate would be set during the budget process this spring. The
administration maintains that the rate would have to be between 1.3 and 1.4
percent to collect the same amount of revenue as last year, meaning $1,300 to
$1,400 per $100,000 of a home's value.

The resulting bills would be due in 2014.

Contact Troy Graham at 215-854-2730 or tgraham@phillynews.com, or follow on
Twitter @troyjgraham.


Mapping out plans for a greener Parkway

http://www.philly.com/philly/news/breaking/20130204_Mapping_out_plans_for_a_gree
ner_Parkway.html

lp_in_corraling_labor_costs.html

                             235 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           The Philadelphia Inquirer

                             August 21, 2011 Sunday
                                JERSEY-C Edition

Phila. aims to boost volume of sheriff sales;
The goal is to auction off 600 tax-delinquent properties every month so people
"recognize we're really serious."

BYLINE: By Bob Warner; Inquirer Staff Writer

SECTION: PHILADELPHIA; P-com News Local; Pg. B03

LENGTH: 738 words


After promising tougher enforcement for more than a year, the Nutter
administration is planning a stiff run-up in the number of tax-delinquent
properties to be auctioned off at city sheriff sales.

City Finance Director Rob Dubow and Revenue Commissioner Keith Richardson said
last week that they expect to offer 200 tax-delinquent properties at a sheriff's
sale next month, and raise the number to 600 a month by January 2012.

By comparison, over 11 years from 2000 through 2010, the city tried to sell just
100 tax-delinquent properties a month, and barely half those sales went through,
according to figures provided by the Sheriff's Department last year.

"We're not trying to move people out of their homes," Richardson said in an
interview. "We're just trying to get them to take seriously their responsibility
to the city and School District. . . . When people start to recognize we're
really serious, we'll get more people coming to us to work out payment
agreements."

The two men spoke in response to The Inquirer's report last week that described
Philadelphia's property-tax collection system as the least effective among the
nation's big cities.

More than 110,000 Philadelphia properties, nearly one in five, are delinquent,
their owners at least nine months overdue in paying their real estate tax bills.

The problem costs the city and School District millions of dollars in revenue -
$232 million in unpaid taxes, penalties, and interest over the last 10 years,
according to a Revenue Department report - and plays a major role in creating
and sustaining urban blight.

A national authority on property-tax collection systems, law professor Frank S.
Alexander of Emory University in Atlanta, described the city's delinquency
levels as "astronomical."

"Those numbers tell you there is a very high rate of nonenforcement," Alexander
said. "It means that the city has made a decision not to go after those
properties."

In an article in this issue of The Inquirer, Dubow and Richardson say the Nutter
administration views Philadelphia's legacy of tax delinquency and vacant
property as "one of the biggest challenges facing the city."

They say the city has already taken steps to strengthen tax collections and is
developing new policies to deal with vacant land, an effort involving multiple
city agencies, community-development corporations, private developers and City
Council.

In recent years, the bulk of real estate in sheriff sales has been foreclosed on
by lenders after owners failed to pay mortgages. The number of properties forced
into sheriff sales by the city because of unpaid real estate taxes has been
relatively small - although the totals are suspect because of record-keeping
problems at the Sheriff's Department, now under review by a variety of auditors,
law firms, and law enforcement agents.

Records provided last year by aides to John Green, the former sheriff, put the
number of tax-related sheriff sales at 128 properties in all of 2010, the lowest
figure in the last 11 years.

A Revenue Department database shows 224 tax-related sales in 2010, down from 257
in 2008 and 328 in 2009, Richardson said.

Those annual figures could be matched in a single month if the city follows
through with the expansion it promises.

Dubow said the small number of sheriff sales last year was attributable to two
factors: the tax amnesty program that represented the city's major revenue
thrust the first half of 2010, and the bookkeeping problems that consumed the
Sheriff's Department toward the end of the year, prompting a scathing audit by
City Controller Alan Butkovitz and a five-month suspension of sheriff sales
beginning in December.

The amnesty allowed delinquent taxpayers to settle balances for the original
taxes due, no penalties, and just half the calculated interest payments. The
program raised $73 million, about $24 million of that being delinquent property
taxes, according to the city.

As the amnesty program was ending in June 2010, the city promised tougher
collection efforts against delinquents who failed to take advantage of the
amnesty.

The threats included tripling the number of properties put up for sheriff sale
for unpaid taxes, from 200 a month to 600.

But data suggest the city didn't even get the monthly volume up to 200.

Contact staff writer Bob Warner

at 215-854-5885 or warnerb@phillynews.com.

                     Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)

                           November 1, 2007 Thursday
                                 SOONER EDITION

SECTION: LOCAL; EAST/CITY/STATE/WEST; Pg. B-2

LENGTH: 1587 words


EAST

State senator's son found delinquent

The son of state Sen. Bob Regola has been found delinquent by a judge in
Westmoreland County, KDKA-TV reported.

Citing anonymous sources, the station reported yesterday that Bobby Regola IV
was found delinquent in juvenile court. State police charged the youth with
illegal possession of a firearm following a coroner's inquest into the death of
a 14-year-old neighbor, Louis Farrell.

Louis Farrell was found dead with a gun that belonged to the senator near his
body. His death was ruled a suicide. He lived next door to the Regolas.

Mr. Regola, R-Hempfield, is awaiting trial on charges that he lied under oath at
a coroner's inquest into the death of Louis Farrell.

Indiana County thieves snatch $45,000 in jewels

Investigators were searching for smash-and-grab thieves who stole more than
$45,000 in diamonds from a mall in White Township, Indiana County.

Two men used a masonry hammer to smash the display case window at Lorelli's
Jewelry at Indiana Mall, state police in Indiana said.

The men took 18 rings, valued at $45,580, from the display and fled the store
with employees in pursuit.

The thieves were seen getting into a waiting car. The vehicle had been reported
stolen from a parking lot near the campus of Indiana University of Pennsylvania.
The owner of the car did not know of the auto theft until contacted by state
police.

State police asked anyone with knowledge about the theft or the suspects to call
the Indiana barracks at 724-357-1960.

Edgewood police chief to retire

Paul Wood, police chief in Edgewood for the last five years and a former chief
in Wilkinsburg, said yesterday that he's retiring.

Chief Wood, 65, said he and his wife will move to their lakefront home in South
Carolina. "It's time," he said. "I've been doing this for 45 years."

The chief told his 12 officers yesterday that he was leaving and mailed a
resignation letter to borough council.

He had been chief since 2002 after returning to Pennsylvania from Minnesota,
where he was the chief of police in Roseville, a Minneapolis suburb.

A native of Hagerstown, Md., he worked as a police officer there for more than
30 years, including eight as the chief. He then became chief in Wilkinsburg from
1993 to 1996 before moving to Minnesota.

The Wilkinsburg department earned national honors under his leadership.

Motorcycle crash kills IUP student

A college student died in surgery Tuesday night after a crash between his
motorcycle and a pickup truck in Homer City, Indiana County, police said.

Mark Dushok, 21, of Luzerne County, died at 11:23 p.m. during emergency surgery
at Conemaugh Memorial Medical Center, Homer City Police Chief Lou Sacco said.

Mr. Dushok, a student at Indiana University of Pennsylvania, was riding his
motorcycle north on Route 119 in Homer City when a southbound pickup truck made
a left turn at Route 56 into the bike's path, Chief Sacco said.

The truck driver, William Stiles, 74, of Blairsville, was not injured.

Second man arrested in Wilkinsburg shooting

A second suspect has been apprehended in the Oct. 6 robbery of a man who shot
and wounded two of the suspects.

Tyree Allen, 23, of White Oak, was to be arraigned today on charges of robbery,
reckless endangerment, conspiracy and a weapons violation.

Mr. Allen, police said, was one of three people who tried to rob a Wilkinsburg
man at gunpoint when he tried to make an illegal drug buy.

When the suspected drug dealer grabbed the man from behind and put a pistol to
his head, the victim fought to get free, falling backward out of his car onto
the ground.

The victim and the suspected dealer then began firing their weapons, police
said.

Mr. Allen and a woman whom police say helped him in the robbery fled, although
the woman, Lolitta Irvin, 20, also was wounded.

The third suspect, identified by police as Lamont Frazier, 20, of Garfield, also
was wounded in the fracas. However, before he had been identified as a suspect,
he was treated at a hospital and disappeared.

Mr. Frazier still was being sought, police said.

A preliminary hearing for Ms. Irvin is scheduled Nov. 1 before District Judge
Kim Hoots in Wilkinsburg.

Missing Indiana County woman found dead

An Indiana County woman missing since Friday was found dead in Westmoreland
County yesterday.

Authorities discovered the body of Christina Michelle Sandolfini, 32, of
Saltsburg, in a wooded area of Derry about a half-mile south of Bush Road near
Route 981 at around 3:30 p.m.

Ms. Sandolfini was last seen at about 8:50 a.m. Friday near the Mannito Golf
Course in Derry, not far from where her body was discovered.

At around 3:30 a.m., she was seen leaving Westmoreland Hospital in Greensburg
after visiting her husband, who was a patient there. State police were
continuing to investigate her death.

CITY

Accused child predator arrested after trick-or-treat

County sheriff's deputies arrested an accused child predator last night while he
was trick-or-treating with his children.

Vernon Duncan, 31, of Mount Oliver, was wanted since September for involuntary
deviate sexual intercourse and other charges of sexually assaulting a child,
police said.

The sheriff's office learned from Mr. Duncan's neighbors in the 100 block of
Penn Avenue in Mount Oliver that he entered a vehicle last night with four
children and his girlfriend.

Deputies located Mr. Duncan at a fast food restaurant on the 1800 block of East
Carson Street in the South Side, arresting him without incident. He was held in
Allegheny County Jail awaiting arraignment last night.

Volunteers sought for Beechview cleanup

Allegheny CleanWays needs volunteers Saturday from 9 a.m. to noon to help clear
debris -- including more than 100 tires -- from the western portion of the
Beechview-Seldom Seen Greenway near Route 51.

The event is being staged at the parking lot of Vanucci Park off Orangewood
Avenue in Beechview.

The greenway of 90 acres of wooded hillside and valleys was established on
public land in July 1985.

Allegheny CleanWays will provide gloves and other equipment, refreshments and
lunch. Contact Mary Wilson or Myrna Newman at 412-381-1301 to volunteer.

Monongahela Incline to close Sunday for work

The Monongahela Incline will close for routine maintenance from 8:45 a.m. until
5 p.m. Sunday.

Port Authority will operate shuttle bus service between the upper and lower
stations of the incline during the closure. The Mon Incline will resume service
at 5 p.m. and operate until its midnight closure.

Downtown Farmers Market open till next week

The Downtown Farmers Market will remain open today and next Thursday because of
the warm weather. The market is open from 10:30 a.m. to 2 p.m.

Consultant begins study of city neighborhoods

A Philadelphia-based consultant started a study of city of Pittsburgh
neighborhoods yesterday, with the goal of providing detailed data and guidance
on development investment.

Mayor Luke Ravenstahl introduced The Reinvestment Fund at a news conference that
announced the start of the $35,000 study funded by the Urban Redevelopment
Authority and the Surdna Foundation.

"We have to ensure that we are investing our limited resources wisely," said Mr.
Ravenstahl. TRF's data will allow the city to rebuild "using hard data, instead
of politics" to steer limited funds.

Ira Goldstein of TRF said his organization will drive through every
neighborhood, talk with community advocates and comb data on housing, vacancies,
abandonment, foreclosures and more.

The work is expected to be complete in January.

STATE

House OKs statewide effort to curb greenhouse gases

The state House yesterday approved a Pennsylvania Greenhouse Gas Reduction Act
that would require an inventory of heat trapping emissions and development of a
statewide tracking and reduction plan.

Citizens for Pennsylvania's Future, a statewide environmental group, said in a
press release that the legislation is "the coolest thing the House of
Representatives has ever done."

House Bill 110, sponsored by Rep. Greg Vitali, D-Delaware, passed on a vote of
182-15. Bipartisan support was created through an amendment by Rep. Dave Reed,
R-Indiana, that clarified the goals of the legislation and guaranteed a diverse
group to advise the state Department of Environmental Protection on
implementation.

The Senate version of the legislation, Senate Bill 266, the Pennsylvania Global
Warming Act, has been amended and approved by the Environmental Resources and
Energy Committee. No vote of the full Senate has been scheduled.

Pennsylvania emits 1 percent of the world's greenhouse gases -- more than 105
developing countries combined. Twenty-eight states have already passed climate
action plan legislation.

"Cutting our global warming pollution by conserving energy, using more wind and
solar energy and pioneering new energy technologies presents a tremendous
economic opportunity," said John Hanger, PennFuture's president and chief
executive officer.

WEST

Testimony to conclude in federal death penalty case

Testimony was expected to conclude today in the penalty phase of the federal
case against Jelani Solomon.

He was convicted last week of ordering the shooting death of Frank Helisek Jr.,
53, of New Brighton in January 2004.

The jury must decide if Mr. Solomon, 28, of Beaver Falls, should be executed,
spend the rest of his life in prison, or some other amount of time.

Mr. Solomon paid Claron Hanner in cocaine and cash to shoot Mr. Helisek to
protect his drug enterprise and retaliate against Mr. Helisek's son, Shawn.

Shawn Helisek was cooperating with the state attorney general's office in a drug
investigation of Mr. Solomon.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             237 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                       Grand Forks Herald (North Dakota)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            August 1, 2007 Wednesday

Law changes period to pay delinquent taxes

BYLINE: Stephen J. Lee, Grand Forks Herald, N.D.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 478 words


Aug. 1--Beginning this year, property owners in North Dakota will have only
three years instead of five years to pay delinquent property taxes before the
county can take over the property.

This means, come 2010, some property owners may have taxes five years and three
years delinquent at once -- the taxes for 2005 and, under the new law, for 2007
-- meaning they would have to pay two years' worth of taxes and penalty and
interest to keep the county from taking ownership of the property, not just one
year.

This past spring, along with that change, the Legislature gave counties a way to
help taxpayers avoid that possible double whammy by allowing a two-month grace
period. So, beginning today and running until Oct. 1, Grand Forks County will
waive all penalty and interest costs on delinquent property taxes paid in full.

All counties are not giving taxpayers that window of opportunity, said Debbie
Nelson, auditor and director of finance and taxes for Grand Forks County.

But Grand Forks County Commissioners decided to do it, and Nelson said some
people already have sent in checks.

Penalty and interest costs, on average, tend to total about 12 percent of the
actual tax bill, so there are real savings, Nelson said.

For example, there are $5.17 million in delinquent property taxes in the county,
she said. The interest and penalties on top of that total add up to $643,925,
Nelson said. If every one of those property owners took advantage of this grace
period, they could save a collective $643,925.

So, her advice is: If you owe property taxes, now is a good time to pay them and
get a pass on paying the penalties and interest.

That could include taxes due for the year 2002 through the first half of 2006,
she said.

Nelson said county auditors pushed for the legislation, which the Legislature
passed overwhelmingly. The idea is that decreasing the time allowed to pay
delinquent taxes before the county takes over ownership of the property will
help keep the tax bills from mounting to a point where property owners can't pay
them off, Nelson said.

Nelson recently published a list of about 70 property owners in the county
delinquent on five years of taxes: unless the first year is paid soon, the
property will become the county's and sold. The taxes due range from about $50
to nearly $7,000.

She sent out notices of the two-month grace period to about 1,700 of the
county's 30,000 property owners; they are the ones with some delinquent taxes.

To see more of the Grand Forks Herald, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.grandforks.com. Copyright (c) 2007, Grand Forks Herald, N.D.
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                                 The Bond Buyer

                             March 30, 2009 Monday

Ohio Port Authorities' Bond Funds Face Delinquent Borrowers

BYLINE: Caitlin Devitt

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 28 Vol. 367 No. 33095

LENGTH: 656  words


CHICAGO - At least three of Ohio's six port authority bond fund programs are
grappling with delinquent borrowers who are struggling to repay loans from the
funds in the declining economy.

The possibility of increasing loan defaults prompted Fitch Ratings to place all
six bond funds on rating watch late last year. On Friday, Fitch cut its rating
two notches to BBB-minus, the lowest investment grade credit, from BBB-plus on
the Toledo-Lucas County Port Authority's Northwest Ohio Bond Fund, noting that
two of its borrowers are delinquent and that the weak economy could imperil
other borrowers.

The downgrade comes two weeks after Fitch cut its implied revenue bond rating to
BBB-minus from BBB on the Cleveland-Cuyahoga County Port Authority. Its actual
bond fund remains on credit watch negative. The downgrade was largely due to the
authority's internal finances, but analysts noted that the bond fund program is
dealing with one delinquent borrower as well as declining revenues.

In its downgrade on the Toledo-Lucas County authority's bond fund program last
week, Fitch said it was concerned about the economy's impact on the borrowers'
ability to make timely repayments to the fund. Of the program's 23 borrowers,
two are currently delinquent. The fund has a total of $87.5 million in
outstanding bonds.

Paul Toth, interim president of the Toledo-Lucas County Port Authority, said he
was confident the fund's late borrowers would make full payments by May 15, when
the debt service payment is due. "None of our borrowers have ever missed a bond
payment even if they have missed monthly payments," he said.

The delinquent borrowers - both trucking businesses - suffered "temporary
cash-flow problems" and have promised to make full payments in the coming weeks,
Toth said. "We don't believe the bond fund merited the downgrade, but of course
we're biased, as in 20 years of history we've always stepped in and dealt with
any late payments."

If the borrowers were unable to make a debt service payment, the authority would
dip into its reserves, which total $28.1 million, or 32% of the bonds
outstanding, Toth said. "The bondholder wouldn't even know if these guys missed
a [bond] payment because it would be cured."

Fitch is expected to soon release rating updates on the Cleveland-Cuyahoga
County and Summit County port authorities' bond fund programs. Both the BBB-plus
rated programs, which are on rating watch negative, are also dealing with
delinquent borrowers.

Officials at the Cleveland-Cuyahoga County authority are optimistic that payment
problems with its borrower, Universal Heat Treating Inc., will be short term and
that its May 15 debt service payment will be met. "There's a system of reserves
in the program, or the port's auxiliary reserves, or the borrower could make
good on past due payments," said the authority's chief financial officer Brent
Leslie.

Another possible headache is a borrower that recently landed in receivership
after missing payments on an $81 million commercial mortgage loan.

A federally appointed receiver took over City View Center LLC in late February
and is currently deciding whether to sell the property, a retail mall.

The Cleveland-Cuyahoga County and Summit County port authorities in 2004 issued
a total of nearly $12 million of bonds to finance the project. The bonds are
backed by property taxes generated from the center, which is located in a tax
increment financing district.

The commercial loan trustee, the Bank of New York Mellon, made a recent $1.3
million property tax payment, and the payments are currently up to date, Leslie
said. "We're pretty confident that the debt service through May 2011 is taken
care of, and we're still assessing the situation."

The BBB-plus ratings of three additional bond fund programs - the
Dayton-Montgomery County Port Authority, the Lorain County Port Authority, and
the Columbus-Franklin County Finance Authority - are on rating watch evolving.

URL: http://www.bondbuyer.com/

                             239 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                   November 1, 1995, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION

Heart, sweat rates may be tip to delinquency

BYLINE: Tim Friend

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 193 words


A sluggish nervous system may be at the root of thuggish behavior, suggests new
research out today.

Heart rates and sweat rates, markers for arousal levels of the autonomic nervous
system, are slower in juvenile delinquents who turn to crime as adults than in
normal adolescents and delinquents who straighten up, says UCLA psychologist
Adrian Raine.

"Burglarizing a house, beating up other people or stealing things may be like a
shot of adrenaline, a way to get their arousal levels up to normal," he says.

Raine tested 51 English boys, all of whom were 15 in 1978. Two-thirds of the
boys were juvenile delinquents.

Raine checked for criminal records by age 29 and whether there was an
association with the original test. He found:

Heart rate of delinquents who became adult criminals was an average nine beats
per minute slower than delinquents and non-delinquents with no crimes as adults.

Sweat rates were three times slower among criminals than non-criminals.

Raine says testing of children may predict who is at risk for criminal behavior.
Giving biofeedback to increase arousal levels may divert a child from
delinquency and crime.

LOAD-DATE: November 02, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 1995 Gannett Company, Inc.


                             240 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                             National Mortgage News

                               November 27, 1989

New England Real Estate Market Drop Batters Thrifts' Balance Sheets

BYLINE: By JEFFREY N. TUCHMAN, NTMN Correspondent

SECTION: REAL ESTATE; Pg. 26

LENGTH: 915 words

DATELINE: BOSTON


New England's real estate market, which in the last 12 months has battered the
balance sheets of the region's financial institutions, has worsened to such an
extent that capital levels in the first Federal Home Loan Bank district are
expected to decline significantly in the second half.

This comes at a time when more onerous capital regulations leave the district's
members $ 310 million below Federal requirements.

Analysts say capital as a percentage of assets, which at mid- year stood at 5.4%
for district members, will drop in the third and fourth quarters.

"If New England thrifts were forced to mark non-performing assets to market
(liquidation value), writeoffs could reach 40-50%," Gerard S. Cassidy, first
vice president, Tucker Anthony, Portland, Maine, said.

"As it is, regulators will force thrifts to raise reserves to the 30%-35% level,
which could mean a reduction in capital over time of up to 20%."

A 20% reduction in capital would plunge district levels to 4.32% of assets.

Henry S. Peltz, vice president, Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, said regulators from
the Office of Thrift Suypervision, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., and the
state banking commissioners offices "are vying with one another to be tougher
than the other.  The outlook is somber at best."

Writedowns for non-performing assets already have had a severe impact on
earnings, Mr. Peltz said.

"Up to now, it's mostly been an income hit," he pointed out.

"Then the regulators come in, force the institutions to increase their loan loss
provisions, and then it's a capital hit."

Figures on delinquent assets and capital reserves compiled by W.C. Ferguson &
Co., Irving, Texas, show a 149% increase in loans 60-days past due during the
first two quarters at 96 thrift institutions in the first Federal Home Loan Bank
District.

Delinquent loans increased from $ 722 million in the first quarter to $ 1.8
billion in the second quarter.

Non-performing loans at 357 savings banks insured by the Federal Deposit
Insurance Corp. increased 46% in the second quarter to $ 1.9 billion.

Loans 60-days past due at the 96 district thrifts increased from 1% of assets in
the first quarter to 2.6% of assets in the second.

Thirteen institutions in the first quarter had more delinquent loans than GAAP
capital, while 17 thrifts had more 60-day delinquencies than capital in the
second quarter.

The 357 FDIC-insured institutions, which have a GAAP capital ratio of more than
9% of assets, have reserves equal to 36% of non-accruals.

While increases in non-performing loans will require significant increases in
reserves, capital levels are not immediately threatened.

This is not the case among the 96 FHLB member loans, whose GAAP capital is 5.4%
of assets.

Loan loss reserves at these institutions is believed to be below 30%.

Analysts expect a 25%-50% increase in delinquent loans in both the third and
fourth quarters.  This would bring delinquent loans from $ 1.8 billion at
mid-year to about $ 3.3 billion by year-end.

Roughly 80% of the district's delinquent loans will become non-performing, which
will cause regulators to force institutions to increase writedowns and reserves
significantly.

Reserves likely will come out of capital, since the district's earnings have
been meager this year.

Return on assets were a scant 0.03% in the June 30 quarter.

Capital, measured by generally accepted accounting principles, has held steady
in the first half at the $ 3.7 billion level, or 5.4% of assets.

Complicating the deteriorating situation are the risk-based capital regulations,
under which thrifts must hold risk-adjusted capital of 6.4% of assets by Dec. 7.

New England thrifts altered their balance sheets in 1987, moving from home
mortgage lending, which requires the least amount of risk-adjusted capital, to
commercial real estate, construction, and commercial loans, which require the
most.

Commercial real estate, condos and construction projects in foreclosure have
been difficult to move in the last year, as buyers have retreated in the face of
a deepening New England recession.

Commercial banks have been writing down 20-25% of their non-performing assets,
and thrifts likely will do the same after a wave of examinations in the next two
months.

But even single-family homes in foreclosure, which once could be sold for full
value "on the courthouse steps," now get only 65-75 cents on the dollar,
according to James Moynihan, senior vice president, Advest Inc., Boston.

"The buyers are just not there," he said.  Mr. Cassidy of Tucker Anthony said
that while empirical evidence shows only a 1-3% decline in New England's home
prices, "anecdotal evidence shows prices down 10-30%."
1st FHLB District Thrifts

                      1st Qtr      2nd Qtr
                        1989         1989
Assets               $ 69.3 Bil.  $ 68.8 Bil.

Delinquent Loans      $ 722 Mil.   $ 1.8 Bil.

Delinquent Loans
as % of Assets                1%         2.6%
GAAP Capital          $ 3.7 Bil.   $ 3.7 Bil.
GAAP Capital
as % of Assets              5.3%         5.4%

Delinquent Loans
as % of Capital              20%          49%

(96 Institutions)
Source: Ferguson & Co.

                         1st Qtr     2nd Qtr

Non-Performing Loans    $ 1.3 Bil.  $ 1.9 Bil.

Non-Performing Loans
as % of Assets                1.2%        1.7%
GAAP Capital             $ 10 Bil.   $ 10 Bil.

                        Glendale News-Press (California)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            December 12, 2011 Monday

Local businesses on delinquent taxpayer list

BYLINE: Mark Kellam, Glendale News-Press, Calif.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 438 words


Dec. 12--TWO BURBANK BUSINESSES -- an investment firm and a tire company -- have
been added to the state's list of delinquent taxpayers, which also includes
several Glendale enterprises that have remained there for several years.

The California State Board of Equalization's report for the fourth quarter of
2011 lists the Winston Tire Co. and Investment on Financial Capital Inc. in
Burbank as owing $1.69 million and $1.71 million, respectively.

The board releases a quarterly list of the top 250 delinquent businesses that
owe more than $100,000 in taxes to the state.

The Burbank firms were two of 16 businesses added to the latest list, which
totals $419.5 million in tax liens -- this at a time when lower-than-expected
mid-year budget figures have triggered another round of budget cutting in
Sacramento.

The Alameda Avenue address listed for Winston Tire now houses Fotokem, a film
post-production company that has been at the site for about seven years,
according to employee Ann Nakamoto.

The address on Flower Street where Investment on Financial Capital reportedly
was located was locked late Monday afternoon. There was no sign on the door
indicating a business name.

A woman who answered the phone at a number listed for the firm on Tuesday said
she didn't know anything about back taxes, but when asked to speak with a
supervisor, she hung up the phone.

USN Television Group in Glendale was added to the state list last March for
owing about $730,000. Its address on Colorado Street is now home to Arecont
Vision, manufacturer of surveillance cameras and software.

Four other alleged scofflaws have been on the delinquent taxpayer list for
several years, including Vegas Truck Stop, Continental Homecare Inc., which
filed for bankruptcy in 2008, and Ara Lousinian -- all in Glendale -- and
Aslanyan and Kocoglu Inc. in Burbank.

Board of Equalization spokeswoman Cristina Herrera said her agency doesn't have
a timeline to gauge when more aggressive collection measures, such as seizing
assets, should be taken, but the debtors are tracked.

"Everyone leaves a trace [electronically]," she said.

Each delinquent taxpayer is reviewed on a case-by-case basis, she added.

Taxpayers can have their names removed from the list if they pay their bills,
agree to a payment plan or have their tax lien lifted through bankruptcy.

The quarterly list of delinquent businesses will grow to the top 500 in January,
in accordance with recent state legislation, Herrera said.

MAINTENANCE ASSOCIATION under said Notice of Delinquent Assessment heretofore
executed and delivered to the undersigned a written Declaration of Default and
Demand for Sale, and a written Notice of Default and Election to Sell. The
undersigned caused said Notice of Default and Election to Sell to be recorded in
the county where the real property is located and more than three months have
elapsed since such recordation. NOTICE TO POTENTIAL BIDDERS: If you are
considering bidding on this property lien, you should understand that there are
risks involved in bidding at a trustee auction. You will be bidding on a lien,
not on the property itself. Placing the highest bid at a trustee auction does
not automatically entitle you to free and clear ownership of the property. You
should also be aware that the lien being auctioned off may be a junior lien. If
you are the highest bidder at the auction, you are or may be responsible for
paying off all liens senior to the lien being auctioned off, before you can
receive clear title to the property. You are encouraged to investigate the
existence, priority, and size of outstanding liens that may exist on this
property by contacting the county recorder's office or a title insurance
company, either of which may charge you a fee for this information. If you
consult either of these resources, you should be aware that the same lender may
hold more than one mortgage or deed of trust on the property. NOTICE TO PROPERTY
OWNER: The sale date shown on this notice of sale may be postponed one or more
times by the mortgagee, beneficiary, trustee, or a court, pursuant to Section
2924g of the California Civil Code. The law requires that information about
trustee sale postponements be made available to you and to the public, as a
courtesy to those not present at the sale. If you wish to learn whether your
sale date has been postponed, and, if applicable, the rescheduled time and date
for the sale of this property, you may call FOR SALE INFORMATION, PLEASE CALL
(855)986-9342, or visit this Internet Web site www.superiordefault.com  using
the file number assigned to this case 2016-1234 . Information about
postponements that are very short in duration or that occur close in time to the
scheduled sale may not immediately be reflected in the telephone information or
on the Internet Web site. The best way to verify postponement information is to
attend the scheduled sale. THE PROPERTY IS BEING SOLD SUBJECT TO THE NINETY DAY
RIGHT OF REDEMPTION CONTAINED IN CIVIL CODE SECTION 5715(b). PLEASE NOTE THAT WE
ARE A DEBT COLLECTOR AND ARE ATTEMPTING TO COLLECT A DEBT AND ANY INFORMATION WE
OBTAIN WILL BE USED FOR THAT PURPOSE. Date: 10/03/2016. S.B.S LIEN SERVICES,
31194 La Baya Drive, Suite 106, Westlake Village, California, 91362. By: Annissa

                             244 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                            Mortgage Servicing News

                                 February 2013

Shadow Inventory Supply Through October At Seven Months

BYLINE: Evan Nemeroff

SECTION: MANAGING REO; Pg. 18 Vol. 17 No. 02

LENGTH: 455  words


The current stock of foreclosed and real estate owned properties deemed to be
shadow inventory but not yet ready to sell on the open market as of October 2012
fell on an annual basis.

According to CoreLogic, the October residential shadow inventory level was 2.3
million units, representing a supply of seven months. This is a 12.3% drop from
a year ago, when shadow inventory stood at 2.6 million units.

In July, the pending supply was also 2.3 million residential units, but a
six-month supply.

Out of the 2.3 million shadow inventory properties nationwide through October,
more than 1 million are seriously delinquent and not yet foreclosed upon, which
is approximately a 3.3-month supply.

Additionally, 903,000 are in some stage of foreclosure, representing a 2.8-month
supply, while 354,000 are already in REO, resulting in a 1.1-month supply.

"The size of the shadow inventory continues to shrink from peak levels. We
expect a gradual and progressive contraction in the shadow inventory in 2013 as
investors continue to snap up foreclosed and REO properties and the broader
recovery in housing market fundamentals takes hold," said Anand Nallathambi,
president and CEO of CoreLogic.

CoreLogic estimates pending supply by calculating the number of properties that
are seriously delinquent, in foreclosure and held as REO by mortgage servicers
but not currently listed on multiple listing services. The Irvine, Calif.-based
analytic firm said the latest shadow inventory figures represent 85% of the 2.7
million properties currently seriously delinquent, in foreclosure or in REO.

Serious delinquencies-which are the main driver of the shadow inventory-declined
the most in Arizona (13.3%), California, 9.7%), Michigan (6.8%) and Wyoming
(5.9%).

Meanwhile, Florida, California, Illinois, New York and New Jersey made up 45% of
the properties that were seriously delinquent, in foreclosure or in REO over the
three months ending in October 2012. A year ago, these same states accounted for
51.3% of all distressed mortgages that were in REO, foreclosure, or at least 90
days delinquent.

The October 2012 dollar volume of shadow inventory was $376 billion, down from
$399 billion during the same time period last year, CoreLogic stated.

Furthermore, CoreLogic said the pending supply of shadow inventory is manageable
in 2013 and won't have a major effect on the supply and demand of the housing
market.

"Given the long foreclosure timelines in many states, the current shadow
inventory stock represents little immediate threat to a significant swing in
housing market supply," said Mark Fleming, chief economist for CoreLogic.
"Investor demand will help to absorb the already foreclosed and REO properties
in the shadow inventory in 2013."

URL: http://www.mortgageservicingnews.com/

LOAD-DATE: February 1, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newsletter

JOURNAL-CODE: MSN

                             245 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           The Philadelphia Inquirer

                              June 10, 2012 Sunday
                                  WEB Edition

Property-tax delinquents owe city, schools $515.4M.

BYLINE: By Patrick Kerkstra Patrick Kerkstra is a freelance journalist and
former Inqui

SECTION: NEWS; P-com Opinion; Pg. WEB

LENGTH: 1259 words


Philadelphia property-tax delinquents piled up an additional $43.8 million in
new debt over the last year, increasing the total amount owed to the city and
School District to $515.4 million, an increase of 9.3 percent in a single year,
city records show.

There are now about 103,000 tax-delinquent properties in Philadelphia. About 18
percent of all parcels in the city are in arrears. As documented in an
Inquirer/PlanPhilly series in August, no other big city in the nation approaches
that level of property-tax delinquency.

Past-due property taxes have long been a contentious issue in Philadelphia, but
the growing pot of delinquent cash has attracted more attention than usual in
recent months.

That's because City Council and Mayor Nutter have enacted two straight
property-tax hikes in two years, and are considering a citywide property
reassessment that would collect an additional $94 million. Meanwhile, the School
District of Philadelphia, which relies on property taxes for 80 percent of its
local funding, is in the midst of perhaps the worst financial crisis in its
history.

The School Reform Commission, Council members, activists, and residents have
been clamoring for the city to do a better job of collecting delinquent property
taxes, both to throw a lifeline to the schools and to limit tax hikes on the
majority of property owners who pay their share.

"The numbers speak for themselves. It's ludicrous: half-a-billion in revenue
still on the table, and more of it every day," said State Sen. Michael Stack
(D., Phila.), one of a growing number of critics.

The Nutter administration has heard the complaints.

"The Revenue Department is not insensitive to the shortcomings of the present
real estate tax-collection system, and over the past few years, we have taken
steps to improve that system," revenue commissioner Keith Richardson said during
City Council testimony last week.

By some measures, the situation is improving. The city is on track to meet its
budgeted delinquent-collection goals. And the administration has reduced the
number of delinquent accounts by more than 8,000 in a single year.

But by the most critical and basic standard &mdash; the total amount owed the
city and schools &mdash; the delinquency epidemic continues to grow, as it has
throughout Nutter's administration. An Inquirer/PlanPhilly analysis of city
records shows that between 2009 and April 30, 2012, the debt owed by
property-tax deadbeats, including principal, interest, and penalties, has
increased by 21.3 percent, from $425 million to $515.4 million.

"They're not even treading water. They're falling behind," said Councilman Bill
Green, who has proposed a bill that would overhaul the way the city collects
delinquent property taxes.

The Problem

Mass property-tax delinquency has been the norm in Philadelphia for at least 20
years. And in their more candid moments, city officials suggest that may always
be the case.

"This is a very poor city, and there are a lot of areas with a lot of tax
delinquencies," said Frances R. Beckley, chief counsel to the Revenue
Department. "There's a chunk of this, that, if you were to be realistic, you're
never going to do anything with."

Yet no other big city, including communities with far worse poverty rates, such
as Detroit and Cleveland, has a delinquency rate as high as Philadelphia's.

Elsewhere, delinquent property owners are given a hard deadline, typically no
more than a year or two, to settle their accounts. If the deadline passes
without a resolution, delinquent property owners often automatically lose their
land, usually at sheriff's auction or to a government-run land bank.

But in Philadelphia, many tax-delinquent properties are left to languish for
years, even decades, without being subjected to meaningful enforcement action.
The average amount owed on tax-delinquent properties is $5,000, and the typical
delinquent is seven years past due. More than 13,000 properties are 15 or more
years behind, including more than 2,100 parcels that are at least 30 years
delinquent.

The effects of so many long-term delinquencies go beyond lost revenue. Tax-
delinquent properties are at least 4.5 times as likely to be vacant as
properties whose owners are current on their taxes, a recent Inquirer/PlanPhilly
analysis of public data found. And vacant properties spread blight, depress
property values, and cost the city millions annually in maintenance.

Potential Fixes

Harrisburg and City Council are considering bills that would reinvent the city's
system for collecting delinquent taxes. The proposed reforms would compel the
city to foreclose on delinquent properties after one year of nonpayment. The
parcels could be sold at sheriff's auction or put in a land bank (which would
require additional legislation also under consideration at the city and state
levels). The locally drafted ordinance would also make it easier for tax
delinquents to get into compliance through payment plans.

Councilman Green, who is co-sponsoring the overhaul with Councilwoman Maria
Qui&ntilde;ones S&aacute;nchez, said the system needs certain and hard-and-fast
rules.

In the administration's view, Green's bill combines a too-lenient payment plan
with an overly harsh crackdown on those who can't or won't pay. City officials
also worry about the city's legal exposure if it were forced to bank tens of
thousands of delinquent properties, many of which are vacant, that nobody wanted
at sheriff's auction.

That reasoning aggravates land-bank supporters, who contend that the city is
responsible for the problems delinquent parcels create, regardless of who
formally holds title.

"When people look at a vacant house, they see it as the city's problem,"
S&aacute;nchez said.

Where the private market is weak, "the city should be acquiring these abandoned
delinquent properties, clearing titles, and creating an assemblage that could
lead to faster development," S&aacute;nchez said.

This redevelopment-centered approach to delinquency enforcement runs counter to
the Nutter administration's view.

"We don't think being the largest owner of delinquent property should be the
goal," city Finance Director Rob Dubow said, noting that the city already owns
more vacant land than it can manage. "Our goal here is to get paid."

To that end, the administration has a series of new initiatives under way or in
the works, including:


A bureaucratic reshuffling designed to give one department &mdash; Revenue
&mdash; clear responsibility for delinquencies.

Hiring a second collection agency to pursue delinquent properties.

Targeting landlords with multiple delinquencies for aggressive enforcement.

Prioritizing nuisance properties for sheriff's sale and denying problem
landlords the convenience of payment agreements.

Earlier dunning of property owners, starting with a phone call shortly after
payment is due (March 31).

But the city's claims of progress are hard to reconcile with the fast-growing
debt ($43.8 million in a single year) property-tax delinquents owe.

Asked what was preventing the city from doing more, Richardson said the
delinquency pool was not as large as it seemed. For instance, more than 10,000
properties are caught up in bankruptcy proceedings, and thus cannot be
foreclosed upon, he said. And 11,000 are subject to payment plans.

That leaves about 80,000 properties for the city to go after.

Contact Patrick Kerkstra at patrick@patrickkerkstra.com or follow on Twitter
@pkerkstra.

A searchable interactive map of the city's delinquent properties is at
philly.com/delinquent2012

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                   The Times-Tribune (Scranton, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           September 24, 2010 Friday

Lackawanna County tax sale recoups $192,000 in delinquent taxes

BYLINE: Charles Schillinger, The Times-Tribune, Scranton, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 306 words


Sept. 24--An upset tax sale this week recouped almost $192,000 in back taxes for
Lackawanna County, schools and municipalities, and will allow hundreds of
properties to be brought to judicial sale in five months.

The Lackawanna County Tax Claim Bureau put up for auction 340 properties Monday
as part of its upset tax sale that targets delinquents. Buyers purchased 54 of
the properties, a fifth of which were in Scranton.

The annual upset sale is not as successful as a judicial sale, which auctions
tax delinquent properties that are free of liens. Before a property can go to a
judicial sale, it must first be offered in an upset sale.

Properties that survived the upset sale will be scheduled for a judicial sale
anticipated for Feb. 14, said tax claims bureau deputy director Ron Koldjeski.
Including other properties, he said he expects more than 350 properties to be
brought to judicial sale.

In a judicial sale in February, the tax claim office advertised 215 parcels for
sale and, after many paid their taxes, 65 were brought to auction, selling for
about $1.3 million.

Mr. Koldjeski said delinquents with properties that did not sell in Monday's
upset sale have until November to pay taxes.

Once paperwork on the properties is in the hands of lawyers, a $1,000 fee is
added to pay for legal preparation for the judicial sale.

Contact the writer: cschillinger @timesshamrock.com

                        The Augusta Chronicle (Georgia)

                           January 12, 2005 Wednesday
                              Correction Appended
                                  ALL EDITION

MAYOR FAVORS REBUKE ON DEBT

BYLINE: By Sylvia Cooper Staff Writer

SECTION: METRO; Pg. B01

LENGTH: 464 words


Mayor Bob Young wants to resurrect an old cartoon character from the old Augusta
Herald newspaper or something similar to shame residents who owe the city money
or won't keep their property up.

The character, who used to appear in top hat and tails rebuking negligent
property owners, was called Broadus Street.

"If there was a bad-looking piece of property, Broadus Street would be standing
there saying, 'Shame on these people,'" Mr. Young said. "It was great. We need
to get Broadus Street out of retirement."

In his State of the City address last week, Mr. Young proposed steps the
government should take to collect the money owed the city and force the owners
of rundown property to clean it up or face the consequences.

"First, I would charge the administrator, as one of his first tasks this year,
to identify all collectable accounts across the (city)," he said. "Those which
are determined to be uncollectable should be written off the books. Those which
are valid should be aggressively pursued by professional collection services."

Mr. Young also proposed an amnesty period, during which penalties and late
charges would be waived for those who paid, before turning the accounts over for
collection.

At last count, there was $14.09 million in delinquent property taxes on the
books, from 1997 through 2004, most of it - $8.07 million - from last year's
bills. The city receives about 40 percent of that amount, the school board about
59 percent and the state 0.75 percent, according to Jack McAdams, the chief
financial officer for the Richmond County Tax Commission.

About 1 percent of the total is uncollectable because the debtors have gone
bankrupt or left town with all their assets.

Also, $530,199 in delinquent residential garbage bills is on the tax office
books. Private trash haulers who use the Deans Bridge Road landfill owe a total
of $1.5 million.

Delinquent water and sewer bills total $831,043, more than half of which has
been turned over for collection, according to utility department officials.

Mr. Young decried the city's lack of a consistent policy on handling delinquent
accounts.

"We need a uniform policy in the organization," he said. "Some departments
charge interest. Some don't. Some charge penalties. Some don't. Some try to
collect. Some don't."

The tax commission charges a 10 percent penalty on all property tax bills when
they become delinquent, and the city charges 1 percent per month interest
thereafter.

The utility department charges a 10 percent per month late fee after the bill is
30 days delinquent, according to Steven J. Little, the assistant director of
finance and administration. The landfill charges 1.5 percent interest on
delinquent accounts.

Mr. Young also wants to crack down on property owners who allow their lots to
become overgrown.

LOAD-DATE: May 7, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CORRECTION-DATE: January 13, 2005



CORRECTION: To err is human. To turn over an erroneous list of delinquent water
and sewer accounts to be published in the newspaper is that principle at work in
the Augusta Utilities Department.

A list of delinquent accounts supplied to The Augusta Chronicle and published in
Wednesday's editions was the result of human error, said Steven J. Little, the
utility department's assistant director of finance.

An original computer file of accounts that were turned over to collections by
the utility department and later sent back from the collection agency was
incorrect, Mr. Little said.

"After the problem with the file was discovered and corrected by Augusta
Utilities, a revised file was created," he said.

So far, so good.

Then the erroneous file was sent to the newspaper from the utility department
and published.

Some of the customers listed as owing thousands in delinquent charges who
actually owed in the hundreds or less took exception.

"Augusta Utilities Department sincerely regrets the error and offers the
following list correcting the amounts reported yesterday, as well as a new
schedule of the largest amounts turned over to the collection agency by Augusta
Utilities through Dec. 10, 2004," Mr. Little stated in an e-mail Wednesday.

                        Cumberland Times-News (Maryland)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           November 18, 2014 Tuesday

Audit finds concerns at Uninsured Employer's Fund

BYLINE: Cumberland Times-News, Md.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 361 words


Nov. 18--CUMBERLAND -- An audit of the state fund which pays workers'
compensation awards to workers who did not receive payments from their employers
needs to do a better job of tracking and documenting its activities. The fund
pays the workers if their employers failed to procure workers' compensation
insurance as required by state law.

The Office of Legislative Audits released the audit report Friday. According to
the audit "for fiscal year 2013, income ... totaled approximately $8.8 million,
claim payments (indemnity and medical payments) totaled approximately $7.5
million, and operating expenses totaled approximately $1.2 million. UEF's
(Uninsured Employers Fund) fund balance as of December 31, 2013 totaled
approximately $11.3 million."

One audit funding was that the fund did not adequately monitor and pursue
collection of delinquent employer accounts. Collection notices were not sent out
as required by the state's collection unit, and delinquent accounts were not
routinely referred to the state collections units for additional collection
activity.

"As of October 7, 2013, based on our analysis of data from UEF's records, there
were 1,954 delinquent accounts totaling approximately $12.9 million that, based
on their age, should have been referred to CCU (Central Collections Unit) but
had not been referred. This included 57 delinquent accounts with balances
greater than $50,000 totaling approximately $7.1 million. As of October 7, 2013,
these accounts had been delinquent for periods ranging from 189 days to more
than 13 years. Delays in the pursuit of outstanding debts may decrease the
likelihood of collecting the funds," according to the audit.

In addition, the fund did not have a process to identify and refer delinquent
employers for the suspension of their licenses.

Security of the funds computer network was also inadequate, the auditors found.

Fund officials, in a response dated Oct. 24, agreed with the audit's findings
and said they will work to address the problems.

                             National Mortgage News

                               November 10, 2014

Insurers Radian, MGIC Lower Delinquencies in October

BYLINE: Colin Wilhelm

SECTION: SERVICING Vol. 1 No. 1

LENGTH: 157  words


Mortgage insurers Radian Guaranty Inc. and MGIC Investment Corp. both saw their
inventory of delinquent loans drop during October.

According to figures provided by Philadelphia-based Radian, the company entered
the month with 46,843 delinquencies, plus added 4,098 loans to the inventory
during the month. But the company was able to cure 3,676 of its delinquent
loans, and saw a little over 1,000 more come off its books thanks to claims
paid, rescissions and denials.

Radian finished October with 46,242 delinquent loans. The company wrote $3.75
billion in new insurance policies during the month.

MGIC, headquartered in Milwaukee, entered the month with 83,154 delinquencies
and there were 7,543 new loans added to the inventory. But the company reduced
its total through 6,564 cures, 1,704 payments, and 60 rescissions and denials,
ending the month with a total of 82,369 in delinquent loans. It wrote $3.3
billion of new policies during October.

                          Reading Eagle (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           August 17, 2011 Wednesday

Judge finds Birdsboro boy delinquent

BYLINE: Mary Young, Reading Eagle, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 412 words


Aug. 17--A 17-year-old Birdsboro boy who had been attending a Lancaster trade
school must spend at least six months in a residential program for juvenile
delinquents for punching a Birdsboro man outside a borough pizzeria.

Samuel Swavely of the 500 block of East Main Street will be transferred within
the next few days to the Youth Service Agency near Jim Thorpe in Carbon County
for the July 1 beating of Klint Howard, 42, on a parking lot near Vinnie's
Pizzeria & Restaurant.

Judge Timothy J. Rowley found Swavely delinquent on charges of aggravated and
simple assault and related offenses.

According to testimony by pizzeria workers, Andre Lubrano, the owner of the
pizzeria, asked Edward Kelly, age unavailable, of Birdsboro to leave because he
was cursing at Lubrano for not having the beer he wanted. Howard followed Kelly
outside, waving his arms.

They said Howard, a frequent customer, was protective of the workers.

One of the workers said she saw Swavely get out of Kelly's car and hit Howard
three times on the head.

Another worker said he saw the last punch that knocked Howard down.

Both said they saw Swavely lift Howard's head 6 to 8 inches off the ground and
drop it on the macadam.

Kelly testified that he stood by and watched as Howard grabbed Swavely's shirt,
ripped it, then hit Swavely.

He recalled Swavely saying that he lifted Howard's head to see whether Howard
was breathing and laid it down gently.

Kelly said Swavely is a friend of his girlfriend's daughter.

Howard suffered a severe head injury, officials said.

Roarke Aston, Swavely's Exeter Township attorney, argued that Swavely was
defending himself after Howard hit him and that the only witness who saw the
entire incident was Kelly.

Assistant District Attorney Bryan Boughter argued that when one of the workers
turned away for a few seconds, the other was watching.

Rowley said he did not find Kelly's testimony credible and believed the workers.
Swavely was safe in the car and became the aggressor when he got out of the car,
Rowley said.

Juvenile probation officials said Swavely's status will be re-evaluated in six
months.

                             251 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                February 5, 2000, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

New York's Tax Delinquents Appear at Click of a Mouse

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON

SECTION: Section B; Page 5; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 631 words


Combining a trendy new method (publication on the Internet) with the tried and
true (public humiliation), the city of New York this week tried to induce
delinquent taxpayers to settle up by listing them on the World Wide Web.

Nineteen companies -- and, in many cases, their officers -- that owe a total of
$9 million in various business taxes appear on the list, which was posted on
Tuesday at www.nyclink.org/finance. Some of the tax debts go back to the early
1990's, while the most recent dates to last March, said James Moses, a spokesman
for the Department of Finance.

One of the delinquents has already gotten in touch with the Department of
Finance to discuss paying its back taxes, Mr. Moses said, "so I guess you can
say it has been a success already." (He refused to disclose the name of the
company.) There are about 340 delinquent companies, Mr. Moses said, noting that
the city published the names of those that owe at least $100,000.

Several other governments, including Connecticut and Washington, D.C., have
posted the names of taxpayers who owe big sums.

In New York, few of the biggest debtors, several of whom owe more than $1
million in taxes and interest, are household names. Indeed, many appear to be
defunct.

That is the case with two related companies that, combined, have the biggest
debt on the list, according to a lawyer for one of their former partners,
Michael J. DeSola. The two companies, Murtha DeSola Finsilver Fiore Inc. and
DeSola Fiore Group, owe almost $1.4 million, according to the city.

"First of all, the companies disagreed with the city's determination at that
time, and to bring it up a decade later is really strange," said Arthur C.
Schupbach, a lawyer for Mr. DeSola, who since 1990 has run the DeSola Group, a
corporate consulting firm.

Others on the list are tied up in litigation. Martin W. Field and his daughter,
Laurel, were the principals in a partnership that built a Days Inn hotel near La
Guardia Airport.

A bank repossessed the hotel in 1992, Mr. Field said, and the parties have been
in court since, fighting about, among other things, who owes how much of the
back taxes.

The city says it is owed more than $1.2 million in hotel occupancy taxes; Mr.
Field says the amount owed is far less. And he complains that the publicity may
put a damper on his efforts to expand the two other airport hotels he owns in
Queens.

Even more obscure is Fanad Inc., a Brooklyn concern that the city says owes more
than $1 million in general corporate taxes.

According to state records, Fanad holds the liquor license for Smith's Bar and
Grill in Park Slope. Reached at the bar, Michael E. Brady, Fanad's chief
executive, would say only, "It's definitely a false thing."

Some of those whose names showed up on the city's list said they had no idea how
they got there. "I don't understand what's going on," said Maria DeCarvalhosa,
who the city says owes $891,000 in unincorporated business taxes. Reached on her
cellular phone, Ms. DeCarvalhosa declined to say whether she did business in the
city and said, "I think there is a mistake."

Dr. Miles Galin said he thought the tax troubles of his former partnership,
Galin/Boniuk M.D. P.C., had been settled years ago. His partner has retired, Dr.
Galin said, and while he does research, he no longer practices (his license was
revoked in 1997, according to the State Health Department).

The city has published his name, he complained, "to intimidate, to embarrass."

Probably the best-known name on the list belongs to the Taco Bell Corporation,
which the city says owes more than $580,000 in commercial rent tax. "We're
currently investigating it," said Laurie Gannon, a spokeswoman for the company
in Irvine, Calif. "We've never had anything like this happen before."

http://www.nytimes.com

                   The Times-Tribune (Scranton, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            February 21, 2014 Friday

Clarks Summit sewer delinquents face water shut-off

BYLINE: Michael Iorfino, The Times-Tribune, Scranton, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 331 words


Feb. 21--Clarks Summit property owners who have ignored repeated warnings to pay
their delinquent sewer bills could soon be without running water.

Borough officials this week sent letters and emails to longtime delinquent
ratepayers and posted notices on their doors informing them of Tuesday's
deadline to pay back at least some of what they owe. If property owners fail to
do so, borough Manager Virginia Kehoe will tell Pennsylvania American Water Co.
to shut off water at their properties.

"The water company will do the shut-offs after we give them all the paperwork,"
Ms. Kehoe said. "Wednesday would be the earliest it's turned off."

As many as a couple hundred ratepayers are delinquent, but borough officials are
focusing on property owners who haven't paid the bill -- $47 a month per
equivalent dwelling unit -- in months, council Vice President Dominic Scott
said.

Late last year, when the delinquent payments exceeded $100,000, officials issued
letters to at least 75 property owners who owed more than $746 in sewer
payments.

The number of delinquent accounts and the amount owed to the borough have
fluctuated in recent months, as Clarks Summit received as much as $40,000 in
delinquent payments, said Mr. Scott, chairman of the borough's sewer committee.

But some owners continued to ignore the notices, prompting officials to send a
follow-up letter notifying them they had 37 days to, at the very least, work
toward paying what they owed. The letters warned property owners that if they
continued to ignore the issue, officials would shut their water off.

"We really don't want to shut off their water, especially in the winter, but
what are you going to do?" Mr. Scott said. "How can you make these people pay?"

Anyone with questions can call 570-586-9316.

Contact the writer: miorfino@timesshamrock.com, @miorfinoTT on Twitter

                             253 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                      The Times-Tribune (Corbin, Kentucky)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           October 19, 2011 Wednesday

Whitley County attorney appointed

BYLINE: Sharae Myers, The Times-Tribune, Corbin, Ky.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 363 words


Oct. 19--CORBIN -- Don Moses was appointed and sworn in as the new Whitley
County attorney on Tuesday. Moses' appointment fills the vacancy left by the
recent appointment of Paul Winchester to the 34th Circuit Court judge's seat.

Whitley County Judge/Executive Pat White, who made the appointment, said he had
been approached by five or six interested candidates. It came down to Moses and
Bob Hammons, both of whom have previous experience in the county attorney's
office.

White said he chose Moses over Hammons because of a conflict of interest since
Hammons serves as the Corbin city attorney and is the brother-in-law to Corbin
Mayor Willard McBurney. White said both men "are capable, good gentlemen and
experienced members of the bar."

Before the appointment, White said issues were raised concerning delinquent
property and occupational taxes owed by Moses.

While Moses did not owe delinquent property taxes, White said he did owe
delinquent occupational taxes.

"I met with Moses and told him he couldn't have any delinquent taxes to be
considered for the position," White said.

White said Moses is now current on his occupational taxes.

White said Moses used to live in Tennessee and now has lived in Whitley County
long enough to meet residency requirements for the position. "Moses lives on
Beck's Creek Road, and I pass his house every day on my way home. He lives four
miles closer to town than I do," White said.

Moses said his main focus "is to do the best I can for all the people in Whitley
County, be fair and even-handed with all of them. These are my people."

Moses said he would be available for any citizen who wants to see him. "If I'm
not in court my door is open," Moses said, adding that if he isn't in, he will
return all calls.

Moses said his staff will remain in the courthouse, and he will continue to work
from    his Main Street office in Williamsburg.

"We will see a fairly seamless transition," Moses said.

Moses will serve until the May primary election.

He said he plans to run for the position at that time.

Ky.) at www.thetimestribune.com Distributed by MCT Information Services
