                     News-Journal (Daytona Beach, Florida)

                              May 12, 2003 Monday
                             Volusia Review Edition

County tax auction is set for May 30

BYLINE: Audrey Parente Staff Writer

SECTION: A; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 528  words


Delinquent Volusia County real estate property tax certificates totaling nearly
$20.5 million will be auctioned in the Thomas C. Kelly Administration Center,
123 West Indiana Ave., DeLand, at 9 a.m., May 30.

Revenue Director Bernard Kane said the number of parcels accounting for the
delinquencies total 21,432.

"The number has gone up about seven percent from last year, but there is no
apparent reason, and it might come down by the time we go to sale," Kane said.

A penalty of three percent is charged against delinquent taxes, and once the
auction list is published, a $5 advertising fee is tacked to each unpaid bill.

To avoid the auction, Kane said, delinquent payments plus the fee, must be made
to one of four county locations not later than 5 p.m. on May 29.

The locations are: 250 N. Beach St., Daytona Beach; 2744 Enterprise Rd., Orange
City; 123 W. Indiana Ave., Room 103, DeLand; and 111 Canal St., New Smyrna
Beach.

"Payments must be in our hands by the deadline. Postmarks will not be honored,"
Kane said.

Failure to meet the payment allows interested buyers to bid a particular
interest rate on the overdue taxes.

Once a tax-delinquent property certificate is auctioned, the property owner
would have to pay the amount of back taxes, the penalty, the advertising fee,
five percent commission, five percent interest and a $6.25 service charge
through Aug. 31.

If the owner has not paid the taxes and penalties after at least two years, the
certificate holder could seek a tax sale on the property. When the property is
sold, the certificate holder would receive his initial investment, plus the
total amount of interest due at the bid rate, plus expenses to take the property
to sale.

The certificate holder could also bid for ownership of the property at that
time.

Kane said the tax certificate sale is an effective incentive since the county
usually collects practically all delinquent property taxes as a result of this
procedure.

The tax collector's office also publishes a list of delinquent tangible property
taxes, including such items as business assets, mobile home attachments, rental
condo fixtures and other items.

There are 6,852 delinquent tangibles totaling nearly $1.7 million.

If payments of tangible property taxes are not made by May 30, warrants are
issued and later ratified. Once warrants are ratified, the tax collector has the
right to levy fines and seize property to sell for taxes.

Send questions to any of the four county locations.

Additional copies of Volusia County delinquent tax list, inside this issue, may
be obtained from Volusia Review news racks at the following locations:

DAYTONA BEACH: 901 Sixth St.; Justice Center, 251 N. Ridgewood Ave.; Courthouse,
125 Orange Ave.

ORMOND BEACH: Post Office, 145 W. Granada Blvd.

DELAND: News-Journal Office, 114 S. Alabama Ave.; N. Woodland Blvd. and W. Rich
Ave.; Potato Patch, 635 S. Woodland Blvd.

ORANGE CITY: Post Office, 260 Industrial Drive; News-Journal Bureau, 1107 Saxon
Blvd.; Perkins Restaurant, 1286 Saxon Blvd.

DELTONA: Post Office, 944 Deltona Blvd.

NEW SMYRNA BEACH: Courthouse, 124 Riverside Drive; News-Journal Office, 239
Canal St.

EDGEWATER: G Gas station, 115 N. Ridgewood Ave..

LOAD-DATE: July 30, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

JOURNAL-CODE: DBNJ

                Copyright 2003 ProQuest Information and Learning
                              All Rights Reserved
                               ProQuest SuperText
                    Copyright 2003 News-Journal Corporation


                             298 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                February 27, 1996, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

Threat to Driver's Licenses Leads to More Child Support

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

SECTION: Section B;  Page 4;  Column 1;  Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 675 words

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 26


New York State will start distributing a list of the 10 parents who owe the most
money in child support payments in hopes of putting more pressure on delinquent
parents, Gov. George E. Pataki said today.

The list is the latest measure by the Pataki administration to assure that
parents pay what they owe in child support. The Governor also announced today
that New York had collected nearly $2 million in child-support payments since it
began suspending the driver's licenses of chronic nonpayers.

In connection with his campaign to publicize the names of the 10 most delinquent
parents, the Governor displayed "Wanted" posters with their names and
photographs. Together, they owe about $750,000 in support for 24 children, state
officials said.

"I hope that making public the names of these delinquent parents serves as a
wake-up call to other parents who owe child support," Mr. Pataki said.

At the top of the list is Lewis Brown of Freeport, L.I., who the state says owes
$126,665 in support payments for his two children. Of the 10 people on the list,
9 are men. The lone woman is Elizabeth Moore of Albany, who officials say owes
$53,467 in payments to her two children.

Mr. Pataki said the $2 million that the state had collected so far in its
campaign against delinquent parents came from 1,400 people who received notices
from the State Department of Social Services warning them that their licenses
would be revoked if they did not begin making child-support payments.

Under the new policy, put in place six months ago, New York mailed notices to
380,000 delinquent parents last fall in an attempt to put some sting into
child-support collection programs that have proved to be largely ineffective.
State officials hope the policy will reduce welfare costs by enabling some
families who begin getting their child-support payments to pull themselves out
of poverty.

"Children need the financial and emotional support of both parents," the
Governor said in a statement today. "It's important that people get the message
that abandoning your children violates a fundamental human value."

State courts have 380,000 cases of child-support payment orders in place. In
350,000 of those cases, or 92 percent, parents are behind in payments. Together,
they owe about $1.6 billion, state officials said. In 170,000 cases, or almost
half, no payments have ever been made.

Last year, the state collected $622 million in child-support payments, including
the $2 million brought in under the new program.

Until now, the new policy of suspending licenses has been in effect only in New
York City and 10 other counties. But Mr. Pataki said today that it would be
expanded into a statewide program beginning Friday.

The policy permits state officials to randomly compare Department of Motor
Vehicle records to lists of parents who have fallen more than four months behind
in child-support payments. The licenses of delinquent parents remain suspended
until they either pay the arrears or agree to a payment schedule.

State officials said the policy is expected to increase child-support payments
by $30 million this year because it will be used in the entire state.

Before the new policy was enacted, the state's strongest tool for enforcing
child-support payments was to deduct money from a delinquent parent's paychecks.
But that policy has often been ineffective because people change jobs often, and
many employers are slow to forward information to the state.

These are the names the Governor made public today, with their places of
residence and the amount of money the state says each one owes:

Lewis D. Brown, Freeport, L.I. -- $126,665.

Leonardo Almonte, Copaigue, L.I. -- $94,750.

Craig Hackett, Mount Vernon -- $89,551.

Norbert Meier, Voorheesville -- $77,825.

Ronald Ayers, North Collins -- $70,401.

Nicholas Kovalas, Riverhead, L.I. -- $62,613.

Noel H. Piercy, Buffalo -- $62,000.

Michael Thomas, Kingston -- $61,182.

Oscar Antonio Genao, Shirley, L.I. -- $56,405.

Elizabeth Moore, Albany -- $53,467.


LOAD-DATE: February 27, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. George E. Pataki displayed the "Wanted" posters of two
parents who the state says have skipped out on child-support payments.
(Associated Press)

                   Copyright 1996 The New York Times Company


                             299 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                             National Mortgage News

                               September 22, 2014

Five Cities That Are Still Paying for Loan Meltdown

BYLINE: Andy Peters

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 14 Vol. 39 No. 1

LENGTH: 699  words


Credit quality has steadily improved throughout the industry, but lenders in
some cities still have a case of persistent heartburn when it comes to
delinquent loans.

In at least five large metro areas - Atlanta, Baltimore, Chicago, Milwaukee and
Indianapolis - the delinquency rate remained above the national average in three
lending categories as of June 30, according to data from research firm Trepp
LLC. The categories are commercial real estate, construction and multifamily
housing.

In Atlanta, for example, the proportion of delinquent construction loans
improved from 21.7% as of June 30, 2012, to 7.8% as of June 30 this year,
according to Trepp. But that's still 450 basis points above the national average
of 3.3%.

Baltimore, Chicago, Milwaukee and Indianapolis each posted similar rates of
steady improvement, but it hasn't been enough to fully compensate for the damage
done during the financial crisis, said Matthew Anderson, a managing director at
Trepp. The pace of a metropolitan region's economic recovery is often the prime
factor.

"In Chicago itself, for example, the economy is recovering, but slower than in
Los Angeles or New York," Anderson said.

The situation could leave lenders in these markets vulnerable to another
economic shock. Concerns have risen that credit quality could take a turn for
the worse, as some banks have been loosening underwriting standards to beat out
rivals for commercial and industrial loans, as they chase higher yields. The
Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve have both
warned about loosening of underwriting standards in the past year.

Trepp's count of delinquent loans combines three categories: loans that are 30
to 89 days past due; loans that are past due 90 days or longer; and nonaccrual
loans.

Atlanta and Chicago have been slower to recover because both cities have a large
number of small, independent banks. Those institutions have had a harder time
unloading delinquent assets, said Jim Adkins, a founder and managing member of
Artisan Advisors in Barrington, Ill.

"They really haven't had the opportunity to clean themselves up like the big
boys have," Adkins said. "They haven't had the capital to get the bad loans off
their books."

Indeed, larger banks that operate in the Chicago area have cleaned up their
books. Noncurrent loans, as a percentage of all loans, at $19 billion-asset TCF
Financial, in Wayzata, Minn., improved to 1.61% at the end of the second
quarter, compared with 2.53%, as of June 30, 2012. TCF operates 159 branches in
the Chicago area.

"The whole story in credit at TCF is improving," William Cooper, TCF's chairman
and chief executive, said on Sept. 8 at the Barclays Global Financial Services
Conference.

To cope with credit quality issues, some banks have diversified types of
geographies of lending and tried to lower deposit costs.

TCF "changed its model" to increase core deposits and expand lending nationally.
Those moves have helped TCF improve its credit quality, Cooper said.

"To the degree we had credit issues at the bank, they weren't credit issues off
the national, they were residential loans we made in our own marketplace,
commercial real estate loans we made in our own marketplace," Cooper said. "The
credit quality...of those national platforms is excellent and will continue to
be excellent."

But large and regional banks, like TCF, have also had advantages that community
banks lacked, Anderson said.

"The larger banks had more severe credit-quality problems early on, but they've
also had much greater access to capital markets," he said. "The first round of
stress testing had the desired, but also unanticipated, outcome that the large
banks were immediately able to go out to the capital markets and raise equity."

Factors specific to a region also play a role in the rate of improvement,
Anderson said. Some areas, like the Southwest and the West, seem poised to lead
the nation's loan growth over the coming months. But those areas also had
steeper declines, and thus had farther to come back.

"There was a lot of construction on the periphery of the metro area of Atlanta,"
Anderson said. "When the market fell, the exurban areas were hit particularly
hard."

URL: http://www.nationalmortgagenews.com//

LOAD-DATE: September 22, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: NMN


                        Copyright 2014 SourceMedia, Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                             300 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                             National Mortgage News

                               September 22, 2014

the nation's loan growth over the coming months. But those areas also had

"There was a lot of construction on the periphery of the metro area of Atlanta,"

hard."

                             301 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                             National Mortgage News

                               September 22, 2014

Indeed, larger banks that operate in the Chicago area have cleaned up their
books. Noncurrent loans, as a percentage of all loans, at $19 billion-asset TCF
Financial, in Wayzata, Minn., improved to 1.61% at the end of the second
quarter, compared with 2.53%, as of June 30, 2012. TCF operates 159 branches in
the Chicago area.

"The whole story in credit at TCF is improving," William Cooper, TCF's chairman
and chief executive, said on Sept. 8 at the Barclays Global Financial Services
Conference.

To cope with credit quality issues, some banks have diversified types of
geographies of lending and tried to lower deposit costs.

TCF "changed its model" to increase core deposits and expand lending nationally.
Those moves have helped TCF improve its credit quality, Cooper said.

"To the degree we had credit issues at the bank, they weren't credit issues off
the national, they were residential loans we made in our own marketplace,
commercial real estate loans we made in our own marketplace," Cooper said. "The
credit quality...of those national platforms is excellent and will continue to
be excellent."

But large and regional banks, like TCF, have also had advantages that community
banks lacked, Anderson said.

"The larger banks had more severe credit-quality problems early on, but they've
also had much greater access to capital markets," he said. "The first round of
stress testing had the desired, but also unanticipated, outcome that the large
banks were immediately able to go out to the capital markets and raise equity."

Factors specific to a region also play a role in the rate of improvement,
Anderson said. Some areas, like the Southwest and the West, seem poised to lead
the nation's loan growth over the coming months. But those areas also had
steeper declines, and thus had farther to come back.

"There was a lot of construction on the periphery of the metro area of Atlanta,"
Anderson said. "When the market fell, the exurban areas were hit particularly
hard."

URL: http://www.nationalmortgagenews.com//

LOAD-DATE: September 22, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: NMN


                        Copyright 2014 SourceMedia, Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                             302 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                             National Mortgage News

                               September 22, 2014

Five Cities That Are Still Paying for Loan Meltdown

BYLINE: Andy Peters

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 14 Vol. 39 No. 1

LENGTH: 699  words


Credit quality has steadily improved throughout the industry, but lenders in
some cities still have a case of persistent heartburn when it comes to
delinquent loans.

In at least five large metro areas - Atlanta, Baltimore, Chicago, Milwaukee and
Indianapolis - the delinquency rate remained above the national average in three
lending categories as of June 30, according to data from research firm Trepp
LLC. The categories are commercial real estate, construction and multifamily
housing.

In Atlanta, for example, the proportion of delinquent construction loans
improved from 21.7% as of June 30, 2012, to 7.8% as of June 30 this year,
according to Trepp. But that's still 450 basis points above the national average
of 3.3%.

Baltimore, Chicago, Milwaukee and Indianapolis each posted similar rates of
steady improvement, but it hasn't been enough to fully compensate for the damage
done during the financial crisis, said Matthew Anderson, a managing director at
Trepp. The pace of a metropolitan region's economic recovery is often the prime
factor.

"In Chicago itself, for example, the economy is recovering, but slower than in
Los Angeles or New York," Anderson said.

The situation could leave lenders in these markets vulnerable to another
economic shock. Concerns have risen that credit quality could take a turn for
the worse, as some banks have been loosening underwriting standards to beat out
rivals for commercial and industrial loans, as they chase higher yields. The
Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve have both
warned about loosening of underwriting standards in the past year.

Trepp's count of delinquent loans combines three categories: loans that are 30
to 89 days past due; loans that are past due 90 days or longer; and nonaccrual
loans.

Atlanta and Chicago have been slower to recover because both cities have a large
number of small, independent banks. Those institutions have had a harder time
unloading delinquent assets, said Jim Adkins, a founder and managing member of
Artisan Advisors in Barrington, Ill.

"They really haven't had the opportunity to clean themselves up like the big
boys have," Adkins said. "They haven't had the capital to get the bad loans off
their books."

Indeed, larger banks that operate in the Chicago area have cleaned up their
books. Noncurrent loans, as a percentage of all loans, at $19 billion-asset TCF
Financial, in Wayzata, Minn., improved to 1.61% at the end of the second
quarter, compared with 2.53%, as of June 30, 2012. TCF operates 159 branches in
the Chicago area.

"The whole story in credit at TCF is improving," William Cooper, TCF's chairman
and chief executive, said on Sept. 8 at the Barclays Global Financial Services
Conference.

To cope with credit quality issues, some banks have diversified types of
geographies of lending and tried to lower deposit costs.

TCF "changed its model" to increase core deposits and expand lending nationally.
Those moves have helped TCF improve its credit quality, Cooper said.

"To the degree we had credit issues at the bank, they weren't credit issues off
the national, they were residential loans we made in our own marketplace,
commercial real estate loans we made in our own marketplace," Cooper said. "The
credit quality...of those national platforms is excellent and will continue to
be excellent."

But large and regional banks, like TCF, have also had advantages that community
banks lacked, Anderson said.

"The larger banks had more severe credit-quality problems early on, but they've
also had much greater access to capital markets," he said. "The first round of
stress testing had the desired, but also unanticipated, outcome that the large
banks were immediately able to go out to the capital markets and raise equity."

Factors specific to a region also play a role in the rate of improvement,
Anderson said. Some areas, like the Southwest and the West, seem poised to lead
the nation's loan growth over the coming months. But those areas also had
steeper declines, and thus had farther to come back.

"There was a lot of construction on the periphery of the metro area of Atlanta,"
Anderson said. "When the market fell, the exurban areas were hit particularly
hard."

URL: http://www.nationalmortgagenews.com//

LOAD-DATE: September 22, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: NMN

"There was a lot of construction on the periphery of the metro area of Atlanta,"

hard."

                                American Banker

                          September 17, 2014 Wednesday

Five Cities that Are Still Paying for Commercial Lending Meltdown

BYLINE: Andy Peters

SECTION: CONSUMER FINANCE Vol. 179 No. 144

LENGTH: 699  words


Credit quality has steadily improved throughout the industry, but lenders in
some cities still have a case of persistent heartburn when it comes to
delinquent loans.

In at least five large metro areas-Atlanta, Baltimore, Chicago, Milwaukee and
Indianapolis-the delinquency rate remained above the national average in three
lending categories as of June 30, according to data from research firm Trepp
LLC. The categories are commercial real estate, construction and multifamily
housing.

In Atlanta, for example, the proportion of delinquent construction loans
improved from 21.7% as of June 30, 2012, to 7.8% as of June 30 this year,
according to Trepp. But that's still 450 basis points above the national average
of 3.3%.

Baltimore, Chicago, Milwaukee and Indianapolis each posted similar rates of
steady improvement, but it hasn't been enough to fully compensate for the damage
done during the financial crisis, said Matthew Anderson, a managing director at
Trepp. The pace of a metropolitan region's economic recovery is often the prime
factor.

"In Chicago itself, for example, the economy is recovering, but slower than in
Los Angeles or New York," Anderson said.

The situation could leave lenders in these markets vulnerable to another
economic shock. Concerns have risen that credit quality could take a turn for
the worse, as some banks have been loosening underwriting standards to beat out
rivals for commercial-and-industrial loans, as they chase higher yields. The
Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve have both
warned about loosening of underwriting standards in the past year.Trepp's count
of delinquent loans combines three categories: loans that are 30 to 89 days past
due; loans that are past due 90 days or longer; and nonaccrual loans.

Atlanta and Chicago have been slower to recover because both cities have a large
number of small, independent banks. Those institutions have had a harder time
unloading delinquent assets, said Jim Adkins, a founder and managing member of
Artisan Advisors in Barrington, Ill.

"They really haven't had the opportunity to clean themselves up like the big
boys have," Adkins said. "They haven't had the capital to get the bad loans off
their books."

Indeed, larger banks that operate in the Chicago area have cleaned up their
books. Noncurrent loans, as a percentage of all loans, at $19 billion-asset TCF
Financial, in Wayzata, Minn., improved to 1.61% at the end of the second
quarter, compared with 2.53%, as of June 30, 2012. TCF operates 159 branches in
the Chicago area.

"The whole story in credit at TCF is improving," William Cooper, TCF's chairman
and chief executive, said on Sept. 8 at the Barclays Global Financial Services
Conference.

To cope with credit quality issues, some banks have diversified types of
geographies of lending and tried to lower deposit costs.

TCF "changed its model" to increase core deposits and expand lending nationally.
Those moves have helped TCF improve its credit quality, Cooper said.

"To the degree we had credit issues at the bank, they weren't credit issues off
the national, they were residential loans we made in our own marketplace,

credit quality "\xA6 of those national platforms is excellent and will continue
to be excellent."

But large and regional banks, like TCF, have also had advantages that community
banks lacked, Anderson said.

"The larger banks had more severe credit-quality problems early on, but they've
also had much greater access to capital markets," he said. "The first round of
stress testing had the desired, but also unanticipated, outcome that the large
banks were immediately able to go out to the capital markets and raise equity."

Factors specific to a region also play a role in the rate of improvement,
Anderson said. Some areas, like the Southwest and the West, seem poised to lead
the nation's loan growth over the coming months. But those areas also had
steeper declines, and thus had farther to come back.

"There was a lot of construction on the periphery of the metro area of Atlanta,"
Anderson said. "When the market fell, the exurban areas were hit particularly
hard."

                             305 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                             June 24, 2014 Tuesday

Internal Revenue Service: REVENUE OFFICER (ATAT) 14CW3-SBB1429-1169-13-CG

LENGTH: 2560  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of Personnel Management has issued the following job announcement:

Job Title:REVENUE OFFICER (ATAT)

Department:Department Of The Treasury

Agency:Internal Revenue Service

Job Announcement Number:14CW3-SBB1429-1169-13-CG
SALARY RANGE:
 $82,642.00 to $127,187.00 / Per Year
OPEN PERIOD:
 Monday, June 23, 2014 to Monday, July 07, 2014
SERIES & GRADE:
 GS-1169-13
POSITION INFORMATION:
 Full Time - Permanent
PROMOTION POTENTIAL:
13
DUTY LOCATIONS:
 2 vacancies in the following location(s):
Oakland, CA View Map
Sacramento, CA View Map
Bloomington, IN View Map
Indianapolis, IN View Map
Lafayette, IN View Map
More Locations  (1)
WHO MAY APPLY:


IRS employees on Career or Career Conditional Appointments in the competitive
service

SECURITY CLEARANCE:
 Public Trust - Background Investigation
SUPERVISORY STATUS:
 No
JOB SUMMARY:

About the Agency

WHAT DOES A REVENUE OFFICER DO? As a Revenue Officer you will be responsible for
collecting delinquent accounts, securing delinquent tax returns and determining
actions necessary to bring taxpayers into full compliance. In this position, the
cases assigned involve taxpayers and taxpaying entities with high income levels
from diversified sources including substantial foreign income and assets. You
will execute all procedures and processes consistent with the protection of
taxpayer rights afforded by law and in a manner than ensures the honesty and
integrity of the service.
WHAT IS THE SB/SE DIVISION?The Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE) Division
provides examinations and taxpayer education services for about 7 million small
businesses and upwards of 33 millions self-employed and supplemental income
taxpayers. SB/SE taxpayers generally have higher incomes than most taxpayers,
need to file twice as many tax forms, and generally need to rely more on paid
tax preparers and the taxpayer education outreach activities of the IRS.


Positions are located in 1 vac to be filled in 2017 S Liberty Dr Bloomington, IN
575 N Pennsylvania Indianapolis, IN 955 Mezzanine Dr Ste B Lafayette, IN or 201
Thomas Johnson Dr Frederick MD; 1 vac to be filled in 1301 Clay St Oakland, CA
or 4330 Watt Ave Sacramento, CA.
TRAVEL REQUIRED

Occasional Travel
    Travel locally and/or overnight approximately one to five days per month

RELOCATION AUTHORIZED

No

KEY REQUIREMENTS

Please refer to "Conditions of Employment."
    Click "Print Preview" to review the entire announcement before applying.

DUTIES:
Back to top

As a Revenue Officer you will:

Collect delinquent tax and secure delinquent returns from taxpayers who have not
resolved their obligations.
    Conduct interviews with taxpayers and/or their representatives in different
environments such as the business location, residence or office as part of the
investigative process.
    Provide guidance on a wide range of financial problems to assist the
taxpayer in developing a plan of action to resolve all delinquencies.
    Analyze sophisticated financial statements/records that include balance
sheets, income statements and profit and loss statements.
    Search public records, tax returns, and financial and credit information to
locate distrainable assets.
    Perform complex credit and financial analysis and evaluation of assets on
casework involving actions.
    Recognize novel and complex issues that often arise in taking appropriate
enforcement action such as suits, seizures and injunctive relief actions.
    Compose complex correspondence, technical reports, research, affidavits,
statements and testimony necessary to support complex or sophisticated
collection action in court cases to Appeals and Criminal Investigation.

WHERE CAN I FIND OUT MORE ABOUT OTHER IRS CAREERS? If you want to find out more
about IRS careers, visit us on the web at www.jobs.irs.gov

QUALIFICATIONS REQUIRED:
Back to top

You must meet the following requirements by the closing date of this
announcement.

GS-13 LEVEL: You must have 1 year of specialized experience at a level of
difficulty and responsibility equivalent to the GS-12 grade level in the Federal
service. Specialized experiencedemonstrating the ability to: Collect delinquent
Federal taxes and securing delinquent returns; Conduct investigations of alleged
criminal violations of Federal tax statutes and making recommendations for
criminal prosecutions and civil penalties; Perform internal audits,
administrative, or management duties directly related to the collection of
Federal taxes; Furnish taxpayer assistance and information to the general public
or determine, redetermine, or advise of liability for Federal taxes.
At this level, you must demonstrate a comprehensive knowledge of the Internal
Revenue Code and related regulations and procedures pertaining to income,
estate, gift, employment, or excise taxes; knowledge of a wide range of
investigative or analytical techniques and methods; Knowledge of accounting
practices and methods sufficient to analyze and evaluate financial
statements/records (e.g., balance sheets, profit and loss statements, income
statements, bank records, etc.) sufficient to locate distrainable assets,
determine ability to pay, and trace and follow income streams; Specialized
knowledge of tax and business laws, regulations, judicial processes, laws of
evidence, revenue rulings, precedent decisions, etc.; Ability to meet and deal
effectively with taxpayers and/or their representatives, who may be
uncooperative or hostile; and the Ability to write clear and concise examination
reports.

Additional Specialized Experience:

To be qualifying, your experience must be sufficient to demonstrate the ability
to: Conduct collection activities using a variety of Collection tools such as
levy, Notice of Federal Tax Lien, seizure, and suits involving multi-layered
and/or multi-entity nominee/alter-ego investigations. Comprehensive knowledge of
business laws, practices, judicial processes, rules of evidence, court decisions
and relationship between Federal and State laws. Secure delinquent returns using
a variety of tools such as summons and preparing substitute for returns per IRC
6020(b); use computer systems to capture information secured and to aid in the
collection of Federal taxes or delinquent Federal tax returns and to conduct
research such as locator services, credit bureau reports, and real estate
programs; prepare the assembly of trust fund recovery penalty files, suit and
seizure packages and lien activity packages including discharge, subordination,
and withdrawal as well as drafting special condition liens.

-The experience may have been gained in either the public or private sector. One
year of experience refers to full-time work; part-time work is considered on a
prorated basis.
-To ensure full credit for your work experience, please indicate dates of
employment by month/year, and indicate number of hours worked per week, on your
resume.

In addition to the above requirements, you must meet the following, if
applicable:
You must have been at the GS-12 level for 52 weeks (time-in-grade requirement).

Positions will be handling ATAT cases "Abusive Tax Avoidance Transactions"
HOW YOU WILL BE EVALUATED:

Your application includes your resume, responses to the online questions, and
required supporting documents. Please be sure that your resume includes detailed
information to support your qualifications for this position; failure to provide
sufficient evidence in your resume may result in a "not qualified"
determination.

Rating: Your application will be evaluated on the CJEs of the position to be
filled per the National Agreement Article 13.

Your application will also be rated and ranked among others, based on your
responses to the online questions, regarding your experience, education,
training, performance appraisals and awards relevant to the duties of this
position. IRS employees may obtain most recent awards listing at
https://persinfo.web.irs.gov/

Your rating may be lowered, if your responses to the online questions are not
supported by the education and/or experience described in your application.

Referral: If you are among the top qualified candidates, your application may be
referred to a selecting official for consideration. You may be required to
participate in a selection interview. We will not reimburse costs related to the
interview such as travel to and from the interview site

If you are a displaced or surplus Treasury employee eligible for the Career
Transition Assistance Plan (CTAP), you must receive a score of 80 or better to
be rated as well qualified to receive special selection priority.

HOW TO APPLY:
Back to top
The following instructions outline our application process. You must complete
this application process and submit any required documents by 11:59 p.m. Eastern
Time (ET) on the closing date of this announcement. We are available to assist
you during business hours (normally 8:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m. ET, Monday - Friday).
If applying online poses a hardship, please contact us by noon ET on the
announcement's closing date.

Treasury believes in a working environment that supports inclusion; please view
our reasonable accommodation policies and procedures at
http://jobs.irs.gov/seasonal/reasonable-accommodation.html. We will provide
reasonable accommodation to applicants with disabilities on a case-by-case
basis. Please contact Katie Haugen @ 801-620-6525 if you require this for any
part of the application and hiring process.

To begin, either click the "Create a New Account" button and follow the prompts
to register or if you previously registered, click the "Apply Online" button and
follow the prompts.
    You will be re-directed to Treasury's CareerConnector system to complete
your application process; answer the online questions, and submit all required
documents. (To submit supporting documents, click one of the available options;
Upload; Fax; or Reuse existing documents. To protect your privacy, we suggest
you first remove your SSN). Also, go to "My Account" to view and update your
information, as necessary.
    To complete, you must click the "Finish" button located at the bottom of the
"Application Review" page.
    To verify your application is complete, log into your USAJOBS account,
select the Application Status link and then select the more information link for
this position. The Details page will display the status of your application, the
documentation received.
    To return to an incomplete application, log into your USAJOBS account and
click Update Application in the vacancy announcement. You must re-select your
resume and/or other documents from your USAJOBS account or your application will
be incomplete.

If you are experiencing system issues with your application, please contact the
CareerConnector Help Desk at careerconnectorhelp@treasury.gov and/or the USAJOBS
Help Desk.

                             306 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                The Morning Call

                          November 18, 2004, Thursday

Northampton County, Pa., school district considers crackdown on tax deadbeats

BYLINE: By Kathy Lauer-Williams

LENGTH: 386 words



The Northampton Area School District is considering hiring a Montgomery County
law firm to collect more than $ 1.2 million in delinquent real estates tax.

Alan Portnoff of Portnoff Law Associates of Wynnewood told the school board
during a presentation Monday that his firm has a 75 percent success rate once it
gets involved.

Portnoff said his firm, which only collects delinquent taxes, represents 40
Pennsylvania school districts and municipalities, including Easton, Bethlehem
and Allentown. Portnoff said the company has been collecting delinquent taxes
for 17 years.

"We are a law firm and not a collection agency," he said. "It is not fair for
the people who pay their taxes to have to subsidize those who choose not to."

He said the firm offers an initial grace period up to 30 days, in which 25
percent to 35 percent of taxpayers usually pay. He said the firm is paid $ 40
for each initial mailing, and all subsequent legal fees are paid by the
taxpayer.

The district's delinquent taxes are collected by Northampton County, which
charges a 5 percent fee on the overdue amount and other fees.

Portnoff said the firm is able to pursue tax scofflaws more aggressively than
Northampton County, which legally must wait 21/2 years before placing a property
up for sheriff's sale.

Karen Miller, of the county's delinquent tax office, said Portnoff's fees are
very high and put more burden on the taxpayer.

She said the county's fees are lower and that laws governing sheriff sales are
"intended to protect the taxpayer."

She added having Portnoff collect delinquent taxes also might cause confusion
among taxpayers.

However, Portnoff said the firm offers a hardship program that allows taxpayers
with extenuating circumstances to establish a payment plan.

He admitted the firm has a reputation for being tough on delinquent taxpayers
but that it usually results in fewer future delinquencies once the firm takes
over.

The school board, which is interested in increasing the return on delinquent
taxes, last year considered publishing the names of tax scofflaws on the
district's Web site.

The board will consider the Portnoff proposal at its December meeting.


-----

To see more of The Morning Call, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.mcall.com.


LOAD-DATE: November 19, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

KR-ACC-NO: AA-TAX-DEADBEATS-20041118

JOURNAL-CODE: AA

               Copyright 2004 Knight Ridder/Tribune Business News
                        Copyright 2004 The Morning Call


                             307 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                September 3, 2000, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

Delinquent Common Charges

SECTION: Section 11; Page 8; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 674 words



Q: What happens when those who live in a condominium pay extra common charges
for owners who do not pay their way? Over a period of 15 or 30 years, a $250 a
month additional fee adds up to a hefty sum.  Those of us who do pay our share
actually wind up paying for those who do not. When this money is recovered at
the time of sale because of liens placed on the apartment by the condominium
association, do we get reimbursed? What if we move out before the delinquent
homeowner sells? Is the board obligated to find us and reimburse us? . . . Jeff
Shermer, Plainview, N.Y.
A: Arthur I. Weinstein, a Manhattan lawyer who is vice president of the Council
of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums, said that a condo unit's common
charges are usually based on that unit's percentage interest in the condominium.
If one or more of the owners do not pay their common charges, he said, the board
has the right to divide the resulting shortfall among the paying unit owners in
the form of higher common charges.

"If the condominium recovers the shortfall from the delinquent owners, the
condominium's cash needs will be reduced and the unit owners will indirectly
recover the extra amount laid out for the delinquent owners," Mr. Weinstein
said.

He said that the letter writer is correct in pointing out that if he moves from
the building before the money is recovered he will not receive the benefits. At
the same time, however, he said, it is possible that the letter writer is now
enjoying the benefits of recovered delinquencies that were paid for by former
owners of his apartment.

It is possible for the board to establish a policy that will ensure that those
who contributed to a delinquent owner's shortfall will be repaid.  "You could
suggest to the board that the problem be solved by an agreement among all unit
owners that provides that shortfalls be funded by loans to the condominium from
each unit owner," Mr. Weinstein said.  "Those loans would then be repaid to each
unit owner when the arrearages are recovered."

However, he said, this would be an awkward way to handle the problem, and he
would generally recommend against it. "Arranging for loans would require the
agreement of all unit owners," he said. "And since the condominium's lien for
unpaid common charges is secondary to any unpaid bank loans secured by the
defaulting owner's apartment, it is by no means certain that the condominium
will recover the shortfall."

And that, he said, could result in the loans from unit owners remaining on the
books of the condo forever.

Painting Apartment That's Stabilized

Q: Our building's new owner has discontinued the previous owner's practice of
having rent-stabilized apartments painted every three years. A month ago, I sent
a certified letter to the new owner requesting a new paint job, and the response
has been stony silence. Would the easiest resolution be for me to hire a painter
and deduct the cost from my rent? . . . Mel Schechter, Manhattan.
A: Fred L. Seeman, a Manhattan landlord-tenant lawyer, said that while the Rent
Stabilization Law does not require landlords to paint tenants' apartments, the
New York City Housing Maintenance Code requires a landlord to paint a tenant's
apartment once every three years.

"Armed with the knowledge that the new owner is in violation of the Housing
Maintenance Code, the tenant should complete the paper trail he has already
begun," Mr. Seeman said.

He explained that the tenant should send another certified letter to the new
owner pointing out that the owner's continued failure to paint the apartment is
a violation of the Housing Maintenance Code.

The letter should put the owner on notice that if he fails to paint the
apartment, the tenant will have no choice but to have the apartment repainted in
a similar color scheme and then deduct the cost of the repainting from the rent.

If the landlord then takes the tenant to court, Mr. Seeman said, the tenant can
produce the letters and the bill for the painting as a legal defense.

http://www.nytimes.com

LOAD-DATE: September 3, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Question

                   Copyright 2000 The New York Times Company

                                US Official News

                             March 1, 2014 Saturday

Oregon: Revenue Agent 3 Job Code: DOR14-0021

LENGTH: 934  words

DATELINE: Salem


The State of Oregon has issued the following Job Vacancy:

Job Code:  DOR14-0021
Job Title:  Revenue Agent 3
Opening Date/Time:  Tue. 02/25/14 12:00 AM Pacific Time
Closing Date/Time:  Tue. 03/11/14 11:59 PM Pacific Time
Salary:  $2,942.00 - $4,273.00 Monthly
Job Type:  Permanent
Location:  Portland, Oregon
Agency:  Revenue-Personal Tax & Compliance



Description  Benefits  Supplemental Questions





The Oregon Dept. of Revenue is currently recruiting for Revenue Agent 3 to join
our Personal Tax and Compliance unit in Portland. This is a full-time, SEIU
represented position. This recruitment may be used to fill additional vacancies
as they occur.
The purpose of this position is to collect tax liabilities for all tax programs,
secure delinquent tax returns, and resolve account maintenance problems on
assigned accounts. Provide information to the public in a helpful, pleasant and
professional manner. The work is performed both in the field and from the
office.

Duties & Responsibilities:

Take appropriate action to collect delinquent taxes. This is accomplished in the
following ways:
·         Contact taxpayer or representative, by phone or in person, to
encourage payment before determining appropriate legal action.
·         Set up, monitor and enforce payment agreements based on financial
information gathered in the field, by phone or provided on financial statements
completed by taxpayers. Verify accuracy of information obtained.
·         Generate notices, correspondence and demands regarding delinquent
taxes.
·         Locate taxpayers, search for assets and determine collection potential
of accounts by performing field, computer and telephone research. This may
include locating and inventorying real and personal property assets and
determining priority of existing liens.
·         Initiate warrants and garnishments against assets when appropriate
(wages, bank accounts, real property or other assets that are subject to
garnishment).
·         Determine and assess officer liability per established policies and
procedures. This involves determining who is responsible for paying the
withholding debt.
·         Coordinate collection action with other agencies to setup payments,
perform compliance checks and share information to determine liability.
·         Document all contacts online.
·         Determine collectability of account and when appropriate, take
necessary action to recommend the liability be cancelled.
·         Review settlement offers for required documentation and refer
completed offers to the Settlement Offer Committee for review.
·         Receive and receipt payments in the field and convey them to
appropriate field office staff for processing.
·         Take last resort collection action when necessary per established
processes and procedures. These actions could include till taps, license
suspensions, contract suspensions, seizures and any other agency approved
action.
Take appropriate action to bring all assigned taxpayers into compliance in all
tax programs. This is accomplished in the following ways:
·         Initiate notices, correspondence and demands to notify taxpayers to
file delinquent returns for all applicable tax programs.
·         When taxpayers file requested delinquent returns, perform a cursory
review of the return received and forward the return for processing or refer the
return to the appropriate person for audit or adjustment.
·         When taxpayers do not comply with the request for filing delinquent
returns, initiate the necessary correspondence and assess tax, penalty and
interest appropriately or refer the case to the appropriate person for
follow-up.
·         Resolve all tax account maintenance issues including calculating
adjustments of monies, locating misapplied payments and documenting actions on
the system.
Assist and educate the public both in person and by telephone. This is done in
the following ways:
·         Answer general questions about various tax programs administered by
the department.
·         Providing correct forms and publications as needed.
·         Explaining department notices, procedures and policies to taxpayers
and tax professionals.
·         Participation in assistance events, this could include assisting
taxpayers in filing tax returns, speaking to local business groups on tax
topics, participating in business fairs, and making presentations to interested
groups on various tax topics.
WORKING CONDITIONS
The working conditions include frequent contact with taxpayers by phone, in
person or occasionally in remote locations that are frustrated or upset.
Occasionally subjected to profanity and infrequently subjected to threat of
bodily harm. This position is required to take appropriate safety measures and
there will be an occasional need to inspect construction sites, heavy equipment,
and vehicles to assess for feasibility of seizure, by climbing in, on, and over
obstacles. Regular operation of motor vehicle; occasionally driving in hazardous
weather conditions. Occasional overnight travel; working before or after regular
business hours. Continuous exposure to noise from phones, computers and voices
in an open work area. Frequent leafing through files and file folders. Continual
use of video-display terminals, telephone and calculators, requires sitting and
using keyboards and keypads for extended periods of time. Occasionally required
to lift items, typically up to 15 pounds and occasionally up to 50 pounds, climb
stairs, bend, squat, twist, reach, and walk frequently over uneven terrain.

For Further information please visit: http://agency.governmentjobs.com/oregon/

                       Sarasota Herald Tribune (Florida)

                           October 7, 2009 Wednesday

Investors wary of project's tax-bill gamble

BYLINE: JOHN DAVIS

SECTION: A; ARTICLE; Pg. A01

LENGTH: 949 words

DATELINE: NORTH PORT


NORTH PORT

They named their project Gran Paradiso, and developers certainly had big dreams
for an exclusive, gated subdivision at North Port's western gateway.

But today, Gran Paradiso's claim to fame is its status as Sarasota County's
biggest tax delinquent, with $3 million in taxes overdue since April.

Gran Paradiso cannot entice investors to front the cost of the delinquent taxes,
even with the incentive of 18 percent interest on the advance.

The wariness signals an erosion of confidence in the community's future in an
already dismal real estate market.

Gran Paradiso's are by far Sarasota County's largest unpaid tax bills; 2,000
other parcels, many in North Port, combined account for about $650,000.

Each year, Sarasota County and other local governments collect money to cover
delinquent taxes by auctioning instruments called tax certificates. Interest
rates for the certificates start at 18 percent and bidders willing to take the
lowest amount in interest win the certificate.

The bidders essentially pay the tax bills as short-term loans to property
owners, profiting by the interest.

Unsold certificates, like those for Gran Paradiso, automatically go to the 18
percent rate of interest, an added incentive to investors.

Last year, the 18 percent deal was enough to attract buyers for all of the
county certificates. Gran Paradiso was not among the delinquent.

Whether investors are willing to tie up hundreds of thousands of dollars while
gambling that the development will eventually pay the debt with interest appears
increasingly unlikely.

Most of the development's unpaid taxes are covered by 12 tax certificates,
including one for $936,452, after interest and other fees.

Florida tax certificate investing expert James Mikel recommends against buying
such large certificates. He says the Gran Paradiso deal would mean unnecessary
risk, when investors could spread the same amount of money over hundreds of
parcels, spreading the risk of not being paid while still having the potential
for an 18 percent return.

"You don't want to have a huge risk on a few properties," said Mikel, noting
that he advises investors to focus on properties in the $25,000 to $40,000
range, typically vacant land where a few hundred in taxes are owed.

The lower tax bill typically means owners are not in a rush to pay the tax bill
-- meaning more interest for investors -- but attainable enough that the owner
is not likely to remain delinquent for two years, prompting the investor to seek
to force a sale of the property to pay the taxes and interest.

In Gran Paradiso's case, the company would have to come up with more than half a
million dollars just to cover interest for one year, in addition to the $3
million bill itself.

The prospect of insolvency is also a threat.

"If the company files for bankruptcy, that could create a hindrance," Mikel
said.

More jarring than the absence of buyers for Gran Paradiso's debt is the
developer's inability to pay its taxes, given that developer Sam Rodgers and
partners, under limited liability companies, spent more than $55 million to buy
the Gran Paradiso parcels in 2004.

Local real estate agent Russ Smith calls it another sign of dismal times for a
community with an uncertain future.

"Those folks, they know the cost of holding on," said Smith of the years an
investor could wait before seeing a return on Gran Paradiso's tax debt.

All but about $64,000 of the tax debt is owed to the West Villages Improvement
District. West Villages is a state-sanctioned development district allowed to
issue bonds and charge assessments to landowners to build a community from
scratch, including streets, water and sewer service and other infrastructure.

Venice attorney Jeff Boone, who represents the district's largest landowner,
Fourth Quarter Properties, said his client has not been alarmed by Gran
Paradiso's failure to pay, noting that the development as a whole has slowed in
the current downturn.

"Everybody's just doing their best to try to get through this," he said.

Rodgers, head of the Gran Paradiso companies, declined to comment for this
story.

In April, Rodgers said the tax bill would be paid in full by April 30. When the
payment was not made, the tax certificates went to public auction in May and
failed to sell.

The certificates are now available on the tax certificate sale Web site,
www.sarasotacountytaxsale.com.

Mikel noted that Gran Paradiso is not the only developer facing this problem. In
Miami-Dade, a tax certificate worth $1.7 million has also gone unsold. It is for
taxes owed by TCI Investment Group for a property with a taxable value of $82
million.

With homebuilding in North Port at a standstill in July and August, Smith said
that the value of Gran Paradiso's land is a non-factor to investors, who are
wary of whether the development will begin making money any time soon.

Gran Paradiso remains little more than an elaborate gate with trailers for
business offices and six model homes for potential buyers. Rex Rodgers, Sam
Rodgers' son and business partner, was staffing one of the models recently, but
did not want to talk about the tax situation. He noted that a handful of houses
have been sold and Gran Paradiso is open for business.

"We can't stop now," he said.

The development's Web site offers homes from the $200,000 range to over $1
million, substantially higher than many of the houses available in central North
Port, where foreclosures and a glut of inventory have driven prices to record
lows, in many cases less than the cost of construction.

"It's so far down that the land is not the big issue," Smith said. "It's the
cost of building a house."

FAX BOX

GRAN PARADISO:

In dismal real estate market, no takers on its certificates

LOAD-DATE: December 11, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: The Gran Paradiso development, at North Port's western gateway, has so
far failed to entice investors to front the cost of its $3 million in delinquent
taxes, even with the incentive of 18 percent interest on the advance.

                          The Times (Munster, Indiana)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             June 17, 2014 Tuesday

Lake to sue tax-delinquent Gary School Board member

BYLINE: Bill Dolan, The Times, Munster, Ind.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 487 words


June 17--CROWN POINT _ Lake officials plan to sue to recover more than $566,000
in delinquent property taxes and late penalties owed by a Gary School Board
member.

Lake County Attorney John Dull said Monday the Lake County Board of
Commissioners authorized litigation aimed at 96 parcels now under the name of
Marion R. Williams, who has represented the Gary Community School Corp.'s 4th
District since 2008.

The school district has recently been forced to close six schools because of
declining enrollment and an inability to collect even half the property taxes on
official books, contributing to the school district's $23.7 million budget
deficit.

Dull said if the county wins a judgment against Williams, it can "garnish the
money that he receives as a member of the Gary School Board as well as any other
monies on file that you can discover," Dull stated.

The Board of Commissioners and the county treasurer share the responsibility of
collecting overdue property taxes, usually by selling delinquent properties to
the highest bidder at auctions three times a year.

Treasurer John Petalas said many of Williams' properties already are scheduled
to go on the block at his upcoming tax sale later this summer, but he notes many
of Gary's more than 10,000 abandoned properties rarely sell.

Petalas said he has directed his attorneys to pursue Williams and other
delinquent taxpayers in court previously.

Williams said if the county proceeds against him he will file his own class
action suit "in the name of all Gary citizens" against the county for assessing
property values at unreasonably high amounts.

Williams said he is only one of many property owners trying to reinvest in his
community, holding long-abandoned lots and houses made largely worthless by
vandalism, high tax assessments and a refusal by banks to lend to Gary property
owners.

Williams said he had little success in getting the Calumet Township assessor to
acknowledge the assessment problem as he sees it. Edward Gholson, chief deputy
assessor for Calumet Township, said last week Williams can appeal to the county
and the state if he remains dissatisfied.

County records indicate the parcels under Williams' name have an official
assessed value of more than $1.2 million, even though he bought many of them in
county tax sales for less than $100 apiece.

Williams said last week some of the properties he owned were divided among his
ex-wife and children following a divorce, although county records still reflect
him as the owner.

Dull said the county has sued Williams for the taxes that accrued when he was
the owner of the properties, whether or not he now owns them.

Williams also said he also believes the tax situation is being used by opponents
within the school district disturbed by his complaints about waste and
corruption.

www.nwitimes.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

                                US Official News

                           November 25, 2014 Tuesday

West Virginia: Coal Co. Operating Above the Law, Revitalizing Coal Country,
14-Year-Old TN. Banjo Picker & more

LENGTH: 315  words

DATELINE: Charleston


West Virginia Public Broadcasting has issued the following news release:

Perfect for your Thanksgiving road-trip: Fifty-one minutes of some great
Appalachian stories, including: NPR's mine safety investigation continues. Where
is the the mine with the highest delinquent fines in the U.S.? What happens when
mines don't pay their fines? And an update from the Appalachian Project, and how
a financial adviser in Johnson City, TN decided to begin recording oral
histories across Appalachia. These stories and more, in this week's episode of
Inside Appalachia.

Last week we heard two reports from a joint investigation on the mining industry
by NPR and Mine Safety and Health News. The investigation found that mining
companies and contractors owe nearly 70 million dollars to the government for
violating federal health and safety laws. But the mines' owners have been able
to stay in business and continue to extract coal. Where is the mine with the
highest delinquent fines in the U.S.? For that, reporter Anna Boiko-Weyrauch
takes us to Kentucky.

Credit Courtesy of the Meade family

What happens when mines don't pay their fines? Now a big, bureaucratic failure
with real implications for the people who work in mines. Turns out the federal
mine safety agency has not collected millions of dollars in penalties for safety
violations in the nation's mines. NPR's investigative series found that during
the time period when mining companies were delinquent in their payments, they
committed 130,000 additional violations. NPR's Howard Berkes examines one last
question. Since fines are supposed to deter unsafe practices, what can be done
to make delinquent mine owners pay up?

What's in a Name?  This town in Appalachia gets its name from a frightening
creek that almost swept two travelers underwater. Is it Hell for Certain, KY,
Difficult, Tennessee or Deadly, Pennsylvania?

Appalachian Project Up

LOAD-DATE: November 27, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


              Copyright 2014 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

                                US Official News

                           November 22, 2014 Saturday

West Virginia: Coal Co. Operating Above the Law, Revitalizing Coal Country,

                             313 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                       Florida Times-Union (Jacksonville)

                           December 22, 2012 Saturday

A.M. BRIEFING

SECTION: Pg. C-4

LENGTH: 467 words


FEWER AREA HOME LOANS DELINQUENT

Home loan delinquency rose a bit last month, according to Lender Processing
Services' monthly report. A total of 7.12 percent of homes across the country
were 30 days or more past due but not in foreclosure at the end of November.
That's 1.19 points over October but still down 9.06 points from this time last
year.

For the Jacksonville area, LPS' latest figures are for October. They show 9.21
percent of loans being delinquent, down 2.5 points from September and 3.8 down
from a year earlier.

A report from another data analyst, CoreLogic, has different numbers, similar
trends. It reported 13.65 percent of home loans in the Jacksonville 90 days or
more delinquent at the end of October. That's the lowest rate since August 2011.
The foreclosure rate of 8.33 percent is the lowest since December 2010.

Roger Bull/The Times-Union

DELTA NEEDS MORE FLIGHT ATTENDANTS

ATLANTA | Delta Air Lines is looking for up to 400 flight attendants, many of
them for overseas flights for next summer.

Roughly one-third of the hires will be people who speak the language in some of
the overseas cities where Delta flies. It's looking for speakers of Portuguese,
Japanese, Mandarin and Hindi.

Delta says it has received 22,000 applications. CEO Richard Anderson says in a
message to employees that Delta is getting two applications every minute.

Delta plans to begin interviewing applicants in January, with training beginning
in the spring.

Starting two years ago, Delta added 1,000 flight attendants, including recalling
425 from furlough.

Associated Press

AUTOMAKER PLANS WEST GEORGIA PLANT

HOGANSVILLE, GA. | Georgia Gov. Nathan Deal says a Korean auto manufacturer
plans to build a new casting facility at its manufacturing complex in west
Georgia, creating 660 jobs by 2020.

Mando Corp. announced plans in 2011 to construct its existing manufacturing
facility in Meriwether County.

Deal said in a statement Friday that it selected the west Georgia site for an
expansion involving the new casting facility after a competitive search.

Deal said that with the expansion, Mando will become the largest employer in
Meriwether County.

Associated Press

DISNEY PURCHASES LUCASFILM LTD.

BURBANK, CALIF. | Disney says it has completed its acquisition of Lucasfilm Ltd.
for $4.06 billion in cash and stock.

The company said Friday that it issued 37.1 million shares and made a cash
payment of $2.21 billion to buy the maker of "Star Wars" from its sole owner,
George Lucas.

The total transaction value was based on Friday's closing price of $50 for
Disney shares.

The deal includes special effects giant Industrial Light & Magic, video game
maker LucasArts and sound studio Skywalker Sound.

The Walt Disney Co. has said it will revive the "Star Wars" franchise beginning
with "Episode 7" in 2015.

Associated Press

LOAD-DATE: February 5, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             314 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                              The Lima News (Ohio)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             June 18, 2009 Thursday

Allen County is owed $10M, wants it now

BYLINE: Heather Rutz, The Lima News, Ohio

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 398 words


Jun. 18--LIMA -- Just as property owners have an obligation to pay their taxes,
county treasurers are legally bound to collect it.

That's the thought behind stepped up efforts by the Allen County Treasurer's
Office to secure delinquent tax dollars.

Collections manager Bob Scherger, hired in February, updated county
commissioners Wednesday about his efforts to date.

Allen County has more than $10 million owed on 3,600 parcels from delinquent
property owners, Scherger said. The county identified the top 700 most
delinquent parcels, representing $7.4 million.

"We've ID'd the top 700 heavy hitters and we're getting after them," Scherger
said.

Since February, Scherger has brought $486,000 current, he said.

Scherger's position, created when others at the county have been eliminated, is
funded through delinquent tax dollars collected; a state law allows counties to
take a percentage off the top they collect to fund the work.

Treasurer Jim Link is also using two new methods to address the issue.

Link or Scherger are nearly complete visiting all townships, villages and cities
in the county asking for help tracking down delinquent taxpayers.

"The thinking is that these are the folks who know the people in their
communities and have information that can help us," Link said. "Did this person
move in with his kids or move out of state? That kind of thing." Link said he
will annually visit elected officials with delinquent lists, which are public
record, from their communities.

The office and city are about six months away from implementing another solution
now allowed by Ohio law, administrative foreclosure.

When a property is vacant and abandoned and has delinquent taxes, a new board
being established can foreclose on the property and move it to ownership by the
city, which can quickly sell it or develop it, Link said. The program is
different than the current slow moving land bank system, which can take years to
move a property.

You can comment on this story at www.limaohio.com.

To see more of The Lima News or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.limanews.com. Copyright (c) 2009, The Lima News, Ohio Distributed by
McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                             315 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          Reading Eagle (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           October 13, 2010 Wednesday

Collection of delinquent fees a boost to city

BYLINE: Don Spatz, Reading Eagle, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 322 words


Oct. 13--There's a bit of good news in the city's quest to find more money: The
company hired to collect delinquent trash and recycling fees has wrested more
than $1 million from delinquent payers, well over the $600,000 projected.

In September 2009, Norristown-based Portnoff Law Associates was handed 4,000
accounts with delinquencies totaling $1.4 million. It not only billed the
customers for the city fees, but added its own collection fees to the bills,
resulting in no out-of-pocket expense to the city.

Geoffrey Zolna, city solid waste manager, said Tuesday that officials believed
that using the firm would help collect the delinquencies but the city wasn't
expecting more than $1 million.

The money goes to the city's Recycling Enterprise Fund, an account separate from
its general fund budget. Although that fund had a deficit in 2008 and 2009, it
now has a surplus, Mayor Tom McMahon said.

Most of the money will stay in the fund, said Frank Denbowski, the mayor's chief
of staff and former solid waste coordinator.

But he said about $300,000 will go to pay legitimate trash and recycling
expenses that normally are paid from the general fund, such as the salaries of
the workers who pick up the baskets and leaves, or clean trash and debris from
the gutters and catch basins.

Denbowski said the money is a one-time windfall because the city was catching up
with several years of delinquencies. Portnoff will continue to collect the
delinquent fees next year, but he said the amount likely won't be as much.

To see more of the Reading Eagle, or to subscribe, go to
http://www.readingeagle.com. Copyright (c) 2010, Reading Eagle, Pa. Distributed

                             317 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                              The Bismarck Tribune

                            December 11, 2015 Friday

We need to detain fewer kids

SECTION: A; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 535 words


North Dakota knows it has problems with its prison system. Overcrowding has the
state looking for alternatives in other states for housing prisoners and ways to
reduce the inmate count. Two stories on Sunday by reporter Andrew Sheeler looked
at these issues.

A less talked about situation deals with the detention of juvenile delinquents.
A Forum News Service story on Monday noted that North Dakota is the only state
that hasn't seen a drop in the per-capita rate of delinquents required to live
in correctional centers, group homes and other facilities. Experts argue that
evidence shows most delinquents fare better when they can stay with their
families and in their schools, according to the story.

While more than half of states reported a decline of more than 50 percent in the
per-capita rate of delinquents detained from 2001 to 2013, North Dakota saw an
18 percent increase. The figures come from an analysis by the Pew Charitable
Trusts, a national nonprofit group.

Why North Dakota has bucked the trend that has seen all the other states post
declines remains uncertain.

One reason may be related to the lack of mental health and substance abuse
programs in rural communities, resulting in delinquents needing these services
being sent to facilities where they can receive them. Many of these kids are
nonviolent.

While state officials question some of the Pew data, they acknowledge the state
continues to detain more juveniles. They do stress that judges weigh what's best
for the child along with what's in the best interest of the community. The
Tribune doesn't disagree that some juveniles need to be locked up. They have
committed violent crimes and pose a threat to society. However, there doesn't
seem to be a good reason why North Dakota can't reduce its number of kids being
detained.

The Pew study and state officials say the best results occur when juveniles can
stay close to home and school. "Anytime you can serve kids closer to their home
environment, that's the best that we can all do," Lisa Bjergaard, director of
the Juvenile Services Division at the state Department of Corrections and
Rehabilitation, told the Forum News Service.

If other rural states, like Montana, can reduce their numbers, North Dakota
should be able to do so.

North Dakota's Commission on Alternatives to Incarceration has been looking at
ways to reduce the number of inmates in the state, with the main focus on
adults. Sen. Ron Carlisle, R-Bismarck, who chairs the commission, says this is
the type of issue commission members have been examining. They brought a number
of bills to the last legislative session. Just one dealt with juveniles and it
passed. It eliminated the mandatory transfer of juveniles to adult court in
cases that involve making, delivering or possessing drugs.

The commission and other agencies need to find ways to reduce the number of
juveniles being detained. The Tribune has argued for some time that the state
jails too many people. It's essential the state finds ways to rehabilitate
juveniles before they become adult offenders and help clog our cells. This may
require providing more services to rural communities, but it will be worth it if
we can set more kids on the right path.

LOAD-DATE: December 11, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


       Copyright 2015 The Bismarck Tribune, a division of Lee Enterprises
                              All Rights Reserved


                             318 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         Hartford Courant (Connecticut)

                           February 6, 2008 Wednesday
                        3 ENFIELD/NORTH CENTRAL EDITION

BRINGING IN THE OVERDUE TAXES;
MORE AGGRESSIVE COLLECTION URGED

BYLINE: LARRY SMITH; Courant Staff Writer

SECTION: CONNECTICUT; Pg. B3

LENGTH: 357 words

DATELINE: ENFIELD --


Town officials are considering ways to more aggressively pursue delinquent
property taxpayers.

Finance Director Lynn Nenni told the town council Monday that the town collects
about 97 percent of the taxes owed to it. While the collection percentage is
high, the uncollected taxes are worth more than $2 million and are owed by more
than 200 taxpayers, Nenni said.

"To begin with, we really do have a good collection rate," Nenni said.

Nenni is recommending that the town send out notices to delinquent taxpayers on
a more regular basis than their tax bills. She is also recommending that the
town have regular annual auctions on delinquent properties.

Under the current ordinance, the town can't pursue delinquent taxes until three
years have gone by, Nenni said. However, state statutes say delinquency starts
the day after the taxes are due, she said.

Council member William Ragno has been urging the town to do a better job at
collecting delinquent taxes.

Ragno said while a two or three percent non-collection rate may seem small, the
amount of money that represents is significant. Collecting delinquent taxes
could help officials prevent raising taxes for everyone, he said.

"I think it's a matter of being equitable for people paying their taxes," Ragno
said.

Town Attorney Kevin Deneen said the town council has previously passed four
resolutions on tax collections. Deneen said there are some open questions in the
resolutions on issues such as what constitutes an attempt to pay delinquent
taxes that have to be made clear.

The amount of money owed the town, whether through a lien or not, takes
precedence over any other debt the property owner has, Deneen said.

Council members have suggested other ways to encourage paying off delinquencies
such as not letting delinquent contractors bid on town projects, preventing
delinquent developers from doing any developments until their debt is paid or
sending property owners notices other than their bi-annual tax bills.

Mayor Scott Kaupin said the council's general government will oversee research
on the issue before the full council considers a resolution.

Contact Larry Smith at lsmith@courant.com

LOAD-DATE: February 6, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved


                             319 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                     Valley Morning Star (Harlingen, Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             May 11, 2011 Wednesday

San Benito school board president owed taxes

BYLINE: Fernando Del Valle, Valley Morning Star, Harlingen, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 437 words


May 11--SAN BENITO -- School board President Oscar Medrano was delinquent on
property taxes for two years in this town where former Mayor Joe Hernandez was
ousted from office last year when records showed he owed taxes.

Medrano, a volunteer services coordinator at Valley Regional Medical Center in
Brownsville, faces Fatima Huerta, a student at University of Texas at
Brownsville, for the board's Place 6 seat in Saturday's election.

Medrano, who said he paid most of his back taxes Tuesday, owed $1,705.15 in
delinquent taxes, penalties and interest on two properties for 2009 and 2010,
Carlos Rodriguez, supervisor of Cameron County's property tax division, said.

Medrano on Tuesday paid the taxes, penalties and interest on the home on
Poinciana, but remained delinquent on property taxes, penalties and interest on
a lot on Norma Linda Road, Rodriguez said late Tuesday afternoon.

Medrano owed $1,2-

47.28 in taxes, penalties and interest for 2009 and 2010 on a home at 216 N.
Poinciana and $457.87 in delinquent taxes, penalties and interest for 2010 on a
six-acre lot on Norma Linda Road, officials said.

But delinquent taxes will not affect his eligibility to be a candidate because
the school district does not prohibit delinquent taxpayers from seeking or
holding office, Emma McCall, the district's business manager, said.

McCall said Medrano was current on his school taxes.

Since 2004, Medrano was late in paying his taxes on the home on Poinciana,
Rodriguez said.

Medrano, who said he moved from the Poinciana home in 2008, said he hadn't paid
his taxes on the property because he had been trying to sell it to a buyer who
would assume tax liability.

"I'm negotiating right now to sell the house," said Medrano, who was first
elected in 2008.

Unpaid taxes became an issue here when San Benito city commissioners declared
that Hernandez had violated a City Charter clause they claim states that elected
officials forfeit office when they are delinquent on city property taxes.

Hernandez owed taxes on his home, barbershop and lot when he was removed from
office in January 2010.

Hernandez, who has argued the City Charter clause applies to candidates seeking
office, has made an issue of his ouster during his campaign that pits him
against Mayor Jack Garcia.

To see more of the Valley Morning Star, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.valleymorningstar.com/. Copyright (c) 2011, Valley Morning Star,
Harlingen, Texas Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For more
information about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information
Services (MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com.
