                   Morning Star (Wilmington, North Carolina)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                             March 25, 2016 Friday

Delinquent taxpayers owe New Hanover nearly $4 million

BYLINE: Hunter Ingram, Star-News, Wilmington, N.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 812 words


March 25--NEW HANOVER COUNTY -- Nearly $4 million in 2015 property taxes is owed
to New Hanover County as of March 21, according to an annual report released by
the county tax department.

Businesses, corporations, dissolved entities and homeowners are among the 3,635
property owners who owe $3.89 million on parcels in the county. The balances
range from just over $53,000 to $5.82.

The county's tax collection rate was 98.8 percent last year, said county Tax
Administrator Roger Kelley. Property tax bills became delinquent on Jan. 6,
after which time property owners receive two notices.

Wilmington Mayor Bill Saffo's name was on the list for $1,788.96 -- taxes
connected to a lot in an industrial park off North Kerr Ave he formerly owned
along with several family members.

Saffo said the land had been under contract and was set to close last year, but
the closing was delayed until this month. The taxes were paid Monday by a law
firm, according to county records.

"It should have been paid at the time it was due," said the mayor, who said he
did not know of the overdue taxes until he was contacted by the StarNews on
Thursday.

"Obviously you want to pay your taxes," Saffo said. "That's part of living in
the city and living in a great county like ours."

Payment plan

This is the second year in a row that the county's delinquency list has
dwindled. At this time last year, New Hanover was owed $4 million on about 4,200
parcels. In 2014, the county was owed $5.7 million on 4,952 parcels.

Kelley attributes the diminished number of delinquent taxpayers to increased
enrollment in the tax office's coupon program that began in September 2014. The
program allows property owners to pay their taxes in four installments leading
up to the due date. Previously, payment plans were only offered once an account
became delinquent.

"There are a lot of people using them, even some businesses," Kelley said. "A
lot of residents never knew they didn't have to pay it all at once, especially
senior citizens."

Kelly said the county is required by law to run the names of delinquent
taxpayers in print; the list will appear in Sunday's StarNews. But he said the
public tactic doesn't have the same effect it used to.

"It used to be embarrassing for people to see their name in the paper, but now
they don't seem to care," he said.

From high to low

Interest accrues monthly on unpaid property taxes at a rate of 2 percent for
January and 0.75 percent each month after that, Kelley said.

Joyner Marina LLC sits atop this year's list, owing $59,442.19 on two parcels.
Last year, Joyner came in second with $56,793.26 owed on the same two parcels.
Multiple calls to Joyner Marina on Thursday were not returned.

Raleigh-based Foreverhome LLC, which also operated locally under the name
Foreverhome of Wilmington, claims 24 parcels on the list, totaling $53,628.44 in
uncollected taxes. This comes after news broke last summer of the company's
"cash flow problems." At the time, co-founder Mark Ward said the setback was
temporary. The homebuilder had ongoing projects in Wilmington, Middle Sound,
Porters Neck, Castle Hayne and Landfall.

The company could not be reached for comment Thursday.

Foreverhome owned 27 properties on last year's list with unpaid taxes totaling
$37,277.83.

New Hanover Health Investors LLC, which has been dissolved, owes the county
$43,144.42 on one parcel at 3915 Stedwick Court.

City Marina Wilmington LLC owes $34,301.48.

Astor Holdings LLC, which was dissolved in 2009, still owes the county
$27,141.63 in outstanding taxes on four parcels.

But not everyone owes thousands of dollars to the county -- 249 taxpayers owe
less than $20.

Kelley said he understands that some of the uncollected taxes are from people
still climbing their way out of a struggling economy.

"We've still got a lot of unemployed residents out there trying to get caught
up," he said.

Reporter Julian March contributed to this story.

Reporter Hunter Ingram can be reached at 910-343-2327 or
Hunter.Ingram@StarNewsOnline.com

To pay property taxes:

In-person payments -- cashiers check, money order or cash -- can be made at 230
Government Center Drive, Suite 190, between 7:30 a.m. and 5 p.m.

--To pay by check, send payment to New Hanover County Tax Office, PO Box 18000,
Wilmington, NC 28406

--To pay by credit or debit cards, property owners can go to
www.officialpayments.com or call 1-800-2-PAY-TAX. The jurisdiction code is 4345.
A vendor provides this service and charges a fee. Property owners will need
their bill year, type and number.

The New Hanover County Tax Office doesn't accept credit or debit cards at this
time.

Property owners need to indicate their bill year, bill number and type of tax to
ensure their account is credited properly.

___ (c)2016 the Star-News (Wilmington, N.C.) Visit the Star-News (Wilmington,
N.C.) at www.starnewsonline.com Distributed by Tribune Content Agency, LLC.

                            Dayton Daily News (Ohio)

                          September 30, 2010 Thursday

Delinquent water bill changes get OK;
Trotwood will no longer just assess fee to property taxes.

BYLINE: By Toni Coleman Contributing Writer

SECTION: ENGLEWOOD TROTWOOD CLAYTON BROOKVILLE UNION AND DAYTON; Pg. RB2

LENGTH: 432 words


TROTWOOD - An ordinance to establish and refine a more stringent set of
procedures and guidelines to collect the nearly $500,000 owed to Trotwood for
water delinquency charges was unanimously approved by council.

Passage of the ordinance on Sept. 20 allows city manager Mike Lucking and the
finance department to set up a heightened awareness of the debt collection
process. In the past, if water bills were overdue and not paid in full by the
required deadline, the bill was assessed to the individual on their property tax
receipt and sent to the Montgomery County Auditor.

The difficulty with this process is "Trotwood still buys and pays for water
regardless of whether the customer pays or not," Lucking said.

The procedure for the collection of non-payment of delinquent water charges are:

Any delinquent account that's shut off will remain off until all charges are
paid in full. This includes late fees, off and on and return checks charges,
should they apply.

The water service will remain off even if balances have been sent to the county
auditor's office to be placed on the tax duplicate for collection with the
property taxes. Delinquent accounts turned over to the County Auditor for
assessment will need to be paid in full at the auditor's office. A paid in full
receipt for delinquent charges should be presented to the finance department for
service to be restored.

Trotwood has an appeals process if someone wants to dispute their bill and set
up a hearing. "Payment arrangements must be maintained this time around, in
order to keep water services turned on," said Lucking.

In other business

The city dropped its annual leaf pickup program in 2009 to help balance the
city's general fund.

City council leaders requested funds to help ease the burden for senior citizens
this year.

The city council unanimously passed a 7-0 motion Sept. 20, to allocate $25,000
from the city's general fund to assist with leaf pickup on every street in
Trotwood during November.

Rumpke's refuse trucks still offers leaf pickup of as many as 15 bags left at
the curb so they can get rid of leaves until the unbagged (loose) leaves are
picked up in Nov.

Money's still tight, according to Councilman Rap Hankins, who isn't sure how
many times leaves will be picked up on each street. "If we can make more than
one pickup we will, but when the money runs out, it's gone," Hankins said.

The city doesn't plan to increase funding for leaf pickup beyond the amount
already allocated.

The Trotwood City Council meets again Oct. 4 at 7:30 p.m. at the Trot-wood
Community Center council chambers, 4000 Lake Center Drive.

LOAD-DATE: September 30, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                 January 14, 1995, Saturday, FIVE STAR Edition

MSD IS CLOSING BUSINESSES WITH DELINQUENT SEWER BILLS

BYLINE: Fred W. Lindecke Missouri Political Correspondent

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2B

LENGTH: 354 words


The Metropolitan St. Louis Sewer District has started closing businesses that
fail to pay their sewer bills.

The MSD recently plugged the sewer line of four St. Louis businesses, and the
city Water Division shut off water service. The businesses could not operate
because they did not have sanitary facilities.

Two of the businesses later paid their delinquent bills, plus an $ 800 charge
for disconnecting and then reconnecting them with the sewer line, said John
Koeper, the MSD's executive director.

The other two companies are still shut down.

The shutdowns are the first by the MSD to collect delinquent bills, Koeper said.
The sewer district was using a state law enacted in 1993 allowing sewer
companies to work together with water companies to enforce payment of sewer
bills.

"It's a harsh thing to do, but the taxpayers must make up for the lost income if
the bills are not paid," Koeper said. The MSD has about $ 7 million in
delinquent business and residential accounts.

Sewer companies have had chronic difficulty in collecting past-due bills because
customers know how complicated it is to cut off sewer service, Koeper said.

In August, the MSD selected 25 of the biggest delinquent business accounts that
had not responded to dunning over the telephone or liens placed on their
property. One of the accounts dated back to 1981, Koeper said.

After being threatened with shutoff of water and sewer services, 21 paid a total
of nearly $ 80,000. The four customers whose lines were blocked owed more than $
20,000, Koeper said.

Blocking sewer lines of delinquent bill-payers will continue, Koeper said. The
first 25 companies "were the quickest and easiest to do because we could reach
their sewer lines from inside the business. The tough ones will be where we have
to dig up the street. They will have to pay a higher reconnection fee," he said.

The MSD has yet to develop a policy on blocking sewer lines of delinquent
residential customers, Koeper said. "We have to work out a system for
determining who can afford to pay" before proceeding against residential
property, he said.

                                The New York Post

                             April 23, 2004 Friday

TAX DEFAULTS SOAR AS HOMEOWNERS STRUGGLE

BYLINE: LOIS WEISS

SECTION: Sports+Late City Final; Pg. 38

LENGTH: 201 words


New York City homeowners appear to be on the verge of a meltdown.

While home sale prices and tax rates increased last year, the tax delinquency
rate soared, according to a new report.

A Dept. of Finance spokesperson blames the uptick in homeowner delinquency on a
mid-year rebilling plus a rate increase in the same bill. "It's confusion, not
hardship," said Sam Miller. For Class I properties - one- to three-family homes
- the number of delinquent parcels at the end of fiscal year 2003 (from July 1,
2002, to June 30, 2003) rose 50 percent to 137,578, while the amount owed
increased 16 percent to $62.9 million. Comparing Class I delinquencies from
March 31, 2003, to March 31, 2004 - stats not available in the report - the
number of delinquent parcels rose to 81,543 from 127,581. The number of
delinquent Class II condominiums, whose owners are responsible for their own
taxes, increased to 15,688 in 2003 from 8,840 in 2002, going from a 3.3 percent
delinquency rate to 4.6 percent. Another 3,000 condos in Class I were also
delinquent, versus 1,907 the year before.

An 18.5 percent across-the-board tax increase became effective last year. City
Hall is seeking a rebate, which needs Albany's OK.

                                US Official News

                          September 19, 2013 Thursday

Arizona: SENATE BILL 1228

LENGTH: 1251  words

DATELINE: Phoenix


Office of the Legislative, The State of Arizona has issued the following bill:

AN ACT

Amending title 37, chapter 2, article 4, Arizona Revised Statutes, by adding
section 37-287.01; amending sections 37-288 and 37-289, Arizona Revised
Statutes; relating to state trust land leases.

(TEXT OF BILL BEGINS ON NEXT PAGE)


Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Arizona:

Section 1.  Title 37, chapter 2, article 4, Arizona Revised Statutes, is amended
by adding section 37-287.01, to read:

37-287.01.  Default on long-term lease; forfeiture and cancellation of lease;
extension of time for payments

A.  If a lessee of a lease in excess of ten years defaults in a payment of rent,
as provided in the lease, or fails to comply with a condition, covenant or
requirement of the lease, the lease and the lessee's rights under the lease are
subject to forfeiture and cancellation as provided by this section and section
37-289.  Within sixty days after default or failure the department shall notify
the lessee of the default or failure by certified mail to the lessee's last
known address of record with the department.

B.  On the written request of a lessee of a lease in excess of ten years, the
commissioner may extend the time for payment of the delinquent amount for a
period of not more than five years on terms that the commissioner considers to
be appropriate as follows:

1.  The commissioner may grant an extension in response to a request made within
sixty days before the due date of the payment.  An extension under this
paragraph begins on the date the payment was due and continues for the period
stated in a written notice to the lessee.

2.  The commissioner may grant an extension in response to a request made within
sixty days after the date of the default or failure notice provided in
subsection A of this section.  An extension under this paragraph begins on the
date of the notice and continues for the period stated in a written notice to
the lessee.

3.  If the department does not act on a request for extension within thirty days
after receiving the request, the request is considered to be denied.  If the
lessee fails during the period of the extension to complete all delinquent
payments of rent, penalty and interest, the lease is subject to default and
cancellation as provided by this section and section 37[#x2011]289, except that
if the last day of the last period of extension expires on the last day of the
five[#x2011]year period and all delinquent payments have not been paid by the
last day of the five[#x2011]year period, the lease is automatically canceled on
the last day of the five[#x2011]year period and shall be so noted on the records
of the department.

4.  If a payment of rent is made after the due date, payments must be made
according to the extension granted by the commissioner under this subsection.

C.  There shall be added to the delinquent rental a penalty and delinquent
interest.  The rate of interest on delinquent rent shall be set by the state
treasurer.  The penalty shall be the greater of a minimum processing cost as
determined by the commissioner or five per cent.  The delinquent rent, penalty
and interest shall be a lien on the improvements, crops and property on the
land.

Sec. 2.  Section 37-288, Arizona Revised Statutes, is amended to read:

37-288.  Default on short-term lease; forfeiture and cancellation of lease;
extension of time for payment; penalty and interest on delinquent rental;
automatic termination for arrearage

A.  A lessee of state lands violating any condition of the lease shall be in
default and shall forfeit the lease and the lessee's rights under the lease
after cancellation pursuant to section 37[#x2011]289.

A.  If a lessee of a lease of ten years or less defaults in a payment of rent,
as provided in the lease, or fails to comply with a condition, covenant or
requirement of the lease, the lease and the lessee's rights under the lease are
subject to forfeiture and cancellation as provided by this section and section
37-289.

B.  If the lessee of a lease of ten years or less fails to pay the rent when
due, the department may extend the time for payment an additional period not to
exceed ninety days.  The department shall not extend the period for payment of
rental more than three times in one lease year and in no event for more than two
hundred seventy days.

C.  There shall be added to the delinquent rental a penalty and delinquent
interest.  The delinquent rate of interest on delinquent rent shall be set by
the state treasurer under section 37[#x2011]247, subsection D.  The penalty
shall be the greater of a minimum processing cost as determined by the
commissioner or five per cent.  The delinquent rent, penalty and interest shall
be a lien on the improvements, crops and property on the land.

D.  If, on a lease of ten years or less, the annual rental at any time is one
calendar year in arrears from the date the rental payment was due, the lease
shall automatically terminate and the department shall proceed to cancel it on
the records of the department.

Sec. 3.  Section 37-289, Arizona Revised Statutes, is amended to read:

37-289.  Procedure on cancellation of lease; notice, default, hearing and appeal

A.  Before any lease is canceled, the commissioner shall take the following
steps:

1.  Immediate Notice of default shall be sent by certified mail to the lessee
and to any parties who have registered with the department as mortgagees or
other lienholders of the lessee's interest.  The notice shall inform the lessee
and his registered mortgagees and lienholders of the specific nature of any
default and their right to cure any curable default.

2.  For leases of ten years or less, the lessee and his registered mortgagees
and lienholders have thirty days from receipt of notice of default in which to
cure any default involving failure to pay rent, taxes or other assessments, and
forty[#x2011]five days from the receipt of notice to cure any other curable
default.

3.  For leases of more than ten years, the lessee and registered mortgagees and
lienholders have sixty days from receipt of notice of default in which to cure
any curable default.

3.  4.  As a condition of curing a default, the commissioner may require the
lessee and his registered mortgagees and lienholders to waive any right to cure
future defaults of the same type.  A waiver of the right to cure is valid only
until the expiration of the current lease.

B.  If the default is not cured within the applicable time period, the
commissioner may make an order canceling the lease, and if it appears that the
lease was procured through fraud, deceit or wilful misrepresentation, the
improvements on the land shall be forfeited to the state.  If the lease is
canceled for any other reason, the lessee shall be permitted to remove his the
lessee's improvements at any time within sixty days after the date of
cancellation.

C.  In the event of cancellation the commissioner shall make a formal order
canceling the lease, and a copy of the order shall be mailed to the last known
post office address of the lessee and his registered mortgagees and lienholders.

D.  The lessee and his registered mortgagees or other lienholders may appeal a
cancellation order pursuant to title 41, chapter 6, article 10.  If no appeal is
made within the prescribed time or if no notice is filed with the department
pursuant to section 37[#x2011]255, subsection C, the order shall become final
and the lease shall be canceled on the records of the department.

For further information please visit: http://www.azleg.gov/

                             National Mortgage News

                                December 3, 1990

Countrywide Selling Portfolio of Agency Servicing

SECTION: Pg. 8

LENGTH: 529 words

DATELINE: PASADENA, Calif.


Countrywide Servicing Exchange has for sale a $ 50 million Government National
Mortgage Association/Federal National Mortgage Association/Federal Home Loan
Mortgage Corp. servicing portfolio.

There are 690 loans in the portfolio including 385 Ginnie Mae, 238 Fannie Mae
and 67 Freddie Mac.

All loans were originated in Florida.  Most are located in the central part of
the state.  There are 30 loans originated in Broward County (Fort Lauderdale).
There are no loans in Dade County (Miami).

The average loan balance for the entire portfolio is $ 72,293.

The weighted average note rate is 9.974%.  The net service fee is .421%.

The portfolio has a weighted average original term of 327 months and a weighted
average remaining term of 322 months.

The projected average escrow balance is $ 699.  The monthly principal and
interest rate payment is $ 450,651 or $ 653 per loan.

The monthly tax and insurance payment is $ 74,176 or $ 108 per loan.

In the Ginnie Mae portfolio, there are four loans that are delinquent at least
30 days and two that are delinquent at least 60 days.

All loans are fixed-rate and level payment.  All pools will have final
certification within the timeframe required by Ginnie Mae.

The Fannie Mae portion of the package has five loans that are delinquent at
least 30 days.

All loans were sold on a non-recourse basis.

There are no participations or graduated payment mortgages.  There is one
buydown loan with a principal balance of $ 171,087.

The 25 balloon loans have a 30-year amortization schedule for the principal and
interest and are due in seven years.

There are 12 adjustable-rate mortgages in the Fannie Mae portfolio.  All are
tied to the one-year Treasury bill with a margin of 2.750%.  Interest and
payments adjust annually.

All the loans have an annual interest rate cap of 2.00% and lifetime interest
rate cap of 6.00%.

There is one delinquent loan in the Freddie Mac portfolio.

All loans were sold on a non-recourse basis, and are fixed-rate and level
payment.

Countrywide also is offering for sale a $ 103.1 million Government National
Mortgage Association mortgage servicing portfolio.

The portfolio consists of 1,256 loans, all originated in California.  There are
1,036 FHA loans and 220 VA loans.

The weighted average note rate is 9.935%.  The weighted average net service fee
is .440%.

The portfolio had an original term of 360 months and a weighted average
remaining term of 352 months.

There are 24 loans that are delinquent at least 30 days.  There is one loan that
is delinquent 60 days.  There are no foreclosures.

The monthly principal and interest payment is $ 903,471 or $ 719 per loan.

The projected average escrow balance is $ 627.

There are 47 pools in the portfolio.  At this time, 15 have received final
certification, and nine additional pools have been submitted for final
certification.

According to Countrywide, all pools will be certified within the time frame
required by Ginnie Mae.

All the loans were originated by the seller on a retail basis.

Over 95% are on single family detatched residences.  A similar figure is given
for owner occupied properties in portfolio.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                             350 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                          South Bend Tribune (Indiana)

                   August 27, 2005 Saturday Michigan Edition

County owed millions in taxes;
First tax sale in three years tentatively set for Oct. 3.

BYLINE: By JAMES WENSITS; Tribune Political Writer

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. B5

LENGTH: 452 words


SOUTH BEND -- St. Joseph County is owed $17.7 million in delinquent property
taxes, and county officials are doing their best to collect some of it.

Even if they do, though, it won't help the county's current budget crunch.

That's because state tax laws set a ceiling on the tax levy -- the amount of
taxes that can be spent. The levy is allowed to increase slightly each year but
it isn't directly affected, by an increase in tax collections.

To further the collection process, county Treasurer Sean Coleman has started
sending out notices warning delinquent taxpapers that their properties can be
sold for back taxes.

Coleman has set Oct. 3 as the tentative date for the tax sale, which would be
the first held by the county in three years.

Tax sales are normally held annually, but the county has been in turmoil because
of the last reassessment and changes in how property is assessed.

In all, the treasurer said he is sending out 5,894 delinquent tax notices. Those
notices are expected to generate new income for the county as people scramble to
pay what they owe rather than lose their property.

Not all of the tax notices are expected to bear fruit.

According to Coleman, some of the delinquent properties are already owned by
government entities, some are pending an appeal and some are not eligible for
tax sale because they are in bankruptcy actions.

Even if the list of delinquent property owners that can be collected from is
pared down considerably, the potential for tax income is enormous.

A recent review of county government operations recommended that the county hold
a tax sale because of that potential.

According to that report, just under 2,100 parcels that were eligible for a
recent tax sale in Delaware County (Muncie) generated $2.6 million in taxes
collected before the sale and $894,000 more at the sale itself.

In Porter County, with just more than 1,000 eligible parcels, $1.8 million was
collected before the sale and $629,000 more at the sale.

No matter how much money is generated by the St. Joseph County tax sale, Chief
Deputy Auditor John Lentz said state law won't allow any of it to finance next
year's county budget.

Under state law, the county is allowed a tax levy of $30.4 million for next
year. If $5 million should be collected at the tax sale, Lentz said, it would go
into an excess levy fund and be held until next year, when it would be
subtracted from the available levy for the 2007 budget.

Because the tax levy is the result of the overall assessed valuation multiplied
by the tax rate, the net effect would be to lower property taxes.

Staff writer James Wensits:

jwensits@sbtinfo.com

(574) 235-6353


LOAD-DATE: August 30, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                 Copyright 2005 South Bend Tribune Corporation

                            March 19, 2015 Thursday

BRIEF: Pittston focusing on delinquent fees

BYLINE: Sarah Scinto, The Times-Tribune, Scranton, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 163 words


March 19--PITTSTON -- City officials hope to begin recouping about $500,000 in
delinquent sewer maintenance fees with an amendment to the city's code.

City council voted unanimously Wednesday night to amend the Sewer Rents and
Charges section of the city's code to allow Wyoming Valley Sewer Authority to
shut off water service to properties with delinquent fees.

City Manager Joe Moskovitz said about 1,100 properties within city limits have
delinquent sewer fees.

Mr. Moskovitz noted the city raised its sewer maintenance fees this year partly
because of the large amount of delinquent fees.

The amendment includes several payment plan options for people who have fallen
behind on their sewer maintenance fees. Mr. Moskovitz said the city is willing
to work with residents and property owners to help them keep their water
service.

               The Valley News-Dispatch (Tarentum, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              April 8, 2013 Monday

Trip raises delinquent tax issue at Highlands School District

BYLINE: Tom Yerace, The Valley News-Dispatch, Tarentum, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 785 words


April 08--A Highlands School Board member owes the district $33,000 in
delinquent taxes on four properties.

Despite that, board member Ron Lang plans to attend a national school conference
in California later this week -- a trip that will cost taxpayers about $2,000.

An eight-year member of the board, Lang owes the taxes on his house on Ninth
Avenue in Brackenridge and three business properties in Tarentum, according to
the Highlands Tax Office.

"I had business complications a while back," Lang said. "I put this on a payment
plan agreement with the school district. It's just dirty politics."

The issue arose when fellow board member Debbie Beale submitted a letter to the
editor of the Valley News Dispatch about it.

Records show that Lang owes:

--About $9,600 in back taxes on his house from 2007 through 2010.

--$12,800 on the Praha Hotel in Tarentum, his primary business from 2007 through
2011.

--About $10,600 on the building along Fifth Avenue in Tarentum that houses
Bangor's bar, plus a separate but adjoining rear lot that faces Fourth Avenue.
Those taxes are delinquent for the years 2007 through 2011.

District Business Manager Jon Rupert confirmed that Lang is on a payment plan,
paying $500 per month on the taxes plus a penalty and 10 percent interest.

Lang said he intends to have the taxes paid up around Labor Day.

Beale said constituents asked her to look into the matter while passing out her
nominating petitions for the upcoming primary election. Both she and Lang are
unopposed in District 2 in May.

The tax office confirmed Lang is the only board member who is delinquent on
taxes.

Problems not unique

Rupert said such delinquencies are not unusual.

"I know this happened before and he came in and paid it all off," Rupert said.
"People go in cycles."

Beale said she tried to keep the matter "behind closed doors," bringing it up at
a closed executive session and asked Lang to "do the right thing."

"What set me off is that he booked a trip to California for the national
convention," Beale said. "I cannot be a representative for the taxpayers and sit
there and support that. I can't do it. I won't do it."

The National School Boards Association conference is in San Diego from April
12-15.

Rupert said it costs the district about $2,300 to send a board member to the
conference, including airfare, hotel and registration.

"How could he possibly think that it would be OK for him to have the taxpayers
pay for him to go to a national convention?" Beale said. "I had no clue that
this was going on. None of us did."

"What's the difference from going to San Diego or going to Hershey?" Lang said.

He said Beale goes to the state school boards' convention in Hershey every year
and the district pays for the hotel, convention costs and driving mileage.

The airfare for the San Diego conference is $375, according to Rupert. The
driving reimbursement is 56.5 cents per mile, so the district pays $251 for a
board member to make the 445-mile round trip to Hershey.

"I will not bill the district a penny for food," Lang said. "The only thing (the
district pays for) is the airfare and the hotel."

Lang said he would not answer any other questions on the advice of his attorney,
saying he is considering legal action against Beale.

But, he said, Beale has had her own tax problems with the district.

According to a case file from District Judge Carolyn Bengel's office, Beale and
her husband, William, settled a 2009 civil complaint filed by Highlands over
$2,481 in unpaid wage taxes from 2003 and 2004. The Beales paid $2,588 for the
taxes and court costs.Beale said the case resulted from her husband working in
Newton Falls, Ohio, and his wage taxes being withheld and paid there. She said
her husband asked Newton Falls to forward the taxes back home. She said they
believed that was done, but it wasn't.

When asked about Lang's tax situation, board President Carrie Fox said, "I
believe people need to pay their taxes. But I don't know everybody's personal
problems and personal issues. I don't know what's going on in (Lang's) life."

She said Lang does a good job serving on the board. She also noted he served as
Highlands girls basketball head coach in 2012-13 -- without pay.

"I've told the board it is not up to us to judge him," Fox said. "It is up to
the electors out in the Valley, the people who elect him," she said.

Beale said she's not judging Lang.

"I just don't think he should take this trip," she said.

Tom Yerace is a staff writer for Trib Total Media. He can be reached at
724-226-4675 or tyerace@tribweb.com

-tax-issue-at-Highlands-School-District-0408-20130408

                  The State Journal-Register (Springfield, IL)

                             July 5, 2003 Saturday

County auction of delinquent properties slated Aug. 5

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. 19

LENGTH: 108 words


Sangamon County will auction 169 properties that were delinquent on property
taxes for 1999 and earlier at a public auction at 6 p.m. Aug. 5 at the Prairie
Capital Convention Center.

Bidding will start at $450 per property. Bidders are encouraged to attend the
auction sale. Each item will sell to the highest bidder.

Sale catalogs are available for $10 each at the Sangamon County treasurer's
office in Springfield.

For further information, contact the auction sale department of the Sangamon
County Delinquent Tax Agent's Office at (800) 248-2850 or (618) 656-5744.

Office hours are 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. Monday through Friday.

                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          September 5, 2012 Wednesday

Erie Redevelopment Authority seeks tax forgiveness

BYLINE: Erica Erwin, Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 430 words


Sept. 05--The Erie Redevelopment Authority today will ask Erie City Council to
forgive delinquent taxes on 15 properties to make the properties more attractive
for resale.

"Ultimately, the idea here is to see these properties improved and returned to
the tax rolls," said Kim Green, the authority's executive director.

City Council will vote on whether to forgive back taxes, fines and penalties
that amounted to $13,773 as of Tuesday, according to Erie County tax records.
That amount does not include fees.

Most of the properties are vacant parcels. Each of the properties was declared
tax exempt by the Erie County Board of Tax Assessment Appeals in fall 2011, but
the board has no authority to forgive delinquent taxes, Green said. The latest
delinquency dates back to 2006; most properties are delinquent for more than one
year.

The back taxes make it more difficult to sell the properties, Green said. The
2013 assessed value of the properties ranges from $4,300 to $123,900, according
to county tax records. The total amount owed on the properties, including
delinquent taxes, penalties and interest but excluding fees, ranges from $21.10
to nearly $10,230.

"Nobody's going to purchase these for the amounts owed on them," Green said.
"They're going to continue to be blighted properties that make the value of the
properties in the other neighborhood go down. The goal is to get them back in
productive use so the properties can pay taxes to the city, the county and the
school districts."

The authority, which is largely funded through state and federal grants, has no
money to pay the back taxes, Green said. The grants can't be used to pay
delinquent taxes, she said.

"When the buyer does come in and buys the property, we have to use the money the
buyer gives us to pay back the federal government for the acquisition cost, the
demolition cost, so we rarely ever see a profit on these properties," she said.

The authority also intends to ask two other taxing bodies -- Erie County and the
Erie School District -- for forgiveness on the same properties, Green said. As
of Tuesday, the total owed to the county and school district, including back
taxes, interest and penalties but excluding fees, was $7,104 and $20,550,
respectively.

All three taxing bodies would have to approve of the move before any delinquent
property taxes are forgiven.

ERICA ERWIN can be reached at 870-1846 or by e-mail. Follow her on Twitter at
twitter.com/ETNerwin.

                       Florida Times-Union (Jacksonville)

                            April 21, 2010 Wednesday

Credit unions' bad loans fewer than banks;
A majority of the Jacksonville businesses did lose money in '09.

BYLINE: MARK BASCH

SECTION: Pg. D-1

LENGTH: 855 words


Just like the trend in the local banking industry, many of Jacksonville's credit
unions posted net losses in 2009.

But unlike the commercial banks, credit unions aren't saddled with large numbers
of problem loans that threaten their future financial health.

A look at the 2009 financial reports filed by all 24 federally-insured credit
unions headquartered in the Jacksonville metropolitan area shows that a majority
did lose money last year, as the weak economy caused some borrowers to default
on their loans. But after writing off those loans last year, the credit unions
didn't carry a lot of bad loans on their books into 2010.

"The overall health is actually really good," said Terry West, president and CEO
of VyStar Credit Union, Jacksonville's largest credit union.

At the end of 2009, the total amount of delinquent loans at the 24 credit unions
equaled only 2.1 percent of all loans. Meanwhile, bad loans at Jacksonville's 16
commercial banks equaled 11.6 percent of all loans.

More ominously for banks, the total amount of overdue loans was about equal to
their total capital. That means if the banks have to write off all those bad
loans, it will wipe out their capital. But the credit unions' bad loans equaled
only 14.4 percent of their capital.

John Hirabayashi, president of Community First Credit Union of Florida, said
credit unions are more conservative than commercial banks in their lending
practices.

"One of the biggest differences is credit unions aren't into commercial real
estate loans as much as banks," Hirabayashi said.

He also said credit unions don't make "exotic" loans.

"Credit unions mostly originate what we would call conforming Fannie Mae loans,"
he said.

Credit unions are financial institutions that are formed to serve a group of
people with a common bond, such as employees of one company or people who live
in a community. The credit unions are cooperative institutions owned by their
members, unlike banks that are owned by a group of shareholders.

"There is pressure on them to generate earnings but it's not the same as a
for-profit institution" said Chip Filson, president of Callahan & Associates, a
Washington, D.C., firm that provides consulting services for the credit union
industry.

With the weak economy, lending by banks decreased in 2009. But the credit union
industry increased lending by 7 percent last year to a record of $272 billion in
new loans, Filson said.

"The credit unions exist to serve the membership, not the marketplace," he said.
"They kept lending because that's what they're in business to do."

Although credit unions have fewer problem loans than banks, the economy did take
a toll in 2009.

"We have people who normally pay their bills who can't. They don't have the
money," said West.

VyStar was profitable in 2009, but West expects some credit unions to lose money
this year.

"With unemployment this high, you're going to continue to see losses through
2010," he said.

But West is optimistic about the overall state of the credit union industry.

"The vast majority are weathering the storm pretty well," he said.

mark.basch@jacksonville.com, (904) 359-4308

JACKSONVILLE CREDIT UNIONS

This chart shows 2009 financial data for all federally-insured credit unions
headquartered in the Jacksonville metropolitan area, based on reports filed with
the National Credit Union Administration.

CATEGORIES DEFINED

Assets: The size of the credit union.

Net worth/assets ratio: The credit union's net worth (its capital) as a
percentage of its assets as of Dec. 31, 2009.

2009 earnings, or net loss.

Delinquent loans/loan ratio: The amount of delinquent loans as a percentage of
the credit union's total loans. Delinquent loans are defined as loans in which
the borrower is behind on payments by two months or more.

Delinquent loans/net worth ratio: Delinquent loans as a percentage of the credit
union's net worth.

                             356 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            February 2, 2014 Sunday

Erie City Council to start 'brainstorming' solutions for delinquent trash fees

BYLINE: Kevin Flowers, Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 504 words


Feb. 02--Erie City Council has promised to aggressively tackle the issue of more
than $1.6 million in delinquent garbage fees.

That work begins this week at the panel's first Finance Committee meeting of
2014.

Councilwoman Jessica Horan-Kunco said overdue garbage bills -- and
"brainstorming" ways to more effectively collect them -- will be the top agenda
item at Wednesday's meeting.

Horan-Kunco will serve as City Council's Finance Committee chairwoman this year.

Erie Water Works Chief Executive Paul Vojtek and Paul Lichtenwalter, the city's
finance director, will attend, Horan-Kunco said. Mayor Joe Sinnott said City
Solicitor Greg Karle's office will also send a representative.

"We want to talk about the collection and billing process now with Erie Water
Works, how it's working now, when liens are filed against those who are
delinquent and things like that," Horan-Kunco said. "We want to talk to the
Solicitor's Office about what our possible legal remedies are. We're in the
initial stages of these conversations, but we want to see what might be possible
with the collections."

Delinquent garbage fees have become a hot-button issue both at City Hall and
with the public in the wake of council's Dec. 18 passage of the city's $69.7
million budget for 2014.

That budget included increases in city residents' garbage and sewer fees, which
meant $3.1 million in new money for the spending plan.

The garbage fee increase means that the average city resident will see garbage
fees rise from an average of $48 every three months, or $192 per year, to $55
every quarter, or $220 per year, Lichtenwalter has said.

Many city residents, though, have expressed outrage that the garbage fees were
increased at a time when hundreds of customers refuse to pay their bills.

The Erie Times-News reported on Jan. 19 that as of Dec. 31, garbage
delinquencies total nearly $1.6 million, according to the Water Works.

Further, when you include municipal liens totaling more than $930,000 filed
against many other delinquent accounts, the total delinquency amount swells to
about $2.5 million, said Vojtek, the Erie Water Works' chief executive.

City Council included what's known as sunset provisions on the garbage fee
increase, meaning it is in place for 2014 only, unless council agrees to an
extension.

The provision was intended to push Sinnott's administration, council and other
city officials to work together to find a solution to the delinquency problem.

Council members have talked about a number of possible alternatives, including
hiring a collection agency to go after the delinquent revenue and rolling
garbage payments into property owners' yearly tax bills.

Sinnott has said the city could soon launch a searchable database of delinquent
garbage customers on its website, www.erie.pa.us.

KEVIN FLOWERS can be reached at 870-1693 or by e-mail. Follow him on Twitter at
twitter.com/ETNflowers.

                              Bank Technology News

                                 September 2012

"Kinder, Gentler" Collections;
BBVA Compass has created a web portal that lets delinquent debtors work out
their own issues in the privacy of their home

BYLINE: Penny Crosman

SECTION: HOTTOPICS: SELF-SERVICE; Pg. 8 Vol. 25 No. 9

LENGTH: 802  words


The stereotypical collections process, often a hash of stern automated messages,
threatening calls from live collections agents and excessive penalties, has long
stood in need of an upgrade.

BBVA Compass, Birmingham, Ala., is using technology to create a "kinder,
gentler" system that's also far more efficient and cost-effective. It has built
a self-service website that delinquent borrowers and cardholders can use to ask
for help, schedule a payment, or make a promise to pay (calling off the
collections hounds for whatever time period the customer specifies).

"We began having conversations several years ago about how we could leverage
convenience in terms of how the customer wants to interact with us," says Mark
Tuggle, executive vice president and director of collection and recovery at BBVA
Compass. "Sometimes banks make the mistake of building a process down to the
customer. We felt the best approach would be to build it from the customer
view."

Tuggle's team thought about how they would want to interact with a bank in the
case of a delinquent account.

"Some customers would prefer to handle the transaction by going online and
making a payment or making a promise that they'll make a payment at another time
or schedule a time to talk to us," Tuggle says. "We built all of that into our
Web Promises application."

Online, customers are directed to authenticate themselves, shown the current
status of any overdue accounts, asked to provide current contact information,
and offered several options. They can make an ACH payment from any bank account,
they can send the bank a note, they can make a promise to pay at a future date
or they can ask to be called back at an appointed time.

The bankers originally expected that most of the users of the app would be early
stage delinquent accounts, 15 to 30 days past due. But they're also seeing a
fair amount of usage on more chronic delinquent accounts. "We are happy to see
both," Tuggle says, although he would not share any usage numbers. Adoption is
increasing, he says.

"Just because a customer is delinquent doesn't mean we don't value them," he
says. "They're a customer like any other customer, we want to take care of their
needs."

BBVA Compass built the customer interface for this application. The engine that
takes the customer's input and feeds it in real time to the bank's collections
system is software from CGI called Web Promises; CGI also provides the ACH
interaction that enables payments to be made from the site. The system used by
the bank's collections agents, CACS, is also a CGI product. The transactions are
all real time, so if a customer promises to make a payment in two weeks, that
information is immediately provided to the collections agent handling that
account and the record shows that that customer should not be called until after
that date, plus a few grace days.

The setup of the new site and integration with collections operations and ACH
took about nine months.

"This had a fairly high level of difficulty, it was uncharted territory at the
time, at least from a collections perspective," Tuggle says. There was also an
authentication piece to be built in (the bank ended up extending software it
uses elsewhere for fraud detection), to ensure the bank was talking to the right
people, and it also took time to get signoff from the legal and compliance
departments.

The bank has not yet seen a drop in delinquency or chargeoff rates from using
this tool.

"We'll know more as usage rates increase," Tuggle says. "The true value is the
efficiencies gained internally on the cost side. The more customers want
self-help, we want them to have that capability to do that.

"Those customers that need personal assistance, we want to talk to see if we can
help them. There's efficiency for us, but moreover for the customer there's the
convenience piece. Some customers just want to make a payment and they don't
want to talk to us. We want to facilitate that."

One benefit the bank is seeing: while regulations restrict the hours outbound
collections calls can be made, the website operates 24/7.

The next step for this project is to add other pieces of multichannel contact.
Text alerts, chat and loan portals for loan modification assistance are all
being looked at. Some of this is constrained by the regulatory environment right
now, he says.

"The whole idea of kinder, gentler collections is the right thing to do," Tuggle
says. "There is a fair amount of regulation around how to interact with the
customer. We think by providing communication channels for our customers that
they are comfortable with, our results will be better. There's the old school
and the new school, and we've signed up for the new school."

BOTTOMLINE

BBVA Compass is exploring collections that are more efficient and more
compassionate at the same time.

URL: http://www.americanbanker.com/btn.html/

LOAD-DATE: September 4, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Magazine

JOURNAL-CODE: BTN

                     Valley Morning Star (Harlingen, Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              May 21, 2012 Monday

Late tax notices are out

BYLINE: Allen Essex, Valley Morning Star, Harlingen, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 440 words


May 21--BROWNSVILLE -- A total of 32,446 delinquent property tax notices for
2011 are in the mail but property owners have options to avoid a lawsuit aimed
at collecting back taxes, Cameron County Tax Assessor-Collector Tony Yzaguirre
said.

"I urge any property owner who cannot pay their taxes in full to visit any of
our tax offices and take advantage of payment plan options," Yzaguirre said.

Installment plans are available to pay taxes, penalties and interest, he said.

On July 1, all delinquent tax accounts will be turned over to a law firm for
collection, he said.

"At that point a 15 percent or 20 percent attorney fees, depending upon the
policy adopted by each tax jurisdiction, will be automatically assessed or added
to the balance of taxes due unless the taxpayer enters into a tax payment
agreement," he said.

Taxes for 2011 became delinquent on Feb. 1, but if a taxpayer signs an agreement
with the Tax Assessor-Collector's Office before June 30, no attorney fees for
taxes due for 2011 will be added on July 1 to taxpayers who continue to make
timely payments, Yzaguirre said.

"The installment plan provides taxpayers a little relief by allowing them
several additional months to pay their taxes in installments without threat of a
lawsuit," he said.

A penalty does not apply to delinquent taxes subject to installment agreements
before July 1, Yzaguirre said.

He said property may not be seized or sold and a lawsuit may not be filed to
collect delinquent taxes subject to an installment agreement, unless the
property owner:

- Fails to make a payment as required by the agreement,

- Fails to pay other property taxes collected by the unit when due as required
by the collector,

- Or breaches any other condition of the agreement.

Elderly or disabled taxpayers may also sign a deferral agreement stating they
cannot afford to pay their property taxes, but taxes will continue to accumulate
until the property changes hands, Yzaguirre said.

Disabled or senior citizens over age 65 may make quarterly payments of their
property taxes if they qualify for an exemption under Section 11.13(c) of the
Property Tax Code, Yzaguirre said. Those who make quarterly payments on time
will not be assessed penalties for late payments, he said.

All 2011 personal property taxes not paid prior to April 3 have already been
turned over to the law firm for collection, Yzaguirre said.

Payments may be made online by credit card or Internet check (iCheck) at:
www.cameroncountytax.org, he said.

(Harlingen, Texas) at www.valleymorningstar.com Distributed by MCT Information

                       Copyright 2012 Valley Morning Star


                             359 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                            Dayton Daily News (Ohio)

                            October 6, 2005 Thursday

Delinquent taxpayers beware!;
Names will be published in paper; predatory lenders likely will come calling

BYLINE: By Ken McCall kmccall@DaytonDailyNews.com

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 549 words


DAYTON - If you're behind on your property taxes, you'll soon have two more
things to worry about, Montgomery County Treasurer Hugh Quill warned at a
Wednesday news conference.

All property owners in the county who have been declared delinquent on their
property taxes will not only face additional fees, but they are also going to
get their names in the paper. Twice.

As a result, Quill cautioned, delinquent owners may find themselves besieged by
predatory lenders trying to take advantage of their difficulties by offering
costly loans.

The treasurer's office is getting ready to auction off property tax liens to
investors on Nov. 19. State law requires the county to publish the names and
addresses of delinquent property owners twice before the sale can go forward.

Quill said his office has sent out three warnings to delinquent taxpayers, and
the new program has already been a success. More than 5,500 owners paid their
back taxes in full since Aug. 29, he said, resulting in more than $7 million in
additional tax revenue. Another 2,000 owners have set up payment programs, he
said.

In addition, Quill said, overall collections are up more than would be expected
by rising property values. He estimates the program has resulted in more than
$27 million in additional collected taxes that will mostly go to local schools.

"We have obviously convinced people who have used nonpayment of taxes as a way
of financing real estate speculation that we are serious," Quill said.

Nevertheless, he said, about 6,000 property owners remain delinquent, so their
names and properties will be published twice this month in the Dayton Daily
News. Predatory lenders, he said, are likely to use the list to try to sell
loans.

"This is going to be a neon sign to predatory lenders out there who have been
prowling our streets for many, many years," Quill said.

An inflated property appraisal, large prepayment penalty, cash incentives and a
large balloon payment at the end of the loan are some of the possible signs of a
predatory loan.

Quill urged county residents to call his office or the Miami Valley Fair Housing
Center*if they have concerns about predatory lending.

Jim McCarthy, president of the center, encouraged property owners to call his
office or visit the center's Web site for information. The center, he said, can
not only help educate people about predatory lending but can also help folks who
have been victimized.

"Be wary of anyone who would contact you offering assistance with your
mortgage," McCarthy said. "The bottom line is ... if it sounds too good to be
true, it probably is."

The Rev. Robert Baines, president of the Dayton NAACP, said his organization
also is getting involved in the battle against predatory lending, because the
African-American community has been "disproportionately affected, some would say
five times as likely" to be targeted by unscrupulous lenders and loan brokers.
He urged other black community organizations, churches and mosques to join the
fight.

The NAACP, Baines said, will help with community outreach and lobby the state
legislature for changes in law.

"If we can fix the system," Baines said, "we can resist victimization not by
just educating the targeted people, but by preventing predatory lenders from
coming into our community in the first place."

LOAD-DATE: October 10, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                     Copyright 2005 Dayton Newspapers, Inc.


                             360 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        The Augusta Chronicle (Georgia)

                              July 9, 2006 Sunday
                                  ALL EDITION

DEBTS COMPOUND WOES;
COLLECTING UNPAID ACCOUNTS COULD REMEDY BUDGET DEFICIT

BYLINE: By Sylvia Cooper Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A01

LENGTH: 880 words


City of Augusta department heads have been ordered to cut their budgets 15
percent, layoffs are inevitable, a property-tax increase is certain, as is more
borrowing from emergency reserves - all to plug a $5 million deficit in this
year's budget.

Some of those measures would not be necessary, however, if the city could
collect its share of the $6.83 million in overdue property taxes from 1998
through last year, a sum that doesn't include a one-time 10 percent penalty and
annual 12 percent interest compounded. Throw in $821,868 in unpaid garbage fees
and $138,044 in delinquent business license fees, and employees would be assured
of getting to keep all of the 8 percent raises commissioners gave them last
year.

And that's without mentioning the millions in uncollected court fees and fines,
such as the more than $8 million from misdemeanor cases in Augusta since 1998
and $2.4 million still unpaid before that year. The uncollected total from
felony cases was not available from the state Department of Corrections last
week.

When Augusta-Richmond County sends out property tax bills, the city gets about
40 percent, the school board gets about 59 percent and the state gets a tiny
share, about 0.75 percent of every dollar assessed, said Jack McAdams, the chief
financial officer for the Richmond County Tax Commission.

The long-term solution of cracking down on delinquent accounts once trumpeted by
former Mayor Bob Young would seem to be the simplest, but commissioners have
never shown much enthusiasm for such activity. Mr. Young's effort was not a
stunning success, and since his departure, such an effort had no champion.

Enter City Commissioner Joe Bowles.

Mr. Bowles, elected late last year, said he started looking around for money to
remedy the budget deficit.

"I'd like to see us turn it over to a collection agency," he said. "I definitely
think the city needs to address the situation of $7 million in uncollected
taxes. It would be beneficial to the city and school board."

However, Tax Commissioner Jerry Saul would have to approve such a move, Mr.
Bowles said, which is why he wants commissioners to meet with Mr. Saul.

"I think it's worth the commission exploring any possibility of collecting
revenue," Mr. Bowles said.

Some commissioners say measures to collect would hurt the poor, but there are
procedures for not doing that, Mr. Bowles said.

"There are just ways you can go around and not hurt seniors on a fixed income,"
he said.

Currently the tax commission places liens on property with delinquent taxes and
takes legal steps to seize and sell those with the largest balances and
multiple-year delinquencies, said North Williamson, the delinquent tax
commissioner.

About 1 percent of delinquent taxes are not collectable because the debtors have
gone bankrupt or left town with all their assets.

Last month, Augusta mayoral candidate Steven Kendrick proposed a one-time
property tax amnesty aimed at collecting delinquent taxes. During the 30- to
60-day amnesty, penalties and interest on delinquent accounts would be waived to
encourage people to pay up.

Mr. Williamson doesn't think that would work.

"If they didn't pay before there was a penalty and interest, what makes him
think they would pay now?" he asked.

In addition to past-due taxes and fees that directly affect the city's general
fund, utility bills delinquent more than 90 days total $388,164 and overdue
landfill fees $277,440.

Those departments operate as "enterprise funds," which means they operate as
businesses do and should be self-supporting, which the utility department is.
But when deficits occur in them, cash from the general fund must be used to fund
the department's cash-flow needs.

Because of annual 11 percent increases in water and sewer bills since 2001,
utility finances are in good shape, the danger there being that Augusta
commissioners might be tempted to tap into those funds to help pay for
government operations, as was done in the old city of Augusta before
consolidation.

The city's revenue bond documents prohibit such transfers, but they probably
would not be illegal, only detrimental to the city's reputation with bond-rating
agencies, according to Steve Little, the utility department's assistant director
of finance and administration.

The city's garbage collection fund is a different story. In the 2004 city audit,
Cherry Bekaert & Holland noted an accumulated deficit in the fund that had
increased about $1 million per year for two years, causing the general fund to
advance more than $1 million of its pooled cash balance to fund garbage
collection, bringing the total borrowed from the general fund to about $1.7
million. Last year, the deficit grew by another $1 million.

The auditors recommended that management review the garbage collection fund and
change its operations to address the increasing deficit and resolve the existing
accumulated deficit. Solid Waste Director Mark Johnson said the main reason for
the deficit is that fees were not increased the five years of operation although
hauler contract costs went up.

City Administrator Fred Russell favors almost any plan for raising money that
commissioners approve because they have given him the burden of finding $5
million.

Reach Sylvia Cooper at (706) 823-3228

or sylvia.cooper@augustachronicle.com.

County Tax Commissioner's office at the Greene Street Municipal Building.

                         The Tribune (Seymour, Indiana)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           October 13, 2010 Wednesday

Tax sale nets $1.7 million

BYLINE: Aubrey Woods, The Tribune, Seymour, Ind.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 568 words


Oct. 13--The county's annual delinquent property tax sale conducted Oct. 6
netted more than $1.7 million from owners and buyers.

"Tax sales are a necessary function of county government," Jackson County
Treasurer Kathy Hohenstreiter said of the sale.

Hohenstreiter, who conducted the sale along with county Auditor Debbie Eggeman,
said it is only fair to the people who pay their property taxes every year to
pursue those who do not pay.

She said before the sale was conducted, the owners of 509 parcels paid their
delinquencies, penalties and costs in full and were able to keep their
properties. That allowed the county to collect $1,606,697.56 in delinquent
taxes.

That money will be distributed to local taxing units, including schools,
libraries, municipalities and the county, during the second property tax
distribution in December.

Property may be sold at the property tax sale to satisfy the tax obligation and
is sold to the highest bidder.

The former owners of property sold at the sale have one year after the sale to
redeem the delinquent property taxes and costs and penalties to keep their
property. They also must pay 10 percent of the delinquent property taxes to
redeem the property.

"If those people do not come and redeem the property, the new owners get to keep
the property," Hohenstreiter said.

SRI Inc. of Indianapolis conducted the sale of 139 parcels, which were offered
to 35 bidders.

Seventy of those properties did not sell. The 69 that did brought in another
$107,954.09 in back taxes.

County commissioners will acquire liens on the 70 properties that did not sell
during the delinquent property tax sale and may offer those properties to the
public at a sale at a later date.

The county charges a $25 fee for its costs to hold the sale, and SRI Inc. also
charges a fee, Hohenstreiter said.

The state requires each of the 92 counties to hold a property tax sale for those
properties where an owner has failed to pay property taxes from the prior year's
first installment. There was no  property tax sale in 2009 in Jackson County
because there was just one property tax bill deadline late in the year because
of delays in reassessment, Hohenstreiter said.

Eggeman said in a press release that the ultimate goal is to return these
properties to the tax rolls as quickly and efficiently as possible.

"Property owned by people that pay their property taxes ensure our local
government services are fully funded," Eggeman said.

How to pay

Second installments of property taxes are due Nov. 10

Taxes may be paid in person at the Jackson County treasurer's office at the
courthouse in Brownstown.

Taxpayers may also pay at The Peoples Bank branches in Brownstown, Crothersville
and Seymour as well as State Bank of Medora or online at www.jackson-tax.net.

Homeowners are also reminded to send in the pink homestead verification form to
the Jackson County auditor's office. The form was included with this year's
property tax bills and must be returned by Jan. 1, 2013.

To see more of The Tribune or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.tribtown.com/. Copyright (c) 2010, The Tribune, Seymour, Ind.
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For more information
about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services
(MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com, e-mail services@mctinfoservices.com, or
call 866-280-5210 (outside the United States, call +1 312-222-4544).

                        The York Dispatch (Pennsylvania)

                            December 11, 2009 Friday

Tax-delinquent York County firms owe $262,000

BYLINE: CHRISTINA KAUFFMAN The York Dispatch

SECTION: BUSINESS

LENGTH: 403 words


Six York County businesses are on a list of 244 delinquent taxpayers released by
the state Thursday.

The six local firms owe more than $262,000 in employer-withheld taxes and sales
taxes, said Department of Revenue spokeswoman Stephanie Weyant.

She said the state publishes the list to "shame" businesses, which have had
multiple opportunities to pay the taxes before being placed on the list.

There are at least 23 other states that use the same tactic to collect on the
delinquencies, she said.

"It has been successful," she said. "Since 2006 we've collected $110 million
attributed to the list. ... It's sort of that public embarrassment factor."

Since September, the last time the state has updated the list, 14 businesses
were removed but another 32 were added, she said.

York businesses: American Sign Co., 402 N. Queen St., had the largest delinquent
bill in York County, $99,048.31.

Guru Inc., which does business as Domino's Pizza at 2825 Carlisle Road in Dover,
owes $67,868.25.

First Capital Pizza Inc., which operates Domino's franchises in Red Lion and
York, owes $60,835.29.

B&T Towing & Auto Repair Inc. at 2530 Delta Road in Chanceford Township is
$16,875.55 delinquent.

Factory Direct Windows, 225 Pauline Drive in York Township, owes $9,469.09.

Imports Plus Auto, 10 Wintergreen Lane in Lower Windsor Township, made the list
for $8,736.99.

Business owners could not be reached for comment.

Weyant said she couldn't speculate on why the businesses haven't paid the taxes;
some of the taxes were withheld from employee paychecks.

The businesses on the list are contacted multiple times and exhausted all of the
state's collection efforts before being placed on the list, she said.

The information on their delinquency became public because the state has placed
liens against them, she said.

Statewide: The 244 businesses on the list statewide owe more than $8 million,
said Revenue Secretary Stephen Stetler.

"These businesses collected taxes from their customers and employees but failed
to send the money to the Commonwealth," Stetler said. "I encourage
taxpayers to visit the department's Web site ... to see the list of delinquent
businesses."

The Web site is www.revenue.state.pa.us. Click on "Hot Topics," and "Tax
Delinquent List."

Delinquent taxpayers who appear on the list should contact the Revenue
Department to make payment arrangements, he said.

--Reach Christina Kauffman at 505-5436 or ckauffman@yorkdispatch.com

                       Charleston Gazette (West Virginia)

                            March 27, 2014, Thursday

Delinquent taxpayer pays Kanawha County

BYLINE: Rusty Marks, Staff writer

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. P8A

LENGTH: 374 words


Kanawha County tax officials just reached a settlement with the county's biggest
delinquent business taxpayer. And all it took was a lawsuit.

Allen Bleigh, Kanawha County chief tax deputy, said owners of Keystone
Industries agreed to pay their outstanding taxes after the county hired outside
lawyers to take the company to court. Keystone Industries, which operates coal
mines in the county, owed the county more than $398,000 in back taxes, Bleigh
said.

"This accounted for a large percentage of the money that was out there that's
collectible," Bleigh said.

For the past several years, Kanawha County Commission President Kent Carper has
been pushing county tax officials to crack down on businesses and other property
owners who owe back taxes. Tax officials sent out a barrage of threatening
letters, and recently decided to hire outside lawyers to take delinquent
taxpayers to court.

Bleigh said Keystone Industries did not respond to previous attempts to collect
back taxes. But company officials agreed to pay up once the county took them to
court. With interest and penalties, the company will pay the county about
$408,000, Bleigh said.

Headquartered in Fort Myers, Fla., Keystone Industries has coal production
facilities in Bulgaria, Canada, China, Colombia and Korea and operates coal
terminals in Jacksonville, Florida and Ironton, Ohio, according to the company's
website.

Locally, Keystone Industries operates Keystone Development in Marmet. According
to the company's website, Keystone Development has 6,000 acres of coal reserves
in Kanawha County, and has been in production since 2001.

Bleigh said Keystone was the biggest delinquent taxpayer in the county.

Tax officials are taking two other business to court, one owing about $55,000 in
back taxes and the other owing about $15,000.

Kanawha County still has about $9.5 million in unpaid tax tickets. Bleigh said
some of that money cannot be recovered because owners have gone out of business
or declared bankruptcy.

"We've gone after some of the larger ones," Bleigh said. "Now we're going to go
after some of the smaller tax tickets."

More than half of the unpaid tax tickets still out there are for less than $50,
he said.

Reach Rusty Marks

at rustymarks@wvgazette.com or 304-348-1215.

                        Topeka Capital-Journal (Kansas)

                           December 4, 2014 Thursday

40 properties with delinquent utility bills still have water

BYLINE: Aly Van Dyke.

aly.vandyke@cjonline.com

LENGTH: 547 words


None of the 40 properties delinquent on their Topeka utility bills by $500 or
more had its water shut off as of Wednesday.

The list provided Monday by the city included two industrial properties, 14
commercial properties and 24 residential properties. It reflected properties
that, as of Nov. 28, owed at least $500 with bills past due by 41 days or more.

The list includes Heartland Park Topeka, which owed $44,645.11; two locations of
Hill's Pet Nutrition Inc. at 320 N.E. Crane, which owed $8,796.54; and four
properties owned by bankrupt developer Kent Lindemuth, which owed a total of
$12,962.12.

"There are occasions when a commercial account is struggling and, like
residential customers, we work with them in a manner that is beneficial for
everyone to get the bills paid current," said financial and administrative
services director Doug Gerber.

In the case of Heartland Park, he said, "it's not the city's best interest to
shut off the utility" before its pending deal to purchase the racetrack with new
Sales Tax Revenue bonds is settled.

"It would make it more difficult to sell and to start up a new operation,"
Gerber said.

He noted Hill's Pet Nutrition on Nov. 21 mailed full payment for its delinquent
bills. This delinquency, Gerber said, was the result of "a number of factors,"
including staffing issues at the facility and the Thanksgiving break at the
city.

"It's an anomaly that Hills appeared on our list," he said. "They have a great
payment history."

Gerber said the city gives a courtesy call to commercial customers about
delinquent accounts. This typically resolves the issue, he said, citing
information from the city's billing department.

"A lot of the commercial/industrial properties in town do not pay their own
bills, they are actually paid through their corporate offices, which can be
located elsewhere," he said. "This gives them an opportunity to make contact
with their accounts payable departments and expedite payment."

However, Topeka doesn't send out separate delinquent notices. It instead
highlights the amount owed on the monthly utility bills, according to an email
from the city.

Utility bills become delinquent 21 days after the billing date. After another 20
days, the account becomes eligible for shut-off - though that typically doesn't
happen for at least another week. Accounts owing $60 or less aren't shut off.

That means water typically is shut off after 48 days of delinquent payments.
Records provided to The Topeka Capital-Journal show delinquencies ranging from
41 days to 120 days, excluding Heartland Park. The racetrack last paid its water
and street utility bills on Aug. 7, 2013.

"There are various reasons we don't shut off accounts immediately, for both
residential and commercial customers," Gerber said. "In general, the city tries
to work with the customer to set payment plans for overdue bills."

Collecting delinquent utility bills also can be complicated with bankruptcies,
he said, which typically place a hold on creditors from taking any action to
collect the debt.

The city redacted 15 "individually identifiable residential customers" as an
exemption under state statute. The properties ranged from a couple of $50,000
homes in the Montara subdivision to two properties valued at more than $200,000
in southwest Topeka.

                   The Times-Tribune (Scranton, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             May 25, 2011 Wednesday

Scranton Redevelopment Authority default puts city on hook for $1.56 million

BYLINE: Josh Mrozinski, The Times-Tribune, Scranton, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 484 words


May 25--The Scranton Redevelopment Authority has defaulted on a line-of-credit
loan related to the collection of delinquent real estate taxes, and a bank is
demanding the city make a payment of more than $1.56 million.

City council discussed the issue at its meeting on Tuesday.

"The city has been declared in default, and now they (Pennstar Bank) have made
full demand on the city," said Boyd Hughes, council solicitor.

The city is responsible for the default because it guarantees the authority's
debt, Mr. Hughes said.

In a May 19 letter, law firm Rhoads & Sinon LLP said the authority is in default
relative to a sale agreement between the city and the authority for delinquent
tax claims for years 2004, 2005 and 2006.

The authority, which used a loan from Pennstar Bank to buy the delinquent taxes
from the city, subsequently contracted with Commonwealth Financial Systems to
have the delinquent taxes collected.

The letter says Pennstar Bank demands the city repurchase unredeemed tax claims,
which were valued at $1.56 million, plus interest at the default rate of $227.56
per day through the payment date. Payment is expected on or before June 18.

Council Finance Chairman Frank Joyce said he would like to have a public meeting
with the administration about the city's financial issues.

Efforts to reach Mayor Chris Doherty and Business Administrator Ryan McGowan
after the meeting were unsuccessful.

William Lazor, chairman of the redevelopment authority's board, said the
delinquent taxes will have to be pursued and applied to the loan.

Also Tuesday night, council unanimously overrode Mr. Doherty's rescinding last
week of his signature on legislation on a contract with insurance broker Knowles
Associates LLC.

Mr. Hughes said the mayor effectively vetoed the legislation last week when he
crossed out a signature he made on the legislation about four months ago after
it was passed by council in January.

In other business Tuesday, council introduced legislation for:

--Three-year lease agreements with various Little League organizations for their
use of the Weston Park Little League Field.

--A contract with Northeast Revenue Services LLC and Caverly, Shea, Phillips and
Rodgers LLC to collect delinquent real estate taxes for 2004 through 2008.

--Appointment of Wayne Hiller to the Scranton Parking Authority.

--Appointment of Arianne Slocum to the civil service commission.

--Appointment of Carol Oleski to the Scranton Municipal Recreation Authority.

--Appointment of Joseph Murphy to the planning commission.

Contact the writer: jmrozinski@timesshamrock.com

To see more of The Times-Tribune or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://thetimes-tribune.com/. Copyright (c) 2011, The Times-Tribune, Scranton,
Pa. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For more information
about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services
(MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com.
