                     The Lebanon Daily News (Pennsylvania)

                            March 14, 2009 Saturday

Tardy payers of tax targets

BYLINE: Lebanon Daily News

SECTION: LOCAL

LENGTH: 638 words


Two locals among 225 on state's list By RICHARD FELLINGER

Staff Writer

HARRISBURG -- At a time when every dollar of state revenue counts, officials are
trying to track down nearly $6.6 million in delinquent taxes from more than 200
businesses in Pennsylvania.

The Department of Revenue recently updated its tax-delinquent list, which shows
225 businesses that failed to pay certain taxes to the state. Each business
either collected sales taxes from its customers or withholding taxes from its
employees, or both.

Two Lebanon County businesses are among the delinquent taxpayers: Ye Olde Bake
Oven in Myerstown, listed for owing $41,985; and Whitaker Cleaning Systems in
Lebanon, owing $23,173.

Businesses owing the state the most are Crisman Harwood Flooring of Pottstown,
which was listed for owing $175,032; New Jersey-based Sequel Solutions Plus,
owing $161,265; and K&D Jewelers of Bethlehem, owing $139,460.

Whitaker Cleaning Systems is among 38 businesses added to the list in the last
week, while Ye Olde Bake Oven has been on the list since December, said Revenue
Department spokeswoman Elizabeth Brassell.

Co-owners of both local businesses say the troubled economy has hurt their
finances. Linda Brown of Ye Olde Bake Oven said her company has been paying what
it can on the $41,985 bill.

"We got behind, and the economy is bad," she said.

Businesses can come off the list by setting up a formal payment plan, but not if
they make random payments without paying it in full, said Brassell.

Karen Whitaker of Whitaker Cleaning Systems said she wants to pay her delinquent
tax bill and has been trying. She said the business had been on a payment plan
to stay off the list but was unable to keep up all the payments.

While $6.6 million is a small fraction of the state's $28 billion budget, the
delinquent taxes serve as a reminder that the state is scraping to get through
this year. Gov. Ed Rendell has estimated a $2.3 billion budget shortfall this
year and has cut programs and frozen most state hiring to help cover it.

And while the budget crisis developed in recent months, the list is not new.
State officials created it in 2006, hoping the publicity and accompanying court
action would pressure businesses into paying up.

State officials file a lien against each business in county court, which
essentially freezes its finances and ensures the state gets paid if the business
is sold.

And the state promotes the list. When the updated list was released last week,
Revenue's acting secretary, Stephen Stetler, encouraged people to check it out
on the department's Web site at http://www.revenue.state.pa.us .

The bad publicity hurts the cleaning business even more, Whitaker said.

"This is just making it worse for businesses," she said. "Businesses are
struggling now. I'm just mortified over this whole thing."

Brassell said revenue officials who track down the late taxes are doing a job
for the benefit of all taxpayers, and businesses that pay their taxes shouldn't
have to carry the burden for those that don't.

"It's really a matter of tax fairness as well," she said.

State officials give delinquent businesses several chances to pay up, Brassell
said. Revenue officials contact each business several times and also offer them
the payment plan to catch up.

Often, just the threat of being put on the list encourages business owners to
pay, Brassell said. Since the list was started, delinquent businesses have paid
$87 million and started payment plans for an additional $20.7 million after
being threatened with the list.

Yet collecting from some businesses can be difficult because some go out of
business.

Among them is Smokey Joes Barbeque Grille in York, which closed last summer and
was listed for owing $24,474. A message left at a forwarding phone number for
owner Joseph Whitehead was not returned.

StateBureau@LDNews.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             369 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                   The Record-Eagle (Traverse City, Michigan)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           January 30, 2010 Saturday

Tax shortfall may force borrowing

BYLINE: Sheri McWhirter, The Record-Eagle, Traverse City, Mich.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 724 words


Jan. 30--TRAVERSE CITY -- Large, idled and tax-delinquent developments in Grand
Traverse County caused a sharp spike in projected foreclosures and may lead
county officials to borrow millions to cover unpaid taxes.

Michigan's ongoing recession halted a number of developments around the county
and caused a ripple effect in both the construction industry and tax payments to
cities, townships and the county.

The county annually settles delinquent taxes with smaller municipalities, but
this year doesn't have the cash to do so without a loan, a figure that could
reach $6 million, said William Rokos, county treasurer.

It's a sign of lousy economic times, he said, and others agree.

"Suddenly, the building activity has slowed down tremendously," said Robert
Whims, president of the Home Builders Association for Grand Traverse Area.

Developers are struggling to secure construction loans, and housing demand has
plummeted. That leaves developers holding vast tracts with slim chances for a
quick return on their investments.

"Their property still has value and will have value, but they're just trying to
keep the lowest financial profile they can until the storm is over. Hopefully
that will be soon," Whims said.

Cash-strapped developers frequently put their tax debt on the back-burner,
boosting the delinquent taxes load on the county's books, Rokos said.

"A lot of it is these developments that have been started, but stalled and they
don't have the cash flow to pay taxes on time," Rokos said.

Most do eventually pay, but it's believed more may not do so this year. And more
homeowners also are paying later, but delinquent taxes on static development
sites account for a much greater total, Rokos said.

"It's a question of management of cash flow," said local developer Gene LaFave.
"In this cycle, cash is scarce. There are little ways to generate cash from
property sales. If you can't get money to build, nobody can get money to buy. So
most of your money is sitting in assets that are not liquid."

LaFave said his taxes are paid, but it's tougher to stay current in today's
economic climate.

Local developer Thom Darga said paying taxes late is a survival tactic for some
developers, a ploy he hasn't used.

"It's a bridge. Until you're in a position for some recovery from a sale, it's a
way to save cash," Darga said. "In the development business right now, cash flow
makes the situation a little more stable."

Rokos projects between 18 and 200 parcels will be foreclosed this year, a
dramatic hike over last year's 15 foreclosed properties. At the end of 2009,
delinquent properties jumped to 427, up from 225 such properties at the end of
2008, according to county records.

Additionally, delinquent 2007 taxes totaled about $1.2 million by the end of
2009, an increase over about $404,000 in delinquent 2006 base taxes at the end
of 2008. And more tax debt builds each year.

"We haven't borrowed to buy up the delinquent taxes since 1991," Rokos said.
"It's not the end of the world, but it's a trend. We may have to borrow money."

LochenHeath 18-hole golf and housing development in Acme Township owes the most
in delinquent 2007 taxes -- about $640,000 -- and its 121 parcels will be
foreclosed in April if those bills aren't paid, Rokos said.

The county awaits about $4.6 million in outstanding 2008 taxes, as well. If not
paid, those properties face foreclosure next year.

Local developer Bill Clous is among those who owe the most in late 2008 taxes.
Clous' Traverse City-based Eastwood Custom Homes builds middle-class and upscale
houses across the region. His company repeatedly has been cited for
environmental violations related to illegal wetlands bulldozing.

County records show Clous and Eastwood Custom Homes collectively owe about
$50,000 in late 2008 taxes. The properties will be lost to foreclosure, should
those taxes not be paid by the end of March next year.

Clous did not return a call seeking comment.

To see more of The Record-Eagle or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.record-eagle.com/. Copyright (c) 2010, The Record-Eagle, Traverse
City, Mich. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints,
email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send
a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee
Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                                   USA TODAY

                          December 12, 2012 Wednesday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Mortgage delinquencies to stay high through next year;
Hardest-hit states will show best improvement

BYLINE: Julie Schmit, @JulieSchmidt, USA TODAY

SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 5B

LENGTH: 445 words


Here's some good news on home loan delinquencies.

If not for all the homeowners who haven't paid their mortgages in more than a
year, the  home loan delinquency rate would be only slightly higher than normal,
new research by credit monitor TransUnion shows.

The delinquency rate would fall to about 2.5%, down from more than 5%, if those
borrowers were taken out of the equation, says Tim Martin, TransUnion vice
president.

Prior to the foreclosure crisis and housing bust, the normal mortgage
delinquency rate was about 1.5% to 2%, TransUnion says. The company expects the
delinquency rate, which looks at borrowers 60 or more days past due, to finish
this year at 5.32% and to drop  slightly to 5.06% by the end of next year.

The nation's higher-than-normal mortgage loan delinquency rate is not driven by
new loans. "It's a lot of folks  who've been delinquent for a really long time,"
Martin says.

Before the recession, it was unusual for a borrower to go more than 180 days
without either  fixing their situation or going through the foreclosure process,
TransUnion says.

As of the end of October, homes that went through a foreclosure sale were
delinquent an average 728 days, mortgage tracker Lender Processing Services
says. That was up from 497 days two years earlier.

If the pace of improvement in curing delinquent loans doesn't pick up, national
home loan delinquency rates will take another four years to get back to
"normal," TransUnion says.

More than 80% of the nation's currently delinquent home loans originated before
2008, TransUnion's data show. The pre-2008 loans make up 54% of all mortgages,
it says.

TransUnion predicts the biggest declines in mortgage delinquency rates next year
will occur in several states that were hit hardest by foreclosures. Nevada will
see a 19% drop. California and Arizona will post 12% declines.

In all of those states, foreclosures don't go through the courts, so they can
occur more rapidly than they typically do in states where foreclosures do go
through the courts.

Thirteen states will see mortgage delinquency rates rise next year, TransUnion
says.

They are largely states that have lower delinquency rates now, Trans-Union says,
and include North Dakota, South Dakota and Nebraska.

Despite  increases, those three states will end next year with the lowest
delinquency rates in the nation, TransUnion predicts.

North Dakota will be at 1.5% of home loans being 60 or more days late. Nebraska
and South Dakota will come in at about 2.3%.

Florida will have the highest delinquency rate at almost 12%, followed by Nevada
at slightly more than 8%.

The national mortgage delinquency rate peaked in the fourth quarter of 2009 at
6.89%.

                        Lancaster New Era (Pennsylvania)

                              May 12, 2009 Tuesday

Bear Hunting For $3B In Taxes;
 Lititz Republican Says State Can Gain By Trading Penalties For Payments.
Department Of Revenue Disagrees.

BYLINE: Jack Brubaker

SECTION: B; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 654  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Pennsylvanians owe more than $3 billion in delinquent taxes.

The state is looking at a budget deficit this year approaching a similar number.

State Rep. John Bear, a Republican from Lititz, has rubbed those two facts
together and come up with a partial solution to the deficit dilemma.

He wants to create a tax amnesty program to encourage debtors to fork over some
of the outstanding debt.

The state Department of Revenue, however, opposes tax amnesty because it would
raise too little money and would encourage future delinquencies.

But Bear is determined.

"Pennsylvania has always been deficient in this area of revenue collection,''
Bear says. "We need to improve in the long term and short term.''

Long term, the state needs to upgrade its computer system and personnel in the
Department of Revenue, Bear says. The department agrees with that and has begun
to change.

Short term, Bear believes, Pennsylvania needs to provide a limited tax amnesty
program similar to the one that raised $93 million during the Ridge
administration in 1995-96.

Bear plans to sponsor a bill calling for these initiatives. He is circulating a
memo about the bill this week. House Republican Minority Leader Sam Smith and
Policy Chairman Stan Saylor have signed onto it.

The bill will become part of the GOP House caucus' stimulus package, Bear says,
but he hopes for bipartisan support.

The bill will not have the backing of Stephen H. Stetler, secretary of the
Department of Revenue.

Although the last amnesty program raised nearly $100 million, says department
spokeswoman Stephanie Weyant, the Ridge administration issued a report afterward
saying the program should not be repeated.

The department spent $10 million administering the program, Weyant says, and
found that collections of delinquent taxes fell by nearly $63 million during the
next two years.

While the program raised a few million dollars short term, she says, experience
in other states shows that delinquent taxpayers simply wait for the next amnesty
program and the state loses more money.

"Amnesty creates a behavior that is not conducive to the next tax collection,''
Weyant says.

But Bear counters that the 97 percent of Pennsylvanians who do pay their taxes
on time are footing the bill for the delinquents and that's not fair.

"If I were a taxpayer, I would want these people to pay so that my taxes
wouldn't go up,'' he says.

The Department of Revenue estimates that about half of the outstanding $3
billion is collectible. The rest can't be collected because of bankruptcies,
deep indebtedness and other factors, according to the department.

Bear's plan, patterned on the Ridge administration's program, would establish a
tax amnesty period of 90 days during the 2009-10 fiscal year.

In exchange for eliminating all penalties for delinquent taxes, late payers
would have to pay all taxes and interest.

Only delinquent taxes prior to Dec. 31, 2006, would qualify.

Delinquent taxpayers who do not participate in the program would have an
additional 15 percent nonparticipation penalty added to their totals.

The other part of Bear's bill deals with Revenue's outdated and inefficient
computer system.

"The system is not integrated,'' says Bear, who served as a public sector
management consultant for a decade. "One system deals with corporate taxes,
another with personal income taxes. People are assigned to different systems.
There's no big picture.''

The Department of Revenue has begun planning for a massive overhaul of the
department. The department requested $21 million for the work this year and
similar amounts over the next four years.

The Senate eliminated $16 million from this year's Department of Revenue budget,
which Bear wants the House to fund and recommend again to the Senate.

"All told, this (overhaul) will cost taxpayers approximately $120 million over
five years,'' Bear says, "but the return on investment will more than pay for
this investment several times over.''

                           Grand Haven Tribune, Mich.

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                             April 14, 2015 Tuesday

County issues $6.1M to cover delinquent taxes

BYLINE: Alex Doty, Grand Haven Tribune, Mich.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 336 words


April 14--NORTHWEST OTTAWA COUNTY -- The Ottawa County Treasurer's Office has
completed the annual settlement of local government tax rolls.

Checks to local governments, school districts and special assessment districts
totaling more than $6.1 million for 3,991 delinquent properties across the
county were mailed Friday.

"More than $6 million seems like a lot, but the good news is that this continues
a multi-year trend where the amount of delinquent properties and dollar amounts
have continued to decrease," Slagh said.

Michigan law allows property taxes to be collected by local governments until
March 1. After that, the county treasurer must purchase any unpaid taxes from
each local government by paying the entire taxes owed so that schools, local
governments and authorities can continue to operate.

According to county officials, the funds to make these large payments are
accomplished through the Delinquent Tax Revolving Fund.

"The County Board of Commissioners had the foresight to establish the fund and
then maintain a sustainable balance in (the fund), so that as the treasurer
collects the delinquent taxes annually it replenishes these funds, making it
unnecessary to borrow to make the delinquent tax purchases," Slagh said.

Slagh noted that the program allows local taxing units to receive all of their
property tax revenues soon after settlement rather than having to wait until the
delinquent taxes get paid.

"Full payment of back taxes by property owners doesn't happen for months, or
even years in some cases," Slagh said.

After March 1, the responsibility of collecting delinquent taxes transfers to
the county treasurer.

If taxpayers are unable to pay property taxes at the end of three years, their
property is subject to tax foreclosure.

Read the complete story in today's print or e-edition of the Grand Haven
Tribune.

Tribune (Grand Haven, Mich.) at www.grandhaventribune.com Distributed by Tribune
Content Agency, LLC

                       The Indianapolis Business Journal

                               December 22, 2009

Other states duplicate Indiana's tax-amnesty program;
Daniels has no plans to repeat program that recovered about $245 million from
delinquent payers in 2005

LENGTH: 691 words


Other states duplicate Indiana's tax-amnesty program Daniels has no plans to
repeat program that recovered about $245 million from delinquent payers in 2005

Turns out it's a pretty good time to be a tax cheat.

Desperate to bring in revenue in the middle of a recession, states across the
country are adopting tax-amnesty programs similar to one Indiana had three years
ago, offering to let people pay their past-due tax bills with little or no
penalties or interest.

"Something is better than nothing," said Dino DiCianno, executive director of
the Nevada Taxation Department.

DiCianno said Nevada gave up more than $14 million in penalties and interest to
collect nearly $41 million between July and October.

Oklahoma, like Nevada, generated about twice as much as it expected from its
offer of amnesty, raising $82 million through its 90-day Clean Slate program for
businesses and individuals.

New York has a program under way, and Connecticut and Massachusetts are drawing
up theirs. California debated one before rejecting it in favor of stiffer
penalties. Delaware's incoming governor campaigned on the idea. A similar
program is being considered for Louisiana when its lawmakers return in April.

Indiana held the only tax-amnesty period in its history for three months in
2005. The state gave individuals and businesses who owed back taxes a chance to
pay their state bills without penalties, interest or collection fees. The
program netted about $245 million.

Republican Gov. Mitch Daniels stressed at the time that the program was a
onetime grace period that would not be repeated. Daniels' spokeswoman Jane
Jankowski says his position on the issue hasn't changed. Some lawmakers never
liked the idea, and there hasn't been talk of another amnesty period.

State after state is facing a disastrous drop-off in tax revenue because of the
stock market collapse and the recession. Many states have already cut their
budgets and started laying off employees.

"Anything you can do to speed up cash flow is cheaper than your alternatives,
like borrowing," said Verenda Smith, spokeswoman for the Federation of Tax
Administrators.

When Indiana's amnesty period started, the state was owed about $1.3 billion. In
2006, Indiana was still owed more than $1 billion in delinquent taxes. But the
Department of Revenue has been working to bring those numbers down, agency
spokeswoman Stephanie McFarland said.

Last year, the state collected $13.3 billion in revenue and had $551 million
outstanding. Even as collections rose to $14 billion in 2008, the amount of
delinquent taxes fell to $533 million, McFarland said.

Many states are reluctant to offer amnesty, arguing that it rewards cheaters,
discourages honest taxpayers and poaches revenue the states will ultimately
collect - especially as they improve databases they use to catch delinquents.
They worry, too, that people will hold back on their taxes and simply wait for
the next amnesty.

"If the attitude is we're going to hand out get-out-of-jail-free cards, people's
attitudes can change," said Paul Warren of the California Legislative Analyst's
Office. "You can have a breakdown in compliance."

An Oklahoma City lawyer challenged his state's amnesty program all the way to
the state Supreme Court, arguing that the Oklahoma Constitution prohibits
forgiving a state debt. The court rejected his claim in a one-sentence ruling.

"It is a slap in the face to all law-abiding Oklahomans who pay their taxes as
required by law," said lawyer Jerry F. Fent.

New York, which has a $1.5 billion deficit, began a limited amnesty last January
that covers income, corporate and sales taxes. The state has collected $11
million so far and hopes to take in $30 million.

Connecticut Gov. Jodi Rell has warned that the state faces nearly $6 billion in
deficits over the next two fiscal years. The state is hoping to generate $40
million by instituting a 56-day tax amnesty program next spring.

It will let taxpayers pay their late state taxes without penalty, and with a
25-percent reduction in interest.

"States are trying to reach for every tool in the toolbox right now," said
Connecticut Senate President Pro Tem Don Williams.

LOAD-DATE: June 8, 2010

                             374 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The American Banker

CREDIT CARD STATEMENTS

                            February 4, 1985, Monday

By CHARLES G. DALEY


Does a consumer have a cause of action against a creditor for violation of the
Truth-in-Lending Act by continuing to report the account as delinquent without
sending the consumer periodic statements once the account has been paid in full?

YES. Once the account has been paid in full, the creditor has an obligation to
send the consumer periodic statements if the creditor erroneously continues to
report the account as delinquent. (Saunders v. Ameritrust of Cincinnati, 587 F.
Supp. 896, Ohio, 1984.)

Ameritrust extended installment credit to Michael Saunders by issuing to him a
VISA credit card. When Mr. Saunders' account became delinquent in 1980,
Ameritrust instituted collection proceedings. Mr. Saunders agreed to abide by a
payment schedule until the summer of 1981. At that point, the bank brought suit
in an Ohio court to recover the balance of $272. In September 1981, Mr.
Saunders agreed to pay the balance and, as a result, the bank did not pursue its
lawsuit.

In April 1982, Mr. Saunders received a letter from the bank's lawyers stating
that his account had been paid in full. Nevertheless, the records of the
Cincinnati Credit Bureau showed that, as late as 1983, Mr. Saunders owed
Ameritrust $740 on his VISA account and that his last payment was in September
1980.

The essence of Mr. Saunders' suit against the bank was that the bank continued
to report his account as delinquent to the Credit Bureau, without sending him a
periodic statement. He asserted that under the Truth-in-Lending Act, the bank
was under a duty to send him periodic statements of his account, and that the
bank violated the act if it continued to erroneously report his account as
delinquent.

The bank denied that it had reported his account as delinquent. The bank
contended that even if it did continue to report his account as delinquent, it
had no obligation to send periodic statements once collection proceedings were
instituted. Without billing statements, no billing error could have occurred.
Finally, the bank claimed that since the bank did not receive notice of the
alleged billing error from Mr. Saunders, the Truth-in-Lending Act procedures did
not apply, and Mr. Saunders suit should be dismissed.

The court did not agree with the bank's contentions, but it recognized that once
the bank brought collection proceedings against Mr. Saunders, the bank was
relieved of its obligation to send billing statements. However, once Mr.
Saunders paid his account in full, the bank's duty to send periodic billing
statements began all over again. The failure to provide periodic statements is a
violation of the Truth-in-Lending Act.

Since Mr. Saunders was not aware of the bank's billing error in reporting the
account delinquent, he could not notify the bank of its error. The court ruled
that if Mr. Saunders could prove his allegations at a trial, the bank would be
liable for erroneously reporting his account as delinquent and for failing to
send Mr. Saunders periodic statements.

SECTION: WHAT'S YOUR ANSWER; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 500 words

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 1985 American Banker, Inc.


                             375 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        The Augusta Chronicle (Georgia)

                          December 19, 2007 Wednesday
                                CAROLINA EDITION

County urges you to pay up

SECTION: METRO; Pg. B09

LENGTH: 289 words


The Warnings

Delinquent taxpayers in Columbia County likely will get their first warning this
week to settle their bills. County tax officials will drop "encouragement
letters" in the mail Thursday to those who have not paid their property taxes,
said Columbia County Tax Commissioner Kay Allen. Richmond County landowners
delinquent on their taxes won't receive notices until after the New Year,
Augusta Tax Commissioner Jerry Saul said.

Due Dates

Real and personal property taxes were due in Columbia and Richmond counties Nov.
15. Property taxes in Aiken County are not due until Jan. 15, an Aiken County
tax official said. Unpaid accounts won't be considered delinquent until March
16.

The Consequences

Residents of Columbia County who had not paid their property taxes by the due
date were assessed a 1 percent penalty fee, which is charged again each month of
nonpayment, Ms. Allen said.

If taxes still have not been paid by Feb. 15, the county will charge a one-time
10 percent penalty fee. Eventually, nonpayment of taxes could result in seizure
of property, which will be sold at auction, but that's rare, Ms. Allen said.
Richmond and Aiken counties also assess penalties for nonpayment of taxes.
Nonpayment also can have a negative effect on a person's credit rating, said
Richmond County Chief Deputy Tax Commissioner North Williamson.

The Delinquents

At the end of November, Augusta's tax commission had nearly 16,000 accounts
still unpaid for the 2007 tax year, Mr. Williamson said. A single delinquent
taxpayer can be responsible for several accounts, he said. Columbia County tax
officials will send out nearly 3,500 "encouragement letters" Thursday to anyone
delinquent on paying their property taxes.

- Compiled by Donnie Fetter

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                        The Augusta Chronicle (Georgia)

                          December 19, 2007 Wednesday
                                 FINAL EDITION

County urges you to pay up

SECTION: METRO; Pg. B01

LENGTH: 289 words


The Warnings

Delinquent taxpayers in Columbia County likely will get their first warning this
week to settle their bills. County tax officials will drop "encouragement
letters" in the mail Thursday to those who have not paid their property taxes,

                             377 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                            Dayton Daily News (Ohio)

                            December 8, 2006 Friday

Money from tax windfall to help schools;
Dayton officials say $3.8 million raised from the auction of 2,000 delinquent
tax liens will save up to 67 jobs.

BYLINE: By Scott Elliott Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. A4

LENGTH: 300 words


DAYTON - A $3.8 million windfall from delinquent taxes will save up to 67 jobs -
half of Dayton Public Schools layoffs planned for January.

The money comes from an auction of about 2,000 delinquent tax liens by
Montgomery County Treasurer Hugh Quill's office last month, which raised $6.8
million total.

"These funds will not do it all, but they will help us greatly," Superintendent
Percy Mack said Thursday.

Last year, Quill's office auctioned off 2,000 delinquent tax liens, bringing in
$9.1 million. Dayton schools got about $6 million of that money.

The sales target landowners with unpaid taxes. Companies, usually large banks,
buy the debt and can charge fees to the debtor during collection. The 2,000
liens were bundled together and the debt buyer was required to purchase all of
it.

Quill said the trick is to combine properties with a good likelihood of
collection with those that have a worse chance of paying off. One of the biggest
liens in this year's bundle was the downtown Arcade property, which owed
$250,000. About 65 percent of that bill was owed to the district.

The timing of the windfall was very good for the district, which in October
announced that a financial crisis would force cuts in January and a tax levy in
May. Meanwhile, the district is in talks with teachers, who rejected a contract
offer last month.

While the money has little impact overall on the bottom line for a district with
a $225 million budget, it can be very helpful when applied to the January cuts,
Mack said. "This opens some doors where we can look at how we can work with
people," he said. "We've got to keep our academic growth moving."

Contact this reporter at (937) 225-2485 or sellio tt@DaytonDailyNews.com.

? Scott Elliott blogs about kids, schools, teaching and learning
DaytonDailyNews.com/ getonthebus

LOAD-DATE: December 8, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                     Copyright 2006 Dayton Newspapers, Inc.


                             378 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                 The Bond Buyer

N.Y. Governor to Back Three Local Financing Bills, Official Says

                            March 25, 1997, Tuesday

By Elizabeth Roy

DATELINE: ALBANY



New York Gov. George Pataki will push three bills aimed at helping local
governments improve their finances during this legislative session, an
administration official said Friday.

The three proposals would amend the state constitution to prohibit future
unfunded mandates, allow municipalities to securitize delinquent tax liens, and
allow distressed municipalities to finance deficits. Assistant chief budget
examiner Catherine H. Durand outlined the bills for participants in the state
Government Finance Officers Association's annual meeting.

A bill to amend the constitution to end unfunded mandates has been introduced in
the state Senate by Mary Lou Rath, R-Williamsville, chair of the house's
Committee on Local Governments.

The bill covering laws, executive orders, rules, and regulations would make
compliance with new unfunded mandates whose implementation costs exceed $20,000
voluntary for local governments. It is under consideration by the Senate
Judiciary Committee. The bill would exempt mandates that: are necessary for
compliance with federal law; are requested by a home rule message; apply equally
to governmental and nongovernmental entities; reapportion responsibilities
between political subdivisions; or arise from the governor's exercising of
emergency powers. A council would be established to handle appeals.

Supporters of ending unfunded mandates have pressured the administration to
"take a statutory approach" to ending them rather than attempting a
constitutional amendment, which requires passage by two consecutive two-year
legislative sessions before it can go before voters, Durand said.

But Pataki is committed to the constitutional approach because it would prevent
the Legislature from suspending the requirement at will. "There's no way to get
around it once it's in the constitution," she said.

The proposal to enable municipalities to securitize delinquent tax liens has
been sent to the Legislature but does not yet have a sponsor.

Under it, the securitization of delinquent tax liens - currently uneconomical
for small municipalities - would become cost-effective because it could be done
on a pooled basis.

"The sale of municipal tax liens is not new," Durand said, noting that New York
City securitized its delinquent liens last year. "But the concept of doing it on
a pooled basis is a brand new one."

The proposal would allow the state's Municipal Bond Bank Agency - an entity
created more than 20 years ago but which has seen little use - to buy delinquent
liens from municipalities with the proceeds of bond issues. The local
governments would at once receive a cash infusion and relinquish the
responsibility for collecting the delinquent payments to a collection agent.

When implemented in New York City and elsewhere, the securitization of
delinquent liens has led to better collection rates, delivering "a second,
recurring benefit," Durand said.

Pataki's third initiative, to be introduced in bill form "imminently," Durand
said, addresses how to prevent local governments from reaching advanced stages
of fiscal stress.

State Comptroller H. Carl McCall is also preparing to reintroduce a bill with
the same aim. He introduced the bill for the first time during the last
legislative session.

Pataki's and McCall's proposals contain many of the same provisions, including
an "early warning system" by which local governments would be monitored for
initial signs of fiscal stress, and a mechanism by which they could finance
deficits.

SECTION: THE REGIONS; Pg. 27

LENGTH: 585 words

                             379 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                     May 16, 1991, Thursday, FINAL EDITION

Delinquent dad found, but not caught

BYLINE: Mimi Hall

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 439 words


Just two days after his face appeared on ''wanted'' posters across the nation,
Gregory Lewis Morey - a delinquent dad on the run - was recognized by his
co-workers and a warrant is out for his arrest.

But authorities are worried he'll get away once more.

Morey was tipped off when his boss, who saw Morey's picture in Tuesday's USA
TODAY, suspended him from his job as a Salt Lake City restaurant manager. Now,
they say, the Arizona native may run again.

He's good at it.

In the 10 years since his 1981 divorce, Morey has moved in and out of half a
dozen states and changed his Social Security number four times to avoid paying $
600 a month in child support for his three children.

The total he owes: $ 74,100.

Morey and 21 other missing child-support evaders - behind more than $ 650,000 in
support - now are appearing on wanted posters in a new effort to find delinquent
parents.

Morey most recently moved to Utah, where he had been managing Fajita Willy's.

But then his boss saw his wanted poster pictured in the newspaper.

The boss, Stan Ashby, brought the paper to work and showed it to other shocked
employees. After a meeting, he confronted Morey, whom he described as being
upset.

''I was stunned,'' says co-worker Jeff Furse. ''I never would have guessed this.
He comes off as being real nice.''

Morey did not return calls.

Wednesday, the Arizona attorney general's office issued the arrest warrant. If
convicted on the three felony counts of non-support, Morey could face 5 1/2
years in prison and $ 450,000 in fines.

''There aren't a whole lot of absent parents who act as bad as this one,'' says
Jim Kidder of Utah's child support bureau.

Utah officials also learned that Morey changed a letter in his name, helping to
foil computer searches for him. On his Utah driver's license, his name is Grey
instead of Greg.

Officials from both states now say they're concerned that Morey will get away.

''We're going to have a hard time tracking this guy now that his boss has made
him aware,'' says Laura Begley of Arizona's child support office. ''If he flees,
we'll be starting from scratch again.''

Morey's ex-wife, Susan Aldrich of Phoenix, predicts if Morey takes off again, he
won't get far this time. Thanks to the posters, ''every woman who's owed child
support is looking for that man,'' she says.

Aldrich, who spent years on welfare after Morey's disappearance, says she's
especially hopeful this time because her son Greg, 14, has a tumor on his leg.
Aldrich is concerned her insurance won't cover the medical bills.

Her message to Morey: ''Don't run. Your son needs your support now.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: PHOTO; b/w, AP

CUTLINE: MOREY: Owes $ 74,100 in child support payments

THE NATION

                      Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

                          The Philadelphia Daily News

                              May 27, 2014 Tuesday
                                  WEB Edition

Delinquent property tax collection on the rise

BYLINE: BY MICHELE TRANQUILLI; Daily News Staff Writer tranqum@phillynews.com,
215-854-2348

SECTION: WEB; P-com News Politics; Pg. 999

LENGTH: 694 words


THE CITY of Philadelphia collected more than $45 million in back property taxes
in the first four months of the year and cut the number of tax-delinquent
properties by about 30,000 - a reduction of 25 percent from the previous year,
records show.

Revenue commissioner Clarena Tolson said the $45 million represents about half
the $91 million in delinquent property-tax revenue collected for all of last
year. It poured in from properties whose balances were eliminated through
payment or sheriff's sale, and through partial payments on outstanding bills,
she said.

"Once people realize the city has changed its approach to delinquency, they tend
to pay," Tolson said. She credits her department's collection success to "a
concerted and strategic effort to support the school district through aggressive
collection of taxes."

At the end of 2013, the city had 126,000 tax-delinquent properties, owing more
than $575 million in back taxes on file, according to records obtained by the
Daily News. By April 15, the number of delinquent properties - most of them
fewer than three years behind - had dropped by about 30,000, records show.

The largest tax debts cleared included $8 million collected through the
settlement of the former Foxwoods site, at 1499 S. Columbus Blvd., and just over
$900,000 paid by Penn Wynn Inc., owner of a large apartment complex at 2201 Bryn
Mawr Ave., which owed four years' worth of back taxes.

Penn Wynn paid up, Tolson said, after the city threatened to sell the property
at sheriff's sale to collect the debt.

"It's great they're able to really start collecting," said Jeff Goldman, of
South Philadelphia, co-founder of Scioli Turco, a nonprofit that rehabs derelict
properties in Philadelphia.

"The school district really needs ," he said, referring to a portion of the tax
revenue that will go to help fund city schools. "In other cities, if you don't
pay for two years, you've got to scramble. It's about time."

Tolson said part of the revenue department's more aggressive collection efforts
involve sending out bills for 2014 taxes, which were unpaid by the end of March.
Any account with an unpaid balance from 2013 had a lien placed on it on Jan. 1,
and was sent to a collection agency, she said.

For those who still refuse to pay, the city has any number of other tools at its
disposal.

The city has begun revoking commercial licenses for delinquent taxpayers and
pushing more properties to sheriff's sale.

In addition, the city can have delinquent properties placed with a third party
through a process known as sequestration. The third party would then collect
rents and turn them over to the city until the tax debt was paid in full. Since
the program started in October, the city has collected $4.9 million from about
350 accounts, Tolson said.

Meanwhile, Act 93, which went into effect this year, allows the city to place
liens on property owned by tax deadbeats outside Philadelphia County. So, if you
live in Bryn Mawr, but owe property taxes in Philly, watch out.

Tolson said her department is working with agencies around the state to develop
a process to initiate the liens. She said she hoped to start placing liens on
properties in the next few months.

For the average owner-occupied home that is behind on its taxes, Tolson noted
that the Revenue Department has been holding outreach meetings to make people
aware of payment programs that can reduce or eliminate interest and penalties.
Senior-citizen assistance programs are also available.

Otis Bullock Jr., executive director of Diversified Community Services, a
nonprofit social-services agency based in Point Breeze, said he worries that the
new policies will negatively affect residents.

"Many families in Point Breeze cannot afford to pay these increased taxes,
especially given these new aggressive policies and deadlines," he said.
"Diversified wants to ensure our Point Breeze residents receive the necessary
support during these troubled times."

But Mayer Krain, of Northeast Philadelphia, said he welcomed the city's more
aggressive collections efforts.

"It's a long time coming," he said. "It hurt a lot of people, not collecting on
a timely basis."

LOAD-DATE: May 28, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                  Copyright 2014 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC

                     The Journal Record (Oklahoma City, OK)

                             June 14, 2016 Tuesday

OKC re-signs with company to collect bad utility debt

BYLINE: Brian Brus

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 384  words


OKLAHOMA CITY - City Hall has renewed a contract with Credit Systems
International Inc. to collect delinquent utilities accounts worth millions of
dollars.

The $100,000 annual deal puts about four times that amount in city coffers,
Utilities Director Marsha Slaughter said. Although that's a significant
reclamation of lost revenue from water services, it's still just a drop in the
bucket.

Oklahoma City's utilities customer service division refers an average of 750
accounts per month to collection services. Delinquent accounts typically have an
average minimum past-due amount of $500 and are 100 days old. That's about
$375,000 per month, or $4.5 million per year.

The Arlington, Texas-based company has improved its margin of returns over the
last four years, Slaughter said, although no figures were immediately available
for publication. CSI has a good history of customer service, working out
solutions without being aggressive, she said; the Better Business Bureau of
Texas gives the company an A-plus rating.

Company officials could not be reached for comment Tuesday.

The number of delinquent accounts has not risen, even as Oklahoma has fallen
into a difficult economy because of oil prices, she said.

The department's ultimate goal is to reduce delinquent accounts so that
collections are unnecessary. To that end, new electronic payment options such as
smartphone apps and text reminders will be introduced in the next fiscal year,
Slaughter said.

"We're trying to give our customers more choices," she said. "By the time they
reach delinquency, cases tend to be somewhat complicated, such as bankruptcies.
... There's no perfect resolution for bad debt. It would be better to improve
customer service before that point. But if uncollected debt is allowed to rise,
it ends up hurting everyone else as well. "

City staff members were directed to tighten operations in the face of a smaller
budget overall for fiscal year 2016-2017 compared with the fiscal year that ends
with June. The City Council on Tuesday approved that $1.26 billion budget. The
general fund, which pays for most day-to-day operations at the city, was down
4.9 percent at $414.2 million.

                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           February 1, 2014 Saturday

BRIEF: Erie City Council to start 'brainstorming' solutions for delinquent trash
fees

BYLINE: Kevin Flowers, Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 205 words


Feb. 01--Erie City Council has promised to aggressively tackle the issue of more
than $1.6 million in delinquent garbage fees.

That work begins this week at the panel's first Finance Committee meeting of
2014.

Councilwoman Jessica Horan-Kunco said overdue garbage bills -- and
"brainstorming" ways to more effectively collect them -- will be the top agenda
item at Wednesday's meeting.

Horan-Kunco will serve as City Council's Finance Committee chairwoman this year.

The Erie Water Works Chief Executive Paul Vojtek and Paul Lichtenwalter, the
city's finance director, will attend, Horan-Kunco said. Mayor Joe Sinnott said
City Solicitor Greg Karle's office will also send a representative.

"We want to talk about the collection and billing process now with Erie Water
Works, how it's working now, when liens are filed against those who are
delinquent and things like that," Horan-Kunco said. "We want to talk to the
Solicitor's Office about what our possible legal remedies are. We're in the
initial stages of these conversations, but we want to see what might be possible
with the collections."

                                 The Bond Buyer

                             May 15, 2013 Wednesday

Wayne Charter County, Mich., GOs Lowered to BBB by S&P

SECTION: MARKET NEWS Vol. 122 No. 93

LENGTH: 496  words


Standard & Poor's Ratings Services said it has lowered its rating on Wayne
Charter County, Mich.'s limited-tax general obligation bonds to BBB from
BBB-plus.

The outlook is stable. At the same time, Standard & Poor's assigned its SP-1
rating to the county's limited tax GO delinquent tax notes.

"The downgrade reflects ongoing financial deterioration caused primarily by a
prolonged structural imbalance," said Standard & Poor's credit analyst Jane
Ridley.

The rating on the notes is based on the following credit factors: good projected
coverage when incorporating additional liquidity and other pledged revenues;
strong history of collections; and limited-tax GO pledge.

The 2012 real property taxes due to Wayne County, outstanding and uncollected as
of May 15, 2013, and the county's limited-tax GO pledge secure the series 2013
notes. Pledged revenues securing the notes include $300.7 million of 2012
delinquent property taxes and fees estimated to be delinquent after May 15,
2013.

However, only $238 million of that amount is expected to be available during the
amortization period of the notes. The notes are being issued as fixed rate with
no put feature.

These notes are being issued as pari passu with any other future notes secured
by 2012 delinquent taxes. Should additional notes be sold in variable-rate mode,
it is Standard & Poor's understanding and expectation that future structures
will not include a put unless there is a liquidity facility.

The BBB rating on the county's series GO limited and unlimited bonds reflects
the following credit factors: economic diversification beyond the city of
Detroit and a relatively diverse tax base; demonstrated strides toward
stabilizing financial operations through an agreement with the Third Circuit
Court; a good financial management profile that includes development and
implementation of policies designed to improve operational efficiencies across
the organization; and a debt burden considered moderate.

Offsetting factors include: a negative unreserved general fund balance that
continues to grow and a significantly reduced cash position; significant
challenges in the form of falling revenues, rising expenditures, pressure from
expenditures outside county management's control, and a challenged economic
climate; significant economic pressures given falling property values and the
related implication for property tax revenues; and economic indicators
considered just adequate.

The stable outlook reflects Standard & Poor's expectation that Wayne County will
continue to work toward regaining structural balance and that its progress will
be observable over the outlook's two-year time horizon. Should the county's
financial condition deteriorate significantly, Standard & Poor's could lower the
rating.

Given the challenges to date and the county's ongoing need to make changes with
both long- and short-term impacts, Standard & Poor's does not expect to raise
the rating during the course of the outlook period.

URL: http://www.bondbuyer.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                           The Orange Leader (Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            November 7, 2011 Monday

New election map under consideration by Orange Council

BYLINE: David Ball, The Orange Leader, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 600 words


Nov. 07--ORANGE -- After nearly a year's worth of work, a new district map will
be considered at the regular meeting of the Orange City Council beginning at 9
a.m. on Tuesday, November 8 at the Orange Public Library Auditorium at 220 N.
5th Street.

The council will deliberate the drafting of an ordinance establishing new
boundaries for the city's four single-member council districts.

The council conducted a public hearing last month to obtain citizen input on
draft plans for the reapportionment of the city's four single-member council
districts.

Alan Bojorquez of the Bojorquez Law Firm of Austin, presented draft plans for
the reapportionment of the city's four single-member council districts.

The plan was approved by the U.S. Department of Justice One Person, One Vote
program and made necessary to be within federal election guidelines.

The certification of 2011 assessed tax roll and 2011 delinquent tax roll summary
of $6,030.156.78 will be considered for approval. Orange County Tax
Assessor-Collector Lynda Gunstream will be presenting.

A resolution will be considered authorizing a change to the collection of
delinquent business personal property taxes. Gunstream stated the taxes are
normally turned over to the county's delinquent law firm on July 1.

The Legislature has provided an opportunity to turn over the collection of
delinquent business personal property taxes to the law firm on April 1.

Gunstream believes early turn over is beneficial for speeding up the collection
process by three months, providing an excellent opportunity to collect
delinquent tax revenue before it is gone and it's cost free.

The council will conduct a public hearing and consider for approval the taxation
of Goods in Transit that are otherwise exempt from taxation by the Texas Tax
Code.

The Legislature passed the measure this session. Goods in Transit is defined as
tangible personal property detained in a location in this state whose owner did
not have direct or indirect ownership of the facility at which the property was
assembled, stored, manufactures, processed or fabricated.

Councilmembers will vote upon an ordinance granting a franchise to Waste
Management to operate a commercial closed container garbage collection service
in the city.

The ordinance will provide the terms, conditions, obligations and limitations of
the service. The city will have the authority to regulate rates, provide
franchise payments and provide for severability.

Jerry Ziller, deputy chief of the Orange Fire Department, will present a
resolution for adopting the Regional Hazard Mitigation Action Plan to the
council.

The resolution reads the city of Orange has experienced many natural disasters
over the past century resulting in property loss, loss of life, economic
hardship and threats to public safety and health.

The Regional Hazard Mitigation Action Plan and the Orange County Hazard
Mitigation Action Plan were developed after more than three years of research
and extensive work by the city, the county, the South East Texas Regional
Planning Commission and others. The plans will protect people and property
affected by natural hazards.

The council will consider a motion accepting the resignation of Joyce McGee from
the Orange Housing Authority Board.

Her letter reads, "Effective immediately I am resigning from the Housing
Authority Board of Commissioners. It has been a pleasure to serve and hope that
in the future I can serve again or on another board."

Texas) at www.orangeleader.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

                 The State Journal- Register (Springfield, IL)

                             July 28, 2015 Tuesday

News in brief

SECTION: IL NEWS; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 456 words


Staff and wire reports

Chicago

Visitor numbers up 3.5 percent during 2014

Illinois tourism officials say the state saw a 3.5 percent increase in visitors
during 2014.

The Illinois Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity announced the
numbers Monday as it starts a four-day statewide tour with stops in Marion,
Effingham, Quincy, Springfield, Peoria, Champaign, Rockford and the Chicago
suburbs.

The agency says there were 109.4 million visitors to Illinois last year. Those
visitors generated $2.7 billion in sales taxes for the state, an increase of
$133.8 million in one year. State officials attribute 306,000 Illinois jobs to
tourism.

This fall, the Illinois Office of Tourism will launch the "Illinois Made"
program to showcase inventors and artists. In the spring, a newly formatted
Illinois travel magazine will debut.

Springfield

Tax auction planned Aug. 12

Sangamon County will conduct an auction of delinquent real estate and mobile
home taxes at 7 p.m. Aug. 12 at the Prairie Capital Convention Center, 1
Convention Center Plaza.

The auction is for 202 properties delinquent from 2011 and 97 mobile homes
delinquent from 2012.

Bids begin at $600.

Bidders are encouraged to attend the auction, but written bids can be submitted
to: Auction Department of the Sangamon County Tax Agent's Office, P.O. Box 96,
Edwardsville, IL 62025. Written bids with full payment must be received by 5
p.m. Aug. 5.

Sale catalogs are available at iltaxsale.com. Additional information also is
available by contacting the tax agent at (800) 248-2850 or (618) 656-5744.

Minneapolis

Minnesota raises state minimum wage to $9

Minnesota will vault past Illinois, Michigan and South Dakota this week to gain
the highest minimum wage in the Midwestern region at $9 an hour, which also will
rank among the most generous state wage floors in the country.

The dollar-per-hour bump taking effect Saturday for some 288,000 of Minnesota's
lowest-paid workers is the second of a three-stage increase adopted in 2014,
when the state had one of the lowest minimum wages in the region. Next August,
the wage will rise again to $9.50, and it will go up automatically with
inflation in following years.

For now, this step gives Minnesota the highest minimum wage of any state away
from the east or west coasts.

New York

Best Buy to sell Apple Watch

The Apple Watch is heading to some Best Buy stores ahead of the holiday shopping
season.

Best Buy Co. says it will sell the Apple Watch at 100 of its stores and on its
website on Aug. 7. Another 200 Best Buy stores will offer the smartwatch before
the end of the year.

Best Buy, which has more than 1,000 stores in the U.S., says it's the first
national retailer to sell the watch outside of Apple Inc.'s stores.

LOAD-DATE: July 28, 2015

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Article

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             386 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                             National Mortgage News

                               September 16, 1991

Life RE Overdues Hit $ 10B

SECTION: Pg. 1

LENGTH: 517 words

DATELINE: NEW YORK


Delinquent mortgages held by insurance companies surged past $ 10 billion in the
second quarter of 1991, a record for the industry, according to a report by a
trade association.

According to statistics from the American Council of Life Insurance, 5.3% of the
$ 221 billion in mortgages held by the industry was delinquent at June 30, up
sharply from 4.68% in the first quarter, and more than two points higher than
the 3.03% rate last year.

Moreover, the industry has been forced to take possession of a record number of
properties in foreclosure.

"Loans in process of foreclosure rose to a record high 2.40%, up from 2.12% at
March 31," said the ACLI report.

ACLI noted that all areas of the industry's mortgage portfolio were weaker in
the second quarter, but the commercial sector in particular pushed the numbers
higher.

In the quarter, commercial delinquencies rose to 5.41%, up from 4.77% the
quarter before and well above the 3.00% rate a year ago.

This category is important to the insurance industry in that it comprises 92% of
all of the mortgages held.

Delinquent residential mortgages, which are only 4% of the group's portfolio,
rose to 1.78% from 1.67% three months before and 1.49% a year ago.

Mortgages on agricultural property make up the balance of the industry's
portfolio, and they were also up sharply to 6.35% in June, from 5.78% in March
and 5.26% a year ago.

The industry also experienced a major increase in the amount of foreclosed
commercial real estate in the second quarter.

At June 30 last year, ACLI reported $ 1.4 billion of foreclosed property in the
hands of life insurance companies, but this June, the number exploded to $ 2.4
billion, an increase of more than 70%.

The commercial deterioration cut across the board by category and by region,
said ACLI.

On a regional basis, only the West South Central (Louisiana, Texas, Oklahoma and
Arkansas) and Mountain states (Arizona, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New
Mexico, Utah, and Wyoming) showed improvements in nonperforming mortgages, but
still remained among the most delinquent regions.

The WSC states fell to 5.32% and the Mountain states declined to 7.84%, from
6.42% and 9.93% respectively.

By far the most troubled region for the industry is New England where 8.30% of
the mortgages are delinquent up from 6.06% three months before and 3.45% a year
ago.

Importantly, these two regions comprise only 11% of the industry's total
mortgage holdings.

Another troubled region is the West North Central which includes Iowa, Kansas,
Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, and the Dakotas.

Total commercial mortgage delinquencies were 7.76%, up more than two points from
5.43% three months ago and 4.69% last year.

Within the industry's commercial mortgage portfolio, its office properties
delinquency rate rose for the sixth consecutive quarter to 6.22%, from 5.46%
three months ago and 3.58% last year.

Other weak sectors include hospitality at 11.6%, up from 10.35% in the prior
quarter and 8.11% a year ago; and apartments at 5.57% from 4.32% and 3.20% 90
days and a year ago respectively.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Graph, Life Insurance Mortgage NPAs Up Sharply In 1991, Life Co.
mortgage delinquencies rose more than 200 basis points in the past year,
climbing to 5.30% at June 30, 1991.  Source: American Council of Life Insurance

                             National Mortgage News

                                October 21, 1985

Banks See Rise In Bad RE Loans

SECTION: COMMERCIAL BANK MORTGAGES; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 708 words

DATELINE: NEW YORK


Commercial banks with the largest portfolios of non-performing real estate loans
in 1983 mainly saw their bad paper go up again last year.

The leader in non-performing mortgages last year, Bank of America, San
Francisco, held about $ 1 billion of those loans, according to Sheshunoff & Co.,
Austin, Texas.

Sheshunoff obtained its data from preliminary year-end reports of condition and
income filed with the Federal Reserve Board.

Bank of America's delinquent real estate loan portfolio last year represented an
increase of 5.5% over 1983, and 5.1% of its total real estate loan portfolio.

A spokesman for the bank disputed the figure.

Crocker National Bank, San Francisco, had the second largest non-performing real
estate loan portfolio last year, but showed a decrease from the year before.

Crocker's total non-performing real estate loans last year were $ 349 million,
which was a 13.7% drop from 1983.

A Crocker spokesperson declined to comment on specifics contributing to the
bank's large holdings of bad real estate loans, but said that Midland Bank, New
York, Crocker's parent, transferred the non-performing real estate loans to a
new subsidiary last September in order to more quickly dispose of the loans.

Last year, Crocker's non-performing delinquent real estate loans represented
6.97% of its total real estate loan portfolio.

Security Pacific National Bank, Los Angeles, held the third highest amount of
non-performing real estate loans last year among commercial banks nationwide.

Security Pacific's delinquent real estate loans, both commercial and
residential, totaled $ 256 million, which was an increase of 143% from 1983.

The top five holders of non-performing real estate loans for the year were
rounded out by The Bank of New York with $ 253 million -- a 47.7% rise from the
year before, and Citibank, New York, with $ 252 million -- a 55.6% rise from
1983.

The top five banks in this area held a total of $ 2.1 billion in non-performing
real estate loans last year.

First Interstate Bank of California, Los Angeles, held the sixth largest amount
of delinquent real estate loans in 1984.  First Interstate's non-performing
loans were at $ 186 million last year, a drop of 40.5% from 1983.

Layton Tuck, senior vice president, real estate loans, said First Interstate was
helped by an improved economy and an increase in building in certain areas of
California last year, and that the bank also stepped up its liquidations.

First Interstate's bad real estate loans last year represented 5.43% of its
total real estate loan portfolio.

Chase Manhattan Bank, New York, was seventh among commercial banks in total
non-performing real estate loans, with $ 170 million.  That figure is a 12.2%
increase in that category from the year before.

Chemical Bank, New York, had a jump of 77% in non-performing real estate loans
last year, and was eight highest in the category with $ 144 million in such
loans.

Chemical's delinquent real estate loans, despite the sharp rise, were just 5.59%
of its total commercial and residential real estate loan portfolio.

Continental Illinois NB & Trust Co., Chicago, eliminated 46.8% of its delinquent
real estate loans by year-end 1984 through its restructuring program with the
Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.

A spokesperson for the bank said that in September 1984 Continental transferred
$ 308 million in non-performing real estate loans to the FDIC and added another
one million in such loans before the end of the year.

At the end of last year Continental still held $ 135 million in delinquent real
estate loans, which represented 6.69% of its total real estate loan portfolio.

Seattle First National Bank finished out the top ten commercial banks, the top
ten commercial banks with $ 116 million in non-performing loans by year-end
1984, which was a 25.1% drop from 1983, and 6.61 percent of its total
residential and commercial real estate loan portfolio.

The non-performing top ten commercial banks held a total of $ 2.8 billion in
non-performing loans.

The top 25 banks with the largest delinquent real estate loan holdings reported
a total of $ 3.7 billion in bad loans last year.

The top fifty banks in this area reported a 1984 total of $ 4.4 billion.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Graph, REAL ESTATE LOANS COMMERCIAL BANKS as of Dec. 31, 1984, (dollars
in millions) Source: Sheshunoff & Co.

                   Copyright 1985 National Thrift News, Inc.

                           The Philadelphia Inquirer

                             July 1, 2015 Wednesday
                                 CITY-D Edition

City nets $2 million in sale of liens

BYLINE: By Claudia Vargas; Inquirer Staff Writer

SECTION: PHILADELPHIA; P-com News; Pg. B01

LENGTH: 362 words


An online sale of liens on tax-delinquent properties has netted Philadelphia
$2.1 million, city officials said Tuesday.

More than a quarter of the 865 liens that were for sale were picked up by
investors. The threat of the sale alone moved owners of an additional 1,414
delinquent properties to pay $5.5 million to clear back taxes owed. And a
further 506 property owners enrolled in payment plans to cover $2.2 million in
unpaid taxes.

"This has been the fastest and most impactful enforcement tool that anyone in
Revenue can recall," Revenue Commissioner Clarena Tolson said in a statement.
"From start of process to finish was just over [seven] weeks."

The auction, completed Tuesday, was a pilot program of the Revenue Department
and one in a series of efforts by the city to deal with its 98,000 tax-
delinquent properties, which represent nearly one in five parcels in the city.

Only liens were for sale, not the actual properties. The new owners of the liens
can recoup their investments by collecting the taxes owed on the properties.

Tolson's department notified more than 4,000 delinquent property owners they
would be subject to the lien sale if their taxes were not paid.

"Many properties were later eliminated from the process because of tax-exempt
status, appeals, bankruptcy," and other issues, according to Mark McDonald,
Mayor Nutter's spokesman.

The city ultimately gave a list of 1,261 properties to Indianapolis-based SRI
Inc., which had been contracted to run the online auction. Property owners
quickly came forward to pay taxes and related liens and fees.

"Taxpayers that came in with payments through the close of business on Friday
were removed from the sale," Tolson said. "In fact, we continue to have
taxpayers come in to make payment on liens that did not sell."

The liens that did not sell remain on the city's books as tax-delinquent
properties.

The 240 property owners whose liens were purchased will receive letters from the
city explaining that their tax debt is now to be paid to the purchaser of their
lien. Tax lien purchasers may later foreclose on the property if the debt is not
paid.

cvargas@phillynews.com 215-854-5520 @InqCVargas


LOAD-DATE: July 1, 2015

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                            Kokomo Tribune (Indiana)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             April 3, 2010 Saturday

County mailing delinquent tax letters to property owners

BYLINE: Ken de la Bastide, Kokomo Tribune, Ind.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 324 words


Apr. 3--KOKOMO -- Courtesy letters are being mailed to 2,100 property owners in
Howard County that are delinquent on their property tax payments, offering them
each the opportunity to stay off the tax sale list.

Howard County Treasurer Martha Lake said Thursday the letters will be mailed
Monday so property owners can remain off the tax sale list and save some money.

The letters will include the amount owed on unpaid property taxes dating from
the spring 2009 tax collection and for previous years. Lake said the amount
doesn't include the fall 2009 and spring 2010 taxes owed.

Lake said the spring tax bill statement will be mailed on April 10 and the
payment is due on May 10, which is on schedule.

She said the letters being mailed will include penalties, interest and any
assessments owed.

The delinquent taxes have to be paid in full by June 29 to keep a property off
the tax sale list.

Lake said the county's tax sale is set for Oct. 13

Delinquent taxes paid by May 10 will not incur additional penalties, but after
that date the amount owed will increase.

Lake said the Treasurer's office can take partial payments for delinquent taxes
until June 29.

"We have sent courtesy letters in previous years and have gotten a good
response," she said.

Last year the county mailed more than 2,000 letters and the number of properties
included on the tax sale list was reduced to approximately 600.

Ken de la Bastide is the Kokomo Tribune enterprise editor. He can be reached at
765-454-8580 or via e-mail at ken.delabastide@kokomotribune.com

                   The Times-Tribune (Scranton, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           October 17, 2009 Saturday

Sugarloaf woman: County too lenient on delinquent taxes

BYLINE: Kent Jackson, The Times-Tribune, Scranton, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 397 words


Oct. 17--By allowing owners of 2,000 properties extra time to pay their taxes,
Luzerne County shows too much leniency in the midst of a multi-million budget
crisis, a Sugarloaf woman said.

Darlene Straka asked the county for a list of properties whose owners pay taxes
through an installment plan.

She received 40 pages of properties for which the delinquent taxes amount to
tens of thousands of dollars.

"Most taxpayers on this list have multiple properties, many in the teens and at
least one in the twenties. Yes! Twenty properties by one owner put on a
installment plan," Straka wrote in a letter to the Standard-Speaker in Hazleton.

The list includes businesses as well as homeowners.

Straka said she can understand granting extensions to owners of single homes who
face hardships such as "serious physical illness or injury or prolonged
unemployment."

But not to businesses and owners of multiple properties.

Allowing extra time to some taxpayers burdens those who pay on time and
contributes to the county's budget deficit, she said.

Straka wonders how the county's Tax Claim Bureau, which the FBI is
investigating, can enforce payment agreements with so many property owners.

Luzerne County Commissioner Chairwoman Maryanne Petrilla said a policy requires
delinquent owners to pay 25 percent of their balance and enter a payment
agreement as a last chance to keep their properties.

"Once you go in into arrears, then you go for tax sale," Petrilla said.

Told what Straka learned about the delinquent properties, Petrilla said the
commissioners should look at owners of multiple properties.

"If it's the same people doing it over and over again, perhaps we have to look
into what requirements we have and what we can change," Petrilla also said.

The county's budget deficit was estimated at $29 million a few weeks ago, but
Petrilla said adjustments to revenues and expenditures have trimmed the deficit
to $18 million to $20 million.

kjackson@standardspeaker.com

                                US Official News

                          February 25, 2015 Wednesday

Washington: ORDER INSTITUTING ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEEDINGS AND NOTICE OF HEARING
PURSUANT TO SECTION 12(j) OF THE SECURITIES EXCHANGE ACT OF 1934

LENGTH: 1170  words

DATELINE: Washington


US Securities and Exchange Commission, The Government of USA has published the
following document:


UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
Before the
SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION

SECURITIES EXCHANGE ACT OF 1934
Release No. 74366 / February 25, 2015

ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEEDING File No. 3-16401

ORDER INSTITUTING
ADMINISTRATIVE
PROCEEDINGS AND NOTICE OF
HEARING PURSUANT TO
SECTION 12(j) OF THE
SECURITIES EXCHANGE ACT
OF 1934
I.



  The Securities and Exchange Commission ("Commission") deems it necessary and
appropriate for the protection of investors that public administrative
proceedings be, and hereby are, instituted pursuant to Section 12(j) of the
Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") against the Respondents named
in the caption.

II.

  After an investigation, the Division of Enforcement alleges that:

A. RESPONDENTS

1. Energiz Renewable, Inc. ("ERIP") (CIK No. 859313) is a dissolved Florida
corporation located in Keyport, New Jersey with a class of securities registered
with the Commission pursuant to Exchange Act Section 12(g). ERIP is delinquent
in its periodic filings with the Commission, having not filed any periodic
reports since it filed a Form 10-Q for the period ended September 30, 2011,
which reported a net loss of $936,682 for the prior nine months. As of February
23, 2015, the common stock of ERIP was quoted on OTC Link operated by OTC
Markets Group Inc. (formerly "Pink Sheets") ("OTC Link"), had seven market
makers, and was eligible for the "piggyback" exception of Exchange Act Rule
15c2-11(f)(3).
2. Iron Eagle Group, Inc. ("IEAG") (CIK No. 1043825) is a void Delaware
corporation located in New York, New York with a class of securities registered
with the Commission pursuant to Exchange Act Section 12(g). IEAG is delinquent
in its periodic filings with the Commission, having not filed any periodic
reports since it filed a Form 10-Q for the period ended June 30, 2012, which
reported a net loss of $1,126,202 for the prior six months. As of February 23,
2015, the common stock of IEAG was quoted on OTC Link, had seven market makers,
and was eligible for the "piggyback" exception of Exchange Act Rule
15c2-11(f)(3).
3. MedClean Technologies, Inc. ("MCLN") (CIK No. 40528) is a delinquent Delaware
corporation located in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania with a class of securities
registered with the Commission pursuant to Exchange Act Section 12(g). MCLN is
delinquent in its periodic filings with the Commission, having not filed any
periodic reports since it filed a Form 10-Q for the period ended September 30,
2012, which reported a net loss of $720,524 for the prior nine months. As of
February 23, 2015, the common stock of MCLN was quoted on OTC Link, had eight
market makers, and was eligible for the "piggyback" exception of Exchange Act
Rule 15c2-11(f)(3).
 B.  DELINQUENT PERIODIC FILINGS
4. As discussed in more detail above, all of the Respondents are delinquent in
their periodic filings with the Commission, have repeatedly failed to meet their
obligations to file timely periodic reports, and failed to heed delinquency
letters sent to them by the Division of Corporation Finance requesting
compliance with their periodic filing obligations or, through their failure to
maintain a valid address on file with the Commission as required by Commission
rules, did not receive such letters.
5. Exchange Act Section 13(a) and the rules promulgated thereunder require
issuers of securities registered pursuant to Exchange Act Section 12 to file
with the Commission current and accurate information in periodic reports, even
if the registration is voluntary under Section 12(g). Specifically, Rule 13a-1
requires issuers to file annual reports, and Rule 13a-13 requires issuers to
file quarterly reports.
6. As a result of the foregoing, Respondents failed to comply with Exchange Act
Section 13(a) and Rules 13a-1 and 13a-13 thereunder.
III.

  In view of the allegations made by the Division of Enforcement, the Commission
deems it necessary and appropriate for the protection of investors that public
administrative proceedings be instituted to determine:

A. Whether the allegations contained in Section II hereof are true and, in
connection therewith, to afford the Respondents an opportunity to establish any
defenses to such allegations; and,

B. Whether it is necessary and appropriate for the protection of investors to
suspend for a period not exceeding twelve months, or revoke the registration of
each class of securities registered pursuant to Section 12 of the Exchange Act
of the Respondents identified in Section II
  2
hereof, and any successor under Exchange Act Rules 12b-2 or 12g-3, and any new
corporate names of any Respondents.

IV.

  IT IS HEREBY ORDERED that a public hearing for the purpose of taking evidence
on the questions set forth in Section III hereof shall be convened at a time and
place to be fixed, and before an Administrative Law Judge to be designated by
further order as provided by Rule 110 of the Commission's Rules of Practice [17
C.F.R. § 201.110].

  IT IS HEREBY FURTHER ORDERED that Respondents shall file an Answer to the
allegations contained in this Order within ten (10) days after service of this
Order, as provided by Rule 220(b) of the Commission's Rules of Practice [17
C.F.R. § 201.220(b)].

If Respondents fail to file the directed Answers, or fail to appear at a hearing
after being duly notified, the Respondents, and any successor under Exchange Act
Rules 12b-2 or 12g-3, and any new corporate names of any Respondents, may be
deemed in default and the proceedings may be determined against it upon
consideration of this Order, the allegations of which may be deemed to be true
as provided by Rules 155(a), 220(f), 221(f), and 310 of the
Commission's Rules of Practice [17 C.F.R. §§ 201.155(a), 201.220(f), 201.221(f),
and 201.310].

  This Order shall be served forthwith upon Respondents personally or by
certified, registered, or Express Mail, or by other means permitted by the
Commission Rules of Practice.

  IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the Administrative Law Judge shall issue an initial
decision no later than 120 days from the date of service of this Order, pursuant
to Rule 360(a)(2) of the Commission's Rules of Practice [17 C.F.R. §
201.360(a)(2)].

  In the absence of an appropriate waiver, no officer or employee of the
Commission engaged in the performance of investigative or prosecuting functions
in this or any factually related proceeding will be permitted to participate or
advise in the decision of this matter, except as witness or counsel in
proceedings held pursuant to notice. Since this proceeding is not "rule making"
within the meaning of Section 551 of the Administrative Procedure Act, it is not
deemed subject to the provisions of Section 553 delaying the effective date of
any final Commission action.

  By the Commission.



              Brent J. Fields
              Secretary
  3
