                      Bowling Green Daily News (Kentucky)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             March 30, 2008 Sunday

Officials: Unpaid tax bills can lead to higher debts

BYLINE: Robyn L. Minor, The Daily News, Bowling Green, Ky.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 812 words


Mar. 30--Area officials are urging residents to pay their outstanding tax bills
soon -- before they are sold at courthouse auctions around the region beginning
next month.

If left unpaid, property owners could end up paying 100 percent more than they
owed to begin with to prevent a home from eventually going into foreclosure.

One company that has shown interest in purchasing bills around the region, Tax
Ease, is a Texas-based company that specializes in making property tax loans to
homeowners and businesses, according to its Web site; the loans are tied to a
five-year payback.

Warren County Sheriff's Office bookkeeper Carol Hurd said she has received calls
from four companies interested in purchasing the bills -- an interest level high
enough that the state will step in and stop the sale, as it did in 2007.

If companies show an interest in more than 10 percent of the total bills, the
sale is stopped and the state takes over the bills, turning them over to the
county clerk's offices, potentially for sale again. Hurd on Friday said she
still had about 678 outstanding bills for real estate.

Companies which "buy" the bills at auction are essentially giving delinquent
taxpayers a loan that they didn't ask for; the companies than attempt to recoup
the money, often with a number of "fees" attached.

There is a legal limit on the interest they can charge, though there used to be
no such limit on the administrative fees they can tack onto those bills.

"We had an incident where a $300 bill turned into a $900 bill in one year,"
Logan County Clerk Scotty Harper said.

State legislation effective July 2007 now stipulates that if the delinquent bill
is less than $350, a company may only charge a fee of up to 100 percent of the
bill; if it is from $351 to $700, they can charge fees up to 80 percent of the
bill, not to exceed $560; for bills more than $701, the fees can be 70 percent
or no more than $700.

But, Harper said, they can also charge attorney fees

Harper said because of potential cost to taxpayers, his office and other county
officials are doing what they can to spread the word that people should pay
their bills now if at all possible.

As recently as Thursday, Harper said the county still had about 600 outstanding
bills.

Nancy Botts, sheriff's bookkeeper in Barren County, said companies can
potentially own several outstanding bills on one person. For instance, the
company that purchased a delinquent bill in 2007 has first right to purchase a
delinquent bill for the same person in 2008 -- meaning that the money owed will
continue to compound, Botts said.

Like Hurd, Botts said she has had inquiries from individuals interested in
purchasing delinquent tax bills, something which seems to have increased this
year.

"Once we explain to them this isn't like Florida ... that you are just
purchasing the delinquent bill and the right to file a lien ... once they
realize all that, about 90 percent of those people aren't interested anymore,"
Hurd said.

She expects that get rich-quick schemes and other Internet courses that
reportedly teach people how to make money foreclosing on properties has prompted
more interest in the purchases, though Kentucky law makes it difficult to make
money that way in comparison to a number of other states.

-- For more information about regulations on delinquent tax sales, check out KRS
134.450 and KRS 134.452, which can be accessed through the Legislative Research
Web site at www.lrc.ky.gov.

Delinquent tax bill sales:

--Allen County's tax sale is 10 a.m. April 26; visit www.acsoky.org and click on
delinquent taxes for a list that is updated weekly.

--Barren County's tax sale is 10 a.m. April 16; visit
www.barrencountysheriff.com and click on delinquent tax list for a list that is
updated weekly.

--Butler County's tax sale is from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. May 2; visit
www.butlercounty.ky.gov and click on delinquent tax bills for list.

--Edmonson County's tax sale is tentatively set for May 7. After April 7, its
tax list will be available at www.edmonsoncounty.com/taxlist.html.

--Logan County's tax sale is 10 a.m. April 7. For a list, visit
www.etaxfiles.com and click on Logan.

--Simpson County's tax sale is 10 a.m. April 17. For a list, visit
simpsoncounty.us, click on departments, then sheriff and then scroll down to
delinquent taxes.

--Warren County's sale is 1 p.m. April 9. For a list, visit:
www.warrencountykysheriff.com/DelinquentTaxDatabase/Delinquent
_Tax_Bills_list.asp.

To see more of the Bowling Green Daily News, or to subscribe to the newspaper,
go to http://www.bgdailynews.com. Copyright (c) 2008, The Daily News, Bowling
Green, Ky. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints,
email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send
a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee
Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                 The Tribune-Democrat (Johnstown, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          September 17, 2008 Wednesday

BRIEF: Somerset delinquent tax sales low; stimulus rebates cited

BYLINE: Kirk Swauger, Tribune-Democrat, Johnstown, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 245 words


Sep. 17--SOMERSET -- Only 15 properties were sold at the Somerset County tax
sale Tuesday, an uncommonly low number the tax claim director attributes in part
to delinquent taxpayers using their federal stimulus checks to pay their levies.

"This was a pretty good sale all around that we got it down so much," Tax Claim
Director Kathryn Rose said. "I know we had some people come in and use their
stimulus checks" to pay the taxes.

Of the 15 properties, only three homes were sold: One in Conemaugh Township
netted $19,500 for $3,600 in back taxes; another in Southampton Township sold
for $10,000 for $3,100 owed; and another in Upper Turkeyfoot Township went for
$6,000 to pay off $3,400 in delinquent taxes.

The remainder of the properties, Rose said, were land along with one or two
mineral rights.

The county took 68 properties to the sale, far fewer than in past sales.

"It was one of the best sales we've ever had," Rose said, adding that the
ability to use credit cards to pay taxes was another reason most taxes were paid
before the sale.

To see more of The Tribune-Democrat or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.tribune-democrat.com. Copyright (c) 2008, Tribune-Democrat,
Johnstown, Pa. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For
reprints, email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or
847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group
Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                          The Anniston Star (Alabama)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            February 4, 2011 Friday

Catching up: Public officials' delinquent property taxes are being paid

BYLINE: Laura Camper, The Anniston Star, Ala.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 321 words


Feb. 04--Nearly all late payers flagged in a recent story in The Star about
local elected officials who were delinquent on their property taxes have now
paid up.

Anniston City Councilman Herbert Palmore, Hobson City Mayor Alberta McCrory and
Weaver Councilwoman Sheila Field all paid their tax bills on Jan. 21, the day
the news broke in the newspaper. Ohatchee Mayor Steve Baswell, who paid 12 of
his 13 tax bills on Dec. 28, paid the delinquent bill on Jan. 25.

Councilman Ben Little paid his delinquent property taxes on Feb. 1.

Only Hobson City Councilman O'Mildred Ball and Weaver Councilman Mike Warren
still have properties listed as delinquent.

Warren paid the taxes on Jan. 4 for the property where he resides. He is listed
as owner of another property with an ex-wife and that property tax bill had not
been paid as of Feb. 2. However, he said he has not been responsible for the
taxes on that property since 1986.

Ball still owes $189.20 for his property at 926 Bradford St, according to the
county web site.

Ball could not be reached for comment.

Vickie Kirby, chief clerk over tax collections for Calhoun County said the
delinquent tax payments have trickled in over the month, but as of Feb. 2, 6,022
of the 7,920 delinquent tax bills that were mailed were still delinquent.

However, she said the payments are on par with last year. On Feb. 2, 2010, the
county had collected $40,621,000 in property taxes and as of Feb. 2 this year,
it had collected $40,613,000.

The office will be mailing out a second wave of delinquent notices on Feb. 18.

Star staff writer Laura Camper: 256-235-3545.

To see more of The Anniston Star or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.annistonstar.com/. Copyright (c) 2011, The Anniston Star, Ala.

about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services
(MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com.

                          The Anniston Star (Alabama)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            February 4, 2011 Friday

                             396 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                Payments Source

                            November 16, 2012 Friday

Serious Mortgage Delinquencies Drop to Lowest Mark in Four Years

BYLINE: Darren Waggoner

SECTION: CCR - RISK & ANALYTICS Vol. 1 No. 1

LENGTH: 482  words


The percentage of mortgages that were more than 90 days behind or in the
foreclosure process dropped to 7.03 percent in the third quarter from 7.31
percent in the second quarter and 7.89 percent in the year-ago period, according
to the Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA).The rate of seriously delinquent home
loans, a proxy for the so-called shadow inventory of homes, fell to the lowest
mark since 2008 when it was 6.3 percent as employment improved and recovering
housing demand made it easier for homeowners to sell. It is considered great
news for the housing market because it reduces concerns that the current backlog
will exist long term, according to MBA officials. The shadow inventory as of the
second quarter fell 10 percent from a year earlier to 2.3 million homes,
representing a six-month supply, according to a report from data provider
CoreLogic.

The company includes seriously delinquent loans, homes in foreclosure and
bank-owned properties that haven't been listed in its definition of shadow
supply.As the economy improves, delinquent homeowners are catching up on
payments or finding alternatives to foreclosure. That's helping to reduce shadow
inventory - typically defined as homes with seriously delinquent mortgages, in
foreclosure or held by banks and not for sale - and limiting the prospect that
distressed properties will flood the market and depress prices.The percentage of
loans in the foreclosure process at the end of the third quarter was 4.07
percent, down 0.2 percentage point from June. That was the biggest drop in
records dating to 1979, according to the MBA.At the end of September, 2.32
million existing homes were available for sale, 20 percent fewer than a year
earlier, according to the National Association of Realtors. That represented a
5.9-month supply, the lowest since March 2006, near the peak of the housing
boom. The decline in inventory is helping to boost home selling prices as buyers
compete for properties. U.S. home prices jumped 5 percent in September from a
year earlier, the biggest increase since July 2006, CoreLogic Inc. said.More
borrowers were able to make their monthly payments as unemployment rate dropped
to 7.8 percent in September, the lowest since January 2009. Â The overall U.S.
mortgage delinquency rate - the share of loans at least one month late - fell to
7.4 percent in the third quarter on a seasonally adjusted basis from 7.58
percent in the previous three months, the MBA reported.States such as California
and Arizona that don't require court approval for foreclosures are seeing the
most rapid improvement in delinquencies, while judicial states such as Florida,
New Jersey and New York are falling behind. The foreclosure rate for judicial
states was 6.6 percent in the third quarter compared with 2.4 percent in
non-judicial states, the largest gap going back to at least 2006, according to
MBA officials.

URL: http://www.paymentssource.com

LOAD-DATE: November 16, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Magazine

JOURNAL-CODE: PAYMENTSSOURCE_NEWS


                        Copyright 2012 SourceMedia, Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                             397 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                   September 26, 1994, Monday, FINAL EDITION

Delinquents may show signs early

BYLINE: Marilyn Elias

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 152 words


About 3 out of 5 boys who will turn into hard-core delinquents by age 13 can be
identified in kindergarten through teachers' behavior ratings, a new study
suggests.

Early preventive therapy could avert a destructive future for many, says
psychologist Richard Tremblay of University of Montreal, Quebec.

"By kindergarten, the personality profiles that predict delinquency apparently
are already in place," he says.

He studied 1,034 boys in kindergarten. Eight years later, he looked at their
drug and alcohol use, and involvement in stealing, gangs and vandalism.

Findings, in Archives of General Psychiatry, show boys most likely to be
troublemakers are seen in kindergarten as:

-- Impulsive, hyperactive.

-- Low in anxiety or caution.

-- Low in desire to help others and unconcerned about angering others.

About 2 out of 5 delinquents didn't show those patterns in kindergarten, he
adds.

LOAD-DATE: September 27, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 1994 Gannett Company, Inc.


                             398 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           January 14, 2015 Wednesday

Idaho:Regulators Take Action Against Delinquent Mines

LENGTH: 1325  words

DATELINE: Boise


Parallels of Idaho has issued the following news release:

Two weeks after NPR and Mine Safety and Health News reported nearly $70 million
in delinquent mine safety penalties at more than 4,000 coal and mineral mines,
federal regulators suddenly revived a rare approach to force mines to pay.

They cited a delinquent coal mine for failing to pay $30,000 in overdue
penalties and gave the mine's owner two weeks to pay. He didn't, so the Mine
Safety and Health Administration (MSHA) shut down the mine. Within 40 minutes,
mine officials agreed to a payment plan and the mine reopened.

It sounds like a straightforward and tough response, but it might not stand up
to legal scrutiny. Federal law doesn't give MSHA the authority to shut down
mines simply because they haven't paid their safety penalties. But the agency
can force a mine to fix safety violations. In this case, the failure to pay
penalties is considered an unfixed violation.

Response From The Mine Safety And Health Administration

The following is the agency's response to the NPR/Mine Safety and Health News
series on Delinquent Mines.

Mine operators have the primary responsibility under the Mine Act to prevent the
existence of unsafe and unhealthful working conditions. When they fail in their
responsibility for compliance with the Act and its standards and regulations,
MSHA uses the enforcement tools it has at its disposal. As a result of, and
immediately after the Upper Big Branch Mine disaster, those tools now include an
enhanced enforcement program to provide a more effective means of improving
working conditions in the mines of chronic violators.

Specifically, through MSHA's impact inspections and Pattern of Violations
program, the Agency provides extra scrutiny where necessary. Click here to
continue reading the full response.

"The operator in this particular case did not challenge that legally. Somebody's
going to," says Larry Grayson, a mine safety expert at Penn State University,
and a consultant to industry and Congress.

"And then that's going to protract the amount of time it's going to take to
resolve the issues," Grayson, a former mine superintendent, adds.

As the NPR/Mine Safety and Health News investigation found, delinquent mines
committed 131,000 violations and reported nearly 4,000 injuries while they were
delinquent and while MSHA targeted many of them with other enforcement. Many
mines were delinquent and continued to operate for years.

MSHA's attempt to shut down a delinquent mine isn't new. NPR identified three
other cases in 2009. But Labor Department lawyers abandoned the tactic,
according to multiple current and former agency officials, because it's not
clear whether it's permitted by mine safety law.

"Until it is challenged, it is iffy," says Grayson, who says it will probably
take a court challenge to be sure. "But once that process starts, as slow as it
may be, there will be a level of worry among the operators, and hopefully it
would change many of them."

MSHA says it's also putting together what it calls a "better early warning
system" for delinquent mines it might take to federal court to seek court orders
for payment.

But neither MSHA chief Joe Main nor agency lawyer Heidi Strassler would discuss
these initiatives. They "are not available for taped interviews," says MSHA
spokeswoman Amy Louviere.

The action MSHA took recently targeted the Watson Branch coal mine in Claiborne
County, Tenn., which is operated by Solid Fuel Inc. Owner Darrell Wagner
operates three other mines that have more than $2 million in overdue fines, some
a decade old. Those three mines are now closed.

One of Wagner's mining companies, Wilcoal Mining Inc., agreed to pay more than
$626,000 in overdue penalties in federal court in 2013, but MSHA records
indicate no payments were made. When asked to explain this failure to enforce
the settlement, the agency said in a written statement, "We do not discuss
internal attorney-client decision making concerning litigation strategy."

While they were delinquent and operating, Wagner's mines produced more than
244,000 tons of coal, according to government records. That coal is valued at an
estimated $13.6 million, based on Energy Information Administration coal price
reports for the same area and the same years.

Wagner did not respond to an interview request made through his attorney.

Wagner's Watson Branch mine was hit with five surprise blitz inspections while
it continued to ignore its penalties. MSHA touts these special inspections
targeting mines with troubled safety records, including delinquent mines. But
NPR found that just 10 delinquent mines that had these so-called "mine impact
inspections" were cited for 5,700 violations and reported 120 injuries while
they were delinquent and while MSHA applied this and other enforcement.

"They can continue to target egregious mines [but] it would be a very slow
process," says Grayson. "Look at all of the injuries that are going to occur.
And these are the high-injury-rate mines or operators. That's almost untenable
for the cost of human health."

NPR found that delinquent mines overall have an injury rate 50 percent higher
than mines that pay their fines.

NPR also found that taking mines to court and getting court orders and
settlements takes months and, sometimes, years. Close to three-dozen cases
reviewed by NPR rarely resulted in payments, and injuries and violations
continued while the cases were litigated.
More From This Investigation
This photo of Roy Middleton working underground at the Kentucky Darby mine now
sits on the mantel in the Middleton home in Harlan County, Ky. He was killed
after an explosion in 2006.
Delinquent Mines
Coal Mines Keep Operating Despite Injuries, Violations And Millions In Fines
The injuries Jack Blankenship sustained after a 300-pound rock pinned him to the
ground while working in a coal mine prevent him from sitting for long periods of
time or walking far. He says he's in constant pain.
Delinquent Mines
Miners At Risk Because Of Unpaid And Uncollected Fines

That has Sen. Bob Casey, D-Pa., a member of the Committee on Health, Education,
Labor and Pensions, urging more definitive action.

"Unless the law is clear and unless the tools are substantial to impose
accountability, [mine operators] will keep violating and take any kind of fine
and just chalk it up to the cost of doing business," Casey says.

"In many cases, [they] won't change their behavior unless the sanctions are
severe and substantial."

Casey says he will soon reintroduce a sweeping mine safety bill that includes
the authority to shut down delinquent mines six months after their fines become
overdue. But the measure failed to pass when both houses of Congress were
controlled by Democrats, and passage is considered even less likely in a
Congress controlled by Republicans.

Some safety advocates suggest pulling the language specifically addressing
delinquent mines and making that a separate bill or attaching it to a budget
measure.

"I'd certainly be willing to evaluate that strategy," Casey says. "I want to get
results, and if results take more than one bill, I'm willing to consider that."

In the meantime, industry responses to NPR's series may add pressure to
delinquent mining companies. A statistician at insurance giant AIG has asked
about NPR's data showing higher injury rates at delinquent mines. He wants to
determine whether delinquent companies have additional risk that has not been
factored into their workers' compensation policies and rates.

And Grayson wants to do a deeper analysis of NPR's findings as part of an
industry effort to assess risk at coal mines and identify unsafe mine operators.

"A bad operator will do anything to basically undercut the cost that they're
going to have to bear," Grayson says. "They're taking market share away from
good performers. It really is unfair competition."

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: January 14, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


              Copyright 2015 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

"In many cases, [they] won't change their behavior unless the sanctions are
severe and substantial."

Casey says he will soon reintroduce a sweeping mine safety bill that includes
the authority to shut down delinquent mines six months after their fines become
overdue. But the measure failed to pass when both houses of Congress were
controlled by Democrats, and passage is considered even less likely in a
Congress controlled by Republicans.

Some safety advocates suggest pulling the language specifically addressing
delinquent mines and making that a separate bill or attaching it to a budget
measure.

"I'd certainly be willing to evaluate that strategy," Casey says. "I want to get
results, and if results take more than one bill, I'm willing to consider that."

In the meantime, industry responses to NPR's series may add pressure to
delinquent mining companies. A statistician at insurance giant AIG has asked
about NPR's data showing higher injury rates at delinquent mines. He wants to
determine whether delinquent companies have additional risk that has not been
factored into their workers' compensation policies and rates.

And Grayson wants to do a deeper analysis of NPR's findings as part of an
industry effort to assess risk at coal mines and identify unsafe mine operators.

"A bad operator will do anything to basically undercut the cost that they're
going to have to bear," Grayson says. "They're taking market share away from
good performers. It really is unfair competition."

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                         Star Beacon (Ashtabula, Ohio)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            October 19, 2008 Sunday

Income tax delinquents targeted by Conneaut

BYLINE: Mark Todd, Star Beacon, Ashtabula, Ohio

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 370 words


Oct. 19--CONNEAUT -- Cash-conscious Conneaut is in the midst of an income tax
crackdown aimed at recouping some of the big bucks owed the city, officials
said.

The number of people delinquent in their tax payments has hit unprecedented
numbers this year, said Larry Gasch, the city's tax administrator. "My gut
feeling is this is the worst year for delinquents," he said.

As of Friday, the city was dealing with 777 delinquent accounts that total
$376,344 in unpaid taxes, Gasch said. That revenue would provide a big boost to
the city's beleaguered budget

"(Conneaut) desperately needs that money," he said. "If we had it we'd be in
pretty good shape."

Delinquencies have jumped the past year, Gasch said. Some $76,672 of the total
was racked up in 2007 alone, he said.

The sour economy is the culprit, Gasch said. Households are being squeezed to
the point where residents feel they can't meet their tax obligations, he said.

"(The economy) is putting us into a bind like everyone else," Gasch said.

The city gives taxpayers every opportunity to pay the money, Gasch said.
Installment plans can be arranged if a lump sum payment isn't possible, he said.

"We hate to turn someone over to a collection agency and summon them into
court," Gasch said.

Even so, the city must often follow that path. Of the 777 pending cases, 268
have been turned over to a collection agency, Gasch said. Some people have been
cited into Conneaut Municipal Court so far this year, a court spokeswoman said.
Several cases are still outstanding, she said.

"We're doing our best to collect," Finance Director John Williams said earlier
this month.

While the majority of delinquents owe relatively small amounts of money, others
are on the hook for very large sums, Gasch said.

"Some owe huge dollars," he said. "Many thousands of dollars."

To see more of the Star Beacon or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.starbeacon.com/. Copyright (c) 2008, Star Beacon, Ashtabula, Ohio

Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                             403 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                       The Chronicle of Higher Education

                            October 1, 2012  Monday

Colleges Grapple With Applicants' Criminal Data, Including Juvenile Records

BYLINE: Caitlin Peterkin

SECTION: STUDENTS; Administration

LENGTH: 1179  words

ABSTRACT

Many colleges seek to collect information on juvenile or criminal violations by
applicants, but what admissions officials do with the data varies greatly.

FULL TEXT

College is often a fresh start for students, but some have pasts that follow
them.

Take, for instance, "S.D.," an 18-year-old man from Pennsylvania who wanted to
go to Temple University. When he was 17, he put an image on a file-sharing
network that resulted in his being charged in juvenile court with one count of
disseminating child pornography.

Under the state's Juvenile Act, courts must notify schools of juvenile offenses
by any student. Since the law was enacted, in 2008, it has been interpreted to
apply to elementary and secondary schools. But in the case of S.D., who is
identified in legal records only by his initials, the court notified Temple.

Last month a Pennsylvania appeals court ruled that the Juvenile Act can apply to
colleges and universities. Judge Sallie U. Mundy, of the Pennsylvania Superior
Court, held that an adjudicated delinquent who "presents a danger to elementary,
middle, and high-school students" does not cease "to present a danger once the
delinquent child enrolls in college."

As S.D. remains anonymous and Temple officials have declined to discuss the
case, it is not known how the ruling has affected the student and his
enrollment. Still, the case has raised concerns about whether juvenile and
criminal records should follow a young person, and how exactly a college should
handle that information.

Most states have school-notification laws. Some, as in Texas and Alabama, refer
specifically to elementary or secondary schools, while others, as in
Pennsylvania and Georgia, leave interpretation more open. According to a report
in 2006 by the U.S. Justice Department's Office of Juvenile Justice and
Delinquency Prevention, 44 states had notification laws.

Meanwhile, a majority of colleges seek to collect criminal-justice information,
most commonly through a request for self-disclosure in the admissions process.
Many applications ask students if they have either a juvenile or a criminal
record. The Common Application, for instance, asks if they have "ever been found
responsible for a disciplinary violation" since ninth grade or have "ever been
adjudicated guilty or convicted of a misdemeanor, felony, or other crime." The
latter can apply to juvenile offenses as well.

Youthful Mistakes, Lifelong Penalties

According to a survey in 2009 by the American Association of Collegiate
Registrars and Admissions Officers, or Aacrao, and the Center for Community
Alternatives, 66 percent of colleges collect criminal-justice data.

What to do with that information is a complex question. On the one hand,
colleges want to protect their students and staff from potential criminals, says
Melissa H. Sickmund, interim director of the National Center for Juvenile
Justice, a nonprofit research organization in Reno, Nev. On the other hand, she
says, young people make mistakes and shouldn't have those held against them for
the rest of their lives.

At DePaul University, which asks applicants if they have ever been convicted of
a felony, "yes" answers go before a committee of administrators who decide
whether to admit the student.

"For us, the bigger issue is whether or not someone who has an indiscretion in
the past is likely to be a good and contributing and trusted member of the
university community," says Jon J. Boeckenstedt, DePaul's associate vice
president for enrollment management. "Some people say that you shouldn't allow a
minor indiscretion to determine whether a student should be admitted," he says.
"But it would always be my preference that colleges and universities know that
indiscretion."

Most colleges that collect criminal-background information have introduced
additional steps in the admissions process. Like DePaul, some have special
committees, including, for example, academic deans and campus security officers.
Others require more from the applicant, such as a letter of explanation, an
interview, or the completion of a probation or rehabilitation program.

Colleges may also order background checks on students who disclose an offense
themselves, although the Aacrao survey found that relatively few institutions
run checks in admissions. Colleges that request checks on students tend to do so
for applicants to particular fields, such as the health sciences, that may
involve work in hospitals, says Joe Finley, president of the contractor
Certified Background. The company has worked with colleges for more than six
years, Mr. Finley says, and only a small fraction of those clients use its
services for admissions.

Automatic Denial of Admission

The University of Virginia considered running criminal-background checks on all
students after the 2010 death of Yeardley Love, a senior, and the arrest on
murder charges of George Huguely V, a classmate with a prior arrest unknown to
the university. Campus officials also suggested setting up a system for state
law-enforcement agencies to notify the university of students' arrests. But
months of deliberation led the university to abandon those proposals, and
officials decided instead to ask students to disclose annually whether they had
been arrested or convicted of any crimes. (Mr. Huguely was sentenced in August
to 23 years in prison.)

Whenever discussion of background checks surfaces, often after a tragic event,
experts debate the fairness and value of such measures. A past offense is not
necessarily predictive of a future one, they say.

"Education is such a powerful tool to provide opportunities for young people who
may have made bad choices," says Michael V. Reilly, executive director of
Aacrao. Conducting regular background checks, he says, would be "impeding the
best pathway for somebody to right their lives."

That argument often guides the thinking of committees that review
self-disclosures on applications. Only about 20 percent of colleges
automatically deny admission to youthful offenders, according to the 2009
survey, with most of those policies pertaining to convictions that involve
violence or sexual offenses.

Campus officials distinguish between indiscretions of youth and more serious
crimes, says DePaul's Mr. Boeckenstedt. There is a difference, many argue,
between a student who shoplifted at the age of 14 and one who committed an
assault at 17. In the case of juvenile records, many are expunged or sealed, Mr.
Boeckenstedt says, and so it's "as if the thing never happened in the first
place."

Beyond protecting students and employees, colleges worry about liability in an
incident involving a student with a prior record known to administrators.

Many cases are not clear-cut, says Mr. Boeckenstedt. "At the far ends are the
minor infractions of youth and the violent activities of someone who is almost
an adult: Those are really easy for everyone to say what should or might happen.
That big area in the middle is what's difficult to figure out what's right for
everyone involved," he says. "This is really an extraordinarily difficult area
to navigate."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                  The State Journal-Register(Springfield, IL)

                              June 25, 2001 Monday

County to auction delinquent properties publicly July 11

SECTION: LOCAL, Pg. 10

LENGTH: 144 words


Sangamon County will auction 115 properties that were delinquent for 1997 and
prior real estate taxes at a public auction at 7 p.m. July 11 at the Prairie
Capital Convention Center.

Bidding will start at $350 per item. Bidders are encouraged to attend the
auction sale.

While written bids are acceptable, the county must receive them at least five
working days before the sale.

They will announce the highest written bid received on a item before the
auctioneer opens the oral bidding.

Each item will sell to the highest bidder.

Sale catalogs are available for $10 at the Sangamon County treasurer's office in
Springfield.

For further information, contact the auction sale department of the Sangamon
County Delinquent Tax Agent's Office at (800) 248-2850 or (618) 656-5744.

Office hours are 8 a.m. to 5 p. m. Monday through Friday.

                             405 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                      May 11, 1992, Monday, FINAL EDITION

Government can get job done, too

BYLINE: Kevin Anderson

SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 6B

LENGTH: 332 words


Two things to remember if you're thinking about hiring a child-support-
collection agency:

- Commercial dad-hunting is new.  It's nearly unregulated. It's aimed at clients
who are usually desperate and unsophisticated. And it has drawn many rip-off
artists.

- The government can do nearly as well as a collection agency if you know how to
make the system work.

''We encourage people to use the state-enforcement system first,'' says Dennis
Bannon, president of Children Support Services, a national agency based in
Laurel, Md. ''It's free, and it can be effective.''

The government system works best when you know precisely where the absent parent
lives and works. Properly navigated and pressured, state systems can get out an
enforcement letter in a matter of days and get a check garnished in as little as
six weeks. There also are state and federal locator systems that can find a
missing parent for as little as $ 5 if you work them properly.

''Government is slow and sluggish, but if you know the system, follow up and
work within a support group, it can work,'' says Geraldine Jensen, president of
the Association for Children for Enforcement of Support and co- author of How to
Collect Child Support. Three-fourths of parents who use state systems through
the 249 ACES chapters collect support within six months.

If you do use a collection agency, scour the contract for clauses that give the
agency any claim to back support collected by the government or to current
support.

''There are some lowlifes in this business,'' says Bannon. Unlike many agencies,
his charges no application fee, doesn't charge for current support that is
resumed and charges 25% or less of overdue support collected.

Another alternative: Hire a lawyer. While a few work on contingency in
child-support cases, most charge hourly fees and want their $ 3,000 to $ 5,000
retainer upfront. Consider that route only if the absent parent is $ 50,000 or
more in arrears and has cash available.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CHILD-SUPPORT SLEUTHS

                                 The Bond Buyer

IRS Reviewing Methods Michigan Counties Have Used to Finance Delinquent Taxes

                             April 7, 1987, Tuesday

By Christopher O'Dea

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 6


Two forms of tax financing used by most Michigan counties may be banned if the
Internal Revenue Service decides that the structure of the issues does not
comply with the 1986 Tax Reform Act, state officials and lawyers said yesterday.

The Internal Revenue Service has raised questions about the tax exemption of
delinquent tax notes and consolidated tax notes. Counties issue both kinds of
notes to provide money to taxing entities that are waiting to collect delinquent
taxes. State officials estimate that sales of such notes surpassed $750 million
last year.

The IRS review "certainly has called a halt to these two programs," said Joel L.
Piell, chairman of the public finance section of the Detroit based law firm
Miller, Canfield, Paddock and Stone. Several counties have postponed their
planned note sales, and Kent County's $15.5 million issue, which was sold last
month, remains in limbo and has not yet been delivered.

Lawyers from three firms that have in the past given opinions on the tax-exempt
status of delinquent tax notes met with IRS officials Friday, but no decision
was reached.

Bond counsel in the state had relied on two private-letter rulings the service
made in 1978 that permitted Alpena and Oakland counties to issue delinquent tax
notes. Now the IRS is apparently "reconsidering" those rulings, "upon which we
based our consolidated tax note program," Mr. Piell said.

The IRS initiated its review of Michigan delinquent tax notes after it received
an anonymous letter last November about an issue for which Miller Canfield wrote
the legal opinion.

In Michigan, cities collect taxes for counties, school districts, and other
tax-levying bodies, Mr. Piell said. The issuer of the tax notes lends the
proceeds of the issues to various taxing bodies, which later repay the loans.
But the Tax Reform Act of 1986 makes clear that the lending of the proceeds is
not the same as spending the proceeds for a project, according to a Treasury
Department source.

If the proceeds are not considered spent, the issue might be subject to
arbitrage restrictions. The 1978 ruling addressed the question of whether the
local taxes were acquired obligations, which are subject to arbitrage
restrictions. The ruling said they were not acquired obligations, allowing two
counties in Michigan to issue delinquent tax notes.

Terence M. Donnelly, partner at Dickinson, Wright, Moon, Van Dusen & Freeman,
said the proceeds of these issues are invested in the unpaid taxes of the
municipalities for which the notes are issued. If the local taxes are called
acquired obligations, he continued, the invested proceeds of an issue can earn
only up to 1/8% more than the interest rate on the notes, under the new tax law.
The 1978 ruling was needed because county officials feared that the penalties
and late fees on delinquent taxes would, in effect, increase the yield on the
unpaid taxes due; the 1978 ruling said delinquent taxes were not acquired
obligations, he said.

In 1986, 78 of 83 counties in Michigan issued delinquent tax notes totaling $765
million, according to Louis Schimmel, director of the Municipal Advisory Council
of Michigan. The Advisory Council had no figures on the amount of consolidated
tax notes issued, but Mr. Schimmel said such issuance was "very large."

Mr. Piell said the delinquent tax note season was just about to begin, and all
issues are now on hold.

Tax note issues already sold are in various stages of limbo. A $15.5 million
Kent County issue sold to Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. on March 18 is still
on the firm's books in when-issued form, said Edward Fitzpatrick, vice president
and manager of the municipal note department in New York. All the notes have
officially been sold.

Kent County has 45 days from the date of sale to close the deal. While that
delay "may be legal, marketwise, I'm not sure that's the way things ought to
go," said Kent County deputy treasurer Ken Scott. Such a delay is "not fair to
anybody," he added. Both Kent County and Prudential Bache were waiting for bond
counsel Dickinson Wright to advise them about the issue's status.

Mr. Donnelly said this afternoon that the IRS "owes us a phone call." Until IRS
officials say how they have reinterpreted the 1978 rulings in light of the new
tax law, the Kent County issue will not close. "Hopefully, we'll be able to
advise clients soon," Mr. Donnelly said.

Miller Canfield has not issued any delinquent tax note opinions yet this year.
The firm of Dykema, Gossett, Spencer, Goodnow & Trigg has issued several
opinions this year, while Dickinson Wright wrote one opinion.

The loss of delinquent tax notes will be inconvenient and cause short term
problems while school districts adjust their budgets to reflect slower
delinquent tax collections, Mr. Schimmel said. But the amounts funded with such
notes are small enough that most taxing bodies won't be permanently hurt, since
delinquent taxes average 5% of total levies in Michigan, he added.

"We lived without them before, and we can live without them again," Mr. Schimmel
said. Most taxing entities will probably resume issuance of standard tax
anticipation notes to finance taxes they expect to collect in the future, he
said. But the ability to finance delinquencies may be gone.

SECTION: Pg. 1

LENGTH: 889 words

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 1987 The Bond Buyer, Inc.


                             407 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                             July 4, 2015 Saturday

Isenhart wary of new court-fines collection system

BYLINE: WILLIAM GARBE william.garbe@thmedia.com

SECTION: A; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 411 words


Iowa Rep. Chuck Isenhart, D-Dubuque, is concerned the new court-fines collection
system signed into law Thursday by Gov. Terry Branstad will unfairly
disadvantage delinquent debtors.

The new rules, written into the state's standings appropriations bill, give
court debt-collection responsibilities to a private debt collector 30 days after
payment due dates are missed. Previously, delinquent accounts were handed over
to a collections agency after one year.

Dubuque County Attorney Ralph Potter said the change could force surcharges of
up to 25 percent upon delinquent debtors, although state court officials said
the rate would be negotiated lower.

"So you owe $1,000 (to the court), and all of the sudden it's $1,250 just
because you're one day late? I mean, that's a real heck of a surcharge," Potter
said Thursday, just before Branstad signed the measure into law.

Since Dec. 1, 2010, state officials had worked with a Kansas City, Mo., firm to
collect debts delinquent by at least one year. By October 2013, that firm had
collected $8.9 million - roughly 3 percent of the total amount the firm could
collect, according to the nonpartisan Legislative Services Agency.

The agency reported the new collection system will allow the private firm to
"use more aggressive debt-collecting practices and have longer access to the
newest debt, which is easier to collect."

Isenhart said he urged Branstad, a Republican, to line-item veto the language in
the bill. He said the surcharge, when compounded by other penalties such as the
loss of driving privileges, makes it difficult for debtors to pay their fines.

"I think this language will make the system worse in terms of its eventual
impact. People can't drive, so they can't go to work, so they can't pay their
debt," he said.

Isenhart said he would prefer to see a system through which people assigned
court fees could work out payment plans in person at county offices.

"Basically, you're making people place a long-distance phone call to someone who
may or may not care about their situation," Isenhart said of the private
third-party collection service.

Supporting the change is Iowa State Court Administrator David Boyd, who urged
Branstad to approve the new language.

"Authorizing the Iowa Judicial Branch to assign debt to a private debt collector
at the time the court debt is deemed delinquent will simplify the collections
process and we believe will increase collections revenue," Boyd wrote in a
letter to Branstad.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             408 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                             National Mortgage News

                               December 26, 2014

Distressed Outlook: Big Banks Continue to Whittle Down Legacy Loans

BYLINE: Kate Berry

SECTION: DISTRESSED Vol. 1 No. 1

LENGTH: 534  words


Â

The nation's largest banks have attacked their delinquent loan portfolios with
gusto, but they may hit barriers in 2015 as they try to further whittle down
their distressed assets.

Some industry experts are predicting anew wave of delinquencies and
foreclosuresin the coming year if interest rates rise, causing home prices to
decline.

Many of the largest banks continue to sell off nonperforming loans. Hedge funds
and private-equity firms have bid up the prices of distressed loans as they seek
to profit from recent home price increases, which could abate in the coming
year.

Bank of America has made the greatest strides in whittling down its distressed
assets afterselling off more than $1 trillion in nonperforming loanssince 2009.
The $2.1 trillion-asset bank in Charlotte, N.C., held 221,000 delinquent loans
on its balance sheet in the third quarter, a 44% drop from a year earlier.

About three-quarters of its nonperforming loans are legacy assets from its 2008
acquisition of Countrywide Financial. B of A held roughly $10 billion in
nonperforming residential mortgage loans at the end of the third quarter, and
$32 billion in delinquent loans inherited from Countrywide. Those totals exclude
home equity loans and lines of credit.

B of A has estimated that it will get back to anormal level of delinquent loans
by 2016.Some analysts think that is an optimistic assessment, since some loans
probably cannot be sold, and working out problem loans - especially those at the
bottom of the barrel - is notoriously slow and labor intensive.

Meanwhile, Wells Fargo held roughly $10.7 billion of loans that were 30 days or
more delinquent in the third quarter, according to the bank's 3Q14 earnings. It
also holds $46.4 billion in legacy loans in its Pick-a-Pay mortgage portfolio
acquired from its 2008 purchase of Wachovia.

Overall, the seven largest banks and one large thrift saw an improvement in the
number of seriously delinquent loans held on their balance sheets at the end of
the third quarter, as of Sept. 30 according to a December report from theOffice
of the Comptroller of the Currency.

Roughly 5.2% or 117,673 residential mortgages were seriously delinquent at the
end of the third quarter, down from 5.5% a year earlier, the report found. The
reporting banks include Bank of America, J.P. Morgan Chase, Citibank, HSBC, PNC,
U.S. Bank, and Wells Fargo, while OneWest Bank is the largest thrift.

But the report also noted that about 8% of mortgages held in bank portfolios
lack credit scores at origination and are a mix of prime, Alt-A, and subprime
mortgages.

"Since 2009, mortgages owned by the servicers have performed worse than
mortgages serviced for (Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac) because of concentrations in
nontraditional loans, weaker markets, and delinquent loans repurchased from
investors," the OCC said.

Large bank lenders have opted to sell defaulted loans to avoid the high costs of
servicing and holding the debt.Large banksin particular have relied on sales of
mortgage servicing rights, as well as servicing transfers, pay-downs and payoffs
to reduce their holdings of nonperforming loans. An estimated $60 billion in
nonperforming loans is expected to have changed hands in 2014.

URL: http://www.nationalmortgagenews.com

LOAD-DATE: December 26, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: NATIONALMORTGAGE_NEWS


                        Copyright 2014 SourceMedia, Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                             409 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                  Herald-Journal (Spartanburg, South Carolina)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              April 2, 2012 Monday

Spartanburg County's delinquent tax sale starts at 10 a.m. Monday

BYLINE: Jenny Arnold, Herald-Journal, Spartanburg, S.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 409 words


April 02--Hundreds of interested bidders have signed up to bid in Spartanburg
County's delinquent tax sale today.

The tax sale, which will be held in council chambers at the County
Administration Building, 366 N. Church St., will start at 10 a.m. and includes
more than 500 properties worth about $1 million to be auctioned, interim Tax
Collector Don Arnold said. Owners failed to pay taxes on all of the properties.

"Opening bids will include all delinquent taxes, penalties and costs, in
addition to taxes owed for the current year on individual properties," Arnold
said last month.

Arnold said Sunday that 300 people have pre-registered to bid, and his office
will register any last minute bidders early this morning before the sale.

"We won't turn anyone away," he said.

With 300 people signed up to bid, Arnold said there is a lot of interest in this
year's sale.

"We've had a really good response," he said. "On the other hand, we've had a lot
of folks who have come in and paid their taxes. That's a great thing too."

When the sale was announced last month, there were 1,000 properties up for
auction, valued at $2 million. Today, there will be 520 properties up for bid,
Arnold said.

The sale will continue until 4 p.m., unless all delinquent taxes are collected
before then. A break is scheduled from 1-2 p.m. If necessary, the sale will
resume at 9 a.m. Tuesday.

It is an open bid sale, bidders bid at their own risk and must use their
numbered bidder cards in order to place bids.

"Each property is sold 'as is' and Spartanburg County makes no warranty express
or implied and no representation whatsoever, including but not limited to, the
value of the property, the size, shape, boundaries, location or physical
characteristics, the number or condition of any buildings or improvements, or
the quality of the title, or warranty as to the fitness for any purpose, and
Spartanburg County urges bidders to research all properties and obtain legal
advice before placing bids," Arnold said.

All sales are final, and all bids must be paid by cash, certified check or
credit card by the end of the sale or by a time set by the tax collector.
Failure to pay results in $300 charges for each bid.

Anyone with questions can call Spartanburg County's Delinquent Tax Office at
596-2597.

Spartanburg Herald-Journal (Spartanburg, S.C.) at www.GoUpstate.com Distributed
by MCT Information Services

-tax-sale-starts-at-10-a-m-Monday-20120402

$32 billion in delinquent loans inherited from Countrywide. Those totals exclude
home equity loans and lines of credit.

B of A has estimated that it will get back to anormal level of delinquent loans
by 2016.Some analysts think that is an optimistic assessment, since some loans
probably cannot be sold, and working out problem loans - especially those at the
bottom of the barrel - is notoriously slow and labor intensive.

Meanwhile, Wells Fargo held roughly $10.7 billion of loans that were 30 days or
more delinquent in the third quarter, according to the bank's 3Q14 earnings. It
also holds $46.4 billion in legacy loans in its Pick-a-Pay mortgage portfolio
acquired from its 2008 purchase of Wachovia.

Overall, the seven largest banks and one large thrift saw an improvement in the
number of seriously delinquent loans held on their balance sheets at the end of
the third quarter, as of Sept. 30 according to a December report from theOffice
of the Comptroller of the Currency.

Roughly 5.2% or 117,673 residential mortgages were seriously delinquent at the
end of the third quarter, down from 5.5% a year earlier, the report found. The
reporting banks include Bank of America, J.P. Morgan Chase, Citibank, HSBC, PNC,
U.S. Bank, and Wells Fargo, while OneWest Bank is the largest thrift.

But the report also noted that about 8% of mortgages held in bank portfolios
lack credit scores at origination and are a mix of prime, Alt-A, and subprime
mortgages.

"Since 2009, mortgages owned by the servicers have performed worse than
mortgages serviced for (Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac) because of concentrations in
nontraditional loans, weaker markets, and delinquent loans repurchased from
investors," the OCC said.

Large bank lenders have opted to sell defaulted loans to avoid the high costs of
servicing and holding the debt.Large banksin particular have relied on sales of
mortgage servicing rights, as well as servicing transfers, pay-downs and payoffs
to reduce their holdings of nonperforming loans. An estimated $60 billion in
nonperforming loans is expected to have changed hands in 2014.

                             411 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           October 29, 2014 Wednesday

United States Courts Opinions: Supreme Court of New York: Matter of Dylan P.

LENGTH: 990  words

DATELINE: Albany


Supreme Court of New York has issued the following order:


Matter of Dylan P.
2014 NY Slip Op 07357
Decided on October 29, 2014
Appellate Division, Second Department
Published by New York State Law Reporting Bureau pursuant to Judiciary Law §
431.
This opinion is uncorrected and subject to revision before publication in the
Official Reports.


Decided on October 29, 2014 SUPREME COURT OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK Appellate
Division, Second Judicial Department
REINALDO E. RIVERA, J.P.
L. PRISCILLA HALL
LEONARD B. AUSTIN
JEFFREY A. COHEN, JJ.

2014-00589
(Docket No. D-15678-13)

[*1]In the Matter of Dylan P. (Anonymous), appellant.


Seymour W. James, Jr., New York, N.Y. (Tamara A. Steckler, Catherine Wise, and
Raymond E. Rogers of counsel), for appellant.

Zachary W. Carter, Corporation Counsel, New York, N.Y. (Francis F. Caputo,
Elizabeth I. Freedman, and Hanh H. Le of counsel), for respondent.


DECISION & ORDER

In a juvenile delinquency proceeding pursuant to Family Court Act article 3,
Dylan P. appeals from an order of disposition of the Family Court, Kings County
(Olshansky, J.), dated January 6, 2014, which, upon a fact-finding order of the
same court dated September 9, 2013, made upon his admission, finding that he
committed acts which, if committed by an adult, would have constituted the crime
of criminal mischief in the fourth degree, and after a dispositional hearing,
adjudged him to be a juvenile delinquent and placed him on probation for a
period of 12 months.

ORDERED that the order of disposition is modified, on the facts and in the
exercise of discretion, by deleting the provision thereof adjudicating the
appellant a juvenile delinquent and substituting therefor a provision
adjudicating the appellant a person in need of supervision; as so modified, the
order of disposition is affirmed, without costs or disbursements.

The appellant admitted to committing acts which, if committed by an adult, would
have constituted the crime of criminal mischief in the fourth degree. At the
dispositional hearing, the appellant argued that he should be adjudicated a
person in need of supervision (see generally Family Ct Act § 712[a]) rather than
a juvenile delinquent, and that he should receive a 12-month period of probation
upon his adjudication as a person in need of supervision. He argued that this
disposition would provide him with the necessary level of probation supervision
and services without adding the stigma of a juvenile delinquency adjudication.
The Family Court rejected the appellant's argument, adjudged him to be a
juvenile delinquent, and imposed a 12-month period of probation. On appeal, the
appellant argues that he should have been adjudicated a person in need of
supervision rather than a juvenile delinquent, and that the disposition imposed
was not the least restrictive available alternative.

"If, upon the conclusion of the dispositional hearing, the court determines that
the respondent requires supervision, treatment or confinement, the court shall
enter a finding that such respondent is a juvenile delinquent and order an
appropriate disposition pursuant to [Family Court Act] section 352.2" (Family Ct
Act § 352.1[1]). "If, upon the conclusion of the dispositional hearing, the
court determines that the respondent does not require supervision, treatment or
confinement, the petition shall be dismissed" (Family Ct Act § 352.1[2]).

Alternatively, however, "[a]t the conclusion of the dispositional hearing the
court, upon motion of the respondent or its own motion, may in its discretion
and with the consent of the respondent, substitute a finding that the respondent
is a person in need of supervision for a finding [*2]that the respondent is a
juvenile delinquent" (Family Ct Act § 311.4[2]; cf. Matter of Sheifa R., 57 AD3d
678; Matter of Michael OO., 53 AD3d 709, 710).

This juvenile delinquency proceeding was commenced as a result of an argument
between the appellant, then age 14, and his mother in their home. After the
argument escalated, the appellant punched and damaged a television that belonged
to his mother. The appellant has no prior delinquency finding, and he accepted
responsibility for his actions. Further, the appellant's mother made great
efforts to play an active and positive role in the appellant's home and school
life. While the record shows that appellant had a history of curfew violations
and several school absences, it further demonstrates that he was making
significant improvements in these areas by the close of the dispositional
hearing. The court could have required the Probation Department or another
agency to monitor the appellant's school attendance and curfew without adding
the stigma of a juvenile delinquent adjudication (see Matter of Jeffrey C., 47
AD3d 433, 434; see also Matter of Ellery C., 32 NY2d 588, 590; Matter of
Jeanette P., 34 AD2d 661, 661).

Under the particular circumstances of this case, the appellant should have been
adjudicated a person in need of supervision rather than a juvenile delinquent
(see Matter of Jeffrey C., 47 AD3d at 434; cf. Matter of Jonathan M., 107 AD3d
805, 807; Matter of Sheifa R., 57 AD3d at 678; Matter of Michael OO., 53 AD3d at
710; Matter of Rosemary R., 29 AD3d 309), and we exercise our discretion under
Family Court Act § 311.4(2) to modify the order of disposition accordingly.

The 12-month period of probation imposed by the Family Court is an appropriate
means to ensure that the appellant continues to attend school regularly and
comply with his curfew. Thus, the portion of the order of disposition imposing
this period of probation, with certain enumerated terms and conditions, need not
be disturbed (see Family Ct Act § 757; 22 NYCRR 205.66; see also Matter of
Michael OO., 37 AD3d 1002, 1003).

RIVERA, J.P., HALL, AUSTIN and COHEN, JJ., concur.
ENTER:

Aprilanne Agostino

Clerk of the Court

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                             413 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        Tribune-Review (Greensburg, PA)

                             June 1, 2013 Saturday

Delinquent parcels breed in Monessen

BYLINE: by KATE WILCOX

LENGTH: 1053 words


Monessen officials say a perfect storm of lost industry and plummeting
population has saddled the city with an unwelcome distinction - more than half
of the 539 properties in Westmoreland County's repository of tax-delinquent
parcels are in the struggling river town.

Although other communities with comparable or larger populations, such as
Jeannette and New Kensington, have weathered crippling economic blows, Monessen,
with 7,700 residents, has about 12 times as many parcels - 273 - on the list of
delinquent properties as either of those towns.

The cache holds real estate that is at least two years delinquent on local and
county taxes and has been put up for sheriff's sale but not sold.

Although Monessen has attempted to demolish its blocks of ramshackle, sometimes
collapsing residential and commercial buildings, city officials say there is not
enough money to raze every blighted building.

Westmoreland County Commissioner Charles Anderson said the success of one town
over another comes down to a community's mindset and the ability of a mayor and
council to make difficult decisions.

"Sometimes, it has to be tough love," he said. "Sometimes, you have to make the
hard decisions."

Using an analogy from his career as a Marine Corps pilot, Anderson said, "You
get into a death spiral, (and) you need to get out of that thing before you hit
the ground."

For Monessen to pull out of its spiral, two things must happen, according to Liz
Hersh, executive director of the Pennsylvania Housing Alliance.

Strict code enforcement is crucial along with careful crafting of a process to
obtain delinquent properties, then demolish or rehabilitate them, Hersh said.

"The biggest failure (comes with) not trying," she added.

"Maybe we can't get the big steel mill back to Monessen, but can we have houses
that have acres of garden space?" Hersh asked.

Echoing Anderson, Hersh said the real key is strong community leadership and
community support.

Monessen's stab at dealing with its blighted properties has divided the
community and sparked bitter political skirmishes that many believe resulted in
Mayor Mary Jo Smith's defeat in the May primary.

Blight spreads

Smith was the leading proponent of a controversial plan called "Monessen
Rising," which called for buying delinquent parcels from the county and
reselling them to artists looking for low-cost properties where they can live,
work and sell their wares.

Smith and other officials enlisted the aid of two Staten Island, N.Y.,
developers, who met stiff opposition along with jeers and shouts when they
discussed the plan at public meetings.

During a recent tour of houses in the county's supply, Smith gestured to a home
without stairs leading to the splintered front porch that is home to a stray cat
living inside a discarded playpen.

"If you lived next to this, would you fix your house up?" she asked.

It's a story that plays out in many neighborhoods across the city.

On some streets, Smith said, it can be difficult to distinguish between homes on
the county's list of delinquent homes and those that are occupied but have been
neglected.

Brian Jensen, executive director of the Pennsylvania Economy League of Greater
Pittsburgh, agreed.

"Once a particular house gets blighted, there's a tendency for that rot to
spread," Jensen said. "Once you get a critical mass of abandoned properties, the
markets tend to depress, just from being a certain distance from a foreclosed
home."

Monessen's aging population has played a role, according to city administrator
John Harhai, who on a recent tour of the city pointed to a house that belonged
to an elderly woman who had moved out of the state to live with her children.

"They can't sell it, can't afford to keep it up," Harhai said. "They feel bad,
but here it sits."

Because real estate was considerably cheaper in Western Pennsylvania during the
housing boom six or seven years ago, many out-of-state corporations purchased
multiple properties in Monessen and other towns sight unseen with the hope of
turning a profit when the market surged.

Many walked away when the recession struck. Some of those companies were each
responsible for 10 or 20 properties on the delinquency list, records show.

Tales of two cities

Like Monessen, New Kensington has battled its share of problems, including
serious crime, an aging population and a depressed economy.

Although with 13,000 residents it is larger than Monessen, it was dealt a
significant blow when Alcoa vacated its research labs off Freeport and Edgewood
roads.

But officials never let that exodus trigger a landslide of vacant, blighted
buildings, which is why it has only 20 properties in the county's cache today,
said Kim McAfoose, executive director or New Kensington's Redevelopment
Authority.

Years ago, she said, particularly tenacious officials began the practice of
buying delinquent properties, then quickly demolishing them.

By courting new businesses and condemning and demolishing unusable properties,
the city attracted businesses such as Geo-Solutions and a branch campus of
Westmoreland County Community College.

"It's a pretty inviting place to do business, and we're going to continue to
keep it that way," Mayor Tom Guzzo said.

For some time, Jeannette has been dangerously close to falling under state
oversight because of its deep financial difficulties.

The loss of Jeannette's glass-making industry, coupled with an aging and
decreasing population, could have spawned a surge in abandoned, tax-delinquent
properties.

Even so, the city, with 2,000 fewer residents than Monessen, has not let that
happen. Records show Jeannette has only 23 homes on the county's list of
seriously delinquent properties that have gone unsold at sheriff's sales.

As the glass industry waned, city officials encouraged the growth of other
businesses, such as Elliott Co., which deals in turbo machinery and employs
about 900 workers.

With limited funding, Monessen has chosen to demolish unsalvageable vacant
houses at a cost of $20,000 each, then try to sell the vacant plots to
neighbors.

But the city lacks the money to purchase and demolish all of its blighted
properties, Smith said.

Anderson said the county is working with Monessen to obtain a $400,000 grant to
purchase additional homes.

Kate Wilcox is a staff writer for Trib Total Media.

LOAD-DATE: June 3, 2013

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          November 19, 2014 Wednesday

Sinnott to present 2015 city budget proposal tonight

BYLINE: Kevin Flowers, Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 286 words


Nov. 19--Erie Mayor Joe Sinnott will present his 2015 city budget proposal
tonight, but he's not talking about the details of the spending plan.

"We are still working on it," Sinnott said Monday. He declined to discuss
specifics, including whether the proposal includes a property tax increase for
city residents.

Sinnott will present his budget at Erie City Council's regular meeting tonight
in Bagnoni Council Chambers at City Hall, 626 State St.

The meeting will start at 7:30 p.m. The city's $69.7 million city budget for
2014 increased sewer and garbage fees, a move that helped spark debate over more
than $2 million in delinquent refuse fee revenues. The city and Erie Water Works
worked together to change billing procedures, so that garbage and sewer bills
are now combined.

Collection rules were also amended, which means that now, customer payments
apply to the most delinquent charges first.

Because a customer's payment is now applied first to the most delinquent
charges, someone who is extremely late on garbage payments would see that
payment go toward the late refuse bill, which would leave the sewer bill unpaid.

Under state law, Erie Water Works can now legally shut off water service, which
is billed separately, to a customer for delinquent sewer charges. City and Erie
Water Works officials believe that change will prompt many overdue customers who
fear losing water service to pay their delinquent bills.

City Council has until Dec. 31 to pass a budget.

KEVIN FLOWERS can be reached at 870-1693 or by e-mail. Follow him on Twitter at
twitter.com/ETNflowers.

                             National Mortgage News

                               December 29, 2014

Distressed: Big Banks Continue to Whittle Down Legacy Loans

BYLINE: Kate Berry

SECTION: SPECIAL REPORT: OUTLOOK 2015; Pg. 8 Vol. 39 No. 14

LENGTH: 535  words


The nation's largest banks have attacked their delinquent loan portfolios with
gusto, but they may hit barriers in 2015 as they try to further whittle down
their distressed assets.

Some industry experts are predicting a new wave of delinquencies and
foreclosures in the coming year if interest rates rise, causing home prices to
decline.

Many of the largest banks continue to sell off nonperforming loans. Hedge funds
and private-equity firms have bid up the prices of distressed loans as they seek
to profit from recent home price increases, which could abate in the coming
year.

Bank of America has made the greatest strides in whittling down its distressed
assets after selling off more than $1 trillion in nonperforming loans since
2009. The $2.1 trillion-asset bank in Charlotte, N.C., held 221,000 delinquent
loans on its balance sheet in the third quarter, a 44% drop from a year earlier.

About three-quarters of its nonperforming loans are legacy assets from its 2008
acquisition of Countrywide Financial. B of A held roughly $10 billion in
nonperforming residential mortgage loans at the end of the third quarter, and
$32 billion in delinquent loans inherited from Countrywide. Those totals exclude
home equity loans and lines of credit.

B of A has estimated that it will get back to a normal level of delinquent loans
by 2016. Some analysts think that is an optimistic assessment, since some loans
probably cannot be sold, and working out problem loans - especially those at the
bottom of the barrel - is notoriously slow and labor intensive.

Meanwhile, Wells Fargo held roughly $10.7 billion of loans that were 30 days or
more delinquent in the third quarter, according to the bank's 3Q14 earnings. It
also holds $46.4 billion in legacy loans in its Pick-a-Pay mortgage portfolio
acquired from its 2008 purchase of Wachovia.

Overall, the seven largest banks and one large thrift saw an improvement in the
number of seriously delinquent loans held on their balance sheets at the end of
the third quarter, as of Sept. 30 according to a December report from the Office
of the Comptroller of the Currency.

Roughly 5.2% or 117,673 residential mortgages were seriously delinquent at the
end of the third quarter, down from 5.5% a year earlier, the report found. The
reporting banks include Bank of America, JPMorgan Chase, Citibank, HSBC, PNC,
U.S. Bank, and Wells Fargo, while OneWest Bank is the largest thrift.

But the report also noted that about 8% of mortgages held in bank portfolios
lack credit scores at origination and are a mix of prime, alt-A and subprime
mortgages.

"Since 2009, mortgages owned by the servicers have performed worse than
mortgages serviced for (Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac) because of concentrations in
nontraditional loans, weaker markets, and delinquent loans repurchased from
investors," the OCC said.

Large bank lenders have opted to sell defaulted loans to avoid the high costs of
servicing and holding the debt. Large banks in particular have relied on sales
of mortgage servicing rights, as well as servicing transfers, pay-downs and
payoffs to reduce their holdings of nonperforming loans. An estimated $60
billion in nonperforming loans is expected to have changed hands in 2014.

URL: http://www.nationalmortgagenews.com//

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             417 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                               May 9, 2010 Sunday

Erie owed $1.15 million in delinquent refuse bills

BYLINE: Mike Maciag, Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 556 words


May 9--Some Erie residents and landlords have started to pay off years of
overdue garbage bills, but new delinquencies continue to pile up.

The city was owed nearly $1.15 million in overdue refuse payments and penalties
at the end of April, according to Erie Water Works, which handles the bills.

City officials considered ideas to combat the delinquencies after the Erie
Times-News first published a report on the overdue bills in January. But the
officials have not decided what, if any, action to take.

City officials, citing health concerns, have said City Hall will not stop
picking up garbage if an account is delinquent.

As of Tuesday, 2,340 accounts were at least six months behind.

City Councilman Mark Aleksandrowicz had been one of the delinquent account
holders.

He owed a total of $475.82 for four rental properties on Tuesday, according to
refuse records. The account for Aleksandrowicz's residence, on Lighthouse Street
in the city, was not delinquent.

Aleksandrowicz's overdue accounts were paid after the Erie Times-News contacted
him about the delinquencies on Thursday.

Aleksandrowicz, president and general manager of Alek's Powersports in Millcreek
Township, had said he couldn't pay because of cash-flow shortages and mortgage
payments on his four low-income rental properties.

"I'm kind of caught in the same boat as one or two thousand legitimate people
and thousands of illegitimate people," he said. "Because I'm elected doesn't
mean that I'm immune" to the same problems others have.

Like many landlords, Aleksandrowicz said vacancies, evictions and remodeling
costs hurt his pocketbook.

"It's a big game of musical chairs," he said. "People can't pay, and they get
evicted."

City Finance Director Paul Lichtenwalter said many people are paying overdue
bills, but others are getting added to the list of delinquencies.

"People are paying these bills, it's just that people are getting a little more
behind than they want to be," he said.

Councilman Joe Schember said hiring a collection agency and offering an amnesty
period were the two most likely options City Council could consider.

An amnesty period could entice some customers to pay by eliminating or reducing
attached penalties.

Councilwoman Jessica Horan-Kunco also previously suggested the city should
explore whether a collection agency could help the city to recoup some of the
overdue money.

But Mayor Joe Sinnott said Friday that an amnesty period wouldn't help the city,
and hiring a collection agency was not legally possible.

"We'll follow what we're able to do according to the law and according to the
processes," he said.

Although some people have put off paying refuse bills for years, they'll have to
pay up eventually.

Erie Water Works files liens against delinquent properties after multiple
notices are sent to property owners.

"We are getting these paid as properties change hands," Sinnott said.

MIKE MACIAG can be reached at 870-1776 or by e-mail.

To see more of the Erie Times-News, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.GoErie.com. Copyright (c) 2010, Erie Times-News, Pa. Distributed by

                               MortgageDaily.com

                            December 9, 2013 Monday

BRIEF: Further Improvement in MGIC Delinquency

BYLINE: Mortgage Daily

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 209 words


Dec. 09--The inventory of delinquent policies fell to the lowest level in years
at MGIC Guaranty Insurance Corp. New business, meanwhile, slowed.

New policies written on residential loans totaled $2.2 billion during November,
monthly operating data indicated.

Business fell from October, when $2.4 billion in home loans were insured.

A year earlier, activity totaled $2.2 billion.

From Jan. 1 through Nov. 30, volume at the Milwaukee-based company amounted to
$27.7 billion.

MGIC's delinquent inventory ended last month at 104,637 policies, falling from
109,629 at the end of October.

At the same point in 2012, the delinquent inventory was 143,153.

It was the fewest number of delinquent policies since at least March 2010.

Using an estimated 965,226 policies in force, the estimated delinquency rate at
the mortgage insurance company was 10.84 percent as of Nov. 30.

The estimated past-due rate fell from a month earlier, when it was 11.33
percent. The rate improved even more significantly compared to a year earlier,
when it stood at an estimated 14.13 percent.

The estimated rate has been lower each month since July 2012, when it was 14.75
percent.
