                             419 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         Spokesman Review (Spokane, WA)

                            February 27, 2011 Sunday
                                  Main Edition

IRS EASES RULES ON LIENS FOR DELINQUENT TAXPAYERS;

BYLINE: From wire reports<P>

SECTION: E; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 522 words


The Internal Revenue Service says it's trying to help people who are struggling
to pay delinquent tax bills, so it's reducing the number of property liens and
easing rules for small businesses to enter into installment agreements.

As the economy has soured, the agency has filed an increasing number of liens on
property owned by delinquent taxpayers. The IRS filed nearly 1.1 million liens
in the budget year that ended in September, compared with 426,000 in 2001.

The steps will double the amount of back taxes a person can owe before facing a
possible lien. Previously, taxpayers who owed at least $5,000 and ignored
numerous IRS notices would get an automatic lien placed on their property. Under
the new policy, the threshold is increased to $10,000.

The change will make it easier for people to have liens withdrawn once tax bills
are paid or they start paying under certain installment plans. More taxpayers
can settle their tax debt for less than they owe, if they meet certain income
and debt requirements.

Small businesses with larger delinquent tax bills will be eligible for 24-month
payment plans. Previously, the tax bill had to be less than $10,000; now it's up
to $25,000.

Liens are notices filed in land records to ensure the government can collect
back taxes when property is sold. They also alert potential creditors and
employers that property owners owe back taxes.

Even once tax bills are paid and liens removed, they can remain on credit
reports for years, hurting the ability of taxpayers to get loans or even a job,
said Nina E. Olson, the National Taxpayer Advocate, an internal watchdog within
the IRS.

<b>TAX BREAK FOR SAME-SEX COUPLES</b>

Many same-sex couples are getting a tax break this year from the IRS, according
to new requirements to report their combined income on federal tax returns.

Under "income splitting," the IRS is requiring all same-sex married couples or
registered domestic partners in Washington state, California and Nevada to
divide their combined income equally and report it on their separate tax
returns.

For some couples, it will mean more money in their 2010 refund; for others,
they'll pay more in taxes.

Either way, the change is significant, both monetarily and emotionally,
officials of Lambda Legal, the national gay and lesbian legal rights group, said
Tuesday in a conference call with reporters.

Those who will save the most are same-sex couples with the biggest disparities
in income. For instance, a couple where one earns $100,000 and the other is a
stay-at-home spouse with little or no income, will split their combined
community earnings on their individual tax returns, with each reporting $50,000
in income. The result: an overall lower tax bill for both.

To illustrate, Lambda officials cited the example of a hypothetical couple:
"David," an attorney earning $225,000, and "Richard," a librarian with $20,000
in income, would see a combined savings of $6,824 in taxes.

The IRS ruling applies in only those states that have community property laws
and that recognize married same-sex couples and registered domestic partners.

<b>TYPE:</b> Column: You and Your Taxes

BRIEF: Delinquent mortgages decline in metro Toledo

BYLINE: The Blade, Toledo, Ohio

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 167 words


June 07--The share of metro Toledo homeÂ­owners with delinquent mortgages
decreased in March for the second consecutive month, a study shows.

The proportion of local mortgages with loan payments late by 90 days or more
dropped to 6.72 percent in March from 6.98 percent in February and 7.43 percent
a year earlier, according to CoreÂ­Logic Inc., a California real estate data
firm. The study, released Monday, shows Ohio's serious home-loan delinquency
rate at 6.72 percent in March, down from 7.22 percent a year earlier.

CoreLogic said 3.69 percent of mortgages in metro Toledo and 3.50 percent in
Ohio were in foreclosure in March. Both figures are higher than in March, 2010.

                                 The Bond Buyer

                             May 15, 2013 Wednesday

S&P: Wayne Charter County, MI GO Bond Rating Lowered To 'BBB' From 'BBB+'

SECTION: MARKET NEWS Vol. 122 No. 93

LENGTH: 524  words


Standard & Poor's Ratings Services has lowered its rating on Wayne Charter
County, Mich.'s limited-tax general obligation (GO) bonds to 'BBB' from 'BBB+'.
The outlook is stable. At the same time, Standard & Poor's assigned its 'SP-1'
rating to the county's limited tax GO delinquent tax notes.

"The downgrade reflects ongoing financial deterioration caused primarily by a
prolonged structural imbalance," said Standard & Poor's credit analyst Jane
Ridley.

The rating on the notes is based on our assessment of the following credit
factors:

"o Good projected coverage when incorporating additional liquidity and other
pledged revenues; "oÂ "o Strong history of collections; and "oÂ "o Limited-tax
GO pledge."oÂ The 2012 real property taxes due to Wayne County, outstanding and
uncollected as of May 15, 2013, and the county's limited-tax GO pledge secure
the series 2013 notes. Pledged revenues securing the notes include $300.7
million of 2012 delinquent property taxes and fees estimated to be delinquent
after May 15, 2013.

However, only $238 million of that amount is expected to be available during the
amortization period of the notes. The notes are being issued as fixed rate with
no put feature.

These notes are being issued as pari passu with any other future notes secured
by 2012 delinquent taxes. Should additional notes be sold in variable-rate mode,
it is Standard & Poor's understanding and expectation that future structures
will not include a put unless there is a liquidity facility.

The 'BBB' rating on the county's series GO limited and unlimited bonds reflects
our view of the following credit factors:

"o Economic diversification beyond the city of Detroit and a relatively diverse
tax base; "oÂ "o Demonstrated strides toward stabilizing financial operations
through an agreement with the Third Circuit Court; "oÂ "o A good financial
management profile that includes development and implementation of policies
designed to improve operational efficiencies across the organization; and "oÂ "o
A debt burden we consider moderate."o Â Offsetting factors include our view of:

"o A negative unreserved general fund balance that continues to grow and a
significantly reduced cash position;"oÂ "o Significant challenges in the form of
falling revenues, rising expenditures, pressure from expenditures outside county
management's control, and a challenged economic climate; "oÂ "o Significant
economic pressures given falling property values and the related implication for
property tax revenues; and "oÂ "o Economic indicators we consider just
adequate."oÂ The stable outlook reflects Standard & Poor's expectation that
Wayne County will continue to work toward regaining structural balance and that
its progress will be observable over the outlook's two-year time horizon. Should
the county's financial condition deteriorate significantly, Standard & Poor's
could lower the rating.

Given the challenges to date and the county's ongoing need to make changes with
both long- and short-term impacts, we do not expect to raise the rating during
the course of the outlook period.

                Intelligencer Journal (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)

                            March 4, 2009 Wednesday

Columbia Acts To Tighten Its Belt;
School District Gets Help With Tax Collection, Energy Consumption

BYLINE: James Buescher, Correspondent

SECTION: B; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 631  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


BY JAMES BUESCHER

Layoffs, bank collapses and a mortgage meltdown: bad times may have hit the
nation's private sector, but that doesn't mean the same effects are being felt
in the Columbia Borough School District.

At least, not yet.

Laura Cowburn, assistant to the superintendent for business services, said
Tuesday "things are fine" with the district's financial picture. However, she
said Columbia officials are bracing for the possibility of a very different
2009-10 school year.

"So far, the only big change we've seen is in interest rates. We have seen some
fluctuations with our returns on investments, but, for the most part, the wave
hasn't hit us yet," Cowburn said.

The school board acted Feb. 19 to improve its balance sheet by turning over
$570,377.98 in delinquent real estate taxes and real estate interim taxes to the
Lancaster County Tax Collection Bureau for collection. At the same meeting, the
board voted to hand over about $28,000 worth of delinquent per capita taxes to
the Halifax-based collection agency of Powell, Rogers & Speaks for collection.

Both those numbers, Cowburn said, are in line with delinquent taxes from
previous years.

"We have about a 93 percent collection rate when it comes to real estate taxes
in Columbia, and ($570,377.98) is in the ballpark when it comes to delinquent
taxes," Cowburn said. "It's something that we budget for, actually. ... When it
comes to collecting taxes we hope that everyone will be responsible, but we're
also realistic."

Because Columbia has a larger-than-normal transient population - such as
relatives temporarily moving in with extended-family members - the school
district collects only about 75 percent of its annual per capita tax. Therefore,
Cowburn said, the $28,000 is "right in line" with the school district's finances
before the economic crash this past fall.

"The way we collect taxes is that we start right after the commencement of the
fiscal year July 1, so the truth is we already had most of our taxes in before
the financial crisis began in earnest," she said.

"It's very, very hard to try and peer into the crystal ball for the 2009-10
school year, Cowburn said, "so for us, the best thing we can do is start
cost-saving measures now, and hope for the best."

Steps taken for next year, Cowburn said, include authorizing an "energy audit"
by The Ryan Corp. of Pittsburgh to take a look at ways the school district could
cut costs.

Columbia's energy audit, she said, began this past fall and has been ongoing
throughout the winter.

Keith Venessey, Ryan chief executive officer, said Tuesday, "Our goal is to look
for errors in billing or opportunities to reduce costs, whatever we can find to
help our clients save money."

Founded in 1990, Venessey's company has worked with more than 80 school
districts in the state plus the city of Pittsburgh and Bucks County to trim
budgets by suggesting alternative equipment such as "green" boilers or tankless
water heaters.

Ryan energy consultants get paid only through a percentage of realized
cost-savings, Cowburn said.

"It's really as simple as that old adage that you should only do your laundry in
the evenings because you're not paying peak rates for electricity. Here, we're
doing things like only turning the building on slowly in the mornings, beginning
at 5:30 a.m., so we're not being charged for a sudden spike in energy usage,"
she said.

The district is eliminating small appliances that are not required for
instructional or medical purposes and installing central heating controls.

Also, the district now relies on grant money when it comes to staff conference
and seminar programs.

For more information about Columbia's cost-savings efforts, or to suggest ways
the district could cut down on costs and save money, contact the administrative
center at 684-2283.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                          Reading Eagle (Pennsylvania)

                            February 18, 2011 Friday

Delinquent teen returning to Maryland

BYLINE: Holly Herman, Reading Eagle, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 419 words


Feb. 18--A 15-year-old Maryland teenager was declared delinquent Thursday in
Berks County Juvenile Court for stabbing a counselor during a Nov. 15 melee at a
New Morgan detention facility.

Jose Flores pleaded guilty before Senior Judge Arthur E. Grim to two counts of
aggravated assault and possessing instruments of crime.

Flores admitted punching, kicking and stabbing counselor Leon Williams in the
back with a pen during a fight in the cafeteria at Abraxas Academy.

Williams suffered three stab wounds to the back.

Grim said Maryland officials agreed to provide four or five years of treatment
services to Flores.

Flores was returned to the Berks County Youth Center, Bern Township, to await
transfer to Maryland.

Flores said he was grateful to return to Maryland and hopes to see his family.

"I hope to be home before my birthday, next Wednesday," Flores said.

Flores was among four teens charged in November with causing a riot, assaulting
counselors and residents, and throwing a desk out of a window.

Several unidentified residents suffered broken noses. Another staffer suffered
facial scratches.

Assistant District Attorney Catherine J. Nadirov said Flores needs long-term
treatment to become a positive member of society.

This was the second melee in five months at the facility, which houses up to 82
repeat-offender juveniles.

A 17-year-old male from Washington pleaded guilty to simple assault and remains
in Abraxas on unrelated charges.

A third defendant, Rasheed Hannah, 17, Philadelphia, is awaiting disposition on
aggravated assault. He is being held in a Philadelphia detention center.

Hannah also is charged with punching counselor Brian Savina in the face while
Savina was at his desk Nov. 29.

Jonathan Warner, 18, Philadelphia, is in Berks County Prison in lieu of $25,000
bail awaiting disposition in adult court.

Warner is accused of punching counselor Jose Nunuz-Ruiz and throwing a chair out
of a window. Nunuz-Ruiz suffered facial scratches.

According to court records:

The 17-year-old male and Hannah assaulted other residents in the cafeteria about
10 a.m. The staff members were assaulted when they tried to break up the brawl.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                           October 8, 2008 Wednesday

State officials push for loan modifications;
After Bank of America agrees to alter 390,000 subprime mortgages, regulators
urge others to follow suit

BYLINE: RUTH SIMON

SECTION: REPORT ON BUSINESS: THE WALL STREET JOURNAL; CREDIT CRISIS: U.S.
MORTGAGES; Pg. B11

LENGTH: 824 words


Attorneys-general and banking regulators from 11 states are calling on the
largest subprime-mortgage-servicing companies in the U.S. to follow Bank of
America Corp.'s lead and embark on a broad-based loan-modification program.

"We believe that every major servicer of subprime loans should adopt these types
of programs as soon as possible," state officials said in a letter sent
yesterday to 16 servicers. "We urge you in the strongest possible terms to adopt
a comprehensive, streamlined and effective loan-modification program as soon as
possible." The letter was signed by Iowa Attorney General Thomas Miller on
behalf of the State Foreclosure Prevention Working Group. Officials in Arizona,
California, Illinois, Massachusetts, Michigan, New York, North Carolina, Ohio
and Texas also added their names to the letter.

A report issued in September by the group, which also includes Colorado, found
that nearly eight out of 10 seriously delinquent homeowners with subprime or
Alt-A loans aren't on track for any type of loss mitigation. Alt-A mortgages are
a category between prime and subprime that frequently includes loans made to
borrowers who don't fully document their income.

As part of a settlement with state attorneys-general announced Monday, Bank of
America agreed to modify the terms of as many as 390,000 subprime mortgages and
option adjustable-rate mortgages that were serviced by Countrywide Financial,
which it acquired July 1. The deal, valued at more than $8.6-billion (U.S.),
aims to initially reduce borrowers' mortgage-related payments to 34 per cent of
monthly income by refinancing borrowers into government-backed loans and
reducing borrowers' interest rate or principal.

Mr. Miller said his office has already heard from three major mortgage
servicers, who have asked for details on the settlement. "Our first approach is
to work with everybody," he said. "Later on, if it is necessary, we would
consider litigation." The settlement shows that broad-based loan modifications
are feasible, state officials say. "If the largest lender in the country
understands the value of this program for its mortgage customers and the overall
economy, so should other lenders," said Illinois Attorney-General Lisa Madigan.

Bank of America owns about 12 per cent of the loans covered by the agreement. In
most other cases, investors have given the company authority to modify loans
when necessary, a Bank of America spokesman said. The Bank of America settlement
follows a template laid down this summer by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.
after it took over IndyMac Bancorp. In an effort to maximize the value of loans
it now controls and to reduce foreclosures, the FDIC is sending letters to
roughly 28,000 delinquent borrowers with IndyMac loans, offering to rework the
terms of their mortgages. The modifications are designed so that
mortgage-related payments don't exceed 38 per cent of gross income.

The FDIC has generally offered to reduce borrowers' interest rates or stretch
the term of their loans to as long as 40 years. Few of the government's offers
have involved a reduction in principal, because other options are more likely to
maximize recoveries, an FDIC spokesman said, adding that thus far, about half of
the delinquent loans that the FDIC has reviewed have qualified for a loan
modification.

An FDIC spokesman declined to comment on the settlement, but said that the FDIC
believes that setting an affordability target represents "a good model" for how
to approach systematic loan modifications. "We have discussed this approach with
Treasury and others as a way to preserve the value of the loans and keep
borrowers in their homes," he added.

Some states are looking at other ways to provide relief to borrowers. In
addition to pushing mortgage servicers to step up loan modifications, Texas may
pursue legal action against bankrupt mortgage companies, said Texas
Attorney-General Greg Abbott.

Not all borrowers who are behind on their loans will qualify for a loan
modification. It is too early to tell how many of those who do get help will
succeed in paying their loans on time. But one preliminary analysis suggests
some approaches work better than others.

Roughly 23 per cent of borrowers who received a principal reduction were at
least 60 days delinquent eight months after their loans were modified, though 80
per cent were seriously delinquent before the modification, according to an
analysis by Credit Suisse Group of subprime-loan modifications completed in the
fourth quarter of 2007.

By contrast, 44 per cent of borrowers were at least 60 days behind on their loan
payments eight months after being put on a repayment plan that resulted in the
same or a higher mortgage payment - typically because missed payments or fees
were added to their loan balance. About 85 per cent of those borrowers were
seriously delinquent before the plan was instituted, according to Credit Suisse.

                             426 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           The Philadelphia Inquirer

                            August 13, 2011 Saturday
                                  WEB Edition

Few delinquents properties worth less than tax debt

BYLINE: By Patrick Kerkstra; FOR THE INQUIRER

SECTION: WEB; P-com News Special Reports; Pg. WEB

LENGTH: 349 words



How much are delinquent properties in Philadelphia actually worth?

Some, like the Foxwoods casino site, are worth plenty. But there are many others
- vacant lots and abandoned shells in some of the city's lowest-income
neighborhoods - with relatively low open-market values.

In the past, Nutter administration officials have suggested that part of the
reason Philadelphia has a large backlog of delinquent real estate accounts is
that many of the properties are worth less than is owed on them in back taxes,
interest, and penalties.

But that argument falls apart under scrutiny.

For one thing, although the city must first seek to sell delinquent properties
for the amount owed in back taxes (plus other municipal liens), it can later
offer the properties for sale at a cheaper price if there are no takers the
first time around. The city and schools might lose out on past revenue, but they
are more likely to collect in the future by transferring ownership of the
delinquent parcel.

Second, most of Philadelphia's tax-delinquent properties are worth more on the
open market than their owners owe in unpaid tax debt, according to an analysis
of the property values of delinquent accounts performed Kevin Gillen, an
Econsult vice president, at The Inquirer's request (the city's own assessed
property values, which have been estimated by the Board of Revision of Taxes,
are far too inaccurate to use).

Gillen, considered the foremost expert on property values in the Philadelphia
region, used a variety of methods to estimate property values for 72,000 of the
111,000 tax-delinquent accounts (he was unable to estimate values on the
remainder for a variety of reasons, such as insufficient local sales comps).

Of the 72,000, all but 519 had property values higher than the amounts owed. And
68,500 of them were worth at least twice as much as their tax debts.

Although many properties sell for less than they are worth at tax sales,
Gillen's analysis makes it clear the city could recoup much, though not all, of
what it is owed by selling off tax-delinquent land.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   The Times-Tribune (Scranton, Pennsylvania)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                            September 9, 2016 Friday

EDITORIAL: Fairness in tax measures

BYLINE: The Times-Tribune, Scranton, Pa.

SECTION: COMMENTARY

LENGTH: 384 words


Sept. 09--It doesn't take an economics degree to understand how an owner of
multiple tax-delinquent properties can make good on his local tax bill. He has
to sell one or more of the properties and use part of the proceeds to settle up
on the others.

State law does not require that, however. It allows local governments to lien
delinquent properties, but only individually; it doesn't consider a delinquent
taxpayer's combined real estate holdings.

Now, local ordinances allow individuals or firms that own multiple delinquent
properties to sell one or more of them -- thus requiring taxes on those
properties to be brought up to date -- while keeping the sale proceeds and
leaving the other properties in arrears. In some cases that is a calculated
strategy by multiproperty landlords.

Ron Koldjeski, the head of the Lackawanna County department that collects
delinquent taxes, has recommended an ordinance that would set a better standard.

Under the proposal, which has been adopted in several other counties, local
governments would be able to collect, from the sale proceeds of any of his
properties, back taxes due on all of an owner's delinquent properties.

Such a rule would shift the cost of delinquency from all other taxpayers, who
must make up for others' delinquency through higher tax rates, to the delinquent
firm or individual property owner. In doing so, it would provide a strong
incentive for owners to keep tax payments up to date so as not to diminish the
value of their equity in any particular property.

Another part of the ordinance would allow the county government to grant
extended payment periods to older residents facing economic hardships, illnesses
or other problems that prevent their timely tax payments. The extension period
would be at a 9 percent interest rate, but the county could reduce or eliminate
that as part of a final settlement. Extensions would be capped so that the owed
amount could not exceed the value of the property, thus enabling the county to
recoup the full amount due when the property is sold.

The commissioners should adopt the proposals as a matter of broad-based tax
fairness for all county taxpayers.

___ (c)2016 The Times-Tribune (Scranton, Pa.) Visit The Times-Tribune (Scranton,
Pa.) at thetimes-tribune.com Distributed by Tribune Content Agency, LLC.

CENTERVILLE

Anthem performers needed for concerts

The Centerville Arts Commission is seeking National Anthem performers for the
2012 Summer Concert Series at Stubbs Park Amphitheater, 255 W. Spring Valley
Road.

Singers and instrumental groups should submit a demo CD to the Arts Commission
at the City Municipal Building, 100 W. Spring Valley Road, Centerville 45458.
Electronic submissions can be made via information@ centervilleohio.gov in care
of the Centerville Arts Commission.

Centerville and Washington Twp. residents are eligible. Parental consent is
required for those under 18. Deadline is May 5 and no compensation will be paid.

More information about the Arts Commission is available at (937) 433-7151,
www.ci.centervill e.oh.us. TERRY MORRIS

WASHINGTON TWP.

Most residents not delinquent on taxes

Washington Twp. officials said less than 2 percent of Washington Twp. and City
of Centerville property owners are delinquent on their taxes, Montgomery County
Treasurer Carolyn Rice said during a presentation at the April 9 township
trustees meeting.

"Of the 25,074 parcels in the combined communities, 459, or 1.8 percent, are
delinquent," she said.

The rate is exactly the same for the unincorporated township portion, which
includes 14,436 of those parcels. Rice said "261, or 1.8 percent, are delinquent
. That's a total value of $2.18 million."

For Montgomery County as a whole, 6 percent of taxpayers are delinquent.

Officials cite 2010 Census data, reported by the Ohio Department of Development,
that puts the Centerville and Washington Twp. population at 56,607, just ahead
of Kettering at 56,163. Dayton is first at 141,527. TERRY MORRIS

DAYTON

Sold-out workshop honors humorist

The family of the late humorist Erma Bombeck chose a hardy hoopsi blue spruce to
plant this spring near her Ohio historical marker outside St. Mary Hall on the
University of Dayton's campus. "They planted trees and crabgrass came up," the
plaque will read.

About 350 writers from around the country and University of Dayton students are
expected to attend a short tree dedication and blessing ceremony at 4 p.m. April
21 with the Bombeck family as part of the sold-out 2012 Erma Bombeck Writers'
Workshop.

The workshop, envisioned as a one-time event when it was launched in 2000, is
now offered every other year at the University of Dayton, where Bombeck
graduated in 1949. The 2012 workshop sold out in eight days.

Follow the workshop on Facebook at facebook.com/ ermabombeck and on Twitter at
twitter.com/ebww. STAFF REPORT

HUBER HEIGHTS

City files objection to liquor permit renewal

The city of Huber Heights officially has filed an objection to a liquor permit
renewal for Heat Nightclub with the Ohio Division of Liquor Control.

City attorney Alan Schaeffer sent the objection in a letter dated March 30, with
a request to set the hearing in Montgomery County. Deadline to file the
objection was May 2.

City council passed a resolution last month objecting to the club's liquor
permit renewal, citing excessive police calls.

From Nov. 20, 2010, through the end of February of this year, Huber Heights
police received 72 calls for service at Heat Nightclub. STEVEN MATTHEWS

                             429 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                            The Blade (Toledo, Ohio)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             April 12, 2011 Tuesday

In April, utilities insist late bills be paid

BYLINE: The Blade, Toledo, Ohio

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 500 words


April 12--April marks more than just the regular return of warmer weather; it
also marks the month when local utility companies look to their delinquent
customers to make good on their past-due bills or face having those utilities
shut off.

Paul Livernois, a spokesman for Michigan Gas Utilities, which provides natural
gas to large swaths of Monroe and Lenawee counties, said April 1 is the end of
the company's annual Winter Protection Plan, which protects eligible seniors and
low-income customers from having their service shut off between Nov. 1 and March
31.

This month the company warned delinquent payers that those who had not made
efforts to catch up on their bill would face disconnection of service.

He said low-income customers should contact local agencies, such as the United
Way's 211 Help Hotline, for assistance that might postpone disconnection before
those organizations' funds are depleted.

"Customers will find we offer options for payment; but the larger the balance,
the larger those payments need to be," Michigan Gas President Chuck Cloninger
said in a written statement. "If there are extenuating circumstances that can be
documented, we need to know about them."

Akron-based FirstEnergy Corp., parent company of Toledo Edison, doesn't do
utility shutoffs over the winter months whenever temperatures are forecast to be
below 20 degrees within the next 24 hours, spokesman Mark Durbin said. The
warmer weather then means the end to any weather-related restrictions on
shutoffs and an end to the company's program that allows delinquent customers to
make a one-time $175 payment to keep their service going.

Chris Kozak, a spokesman for Columbia Gas of Ohio, said the natural gas utility
doesn't have a winter shutoff moratorium, but does observe a practice during
cold-weather months of providing delinquent customers with a 10-day shutoff
notice. As of Friday, that practice ends.

This year, there are about 40,000 more homes across Ohio that have seriously
delinquent accounts with Columbia Gas than there were a year ago, but the number
of customers whose service was terminated this year is down about 33 percent
overall, Mr. Kozak said.

"We continue to see lower gas prices, and we're seeing a lot of outreach
efforts, especially for those seeking help for the first time," Mr. Kozak said.
He said there are still utility assistance programs with funds available, and
customers who believe they may have trouble paying their bill should contact
Columbia Gas as quickly as possible to make payment arrangements and keep gas
flowing.

"By the time the guy shows up at the house with a pipe wrench, it's too late,"
Mr. Kozak said.

-- Larry P. Vellequette

To see more of The Blade, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.toledoblade.com. Copyright (c) 2011, The Blade, Toledo, Ohio
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For more information
about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services
(MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com.

LOAD-DATE: April 12, 2011

                             The Guardian (London)

                                January 7, 2003

Exposure to lead in old homes linked to juvenile delinquency

BYLINE: James Meikle, Health correspondent

SECTION: Guardian Home Pages, Pg. 6

LENGTH: 383 words


Children exposed to lead have a significantly higher chance of becoming juvenile
delinquents, according to research published yesterday.

Teenage boys who went through the juvenile court system around Pittsburgh,
Pennsylvania, in the US, had far higher concentrations of lead in their bones
than non-delinquent children of a similar age, the research showed.

And Herbert Needleman, leader of the study published in the journal
Neurotoxicology and Terotology, said his team estimated that up to 38% of
delinquency in Allegheny County, Pennsylvania, was attributable to the effect of
lead.

He said a programme should be launched to rid old houses of lead contamination,
mainly from paint, since the other main source in the past, petrol, had been
tackled by the adoption of lead-free fuel.

His team's study, which compared lead concentrations in the lower leg bones of
young people, goes further than most in linking lead levels to crimi nality.
Previous research has focused on low IQ and learning disorders.

Between 1996 and 1998, the researchers compared results from 194 boys aged 12 to
18 who had been arrested and judged delinquent in Allegheny County with those
for 147 non-delinquent pupils in Pittsburgh. They found that the delinquent
youths had average lead concentrations of 11 parts per million in their bones
compared with 1.5 in the control group.

Dr Needleman, of the University of Pittsburgh's school of medicine, has been
studying the effects of lead on adolescents for more than 20 years. He said:
"This study provides further evidence that delinquent behaviour can be caused in
part by childhood exposure to lead. For years parents have been telling their
paediatricians that their children's behaviour changed after they were lead
poisoned and the children became irritable, overactive and aggressive."

The differences in lead levels found were startling, he said. "Since we have
taken lead out of gasoline, the only major source is old housing."

There would be clear health and employment benefits in removing lead
contamination from homes, said Dr Needleman. "We have to do it or pay the price.
It would prevent a substantial amount of crime. We estimate between 11% and 38%
of delinquency in Allegheny County is attributable to lead."

                             431 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         Hartford Courant (Connecticut)

                              March 7, 2008 Friday
                               STATEWIDE EDITION

LOAN DELINQUENCIES RISE;
FORECLOSURES HIGHEST IN NEARLY 10 YEARS AS LEGISLATORS DEBATE BORROWER BAILOUTS

BYLINE: KENNETH R. GOSSELIN; Courant Staff Writer

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. E1

LENGTH: 763 words


Home loan delinquencies in Connecticut rose to the highest level since 1985 by
the end of last year, with subprime loans accounting for much of the increase.

At the same time, mortgage foreclosures climbed to numbers not seen in almost 10
years, according to a quarterly report released Thursday by the Mortgage Bankers
Association examining the last three months of 2007.

While the figures seem dire, Connecticut was in better shape than many states,
ranked in the bottom half in both delinquencies and loans in foreclosure.

But the 79 percent increase in "seriously delinquent" loans - those 90 days past
due and in foreclosure - was worse than the nation as a whole compared with a
year ago.

About 13,000 home loans in Connecticut, or 2.53 percent of all mortgages, were
seriously delinquent in the fourth quarter. While that number represents a
sliver of the 545,000 mortgages in Connecticut, it could nonetheless have an
effect on the larger economy should all the homes go into foreclosure.

Housing experts have warned that foreclosures immediately bring down property
values in surrounding neighborhoods, sometimes by several thousand dollars.

Thursday's report comes as state legislators debate mortgage reform and borrower
bailouts. Similar debates are occurring in states across the country and in
Congress.

Gov. M. Jodi Rell announced a Connecticut housing assistance program primarily
for subprime borrowers with adjustable-rate loans who are facing foreclosure.
But it was criticized for helping too few, and Democrats subsequently proposed a
more aggressive plan to replace it.Housing advocates in the Hartford area say
calls from distressed borrowers continue to pour in with no signs of slowing
down.

"My impression is that things aren't improving," said Andrew Pizor, senior
policy counsel at the Connecticut Fair Housing Center. "They are getting worse."

Donald L. Klepper-Smith, an economist at DataCore Partners in New Haven, said he
believes the housing slump will continue at least through the end of the year
and possibly longer. But he said the levels of loan foreclosures in Connecticut,
while rising, are not yet at a crisis point.

For instance, Thursday's report found that 1.55 percent of home loans in the
fourth quarter last year were in foreclosure. Klepper-Smith said he would begin
getting more concerned if that number rose to 2 percent or 2.5 percent.

"The problem still seems to be relatively contained," he said.

Nationally, the number of mortgage delinquencies rose to their highest level in
23 years in the fourth quarter of last year. Connecticut's woes are dwarfed by
problems in states such Michigan and Ohio, where seriously delinquent loans
represent nearly 6 percent of all loans, the highest in the nation.

In Florida, the increase in seriously delinquent loans rose 3.6 percentage
points in the fourth quarter, to 5.19 percent, compared with a year ago.

The housing downturn was touched off by the subprime mortgage crisis, born of
lending - some of it blatantly predatory - to borrowers who couldn't afford the
loans for which they were approved. Most of those were adjustable-rate loans
that are now resetting to higher rates, straining household budgets and pushing
some borrowers into foreclosure.

When home prices were rising, borrowers were building equity and could more
easily refinance. That is no longer the case.

In the early 1990s, Connecticut saw a wave of delinquencies and foreclosures.
But this time things are different. Then, there was a mix of commercial and
residential problems. This time around, however, it's almost exclusively
residential.

Although Connecticut compared favorably with other states at the end of last
year, concern is growing about overall mortgage delinquencies, which rose to
5.08 percent of all loans in the last quarter. That compares with 4.29 percent a
year ago.

"That's higher than I'd like to see it," said Howard Pitkin, the state banking
commissioner.

Pitkin said he would be more comfortable with 3 percent or lower, which would be
a sign of a market regaining stability.

Thursday's report also comes at a troubling time for homeowners who have tapped
deep into their home equity to meet other expenses. A new report said the
average homeowner has less than 50 percent equity for the first time since 1945.

Klepper-Smith said there are other pressures on household budgets: The rising
cost of food, gasoline and home heating oil.

And there is the specter of recession, which could cost the jobs that
Connecticut borrowers need to pay their mortgages.

Contact Kenneth R. Gosselin at kgosselin@courant.com

LOAD-DATE: March 7, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

"seriously delinquent" home loans -- those 90 days past due and in foreclosure
-- a a percentage of all loans. SOURCE: Mortgage Bankers Associations LIBRARY

                               The New York Times

               December 28, 1981, Monday, Late City Final Edition

U.S. TO PURSUE PHYSICIANS WHO DEFAULTED ON LOANS

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section A; Page 17, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 569 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27


Richard S. Schweiker, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, has ordered
that action be taken against doctors and other health professionals who have
defaulted on student loans, it was announced today.

The announcement followed disclosures that nearly a third of the health
professionals who took low-interest loans to get through school were behind in
repayments.

Federal investigators have cited cases in which physicians are earning big
salaries and driving expensive cars while failing to pay back their student
loans.

''Former medical and nursing students who don't pay back their loans are being
unfair to students who follow them,'' Mr. Schweiker said in a statement. ''Some
new students may be unable to get loans to attend medical or nursing school
because some former loan recipients didn't repay theirs.

'We Owe It to Future Students'

''We owe it to future health professions students to stop the widespread
delinquency in loan payments.'' He outlined four steps he was taking: He said
legislation was being prepared to give his department authority to collect
delinquent loans referred to it by schools.  Second, he said, a watchdog program
would be established by the department's inspector general and assistant
secretary for health. In addition, the department's counsel will look into how
the Government can more actively seek out delinquents. Last, he said, the
department will develop performance standards for schools to be used in
considering future loan allocations.

The department makes the money available to schools, which lend it to qualified
students and are then responsible for collecting repayments.

Mr. Schweiker said that preliminary data showed that as many as 30 percent of
borrowers might be delinquent in repaying Health Professions Student Loans and
Nursing Student Loans. The delinquency may exceed $20 million, he said.

Identification in Capital Area

He said that the inspector general's office of his department had finished
preliminary identification of nearly 1,700 delinquents in the
Washington-Baltimore area, and that a nationwide crackdown was under way.

Mr. Schweiker's figures are similar to those supplied earlier this month by
aides to Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, a member of the
Senate Governmental Affairs Committee. They said 50,000 health professionals,
including 5,716 physicians, were seriously delinquent in paying back their
loans.

That depletes by more than $23 million the Government money pool for providing
long-term medical school loans, the Percy figures indicate.

A Percy aide estimated as many as 5,000 prospective doctors, dentists,
optometrists, pharmacists and nurses would be denied Government loans this year
because of the abuses.

The 10-year medical loans of up to $20,000 or more are provided at interest
rates of 3 percent to 7 percent, with repayment not required until at least a
year after graduation. Repayment can be delayed for five or 10 years for
post-graduate residency training, teaching or work in areas that are short of
doctors.

Congress has ordered that no more money be put in the $70 million medical loan
fund, leaving it as a revolving pool.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1981 The New York Times Company

                                US Official News

                           February 25, 2017 Saturday

Bill summary and status of HB 1909 Real property tax; nonjudicial sale of tax
delinquent property.

LENGTH: 487  words

DATELINE: New York



  Richmond: Virginia Lagislative Information Systeam has issued the following
bill summary and status:

   SUMMARY AS PASSED HOUSE:

 Real property tax; nonjudicial sale of tax delinquent property. Permits the
nonjudicial sale of unimproved real property valued at less than $5,000 if taxes
are delinquent for at least three years.

The bill also permits the nonjudicial sale of real property valued at no less
than $5,000 but no greater than $20,000 if taxes are delinquent for at least
three years, the property is not subject to a recorded mortgage or deed of trust
lien, and the property (i) is unimproved and measures less than 4,000 square
feet; (ii) is unimproved and has been determined to be unsuitable for building
(the bill expands the bases on which unsuitability may rest); (iii) has a
structure on it that has been condemned by the local building official; (iv) has
been declared a nuisance by the locality; (v) contains a derelict building; or
(vi) has been declared to be blighted by the locality. The bill also modifies
current law regarding notice of the sale, redemption of the property, and
application of excess proceeds. Current law permits the nonjudicial sale of
unimproved real property valued at less than $10,000 if taxes are delinquent for
at least three years and the property (a) measures less than 4,000 square feet
or (b) has been determined to be unsuitable for building.

                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                     MARCH 28, 2001 Wednesday NORTH EDITION

NORRISTOWN AREA SCHOOL DISTRICT MAY PURSUE TARDY TAXPAYERS

BYLINE: Lee Drutman INQUIRER SUBURBAN STAFF

SECTION: NEIGHBORS NORTH; Pg. B02

LENGTH: 467 words

DATELINE: WEST NORRITON


For years, the Norristown Area School District has been the county poster child
when it comes to delinquent real-estate tax. With $4.8 million in outstanding
money, the district is owed $2 million more than the next closest delinquent,
Abington.

But Norristown school officials have had enough. Now, they say, it's time to
start collecting.

"It's a chronic annoyance," said School Board President Murray Toas. "What we're
trying to do is to collect taxes from those who owe the taxes rather than raise
taxes on everybody else."

The district is contracting a third-party tax-collecting agency to track down
property owners who have not paid their bills in years. This would make the
district the first in the county to aggressively target delinquent back taxes,
said Betsy McBride, deputy treasurer of the county tax-claim bureau.

Of the 21,000 delinquent parcels in the county, 6,500 are within the borders of
the Norristown Area School District and 4,400 are in the borough of Norristown,
McBride said. Yet, Norristown is only one of 24 school districts in the county,
which has a total of $54 million in unpaid school taxes.

Under the current proposal, the Norristown Area School District would pay
Berkheimer Associates, a private tax-collecting agency based in Bangor, Pa., to
track down the chronic delinquent taxes. A fee or commission has not yet been
determined. Chronic delinquent taxes - those unpaid for more than two years -
account for about half of the district's current missing revenue from
real-estate taxes.

Pending approval of the plan by the county tax-claim bureau and the county
commissioners, the district would have Berkheimer notify property owners of
their long-unpaid taxes, and then, if taxes were still not received after dogged
attempts to collect, the county would begin to auction off the properties.

"It's a time-consuming process," said Jim Hunt, Berkheimer's district manager
for the Southeast Pennsylvania region. "This would be the first time we've
undertaken something like this for a school."

Toas said the district would first target the top offenders. The five largest
delinquents account for $431,352 worth of taxes, with one property owner
accounting for $209,555.52. Tom Padden, district business administrator, said
the top offender was a business still in operation, but he would not say which
one. Most of the top 48 offenders, which account for $1,028,472 of the unpaid
taxes, are businesses, Padden said.

Nobody would estimate how many of these delinquent taxes could be recovered. But
Padden had his doubts.

"Some of the properties could go back 50, 70, 80, 100 years," he said. "Some
could be swallowed up in eminent domain and not even exist anymore."

Lee Drutman's e-mail address is ldrutman@phillynews.com.

LOAD-DATE: October 31, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              All Rights Reserved

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                   September 25, 1997, Thursday, ALL EDITIONS

Alpharetta hires collector for tax liens

BYLINE: Devi Sen Laskar; STAFF WRITER

SECTION: EXTRA; Pg. 09H

LENGTH: 303 words



Alpharetta will be getting its money's worth.

The City Council has agreed to sell its tax liens to a private company that will
collect the money or make use of foreclosure options allowed under state law.

The city hired Capital Asset Research Corp. of Atlanta to collect delinquent
taxes. The company was selected among 19 bidders because it offered the most
money and promised to pay the entire balance before it collected its first dime.

Alpharetta is selling the liens for 90 percent of the value of ad valorem taxes,
unpaid utility accounts and any penalties and interest. This means the city will
earn 90 percent of the $ 247,808 in tax liens, or $ 223,027.

Delinquent taxes aren't widespread, said Linda Dale, the city's chief financial
officer. The city has collected about 98.5 percent of all taxes due. These do
not include cases that are under appeal or homeowners who have filed bankruptcy.

But Dale recommended the city enter into a three-year contract with the company
to turn over delinquent accounts on an ongoing basis.

"We've made all reasonable efforts to collect those delinquent taxes, but the
city isn't in the business of collecting taxes, and we felt we had reached a
level of diminishing return," said Mayor Chuck Martin. "Rather than hire someone
full-time, we looked at privatization."

Capital Asset has had this type of purchase agreement with Fulton County for the
past two and a half years and has purchased in excess of $ 53 million in
accounts. The company has worked with the Fulton sheriff's department in an
effort not to overburden their officers with the serving of levies, Dale said.

The company has also bought $ 48 million in delinquent accounts from Pittsburgh
and serves as collector for New York City for accounts totalling more than $ 215
million.

                            Buffalo News (New York)

                            September 9, 2005 Friday
                                 FINAL EDITION

AROUND THE STATE

SECTION: NEWS; Around the State; Pg. A10

LENGTH: 462 words


State plans crackdown on E-ZPass delinquents

ALBANY (AP) -- The Thruway Authority plans to hire a collection agency to recoup
some of the roughly $23 million in outstanding tolls and fees owed by thousands
of motorists who have breezed through E-ZPass lanes without paying.

Delinquent drivers will have one last chance to pay up before their names are
turned over to the collection agency.

Officials admit the authority may get as little as $1 million after disputed
fees are resolved, after St. Louis-based OSI Collection Services takes its 21
percent cut.

"Whether it's $1 million or $2 million, we don't know, but we do think it's
important to make the effort to collect what is owed to the authority,"
Executive Director Michael Fleischer said.

OSI is expected to begin contacting customers with delinquent bills in a few
months. It has worked with such agencies as the Florida Turnpike, the California
Department of Transportation and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.

Separately, Rockland County prosecutors said 20 people have been charged in a
scam in which corporations were falsely billed for $734,000 in tolls through
illegal E-ZPass tags. Two employees of Affiliated Computer Services, the company
that manages the E-ZPass system, organized the fraud, prosecutors said.

-----

U.N. session to pose big security challenge

NEW YORK (AP) -- World leaders will converge on Manhattan next week for the
United Nations General Assembly, creating the largest security challenge for the
city since last summer's Republican National Convention, police officials said
Thursday.

"This is a general assembly like no other," Police Commissioner Raymond Kelly
said following a briefing for commanders at Police Headquarters.

About 170 world leaders are expected to arrive at U.N. headquarters Wednesday
for the assembly's 60th anniversary.

Among those scheduled to attend: President Bush, British Prime Minister Tony
Blair, Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, Iranian President Mahmoud
Ahmadinejad, Russian President Vladimir Putin and Chinese President Hu Jintao.

The dignitaries will receive Secret Service protection. In addition, more than
4,000 New York Police officers will be assigned.

-----

Deutsche Bank building dismantling work starts

NEW YORK (AP) -- The deconstruction of the Deutsche Bank building badly damaged
by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in 2001 has begun, state officials announced
Thursday.

Crews were to begin by preparing the 40-story tower housing the German bank with
scaffolding and fencing, as well as removing the netting that has hung on the
vacant building opposite ground zero, Gov. George E. Pataki and state officials
announced.

The building was heavily damaged when a section of the trade center's south
tower collapsed, tearing through 15 stories.

                        Copyright 2005 The Buffalo News


                             437 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                     March 19, 1995, Sunday, Final Edition

New Relevance for the Junior Republic

SECTION: OP-ED; Pg. C08

LENGTH: 681 words


At Annapolis Junction in Anne Arundel County, near the line with Prince George's
and Howard counties, lies an abandoned residential reform school called Cedar
Knoll, which is still owned by the D.C. Department of Human Services.

Most people know nothing about the history of this property, but given the
present brouhaha about the revival of orphanages for neglected and delinquent
children, that history may have new relevance.

On June 1, 1899, a group of philanthropic citizens of Baltimore and Washington
secured a charter from Maryland as well as land at Annapolis Junction for the
establishment of what they called the National Junior Republic, a private reform
school for delinquent and potentially delinquent boys and girls ages 14 to 21.

The good citizens modeled their institution on William R. George's "George
Junior Republic" in Freeville, N.Y., and they believed it would be an answer to
the problem of delinquent children in the slums of Baltimore and Washington.
Annapolis Junction's proximity to Washington led them to envision their
institution as a prototype for similar centers throughout the nation and as a
center for training staff in the policies and principles of education and
rehabilitation.

Under the National Republic system, boys and a few girls at Annapolis Junction
lived in boarding houses. They paid for their lodging and food with specially
issued tin coins and, like their counterparts in Freeville, worked at jobs that
ranged from ditch-digging and road-building to skilled trades such as farming,
carpentry, masonry and printing. The few girls were cooks, housekeepers and
laundresses.

Particularly enterprising citizens of the National Junior Republic could secure
concessions for producing, buying and selling goods and services. Schoolwork
also was done under contract and reimbursed. Those earning more of the
republic's currency could afford to live in the more desirable boarding houses,
eat better food and buy nicer clothes.

A complement to this economic system of "Nothing Without Labor" and free
enterprise was a political system of self-rule and democracy in which the boys
and girls elected a president and a legislature and administered a court and a
correctional system.

The Baltimore American of June 4, 1913, carried an account of the inauguration
of a president of the National Junior Republic. The inaugural ceremony of the
young Walter Blue, presided over by W. F. Rogers of the Washington Bar
Association, was modeled on the U.S. president's inauguration. After taking the
oath of office, the new boy-citizen president named his cabinet and chief judge.
In response to shouts of "Oh, you, president" and "I voted for you, Blue," he
gave a short speech thanking his fellow citizens for their confidence.

But just four years later, in 1917, the National Junior Republic closed its
doors. This happened for several reasons including the booming job market of
World World I and the period that followed and the increased attendance of
students at senior high schools.

Afew years later, in 1924, the Baltimore Sun painted a forlorn picture of the
once bustling facility:

"Idle is the counting house; empty, the jail. Cobwebs darken the windows of the
chapel. Weeds grow in the fields, and silence hovers over the place where once
grew and flourished 60-odd boys, making their own laws and enforcing them, doing
their own work, learning the lessons of life."

In 1931 the trustees of the defunct National Junior Republic deeded the 144
acres at Annapolis to the Evangelical Lutheran Church. From this body, the land
and buildings passed to the D.C. Department of Human Services and became Cedar
Knoll.

Today, a sense of abandonment and waste once again hangs over the land and
buildings at Annapolis Junction. Yet, the problem of turning disadvantaged city
youth into useful citizens is more of a problem than it ever was when the
century was young. Perhaps it's time for our leaders to give another look at the
unique experiment that was the National Junior Republic.

-- John and Mary Baer


LOAD-DATE: March 19, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo

                       Copyright 1995 The Washington Post


                             438 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                     The News Herald (Panama City, Florida)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          February 13, 2013 Wednesday

County considers reducing public notice on delinquent taxes

BYLINE: Matthew Beaton, The News Herald, Panama City, Fla.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 829 words


Feb. 13--PANAMA CITY-- Bay County is considering dramatically reducing public
notice for delinquent taxpayers, even though it won't save public dollars.

By law, the county must advertise the delinquent tax list annually for real and
personal property. March 31 is the last day property owners can pay their taxes.

The county then culls the delinquent list and puts it online and, as required by
law, in a local newspaper. In years past, the list has run in The News Herald in
May, once a week for three straight weeks. The list appeared in every copy of
The News Herald, about 24,000 total each run date. Last year the cost was about
$210,000, according to Bay County Tax Collector Peggy Brannon at last week's
County Commission meeting.

This year, county staff has recommended the commission consider reducing the
number of copies that carry the list -- to as few as 850 papers -- published
three times, and commissioners are interested.

At last week's commission meeting, Commissioner Guy Tunnell said it appeared
this could save "quite a bit of money" for Bay County. It was pointed out by
Brannon that only delinquent taxpayers would benefit and that the county would
not save money, but the commission remained intrigued.

Under Florida statute, the advertising costs are added to the "delinquent taxes
collected" and are recouped from the delinquent taxpayer. Brannon made that
point at the meeting.

"That is a recoverable cost," she said.

No commissioners would comment for this story because The News Herald is one of
two legally qualified bidders -- the other is the Bay County Bullet, a weekly
publication.

Informing the public

The newspaper industry isn't thrilled about a partial distribution of delinquent
tax lists. On the business side it represents a loss of revenue, but as it goes
to the public it means an erosion of government's duty to keep people informed.

"We think it's very important for public notices to be in print with as broad a
distribution as possible," said Dean Ridings, president and CEO of the Florida
Press Association.

In Ridings' view, every copy of the paper should carry the notice because there
are instances where taxpayers "miss it" -- fail to pay their taxes and don't see
the list in print. A list running in every paper is the best chance to prevent
that from happening.

Ridings also said the list lets property owners know if their neighbors are
delinquent.

"That's a potential impact to you. ... We are 100 percent an advocate for as
much notice as possible," he said.

Because advertising costs are borne by delinquent taxpayers, Ridings was not
sure why the county would consider not putting the list in every copy possible
from the chosen paper.

"I'm not sure I have the answer to that," he said.

Buying tax certificates

Advertising the delinquent tax list serves another purpose -- it lets the public
know it can bid on delinquent property tax "certificates." In buying the
certificate, the purchaser pays the taxes owed and receives an interest rate on
that amount. Eventually, when the delinquent taxpayers pony up for the money
they owe, those who purchased the certificates get their money back.

Interest rates start at 18 percent, and bids go in reverse until the lowest
interest rate offered wins the certificate.

"Most certificates are sold to big investment groups," said Mark Peel, the
county's delinquent tax supervisor. "They'll buy about 90 to 95 percent of what
we have to sell year to year because they bid low interest rates."

Last year, the county sold 7,089 certificates, which totaled nearly $10 million.
With still more than a month before March 31, taxes on 24,136 pieces of property
have not been paid, totaling $26.9 million, Peel said.

If Bay County chose limited distribution, it would be in the minority in Florida
but would not be the first. Leon County's move to limited distribution was
mentioned several times at the last commission meeting, along with the fact that
they were sued over it. While they won, Brannon noted to commissioners that any
litigation costs would fall to the county to cover.

Meanwhile, Bay County has not had trouble selling the certificates. All were
sold last year, Peel said. The only year he could remember all the certificates
not being sold was when the economy took a nosedive during the recent recession.
Even then, the county held a second sale and sold them all off.

And, Peel is confident about this year's sale.

"We will sell them all," he said.

Commissioners last week said they wanted to have two options to review -- a full
distribution as in years past and a partial distribution to compare costs and
also get feedback from the public on which method would be preferred.

The bids will be received by week's end and commissioners are set to vote on
which way to go and who to go with next Tuesday due to deadlines faced by
Brannon.

City, Fla.) at www.newsherald.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

-taxes-0213-20130213

                          The Tampa Tribune (Florida)

                             March 29, 2009 Sunday
                                 FINAL EDITION

FOAMING AT THE DRAIN

BYLINE: RICHARD WHITE, Tribune correspondent

SECTION: BAYLIFE MAGAZINE; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 648 words


WASHING MACHINE PLUMBING ISSUE BUBBLES OVER

By RICHARD WHITE

Tribune correspondent

Q. I am a senior citizen - 77 years old. The owners on the floor above me
installed a washing machine from which suds and water come into my apartment
through the wastewater drains. I reported the problem to the manager but nothing
has been done to correct the problem. We have laundry rooms in the building but,
of course, people prefer to have their own machines.

HS

Miami Beach

A. Many older buildings were not constructed with plumbing drain lines to carry
garbage disposal or washing machine wastewater. If you check your documents,
they may contain such exclusions.

I would suggest that you send a letter to the board of directors and to the
owners of the washing machine concerning the problem. Since the building has
common-area washers and dryers, I assume that it does not have adequate drain
lines. Your board needs to review the matter and take action to have the owners
remove the washer or have a plumber correct the drain system.


Q. I am the board president of a condominium association. We have two owners who
are habitually delinquent. We followed your advice for having a strict and rapid
collection policy, and the delinquent accounts have been sent to an attorney. A
claim of lien has been placed on both units. The owners have not responded.

You have always advocated to bite the bullet and foreclose. Do you still
advocate that, given the economic climate?

DS

Fort Myers

A. My suggestion of fast and rapid legal action, including liens and
foreclosure, is to get delinquent units and homes paying as fast as possible. In
today's economy, with the large number of foreclosures, each delinquent account
must be evaluated as to the best way to proceed.

You established a strict and rapid collection policy and, I hope, had it
approved by your attorney. In the past, I have recommended a series of letters
be sent to the owner as the account becomes increasingly past due, then turning
the matter over to the attorney to lien and foreclosure.

Since the statutes have been changed and require a 30-day notice, I recommend a
slightly different policy: send one letter when the account is 10 days past due,
and a certified letter at the 30-day mark. Turn the matter over to your attorney
at the 60-day point.

The benefits of the strict collection policy are twofold - if you make sure
everyone is aware of the policy. Your paying owners will know you are trying to
protect their interests and delinquent owners know that you will take action if
they do not remain current.

Even in today's economy, that action may be swift foreclosure. Remember, the
object is to get delinquent units paying as fast as possible. Say you have a
unit that is being foreclosed on by the mortgage company and you have title to
the unit because you foreclosed first. You have several options (this must be
discussed with your attorney): You can rent the unit to recover the legal costs
and the delinquent amounts, you can contact the bank and see whether it will
take the title and begin to pay the fees, or you can sell the unit, maybe by a
short sale with the bank's approval.

One good thing about foreclosing on a unit or home is that the association will
not be obligated, or suffer damage to its credit rating, if it does not make
mortgage payments. The association is not on the note.

The key to your question is that each case must be evaluated before proceeding
to foreclosure; you must discuss each situation with your attorney.

Richard White is a licensed community association manager. He does not offer
legal opinions; any other questions and comments concerning association
operations can be sent to Richard White, 6039 Cypress Gardens Blvd., No. 201,
Winter Haven FL 33884-4115; or e-mail camquestion@cfl.rr.com

Copyright © 2009, The Tampa Tribune and may not be republished without
permission. E-mail library@tampatrib.com

                             440 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                   December 14, 1996, Saturday, Final Edition

Loan Servicers Get Tough on Late Payments; Some Delinquent Borrowers Face
Barrage of Calls, Foreclosure

Jerry DeMuth, Special to The Washington Post

SECTION: REAL ESTATE; Pg. E01

LENGTH: 907 words


Homeowners who are at least a month behind or consistently late in their
mortgage payments are beginning to face aggressive loan servicers that are
determined to either get them current or to foreclose in as short a time as
possible.

There is a new breed of mortgage servicing companies, all of which operate
nationally, that buy these loans from lenders. The servicers' intent is to wring
profit from the loans, known as "under-performers," or from the properties.

Letters might be sent to delinquent borrowers as often as weekly and phone calls
might be made as often as daily.

Ocwen Federal Bank FSB of West Palm Beach, Fla., makes daily calls to borrowers
who are more than 45 days delinquent, calls every three days to borrowers who
are 31 to 45 days delinquent, and weekly to borrowers who are no more than 30
days delinquent. Letters also are sent out as often as once a week.

"The ideal work-out situation is that which maximizes our return on investment
in the loan," said John Plum, director of business development at the thrift,
which is a major purchaser and servicer.

"These loans need to be more aggressively serviced," said David Ertel, managing
director of BayView Financial Trading Group in Miami. "It's just [having] a
strong collection area and a strategy for maximizing the value of these type of
loans."

"We go after these people aggressively," said Joseph Caiazzo, chief operating
officer of Franklin Credit Management Corp. in New York. "We call them up and
say, 'Either pay or we'll foreclose.' It takes a lot of energy to bring these
loans back to performing."

Officials at Ocwen and Franklin Credit said some borrowers in the Washington
area already have been affected by the tough approach on delinquencies, but no
more so than in other metropolitan areas around the country.

This hardball approach is in great contrast to the way local banks, ever aware
of public relations problems, handle delinquent mortgages, Caiazzo said.

"Banks are part of the community and when they get problems with collections,
they can't play hardball with borrowers," he said.

Some servicers that buy mortgages that are at least three months behind, known
as "non-performing mortgages," make no effort to arrange for borrowers to get
caught up. Instead, they want to foreclose on the homes and sell the properties
as quickly as state laws permit because investors in the loans get paid from the
sale proceeds, with the servicer getting whatever is left.

"The better the servicing, the more equity the servicer will get," said Justin
Ventura, director of residential mortgage-backed securities at the rating agency
Fitch Investors Service.

Some loans have greater value for these servicers when they go into foreclosure
than if they were made current. If borrower equity is high in a "sub-performing
mortgage," which is a mortgage with a history of late payments, "proceeds
realized in liquidation should be greater than those generated by the borrower
curing or prepaying the mortgage loan," Fitch Investors said in a report.

When rating non-performing mortgage-backed securities, Fitch wants to know how
much time will lapse before investors will see recoveries, something that is
"crucial," Ventura said.

Similarly, Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Co. wants a servicer to be "a no-nonsense
institution" that has a "demonstrated ability to liquidate the property and to
control the expenses of foreclosure and liquidation," said Henry Hayssen, vice
president responsible for all non-performing ratings.

But while servicers that want to make their mortgages current act aggressively,
they will be flexible, working out repayment plans that might allow borrowers to
take as long as 18 months to catch up. If a borrower fails to honor the terms of
a work-out plan, however, chances are the servicer will move quickly to
foreclose.

"There is no option which we will not consider," Ocwen's Plum said. "We offer
modification, forbearance plans, deeds in lieu, shortfall payoffs, full payoffs
and occasionally will pay cash for keys."

"We try to bring the loans current first by trying to get the borrowers up on a
payment schedule," said John Devine, vice president in charge of servicing at
Franklin Credit. "We'll extend the loan out for the number of months they are
behind."

Even while developing a work-out plan with a delinquent borrower, these
servicers are preparing to start foreclosure action immediately should the
work-out fail.

At the same time consultants are trying to resolve the status of the loans,
Ocwen's Plum said, delinquent loans also are assigned to its foreclosure
department. This allows the bank to negotiate from a position of strength, he
said, and a borrower who "truly wants to stay in the home" generally will begin
repaying the loan as agreed.

For Ocwen, that time frame ranges from one month to six months.

Players in the under-performing market see 1997 as an even busier and more
profitable year than 1996.

"A new pool of foreclosures will be occurring in the coming months. More product
will be around in '97," said Victor F. Russell, a managing principal at Moore,
Morgan & Russell Advisors of Carrollton, Tex., a buyer of under-performing
mortgages. An expected record-high number of bankruptcy filings in 1996, he said
indicated that "there's a vast pool of clients for the product. More investors
and servicers are stepping up to the plate."

                          The Monitor (McAllen, Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             March 26, 2013 Tuesday

McAllen school board candidate addresses back taxes

BYLINE: Andrew Kreighbaum, The Monitor, McAllen, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 565 words


March 26--MCALLEN -- Like any candidate for public office, Joe E. Garcia started
his campaign for McAllen school board with a laundry list of items to tackle --
appointing a campaign treasurer, contacting supporters, printing advertisements
and, weeks after filing for the race, paying his delinquent taxes to the
district.

Nearly three weeks after filing a ballot application for the school board, the
local attorney paid a property tax bill to the district for his South Edinburg
home for more than $21,500. The next day, he sent a letter to current trustees
in an attempt to "clarify any misunderstanding" regarding the status of his
property tax account with the district.

Garcia advised the board that he and his wife are "fully paid and are current on
all property taxes due to McAllen I.S.D."

But public records kept by the Hidalgo County Tax Office showed this week that
Garcia, who is challenging Place 7 trustee Sam Saldivar Jr., still owed more
than $13,900 in delinquent taxes and penalties and interest due by the end of
March to entities including South Texas College, South Texas ISD and Drainage
District #1.

Asked Monday about the delinquent taxes and letter to board members, he
questioned how The Monitor learned of the letter then said his school district
property taxes were a non-issue because they were paid off before stating the
conversation was off the record.

After receiving a list of delinquent taxes owed to local entities for his
Edinburg residence via email, Garcia said he would not be able to offer a more
thorough response until Tuesday.

Late Monday, the website of the county tax office showed eight payments were
made that day totaling more than $2,900 to the community college, the drainage
district and South Texas ISD. Nearly $11,000 was still owed to Hidalgo County.

Rolando Garza, the chief appraiser at the Hidalgo County Appraisal District,
said his office had one protest letter on file for Garcia's residence. In the
letter, Garcia claimed the appraised value of his property had increased by
nearly 50 percent from 2012 to 2013.

According to tax office records, he owed delinquent taxes dating back to 2008.

The Monitor reported in October that the City of McAllen had filed a lawsuit
against owners of the Wingate Hotel to recoup $191,000 in delinquent taxes. Joe
and Mary Garcia are listed as corporate directors for Sungate Development, the
hotel's parent company.

The case was settled later that month and dismissed in January. McAllen ISD and
Hidalgo County both previously filed lawsuits against Sungate Development.

McAllen school board President Hilda Garza-DeShazo said that having only served
only a few years as a trustee, she could not say if a letter like the one sent
by Garcia to trustees was unusual.

"This is the first time I've sat on the board, so this is the first time I've
ever seen anything like that," she said.

Garza-DeShazo said she would want to address any questions about delinquent
taxes if she were a candidate for the board herself.

"All I can say is if I was in his position, and I had an opponent, I certainly
would want to clear that up," she said.

Andrew Kreighbaum covers education for The Monitor. He can be reached at
andrew@themonitor.com, (956) 683-4472 and on Twitter, @kreighbaum.

www.themonitor.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

                          The Anniston Star (Alabama)

                             April 7, 2009 Tuesday

Anniston Councilman Dawson pays $10K in delinquent taxes

BYLINE: Mike Faulk, The Anniston Star, Ala.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 292 words


Apr. 7--Anniston City Councilman David Dawson paid more than $10,000 in
delinquent taxes Monday on behalf of himself, his wife and a business partner,
according to the Calhoun County revenue commissioner.

Dawson made the payment after a countywide list of those delinquent on their
2008 property tax payments was published in the Sunday edition of The Star.

Dawson said he was delinquent in part because of confusion between him and his
business partner Thomas Harmon, with whom he owns some rental homes and a small
building on Noble Street. The confusion was over whose responsibility it was to
pay the tax on the properties, Dawson said.

"It's really embarrassing," he said. "It's just one of those things that slipped
by us."

Dawson also owed at least $728.60 on property he owns with his wife. Dawson said
the money was owed on two vacant lots he purchased behind his house that he had
thought were included in his other property tax payments.

Attempts to reach Harmon Monday were unsuccessful, but Dawson said neither he
nor his partner has ever knowingly failed to pay their taxes.

"I assure you there's never been a tax, once brought to our attention, that
wasn't paid," he said.

About Mike Faulk

Mike Faulk covers Cleburne, Clay and Randolph counties, environment and
agriculture for The Star. He is a graduate of the University of Alabama.
