                             443 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                   October 05, 1996, Saturday, Final Edition

Condominium Boards Need to Get Tough on Late Fees With Policy of Zero Tolerance

Benny L. Kass

SECTION: REAL ESTATE; Pg. F03; HOUSING COUNSEL

LENGTH: 916 words


Q: I own a town house in a Maryland condominium association. A recent newsletter
advised all the owners that there are more than $ 35,000 in delinquent
condominium fees. When I asked the management, I was told that several of the
unit owners had filed for bankruptcy protection and that the board was
considering waiving late fees if delinquent owners paid up within a certain
period of time.

What can a board do about these delinquent fees? Clearly, such a potential loss
will affect the financial position of our association significantly.

A: It amazes me when I learn how many community associations and their boards of
directors allow unit owners to become seriously delinquent in the payment of the
monthly assessments.

I have seen community associations with delinquencies exceeding $ 100,000; I
have heard of associations in which individual unit owners owe upward of $
25,000.

Even though the three surrounding jurisdictions of Maryland, Virginia and the
District have different laws and collection practices, there are several general
points that can be made.

* Adopt a "zero tolerance" policy. Depending on what your bylaws require, a
board should adopt a policy that if an an owner is delinquent, collection
procedures will begin immediately. I cannot subscribe to the "business as usual"
procedures adopted by many associations and property managers, whereby, if unit
owners are delinquent, they will get several reminder letters over several
months before the matter is turned over for collection.

It is my belief that if a unit owner is one month behind in his or her fees, it
will be difficult to collect. If a unit owner is two months behind, it will be
even harder -- if not impossible -- to collect. And if a unit owner becomes
three or more months delinquent, you are looking at a potential bankruptcy
situation.

Thus, associations should adopt a policy that no unit owner will be exempt from
the zero tolerance policy. Unless your bylaws require otherwise, when the unit
owner is one day delinquent, the matter should be referred to the attorney
handling collection matters for the association.

* The board should adopt a policy that when a unit owner becomes delinquent,
his/her fee for the balance of the fiscal year is automatically accelerated.
Let's look at this example: The fiscal year is January-December. Owner A is
required to pay $ 100 a month in fees. In February the owner becomes delinquent.
The acceleration policy adopted by the board of directors will make it clear
that Owner A now owes the balance of the year's assessments: in this case $
1,100. When a lawsuit is filed, it will be for the full accelerated fee -- and
not just the one-month delinquency.

Such a policy must be authorized by your association bylaws, and it has been my
experience that most documents contain such an acceleration provision. It also
is important to note that before the policy can be adopted formally, it should
be circulated to all owners for comment. Although holding a public association
hearing on such policy is not required in all three jurisdictions, I recommend
that a board take this extra step to make sure that the owners understand not
only the terms of the proposed collection policy, but the importance of keeping
fees current.

* If an owner has a specific problem and is unable to pay the fee, the burden
should be placed on that owner to approach the board, on a confidential basis,
and ask for permission to delay or defer the payments. Any agreement reached
between the board and the individual owner must be in writing, signed by a
member of the board and the owner.

* If the board obtains a court judgment against the owner, immediate steps to
collect on that judgment should begin. Unless the delinquent owner works for the
District government, his or her wages can be garnisheed. Bank accounts can be
attached to satisfy the judgment. At least four times a year, management should
photocopy each owner's payment check and put that information in the files. This
way, if an owner become delinquent, the board may have an easier time trying to
attach assets.

* If the owner files for bankruptcy protection, he or she still is required to
pay all monthly assessments due after the bankruptcy filing. This is permitted
by federal law, and there is no justification for not going after these payments
-- called "post-petition" payments. The board also should file a proof of claim
to receive payments from the bankruptcy trustee for the amounts owed prior to
the filing.

It is unfortunate that a board has to take a hard-line approach to the
collection of delinquencies. The association should be a friendly place to live;
everyone should be neighborly. However, if owners are consistently delinquent,
this can create a serious problem for all other owners. More importantly, if
there are too many delinquencies within an association, mortgage lenders may
decline making loans for future sales -- thereby accelerating the potential
decline of your association. The buck starts and stops with the board.

So my suggestion is simple: Adopt a "zero tolerance" policy and make sure this
message is sent to all owners on a periodic basis.

Benny L. Kass is a Washington attorney. For a free copy of the booklet "A Guide
to Settlement on Your New Home," send a self-addressed stamped envelope to Benny
L. Kass, Suite 1100, 1050 17th St. NW, Washington, D.C. 20036. Readers also may
send questions to him at that address.

LOAD-DATE: October 05, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 1996 The Washington Post


                             444 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                            The Blade (Toledo, Ohio)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            August 31, 2010 Tuesday

Land bank on agenda for county officials

BYLINE: The Blade, Toledo, Ohio

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 819 words


Aug. 31--Lucas County would get a land bank -- the second of its kind in Ohio --
aimed at turning the county's growing inventory of abandoned and foreclosed
property to good use, under legislation pending before the county board of
commissioners this morning.

If the Lucas County Land Reutilization Corp. gets a vote of approval from the
board of commissioners, the

new entity would have the power to acquire, market, and maintain properties that
sit neglected.

The funds to run the land bank would come from an increase in the interest rate
charged to delinquent taxpayers.

Lucas County Treasurer Wade Kapszukiewicz said the new entity would be able to
cut to 90 days the usual process of moving tax-delinquent properties through the
courts and to sheriff's auctions. It now can take up to two years.

"This program does a number of good things," Mr. Kapszukiewicz said. "Most
importantly it's going to raise property values across the board for citizens of
Lucas County whether or not they're facing foreclosure."

The program was approved in largely bipartisan votes in both houses of the
General Assembly and signed by Gov. Ted Strickland this year.

It is modeled after the land bank established in Flint, Mich., and is an
expansion of the program that was begun in Cuyahoga County in 2009.

Under the legislation, the interest rate charged to delinquent property tax
payers would rise to a maximum of 12 percent annually from the current 4 or 5
percent.

The fund is estimated to collect about $1.5 million a year from that source,
which is expected to be added to from grants and revenue from the sales of
property, Mr. Kapszukiewicz said.

Commissioner Pete Gerken said the goal is to clean up abandoned properties that
bring down the values of neighboring parcels.

"What we're looking to do with this is it will shorten the time frame that
houses will be delinquent and hopefully shorten the period of time that they can
do damage to a neighborhood," Mr. Gerken said.

The land bank also would be able to accept properties that are foreclosed as a
result of mortgage default and could accept any of the hundreds of vacant or
abandoned properties that the city has acquired.

The city sells the properties it owns when requested but doesn't have the
resources to market, maintain, or, if needed, demolish the houses it owns,
officials said.

After the commissioners vote on two resolutions, several public events are
planned involving representatives of the Center for Community Progress, of
Washington, Mr. Kapszukiewicz said.

Dan Kildee, who as treasurer of Genesee County, Michigan, where Flint is
located, pioneered the concept of an active land bank in 2002, is scheduled to
address local officials in a briefing at 10:30 a.m. Tuesday in Toledo City
Council chambers in Government Center.

Lucas County Commissioner Ben Konop said he, too, will vote to establish the
land bank, but said it bears close monitoring as it evolves

"There are some issues with it of oversight and accountability to make sure
there's no sweetheart deals to developers," Mr. Konop said.

"It's going to be a pretty sizable pool of funds. It's hard to say what the
results will be. Whatever we're doing now is minimal and it's not working."

Commissioner Tina Skeldon Wozniak could not be reached for comment.

The corporation would be run by a board of five to nine members, to include, by
statute, two county commissioners, the county treasurer as chairman, the mayor
of Toledo, an appointee from Sylvania Township, and someone with real-estate or
development experience.

Mr. Kapszukiewicz said the entity would have a full-time staff of one or two,
compared with 16 on the staff of the Cuyahoga County land bank.

Terry Glazer, chief executive officer of the United North community development
corporation that redevelops declining neighborhoods in North Toledo, said the
additional resources are welcome.

He said his group and others will look to the land bank to help develop
construction and rehabilitation projects in targeted areas rather than in random
vacant lots.

"It's not going to be the sole savior of neighborhoods. It's going to help,
obviously, with vacant property," Mr. Glazer said.

Mr. Kapszukiewicz said the fund probably would build an inventory of a couple
hundred properties initially -- starting Tuesday -- and would market them to
groups or developers who have an end use in mind. He said both Mercy St. Vincent
Medical Center and Toledo Hospital have expressed interest in acquiring
property.

-Tom Troy

To see more of The Blade, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.toledoblade.com. Copyright (c) 2010, The Blade, Toledo, Ohio
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For more information
about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services
(MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com, e-mail services@mctinfoservices.com, or
call 866-280-5210 (outside the United States, call +1 312-222-4544).

                 The Daily Record of Rochester (Rochester, NY)

                           January 9, 2002 Wednesday

Judge chosen to oversee Juvenile Delinquent Court

BYLINE: Jill Miller

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 238 words


In an effort to ease the caseload in the Monroe County Family Court System,
County Court Judge Elma Bellini will supervise a New Family Court Juvenile
Delinquent Court Part.

The New Family Court Juvenile Delinquent Court, part of the Family Court, will
handle all juvenile delinquent cases in Monroe County. Judge Bellini will
supervise the new part for one year after which she will return to county court.

"This new Juvenile Delinquent Court is one of the first in the state," Judge
Bellini explained. "It's a test program and is a way to reduce the caseload of
the family court judges."

Judge Bellini was selected for the assignment because of her experience in
dealing with criminal cases in Monroe County Court. She will handle all juvenile
delinquent cases, such as robbery, involving youths between the ages of 9 and
15.

The goal of the new court is to help eliminate the case load of family court
judges allowing them time to devote their energy to other types of cases.

"Although my heart is county court, I like the opportunity to get the new court
started," Judge Bellini said. "I believe my criminal experience will be of great
value in starting up this new court. I know it will be a challenge but I am sure
it will be one that I can handle."

The court opened its doors on January 2, 2002 and heard its first cases on
January 3.

Judge Bellini was elected to the bench in the November 2000 election.

           Northwest Florida Daily News (Fort Walton Beach, Florida)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            November 8, 2009 Sunday

Delinquent taxes spike in slumping economy

BYLINE: Dusty Ricketts, Northwest Florida Daily News, Fort Walton Beach

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 539 words


Nov. 8--Death and taxes are said to be the only certainties in life, but
nowadays some people are trying to delay the tax part.

As the economy has slumped the past three years, the amount of unpaid and
delinquent taxes in Okaloosa, Santa Rosa and Walton counties has skyrocketed.

From 2006 to 2008, unpaid property taxes in Okaloosa County increased by 226.1
percent. Walton County's numbers increased by 368.6 percent and Santa Rosa
County's went up a staggering 4,555 percent.

"The economy is making it tough on people," said Stan Nichols, Santa Rosa's tax
collector. "And obviously that's the hardest thing I see is someone coming in
here and either fear of losing their property or having to sell something that's
been in the family for a while breaks your heart. Statutorily, I have to do what
Florida Statutes say, but we are seeing an increase in delinquent taxes."

"Certainly, the economy plays into the factor in that people want to wait until
the last minute to pay their bill," Okaloosa County Tax Collector Chris Hughes
said. "So you'll notice even though there are a lot of delinquents on April 1, a
lot of those are paid before June 1 because people know they can wait before a
lien is put on their house."

In addition to the amount of unpaid taxes that have soared, the number of unsold
tax certificates has increased in the past three years. That has been
particularly true in Santa Rosa, where only 3,286 of the county's 7,229
certificates initially were sold this year.

Hughes said tax certificates usually are purchased by large investors seeking a
guaranteed return. In the past, investors purchased certificates on just about
any type of property, but they have become more selective in recent years.

"They do a lot of research to try to figure out if you're the type of person
that's going to pay your taxes or not pay them," Hughes said.

Taxes are due April 1 of each year, but are not considered delinquent until June
1. At that time, the counties host certificate sales, which get the counties
their money and the investors liens on the properties.

After the lien has been purchased, the property owner has two years to pay off
the back taxes, including interest, or risk having his or her property sold at
auction.

Tax certificates not purchased by investors go back to the county, which will
begin collecting an automatic 18 percent interest on the delinquent taxes.

"Based on the trend we've had the past three years, it looks like that number
will probably increase next year," said Rhonda Skipper, Walton County's tax
collector. "It just depends on how many people decide to pay their taxes
voluntarily.

"We certainly hope it gets better, but I have no way of foretelling the future,
unfortunately," she added. "I wish I could tell you we're on the uphill swing."

To see more of the Northwest Florida Daily News or to subscribe to the
newspaper, go to http://www.nwfdailynews.com. Copyright (c) 2009, Northwest
Florida Daily News, Fort Walton Beach Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune
Information Services. For reprints, email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call
800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The
Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

Internal Revenue Service: REVENUE OFFICER 14CW3-SBB1428-1169-13-CG

LENGTH: 2703  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of Personnel Management has issued the following job announcement:

Job Title:REVENUE OFFICER

Department:Department Of The Treasury

Agency:Internal Revenue Service

Job Announcement Number:14CW3-SBB1428-1169-13-CG
SALARY RANGE:
 $82,642.00 to $119,668.00 / Per Year
OPEN PERIOD:
 Monday, June 23, 2014 to Monday, July 07, 2014

 GS-1169-13

 Full Time - Permanent

13

 9 vacancies in the following location(s):
Little Rock, AR
El Segundo, CA
Glendale, CA

More Locations  (13)
WHO MAY APPLY:
 Current IRS employees on a Career or Career Conditional appt. in the
competitive service
SECURITY CLEARANCE:
 Public Trust - Background Investigation
SUPERVISORY STATUS:
 No
JOB SUMMARY:

About the Agency

WHAT DOES A REVENUE OFFICER DO? As a Revenue Officer you will be responsible for
collecting delinquent accounts, securing delinquent tax returns and determining
actions necessary to bring taxpayers into full compliance. In this position, the
cases assigned involve taxpayers and taxpaying entities with high income levels
from diversified sources including substantial foreign income and assets. You
will execute all procedures and processes consistent with the protection of
taxpayer rights afforded by law and in a manner than ensures the honesty and
integrity of the service.
WHAT IS THE SB/SE DIVISION?The Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE) Division
provides examinations and taxpayer education services for about 7 million small
businesses and upwards of 33 millions self-employed and supplemental income
taxpayers. SB/SE taxpayers generally have higher incomes than most taxpayers,
need to file twice as many tax forms, and generally need to rely more on paid
tax preparers and the taxpayer education outreach activities of the IRS.

Positions are located in SB/SE, Collections.  Locations are listed under
Qualifications Required.

**PLEASE READ PRIOR TO APPLYING TO THIS POSITION** When applying for this
position, please consider each location before selecting.  If you are selelcted
for a position which requires relocation, you are responsible to relocate at
your own expense and report on the negotiated start date.
TRAVEL REQUIRED

Occasional Travel
    Travel locally and/or overnight approximately one to five days per month

RELOCATION AUTHORIZED

No

KEY REQUIREMENTS

Please refer to "Conditions of Employment."
    Click "Print Preview" to review the entire announcement before applying.

DUTIES:


As a Revenue Officer you will:

Collect delinquent tax and secure delinquent returns from taxpayers who have not
resolved their obligations.
    Conduct interviews with taxpayers and/or their representatives in different
environments such as the business location, residence or office as part of the
investigative process.
    Provide guidance on a wide range of financial problems to assist the
taxpayer in developing a plan of action to resolve all delinquencies.
    Analyze sophisticated financial statements/records that include balance
sheets, income statements and profit and loss statements.
    Search public records, tax returns, and financial and credit information to
locate distrainable assets.
    Perform complex credit and financial analysis and evaluation of assets on
casework involving actions.
    Recognize novel and complex issues that often arise in taking appropriate
enforcement action such as suits, seizures and injunctive relief actions.
    Compose complex correspondence, technical reports, research, affidavits,
statements and testimony necessary to support complex or sophisticated
collection action in court cases to Appeals and Criminal Investigation.

WHERE CAN I FIND OUT MORE ABOUT OTHER IRS CAREERS? If you want to find out more
about IRS careers, visit us on the web at www.jobs.irs.gov

QUALIFICATIONS REQUIRED:


You must meet the following requirements by the closing date of this
announcement.

GS-13 LEVEL: You must have 1 year of specialized experience at a level of
difficulty and responsibility equivalent to the GS-12 grade level in the Federal
service. Specialized experience demonstrating the ability to: Collect delinquent
Federal taxes and securing delinquent returns; Conduct investigations of alleged
criminal violations of Federal tax statutes and making recommendations for
criminal prosecutions and civil penalties; Perform internal audits,
administrative, or management duties directly related to the collection of
Federal taxes; Furnish taxpayer assistance and information to the general public
or determine, redetermine, or advise of liability for Federal taxes.
At this level, you must demonstrate a comprehensive knowledge of the Internal
Revenue Code and related regulations and procedures pertaining to income,
estate, gift, employment, or excise taxes; knowledge of a wide range of
investigative or analytical techniques and methods; Knowledge of accounting
practices and methods sufficient to analyze and evaluate financial
statements/records (e.g., balance sheets, profit and loss statements, income
statements, bank records, etc.) sufficient to locate distrainable assets,
determine ability to pay, and trace and follow income streams; Specialized
knowledge of tax and business laws, regulations, judicial processes, laws of
evidence, revenue rulings, precedent decisions, etc.; Ability to meet and deal
effectively with taxpayers and/or their representatives, who may be
uncooperative or hostile; and the Ability to write clear and concise examination
reports.

Additional Specialized Experience:

To be qualifying, your experience must be sufficient to demonstrate the ability
to: Conduct collection activities using a variety of Collection tools such as
levy, Notice of Federal Tax Lien, seizure, and suits involving multi-layered
and/or multi-entity nominee/alter-ego investigations. Comprehensive knowledge of
business laws, practices, judicial processes, rules of evidence, court decisions
and relationship between Federal and State laws. Secure delinquent returns using
a variety of tools such as summons and preparing substitute for returns per IRC
6020(b); use computer systems to capture information secured and to aid in the
collection of Federal taxes or delinquent Federal tax returns and to conduct
research such as locator services, credit bureau reports, and real estate
programs; prepare the assembly of trust fund recovery penalty files, suit and
seizure packages and lien activity packages including discharge, subordination,
and withdrawal as well as drafting special condition liens.

-The experience may have been gained in either the public or private sector. One
year of experience refers to full-time work; part-time work is considered on a
prorated basis.
-To ensure full credit for your work experience, please indicate dates of
employment by month/year, and indicate number of hours worked per week, on your
resume.

In addition to the above requirements, you must meet the following, if
applicable:
You must have been at the GS-12 level for 52 weeks (time-in-grade requirement).

                        Las Cruces Sun-News (New Mexico)

                              July 1, 2005 Friday

County treasurer working to collect delinquent taxes

BYLINE: Diana M. Alba

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. 6A

LENGTH: 444 words


Sun-News reporter

Dona Ana County could have given up about $635,000 to the state of New Mexico
today, the start of the state's fiscal year.

That's the amount of interest and penalties accrued on delinquent property taxes
from 2002. The county turns over delinquent taxes to the state after three
years, but when that happens, it doesn't get to keep the interest or penalties
on those taxes, said County Treasurer Jim Schoonover.

Schoonover, who took office in January, said his office has been working to draw
in delinquent taxes from 2002, so the county won't lose the interest and
penalties to the state. The treasurer's office has collected $595,000 of the
penalties and interest owed, so the state will get about $40,000.

"There was very little tax collection done before January," Schoonover said.

Part of the reason so many taxes were delinquent was because addresses for
taxpayers hadn't been updated, Schoonover said. To deal with this problem, he
hired a temporary employee, who worked to send out notices and update addresses.

"We had 10-15 bins of returned mail," he said, but the temporary employee worked
to track down correct addresses.

Tax rates for county residents decrease when a greater proportion of property
owners pays their taxes, Schoonover said, which is an important reason to ensure
taxes get collected.

"We want to work very hard to make our taxes fair for everyone," he said.

County Manager Brian Haines said money from penalties and interest on delinquent
taxes goes into the county's general fund, which the board of commissioners uses
for various purposes, such as funding law enforcement and the clerk's office.

"Every little bit helps to support these operations," he said. "In general it's
pretty evident to me that Jim is putting more effort into collecting taxes that
I've seen in previous years."

Dona Ana County Commissioner Kent Evans, a Republican, said he has been pleased
with Schoonover's performance so far.

"I think he's highly qualified for the position, and I think he's doing a great
job," Evans said. "I'm just really impressed."

Commissioner Oscar Vasquez-Butler, a Democrat, said it's possible some credit
for the success in the treasurer's office could be attributable to the former
treasurer, David Gutierrez.

"I'm not trying to discredit (Schoonover)," he said. "If he's doing a good job,
great < that's his job."

Diana M. Alba can be reached at dalba@lcsun-news.com

Unpaid tax penalties

Unpaid tax penalties and interest turned over to the state:

2004: $165,000

2003: $90,000

2002: $210,000

2001: $302,000

Source: Dona Ana County treasurer's office

                                  COURIER-MAIL

                              June 12, 1989 Monday

HESITANT 'DELINQUENT' SLOWLY FINDS HIS NICHE

SOURCE: QNP

BYLINE: GAGLIARDI J

LENGTH: 866 words


Hesitant "delinquent' slowly finds his niche By JASON GAGLIARDI AMERICAN actor
Charlie Schlatter says he was ""a little hesitant" about starring opposite Kylie
Minogue in the film The Delinquents. Charlie said he had never seen Kylie act
before and was not sure what to expect when he arrived for The Delinquents'
first rehearsal. ""But as soon as we started doing rehearsals, I felt real
secure and I knew it was going to be great," he said. ""Kylie's fantastic. One
of the best actresses I have worked with, actually. ""I think when people see
this film they are going to be full from eating a lot of words." The Delinquents
is scheduled for national release on December 26. With filming almost over,
Charlie said he was disappointed he had not had time to see more of Australia.
He plans to return for a holiday as soon as he can. ""I got to go to Noosa for a
night, which was nice, except it rained. I got to go to Melbourne for a night,
which was nice, except it rained," he said. ""This film is interrupting my
Australian vacation, to tell you the truth. ""But I'd love to come back. I'm
going to come back for a month if I can and just travel around to Port Douglas
and maybe outback somewhere." In The Delinquents _ shot mainly in Maryborough
and Brisbane _ Charlie plays Brownie Hansen, a 1950s bodgie. ""I just play this
kid in the '50s who falls in love," Charlie said. ""He goes through a lot of
changes; it's a real coming-of-age story about a kid trying to find himself and
find his little niche in the world. ""It's nice, it's real romantic." Charlie
said he had been spared the ordeal of trying to master an Australian accent for
the film. ""I play an American, which I think adds to my character," he said.
""He's real lonely and I think his being an American in Australia is quite
lonely for him and seems to isolate the character." Charlie was born and raised
in New Jersey. He said he started acting while at high school to impress a
girlfriend. His parents persuaded him to attend New York's Ithaca College, where
he majored in musical theatre and appeared in West Side Story, The Boyfriend and
Grease. He is also an accomplished drummer and pianist and writes his own songs.
Charlie made his film debut as Michael J. Fox's younger brother in Bright
Lights, Big City and has since starred in 18 Again with George Burns and in the
Touchstone film Heartbreak Hotel, due for video release in Brisbane on June 29.
""I've been real fortunate with the people I've worked with," Charlie said. ""I
think once you start off with a good crew, with a good cast and everything,
people see you in that league and they want to match you with other people of
the same calibre." Charlie has not performed on stage in the past few years,
having moved to Los Angeles after beginning his acting career. ""It's kind of
tough in the States because once you get locked in the one industry, they kind
of want to keep you there," he said. But he hopes to return to the stage later
this year. ""What I like about theatre is that it's live and it's right there,"
Charlie said. ""But I like the whole film process _ doing little bits here and
there, keeping in mind the whole set design and what's going to happen and
actually having a project that's going to last for a lifetime rather than just
having to live for the moment." When he returns to America, Charlie said he
would begin shooting a new television series, The Pink Panther, which he would
own with MGM and United Artists. ""It's like a cross between Who Framed Roger
Rabbit, The Purple Rose of Cairo and Harvey _ it's got all those weird
elements," he said. Charlie said his hobby was stand-up comedy and as the
interview progressed, he seemed unable to resist honing his skills. Were there
any actors he looked up to? ""The tall ones. Gene Hackman is very tall, I always
look up to him at parties." Did he have something original to contribute to
film? ""No. Nothing at all. I feel as though I'm just a run-of-the-mill grade-B
actor who is very fortunate to be alive." Did he have any ambitions to take his
music further? ""I'm going to take my stereo back to the States." Seriously?
""In Heartbreak Hotel I play guitar and I have to sing. After that movie, RCA
picked up the soundtrack and approached me and they wanted me to do an album
with them. ""At the time we left it on the back burner because I didn't feel I
was ready. I just want to wait until I feel like I have my songs where I want
them to be, until I think they're ready. ""It's very hard for
actors-turned-musicians in the States because Americans tend to puke on that
kind of idea _ "Oh he's an actor, how can he be a musician?' ""It's just the
opposite for musicians who come into movies. People love that. If Billy Joel was
starring in a movie people would fly to see him." When the time was right,
Charlie said he would ""jump at the chance" to record an album. Until then, his
fans will have to content themselves with seeing him on the silver screen.
CHARLIE SCHLATTER . . . ""I think when people see this film they are going to be
full from eating a lot of words." USE QUOTE ONLY IF NEEDED Kylie's fantastic.
One of the best actresses I have worked with

                             450 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                            Mortgage Servicing News

                                    May 2012

Shadow Inventory Stays Flat

BYLINE: Amilda Dymi

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 26 Vol. 16 No. 6

LENGTH: 503  words


No matter how one looks at the current residential shadow inventory data it does
not indicate improvements, even though the overall numbers remained flat at 1.6
million units as of January 2012, according to CoreLogic.

Findings show that despite a total of 3 million distressed sales since January
2009, "the period when home prices were declining at their fastest rate," the
shadow inventory in January 2012 is at the same level as it was in January 2009.

Moreover, it is "approximately four times higher" than its low point of about
380,000 properties it reached at the peak of the housing bubble in mid-2006.

According to CoreLogic's chief economist Mark Fleming, the shadow inventory
persists at almost flat levels regardless of signs of improvement in many other
housing market metrics.

The shadow inventory, or the number of homes not yet in the foreclosure process,
"is approximately half of the size of all visible inventory listings" as for
every two homes available for sale, there is one home in the "shadows."

The best news appears to be the fact that the shadow inventory is almost at the
same level as it was in October 2011, or equal to a six-month supply, that
represents half of the 3 million properties currently seriously delinquent, in
foreclosure or REO.

Another finding: While the overall supply of homes in the shadow inventory is
declining versus a year ago, the declines are being driven by higher balance
loans.

Currently the highest concentration of shadow inventory is for loans with loan
balances between $100,000 and $125,000. But that may change, too, since the
number of loans with balances of $75,000 or less, that are part of the shadow
inventory, increased 3% compared to a year ago.

As expected, most of the inventory is concentrated in states with long
foreclosure timelines and those more severely impacted by price declines such as
Florida, California and Illinois, which account for over one-third of the total,
followed by New York, Texas and New Jersey.

Short sales and foreclosure sales helped offset some of the flow into the shadow
inventory of new loans that are 90 days or more delinquent, or seriously
delinquent.

Year-over-year the shadow inventory decreased from 1.8 million units in January
2011 to 1.6 million this January, "offset by the roughly equal flow of
distressed sales" seen in some hard-hit markets were the demand for REO and
distressed property is now outstripping supply, according to Anand Nallathambi,
president and CEO for CoreLogic.

Of the 1.6 million properties currently in the shadow inventory 800,000 units
are seriously delinquent, 410,000 are in some stage of foreclosure and 400,000
are already in REO.

Year-over-year the total percent of borrowers who were 60 days or more
delinquent-irrespective of delinquency status today-increased to 15.5% in
January 2012, up from 14.3%. Also borrowers who passed the 60-day delinquency
mark in the past but were "cured" and are now current on their payments
increased to 7.2% in January 2012 up from 5.7% a year ago.

URL: http://www.mortgageservicingnews.com/

LOAD-DATE: May 1, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newsletter

JOURNAL-CODE: MSN


                        Copyright 2012 SourceMedia, Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                             451 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                       Austin American-Statesman (Texas)

                              June 2, 2014 Monday
                                 Final Edition

Yes, some federal workers late with taxes

BYLINE: W. Gardner Selby American-Statesman Staff

SECTION: METRO; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 403 words


Conservative activist Michael Quinn Sullivan stirred our interest with this
tweet: "From the 'Do As I Say Not As I Do' department: federal employees owe
$3.3 billion in back taxes."

The leader of Empower Texans told us he based this statement on something he
read in an Associated Press news article, posted online May 22. The AP report
opened: "From workers in Congress and at the White House to active-duty troops,
more than 318,000 federal employees and retirees owe just over $3.3 billion in
back taxes, the Internal Revenue Service said."

The described tally, effective as of Sept. 30, included 714 of about 17,000 U.S.
Senate and House employees, according to IRS officials, though the data behind
its report did not indicate whether members of Congress were delinquent on
taxes. The story said 36 of nearly 1,800 workers at the White House and its
agencies owed taxes, though again there was no detailed breakdown.

To our inquiry, a Washington, D.C.-based IRS spokesman, Bruce Friedland, emailed
the relevant agency chart presenting the number of delinquent workers and
retirees for about 100 federal agencies.

According to the chart, that $3.3 billion owed was a slight decrease from the
$3.38 billion owed by federal workers and retirees a year earlier.

The share of delinquent workers and retirees inched up from 3.2 percent to
nearly 3.3 percent of all people in those categories, based on 318,462 of nearly
9.8 million total retirees and employees, the chart says.

Then again, federal workers and retirees appear to be less widely delinquent
than taxpayers in general. The AP story said the IRS estimates at least 8.7
percent of all taxpayers are delinquent.

Sullivan, nudged about this aspect, emailed: "So what?... Federal employees
should owe zero."

Our ruling:

Sullivan tweeted: "From the 'Do As I Say Not As I Do' department: federal
employees owe $3.3 billion in back taxes."

That dollar total is correct, though this message didn't acknowledge that the
3-plus percent of delinquent federal employees and retirees compares with nearly
9 percent of taxpayers in general.

Basically, fewer federal employees fail to pony up on time.

We rate this claim, which lacks this clarifying information, as Mostly True.

Contact W. Gardner Selby

at 512-445-3644.

Twitter: @gardnerselby

@politifacttexas

Michael Quinn Sullivan
  Statement: "From the 'Do As I Say Not As I Do' department: federal employees
owe $3.3 billion in back taxes."


LOAD-DATE: June 2, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved


                             452 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           Morris Daily Herald, Ill.

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            March 16, 2011 Wednesday

Payments not getting from bank to village on time

BYLINE: Jo Ann Hustis, Morris Daily Herald, Ill.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 455 words


March 16--SENECA -- Commissioner Mark Victor is trying to wade through a water
billing problem, and would welcome a few suggestions.

Or, maybe it's a postal problem. Whichever, he'd like to find a solution.

"The village staff is taking a ton of heat for it," Victor told the council at
the bi-monthly meeting Tuesday evening while explaining an apparent delinquent
water bill issue that first made waves two billing periods ago.

Water users in Seneca have the option of paying their water bills in person
during business hours at the village hall, or depositing their payment in the
24-hour drop-off box at the building. Some customers take advantage of a third
option, and pay the bill at the local bank. The bank mails the receipts to the
village hall.

Bills not paid by the deadline incur a penalty. Of the 900 municipal water
customers in the village, about 30 were dunned for late payment two months ago,
and 15 last month. The hang-up developed when the customers insisted they had
paid their bills on time at the bank.

"The problem seemed to be the time between the bank and the Post Office," Victor
said, noting an apparent snafu when the automatic zip code reader sent the first
batch of receipts to Philadelphia, Pa., instead of a couple blocks across town
to the village hall.

By the time the receipts were redirected from Pennsylvania to Seneca, they were
delinquent. The penalty for a delinquent water bill is $2.70 per month.

Not that it's a lot of money, Victor said. The problem is in erasing the penalty
on one batch of bills that appear delinquent, which means the same would have to
be done on all delinquent bills for that month's billing period.

"It was a small problem at the beginning, but now it's getting big," he said.
"The bank tells us the customers are making their payments on time. But the
transition is sometimes 10 days from the bank to the Post Office to us."

Allowing three more days before the bill becomes delinquent would dam up the
village's automatic billing cycle system, Victor noted. Also, the village does
not accept on-line payments on bills.

Doing so would be too costly for small villages like Seneca, he said.

However, the problem might solve itself if the Postal System carries out its
proposal to shutter Post Offices in many small communities across the nation in
an austerity move.

"So, the problem of the bills might be out of our hands in a little while
anyway," Victor noted.

To see more of The Morris Daily Herald, go to http://www.morrisdailyherald.com.
Copyright (c) 2011, Morris Daily Herald, Ill. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune
Information Services. For more information about the content services offered by
McClatchy-Tribune Information Services (MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com.

                                US Official News

                          September 12, 2013 Thursday

Arizona: SENATE BILL 1369

LENGTH: 2089  words

DATELINE: Phoenix


Office of the Legislative, The State of Arizona has issued the following bill:

AN ACT

amending sections 8-382, 8-409, 13-4401 and 13-4430, Arizona Revised Statutes;
relating to victims' rights.

(TEXT OF BILL BEGINS ON NEXT PAGE)


Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Arizona:

Section 1.  Section 8-382, Arizona Revised Statutes, is amended to read:

8-382.  Definitions

In this article, unless the context otherwise requires:

1.  "Accused" means a juvenile who is referred to juvenile court for committing
a delinquent act.

2.  "Appellate proceeding" means any contested matter before the state court of
appeals, the state supreme court, a federal court of appeals or the United
States supreme court.

3.  "Arrest" means the actual custodial restraint or temporary custody of a
person.

4.  "Court" means the juvenile division of the superior court when exercising
its jurisdiction over children in any proceeding relating to delinquency.

5.  "Crime victim advocate" means a person who is employed or authorized by a
public entity or a  private entity that receives public funding primarily to
provide counseling, treatment or other supportive assistance to crime victims.

6.  "Custodial agency" means any law enforcement officer or agency, a sheriff, a
county juvenile detention center, the department of juvenile corrections or a
secure mental health facility that has custody of a person who is arrested or in
custody for a delinquent or incorrigible offense.

7.  "Delinquency proceeding" means any hearing, argument or other matter that is
scheduled or held by a juvenile court judge, commissioner or hearing officer and
that relates to an alleged or adjudicated delinquent offense.

8.  "Delinquent" means a child who is adjudicated to have committed a delinquent
act.

9.  "Delinquent act" means an act to which this article applies pursuant to
section 8[#x2011]381.

10.  "Detention hearing" means the accused's initial appearance before the court
to determine release before adjudication.

11.  "Final disposition" means the ultimate termination of the delinquency
proceeding by a court, including dismissal, acquittal, transfer to adult court
or imposition of a disposition after an adjudication for a delinquent offense.

12.  "Immediate family" means a victim's spouse, parent, child, sibling,
grandparent or lawful guardian.

13.  "Juvenile defendant" means a juvenile against whom a petition is filed
seeking to have the juvenile adjudicated delinquent.

14.  "Lawful representative" means a person who is designated by the victim or
appointed by the court and who will act in the best interests of the victim.

15.  "Postadjudication release" means release on probation, intensive probation,
work furlough, community supervision or home detention, release on conditional
liberty pursuant to section 41[#x2011]2818 by the department of juvenile
corrections or any other permanent, conditional or temporary release from
confinement, discharge or completion of commitment by the department of juvenile
corrections, a sheriff, a municipal jail, a juvenile detention center, a
residential treatment facility or a secure mental health facility.

16.  "Postadjudication review hearing" means a hearing that is held in open
court and that involves a request by the juvenile for review of a disposition.

17.  "Postarrest release" means the discharge of the accused from confinement.

18.  "Release" means no longer in the custody of the custodial agency and
includes transfer from one custodial agency to another custodial agency.

19.  "Rights" means any right granted to the victim by the laws of this state.

20.  "Victim" means a person against whom the delinquent act was committed, or
if the person is killed or incapacitated, the person's spouse, parent, child,
grandparent or sibling, any other person related to the person by consanguinity
or affinity to the second degree or any other lawful representative of the
person, except if the person or the person's spouse, parent, child, grandparent,
sibling, other person related to the person by consanguinity or affinity to the
second degree or other lawful representative is in custody for an offense or is
the accused.

Sec. 2.  Section 8-409, Arizona Revised Statutes, is amended to read:

8-409.  Consultation between crime victim advocate and victim; privileged
information; exception

A.  A crime victim advocate shall not disclose as a witness or otherwise any
communication except compensation or restitution information between the
advocate and made by or with the victim, including any communication made to or
in the presence of others, unless the victim consents in writing to the
disclosure.

B.  Unless the victim consents in writing to the disclosure, a crime victim
advocate shall not disclose records, notes, documents, correspondence, reports
or memoranda, except compensation or restitution information, that contain
opinions, theories or other information made while advising, counseling or
assisting the victim or that are based on the communication between
communications made by or with the victim and the advocate, including
communications made to or in the presence of others.

C.  The communication is not privileged if the crime victim advocate knows that
the victim will give or has given perjured testimony or if the communication
contains exculpatory material.

D.  An accused may make a motion for disclosure of privileged information.  If
the court finds there is reasonable cause to believe the material is
exculpatory, the court shall hold a hearing in camera.  Material that the court
finds is exculpatory shall be disclosed to the accused.

E.  If, with the written or verbal consent of the victim, the crime victim
advocate discloses to the prosecutor or a law enforcement agency any
communication between the victim and the crime victim advocate or any records,
notes, documents, correspondence, reports or memoranda, the prosecutor or law
enforcement agent shall disclose the material to the accused's attorney only if
the information is otherwise discoverable exculpatory.

F.  Notwithstanding subsections A and B, if a crime victim advocate is employed
or authorized by a prosecutor's office, the advocate may disclose information to
the prosecutor with the oral consent of the victim.

Sec. 3.  Section 13-4401, Arizona Revised Statutes, is amended to read:

13-4401.  Definitions

In this chapter, unless the context otherwise requires:

1.  "Accused" means a person who has been arrested for committing a criminal
offense and who is held for an initial appearance or other proceeding before
trial.

2.  "Appellate proceeding" means any contested matter before the state court of
appeals, the state supreme court, a federal court of appeals or the United
States supreme court.

3.  "Arrest" means the actual custodial restraint of a person or the person's
submission to custody.

4.  "Court" means all state, county and municipal courts in this state.

5.  "Crime victim advocate" means a person who is employed or authorized by a
public entity or a  private entity that receives public funding primarily to
provide counseling, treatment or other supportive assistance to crime victims.

6.  "Criminal offense" means conduct that gives a peace officer or prosecutor
probable cause to believe that one of the following has occurred:

(a)  A felony.

(b)  A misdemeanor involving physical injury, the threat of physical injury or a
sexual offense.

7.  "Criminal proceeding" means any hearing, argument or other matter that is
scheduled by and held before a trial court but does not include any deposition,
lineup, grand jury proceeding or other matter that is not held in the presence
of the court.

8.  "Custodial agency" means any law enforcement officer or agency, a sheriff or
municipal jailer, the state department of corrections or a secure mental health
facility that has custody of a person who is arrested or in custody for a
criminal offense.

9.  "Defendant" means a person or entity that is formally charged by complaint,
indictment or information of committing a criminal offense.

10.  "Final disposition" means the ultimate termination of the criminal
prosecution of a defendant by a trial court, including dismissal, acquittal or
imposition of a sentence.

11.  "Immediate family" means a victim's spouse, parent, child, sibling,
grandparent or lawful guardian.

12.  "Lawful representative" means a person who is designated by the victim or
appointed by the court and who acts in the best interests of the victim.

13.  "Post[#x2011]arrest release" means the discharge of the accused from
confinement on recognizance, bond or other condition.

14.  "Post[#x2011]conviction release" means parole, work furlough, community
supervision, probation if the court waived community supervision pursuant to
section 13[#x2011]603, home arrest or any other permanent, conditional or
temporary discharge from confinement in the custody of the state department of
corrections or a sheriff or from confinement in a municipal jail or a secure
mental health facility.

15.  "Post[#x2011]conviction relief proceeding" means a contested argument or
evidentiary hearing that is held in open court and that involves a request for
relief from a conviction or sentence.

16.  "Prisoner" means a person who has been convicted of a criminal offense
against a victim and who has been sentenced to the custody of the sheriff, the
state department of corrections, a municipal jail or a secure mental health
facility.

17.  "Release" means no longer in the custody of a custodial agency and includes
transfer from one custodial agency to another custodial agency.

18.  "Rights" means any right that is granted to the victim by the laws of this
state.

19.  "Victim" means a person against whom the criminal offense has been
committed, including a minor, or if the person is killed or incapacitated, the
person's spouse, parent, child, grandparent or sibling, any other person related
to the person by consanguinity or affinity to the second degree or any other
lawful representative of the person, except if the person or the person's
spouse, parent, child, grandparent, sibling, other person related to the person
by consanguinity or affinity to the second degree or other lawful representative
is in custody for an offense or is the accused.

Sec. 4.  Section 13-4430, Arizona Revised Statutes, is amended to read:

13-4430.  Consultation between crime victim advocate and victim; privileged
information; exception

A.  A crime victim advocate shall not disclose as a witness or otherwise any
communication except compensation or restitution information between himself and
made by or with the victim, including any communication made to or in the
presence of others, unless the victim consents in writing to the disclosure.

B.  Unless the victim consents in writing to the disclosure, a crime victim
advocate shall not disclose records, notes, documents, correspondence, reports
or memoranda, except compensation or restitution information, that contain
opinions, theories or other information made while advising, counseling or
assisting the victim or that are based on the communication between
communications made by or with the victim and the advocate, including
communications made to or in the presence of others.

C.  The communication is not privileged if the crime victim advocate knows that
the victim will give or has given perjured testimony or if the communication
contains exculpatory evidence.

D.  A defendant may make a motion for disclosure of privileged information.  If
the court finds there is reasonable cause to believe the material is
exculpatory, the court shall hold a hearing in camera.  Material that the court
finds is exculpatory shall be disclosed to the defendant.

E.  If, with the written or verbal consent of the victim, the crime victim
advocate discloses to the prosecutor or a law enforcement agency any
communication between the victim and the crime victim advocate or any records,
notes, documents, correspondence, reports or memoranda, the prosecutor or law
enforcement agent shall disclose such material to the defendant's attorney only
if such information is otherwise discoverable exculpatory.

F.  Notwithstanding subsections A and B, if a crime victim consents either
verbally or in writing, a crime victim advocate may disclose information to
other professionals and administrative support persons that the advocate works
with for the purpose of assisting the advocate in providing services to the
victim and to the court in furtherance of any victim's right pursuant to this
chapter.

For further information please visit: http://www.azleg.gov/

                             454 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        Topeka Capital-Journal (Kansas)

                            October 17, 2014 Friday

Eight downtown properties on S. Kansas Avenue delinquent on taxes

BYLINE: Aly Van Dyke.

aly.vandyke@cjonline.com

LENGTH: 1454 words


Eight properties on S. Kansas Avenue between 3rd and 10th streets are at least
five months delinquent on their 2013 taxes. Combined, the properties owed nearly
$241,000 in back taxes and interest by the end of August.

Adding in other years of delinquencies brings that amount to $620,000.

Six fall in the 700 and 900 blocks of the avenue - right in the middle of the
downtown revitalization effort that to date has pulled in nearly $8 million
between Topeka tax dollars and private funds.

The success of an area depends on the health of the businesses in it, said Edie
Smith, director of marketing and membership for Downtown Topeka Inc. For that
reason, she said, DTI and other partners in the city have worked hard to fill
vacancies - a process that starts by getting the properties out of the hands of
"absentee owners."

Since the start of 2013, 12 buildings along S. Kansas Avenue between 6th and
10th streets have been sold to new local owners, said DTI CEO Vince Frye. Most
of the vacant properties have plans in the works, he said.

Out of town, absentee and delinquent owners along Kansas Avenue, Frye said, soon
will be a thing of the past.

"The people we're working with already realize the great potential for the
future of downtown," Frye said. "We have not been able to finalize anything that
we can make an announcement, but I can tell you there are lots of things that
are being worked at this moment that are very exciting and we think will be
exactly what we want for downtown."

The Topeka Capital-Journal paid $55 for county databases that list property
identification numbers, addresses, owner addresses, property taxes owed and
appraised values. The data reflect delinquencies, with interest, as of Aug. 27.

Top delinquencies

The three properties in the 900 block only show as being delinquent on Aug. 27
for this year's taxes, which were due May 10.

The three in the 700 block, however, have been delinquent since 2011:

- The old Crosby Brothers building. and current home to U.S. Bank, 719 S.
Kansas, delinquent $459,383.77;

- The old Palace Clothing Co. building at 709 S. Kansas, delinquent $94,142.66;
and

- 705 S. Kansas, delinquent $41,855.53.

With another delinquent property at 823 S.E. Quincy, owner Kanza Capital LLC
owed nearly $715,000 in back taxes and interest as of Oct. 9 on just those four
properties.

The time the properties have been delinquent is well within the county's limit
of two years to pursue a tax sale on commercial property. In fact, Kanza Capital
has six properties - those four and another two on S.W. Executive Drive off
Huntoon - on the next list to go to the title company, one of the final steps
toward a county tax sale.

The phone number listed for the company no longer is active, but a statement
from the Kansas Department of Revenue on Aug. 7, 2013, states the department
seized the assets of Kanza Construction and Kanza Services for owing $1.15
million in state sales and withholding taxes.

Company owner Steve Hutchinson bought up the Kansas Avenue properties more than
a decade ago with the intent of restoring and developing the downtown properties
into condominiums, according to Capital-Journal archives. An editorial from 2002
contends renovating the properties "could do a lot toward recapturing the feel
of downtown Topeka in its heyday."

This year alone, Kanza Capital on Aug. 27 owed $264,000 in back taxes and
interest on seven properties.

That is about $9,000 short from the top spot, which again belongs to Topeka
developer Kent Lindemuth. Lindemuth, who filed for bankruptcy near the end of
2012, still has 28 properties registered to his two primary company addresses
for a combined $273,000 in back taxes this year.

Two other property owner addresses had outstanding tax bills of more than
$100,000 as of Aug. 27.

Donna and Perry Marney had 32 delinquent properties, amounting to a total of
$179,308.79 in back taxes.

Reached by telephone Oct. 7 and again Oct. 15, the Marneys indicated they
intended to pay the back taxes before The Topeka Capital-Journal ran this story.

As of Oct. 16, the Marneys had completely paid off nine properties and partially
paid off another, leaving 23 properties delinquent for more than $134,000.

The couple cited several reasons for the delayed payment, including the slow
economy and the fact that half of the property taxes are tied up in escrow with
two banks that don't make tax payments until Dec. 20.

"Obviously we're going to pay them," Donna Marney said. "We're definitely not
people who don't pay our bills."

Perry Marney said he didn't care about most of the remaining properties owed.
The more than $38,700 delinquency at Arbor Valley Senior Home, 6423 S.W. Huntoon
St., will be taken care of once its sale goes through, he said. And 20
properties sit in a development currently caught up in a bankruptcy, so none of
the owners are paying taxes, he said.

Hallmark also topped the list, with $139,986.18 in property taxes and interest
owed. The plant and warehouse, 240 S.E. Madison, was purchased in September 2013
by Industrial Realty Group.

Updated records show the company paid the tax bill Oct. 10 - two days after
first being contacted by The Capital-Journal for this story. A spokeswoman
insisted the records were mistaken.

Interest rate change

Commercial properties can be delinquent two years before the county can start
pursuing a tax sale - though only a small percentage of properties actually make
it that far, Eckert said.

In fact, more than 95 percent of property owners typically pay their taxes on
time - a figure Eckert plans to include in future demand letters, as studies
have shown it leads to quicker repayments.

As of Aug. 27, 5,266 Shawnee County properties were delinquent for a total of
$6.6 million in taxes and interest, county records show.

That compares to one year ago, when some 5,800 properties owed $8.5 million.

The number of delinquent properties has been decreasing the past few years -
something Eckert attributed to the economy.

But that might not be the case going forward, he said.

Lower interest rates on delinquent properties go into effect Jan. 1, 2015, and
could entice more properties to delay their tax payments.

"Tactically, it could be in the better interest of a business to not pay taxes,
because it's cheaper than the bank loan to keep the business going," Eckert
said. "That's not fair to everybody who pays their taxes on time."

The Kansas Legislature last session approved lowering interest rates on
delinquent taxes from 6 percent to 4 percent - lower than the rates for some
commercial loans, Eckert said. Interest rates for properties owing $10,000 or
more will fall from the three-year standard of 12 percent to 10 percent.

The issue, he said, will be a focus of county lobbying firms this legislative
session, he said.

Tax sales

Shawnee County historically has held two tax sales each year, but, this year, it
only has enough properties for one sale, Eckert said.

Shawnee County data show 130 properties - 0.2 percent of the county's 75,000 -
have been delinquent at least two years. Combined, they owe $2 million.

The county can start tax sale action after the property has been delinquent
three years for residential and two years for commercial.

Some commercial properties, however, are delinquent three, four, even seven
years, according to county data.

The primary reason for that is bankruptcies, Eckert said. And some - namely
vacant tracts of land that can't be developed - haven't been acted upon for
strategic reasons.

"We strategically pick properties based on their inherent value," he said. "If
the property won't sell, county taxpayers become the owners."

Every single property of the past six tax sales has sold, he said.

Also, the tax sale process takes time.

More than one year can pass from when owners receive notice their property will
be sent to a title company and when the county files the lawsuit. That primarily
is because the title company's search for all the entities with an interest in
the property takes several months, and the county waits until it has at least
120 properties before filing a suit, Eckert said. Another six to nine months
pass between filing the lawsuit and the actual tax sale, he said.

That gives property owners time to make payments on their properties - they have
to clear at least one year's worth of debt prior to the lawsuit to avoid being
listed. After the lawsuit is filed, Eckert said, they have to pay the total
amount due to avoid their property going to sale.

Ultimately, tax sales are motivated by three factors, he said: To recover taxes,
to secure future taxes and to ensure the property is being kept up.

That, he added, is an important factor in neighborhood health.

LOAD-DATE: October 17, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved


                             455 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                             June 24, 2014 Tuesday

Internal Revenue Service: REVENUE OFFICER 14CW3-SBB1428-1169-13-CG

LENGTH: 2718  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of Personnel Management has issued the following job announcement:

Job Title:REVENUE OFFICER

Department:Department Of The Treasury

Agency:Internal Revenue Service

Job Announcement Number:14CW3-SBB1428-1169-13-CG
SALARY RANGE:
 $82,642.00 to $119,668.00 / Per Year
OPEN PERIOD:
 Monday, June 23, 2014 to Monday, July 07, 2014
SERIES & GRADE:
 GS-1169-13
POSITION INFORMATION:
 Full Time - Permanent
PROMOTION POTENTIAL:
13
DUTY LOCATIONS:
 9 vacancies in the following location(s):
Little Rock, AR View Map
El Segundo, CA View Map
Glendale, CA View Map
Los Angeles, CA View Map
San Bernardino, CA View Map
More Locations  (13)
WHO MAY APPLY:
 Current IRS employees on a Career or Career Conditional appt. in the
competitive service
SECURITY CLEARANCE:
 Public Trust - Background Investigation
SUPERVISORY STATUS:
 No
JOB SUMMARY:

About the Agency

WHAT DOES A REVENUE OFFICER DO? As a Revenue Officer you will be responsible for
collecting delinquent accounts, securing delinquent tax returns and determining
actions necessary to bring taxpayers into full compliance. In this position, the
cases assigned involve taxpayers and taxpaying entities with high income levels
from diversified sources including substantial foreign income and assets. You
will execute all procedures and processes consistent with the protection of
taxpayer rights afforded by law and in a manner than ensures the honesty and
integrity of the service.
WHAT IS THE SB/SE DIVISION?The Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE) Division
provides examinations and taxpayer education services for about 7 million small
businesses and upwards of 33 millions self-employed and supplemental income
taxpayers. SB/SE taxpayers generally have higher incomes than most taxpayers,
need to file twice as many tax forms, and generally need to rely more on paid
tax preparers and the taxpayer education outreach activities of the IRS.

Positions are located in SB/SE, Collections.  Locations are listed under
Qualifications Required.

**PLEASE READ PRIOR TO APPLYING TO THIS POSITION** When applying for this
position, please consider each location before selecting.  If you are selelcted
for a position which requires relocation, you are responsible to relocate at
your own expense and report on the negotiated start date.
TRAVEL REQUIRED

Occasional Travel
    Travel locally and/or overnight approximately one to five days per month

RELOCATION AUTHORIZED

No

KEY REQUIREMENTS

Please refer to "Conditions of Employment."
    Click "Print Preview" to review the entire announcement before applying.

DUTIES:
Back to top

As a Revenue Officer you will:

Collect delinquent tax and secure delinquent returns from taxpayers who have not
resolved their obligations.
    Conduct interviews with taxpayers and/or their representatives in different
environments such as the business location, residence or office as part of the
investigative process.
    Provide guidance on a wide range of financial problems to assist the
taxpayer in developing a plan of action to resolve all delinquencies.
    Analyze sophisticated financial statements/records that include balance
sheets, income statements and profit and loss statements.
    Search public records, tax returns, and financial and credit information to
locate distrainable assets.
    Perform complex credit and financial analysis and evaluation of assets on
casework involving actions.
    Recognize novel and complex issues that often arise in taking appropriate
enforcement action such as suits, seizures and injunctive relief actions.
    Compose complex correspondence, technical reports, research, affidavits,
statements and testimony necessary to support complex or sophisticated
collection action in court cases to Appeals and Criminal Investigation.

WHERE CAN I FIND OUT MORE ABOUT OTHER IRS CAREERS? If you want to find out more
about IRS careers, visit us on the web at www.jobs.irs.gov

QUALIFICATIONS REQUIRED:
Back to top

You must meet the following requirements by the closing date of this
announcement.

GS-13 LEVEL: You must have 1 year of specialized experience at a level of
difficulty and responsibility equivalent to the GS-12 grade level in the Federal
service. Specialized experience demonstrating the ability to: Collect delinquent
Federal taxes and securing delinquent returns; Conduct investigations of alleged
criminal violations of Federal tax statutes and making recommendations for
criminal prosecutions and civil penalties; Perform internal audits,
administrative, or management duties directly related to the collection of
Federal taxes; Furnish taxpayer assistance and information to the general public
or determine, redetermine, or advise of liability for Federal taxes.
At this level, you must demonstrate a comprehensive knowledge of the Internal
Revenue Code and related regulations and procedures pertaining to income,
estate, gift, employment, or excise taxes; knowledge of a wide range of
investigative or analytical techniques and methods; Knowledge of accounting
practices and methods sufficient to analyze and evaluate financial
statements/records (e.g., balance sheets, profit and loss statements, income
statements, bank records, etc.) sufficient to locate distrainable assets,
determine ability to pay, and trace and follow income streams; Specialized
knowledge of tax and business laws, regulations, judicial processes, laws of
evidence, revenue rulings, precedent decisions, etc.; Ability to meet and deal
effectively with taxpayers and/or their representatives, who may be
uncooperative or hostile; and the Ability to write clear and concise examination
reports.

Additional Specialized Experience:

To be qualifying, your experience must be sufficient to demonstrate the ability
to: Conduct collection activities using a variety of Collection tools such as
levy, Notice of Federal Tax Lien, seizure, and suits involving multi-layered
and/or multi-entity nominee/alter-ego investigations. Comprehensive knowledge of
business laws, practices, judicial processes, rules of evidence, court decisions
and relationship between Federal and State laws. Secure delinquent returns using
a variety of tools such as summons and preparing substitute for returns per IRC
6020(b); use computer systems to capture information secured and to aid in the
collection of Federal taxes or delinquent Federal tax returns and to conduct
research such as locator services, credit bureau reports, and real estate
programs; prepare the assembly of trust fund recovery penalty files, suit and
seizure packages and lien activity packages including discharge, subordination,
and withdrawal as well as drafting special condition liens.

-The experience may have been gained in either the public or private sector. One
year of experience refers to full-time work; part-time work is considered on a
prorated basis.
-To ensure full credit for your work experience, please indicate dates of
employment by month/year, and indicate number of hours worked per week, on your
resume.

In addition to the above requirements, you must meet the following, if
applicable:
You must have been at the GS-12 level for 52 weeks (time-in-grade requirement).


Positions to be filled in the following primary locations: 1 vac 3848 W columbus
Dr Tampa, FL; 1 vac 1700 Palm Beach Lakes Blvd W Palm Beach, FL; 1 vac 2283

vac to be filled in either 700 W Capitol Little Rock, AR 11309 Old Hwy 49
Gulfport, MS or 111 E Troy St Ste A Tupelo, MS; 1 vac 225 Green St Fayetteville,
NC; 2 vac to be filled in either 222 N Sepulveda El Segundo, CA 225 W Broadway
Glendale, CA 611 W Sixth St Los Angeles, CA or 290 N. D St San Bernardino, CA

select the Application Status link and then select the more information link for

documentation received.

click Update Application in the vacancy announcement. You must re-select your
resume and/or other documents from your USAJOBS account or your application will
be incomplete.

                                US Official News

                              June 23, 2014 Monday

Internal Revenue Service: REVENUE OFFICER 14CW3-SBB1428-1169-13-CG

LENGTH: 2731  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of Personnel Management has issued the following job announcement:

Job Title:REVENUE OFFICER

Department:Department Of The Treasury

Agency:Internal Revenue Service

Job Announcement Number:14CW3-SBB1428-1169-13-CG
SALARY RANGE:
 $82,642.00 to $119,668.00 / Per Year
OPEN PERIOD:
 Monday, June 23, 2014 to Monday, July 07, 2014
SERIES & GRADE:
 GS-1169-13
POSITION INFORMATION:
 Full Time - Permanent
PROMOTION POTENTIAL:
13
DUTY LOCATIONS:
 9 vacancies in the following location(s):
Little Rock, AR View Map
El Segundo, CA View Map
Glendale, CA View Map
Los Angeles, CA View Map
San Bernardino, CA View Map
More Locations  (13)
WHO MAY APPLY:
 Current IRS employees on a Career or Career Conditional appt. in the
competitive service
SECURITY CLEARANCE:
 Public Trust - Background Investigation
SUPERVISORY STATUS:
 No
JOB SUMMARY:

About the Agency

WHAT DOES A REVENUE OFFICER DO? As a Revenue Officer you will be responsible for
collecting delinquent accounts, securing delinquent tax returns and determining
actions necessary to bring taxpayers into full compliance. In this position, the
cases assigned involve taxpayers and taxpaying entities with high income levels
from diversified sources including substantial foreign income and assets. You
will execute all procedures and processes consistent with the protection of
taxpayer rights afforded by law and in a manner than ensures the honesty and
integrity of the service.
WHAT IS THE SB/SE DIVISION?The Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE) Division
provides examinations and taxpayer education services for about 7 million small
businesses and upwards of 33 millions self-employed and supplemental income
taxpayers. SB/SE taxpayers generally have higher incomes than most taxpayers,
need to file twice as many tax forms, and generally need to rely more on paid
tax preparers and the taxpayer education outreach activities of the IRS.

Positions are located in SB/SE, Collections.  Locations are listed under
Qualifications Required.

**PLEASE READ PRIOR TO APPLYING TO THIS POSITION** When applying for this
position, please consider each location before selecting.  If you are selelcted
for a position which requires relocation, you are responsible to relocate at
your own expense and report on the negotiated start date.
TRAVEL REQUIRED

Occasional Travel
    Travel locally and/or overnight approximately one to five days per month

RELOCATION AUTHORIZED

No

KEY REQUIREMENTS

Please refer to "Conditions of Employment."
    Click "Print Preview" to review the entire announcement before applying.

DUTIES:
Back to top

As a Revenue Officer you will:

Collect delinquent tax and secure delinquent returns from taxpayers who have not
resolved their obligations.
    Conduct interviews with taxpayers and/or their representatives in different
environments such as the business location, residence or office as part of the
investigative process.
    Provide guidance on a wide range of financial problems to assist the
taxpayer in developing a plan of action to resolve all delinquencies.
    Analyze sophisticated financial statements/records that include balance
sheets, income statements and profit and loss statements.
    Search public records, tax returns, and financial and credit information to
locate distrainable assets.
    Perform complex credit and financial analysis and evaluation of assets on
casework involving actions.
    Recognize novel and complex issues that often arise in taking appropriate
enforcement action such as suits, seizures and injunctive relief actions.
    Compose complex correspondence, technical reports, research, affidavits,
statements and testimony necessary to support complex or sophisticated
collection action in court cases to Appeals and Criminal Investigation.

WHERE CAN I FIND OUT MORE ABOUT OTHER IRS CAREERS? If you want to find out more
about IRS careers, visit us on the web at www.jobs.irs.gov

QUALIFICATIONS REQUIRED:
Back to top

You must meet the following requirements by the closing date of this
announcement.

GS-13 LEVEL: You must have 1 year of specialized experience at a level of
difficulty and responsibility equivalent to the GS-12 grade level in the Federal
service. Specialized experience demonstrating the ability to: Collect delinquent
Federal taxes and securing delinquent returns; Conduct investigations of alleged
criminal violations of Federal tax statutes and making recommendations for
criminal prosecutions and civil penalties; Perform internal audits,
administrative, or management duties directly related to the collection of
Federal taxes; Furnish taxpayer assistance and information to the general public
or determine, redetermine, or advise of liability for Federal taxes.
At this level, you must demonstrate a comprehensive knowledge of the Internal
Revenue Code and related regulations and procedures pertaining to income,
estate, gift, employment, or excise taxes; knowledge of a wide range of
investigative or analytical techniques and methods; Knowledge of accounting
practices and methods sufficient to analyze and evaluate financial
statements/records (e.g., balance sheets, profit and loss statements, income
statements, bank records, etc.) sufficient to locate distrainable assets,
determine ability to pay, and trace and follow income streams; Specialized
knowledge of tax and business laws, regulations, judicial processes, laws of
evidence, revenue rulings, precedent decisions, etc.; Ability to meet and deal
effectively with taxpayers and/or their representatives, who may be
uncooperative or hostile; and the Ability to write clear and concise examination
reports.

Additional Specialized Experience:

To be qualifying, your experience must be sufficient to demonstrate the ability
to: Conduct collection activities using a variety of Collection tools such as
levy, Notice of Federal Tax Lien, seizure, and suits involving multi-layered
and/or multi-entity nominee/alter-ego investigations. Comprehensive knowledge of
business laws, practices, judicial processes, rules of evidence, court decisions
and relationship between Federal and State laws. Secure delinquent returns using
a variety of tools such as summons and preparing substitute for returns per IRC
6020(b); use computer systems to capture information secured and to aid in the
collection of Federal taxes or delinquent Federal tax returns and to conduct
research such as locator services, credit bureau reports, and real estate
programs; prepare the assembly of trust fund recovery penalty files, suit and
seizure packages and lien activity packages including discharge, subordination,
and withdrawal as well as drafting special condition liens.

-The experience may have been gained in either the public or private sector. One
year of experience refers to full-time work; part-time work is considered on a
prorated basis.
-To ensure full credit for your work experience, please indicate dates of
employment by month/year, and indicate number of hours worked per week, on your
resume.

In addition to the above requirements, you must meet the following, if
applicable:
You must have been at the GS-12 level for 52 weeks (time-in-grade requirement).
