                             457 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        The Augusta Chronicle (Georgia)

                           October 11, 2006 Wednesday
                                  ALL EDITION

DELINQUENT-TAX VIEWS ARE EXAGGERATED

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. A04

LENGTH: 152 words


Recently, there has been considerable discussion concerning Richmond County's
delinquent taxes and how best to deal with them.

I am in full agreement with those who believe that it is unfair for law-abiding
citizens to pay their taxes while others do not.

However, I am not in agreement with the inference that the budget deficit of
Richmond County relates to delinquent taxes.

I also take issue with the implied idea that delinquent tax collection is
inadequate in Richmond County. Since taking office in 1976, I am extremely proud
to preside over a staff that has increased the overall collection of tax revenue
to its current standard.

The Richmond County Tax Commissioner's Office has collected 99.4 percent of the
property taxes billed through 2005, and we rank in the top 10 percent of
delinquent tax collection rates in Georgia.

Jerry Saul

Augusta

(Editor's note: The writer is Richmond County's tax commissioner.)

LOAD-DATE: October 12, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: LETTER

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


               Copyright 2006 Southeastern Newspapers Corporation
                              All Rights Reserved


                             458 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                 The Times Leader (Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                          February 24, 2016 Wednesday

Luzerne County sells 18 tax-delinquent properties

BYLINE: Jennifer Learn-Andes, The Times Leader, Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 618 words


Feb. 24--Luzerne County officials unloaded 18 tax-delinquent properties Tuesday,
including a dilapidated apartment building on busy Northampton Street in
Wilkes-Barre.

The properties were festering in the repository, a pool of parcels that did not
sell at past back-tax auctions. The county is liable for repository properties
while the owners of record have abandoned them and stopped paying real estate
taxes, officials say.

Luzerne County has more than 1,000 repository properties -- more than any of the
11 other similarly sized third-class counties in Pennsylvania, records show.

The county and other taxing bodies approved 87 repository sales last year.

The apartment building in the batch of 18 sold this week was purchased by Helena
Laurency for $888.

Laurency, who is listed as director of Laurency Optimal Personal Care Agency in
Wilkes-Barre, said Wednesday she won't be prepared to discuss her plans for the
new acquisition for several weeks.

"Nothing has been finalized yet," Laurency said.

Located at the corner of Northampton and South Welles streets, the apartment
building has multiple boarded-up windows.

It ended up in the repository because county, city and school real estate taxes
were not paid from 2012 through 2015, resulting in a combined debt of $18,695,
county tax claim records show.

It's unclear why the 2012 taxes were not paid when New York-based Service Legend
purchased the property for $7,500 in August 2013 from Exact Development, Inc.

Exact had purchased the property in December 2010 for $70,000 from Joseph A.
Fessler, county records show.

Wilkes-Barre officials are "looking forward" to reviewing Laurency's plans for
the apartment building because it is at a high visibility location and adjoins a
0.14-acre vacant parcel owned by the city, Wilkes-Barre's Administrator Greg
Barrouk said.

The city purchased the adjacent parcel, which extends to Park Avenue, for $1 in
July 2006 from Robert Yencha, the deed shows.

Several apartment buildings on Yencha's property were demolished in 2006 because
the structures had been vacant since a March 2004 fire, officials said.

State law allows repository sales at any time without the need to publicly
advertise them.

JEC Land Trust, of Port St. Lucie, Florida, purchased five repository
properties, including a 1.24-acre vacant lot at 182 Ransom Road in Dallas
Township for $750 and a 1.58-acre lot on the Kunkle-Alderson Road in the
township for $500.

LOP Land Trust, which is based at the same Port St. Lucie address as JEC,
purchased four vacant properties for $500 each: a 9-acre tract on Clearview
Drive, Larksville; a 6-acre parcel on Westminster Road, Jenkins Township; a
3-acre property on Canal Street in Plymouth Township; and a 4.32-acre site at
Rear West Main Street, Plymouth.

Here's a list of the other buyers, along with the addresses of the properties
they purchased and their bid amounts according to county records:

-- Jason Carr, Saylorsburg -- 73 Catlin Ave., Wilkes-Barre, $500

-- UMH Properties, Inc., Mountain Top -- 51 and 117 Valley Stream Park, Rice
Township, $500 each

-- Lisa Burns and Raymond Spallone, Wilkes-Barre -- 32 Highland St., Jeddo, $500

-- Patrick Hudock, Wilkes-Barre -- 229 and 225 Willow St., Plymouth, $500 each

-- River Road Properties, Inc., Wilkes-Barre -- 1657 River Road, Jenkins
Township, $500

-- Robert Stackhouse, Pittston -- 401 West Ave., Bear Creek Township, $792

A list of repository properties available for purchase may be viewed at
www.luzernecountytaxclaim.com.

Reach Jennifer Learn-Andes at 570-991-6388 or on Twitter @TLJenLearnAndes.

                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            November 3, 2014 Monday

New bill procedure aimed at Erie garbage delinquencies

BYLINE: Dana Massing, Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 380 words


Nov. 03--Erie garbage customers will soon receive a letter informing them of a
new billing procedure meant to help collect more than $2 million in delinquent
fees.

Those who don't pay their garbage bills under the new system could have their
water shut off.

"The Erie Water Works and the City of Erie have been working very closely in a
joint effort to address the issue of delinquent garbage collection fees," Paul
Vojtek, Erie Water Works chief executive, wrote in an Oct. 31 letter to
customers. "After a thorough evaluation of the problem, and the options
available to resolve it, both parties agreed that combining the garbage bills
with the sewer bills is the best way to collect these delinquent fees."

Under the new arrangement, customer payments will apply to the most delinquent
charges first.

Payment on a sewer/garbage bill would go toward any garbage delinquencies before
the sewer account. If the sewer account then becomes delinquent, Erie Water
Works could legally shut off water service, officials said.

The letter about the billing change will be included with water-only bills that
start going out today. The new combined sewer/garbage bills will follow in a
week to 10 days. Erie Water Works collects water, sewer and refuse bills on the
city's behalf.

In the past, water and sewer fees were combined in one bill and garbage was
separate.

Vojtek said more than 90 percent of customers pay their garbage bills on time
but others are reluctant to do so.

"There was really no leverage you could put on a customer to pay," he said.

The new billing procedure, which is meant to change that, is the result of a May
resolution approved by Erie City Council.

Erie City Council President Mel Witherspoon said he believes the billing change
will help cut into the delinquent fees.

"We'll never collect it all," Witherspoon said. "But I think we'll get a lot of
it. This new way of doing business is right on the money."

Vojtek said he agrees the new billing procedure would help.

"I think it's going to put a big dent in the problem," he said.

DANA MASSING can be reached at 870-1729 or by e-mail. Follow her on Twitter at
twitter.com/ETNmassing.

                                US Official News

                           December 20, 2014 Saturday

Washington: AARX, INC., INITIAL DECISION OF DEFAULT ACQUIRESTUFF.COM, INC.,
December 19, 2014 ADVANCED SCIENTIFIC ASSET HOLDING, INC., AIR SOUTH AIRLINES,
INC., ALTEK POWER CORP., AM BUILD, INC.,

LENGTH: 2170  words

DATELINE: Washington


Transport Security Administration, The Government f USA has issued the following
document:


INITIAL DECISION RELEASE NO. 723
ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEEDING
File No. 3-16266

UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
Before the
SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION
Washington, D.C. 20549


In the Matter of

AARX, INC.,  INITIAL DECISION OF DEFAULT
ACQUIRESTUFF.COM, INC.,  December 19, 2014
ADVANCED SCIENTIFIC ASSET HOLDING, INC.,
AIR SOUTH AIRLINES, INC.,
ALTEK POWER CORP.,
AM BUILD, INC.,
AMBER HILL, INC., AND
AMERICAN FAMILY COOKIES, INC.




APPEARANCE:  Neil J. Welch, Jr., for the Division of Enforcement, Securities and

Exchange Commission

BEFORE:    Cameron Elliot, Administrative Law Judge

SUMMARY

This Initial Decision revokes the registrations of Respondents' registered
securities. The revocations are based on Respondents' failure to timely file
required periodic reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission
(Commission).

INTRODUCTION

On November 10, 2014, the Commission issued an Order Instituting Administrative
Proceedings (OIP) against Respondents, pursuant to Section 12(j) of the
Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (Exchange Act). The OIP alleges that Respondents
each have a class of securities registered with the Commission and are
delinquent in their periodic filings. Respondents were served with the OIP by
November 21, 2014, and their Answers were due by December 4, 2014. See AARX,
Inc., Admin. Proc. Rulings Release No. 2069, 2014 SEC LEXIS 4528 (Dec. 1, 2014).

Following Respondents' failure to timely file Answers, I ordered Respondents to
show cause by December 18, 2014, why this proceeding should not be determined
against them due to their failures to file Answers or otherwise defend this
proceeding, warning that failure to show cause would result in default and the
revocations of the registrations of their securities. See AARX, Inc., Admin.
Proc. Rulings Release No. 2109, 2014 SEC LEXIS 4715 (Dec. 8, 2014). To date, no
Respondent has filed an Answer or responded to the Order to Show Cause.

FINDINGS OF FACT

 Respondents are in default for failing to file Answers or otherwise defend the
proceeding. See OIP at 4; 17 C.F.R. §§ 201.155(a)(2), .220(f). Accordingly, as
authorized by Rule of Practice 155(a), 17 C.F.R. § 201.155(a), I find the
following allegations in the OIP to be true. I take official notice of the
Commission's public official records concerning Respondents. See 17 C.F.R. §
201.323.

AARX, Inc., Central Index Key (CIK) No. 1306299, is a void Delaware corporation
located in Akron, Ohio, with a class of securities registered with the
Commission pursuant to Exchange Act Section 12(g). The company is delinquent in
its periodic filings with the Commission, having not filed any periodic reports
since it filed a Form 10 registration statement on November 12, 2004, which
reported a net loss of $2,291 from the company's September 3, 2004, inception to
September 30, 2004.

Acquirestuff.com, Inc., CIK No. 1143602, is a void Delaware corporation located
in Mississauga, Ontario, Canada, with a class of securities registered with the
Commission pursuant to Exchange Act Section 12(g). The company is delinquent in
its periodic filings with the Commission, having not filed any periodic reports
since it filed a Form 10-KSB for the period ended December 31, 2002, which
reported a net loss of $28,943 for the prior twelve months.

Advanced Scientific Asset Holding, Inc., CIK No. 1386977, is a forfeited
Delaware corporation located in Arlington, Virginia, with a class of securities
registered with the Commission pursuant to Exchange Act Section 12(g). The
company is delinquent in its periodic filings with the Commission, having not
filed any periodic reports since it filed a Form 10-QSB for the period ended
March 31, 2008, which reported a net loss of $87,939 for the prior three months.


Air South Airlines, Inc., CIK No. 1026724, is a forfeited Delaware corporation
located in Columbia, South Carolina, with a class of securities registered with
the Commission pursuant to Exchange Act Section 12(g). The company is delinquent
in its periodic filings with the Commission, having not filed any periodic
reports since it filed a Form 10-Q/A for the period ended June 30, 1997.

Altek Power Corp., CIK No. 1198692, is a British Columbia corporation located in
Kelowna, British Columbia, Canada, with a class of securities registered with
the Commission pursuant to Exchange Act Section 12(g). The company is delinquent
in its periodic filings with the Commission, having not filed any periodic
reports since it filed a Form 20-FR registration statement on January 9, 2003.

AM Build, Inc., CIK No. 1209532, is a permanently revoked Nevada corporation
located in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, with a class of securities registered with
the Commission pursuant to Exchange Act Section 12(g). The company is delinquent
in its periodic filings with the Commission, having not filed any periodic
reports since it filed a Form 10 registration statement on March 28, 2003, which
reported a net loss of $8,085 from the company's June 25, 2002, inception to
August 31, 2002.

Amber Hill, Inc., CIK No. 1384395, is a Nevada corporation located in Sumter,
South Carolina, with a class of securities registered with the Commission
pursuant to Exchange Act Section 12(g). The company is delinquent in its
periodic filings with the Commission, having not filed any periodic reports
since it filed a Form 10-Q for the period ended September 30, 2007, which
reported a net loss of $19,039 for the prior nine months.

American Family Cookies, Inc., CIK No. 1164392, is a dissolved Delaware
corporation located in Lavergue, Tennessee, with a class of securities
registered with the Commission pursuant to Exchange Act Section 12(g). The
company is delinquent in its periodic filings with the Commission, having not
filed any periodic reports since it filed a Form 10-QSB for the period ended
June 30, 2002, which reported a net loss of $31,186 for the prior six months.

 In addition to their repeated failures to file timely periodic reports,
Respondents failed to heed delinquency letters sent to them by the Commission's
Division of Corporation Finance requesting compliance with their periodic filing
obligations or, through their failure to maintain a valid address on file with
the Commission as required by Commission rules, did not receive such letters.

CONCLUSIONS OF LAW

Exchange Act Section 13(a) and Rules 13a-1 and 13a-13 require public
corporations to file annual and quarterly reports with the Commission.
Specifically, Rule 13a-1 requires issuers to file annual reports and Rule 13a-13
requires domestic issuers to file quarterly reports. See 17 C.F.R. §§ 240.13a-1,
.13a-13. "Compliance with those requirements is mandatory and may not be subject
to conditions from the registrant." America's Sports Voice, Inc., Exchange Act
Release No. 55511, 2007 SEC LEXIS 1241, at *12 (Mar. 22, 2007), recons. denied,
Exchange Act Release No. 55867, 2007 SEC LEXIS 1239 (June 6, 2007). Scienter is
not required to establish violations of Exchange Act Section 13(a) and Rules
13a-1 and 13a-13. See SEC v. McNulty, 137 F.3d 732, 740-41 (2d Cir. 1998); SEC
v. Wills, 472 F. Supp. 1250, 1268 (D.D.C. 1978). There is no genuine issue of
material fact that Respondents failed to timely file required periodic reports.
As a result, Respondents failed to comply with Exchange Act Section 13(a) and
Rules 13a-1 and/or 13a-13.

SANCTIONS

 Under Exchange Act Section 12(j), the Commission is authorized, "as it deems
necessary or appropriate for the protection of investors," to revoke the
registration of a security or suspend for a period not exceeding twelve months
if it finds, after notice and an opportunity for hearing, that the issuer of the
security has failed to comply with any provision of the Exchange Act or rules
thereunder. In proceedings pursuant to Exchange Act Section 12(j) against
issuers that violated Exchange Act Section 13(a) and Rules 13a-1 and/or 13a-13,
the determination "of what sanctions will ensure that investors will be
adequately protected . . . turns on the effect on the investing public,
including both current and prospective investors, of the issuer's violations, on
the one hand, and the Section 12(j) sanctions, on the other hand." Gateway Int'l
Holdings, Inc.,
Exchange Act Release No. 53907, 2006 SEC LEXIS 1288, at *19 (May 31, 2006). The
Commission "consider[s], among other things, the seriousness of the issuer's
violations, the isolated or recurrent nature of the violations, the degree of
culpability involved, the extent of the issuer's efforts to remedy its past
violations and ensure future compliance, and the credibility of its assurances,
if any, against further violations." Id. at *19-20.

 Respondents' failure to file required periodic reports is serious because it
violates a central provision of the Exchange Act. The purpose of periodic
reporting is "to supply investors with current and accurate financial
information about an issuer so that they may make sound
[investment] decisions." Id. at *26. The reporting requirements are the primary
tool that Congress fashioned for the protection of investors from negligent,
careless, and deliberate misrepresentations in the sale of securities. SEC v.
Beisinger Indus. Corp., 552 F.2d 15, 18 (1st Cir. 1977). Respondents' violations
are also recurrent in that each repeatedly failed to file periodic reports. See
Nature's Sunshine Prods., Inc., Exchange Act Release No. 59268, 2009 SEC LEXIS
81, at *20 (Jan. 21, 2009) (respondent failed to file seven required periodic
reports due over a two-year period); Impax Labs., Inc., Exchange Act Release No.
57864, 2008 SEC LEXIS 1197, at *25-26 (May 23, 2008) (failure to make eight
filings over an eighteen-month period considered recurrent). Respondents are
culpable because they failed to heed delinquency letters sent to them by the
Division of Corporation Finance or, through their failure to maintain a valid
address on file with the Commission as required by Commission rules, did not
receive such letters, and they were therefore on notice, even before the OIP
issued, of their obligation to file periodic reports. See China-Biotics, Inc.,
Exchange Act Release No. 70800, 2013 SEC LEXIS 3451, at *37 & n.60 (Nov. 4,
2013) (holding that revocation may be warranted even without proof that a
respondent was aware of its reporting obligations). Finally, Respondents have
not answered the OIP or otherwise participated in the proceeding to address
whether they have made any efforts to remedy their past violations, and have
made no assurances against further violations.

 Considering these delinquencies, it is necessary and appropriate for the
protection of investors to revoke the registrations of each class of registered
securities of Respondents.

ORDER

 It is ORDERED that, pursuant to Section 12(j) of the Securities Exchange Act of
1934, the registrations of each class of registered securities of Respondents
AARX, Inc., Acquirestuff.com, Inc., Advanced Scientific Asset Holding, Inc., Air
South Airlines, Inc., Altek
Power Corp., AM Build, Inc., Amber Hill, Inc., and American Family Cookies,
Inc., are hereby
REVOKED.

 This Initial Decision shall become effective in accordance with and subject to
the provisions of Rule of Practice 360, 17 C.F.R. § 201.360. Pursuant to that
Rule, a party may file a petition for review of this Initial Decision within
twenty-one days after service of the Initial Decision. A party may also file a
motion to correct a manifest error of fact within ten days of the Initial
Decision, pursuant to Rule of Practice 111, 17 C.F.R. § 201.111(h). If a motion
to correct a manifest error of fact is filed by a party, then that party shall
have twenty-one days to file a petition for review from the date of the
undersigned's order resolving such motion to correct a manifest error of fact.

This Initial Decision will not become final until the Commission enters an order
of finality. The Commission will enter an order of finality unless a party files
a petition for review or a motion to correct a manifest error of fact or the
Commission determines on its own initiative to review the Initial Decision as to
a party. If any of these events occur, the Initial Decision shall not become
final as to that party.

Respondents are notified that they may move to set aside the default in this
case. Rule of Practice 155(b), 17 C.F.R. § 201.155(b), permits the Commission,
at any time, to set aside a default for good cause, in order to prevent
injustice and on such conditions as may be appropriate. A motion to set aside a
default shall be made within a reasonable time, state the reasons for the
failure to appear or defend, and specify the nature of the proposed defense in
the proceeding. Id.

            _______________________________
            Cameron Elliot
            Administrative Law Judge

                                US Official News

                             June 26, 2014 Thursday

Delinquent Youth -- Especially Girls -- More Likely to Die Violently as Adults

LENGTH: 619  words

DATELINE: Evanston


Northwestern University has issued the following news release:

Delinquency in youth predicts a significantly higher rate of violent death in
adulthood -- especially from firearms -- and females are among the most
vulnerable, reports a new Northwestern MedicineÒ study.

Delinquent females died violently at nearly five times the rate of those in the
general population, according to the study, while delinquent males died at three
times general population rates.

Death rates in Hispanic males and females were five and nine times more than the
general population rates, respectively.

This is the first large-scale study to look at death rates in delinquent females
and adds new data on Hispanics, now the largest minority group in the U.S. The
paper was published June 16 in the journal Pediatrics.

In addition, violent death up to age 34 was predicted by three risk factors in
adolescence: alcohol use disorder, selling drugs and gang involvement, according
to the study.

"Our findings are shocking," said lead author Linda Teplin, the Owen L. Coon
Professor of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences at Northwestern University
Feinberg School of Medicine. "Death rates in our sample of delinquent youth,
ages 15 to 19, are nearly twice those of troops in combat in wartime Iraq and
Afghanistan."

"Early violent death is a health disparity," added Teplin. "Youth who get
detained are disproportionately poor and disproportionately racial and ethnic
minorities. We must address early violent death the same as any other health
disparity."

The study used newly available data from the Northwestern Juvenile Project, a
longitudinal study of 1,829 youth (1,172 males and 657 females, ages 10 to 18
years at baseline) who were detained at the Cook County Juvenile Temporary
Detention Center in Chicago between 1995 and 1998. The authors interviewed
participants and then followed them up using official death records up to 16
years after the initial interviews.

The youth in the study were randomly selected before their case was disposed,
and had not yet been convicted of any crime.

Of the original participants, 111 died. Among those who died, 75 (68 percent)
were victims of homicide of which 68 (91 percent) were killed with firearms.
African Americans were 4.5 times more likely to die from homicide than
non-Hispanic whites.

"Prevention is key," Teplin said. "We need to reduce the likelihood that youth
will become delinquent. And, if they are arrested and detained, we need
interventions to reduce violence. Otherwise, perpetrators often become victims."

Many delinquent youth commit crimes because of untreated psychiatric problems.
For example, they may abuse drugs to self-medicate for depression, and then sell
drugs to afford them, Teplin noted.

"These youth may have fallen through the cracks of the health care system into
the juvenile justice net," Teplin said. "We should avoid the stereotype that
delinquent youth are just bad kids. Many are not hardened criminals; but once
detained, they are on a path fraught with risk."

Other Northwestern authors include Jessica A. Jakubowski, Karen M. Abram,
Nichole D. Olson, Marquita L. Stokes and Leah J. Welty.

The study was supported in part by National Institute on Drug Abuse grants
R01DA019380, R01DA022953 and R01DA028763 and National Institute of Mental Health
grants R01MH54197 and R01MH59463, all of the National Institutes of Health;
1999-JE-FX-1001, 2005-JL-FX-0288 and 2008-JF-FX-0068 from the Of[#xfb01]ce of
Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention; the Substance Abuse and Mental
Health Services Administration, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
and the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation.

For more information please visit: http://www.northwestern.edu

                              Daily The Pak Banker

                              June 19, 2015 Friday

Moody's says RMBS in Ohio and Michigan perform worse

LENGTH: 149  words

DATELINE: New York


Residential mortgage-backed securities (RMBS) deals backed by delinquent loans
concentrated in Ohio and Michigan will perform worse than delinquent loans in
other US states because of high loss severities. This higher level of loss has
been driven in part by significantly higher rates of home value depreciation,
according to a report from Moody's Investors Service.


Moody's analysis of RMBS performance across asset type and vintage shows that
average loss severities for defaulted loans from Ohio and Michigan over the last
two years were higher, at 84% and 77% respectively, than average loss severities
on defaulted loans in other states at 59%. "Certain cities, such as Detroit and
Cleveland, had much higher numbers of loans liquidated with high loss
severities" says Associate Analyst Ilana Fried, author of "Concentrations of
Delinquent Loans in Ohio and Michigan Hurt Performance of RMBS."

                             463 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           Pittsburgh Tribune Review

                            October 25, 2005 Tuesday

Briefs: Candidates run under unique affiliation

LENGTH: 1087 words


Two people campaigning for council in the tiny Cambria County borough of Lorain
haven't started a new party, but they are running under a unique label.

Mike Jacobs and Linda Vivian will appear on the November ballot as Christian
Independents. Cambria County elections supervisor Fred Smith said state law lets
candidates who aren't Republicans or Democrats to pick a label -- known as a
"minor political body" -- as long as it's not more than three words.

"'Christian Independents' is a name we came up with to show that we want what
the Good Lord wants, and that is to be honest and forthright," Vivian said.

Jacobs is simultaneously running for a local school board seat. If he wins both,
Jacobs said, he will "look inside myself to see which one really is the most
important."

Johnstown may sell delinquent tax claims

Johnstown officials are considering the sale of delinquent tax claims to a New
Jersey company.

The city has more than $1.1 million in uncollected taxes for the years 2000 to
2004, which could take the Cambria County tax claim bureau years to collect,
city officials said.

Morristown, N.J.-based XSPAND Inc. would pay the city up front for its tax
claims. The company makes its money on the interest charged to delinquent
taxpayers. A new law passed by the General Assembly last year lets
municipalities sell their tax debts to private companies for collection. XSPAND
could charge up to 9 percent interest, the same rate the tax claim bureau can
collect.

Blair County

Allegheny Ridge Corp. receives mapping grant

The National Park Service has awarded Allegheny Ridge Corp. a $74,300 grant to
create new printed and Internet-based maps for people who want to paddle along
the Juniata River Water Trail.

The grant also includes matching funds for new signs at boat launches along the
trail route. It was announced Monday at a news conference in Canal Basin Park in
Hollidaysburg.

The Juniata River winds through central Pennsylvania and empties above
Harrisburg into the Susquehanna River, the waterway that delivers more fresh
water than any other into the Chesapeake Bay. The Chesapeake Bay Gateways grant
will be matched with money from the Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and
Natural Resources and the Pennsylvania Fish and Boat Commission.

City

Downtown

Police to honor 56 at awards ceremony

The Pittsburgh Bureau of Police will conduct an awards ceremony at 10 a.m.
Friday in council chambers on the fifth floor, of the City-County Building,
Grant Street, Downtown.

Nineteen officers, 26 detectives, five sergeants, a lieutenant, a commander and
four civilians will receive awards. Nine honorees will receive more than one
award.

Awards are for those for meritorious service, officer of the month and
recognition of excellence, certificates of appreciation and commendation and
letters of recognition.

Oakland

New Carlow institute to hold presentations

The first scholarly presentations from the new Carlow University Grace Ann
Geibel Institute for Justice and Social Responsibility will begin at 7 p.m.
Thursday in room 107 of the A.J. Palumbo Hall of Science and Technology, on the
Oakland campus.

Lectures and faculty presenters are: "My Mother's House: A Process for Restoring
the Village," Martha H. Ezzell, graduate program, professional leadership;
"Dionne's Project for Safe Relationships," Irene A. Lietz, English/professional
writing program; "Project to End Human Trafficking," Mary C. Burke, psychology
and professional counseling program; and "Health Promotion Initiatives in Peru,"
Michelle J. Upvall and Joan Reale, School of Nursing.

The institute's commissioned purpose is to develop a woman-centered approach to
leadership that seeks to challenge systemic oppression.

For more information contact Jim Kelly at kellyjm@carlow.edu or 412-578-8839.

Vigil to mark 2,000th U.S. death in Iraq

The day after the 2,000th U.S. soldier has been killed in Iraq, women dressed in
black will gather at 5:30 p.m. at the Friends Meeting House, 4836 Ellsworth
Ave., Oakland.

The American Friends Service Committee, Women's International League for Peace
and Freedom and Code Pink are preparing to commemorate that death --- expected
to occur this week -- and the other war deaths. Men also are invited to join
this silent, candlelight vigil and march from the meeting house down Fifth
Avenue, Bigelow Boulevard and Forbes Avenue. Marchers then will join Pittsburgh
Organizing Group's rally against the war.

For more information, contact Scilla Wahrhaftig at peace.seeds@verizon.net or
412-371-3607.

Allegheny County

Elderly and disabled voters have alternative

Voters who are elderly or disabled and assigned to polling places not accessible
to them may vote by alternative ballot in the Nov. 8 general election, the
Allegheny County Elections Division announced.

To be eligible for an alternative ballot, the voter's polling place must be
designated inaccessible and the voter must be registered to vote in Allegheny
County and be age 65 or older or have a temporary or permanent physical
disability that prevents the voter from entering a polling place with
architectural barriers. Voters should call the elections division at
412-350-4525 to find out if their assigned polling place is accessible.

Applications for alternative ballots are available by mail or in person at
Allegheny County Elections Division, 601 County Office Building, 542 Forbes
Ave., Pittsburgh, PA 15219. The deadline for returning applications is 5 p.m.
Nov. 1. Absentee ballots sent to qualified applicants must be returned to the
elections division by 8 p.m. Nov. 8.

November slated for prematurity awareness

The March of Dimes, as part of its effort to save babies from premature birth,
has designated November as Prematurity Awareness Month and has planned
observances in Allegheny County.

On Nov. 1, a barge lit in pink and blue will move from the Ohio River and past
the Point to the beginning of a candlelight vigil near Heinz Field. Throughout
November, several Pittsburgh landmarks will be lit with pink and blue lights to
symbolize hope for the future of all babies. In conjunction, parents of
premature babies are lighting their front porches to create awareness in their
neighborhoods.

On Nov. 15, Prematurity Awareness Day, March of Dimes' Western Pennsylvania
Division will have a "day of gratitude," marked by events at West Penn and
Magee-Womens hospitals.

For more information on Prematurity Awareness Month activities, call Kelly
Fraasch at 412-391-3193 or visit marchofdimes.com on the Web.

                             National Mortgage News

                               November 18, 1996

Sub-Prime Lenders Cope With Higher Delinquency, Default Risk

BYLINE: By Eric Avidon

SECTION: SPECIAL REPORT; Mortgage Servicing Update; Pg. 34

LENGTH: 493 words

DATELINE: New York


Unlike servicers of conventional mortgages, sub-prime servicers face a high risk
of delinquencies.  In order to combat that higher rate of nonperforming loans,
they must have a better plan of action than their conventional lending
counterparts to deal with borrowers who miss payments.

In fact, there is a 1-1.5% difference in the percentage of conventional loans
that are delinquent and the percentage of sub-prime loans.

Jean Schwindt, vice president and director of investor relations at Tampa-based
IMC Mortgage Co., said, "The challenge of the B&C servicer is that you're
dealing with a totally different customer than the A lender.  The B&C customer
has to be taught to pay their bill on time."

Sub-prime servicers are able to succeed in getting loan payments by setting up a
delinquency management plan that identifies a particular loan's flaws and
connects them to collection personnel, determines when is the proper time to
make initial contact regarding a missed payment, and determines the ultimate
expectations for individual loans.

Frank Pellegrin, executive vice president and servicing manager of Woodbury,
NY-based Delta Funding Corp. said, "To combat B&C delinquencies you need to be
proactive, not reactive.

"You need to have more collectors than conventional loan servicers, make more
collection calls and have a more sophisticated loan processing system-better
technology."

Ms. Schwindt said that at IMC the company has a pool of collection officers who
call delinquent borrowers after a payment is 30 days late, a second set of
officers who call when a loan reaches 60 days late and a final set of collection
officers who contact delinquent borrowers after 90 days.

"Each group of delinquent borrower is different so we have different groups to
call them.  We want to deal with each delinquent group differently in order to
manage the loan pool -- we don't want to scare them off before the loan gets
paid.  Getting the payment without scaring off the delinquent borrower is a very
delicate balance so we have the different callers."

But despite taking steps to combat potential loan failures, the main insurance
against the lost income a bad loan brings is charging higher fees.  Because it
costs more to service B&C loans, B&C servicers charge more to service than
conventional loan servicers.

The trade-off in terms of what makes servicing B&C loans good business,
according to Mr. Pellegrin, "is the fee, rate and income you get."

In addition to delinquencies, a second issue facing sub-prime servicers is loan
run-off, according to Mr. Pellegrin.

He said that when a sub-prime borrower effectively pays their bills for a time
and becomes an A- or high B customer, companies don't want to lose what was
their customer to the A market if the loan is refinanced.  He said, "You want C
or D customers that are good payers who want to refinance to become A or B
borrowers with you.  You don't want to lose the loan."

LOAD-DATE: November 29, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Sarasota Herald-Tribune (Florida)

                            November 12, 2007 Monday
                                  ALL EDITION

Coast shareholders watching the buyout price

BYLINE: John Hielscher

SECTION: BUSINESS WEEKLY; Money Minders; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 530 words


How low will it go?

Stockholders of troubled Coast Financial Holdings Inc. in Bradenton have to be
wondering where their buyout price will wind up.

The original offer of $3.40 per share from First Banks Inc. of St. Louis has
already dropped to $3.17 -- almost 7 percent -- because Coast's loan problems
have gotten even worse.

That took $1.5 million off the table from the already bargain-basement price of
$22.1 million.

Coast officials, in a recent regulatory filing, admit their loan woes will
"likely" continue to deepen and "the per share merger price will be further
reduced."

The company says the loan problems are not just tied to its free-falling
residential construction portfolio, battered by ill-fated dealings with defunct
builder Construction Compliance Inc.

Coast says it has one unidentified borrower with five delinquent loans on
residential and commercial properties totaling $9.5 million.

If the loans become 90 days delinquent, they will become nonperforming, and that
could drop the buyout price even more.

The clock is ticking: one loan of $1.9 million could be delinquent by Thursday;
another of $3.7 million on Nov. 24; and the other three valued at $3.9 million
on Dec. 30.

Shareholders are set to vote Nov. 26 on the merger. That leaves time for $5.6
million of those loans to impact the buyout.

Under the purchase agreement, the price can slip as low as $1.86 per share
before either party can call it off.

Anyone still wondering why Coast directors Michael Ruffino and Alex White
abandoned ship two months ago, selling their shares for $2.60?

Bitterman joins Synovus board

Stewart Bitterman of Sarasota has joined the board of directors of Synovus Bank
of Tampa Bay.

Bitterman is a former real estate developer in New Jersey and New York.

He is a member of the Dattoli Cancer Foundation, a director of the Florida
Winefest & Auction and a board member of the Community Foundation of Sarasota
County.

Orion opens Manatee branch

Orion Bank opened its first office in Manatee County this month. Naples-based
Orion branched into a two-story, 10,000-square-foot building at 5310 State Road
64 E.

T. David Miles is vice president and branch manager of the new office.

The building also houses the bank's commercial and residential lending teams for
the Manatee market.

Orion, a privately owned, $2.6 billion-asset company, operates three offices in
Sarasota County.

It posted $22.3 million in profits through the first nine months of 2007, flat
from last year.

New e-mail scam

Don't fall for a new e-mail scam that appears to be a charity solicitation from
the Internal Revenue Service to help victims of the California wildfires.

The IRS warns that bogus e-mails are circulating that sends readers to a link
that appears to be an IRS Web site. The site asks for donations that includes a
link for people to provide personal and financial information.

The e-mails, in an effort to look legit, include text from a speech about the
wildfires from the California Assembly.

How to spot the fake? The IRS never solicits charitable donations for anyone.

It will not request personal or financial info via e-mails, and it will not ask
for passwords, PINs or similar secret access to accounts.

                     Charleston Daily Mail (West Virginia)

                            August 13, 2007, Monday

New law prods companies to pay property tax;
Businesses that don't pay can lose their licenses

BYLINE: JAKE STUMP, DAILY MAIL STAFF

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. P2A

LENGTH: 522 words


A new state law might be partly responsible for a 13 percent spike in delinquent
personal property tax payments in Kanawha County.

In the past fiscal year, the county collected $315,422 more than the previous
year, according to Allen Bleigh, chief tax deputy.

On July 1, a new law gave the West Virginia Tax Department authority to refuse
to renew a person's or a company's business license if they owe at least $100 in
overdue personal property taxes. That would then allow county sheriffs'
departments to close a business for operating without a license.

Bleigh said he believes the law has helped the county net some of its owed
taxes. But there's still nearly $1 million that goes uncollected.

About 509 accounts owe at least $100 in delinquent taxes. That's down from June,
when there were 718 delinquent accounts.

Altogether, taxpayers still owe the county $923,425, which is also down from the
$1.06 million that was owed just two months ago.

Bleigh said the county hasn't shut down any businesses yet because people
haven't paid up. That would be a last resort, but county officials won't
hesitate if they've exhausted all other options, he said.

"We will come close you down if you don't pay the taxes," Bleigh said. "People
don't believe us because it's something that hasn't been done yet. But we will
do it if it makes people take their role more seriously."

The largest account belongs to Nashville, Tenn.-based Caterpillar Financial
Services, which owes $141,952 just for the 2005 tax season. Caterpillar has an
office in Charleston. According to its Web site, the company is the financial
arm of Caterpillar Inc., a Fortune 500 company and global manufacturer of
construction and mining equipment.

Bleigh said other businesses that owe the most are either bankrupt or already
have worked out a payment plan with the county.

The county tax department is working in conjunction with the prosecuting
attorney's office to whittle down a list of the top accounts to target.

"We're going to spend more time going after the big dollar values first and work
our way down," Bleigh said.

Before the July 1 deadline, the state Tax Department used reports submitted by
the counties to compile a list of 2,000 businesses delinquent in their tax
payments.

Businesses owing less than $100 in delinquent personal property taxes won't face
the penalties outlined in the new law.

One problem that has plagued tax officials when it comes to collecting back
taxes is that several businesses no longer exist or their owners cannot be
located.

On the county level, officials can still pursue payments even if a business is
defunct.

Though the new law has increased tax collections for Kanawha County, Bleigh said
he fears payments have started slowing down.

"I'm confident that collections have dwindled off since the July 1 deadline,"
Bleigh said. "People who were going to pay and pay willingly paid by that
deadline."

Before the recent surge in collections, the county usually would see a minimal 3
percent increase in payments during the months it sent out delinquent notices to
businesses.

Contact writer Jake Stump at jakestump@dailymail.com or 348-4842.

LOAD-DATE: August 14, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                      Copyright 2007 Charleston Newspapers

                     Sunday News (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)

                              July 12, 2009 Sunday

In My Opinion Look To Back Taxes For Revenue Send Submissions To:

BYLINE: In My Opinion / State Rep. John Bear

SECTION: P; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 649  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


State Rep. John Bear

It's budget time in Harrisburg and once again we are at our typical stalemate.
However, this year is different. Instead of running a budget surplus, we have a
$3.25 billion deficit. And while there has been talk of budget cuts and the
possibility of new or increased taxes, one unexplored possibility is
implementing a tax-amnesty program to go after delinquent taxes owed to
Pennsylvania.

We are leaving billions of dollars on the table because the state Department of
Revenue does not have the tools or personnel to effectively track or go after
delinquent taxpayers. Shocked? Don't be. The department is working with
antiquated business processes and computer systems.

But how much are we talking about? According to the Department of Revenue's
April 13 accounts receivable report (which is incomplete for 2008), more than $3
billion in delinquent taxes is owed to the state, of which about $1.6 billion is
deemed to be collectible. Here is how the $1.6 billion breaks down:

Corporation taxes: $813 million.

Sales and use tax: $352 million.

Employer withholding tax: $45 million.

Personal income tax: $329 million.

Inheritance tax: $38 million.

This $1.6 billion could go a long way to solving some present budget woes.
Interestingly enough, that is also about the same amount of money that Gov. Ed
Rendell hopes to raise by increasing the personal income tax from 3.07 to 3.57
percent. What alternative would you prefer?

Why should law-abiding taxpayers always be asked to foot the bill for those who
are unwilling to play by the rules? On average, 97 percent of us generally pay
our taxes on time; 3 percent or more do not. This might not sound like much, but
when you consider that we collect about $28 billion annually, 3 percent added up
over time is a huge number, money we desperately need.

So, what can be done? In the long-term, we need to invest in upgrading our
technological and business infrastructure so we have the computer systems,
business processes, and personnel to adequately address this problem. To the
credit of the administration, the Department of Revenue is in the process of
selecting a vendor to overhaul its legacy computer systems. But this will not
happen overnight and will likely take five years to complete.

That is why I have proposed House Bill 1627, which gives individuals or
companies who owe back taxes a window of opportunity to pay what is owed plus a
portion of the interest without any penalties. If the taxpayer would become
delinquent again within two years, all abated penalties would be reinstated. A
nonparticipation penalty would be added to unpaid delinquent taxes, interest,
and penalties for those who decide not to participate.

Given our current fiscal crisis and the fact the Department of Revenue is in the
process of upgrading its tax collection systems, in the short term, this kind of
program has the potential to collect large sums of unpaid taxes quickly.

Recently, Gov. Jon S. Corzine announced that New Jersey expects to collect as
much as $700 million in unpaid, back taxes through its amnesty program. It was
enacted as part of a series of solutions to close a shortfall in that state's
current fiscal year. From May 4 through June 15, the state waived penalties and
half the interest owed on delinquent taxes for tax returns due on or after
Jan.1, 2002, and before Feb. 1, 2009.

As of June 18, more than $600 million had already been accounted for and about
17,500 envelopes still needed to be opened and processed. Not bad for a month
and half's work. But here is the best part: This solution is nonpartisan.

If New Jersey can do it, so can Pennsylvania! It is time for the Legislature to
think outside of the box.

State Rep. John Bear, a Lititz Republican, represents the 97th District.

Barbara Hough Roda, P.O. Box 1328, Lancaster, PA 17608-1328, or e-mail to
broda@lnpnews.com Columns should be no more than 600 words.

LOAD-DATE: July 13, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                  Wisconsin State Journal (Madison, Wisconsin)

                             August 2, 2009 Sunday
                                  ALL EDITION

WHAT WE SAID...75 YEARS AGO

SECTION: SUNDAY OPINION; Pg. B4

LENGTH: 149 words


"Figures released by the federal census bureau emphasize how distressing is the
delinquent tax situation in this state. The statistics indicate how imperative
it is that the legislature of 1935 pass legislation that will relieve real
estate of a portion of the burden it now carries.

"The census bureau figures show nearly one-third of the taxes assessed against
real estate in Wisconsin for the 1932-33 taxation period are unpaid.

Some method must be provided not only to furnish funds to replace these taxation
losses in the counties having the largest delinquent lists but also to raise
future funds for carrying on state, county and municipal activities....

"Replacing the impaired revenue will mean new forms of taxation. The people of
Wisconsin as well as members of and candidates for the Legislature should be
studying the taxation questions."

- Wisconsin State Journal editorial, Aug. 2, 1934

was delinquent on property taxes for the 1932-1933 tax year. In Racine, Kenosha
and Milwaukee counties, nearly half of all property was delinquent on its real
estate taxes.

                 Augusta Chronicle (Augusta, GA) ~(Augusta, GA)

                                January 13, 2009

Board devises plan to get fees.

BYLINE: Greg Gelpi

LENGTH: 471 words


Jan. 13--Delinquent student accounts could be turned over to a collection agency
under a draft policy being considered by the Richmond County Board of Education.
The issue has arisen because of an increasing amount of outstanding summer
school fees -- $111,902 for the past five school years.

"This is just another thing we're putting in place to make the school system
better," board member Venus Cain said. "The sad part is that this is probably
something that has gone on for years." Summer school fees are due at the time of
registration, but the school system has allowed parents struggling financially
to set up payment plans, she said. The problem "snowballed" over the years. But
the policy proposal could affect more than just summer school students. It would
turn all delinquent student fees over to a collection agency, including fees for
damaged and lost library books and textbooks. Controller Gene Spires said this
might be the first time the school system has turned to a collection service for
delinquent student fees. The proposal builds on existing policy. It establishes
procedures for tracking and recording outstanding fees and formalizes a process
for putting academic holds on accounts owing $20 or more. An academic hold, part
of the current policy, prevents students from getting their report cards and
access to their permanent records. That happens a few times every year,
Hephzibah Middle School Principal Deborah Shepherd said. "We still have report
cards in the vault that were never collected last year," Dr. Shepherd said.
Columbia County also places academic holds on delinquent student accounts,
although Controller Pat Sullivan said she is unsure how successful that has been
with grades available online. She said there has been no discussion about using
a collection agency. Savannah-Chatham County school system, a system similar in
size and demographics to Richmond County, doesn't use a collection agency.
Spokesman Bucky Burnsed said it doesn't have a problem with delinquent summer
school fees because they are collected in advance. Mrs. Cain hopes to prevent
fees from becoming delinquent by setting up a prepayment plan for parents who
anticipate that their children will attend summer school. "I figure people
layaway everything else, prepay everything else, why not summer school?" she
asked. Reach Greg Gelpi at (706) 828-3851 or greg.gelpi@augustachronicle.com.

http://augustachronicle.com.

                   Commonwealth Journal (Somerset, Kentucky)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             July 22, 2010 Thursday

Tax bill sale Aug. 9: Property owners urged to pay up

BYLINE: Bill Mardis, Commonwealth Journal, Somerset, Ky.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 599 words


July 22--SOMERSET -- Pulaski County Clerk Ralph Troxtell is urging people with
delinquent real estate property tax bills to come to his office and pay the
taxes before the bills are sold to third-party purchasers.

Some 1,682 delinquent real estate tax bills for 2009 totaling about $530,000
will be offered for sale August 9, beginning at 9 a.m., in the fiscal courtroom
at the Pulaski County courthouse. Before then, delinquent bills can be paid and
property owners will avoid the high cost of dealing with a third-party
purchaser, Troxtell advised.

"A delinquent tax bill bought by a third-party purchaser becomes a financial
burden on the property owner," Troxtell cautioned. The purchased bill becomes a
lien on the property and with a 12 percent annual interest rate plus various
administrative and legal fees, the bill can triple or quadruple. Left unpaid, it
can eventually lead to foreclosure.

"With 1 percent a month interest and numerous fees, a delinquent tax bill turns
out to be very profitable for third-party purchasers," Troxtell explained.
Buyers go from county to county for the tax bills sales, dates of which are set
by the Kentucky Department of Revenue.

Anybody, after the sale " ... can come to my office and buy an unsold delinquent
tax bill. I have no choice ... I have to sell it ... it's state law ... it's
mandatory," said Troxtell.

Ron Woodson, former Pulaski County property valuation administrator who
currently prepares computer software for county clerks' offices, predicts about
a third of the more than 1,600 delinquent bills will be purchased during the
August 9 sale. Buyers draw a number and are given an opportunity to purchase up
to 25 delinquent bills at a time in numerical order. Troxtell expects the sale
to last about three hours.

A delinquent tax bill purchased by a third-party purchaser becomes a lien on the
property. Buying the tax bill is not buying the property," Woodson explained.
Previous third-party purchasers of a delinquent tax bill on a piece of property
have priority at the upcoming sale to buy the 2009 delinquent tax bill on that
property.

Woodson pointed out that the $530,000 in delinquent taxes is less than 2 percent
of the more than $20 million in taxes collected in 2009 by the Pulaski County
Sheriff's Department.

"This (sale) is not my doing," said Troxtell. "It is required by state law
(House Bill 262)." The law now requires the sheriff on April 15 to turn over
delinquent taxes to the county clerk for collection.

Troxtell said Sheriff Todd Wood on April 15 turned over to his office 2,189
delinquent tax bills on which $580,252.98 taxes are due. Since then, 507 of the
delinquent bills have been paid, reducing the total still due on 1,682 unpaid
bills to about $530,000.

Both Woodson and Troxtell emphasized that state law makes it the responsibility
of property owners to pay their taxes whether or not they get a bill. The tax
bill on any property sold after March 31, 2009 went to the seller, not the
buyer, Troxtell added.

He urged taxpayers to go to clerk's website â[#x20ac]"â[#x20ac]"
www.pulaskicountycourtclerk.com â[#x20ac]"â[#x20ac]" to see if they owe taxes on
their property.

To see more of the Commonwealth Journal or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.somerset-kentucky.com/. Copyright (c) 2010, Commonwealth Journal,
Somerset, Ky. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For more
information about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information

services@mctinfoservices.com, or call 866-280-5210 (outside the United States,
call +1 312-222-4544).

                       Sydney Morning Herald (Australia)

                          September 27, 1990 Thursday
                                  Late Edition

SUGAR MAY NOT BE CAUSING THE SOCIAL ROT, AFTER ALL;
ONLY HUMAN

BYLINE: STEPHEN JUAN

SECTION: NEWS AND FEATURES; Agenda; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 487 words


A HIGH sugar diet may improve the behaviour of delinquent adolescents. This is
the surprising finding of new research which could stand conventional nutrition
advice on its ear. Known as the Wisconsin study, the US research finds no
evidence to support the commonly-held view that eating too many sweets
predisposes some adolescents towards hyperactivity, poor academic performance
and disruptive behaviour, or inclines them towards crime.

Since the mid-1970s, a number of studies have theorised a causal link between
heavy consumption of sugary foods and various forms of undesirable behaviour in
children of different ages. For example, Drs R.J. Prinz and J.D. Riddle reported
in a 1986 article in Nutritional Review that sugar ingestion was associated with
hyperactivity in five-year-olds. An implication of the study for older children
was that sugar influenced the psychological processes that underlie the
hyperactive, impulsive and aggressive behaviours long associated with juvenile
delinquency and adult criminality.

But other studies have failed to firmly establish a causal link between sugar
and behaviour. Usually, research comes up with unclear or mixed results

But this debate has just taken an unexpected new twist with the Wisconsin study.
Six researchers from the University of Wisconsin reported results from the first
study comparing the effects of different sweeteners on criminally delinquent and
non-delinquent male adolescents. Their article, "Sucrose and delinquency:
Behavioural assessment" appears in the August issue of Pediatrics. The team
sought "to evaluate the hypothesis that sucrose (sugar)ingestion may compromise
the behavioural performance of juvenile delinquents". They administered tests to
115 delinquent and 39 non-delinquent males after giving them breakfasts
sweetened with either sugar or the artificial sweetener aspartame.

They found "no support for the contention that sucrose ingestion compromises
behaviour". This was true for the delinquents as well as for the non-delinquents
. But most surprisingly of all, they found that the most hyperactive and
disturbed subjects "demonstrated better performance after the sucrose than after
the nosucrose breakfast". Thus, this study implies that just as eliminating
sugar from the diet may improve a delinquent's behaviour, adding sugar may
accomplish the same thing.

But the researchers offer a cautionary note. They think that an individual's
body chemistry and metabolism may cause him to react negatively to sugar, react
positively, or not react at all. They add: "These results indicate that simple
statements regarding the effects of sucrose ingestion on behaviour are likely to
be misleading and highlight the need to consider individual difference variables
when investigating the effects of sucrose on juvenile delinquents." In other
words, any statement as to the effect of sugar on behaviour ought to be taken
with a grain of salt.

LOAD-DATE: July 21, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                Copyright 1990 John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd
                              All Rights Reserved


                             472 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                             National Mortgage News

                                  May 24, 2010

Delinks Up, But VA Rate Improves VA Delinquencies Outperform

BYLINE: Amilda Dymi

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1 Vol. 34 No. 34

LENGTH: 994  words


As national delinquencies creepup, the industry is reviewing outperformers such
as loans insured by the Department of Veteran Affairs, which the Mortgage
Bankers Association is recommending to Congress "to keep strong."

"VA loans have performed better than any other segment of the market"
outperforming their counterparts through the recent housing crisis, said MBA's
James H. Danis II, testifying before the House Veterans Affairs Subcommittee on
Economic Opportunity. And the reason why the VA portfolio has been able "to
weather today's turbulent market" is largely due to conservative underwriting
standards that require fully documented and fully underwritten loans on
owner-occupied properties, he said.

MBA data show the serious delinquency rate for VA loans in the first quarter of
2010 was 5.29%, well below the 7% for prime loans.

Up to 10.06% of all mortgagors were behind on payments at March 31,
which-according to calculations made by National Mortgage News based on MBA
data-means $1 trillion in both first and second liens are overdue.

Compared to the same period a year ago, late payments rose 10%. Meanwhile
"seriously delinquent" loans or loans that are 90 days or more late or in
foreclosure represented 9.54% of all loans, up 2.3% from the first quarter of
2009.

Among worries that global and domestic "fundamental market factors" may be
having a greater influence on delinquency rates than is normally the case, MBA's
chief economist Jay Brinkmann said during a press conference, the first-quarter
national delinquency report shows yet another increase in delinquencies for
residential mortgage loans along with some hope for improvement.

According to Brinkmann, during the past year delinquencies have been driven
"much more" by the recession than by any loan type.

Despite this, quite a few traditional loan type performance patterns persist,
indicating some level of stabilization.

A loan type performance review shows that at 0.69% and 0.89%, respectively,
prime fixed-rate mortgages and VA loans have the lowest delinquency rate
averages, compared to 1.46% for FHA loans, 2.29% for prime adjustable-rate
loans, 2.64% for subprime fixed and 4.32% for subprime ARMs.

Both year-over-year and quarterly improvements in VA delinquency rates were more
prominent in all states. Curiously, Michigan is the new "black sheep" in terms
of deteriorating performance, while the leading delinquent states of California,
Florida, Nevada and Arizona show signs of improvement. While Michigan had the
highest 90-day-plus delinquency rate in the VA group it also had the largest
quarterly improvement. The change was by 33 bps year-to-year and 87 bps 1Q10 vs.
4Q09.

In Washington, D.C., the VA delinquency rate changed 26 bps quarterly, but
showed a dramatic 168 bps improvement in the 1Q10 vs. 1Q09 delinquency rate that
was well above the 152 bps national average and other states within the same
category, such as Vermont at 65 bps and North Dakota at 59 bps.

A closer look shows delinquency rates among VA loans remain the lowest among all
loan types, including FHA and prime fixed loans, which historically have
performed better than all other loan types across the board. The rate of
delinquency starts and 90-day-plus delinquent VA loans by state ranged from
1.81% to 0.24% and 4.47% to 0.85% top to bottom.

What stands out among foreclosure starts in general is the increase in the
percentage of delinquent prime fixed loans from 28.9% in 1Q09 to 36.7% in 1Q10,
"more than likely" due to job loss than loan reset issues. So much so that now
the delinquency market is dominated by prime fixed rate loans.

Subprime loans on the other hand are consistently following an improvement
trend. In 1Q10 the subprime ARM delinquency rate was 14.4%, down from 26.6% in
1Q09, in part due to improvements in the top four problematic states:
California, Florida, Arizona and Nevada.

A year ago these states represented 45.3% of all problem loans in the country
and this year the percentage dropped to 37.9%, lead by significant
quarter-to-quarter and year-over-year improvements in California. The dominance
of these "sand states" is expected to slowly fade out in the coming quarters,
Brinkmann said, with Michigan and other states turning into bottom performers
due to various economic issues in recent years.

On a quarter-to-quarter basis all states saw declines in foreclosure starts in
all loan types, even though most (up to 40 states) saw increases in foreclosure
starts in prime fixed and prime ARM loans and even FHA loans.

And VA loans were the single-best performing loan type consistently showing very
low rates of both foreclosure starts and 90-day and over delinquent rates
quarter-to quarter and year-over-year outperforming FHAs and prime fixed loans.

Higher consistency in loan type performance is a good sign within a wider
context.

Brinkmann said during the press conference that he still sees a "case for
gradual improvement" going forward.

Economic problems in Europe are expected to have some impact on the housing
market. "We should see improvement" in delinquencies and the foreclosure process
especially after the body of loans 90-days-plus delinquent goes through the
system.

Currently, the MBA's chief economist said foreclosed inventory, 90-day and over
delinquent loans and the shadow inventory make up for about 4.3 million loans
that "need to be worked through." If not, they will add to the existing REO
inventory.

Two main factors "that have likely delayed the process" of moving seriously
delinquent loans into a final modification or foreclosure are government
programs that mitigate longer stays of over 90-day delinquent homeowners in
their homes, including various "legal hoops" and new requirements, Brinkmann
said, combined with servicers' capacity shortages. So since the economic
slowdown, the shock from subprime loan defaults and major mortgage processing
issues "are behind us," problems related to the current more traditional
recession.

URL: http://www.nationalmortgagenews.com//

                The Citizens' Voice (Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          September 30, 2009 Wednesday

Restaurateur pays more than $140K in delinquent taxes

BYLINE: Michael P. Buffer, The Citizens' Voice, Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 419 words


Sep. 30--WILKES-BARRE -- Payments totaling more than $140,000 have reduced
delinquent tax bills on 19 properties owned by Robert S. Jabers, a politically
connected restaurateur in Luzerne County.

Without those payments, the county tax claim office would have tried to sell the
properties at a delinquent tax sale on Sept. 16. The office recorded the
payments on Aug. 3 and Sept. 15, records show.

Jabers is owner of the Saber Room Restaurant in Wilkes-Barre, and six of the 19
properties are owned by his company, Excalibur Development Corp. The Saber Room,
94 Butler St., was the site of many fundraisers, political gatherings and
election parties over the years.

Unpaid taxes on Jabers' properties dated back to 2004, and the county could have
listed them for tax claim sales in 2006 and 2007. But the county tax claim
office did not document why the properties were not up for sale in 2006 and
2007.

County officials have said tax claim irregularities are being reviewed by
federal authorities conducting an ongoing public corruption probe. An FBI agent
visited the tax claim office sometime last month, tax claim Deputy Director Beth
Ann Christian said.

Last year, county officials could not explain or justify why a property owned by
Recorder of Deeds James "Red" O'Brien was off not offered at delinquent tax
sales. O'Brien's unpaid taxes dated back to 2003. In June 2008, O'Brien paid off
a delinquent tax bill of $17,855 after selling O'Brien's Irish Pub and
Restaurant in Avoca for $205,000.

In 2008, Jabers paid the county more than $26,000 to reduce his delinquent tax
bill but later defaulted on payment agreements, records show. In April,
Christian said Jabers was not eligible for another payment agreement for three
years, so he would have to pay delinquency amounts in full to avoid having
properties listed at the Sept. 16 sale.

According to campaign finance records that date back to 2000, Jabers has donated
at least $3,250 to various campaigns involving area politicians and judges;
campaigns spent $21,772 on 17 Saber Room events.

mbuffer@citizensvoice.com, 570-821-2073

http://www.citizensvoice.com/. Copyright (c) 2009, The Citizens' Voice,
Wilkes-Barre, Pa. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For

847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group
Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                             474 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                   October 04, 1997, Saturday, Final Edition

Community Association Board's Quick Action Is Essential for Recouping Delinquent
Fees

Benny L. Kass

SECTION: REAL ESTATE; Pg. F05; HOUSING COUNSEL

LENGTH: 875 words


Q: We live in a Maryland community association. Although most of our owners pay
their assessments on time, one owner has refused. Attempts thus far through
legal channels have proved ineffective. His last payment was in 1995; after he
was delinquent for four months, we began legal action.

However, almost two years later we have not received one dime from this owner.
Now, his mortgage lender intends to foreclose. Is there anything the board can
do now and do you have any suggestions so we can avoid this problem in the
future?

A: It will not be a consolation to you, but you are not alone. Many community
associations are facing this identical problem. There are, however, a number of
steps that your association should take to avoid this problem from happening
again.

First and foremost, I strongly recommend that your board of directors -- and
your management company -- begin an educational campaign. Advise your owners --
by newsletter, periodic notices and at your annual meetings -- that they are
owners, and not tenants. Non-payment of monthly assessments hurts everyone in
the association, including the delinquent owner. At the beginning of each year,
a budget is developed; each owner pays his/her share of the annual budget,
usually on a monthly or quarterly basis. If an owner does not make these
payments, your association will not have sufficient funds to meet your monthly
obligations. This can be disastrous for the entire community.

As this column has suggested in the past, you must adopt a "zero tolerance"
collection policy. You advised me that you let your owner stay delinquent four
months before you initiated legal action. Clearly, you can see the problem with
such a delay; if the owner does not have enough money to pay one month's
assessment, how will he/she have funds to pay four months? None of us believe
that the owner would put aside funds for the benefit of the association.

Review your association documents. Your board should have authority to adopt --
as a rule and not as a bylaw amendment -- this zero tolerance policy. Such a
policy contains the following simple concepts:

* When the unit owner is 30 days delinquent, the board will accelerate the
balance of the assessments for the year.

* The board will refer the matter immediately to its legal counsel, with
instructions that a lawsuit against the owner be filed and a lien recorded on
the property without delay.

We all understand that litigation is time-consuming and expensive. Judges do not
always award legal fees to the association, even though the community's legal
documents might authorize such an award. However, what is the alternative? More
importantly, such zero tolerance policy sends a clear message to all owners:
Your board will no longer tolerate delinquencies of any amount, and will take
immediate legal action against all delinquent owners. Some homeowners'
associations have collected overdue fees successfully by filing liens against
their dues-delinquent neighbors and collected the money when owners have sold
their homes or refinanced their mortgages.

Turning to your immediate problem, if the lender forecloses you most likely will
not collect the delinquent fees from the foreclosure sale. It does not, of
course, wipe the slate clean -- you still have the right to go after the
delinquent owner. Once you obtain a court judgment against the owner, or former
owner, and if he/she has any money or has a job, you can take all appropriate
collection steps that are available to a judgment creditor. These include
attachment of bank accounts and garnishment of wages.

In the District of Columbia, condominium associations have a priority position
of up to six months of assessments against any first trust (mortgage) lender --
if that lender's loan was recorded after March 7, 1991. If the loan was recorded
before that date, and the lender forecloses, your association does not get the
priority.

Community association leaders in both Virginia and Maryland have been trying to
get similar "priority" legislation adopted by their state legislative bodies,
but to date have been unsuccessful.

You also asked if you -- as board members -- were meeting your fiduciary
responsibilities to all owners, since this one owner has not paid for such a
long period of time.

Board members can only try to do their best; they are not expected to work
miracles. An important test that the courts often use is to question whether the
members of the board exercised "good business judgment." In your case, you have
taken all the steps necessary to collect, and even though you have thus far been
unsuccessful, you clearly have exercised good business judgment.

Perhaps the best thing to expect now is that the mortgage lender will complete
its foreclosure process. Once the new lender has foreclosed, your association is
entitled to collect fees from the new owner, whether that is the lender itself
or some third party who purchased the property at the foreclosure sale.

Benny L. Kass is a Washington lawyer. For a free copy of the booklet "A Guide to
Settlement on Your New Home," send a self-addressed stamped envelope to Benny L.
Kass, Suite 1100, 1050 17th St. NW, Washington, D.C., 20036.

LOAD-DATE: October 04, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 1997 The Washington Post

                           Ruidoso News (New Mexico)

                            July 27, 2016 Wednesday
                                   1 Edition

Delinquent taxes lead to property sale

BYLINE: By, Dianne L Stallings

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A4

LENGTH: 349 words


A delinquent property tax sale for Lincoln County is set for 9 a.m., Aug. 4, by
officials with the New Mexico Property Tax Division.

Owners of 58 properties on the current sale list that have not paid the
delinquent property tax, County Treasurer Beverly Calaway said. All delinquent
taxes must be paid in full to remove the item from the public auction, she said.

"It's discouraging to have this many properties still on the list, within two
weeks of the tax sale," Calaway said. "These property owners have had adequate
time to pay the delinquent taxes, and in most cases, the property tax is three
or more years past due. My office has sent out numerous letters to the owners, I
also try to contact them in person to let them know of the consequences of
nonpayment, that the property will go to auction by the State of New Mexico."

State Property Tax Division officials start the process of title research, red
tag the property, send certified letters and collection efforts, a full year
before the date of the tax sale, she said. The state agency also will consider
installment agreements for hardship cases, if needed.

The state advertises the delinquent property taxes in the local newspaper and on
line for persons interested in purchasing delinquent properties around the
state. At this time, the Lincoln County Sale List is available on the county
website of lincolncountynm.gov, by clicking on the County Treasurer's web page,
or the list may be purchased at the Treasurer's Office for a fee of $5, Calaway
said. Maps also are also available for $5.

"My goal is to collect 100 percent of the delinquent property tax due on these
properties and to be able to cancel the public auction," the treasurer said. "I
certainly do not want to see anyone lose their property or homes at a public
auction for delinquent property taxes. Believe me, this keeps me awake at
night."

The public auction of real property for delinquent property taxes will be
conducted in the commission chambers of the Lincoln County Courthouse and will
continue until all described real property has been offered for sale.
