                                US Official News

                             March 5, 2015 Thursday

Washington: ORDER INSTITUTING ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEEDINGS AND NOTICE OF HEARING
PURSUANT TO SECTION 12(j) OF THE SECURITIES EXCHANGE ACT OF 1934

LENGTH: 1303  words

DATELINE: Washington


US Securities and Exchange Commission, The Government of USA has published the
following document:


UNITED STATES OF AMERICA Before the SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION
SECURITIES EXCHANGE ACT OF 1934 Release No. 74447 / March 5, 2015
ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEEDING File No. 3-16421
In the Matter of
Black Sea Metals, Inc., GigaBeam Corp., Safe Technologies International, Inc.,
and Whitemark Homes, Inc., Respondents.
ORDER INSTITUTING ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEEDINGS AND NOTICE OF HEARING PURSUANT TO
SECTION 12(j) OF THE SECURITIES EXCHANGE ACT OF 1934

I.


 The Securities and Exchange Commission ("Commission") deems it necessary and
appropriate for the protection of investors that public administrative
proceedings be, and hereby are, instituted pursuant to Section 12(j) of the
Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") against Respondents Black Sea
Metals, Inc., GigaBeam Corp., Safe Technologies International, Inc., and
Whitemark Homes, Inc.
II.
 After an investigation, the Division of Enforcement alleges that:
A. RESPONDENTS
1. Black Sea Metals, Inc. (CIK No. 1174907) is a revoked Nevada corporation
located in Austin, Texas with a class of securities registered with the
Commission pursuant to Exchange Act Section 12(g). Black Sea Metals is
delinquent in its periodic filings with the Commission, having not filed any
periodic reports since it filed a Form 10-Q for the period ended May 31, 2012,
which reported a net loss of $489,931 for the prior six months. As of February
19, 2015, the company's stock (symbol "BLAK") was quoted on OTC Link, had seven
market makers, and was eligible for the "piggyback" exception of Exchange Act
Rule 15c2-11(f)(3).
 2
2. GigaBeam Corp. (CIK No. 1279831) is a void Delaware corporation located in
Durham, North Carolina with a class of securities registered with the Commission
pursuant to Exchange Act Section 12(g). GigaBeam is delinquent in its periodic
filings with the Commission, having not filed any periodic reports since it
filed a Form 10-QSB for the period ended September 30, 2007, which reported a
net loss of $9,546,809 for the prior nine months. As of February 19, 2015, the
company's stock (symbol "GGBM") was quoted on OTC Link, had eight market makers,
and was eligible for the "piggyback" exception of Exchange Act Rule
15c2-11(f)(3).
3. Safe Technologies International, Inc. (CIK No. 829117) is a forfeited
Delaware corporation located in Coral Springs, Florida with a class of
securities registered with the Commission pursuant to Exchange Act Section
12(g). Safe Technologies International is delinquent in its periodic filings
with the Commission, having not filed any periodic reports since it filed a Form
10-K for the period ended December 31, 2010, which reported a net loss of
$614,199 for the prior twelve months. As of February 19, 2015, the company's
stock (symbol "SFA") was quoted on OTC Link, had eleven market makers, and was
eligible for the "piggyback" exception of Exchange Act Rule 15c2-11(f)(3).
4. Whitemark Homes, Inc. (CIK No. 42284) is a Colorado corporation located in
Sarasota, Florida with a class of securities registered with the Commission
pursuant to Exchange Act Section 12(g). Whitemark Homes is delinquent in its
periodic filings with the Commission, having not filed any periodic reports
since it filed a Form 10-Q for the period ended September 30, 2012, which
reported a net loss of $133,460 for the prior nine months. As of February 19,
2015, the company's stock (symbol "TM") was quoted on OTC Link, had eight market
makers, and was eligible for the "piggyback" exception of Exchange Act Rule
15c2-11(f)(3).
B. DELINQUENT PERIODIC FILINGS
5. As discussed in more detail above, all of the Respondents are delinquent in
their periodic filings with the Commission, have repeatedly failed to meet their
obligations to file timely periodic reports, and failed to heed delinquency
letters sent to them by the Division of Corporation Finance requesting
compliance with their periodic filing obligations or, through their failure to
maintain a valid address on file with the Commission as required by Commission
rules, did not receive such letters.
6. Exchange Act Section 13(a) and the rules promulgated thereunder require
issuers of securities registered pursuant to Exchange Act Section 12 to file
with the Commission current and accurate information in periodic reports, even
if the registration is voluntary under Section 12(g). Specifically, Rule 13a-1
requires issuers to file annual reports, and Rule 13a-13 requires domestic
issuers to file quarterly reports.
7. As a result of the foregoing, Respondents failed to comply with Exchange Act
Section 13(a) and Rules 13a-1 and/or 13a-13 thereunder.
 3
III.
 In view of the allegations made by the Division of Enforcement, the Commission
deems it necessary and appropriate for the protection of investors that public
administrative proceedings be instituted to determine:
 A. Whether the allegations contained in Section II hereof are true and, in
connection therewith, to afford the Respondents an opportunity to establish any
defenses to such allegations; and,
 B. Whether it is necessary and appropriate for the protection of investors to
suspend for a period not exceeding twelve months, or revoke the registration of
each class of securities registered pursuant to Section 12 of the Exchange Act
of the Respondents identified in Section II hereof, and any successor under
Exchange Act Rules 12b-2 or 12g-3, and any new corporate names of any
Respondents.
IV.
 IT IS HEREBY ORDERED that a public hearing for the purpose of taking evidence
on the questions set forth in Section III hereof shall be convened at a time and
place to be fixed, and before an Administrative Law Judge to be designated by
further order as provided by Rule 110 of the Commission's Rules of Practice [17
C.F.R. § 201.110].
 IT IS HEREBY FURTHER ORDERED that Respondents shall file an Answer to the
allegations contained in this Order within ten (10) days after service of this
Order, as provided by Rule 220(b) of the Commission's Rules of Practice [17
C.F.R. § 201.220(b)].
 If Respondents fail to file the directed Answers, or fail to appear at a
hearing after being duly notified, the Respondents, and any successor under
Exchange Act Rules 12b-2 or 12g-3, and any new corporate names of any
Respondents, may be deemed in default and the proceedings may be determined
against them upon consideration of this Order, the allegations of which may be
deemed to be true as provided by Rules 155(a), 220(f), 221(f), and 310 of the
Commission's Rules of Practice [17 C.F.R. §§ 201.155(a), 201.220(f), 201.221(f),
and 201.310].
 This Order shall be served forthwith upon Respondents personally or by
certified, registered, or Express Mail, or by other means permitted by the
Commission Rules of Practice.
 IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the Administrative Law Judge shall issue an initial
decision no later than 120 days from the date of service of this Order, pursuant
to Rule 360(a)(2) of the Commission's Rules of Practice [17 C.F.R. §
201.360(a)(2)].
 In the absence of an appropriate waiver, no officer or employee of the
Commission engaged in the performance of investigative or prosecuting functions
in this or any factually related proceeding will be permitted to participate or
advise in the decision of this matter, except as witness or counsel in
proceedings held pursuant to
 4
notice. Since this proceeding is not "rule making" within the meaning of Section
551 of the Administrative Procedure Act, it is not deemed subject to the
provisions of Section 553 delaying the effective date of any final Commission
action.
 By the Commission.
 Brent J. Fields Secretary

                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                          February 11, 2015 Wednesday

EDITORIAL: Progress, at last, on overdue garbage bills

BYLINE: Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: COMMENTARY

LENGTH: 525 words


Feb. 11--Five years ago, an Erie Times-News investigation revealed that unpaid
garbage bills had become a huge financial drain for the city of Erie. In 2010,
garbage customers owed $1.6 million.

But solutions to press delinquent customers to pay up weren't forthcoming from
City Hall after this newspaper first investigated. When reporter Kevin Flowers
revisited the issue in late 2013, the amount owed to the city had increased to
more than $2 million.

Erie Mayor Joe Sinnott's solution in 2013 was to propose higher garbage fees for
the 2014 budget, from $48 to $55 a quarter, and to post a database on the city
website with the names and addresses of delinquent customers and the amount they
owed.

The database revealed that two elected officials were behind on their garbage
bills. After the publicity, they made payment arrangements with Erie Water
Works, which provides billing services for the city's garbage, water and sewer
bills. The database also revealed that landlords owed thousands. Landlords
blamed tenants for skipping out on their garbage bills, even though the property
owner is the responsible party.

Posting the database online was a victory for transparency in government. You
can view the current list at www.goerie.com/garbagebills.

But publicizing the names and addresses of delinquent customers wasn't enough to
make a dent in collections. Erie City Council finally put teeth into the
collection effort when it approved a resolution directing Erie Water Works to
combine garbage and sewer fees into one bill; partial payment on bills would go
to pay the garbage bill, not the sewer bill. Sewer fees previously had been
charged on the water bill.

Eliminating trash pickup for delinquent garbage customers doesn't work. It would
be nearly impossible for city garbage collectors to figure out which customers
are delinquent when they pick up trash late at night or early in the morning,
and it would be a public health hazard to let garbage pile up on city streets.

But the combined garbage-sewer bill is an effective tool for delinquent
customers. If sewer bills aren't paid, Erie Water Works can shut off water
service. Since the bills were combined after Nov. 1, the number of payment
arrangements for overdue garbage bills has increased from 160 to 1,899, and
$145,000 has been collected. "I think a lot of people have come to a realization
that they received a service that they have to pay for, and they are taking
advantage of a way to pay that over time," said Paul Vojtek, chief executive of
Erie Water Works.

This isn't a perfect solution. People who pay their bills on time are still
paying the higher garbage fee that City Council approved to balance the 2014
budget, and now the sewer charge has been tacked on to that bill.

Still, we salute City Council and Erie Water Works for devising a partial
solution to reduce garbage delinquencies. But more must be done. According to
the online database, updated Feb. 2, the city is still owed $2,025,822.32 in
garbage bills, and that stinks.

___ (c)2015 the Erie Times-News (Erie, Pa.) Visit the Erie Times-News (Erie,
Pa.) at www.GoErie.com Distributed by Tribune Content Agency, LLC

LOAD-DATE: February 11, 2015

                             478 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              September 20, 1989, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

States Using Stiff Methods To Collect Child Support

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1094 words


Using strengthened Federal and state laws, New Jersey, Connecticut and New York
are tracking down parents who fail to pay court-ordered child support and
collecting the money by seizing their wages, intercepting tax refunds or putting
the delinquents in jail until they pay.

In New Jersey, ranked as one of the toughest states in enforcing child support,
many county sheriffs have taken advantage of Federal financial aid to hire
officers exclusively for such cases and have rounded up delinquents in mass
sweeps and jailed some.

In one of the more dramatic sweeps, in Monmouth County, Sheriff William Lanzaro
dispatched 38 officers last month to serve warrants on 66 delinquent fathers.
Thirty-six of them, owing a total of $217,000, were roused from sleep, led away
in handcuffs and forced to sit in the county jail until they paid part of their
debt.

''It's called pay or stay, and they pay,'' said Raymond Rainville, chief of
child-support enforcement services for New Jersey courts. ''It sounds too
simple, but it works.''

Speedier Justice Sought

Under the Federal Child Support Enforcement Amendments of 1984, states were
required to strengthen their enforcement procedures to qualify for Aid to
Dependent Children grants. The amendments suggested speeding hearings through
the use of officials other than judges.

In New Jersey these officials are called hearing officers, and they make
recommendations to a judge. In Connecticut they are called family-support
magistrates, and they recently received authority to incarcerate delinquent
fathers.

The Federal Family Support Act of 1988 required states to have uniform
child-support guidelines for judges to consider in awarding payments. Income and
number of children, for example, would be considered under the guidelines.

Last year the House Ways and Means Committee rated the enforcement programs of
the 50 states, and New Jersey officials note that their state ranked No. 2. New
Jersey has increased collections from delinquent parents from $183 million in
1984 to $280 million projected for this year.

Only three states besides New Jersey received A ratings from the committee:
Michigan, which was ranked first, Delaware, third, and North Dakota, fourth.

A spokeswoman for the New Jersey Department of Human Services, Mary Kay Risi,
said: ''New Jersey is among states that are beginning to look at child-support
enforcement as a law-enforcement issue and the violation of support orders as a
crime. This wasn't the case in the past. One of the states that is using arrests
and raids is Massachusetts.''

Pressure Through Jailing

In Monmouth County, failure to make child-support payments for two weeks usually
leads to a bench warrant for arrest of the parent. After the arrest, each case
is handled individually, said Jan Budnik, a principal probation officer for the
county. ''If their history indicates they have a pattern of nonpayment, they can
be kept in jail in an attempt to make them pay,'' he said.

The probation department gives the court the history of the case, and the judge
determines how much partial payment is needed to obtain release from jail, Mr.
Budnik said.

Of the 36 men arrested in the Monmouth sweep, 16 managed to pay their way to
freedom by the end of the day and eight more did so by the next morning. But
seven remained in jail after two weeks, and the last was not released until
after three weeks, 'No Civil-Rights Issue'

Edward Martone, executive director of the New Jersey branch of the American
Civil Liberties Union, said: ''I don't see any civil liberties implications in
these sweeps. There is no civil-rights issue, but a law-enforcement issue, in
that there is reasonable suspicion that these men are in violation of legitimate
court orders.''

The raids have less to do with punishing delinquent parents than to impress on
them that New Jersey is serious about collecting child support, officials said.
Sheriff Lanzaro, whose first raid in February netted 22 men, said, ''We find
that after we conduct raids, for weeks afterward, delinquent fathers come in
voluntarily and the payments escalate.''

Other New Jersey counties that have conducted sweeps are Camden, Cape May,
Gloucester, Morris, Ocean and Union, and still others are preparing to do so.
Marion Reitz, director of the Division of Economic Assistance of the state's
Department of Human Services, said 17 of the 21 counties in the state were now
being reimbursed by the Federal Government for seeking collections under
warrants.

Sheriff Lanzaro, said that he was able to hire a part-time secretary and two
extra officers with the reimbursements and that he planned to hire a third
officer.

Crackdowns Are Growing

New Jersey, with some 300,000 child-support cases, does not keep figures on the
number of arrests for nonpayment of child support, said Mr. Rainville, the
courts official. Neither does Connecticut, with 93,000 cases, or New York, with
776,000, so comparisons are difficult.

''We have about 90 arrest warrants a month,'' Sheriff Lanzaro said. ''Of these,
we arrest 60 to 70 a month, and of the 20 remaining, about 10 will come in on
their own and pay up.''

Neither Connecticut nor New York use the types of sweeps employed by New Jersey,
officials in those states said, but they added that they, too, had been taking a
harder line on delinquents.

They pointed to upgraded state laws in conformity with Federal standards. And
New York was the first and Connecticut the third state to receive Federal
certification and money for a computer system that links involved agencies in
each state to help track delinquents.

Seizure of Funds and Property

In Connecticut, which was rated sixth by the House Ways and Means Committee,
child-support collections have risen steadily each year to about $70 million
this year, said Anthony DiNallo, director of the Bureau of Child Enforcement in
the Connecticut Department of Human Resources.

Over 50 percent of collections come from seizing wages, he said, but in the last
five years the interception of tax refunds and liens on property have increased
total collections from $4.6 million to $11.8 million.

New York's total collections increased from $188 million in 1984 to $310 million
projected for this year. Collections from tax refund intercepts alone have risen
from $11.5 million in 1984 to $53 million projected for 1989.

Last spring New York began informing delinquent parents who owed more than
$1,000 that they had 90 days to pay up or their debts would be reported to
credit bureaus nationwide.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1989 The New York Times Company


                             479 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        Contra Costa Times (California)

                           October 10, 2012 Wednesday

Alameda County property taxes due by Nov. 1

BYLINE: By Angela Woodall Oakland Tribune

SECTION: MY TOWN; Alameda; News; Local

LENGTH: 172 words


The first installment of this year's property taxes are due Nov. 1 and will be
considered delinquent if not paid by 5 p.m. Dec. 10. The second installment is
due on Feb. 1 and is delinquent if not paid by 5 p.m. April 10. Delinquent
owners will face a 10 percent penalty.

Payments can be made by mail or in person at the County Tax Collector's Office,
1221 Oak Street, Oakland, weekdays between 8:30 a.m. and 5 p.m.

Property owners can also pay by credit card by calling 510-272-6800 or online
atwww.acgov.org . Another payment option is through eCheck, also available
atwww.acgov.org . Those who want to use a credit card or eCheck but avoid online
payments, can visit the county's KIOSK system, located in the lobby of the tax
collector's office.

Property owners who do not receive their tax bill by Nov. 16, should contact the
tax collector's office in writing, calling 510-272-6800 or visitingwww.acgov.org
.

Tax bills received for property no longer owned should be forwarded to the new
owner or returned to the tax collector's office.

                       San Jose Mercury News (California)

                           October 10, 2012 Wednesday

Alameda County property taxes due by Nov. 1

BYLINE: By Angela Woodall Oakland Tribune

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 172 words


The first installment of this year's property taxes are due Nov. 1 and will be
considered delinquent if not paid by 5 p.m. Dec. 10. The second installment is
due on Feb. 1 and is delinquent if not paid by 5 p.m. April 10. Delinquent
owners will face a 10 percent penalty.

Payments can be made by mail or in person at the County Tax Collector's Office,
1221 Oak Street, Oakland, weekdays between 8:30 a.m. and 5 p.m.

Property owners can also pay by credit card by calling 510-272-6800 or online
atwww.acgov.org . Another payment option is through eCheck, also available
atwww.acgov.org . Those who want to use a credit card or eCheck but avoid online
payments, can visit the county's KIOSK system, located in the lobby of the tax
collector's office.

Property owners who do not receive their tax bill by Nov. 16, should contact the
tax collector's office in writing, calling 510-272-6800 or visitingwww.acgov.org
.

Tax bills received for property no longer owned should be forwarded to the new
owner or returned to the tax collector's office.

                            Dayton Daily News (Ohio)

                            March 21, 2009 Saturday

Local headlines

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. A8

LENGTH: 427 words


Help available on delinquent taxes

DAYTON - Property owners whose taxes are late can sign up for a payment plan to
pay the delinquencies, and by doing so avoid additional interest or penalty
charges, according to Montgomery County Treasurer Carolyn Rice.

All delinquent property owners are potentially eligible to sign up for a payment
plan, which requires a down payment when the plan is created. The plans also
require the property owner to stay current on any new real estate tax bills.

Delinquent properties with active plans can be excluded from tax foreclosure and
tax lien certificate sales.

For information call the treasurer's office at 225-4010, option 2.

- Lynn Hulsey, staff writer

Beavercreek close to school site deal

BEAVERCREEK - School officials are close to purchasing a 50-acre site owned by
the Nutter family to build the district's next middle school.

The $1.27 million deal is contingent on a zoning change and environmental
assessment of the land at Dayton-Xenia and Ankeney roads, according to district
officials.

The district plans to build a middle school on the land as part of an
$89-million districtwide building and renovation project. The work is possible
because voters approved a tax request in November after two defeats at the
ballot box.

The current Ferguson Middle School will be used to house students from the now
overcrowded high school, according to the plan. New middle and elementary
schools will be constructed.

Richard Eckhardt, school board president, said the district estimates the middle
school site could save $70,000 annually on transportation costs. District
officials are in the midst of designing the two new schools and preparing for
remodeling across the district.

- Christopher Magan, staff writer

Outlet developer plans job fair

MONROE - The developer of an outlet center project scheduled to open later this
summer in Monroe is planning to conduct a job fair.

Chelsea Property Group, a division of Simon Property Group Inc., will feature a
job fair in late May/early June as it prepares for the August opening of
Cincinnati Premium Outlets off Ohio 63, just east of Interstate 75, in Warren
County, said Michele Rothstein, the company's senior vice president of
marketing.

Stores leasing space at the mall are expected to be announced before the job
fair, she said.

The retail center is projected to generate more than $150 million in annual
sales, 800 to 1,000 full and part-time jobs with an annual payroll of more than
$15 million, and property tax revenue of more than $900,000 per year, according
to project documents.

                             482 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        Topeka Capital-Journal (Kansas)

                           December 3, 2014 Wednesday

Heartland Park under water $45,000 on city utilities bill

BYLINE: Aly Van Dyke.

aly.vandyke@cjonline.com

LENGTH: 1020 words


Heartland Park Topeka owes the city nearly $45,000 in delinquent utility bills.

The racetrack, which currently is in the process of being purchased by the city,
last paid its water and street utility bills on Aug. 7, 2013, said Suzie
Gilbert, the city's communications and marketing director.

Topeka policy indicates water can be shut off after at least 48 days of
delinquency.

The racetrack appears on a list requested by The Topeka Capital-Journal of 40
properties that are delinquent on utility bills by at least $500 and 41 days.
Gilbert didn't respond to a Capital-Journal question asking how many of the
properties had their water shut off.

August 2013 is roughly the time city officials first started developing a
solution for Heartland Park, according to previous statements from city
officials.

However, Gilbert said, the city is among the vendors the racetrack has to pay
back once the Sales Tax Revenue (STAR) bonds go through. According to a breakout
of allocations, Jayhawk Racing will receive $2,392,117 of the estimated $5
million in bonds.

Records show the racetrack owed $44,645.11 as of Nov. 28.

Owner Raymond Irwin, reached by phone Monday, said he was driving and couldn't
talk. He said he didn't know how much the racetrack owed each month in utility
bills.

"I don't handle those things," Irwin said.

While city officials have been discussing solutions to Heartland Park at least
since the summer of 2013, the city publicly disclosed the plan this past May.
Officials said the discussions prior to this summer were proprietary because of
potential litigation.

The city's plan to rescue Heartland Park was set into motion five days after its
release, when the Topeka City Council approved a memorandum of understanding and
workout agreement with CoreFirst and Jayhawk Racing to pursue additional STAR
bonds.

The city's plan involves issuing another $5 million in STAR bonds to purchase
Heartland Park free of debt. The city council on Tuesday voted 7-3 to approve
the pricing of the new STAR bonds.

The city intends to find an owner or management firm to operate the track. The
city recently sent out a request for proposals for such a partner with a
deadline of Dec. 12. As of Monday, at least five responses were received.

Taking on more debt is required to expand the STAR bond district around the
racetrack.

A larger district is necessary to pay off the STAR bond debt after the current
district - which primarily surrounds the racetrack - routinely has fallen short
of revenue projections. By contrast, revenue projections for the expanded STAR
bond district are based on existing state sales tax revenues for businesses
already operating inside the new district.

City leaders have advocated for the plan because it puts the debt burden on
existing state sales tax revenue, which would be diverted to cover the STAR bond
debt, rather than Topeka property taxes. The additional bonds would bring the
project's STAR bond debt to $17 million, the full amount of which the expanded
district is expected to cover.

In absence of a plan to save Heartland Park, the racing complex is on the track
toward foreclosure, and the city would lose $200,000 in annual sales tax
revenue.

A petition effort to put the council's vote to a public vote recently filed an
appeal to a court's decision the petition was invalid. The two-month effort led
by private residents collected more than 3,500 valid signatures.

Heartland Park's delinquent utility bills make up 26 percent of the city's total
delinquent utility payments, as of Nov. 21.

The Topeka Capital-Journal on Nov. 19 requested a list of all properties that
were delinquent at least $500 on utility bills. The city on Nov. 24 provided a
list of 79 properties. However, at 5:30 p.m. Nov. 26, the city informed the
paper the list was inaccurate, as it included properties that weren't yet
delinquent. Because the city was on holiday Nov. 27-28, a correct list wasn't
received until 4 p.m. Monday.

The updated list includes 40 properties that were delinquent on their water,
wastewater and/or streets motor fuel payments, for a total of $91,889.28 as of
Nov. 28. That makes up 54 percent of the total delinquencies of $170,600 as of
Nov. 21.

The list includes accounts with past-due amounts that are $500 or more and are
delinquent by 41 days or more.

Utility bills become delinquent 21 days after the billing date, according to an
email from Gilbert. After another 20 days, the account becomes eligible for
shut-off - though that typically doesn't happen for at least another week.
Accounts owing $60 or fewer aren't shut off.

That means water typically is shut off after 48 days of delinquent payments.
Records provided to The Capital-Journal show delinquencies ranging from 41 days
to 120 days, excluding Heartland Park.

It wasn't known Tuesday how many of the properties on the list were without
water.

Topeka doesn't send out separate delinquent notices. It instead highlights the
amount owed on the monthly utility bills.

Although the city doesn't charge an interest rate on delinquent utility bills,
it assesses a $32 delinquency fee when an account is shut off and a $24 fee to
turn water back on the same day, Gilbert said.

The city contracts with two collection agencies to pursue delinquent payments,
she said.

Of the nearly $92,000 in delinquent bills worth more than $500, more than
$76,000 are owed by commercial or industrial properties.

Two locations of Hill's Pet Nutrition Inc. at 320 N.E. Crane, for example, owe a
total of $8,796.54. The data show the properties have been delinquent at least
41 days.

The property came on the tax rolls in 2013 after being exempt from 2003 through
2012, according to Shawnee County records. The property last year paid
$122,573.55 in property taxes.

Four properties owned by bankrupt developer Kent Lindemuth owed a total of
$12,962.12 and also had been delinquent at least 41 days.

The city redacted 15 "individually identifiable residential customers" as an
exemption under state statute. The properties ranged from a couple of $50,000
homes in the Montara subdivision to two properties valued at more than $200,000
in southwest Topeka.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                 The Tribune-Democrat (Johnstown, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           September 13, 2009 Sunday

Planet Ice property taken out of tax sale

BYLINE: Sandra K. Reabuck, Tribune-Democrat, Johnstown, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 554 words


Sep. 13--EBENSBURG -- The Planet Ice property in Richland Township -- slated to
be offered for sale at Cambria County's delinquent tax sale Monday -- was taken
off the auction block Friday because of its pending sale by a private buyer.

Judge Timothy Creany signed an order putting a "stay" -- or hold -- on the sale
after the owner, Roustanâ[#x20ac][#x2c6]Johnstown, petitioned the court to
remove it from the tax sale. The stay will remain in effect pending the private
sale.

Johnstown attorney Kevin Rozich, representing Roustan, divulged neither the name
of the buyer nor the sale price.

Rozich said that proceeds of the sale will enable the owner to pay the
delinquent taxes.

The sale is scheduled to be completed on or before Oct. 30, the attorney said.

A Web site operated by the Cambria Somerset Association of Realtors lists the
Planet Ice property for $2.99 million. The property is 7.5 acres and the
two-story building is 90,020 square feet. It was constructed in 1997.

The Web site listing describes the property as a multiuse facility that includes
a manufacturing and storage area, ice rink and entertainment complex, and office
suites.

The listing agent is Gary Green of Century 21 All Service Inc. at 212 Bloomfield
St. in Richland Township.

Planet Ice topped the list of delinquent tax properties that were advertised by
the county Tax Claim Bureau in July for the upcoming sale.

The bureau said that a total of $250,577 was due on the property at 195 Jari
Drive. The bureau said that the taxes due included $71,493 for 2009 and other
amounts dating back to 2006.

Roustanâ[#x20ac][#x2c6]Johnstown had arranged a payment plan for 2006 taxes, but
the company became delinquent on its payments.

The tax sale will begin at 10 a.m. Monday in Courtroom No. 1 at the county
courthouse. Several hundred properties from the 1,300 listed in July for the
delinquent sale remain on the auction block. Owners have until the time of the
sale to either pay the back taxes or get onto a payment plan.

Typically few properties are sold at the tax sale because it's a "buyer beware"
sale. New owners assume responsibility for any liens, judgments or mortgages on
the property.

Also on Friday, another well-known property was removed from the sale list in an
order signed by the judge. It is the former White Star personal care home, owned
by Speciality Lifecare Realty Corp., at 429 Napoleon St. in Johnstown.

Johnstown lawyer David Novak said that the property is scheduled for a sheriff's
sale in a mortgage foreclosure Dec. 11. The taxes will be paid as part of the
sheriff's sale, Novak said.

Remaining in Monday's delinquent tax sale is the former Miners Hospital property
on Crawford Avenue in Northern Cambria Borough. It is owned by Northern Cambria
Community Development Corp.

Speciality Lifecare came in second in the delinquent sale list with $143,107
owed, while the Miner's property had been listed at third with $136,533 owed.

To see more of The Tribune-Democrat or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.tribune-democrat.com. Copyright (c) 2009, Tribune-Democrat,
Johnstown, Pa. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For
reprints, email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or
847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group
Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                        SUNDAY TELEGRAM (Massachusetts)

                       May 07, 2004 Friday, FINAL EDITION

DOR tax evaders listed;
 City man named No. 10

BYLINE: Martin Luttrell; TELEGRAM & GAZETTE STAFF

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 300 words

DATELINE: WORCESTER


- A city resident made the top-10 list of Massachusetts tax deadbeats released
yesterday by the state Department of Revenue.

Ut Vuong, with a last known address of 143 Massasoit Road, owes the state
$395,757 in taxes, according to the DOR. Mr. Vuong was 10th among the top tax
delinquents.

The dubious distinction of highest amount owed went to George Varoudakis of
Danvers, with $1,107,053.

No one answered the telephone at the Vuong residence yesterday, and there was no
answer at the door at the gated property on Massasoit Road.

According to the DOR, there are 1,481 listed as delinquent on taxes.

DOR spokesman Timothy J. Connolly said the law prevents disclosure of specifics
on what types of taxes are owed or Mr. Vuong's source of income. The publication
of the list of deadbeats is aimed at putting some pressure on delinquents to pay
their taxes, he said.

''There is a portion of the law that allows the commission to publish the
list,'' Mr. Connolly said. ''The rest of the privacy provision holds. This is
the first time this list has been done in the last decade.''

He said there had not been much response among the delinquents during the day
yesterday.

''Not really. In the time between the notification of assessment nine months ago
to the publication of the list, just over 300 got their names off the list,'' he
said.

After not responding to official notices, the publication of the list of
delinquents may help, he said.

''I think that's part of what this is about,'' Mr. Connolly said. ''The law has
been on the books for this (publicizing delinquents) for 24 years. It's a
work-intensive project for the DOR. This has only been done a couple of times
before by the DOR.

''It's a little easier now with the Internet. We plan to refresh it every
week.''

                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             May 7, 2014 Wednesday

BRIEF: City Council to consider resolution this morning that pushes for combined
garbage/sewer bill

BYLINE: Kevin Flowers, Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 204 words


May 07--Erie City Council will consider a resolution this morning that would
direct the Erie Water Works to change its billing procedures by combining
garbage and sewer fees onto one bill for customers.

The move is part of an ongoing effort to deal with more than $2 million in
delinquent refuse accounts.

Erie Water Works collects water, sewer and refuse bills on the city's behalf.

The resolution also asks Erie Water Works to amend its collection rules and its
contract with the city so that customer payments apply to the most delinquent
charges first.

Paul Vojtek, the Erie Water Works' chief executive, said that since payments
would be applied first to the most delinquent charges, a customer who is
severely late on garbage payments would see his payment go toward the late
refuse bill, which would leave the sewer bill unpaid.

The Erie Water Works could then legally shut off water service, which is billed
separately, to a customer for delinquent sewer charges. Vojtek said state law
allows that.

City Council meets at 9 a.m. in the Bagnoni Council Chambers at City Hall, 626
State St.

Pa.) at www.GoErie.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

                          South Bend Tribune (Indiana)

                             April 27, 2014 Sunday
                                  Mich Edition

Candidate gets caught up on delinquent taxes

BYLINE: Amanda Gray, South Bend Tribune

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A6

LENGTH: 300 words


SOUTH BEND - County Council District E candidate and current president of the
Warren Township Advisory Board Dan Cruz paid in full delinquent taxes and
penalties on three of his rental properties on Thursday, the same day The
Tribune inquired about the lapse.

Cruz owed $3,200 in delinquent tax bills and penalties from last year for three
South Bend homes, according to public records. He was current on one other
rental property and his personal home. Receipts at the St. Joseph County
treasurer's office show that Cruz paid the back taxes on Thursday.

"They were brought to my attention, and I paid them in full," Cruz said.

The other two candidates in the race, current Councilwoman Diana Hess and
candidate Carolyn Archie, do not have any delinquent taxes or penalties,
according to records.

Cruz also has an active house repair code enforcement violation on each of the
same three rental properties. According to code enforcement staff, the
properties are in need of some minor repair work to the homes and garages.

Each of these properties also has a history of code violations, ranging from
mowing and home repair to graffiti, according to records, totaling more than 30
for the three homes over the last 15 years. Inspector Ed Humphrey said that for
many mowing violations, homeowners will take care of the problem before city
crews ever get there.

Cruz said he's in the process of rehabbing the homes, and that the violations
stem from the rehabbing process. One of the homes was a recent purchase, he
said, and he saved it from demolition.

According to records, Hess does not have any active or past code violations.
Archie has eight violations for mowing that stem from 2006 and earlier, but
nothing active or closed in recent months.

                             487 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                            Crain's Detroit Business

                                 August 6, 2007

United Way may withhold cash;
Some members late on pension fund payments

BYLINE: Sherri Begin

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 575 Words


Agencies are continuing to leave the United Way for Southeastern Michigan group
pension fund and up to a third of remaining members are missing contribution
payments - and it could cost the slow payers funding.

About five to 10 of the 31 remaining members are delinquent in making regular
contributions to the plan at any one time, said United Way CFO Cathy Adcock.

Since the end of 2005, 20 of the fund's 51 members have withdrawn or
disaffiliated from the plan.

United Way could withhold funding from members delinquent in making
contributions if internal collection efforts are unsuccessful, said Kelly Major
Green, vice president, marketing and brand experience, in an e-mail.

So far, United Way has sent letters, made telephone calls and met with
delinquent agencies, Adcock said.

However, ``as fiduciary, we have a responsibility to and we will pursue all
avenues available to us to maintain good standing as a fund,'' Major Green said,
declining to identify delinquent members or the amount owed to the fund.

Established in 1945 by United Community Services, which merged with United Way
in 1995, the plan was formed as a way to lessen administrative costs and improve
benefit coverage for smaller nonprofits.

The plan had been adequately funded until 2004, but poor market returns and
declines in interest rates have increased agency liabilities.

Employer contributions in the defined-benefit plan, which had been just 3
percent of payroll, increased to 6 percent in 2005 and had been projected to
rise to an average of about 10.4 percent in 2006, Robert Miles, CEO and
president of Lutheran Child and Family Services of Michigan and chairman of the
pension advisory board for the United Way Pension Plan, told Crain's last year.
United Way and actuary Watson Wyatt are still finalizing liabilities and assets
for departing members for 2006 and 2007. But as of March 31, 2007, the United
Way said in a memo that the market value of the plan assets was approximately
$62.2 million but did not list liabilities. That compares to plan assets of
nearly $81.6 million in 2005. That year, the plan had 2,345 employee
participants and was 80 percent funded with a liability of about $20.4 million.

The plan isn't fully funded, Adcock said, declining to give estimates on assets
and liabilities. ``But we are in a permissible range,'' she said.

Several other organizations are also considering disaffiliating, said Patrick
Heron, president and CEO of Catholic Social Services of Wayne County in Detroit
and chairman of the Association of United Way Agency Executives. He declined to
identify those agencies.

Members are pulling out of the plan for financial reasons, he said.

``Agency boards want to have better control over how their money is being
invested and managed and, in some cases, because they can't afford to continue
participating in this plan.''

By going to a plan of their own, agencies could make contributions on a
quarterly basis, said Deborah Grace, a member in the Bloomfield Hills office of
Dickinson Wright P.L.L.C. The United Way plan requires monthly contributions.

Since the end of 2005, 16 agencies have disaffiliated from and four have
withdrawn. Agencies that disaffiliate must establish a mirror plan for five
years.

Those that withdraw must immediately fund their pension liabilities and then
spin the assets off to their employees through something like a 401K or
individual retirement account.

Sherri Begin: (313) 446-1694, sbegin@crain.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                             488 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                  February 05, 1997, Wednesday, Final Edition

Md. Suspends Licenses Over Child Support; Thousands of Parents Lose Right to
Drive

Paul W. Valentine, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: METRO; Pg. B05

LENGTH: 545 words


More than 4,000 Marylanders have lost their driver's licenses because they are
behind in making child-support payments, as a result of a new state law that
took full effect this week.

State Motor Vehicle Administration officials began suspending the licenses
Monday in hopes of recovering millions of dollars in court-ordered support
payments, some left unpaid for years by non-custodial parents. The agency had
warned about 5,000 parents in a Jan. 10 letter that they must make the back
payments or arrange a payment schedule with the state Department of Human
Resources by Jan. 30.

Of the 5,000 delinquents, about 500, or 10 percent, complied, said Human
Resources spokesman Keith Snipes. As others come into compliance, he said, their
licenses will be restored. The suspensions were recorded in the motor vehicle
agency's computer data bank, where they are available to police officers
throughout the state when they stop cars for traffic violations.

Asked if Human Resources officials were concerned about the 10 percent
compliance figure, Snipes said: "It's a new program. No one knew what to expect.
But I'm disappointed."

The program targets parents who are behind in their payments by more than 60
days. That's about half of the 369,000 Marylanders who are under court order to
pay child support, according to officials.

The District and Virginia, along with about 30 other states, have similar
license-suspension programs to help enforce court-ordered child support. Some
states also suspend the business, occupational and sporting licenses of
delinquents, part of new federal standards for tougher child-support
enforcement.

The Jan. 10 Maryland warning went to parents in Baltimore and Anne Arundel
County. Other parts of the state will be covered in subsequent mailings,
including one late this month.

Snipes said the 4,500 parents who have not complied despite being notified owe
about $ 28 million in support payments, an average of more than $ 6,000 each.
"The top 10 individuals," he said, "represent $ 400,000 to $ 500,000" of the
total.

Even though they are under court order to make regular monthly payments, many
delinquents manage to escape detection and cannot be located, sometimes for
years, Snipes said. Finding delinquents, determining how far in arrears they are
and giving them adequate warning, he said, "is a tedious business. It's a
crawl."

The Human Resources Department, for example, sent out two notices to delinquent
parents several months before the license-suspension warning, describing the new
law and its consequences. The department also bought billboard space and ran
public service radio and television spots throughout the state, Snipes said.

Another time-consuming process, he said, involved separating parents who are
complying from those who aren't. "We want to protect those who should not be
affected by this program," Snipes said.

The program is designed to create a hardship on deadbeats by taking their wheels
away, but exceptions can be made. For a $ 20 fee, delinquents can obtain a
"work-restricted license," which permits them to drive only to and from their
jobs, Snipes said.

Such a license requires an employer's letter saying that driving is essential to
the person's job.

LOAD-DATE: February 05, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 1997 The Washington Post


                             489 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                                The Denver Post

                       November 2, 1998 Monday 2D EDITION

Complaint shows complex BestBank card scheme

BYLINE: By Donald Blount, Denver Post Business Writer

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C-01

LENGTH: 862 words


The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. complaint against two top officials of the
now-defunct BestBank lays out in detail how investigators say a credit-card
program was used to defraud the Boulder bank while enriching the two officials.

The complaint, filed Thursday in U.S. District Court in Denver, names Edward P.
Mattar III, BestBank's former chief executive officer, and Thomas Alan Boyd, the
bank's former president as defendants.

Two others named in the complaint, Douglas R. Baetz and Glenn M. Gallant,
controlling shareholders in Century Financial Group Inc., of Fort Lauderdale,
Fla., also were involved in the credit-card program, according to the complaint.
Century Financial Group contracted with BestBank in 1993 to help run its
subprime credit-card program.

According to the complaint, the program worked like this:

People with no credit cards, and either bad credit or no credit history, were
targeted as possible recipients of BestBank Visa cards. Applicants could not be
in bankruptcy or have more than one 90-day delinquent account in the last six
months.

Those who joined the All Around Travel Club received a BestBank Visa card with a
$ 600 limit. The travel club's $ 498 membership fee and the credit card's $ 45
annual fee were immediately charged to the credit card, a total $ 543.

That balance was listed by the bank as a receivable - an asset. BestBank would
then pay Century Financial the $ 543.

Century Financial kept the $ 45 card fee and transferred $ 498 to the travel
club.

The travel club would in turn pay Century Financial a $ 398 commission and
BestBank a $ 30 merchant fee. Century Financial would pay BestBank a $ 25 card
fee.

When all the shuffling was done, each new card netted Century Financial $ 418
and the travel club $ 70. Even though it was paying out more than $ 400 for each
new card, BestBank still listed the $ 543 receivable as an asset.

The agreement required Century Financial to purchase accounts that were more
than 120 days delinquent. It was also required to maintain a reserve account
equal to 4 percent of the total credit card receivables on the bank's books;
reserves of 15 percent of the accounts 30 to 59 days delinquent; 25 percent of
those 60 to 89 days delinquent; and 50 percent of those 90 to 120 days
delinquent.

And after April 1, 1998, Century Financial was to pay BestBank 1 percent of new
account balances to be added to the allowance for loan and lease losses.

But by May 29, 1998, the numbers weren't adding up, according to the complaint.
The reserve account balance then was only $ 8.8 million, despite delinquencies
of at least $ 179 million. Even if all of those accounts were less than 60 days
late, the reserve balance should have been $ 26.85 million.

The complaint said Century Financial performed certain bookkeeping maneuvers to
make accounts appear current without any payments by cardholders.

Nearly 370,000 accounts, about 74 percent of the total active credit cards, were
improperly credited during the first half of this year and Mattar and Boyd knew
of the practice, according to the complaint.

"Once the improper credits were discovered, Mattar and Boyd informed the bank
regulators that the practice had been discontinued, even though they had actual
knowledge that Century Financial continued to falsely age accounts," the
complaint said.

Even after an internal audit revealed possible widespread fraud, Mattar and Boyd
did not stop funding new travel accounts or require Century Financial to pay a
penalty, but continued to expand the accounts, the complaint said.

As a result, BestBank carried more than $ 179 million in credit card receivables
that were misstated and misrepresented, according to the complaint. And Mattar
and Boyd received nearly $ 9.5 million in performance bonuses this year based on
those receivables.

"Mattar and Boyd took the excessive performance bonuses with knowledge of the
bank's poor financial condition in a scheme or artifice to defraud a financial
institution    ," the complaint states.

Mattar also wired at least $ 2.36 million to various bank accounts that he
controlled during the first seven months of this year. That money may include
funds in addition to the performance bonuses, the complaint said.

Mattar, according to the complaint, also had personal expenses paid for by the
bank, including utilities, association dues and taxes on his Boulder condominium
and personal travel, telephone, parking and credit cards costs.

And the complaint says Mattar attempted to restrict FDIC examiners' access to
the bank, its books, records and employees.

Neither Mattar nor Boyd could be reached Friday for comment.

What happens next depends on how the litigation plays out, said Richard
Fulkerson, the state banking commissioner.

"We agree with the allegations," he said. But it's up to the FDIC, as the bank's
receiver, to recoup the losses from officers and directors.

At this point, it is a civil matter. Results of the FDIC investigation will be
turned over to the district attorney, the FBI or assistant U.S. Attorney,
Fulkerson said. It would be up to them to determine if criminal charges would be
filed.

LOAD-DATE: November 02, 1998

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                             490 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           Pittsburgh Tribune Review

                            March 30, 2011 Wednesday

City has role in fighting blight, controller says

BYLINE: Pittsburgh Tribune-Review

LENGTH: 377 words


Pittsburgh Controller Michael Lamb said Tuesday that the city must do a better
job of maintaining vacant properties it owns as well as selling more properties
so they return to the tax rolls.

"We must make every effort, including working with the citizens in the community
in which these properties are located, to get these properties back on the city
tax rolls," Lamb said in a prepared statement. "We also must create a system so
that these properties are given regular maintenance. They are contributing to
neighborhood blight and in some cases are safety hazards."

Lamb's office conducts performance and financial audits of city departments and
authorities and inspects all goods and services received by the city. His office
audited the city Department of Finance's real estate division and looked at how
the city acquired and disposed of properties from 2008 to last June.

Lamb's office identified 3,108 tax-delinquent properties available for sale. Of
those, 769 properties have been acquired by the city and 1,174 have been given
away or sold, reducing the city's inventory of delinquent properties by 11
percent, according to the audit.

In all, according to the audit, 20,732 properties within the city were listed as
delinquent.

Many properties, according to the audit, are in Perry South,
California-Kirkbride, Garfield, Homewood North, Homewood South, Beltzhoover,
Hazelwood, Middle Hill and Larimer.

Lamb recommended that city-held properties be inspected and scheduled for
regular maintenance so that they don't contribute to neighborhood blight.

Delinquent properties are sporadically maintained by the city Department of
Public Works' "Redd Up" crew and private contractor City Source Associates or
after someone lodges a complaint, according to the audit.

Lamb's report praised the city's Side Yard program, in which homeowners can buy
adjoining lots that can't be developed because of their size or grade for $400.
Since the program's inception in 1994, the audit said, 715 of 1,200 lots were
sold and put back on the tax rolls.

"Early on, we've identified all of the same concerns, and we've been
aggressively dealing with the problems over the last few years," said Marissa
Doyle, communications specialist for the Ravenstahl administration.

                             491 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


             National Post's Financial Post & FP Investing (Canada)

                             August 31, 2007 Friday
                                National Edition

Bankers blame speculators for housing defaults; Mortgage Bankers' Report; Price
Bubble Bursts, Investors Walk Away From Flips Gone Bad

BYLINE: Bob Ivry, Bloomberg News

SECTION: FINANCIAL POST; Pg. FP12

LENGTH: 534  words


Speculators who bought houses never intending to live in them are driving the
rising number of late mortgage payments in the four U.S. states with the highest
rates of default, the Mortgage Bankers Association says in a report released
yesterday.

Sixteen percent of all U.S. prime mortgages in default were due to speculators,
and 12% of subprime mortgages, the mortgage bankers' report says.

Rising home prices in Nevada, Florida, California and Arizona during the
five-year U.S. housing boom that ended last year attracted speculators, who
bought houses to "flip," or sell for a quick profit.

U.S. homebuilders responded to this demand and built more houses than the local
population would buy, said Doug Duncan, chief economist for the Washington-based
mortgage bankers' group.

"When this oversupply became apparent and prices began to fall, many of these
investors simply walked away from their mortgages," Mr. Duncan said.

Subprime loans are available to borrowers with bad or limited credit histories.
Five times more subprime borrowers are late with their monthly payments than
prime borrowers, who have better credit. More than 100 mortgage companies have
gone under or been put up for sale since the beginning of last year, according
to Bloomberg News.

Nevada and Florida have the fastest increases in delinquent loans in the United
States, the report says.

In the first half of 2007, 32% of prime-mortgage defaults and 24% of
subprime-mortgage defaults in Nevada were on properties not occupied by their
owners.

In Florida, speculators were responsible for 25% of prime-loan defaults and 14%
of subprime defaults, the report says.

Twenty-six percent of the prime loans and 18% of subprime loans in default in
Arizona were for properties not occupied by their owners, the report says.

In California, the rate was 21% of prime defaults and 15% of subprime defaults,
the report says. Arizona and California are among the U.S. states with the
fastest increases in delinquent loans in the country, according to the mortgage
bankers group.

The number of Nevada homes in the foreclosure process in July jumped 215%
compared with last year, according to Irvine, Calif.-based RealtyTrac Inc.

The number of homes in the foreclosure process in Arizona rose 189%, in Florida
78% and in California 289%, RealtyTrac figures show.

RealtyTrac data follow homes in the three stages offoreclosure-- delinquent
payments, slated for auction and properties taken over by banks. The mortgage
bankers' report refers only to delinquent payments.

"Defaults are on the rise in most parts of the country," Mr. Duncan said.

"But it should be recognized that it is not always the case of a homeowner
losing his or her home, but is often the case of an investor gambling on a
continued increase in home values and losing that gamble."

Defaulted mortgages are defined as those 90 days or more past due or in
foreclosure. The mortgage bankers' report is based on data collected through the
Home Mortgage Disclosure Act.

Speculative investors represented 17.3% of all U.S. homebuyers in 2005, more
than double the 8.6% in 2001, according to figures in a a separate analysis of
Home Mortgage Disclosure Act data by Los Angeles-based FTI Consulting.

LOAD-DATE: August 31, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Color Photo: Oscar Sosa, Bloomberg News File Photo; Nevada, Florida, California
and Arizona are the U.S. states hardest-hit by the subprime fallout. ;

                              Daily the Pak Banker

                          September 25, 2010 Saturday

LPS' Mortgage Monitor Report: August Data Shows Foreclosure Proceedings
Accelerating; Origination/Refinance Activity on the Rise

LENGTH: 453  words

DATELINE: Karachi


Karachi, Sept. 25 -- The August Mortgage Monitor report released today by Lender
Processing Services, Inc. (NYSE: LPS) shows that foreclosure starts continue to
accelerate with the GSEs displaying more aggressive timelines on early stage
delinquencies. LPS data also shows refinance activity is picking up again as
prepayment rates have been steadily increasing over the last two months and new
originations hit 2010 highs.

As of August month end, there had been more than 2 million foreclosure starts.
While delinquencies during that same time period dropped 5.1 percent as compared
to a year ago, in the context of "normal market conditions," delinquencies
remain at historically high levels.

Breaking the trend of the last three months, agency foreclosure starts declined
slightly in August; however, portfolio foreclosure starts have accelerated. Late
stage delinquencies dominate these new foreclosure starts, though overall the
percentage of seriously delinquent loans not in foreclosure is improving as
compared to the extreme distress seen last year. In January 2009, the percent of
seriously delinquent loans that were current six months prior peaked at 2.92
percent; in August 2010 that rate was 1.65 percent.

The report also shows that approximately 1.01 million loans that were current at
the beginning of January are at least 60 days delinquent or in foreclosure as of
the end of August - a month-over-month increase of 115,000 loans.

As reported in LPS' First Look release, other key results from LPS' latest
Mortgage Monitor report include:

Total U.S. loan delinquency rate:

9.22 percent

Total U.S. foreclosure inventory rate:

3.8 percent

Total U.S. non-current* loan rate:

13.02 percent

States with most non-current* loans:

Florida, Nevada, Mississippi,

Georgia, Illinois

States with the fewest non-current* loans:

North Dakota, South Dakota,

Alaska, Wyoming, Montana

*Non-current totals combine foreclosures and delinquencies as a percent of
active loans in that state.

Note: Totals based on LPS Applied Analytics' loan-level database of mortgage
assets and are extrapolated to represent the industry.

About the Mortgage Monitor

LPS manages the nation's leading repository of loan-level residential mortgage
data and performance information on nearly 40 million loans across the spectrum
of credit products. The company's research experts carefully analyze this data
to produce a summary supplemented by dozens of charts and graphs that reflect
trend and point-in-time observations for LPS' monthly Mortgage Monitor Report.
Published by HT Syndication with permission from Daily Pak Banker. For any query
with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact
Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

Arkansas: TAX INVESTIGATOR Position No.: 2210-8670

LENGTH: 535  words

DATELINE: Little Rock


Department of Finance and Administration, The State of Arkansas has issued the
following job vacancy:


TAX INVESTIGATOR
Agency:  Department of Finance & Administration
Office:  Sales and Use Tax
Section:
Date Posted:  05/19/2014
Posting Expires:  05/23/2014
Summary
The Tax Investigator is responsible for conducting tax investigations and
collecting delinquent taxes. This position is governed by state and federal laws
and agency/institution policy.


Typical Functions
Investigates complaints from the public regarding non-compliance of Arkansas tax
laws and writes reports documenting and detailing the outcome of the
investigation. Assists taxpayers by interpreting tax laws and regulations,
explains taxpayer responsibilities, assists taxpayers in the completion of tax
forms, and computes penalties and interest for taxpayers as needed. Contacts
delinquent taxpayers and collects delinquent taxes, penalties, and interest due
and assists in the resolution of delinquent taxes. Serves legal documents
(Business Closure Orders, Notice of Hearing, etc.) to taxpayers who fail to
comply with Arkansas tax laws. Provides information for affidavits and testifies
at legal proceedings. Prepares and submits daily, weekly, and monthly reports.
May inspect vending and amusement machines for compliance with tax laws.
Performs other duties as assigned.
Special Job Dimensions
Knowledge, Abilities, and Skills
Knowledge of state tax laws. Knowledge of principles and practices of accounting
and bookkeeping. Ability to interpret and apply tax laws, rules, and
regulations. Ability to interview and obtain information. Ability to prepare,
present, and review technical tax information, documents, and reports. Ability
to utilize software based computer systems.
Minimum Education and/or Experience
The formal education equivalent of a high school diploma; plus two years of
college coursework, including six hours in accounting; plus one year of
experience in bookkeeping, tax preparation, tax auditing, or a related field.
Additional requirements determined by the agency for recruiting purposes require
review and approval by the Office of Personnel Management. OTHER JOB RELATED
EDUCATION AND/OR EXPERIENCE MAY BE SUBSTITUTED FOR ALL OR PART OF THESE BASIC
REQUIREMENTS, EXCEPT FOR CERTIFICATION OR LICENSURE REQUIREMENTS, UPON APPROVAL
OF THE QUALIFICATIONS REVIEW COMMITTEE.
Preferred Qualifications
Applicants must reside in Van Buren, Cleburne, or Independence County or be
willing to relocate to same area within a reasonable time.

This is an entry level position with a starting salary of $26,268.
Certificates, Licenses, Registrations
Agency Specific Information
ONLY COMPLETED APPLICATIONS WITH WORK HISTORY WILL BE ACCEPTED.
The work history section of the application must be completed. We do not accept
resumes in lieu of completing this section.

Job Details
Position No.:  2210-8670
Class Code:  X172C
Grade:  C112
Salary Range:  $25,268.00 - $42,918.00 per year
Background
check required?  Yes
Job Type:  Full Time
Location Information

                           Palm Beach Post (Florida)

                             July 19, 2012 Thursday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Sale of troubled FHA loans nearly doubles ;
 About 9,000 mortgages will be sold at auction, including some in Tampa.

BYLINE: By Kimberly Miller Palm Beach Post Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL & BUSINESS; Pg. 6B

LENGTH: 389 words


Nearly double the number of struggling homeowners as originally expected,
including a clump in Tampa, will have their defaulted FHA loans sold to private
investors in September, officials said Wednesday.

The Federal Housing Administration has begun accepting investor applications for
the auction that will now sell about 9,000 delinquent mortgages in discounted
pools to private groups that have more flexibility to modify the loans.

Acting FHA Commissioner Carol Galante said the loan pool was increased from an
original 5,000 because of a surge in interest in the sale, which is part of the
Distressed Asset Stabilization Program.

Originally announced last month, the program plans to hold a sale each quarter
to whittle down the more than 715,000 delinquent mortgages FHA insures. The idea
is private investors can be more creative in restructuring loans to make them
affordable or in offering other alternatives such as a short sale or rent-to-own
scenario.

"Given the strong interest in this program, and the shadow inventory, we are
actually talking now close to 9,000 loans," Galante said. "At its most basic
level, this program creates the opportunity for everyone to come out a winner."

About 3,500 loans will be concentrated in four areas hit hardest by the housing
collapse including Tampa, Phoenix, Chicago and Newark, N.J.

Florida has about 366,650 loans insured by the FHA, according to a first-quarter
report from the Mortgage Bankers Association. Of those, 15 percent -- about
55,000 -- are in foreclosure or 90 days or more late on payments.

Nationwide, FHA insures about 6.7 million loans, 9 percent of which are in
foreclosure or seriously delinquent.

To be eligible for sale through the program, the loan must be at least six
months delinquent and in foreclosure. The borrower cannot be in bankruptcy and
must be ineligible for FHA-offered modification programs.

After an investor buys the loan, the foreclosure is delayed for at least six
months to give the new owner time to work with the borrower on a loan
modification. Because the loans are generally sold for less than what the
borrower owes, the purchaser can reduce or modify the loan while still making a
return on the initial investment, according to the FHA.

For information on the program and qualifications go to
www.hud.gov/fhaloansales.

kimberly_miller@pbpost.com

                             495 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          The Tampa Tribune (Florida)

                               May 8, 2011 Sunday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Board's job is to protect -- not to pity

BYLINE: Richard White

SECTION: BAYLIFE & TRAVEL; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 549 words


Q: Our condominium board refuses to enforce collection of condominium
association dues on emotional grounds that "our neighbors and friends are
hurting" and the board does not want to put liens on units for unpaid dues.

Our outstanding dues money is at $105,000. We now have 30 percent of our units
not paying and delinquent.

These delinquent owners are placing an undue financial burden on those of us
paying. A unit was just sold with a balance of $15,000 in uncollected
association dues. Since there was no lien, the association lost these funds. Is
this board in violation of state law, and what can we do to force the board to
place liens on the owners not paying?

JM, Miami

Answer: To have delinquent amounts of this magnitude, the problem must go back a
few years -- through one or two annual elections.

Apparently, the owners and members agreed with the actions of the board as they
did not elect directors that would protect the paying members' assets.

It is a board duty and fiduciary duty to process delinquent accounts promptly.
Directors must accept responsibility for enforcing the rules; their
responsibilities do not include being neighborly.

Your only solution is to recall this board or vote these directors out at the
next election. When you elect directors that do not do their jobs, you -- the
members -- pay for their mistakes. If an owner has financial problems and does
not pay his or her fees, the board must take proper collection actions to
protect their neighbors who are paying their fees on time.

Your board's mistakes have led to other members paying more than their fair
share. There is no outside help for this problem; you must now cover the loss
and pay. The only way to change going forward is to elect a board that will meet
its responsibilities.

Boards can blend being tough and working with an owner. But that does not
include granting favors to some while neglecting its responsibilities.

Q: Previously, I was a board member of our association and we at various times
emailed our votes on various issues. There was never a published board meeting
for the individual item or business conducted. Are these emails private for the
board only? Or are they public information for the unit owners?

AL, Tampa

Answer: The statutes do not allow directors to vote by email, proxies, or any
other method except in person at a meeting with a quorum of directors present.
The meeting must be properly noticed and the members allowed to attend and
observe the business conducted. However, an absent director can participate by
speaker phone as long as all in attendance can hear. That director would be
counted as quorum and can join in any discussions and vote.

Since emailed votes are illegal, they would be evidence of wrongful actions.
Business conducted based on voting taken by the email could be determined to be
illegal and non-enforceable. A lawsuit would be difficult to defend.

Richard White is a licensed community association manager. He does not offer
legal opinions; any other questions and comments concerning association
operations can be sent to Richard White, 6039 Cypress Gardens Blvd., No. 201,
Winter Haven FL 33884-4115; or email camquestion@cfl.rr.com

Copyright © 2011, The Tampa Tribune and may not be republished without
permission. E-mail library@tampatrib.com

LOAD-DATE: May 10, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

NOTES: Rules of the Roost

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                        Crossville Chronicle (Tennessee)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           November 13, 2014 Thursday

Panel OKs sale of thousands of delinquent tax properties

BYLINE: Gary Nelson, Crossville Chronicle, Tenn.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 626 words


Nov. 13--Earlier this week Cumberland County's Delinquent Tax Committee
requested the clerk and master to prepare for the sale of some 2,500 delinquent
tax properties in the county.

The county hasn't conducted a large-scale delinquent property tax land sale for
several years because officials were awaiting the outcome of a legal case that
could have an effect on counties having to pay property owners association dues.

In a letter to Cumberland County Mayor Kenneth Carey Jr., Clerk and Master Sue
Tollett, County Trustee Kim Wyatt and the county's property tax attorney Joe
Looney recommended the county hold the tax sale.

The committee discussed it earlier this week during its meeting.

"We have delayed scheduling the next Cumberland County tax sale because of the
issues raised by the Travis versus Lakewood Park versus Coffee County, TN case
... We have delayed scheduling a tax sale in hopes that the legislature would
address the problem created by the Travis case. While the legislature did pass a
bill which dealt with this problem, in my opinion, they did nothing to solve the
problem. We are now faced with the situation that we need to schedule a tax
sale," Looney's letter states.

Looney reminded the committee Tennessee Code Annotated 67-5-2507 states counties
are required to have a sale of properties owned by the county through delinquent
tax sales as "expeditiously and advantageously as possible."

According to the Travis case, Tennessee counties could be liable to pay property
owner association (POA) dues on lots they own from delinquent tax sales.

Looney expressed concern to the committee regarding the amount of lots currently
in default that are located in Renegade Mountain, Lake Tansi, Fairfield Glade
and numerous other POA-governed developments in the county.

"It's in the thousands," he said.

Looney told the committee that, in the Coffee County case, the county was sued
for $200,000 worth of POA dues for 60 lots in one subdivision.

"We can't really hold off on the sale any longer and I wanted to make you aware
of the problem we could face. In some cases we may be able give the lots back to
the property owner's association and call it even ... We're in a dilemma,
though, because we've got to have a sale," Looney said.

"We have to have a sale. 2,500 lots, that's a nightmare," Nancy Hyder, 2nd
District commissioner, said.

"With that amount, it could bankrupt the county because those (dues) are every
year," Clerk and Master Sue Tollett said.

"Well, if both parties agree, they can do anything. If it's burdensome to the
county ... you may not have to sell," Looney said.

"What should our next step be?" Hyder asked.

Looney said the county could try to sell the properties first and then maybe
offer those that don't sell as a gift back to the POAs.

"You all tell me what to do. I'm bringing this to you. I'll do what you say,"
Tollett said.

Hyder made a motion for the county to pursue the sale of the properties as
normal.

Tollett said it would take approximately five or six sales to deal with all of
the properties.

Rebecca Stone, 3rd District commissioner, supported the motion.

John Kinnunen, 9th District commissioner, made a motion to let Sue Tollett, or
the clerk and master, to allow the property owners the chance to redeem the
property if the back taxes are paid within a year, without having to notify the
county of that action, as has been the policy in the past.

Stone supported that motion and both were approved unanimously.

The county commission must also approve the sale as well.

Gary Nelson may be reached at gnelson@crossville-chronicle.com

___ (c)2014 the Crossville Chronicle (Crossville, Tenn.) Visit the Crossville
Chronicle (Crossville, Tenn.) at crossville-chronicle.com/ Distributed by MCT
Information Services
