                                US Official News

                              June 30, 2014 Monday

Oregon: Revenue Agent 3

LENGTH: 965  words

DATELINE: Salem


The State of Oregon has issued the following Job release:

Job Code:  DOR14-0073
Job Title:  Revenue Agent 3
Opening Date/Time:  Fri. 06/27/14 12:00 AM Pacific Time
Closing Date/Time:  Continuous
Salary:  $2,942.00 - $4,273.00 Monthly
$35,304.00 - $51,276.00 Annually
Job Type:  Permanent
Location:  Multiple Locations (as stated in job posting), Oregon
Agency:  Revenue-Personal Tax & Compliance



Description  Benefits  Supplemental Questions




The Oregon Dept. of Revenue is currently recruiting for Revenue Agents 3
positions to join our PTAC - Personal Tax and Compliance, Collections section.
These positions are in Gresham, Portland, Eugene, Bend, Medford, Salem, Newport
and Coos Bay. This recruitment will be used to establish a new list of qualified
people and will be used to fill vacancies as they occur. These are full-time,
SEIU represented positions.
If you are interested you should apply now as we could stop taking applications
at any time.
The purpose of this position is to collect tax liabilities for all tax programs,
secure delinquent tax returns, and resolve account maintenance problems on
assigned accounts. Provide information to the public in a helpful, pleasant and
professional manner. The work is performed both in the field and from the
office.

Duties & Responsibilities:

Take appropriate action to collect delinquent taxes. This is accomplished in the
following ways:
·         Contact taxpayer or representative, by phone or in person, to
encourage payment before determining appropriate legal action.
·         Set up, monitor and enforce payment agreements based on financial
information gathered in the field, by phone or provided on financial statements
completed by taxpayers. Verify accuracy of information obtained.
·         Generate notices, correspondence and demands regarding delinquent
taxes.
·         Locate taxpayers, search for assets and determine collection potential
of accounts by performing field, computer and telephone research. This may
include locating and inventorying real and personal property assets and
determining priority of existing liens.
·         Initiate warrants and garnishments against assets when appropriate
(wages, bank accounts, real property or other assets that are subject to
garnishment).
·         Determine and assess officer liability per established policies and
procedures. This involves determining who is responsible for paying the
withholding debt.
·         Coordinate collection action with other agencies to setup payments,
perform compliance checks and share information to determine liability.
·         Document all contacts online.
·         Determine collectability of account and when appropriate, take
necessary action to recommend the liability be cancelled.
·         Review settlement offers for required documentation and refer
completed offers to the Settlement Offer Committee for review.
·         Receive and receipt payments in the field and convey them to
appropriate field office staff for processing.
·         Take last resort collection action when necessary per established
processes and procedures. These actions could include till taps, license
suspensions, contract suspensions, seizures and any other agency approved
action.
Take appropriate action to bring all assigned taxpayers into compliance in all
tax programs. This is accomplished in the following ways:
·         Initiate notices, correspondence and demands to notify taxpayers to
file delinquent returns for all applicable tax programs.
·         When taxpayers file requested delinquent returns, perform a cursory
review of the return received and forward the return for processing or refer the
return to the appropriate person for audit or adjustment.
·         When taxpayers do not comply with the request for filing delinquent
returns, initiate the necessary correspondence and assess tax, penalty and
interest appropriately or refer the case to the appropriate person for
follow-up.

Assist and educate the public both in person and by telephone. This is done in
the following ways:
·         Answer general questions about various tax programs administered by
the department.
·         Providing correct forms and publications as needed.
·         Explaining department notices, procedures and policies to taxpayers
and tax professionals.
·         Participation in assistance events, this could include assisting
taxpayers in filing tax returns, speaking to local business groups on tax
topics, participating in business fairs, and making presentations to interested
groups on various tax topics.
WORKING CONDITIONS
These positions require frequent contact with taxpayers who are frustrated or
upset by phone or in person and occasionally in remote locations and
occasionally subjected to profanity and infrequently subjected to threat of
bodily harm. Employees are required to take appropriate safety measures. There
will be the occasional need to inspect construction sites, heavy equipment, and
vehicles to assess for feasibility of seizure, by climbing in, on, and over
obstacles. There will be regular operation of motor vehicle; occasionally
driving in hazardous weather conditions. Occasional overnight travel; working
before or after regular business hours. There will be continuous exposure to
noise from phones, computers, and voices--in an open work area and frequent
leafing through files and file folders. Continual use of video-display
terminals, telephone, and calculators, requires sitting and using keyboards and
keypads for extended periods of times. Occasionally these positions are required
to lift items, typically up to 15 pounds and occasionally up to 50 pounds, climb
stairs, bend, squat, twist, reach, and walk--frequently over uneven terrain.

For further information please visit: http://agency.governmentjobs.com/oregon/

                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                            October 8, 2015 Thursday

Erie City Council forgives delinquent taxes on 16 properties

BYLINE: John Guerriero, Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 464 words


Oct. 08--ERIE, Pa. -- Property taxes have not been paid on 16 properties in the
city of Erie for years, with delinquencies going back as far as 2000.

The Erie Redevelopment Authority at various times has acquired the properties --
15 vacant lots and one structure -- from owners who had been delinquent in
paying the taxes, said Erie City Councilwoman Jessica Horan-Kunco.

Council took a step Wednesday to get the parcels back on the tax rolls when it
unanimously approved forgiveness of the face value of city taxes totaling
$6,159.

For all property taxes to be forgiven, the other two taxing bodies, Erie County
government and the Erie School District, must follow council's lead. Horan-Kunco
said that is likely now that City Council has given its approval.

The school district taxes on the properties are about $9,157 and the county
taxes are about $2,875, said Scott Henry, the authority's executive director.

City Council took the action, Horan-Kunco said, because "we wanted to move these
into taxable value again."

One structure might be renovated, and the vacant lots likely would be purchased
by neighbors to expand their lawns or for gardens, she said.

The Redevelopment Authority can't sell the properties with delinquent taxes on
the books, she said.

The properties are scattered throughout the city's east and west sides.

In other business, Council President David Brennan said representatives of Erie
City Council and Erie County Council will meet Monday at 4 p.m. at the Erie
County Courthouse to discuss the issues surrounding the possible extension of
the Erie Metropolitan Transit Authority's charter.

Erie County Councilman Kyle Foust and two of his colleagues, Edward T. DiMattio
Jr. and Andre Horton, are part of a county committee that will meet with the
city committee -- Councilmen Curtis Jones Jr., Jim Winarski and Cas Kwitowski.

County and city officials are trying to strike a compromise over an extension of
the charter, which is set to expire in September 2016. EMTA needs County Council
to approve a 50-year charter to continue its operations past that time; City
Council already has approved it.

But County Council this week approved a resolution to host a public meeting
about the possibility of establishing a regional transit authority. The public
meeting probably will be held in early to mid-November at a site and time to be
determined, according to Erie County Clerk Doug Smith.

The regional authority would be a contingency plan if the county can't reach an
agreement with the city over EMTA's charter extension.

JOHN GUERRIERO can be reached at 870-1690 or by e-mail. Follow him on Twitter at
twitter.com/ETNguerriero.

___ (c)2015 the Erie Times-News (Erie, Pa.) Visit the Erie Times-News (Erie,
Pa.) at www.GoErie.com Distributed by Tribune Content Agency, LLC.

                          The Tampa Tribune (Florida)

                            January 15, 2012 Sunday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Board should collect delinquent fees

BYLINE: RICHARD WHITE, Special correspondent

SECTION: BAYLIFE & TRAVEL; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 313 words


BY RICHARD WHITE

Special correspondent

What happens after a lien is filed and recorded on a unit? Can the board
foreclose on the property even if the bank is foreclosing? How many months can a
fee be delinquent?

C.W., Dunedin

Fees are due on the first of the month. If the fee is not paid by the second
day, it is considered delinquent. Legally there is no grace period for
associations. Some documents will allow a few days, or the board can allow a
small grace period. I never recommend that this time be longer than 10 days. I
recommend that the board take some action on the 11th day, such as sending a
reminder letter. If the payment has not been received by the first day of the
next month, a second stronger letter should be sent demanding the fees be paid
by the 10th of that month.

If the payment is not received by the 10th of the second month, then the board
should send a third certified letter that payment is due with a notice that the
account will be turned over to the association's attorney for lien and
foreclosure. The key reason for fast action in collecting delinquent fees is to
protect against those accounts becoming too large for collections.

The board should file liens and foreclosure actions even if the bank has started
foreclosure action. The main reason is that banks will not finalize foreclosure
for years, and then most of the delinquent fees may not be collectable. All
boards should consult with an attorney and establish a working collections
policy.

Richard White is a licensed community association manager. He does not offer
legal opinions; any other questions and comments concerning association
operations can be sent to Richard White, 6039 Cypress Gardens Blvd., No. 201,
Winter Haven FL 33884-4115; or email camquestion@cfl.rr.com

Copyright © 2012, The Tampa Tribune and may not be republished without
permission. E-mail library@tampatrib.com

LOAD-DATE: January 16, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


           Copyright 2012 The Tribune Co. Publishes The Tampa Tribune

                      The Vancouver Sun (British Columbia)

                             July 2, 2011 Saturday
                                 Final Edition

Uncovering the roots of delinquency

BYLINE: Gordon Neufeld, Vancouver Sun

SECTION: WEEKEND REVIEW; Pg. C5

LENGTH: 702  words


In the wake of the Vancouver riot following the Canucks' loss to the Boston
Bruins in the Stanley Cup Final, many are struggling to make sense of this
senselessness. Ironically I was in Europe, preparing to give a keynote address
at a conference on delinquency in Berlin. Unfortunately this is a world problem
that our beloved Vancouver (my hometown) has not escaped.

There are many theories about delinquency and much research going on. After
years of both working with delinquents and studying delinquency, what stands out
to me more than any other factor is their surprising immaturity. On the three
most significant measures of maturation -viability as a separate being, tempered
experience and expression, and the ability to learn from mistakes and failure
-most delinquents come up short. And their brains reflect this remarkable fact.
The prefrontal cortex, the civilizing mixing bowl of the brain, is no more
developed than the average four-year-old's, and the corpus callosum, that bridge
that allows us to use both sides of our brain to solve problems, is also smaller
than it should be. Their physical size and sophisticated demeanour blind us to
the reality that they have failed to grow up as human beings. There are many
contributing issues involved in delinquency, but these only have an effect in
the truly immature.

The other factor that stands out is that their alarm systems do not work. Much
of our brain serves as an alarm system and when it works, we end up being
careful, cautious, concerned and conscientious. When it doesn't work, we end up
being reckless and careless. And when the alarm system is significantly
dysfunctional, we are even attracted to what should alarm us. Once again,
research on the delinquent brain confirms that its alarm systems are on the
blink.

It is true that we can turn off our alarm system temporarily through alcohol,
and I assume that many rioters did just that. This would explain some of their
behaviour, but it certainly does not tell the whole story. The delinquents I
worked with would have all made it their top priority to be in Vancouver that
night and would have fantasized exactly what ultimately happened, even without
the alarm-numbing effect of alcohol.

Both psychological maturation and a working alarm system depend upon a healthy
limbic system (i.e., emotional brain). Most simply put, we need to feel our
feelings, even the most tender and vulnerable ones, in order for the brain to be
able to move us to caution when appropriate and to enable us to grow up over
time. Emotion is both the engine of maturation and the motor of the alarm
system.

But tender feelings are also a luxury that many brains cannot afford. When our
wounds are too much to bear, we become emotionally desensitized, thus losing the
very feelings that are required to realize our human potential as civilized and
considerate beings. The root of the problem is emotional desensitization, or in
intuitive language, hardened hearts. Delinquents of any age are in a flight from
vulnerability that is crippling both their alarm systems and their maturation. I
found the delinquent youth I worked with to be devoid of many of the vulnerable
feelings that are essential to becoming fully human. We are so blinded by their
delinquent behaviour that we often cannot see the heart of the matter.

Such a flight from vulnerability begs for an explanation. We are not living in a
time of war, at least not in Vancouver. We do not have significant poverty; in
fact, many engaging in this behaviour come from affluent homes. What possibly
could be the problem?

The major finding of a large study of adolescents was that what preserved their
emotional health was strong emotional relationships with caring adults. The only
way we can shield our children and youth from wounds too much to bear is through
the strength of their attachments to us. As soon as their peers matter more than
we do, natural human vulnerability becomes too heavy a burden. In short, we are
losing our children to their peers; delinquency is one of the many negative
results.

Gordon Neufeld is a Vancouver-based developmental psychologist who consults with
parents and professionals regarding children and their problems.

LOAD-DATE: July 2, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
